title: Deaths
description: AHMEDImran, beloved son of Anisuddin Ahmed, died of an accident on September 28, 1979. Prayers will be held on Monday, October 1 between 6 and 7PM at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave at 21 St, New York City.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1979

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, Sept. 28 1979

title: Robots Make A Hard Pitch For Soft Drink
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 30  In supermarkets all over the country, fourfoothigh figures will soon be blinking and beeping and trying to persuade shoppers to buy a particular brand of soft drink.

title: Cruel and Usual Punishment
description: Florida, having resumed executions, seems bent on making them unnecessarily cruel. A report to Governor Graham confirms that John Spenkelink, the murderer who went to the electric chair last spring, was denied important rights by prison officials. While it fails to clear up all the charges surrounding the event, the report does show the state was recklessly indifferent to what remained of the condemned man's dignity.

title: Eagles Snap Steelers Streak, 1714
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30  The Philadelphia Eagles, a team attempting to sneak up on unaware opponents in the Natonal Football League, lost their cover today when they beat thechampions, the Steelers, 1714, and ended the Pittsburgh winning streak at 12 games. Now everyone will be wary of the Eagles swarming, opportunistic defense and simple yet persistent offense, both of which helped Philadelphia gain its fourth victory in five games this season.

title: Kissinger Says Hanoi Barred Cambodia Neutrality
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  Henry A. Kissinger, in the latest installment of his memoirs, says that shortly after the overthrow of Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia, North Vietnam rejected an American proposal to start negotiations to guarantee Cambodia's neutrality.

title: ESSAY The Sandbox Plot
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  The New York Times revealed yesterday that law officers had been tipped at the beginning of this year to the possibility of a plot, supposedly masterminded by fugitive financier Robert Vesco, to obtain troop transport planes for Libya by bribing Democratic National Chairman John White and senior White House officials.

title: U.S. to Stop Financing Of Mexican Drug Spray
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)  The United States, in a delicate diplomatic communique, has informed Mexico that it will no longer provide funds for the spraying of marijuana fields with the herbicide paraquat, Carter Administration sources said today.

title: Jazz: Rhythmic Magic And Cohesiveness of Air
description: AIR'S performances at the Public Theater over the weekend kicked off the third season of Joseph Papp's jazzconcert series in style. On Saturday night, thetrio took time out for some unaccompanied solo improvisations by Steve McCall, the drummer, and Fred Hopkins, the bassist, but the meat of the performance was ensemble playing that reached remarkable levels of cohesiveness and rhythmic prestidigitation.

title: Briton and a Harvard Professor Share Columbia's Horwitz Prize
description: Frederick Sanger, a Nobel Prize winner from Britain, and Walter Gilbert, professor of molecular biology at Harvard University, have been awarded Columbia University's Louisa Gross Horwitz Prize, university officials announced yesterday.

title: In Bivalve, the Oyster Is Their World
description: BIVALVE, N.J., Sept. 28  This may be the most aptly named town in the nation.

title: Notes on People
description: Given all the disclosures about Government surveillance in the last few years, it should come as no surprise that one target, apparently, was the late Paul Robeson, the singer and black activist who was an outspoken admirer of the Soviet Union during what used to be called the Cold War.

title: Trip Could Cast Pope as World Leader
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 30  The coming seven days in October will establish whether Pope John Paul II has it within him to become a world leader, Vatican sources predict, or whether he will have to settle for being merely an effective and unusually attractive head of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Spanish Military Assails Violent Political Transition
description: MADRID, Sept. 30  The assassinations in one week of a brigadier general, colonel and a major in the Basque region, and statements by disgruntled, highranking military men criticizing Spain's transition to democracy have upset the nation's political leaders.

title: Canada Tests Direct TV Service By a Satellite to Remote Regions
description: TORONTO, Sept. 30 Watching television has never been much of a regular pastime in northern Ontario and other isolated, sparsely settled areas of this vast country. Reception, when available, is chronically unreliable,varying between nothing and fuzzy in an irregular pattern that discourages viewers. It all tends to increase the sense of isolation that dominates life far from metropolitan areas.

title: Landmark Bookshop in Village Is Closed
description: I can't believe it  it was such an institution, said William Higgins, standing beside his bicycle yesterday as he read the Closed notices in the windows of Eli S. Wilentz's Eighth Street Bookshop in Greenwich Village  a literary landmark since 1947, proclaims the shopfront between Fifth Avenue and MacDougal Street.

title: Marcos Exudes Confidence Amid Problems
description: MANILA, Sept. 24 The annual jitters that since 1973 have raised the level of excited talk in the Philippines during the first three weeks of September have been subsiding once more, and President Ferdinand E. Marcos has entered his eighth year as the nearly absolute ruler of this country.

title: Deaths
description: SAMONSSadie, on September 29, 1979, of 1142C Argyll Circle, Lakewood, N.J., formerly of East Orange, N.J., beloved mother of Bernard Samons, loving sister of Rhoda Bock and Seymour Lowenstein. Also survived by three grandchildren. Funeral from Suburban Chapel of Philip Apter 8 Son, 1600 Springfield Ave., Maplewood, N.J., on Tuesday, October 2, at 11 AM. Interment B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, N.J. Period of mourning will be observed at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Samons, 67F New England Ave., Summit, N.J.

title: Foreigners Own Few U.S. Farms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  Foreign buying of American farm, range and forest land, which has caused legislators and farm organizations to express deep concern, is far less extensive than these groups had feared.

title: Marriage Announcement 2 -- No Title
description: Allison Gordon Wed in Buffalo

title: Sports Briefs
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 30 (UPI) Tom Nissalke, head coach of the Utah Jazz, today put the club's No. 1 draft pick, Larry Knight, and a fouryear veteran, Wilbur Holland, on waivers.

title: Guitar: Robert Wolff
description: LATIN countries by no means have a monopoly on classicalguitar players, now that the instrument has become so popular. Take, for example, Robert Wolff, who played in Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday night. Mr. Wolff hails from Vienna, where he received his musical doctorate in 1973 and studied with such wellknown Austrian guitarists as Karl Scheit and Konrad Ragossnig.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Tchaikovsky's Eugen OnegIn, 8.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Four canzoni a due cants, Frescobaldi ; Aria quarta in G minor from Hexachordum Apolllnls, Pachelbel; Trio Sonata in C minor, Quantz.

title: Driver Wounded During Robbery On Charter Bus
description: The driver of a chartered bus was shot and wounded by one of three robbers who boarded his vehicle as it sat outside the Renaissance Ballroom in Harlem early yesterday, the police said.

title: Hinkle Is Victor by Stroke
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 30  The World Series of Golf was won and lost today on the 17th hole, where Lon Hinkle sank a birdie putt a few minutes before Larry Nelson took a double bogey.

title: Utility Dropping Plan to Ship Gas To Staten Island
description: New Jersey's largest utility company has dropped a plan to ship imported liquefied natural gas through Arthur Kill for storage on Staten Island, saying that Federal officials had not acted to approve the plan since applications were filed seven years ago.

title: Economy Shaky, Jamaican Chief Has Tough Balancing Act
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica For almost two weeks the tropical rains washed over this lush, mountainous island. The downpour deepened potholes in the streets of Kingston that could swallow a car, swept away bridges and roads and wiped out a fifth of the sugar crop.

title: De Gustibus On Substitutes for Garlic And a Southern Sweetmeat
description: A while ago, a column appeared extolling the miracle and tastevalues of garlic. It was noted that the subject was charged with emotion, especially among those known as alliumphiles, who love garlic, and those known as alliumphobes, who detest it.

title: The Theater: Losing Time With Jane Alexander
description: EVERYONE at the Manhattan Theater Club is very brave. John Hopkins, for instance, is the author of the club's current offering, Losing Time, and he has not only written a play, but he has alsowritten a play in three acts. Virtually unheard of nowadays. That, perhaps, does not seem particularly courageous to you. And, considering that the evening's caterwauling continues for a full three hours, it may very well seem simply humane. But consider. Two intermissions give the audience two superb opportunities to slip away furtively into the night. A real chancetaker, this Mr. Hopkins.

title: Excerpts From Pope's Talk to Youth
description: Dear young people, brothers and sisters of our Lord Jesus Christ: This morning the Pope belongs to the youths of Ireland! I have looked forward to this information; I have prayed that I may touch your hearts with the words of Jesus.

title: Truck Rates Increased
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) Truck freightrate increases of up to 2.8 percent have been approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission. A 2.8 percent rate increase was approved for trucking companies belonging to the Middle Atlantic Conference, and a 2.5 percent rate increase for members of the Pacific Inland Tariff Bureau. The increased rates were proposed to help truck companies cover a wage rise.

title: Screen: Pal Gabor's 'Angi Vera' From Hungary:Life for the Party
description: ONE of the quiet highlights of this year's New York Film Festival is "Angi Vera," a Hungarian film with a sharp sense of purpose and a wealth of vivid, revealing details. The year is 1948, and the setting is a political re-education camp, to which a special selection of workers has been sent for several months' training. The title character  Vera is her first name and Angi her last  has been selected for this training because, while working as a nurse, she had the courage to complain publicly about problems in her hospital. Officials of the Party, far from chastising her for this outburst, have chosen to welcome, even exploit, certain kinds of candor.Life at the camp, which is beautifully detailed by the director, Pal Gabor, is strictly regulated. But only part of that is the Party overseers' doing. The workers, who pretend to a certain merriment, have a more inhibiting effect on one another than outsiders possibly could. Some of this grows out of cowardice, or envy, but the bulk of it seems a byproduct of confusion  the Party is new to Hungary, and people still aren't sure what is required, beyond a certain basic humility. At a group meeting, at which each worker submits to criticism from Party officials, one woman is asked, "You are too passive  why?" "I never know whether what I say is correct or incorrect," she says, with obvious embarrassment.Vera, who is played by a frail, mournfully beautiful actress named Veronika Papp, enters this environment fairly innocently. And in the same spirit, she falls in love with her teacher, a married man. But the film charts her discovery that such displays of humanity are unwelcome among comrades, and that renouncing such feelings can be an effective way of currying favor  more effective, even, than not straying from the Party's behavior code at all. After closely observing the self-contradictory attitudes of the other women, and after realizing that modest defiance can amount to obedience, Vera learns a terrible lesson all too well.Mr. Gabor presents this with a delicacy that is astonishing at times, never more so than in a sequence that shows the workers having a modest celebration. There is dancing to music from a hand-cranked Victrola, and everyone gets an apple. A chorus sings, and beer is circulated very cautiously. The highlights of the evening are a couple of contests. In one, the men run past a flask of liquor, and every now and then someone is allowed to take a swig. In another, couples dance forehead-to-forehead, each pair trying to hold up a Ping-Pong ball.Vera and her teacher have their first tryst here and make the most of it, rolling the ball across their faces with an abandon that is, on closer examination, as controlled as the festivities themselves. Although much of Vera's transformation is deduced by the camera rather than demonstrated, this one episode is a subtle, especially well-realized intimation of the ways, both political and sexual, in which she will soon be seduced."Angi Vera" will be shown at 6:15 tonight and at 9:30 P.M. on Wednesday.

title: Now Georgians Splurge on Texas Scale
description: It was the first time in 53 years that the Dallasbased retailer ventured outside Texas for the formal release of its celebrated gift book, and the Georgians invited last week to the Neiman's outlet here were somewhat taken aback by the hisandher dirigibles, the lynxbelly coat and the $36,500 television antenna. My line for this, said Nick Taylor of Atlanta, the punster in the crowd, is wretched Texcess.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Ceres Street is a small, beautiful little avenue, lined with restaurants, Russell Rahn was saying a few days ago when asked how a golf tournament began in Portsmouth, N.H. One day Iwas sweeping the sidewalk outside one of the restaurants, and I started putting cigarette butts into a dust pan with a broom. Mike Smith, a friend, saw me and said, Hey, let me try that. That was the beginning of the Ceres Street open.

title: Pope to Travel in Plane Called Shepherd One
description: BOSTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)  Pope John Paul H will fly 2,272 miles over 12 states on his American peace pilgrimage in a plane named Shepherd One, seated in a private section in a specially made tiltswivel chair.

title: Commodities
description: DESPITE last week's nearly hysterical trading in precious metals, which again drove gold, silver and platinum prices to record levels, it was the stunning surge in copper that mesmerized the commodity futures markets.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TODAY

title: Boston Shooting Brings Call for Rally Near Pope
description: BOSTON, Sept. 30 (AP)  Two groups have called for marches, one to Boston Common tomorrow where Pope John Paul II is to celebrate mass, as a protest against the shooting of a black football player in the Charlestown section.

title: AUTO UNION RATIFIES CONTRACT WITH G.M.
description: DETROIT, Sept. 30 (UPI)  The United Automobile Workers said today that its tentative contract with the General Motors Corporation had been approved overwhelmingly by the rank and file.

title: Nancy Lopez Takes L.P.G.A. Event by 2
description: DALLAS, Sept. 30 (AP)  Nancy Lopez carded a final round 70 today for a 274 total and won the $150,000 Mary Kay Classic golf tournament by two strokes.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The retirement of Henry Ford 2d today as head of the Ford Motor Company places J. Peter Grace, president and chief executive officer of W.R. Grace & Company, in the position of being the chief executive of a Fortune 500 company with the longest tenure in the No. 1 spot. Mr. Grace, who is now 66, became president of the company, which was founded by his grandfather, in 1945 and was officially designated chief executive in 1953. Last year, Grace had sales of $4.3 billion in the chemical, natural resources and consumer services fields.

title: Outdoors
description: AWOODCOCK hunter guards the location of his favorite coverts as zealously as a recluse his privacy, but it is possible for a newcomer to a region to find birds if he is willing to do some exploring.

title: Hoisting the Welcome Sign
description: Let's face it, said Anthony Liga of the South Bronx. There are going to be thousands and thousands of people here to see him. And he won't get out? I can't believe it.

title: Carter Administration Sounding Out Latins On Peacekeeping Unit
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 28  The Carter Administration, concerned over the presence of Soviet troops in Cuba, is consulting with Latin American govern;ments on the creation of a regional military peacekeeping force, according to diplomatic sources.

title: Soaring Price of Silver Rouses Mining Industry
description: KELLOGG, Idaho  While gold has been on investors center stage, silver has been in the wings preparing to steal the show.

title: High Court to Get Tests of U.S. Policies
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  The Supreme Court term that begins tomorrow will, in several of its major cases, test the limits of Federal authority in areas in which activist Government policies have stirred political and economic controversy.

title: Political Wing of I.R.A. To Consider Pope's Plea
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 30 (Reuters)  Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Provisional Irish Republican Army, announced tonight that its ruling body would meet in Dublin tomorrow night to discuss yesterday's appeal for peace in Northern Ireland by Pope John Paul II.

title: Horowitz, 75 Today, Is Eager to Play New Music
description: THE life of a concert musician can be tolerable if your name is Vladimir Horowitz. In that case, you can pick and choose. Mr. Horowitz, discussing the current state of his art the other day, exuded contentment. He had just passed medical examination and was told that everything is perfect, like a man 45 or 50 years old.

title: The Energy Risk Worth Taking
description: The bitter debate over the creation of an energy mobilization board is coming to a head in both houses of Congress. The House must soon decide between very different approaches sponsored by Representatives Dingell and Udall. But first will come a pivotal decisionthis week in the Senate, where a plan close to the one proposed by the Carter Administration is backed by Senator Jackson. Opponents of that bill raise some troubling objections. But given the need to assure speedy development of alternative energy resources, the CarterJackson approach deserves support.

title: ABROAD AT HOME Never Again
description: BOSTON, Sept. 30  After visiting the Holocaust Museum in Israel the Rev. Jesse Jackson said he understood better the persecution complex of many Jewish people that almost invariably makes them overreact to their own suffering because it was so great.

title: Americans in Canal Zone Sadly Witness End of an Era
description: BALBOA, Canal Zone, Sept. 30  The Americans who have long operated the Panama Canal marked the demise of the Canal Zone today in an unmistakably funereal mood, unconsoled by reassurances that life can go on as usual.

title: ROSE GALOWIN HOFFMAN
description: Rose Galowin Hoffman, a literary lecturer, died Saturday at her home in Sarasota, Fla. She was 73 years old. Mrs. Hoffman was the wife of Calvin Hoffman, the critic and author. A public school teacher in New York City during her early career, Mrs. Hoffman later lectured on English and American authors and in support of her husband's theory that Christopher Marlowe wrote works attributed to Shakespeare. She is survived by her husband. No services are planned.

title: The City
description: Led by a drum and bugle corps, procession of neighborhood residents, government officials and church leaders walked from a Harlem church yesterday to West 135th Street for the dedication of 10 renovated adjoining sixstory apartment buildings.

title: Castro Foresees a Crisis If Carter Moves Military
description: MIAMI, Sept. 30 (AP)  President Fidel Castro of Cuba said today that the dispute with the United States over Soviet troops in Cuba could turn into a crisis if President Carter tries to flex American military might.

title: Guidry Fans 4 To Post 201 Total
description: The New York Yankees, the world champions the last two years, ended their season in fourth place yesterday, but were consoled by one individual and one team accomplishment. Ron Guidry became the first Yankee tostrike out 200 batters in consecutive seasons and the team posted its eighth straight victory in defeating the Toronto Blue Jays, 92, at the Stadium.

title: Marriage Announcement 1 -- No Title
description: Mickey J. Littmann Weds Lynn Aidala

title: Amtrak Hilltopper Given Last All Aboard!
description: WILLIAMSON, W. Va., Sept. 30  The headlight of Amtrak Train No. 67, the twocar Hilltopper, running late, brightened the clear track between the sidelined coal cars for the last time tonight. It will probably be the last time Mingo County sees a passenger train.

title: Steel Imports Up 18%
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30 (AP)  The American Iron and Steel Institute reported that 1.78 million tons of steel were imported in August, up 18 percent from 1.51 million tons in July. In August 1978, imports totaled 1.87 million tons.

title: Giants Drop 5th Straight, 2414
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 30  Giant fans will remember this place and date, because Phil Simms made his official National Football League debut today.

title: Jets Stalisties
description: Jets 33, Dolphins 27

title: U.S. Interest in Teamsters' Pension Fund Increasing
description: Government officials are again focusing attention on the Central States Pension Fund of the teamters' union as a resuit of the dismissal of one executive of the fund, the resignation of another and loan proposal that would funnel about $92 million from the fund to a concern headed by a Las Vegas casino operator.

title: Market Place
description: THE RCA Corporation, long a Wall Street wallflower, appears to be getting more support lately as a hightechnology stock. In the last few weeks a number of Wall Street houses have published largely favorable reports on the company.

title: U.S. JURY STUDYING GIBSON'S FINANCING
description: NEWARK, Sept. 28  A Federal grand jury is reportedly investigating fundraising activities during and after Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's 1974 reelection campaign.

title: Dance: Jerry Ames's Tap
description: THERE are dancers whose feathery tap work seems to skim over the air currents created by their chattering feet. Others sink into the ground, getting the full measure of the dance's play against gravity. Jerry Ames, a tap veteran and member of the muchmissed Tap Happening revue of 1969, has both feet just on the ground in a lilting and for the most part precisely articulated walk.

title: Itinerary of the Pope in Ireland and Boston Today
description: Following is the itinerary for Pope John Paul II in Ireland and Boston today. All times are local and approximate, with lastminute changes possible.

description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1979

title: Reagan's Jersey Backers Help Campaign at Dinner
description: BEDMINSTER, N.J. Sept. 30  Ronald Reagan's undeclared candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination received a boost today when more than 350 backers paid $175,000 to hear Mr. Reagan's views on the coming campaign.

title: Bids Invited for Cable TV For Brooklyn, Bronx, S.I.
description: New York City's Bureau of Franchises has issued notice that it is accepting proposals for the cabletelevision franchises for Brooklyn, the Bronx and Staten Island, with the requirement that the systems provide twoway services.

title: U.S. Official Unhappy With Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  The chairman of the Council on Wage and Price Stability, Alfred E. Kahn, said tonight that he was not happy with the 30 percent wage and benefit package in the threeyear General Motors settlement. He added that that it did not necessarily mean the contract was not in compliance with the Government's antiinflation guidelines.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Since most running shoes are not customized to an individual's feet, an improper fit can result in soreness, heel pain, ligament strain, knee problems and even backaches. JogRite Balancers, plastic inserts to fit any shoe, are made to close such gaps that occur between foot and shoe, as well as to balance weight distribution, thus lessening the chance of injury or soreness. They are available for $79.50 from OrthoTec Laboratories, 7800 River Road, North Bergen, N. J. 07047, (201) 8614663, which, upon a $20 deposit, will mall the material for taking impressions of your feet before sending you the correct balancers.

title: The Witch Doctor's Bones
description: BOXING occupied three hours of prime time on television the other night, the John TateGerrie Coetzee heavyweight match in South Africa Oct. 20 will draw some attention away from the World Series, and, if this isn't enough to put matters in perspective, be advised that the New School for Social Research is offering course entitled Tribute to a Champion, a study of the life and social impact of Muhammad Ali.

title: World News Briefs
description: CAIRO, Sept. 30 (AP)  The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson said today that Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, does not seek to exterminate Jews and wants to meet with President Carter.

title: Obsession Yachting Victor on L.I. Sound
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 30Driven by winds gusting to 35 miles an hour, Obsession, a 46foot sloop designed by Sparkman & Stephens, blazed across a turbulent Long Island Sound today to win the 14th annual StamfordDenmark friendship race.

description: EXETER, N.H. UNTIL last summer, Anne Plante and Faith Deming had never heard of Sebastian Coe Last week, the two high school milers from nearby Timberlane Regional High School met the world

title: Stakes Are High in Vote On Sales Tax in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 30  A referendum Tuesday on an additional onecent sales tax has developed into a major test of public attitudes toward a soaring crime rate, toward the political future of this city's first black Mayor and his close associates and toward increased government spending in general.

title: Screen: 'Nosferatu,' Herzog's Dracula:Nip on the Nape
description: IN the filmography of Werner Herzog, that talented West German film maker, "Nosferatu, the Vampyre" looks to be a kind of charming diversion. That's not meant to underrate the movie but to acknowledge that it's something less than the voyage of self-discovery that each of Mr. Herzog's earlier, very original films has been, including "Kasper Hauser," "Heart of Glass," "Stroszek" and "Aguirre, the Wrath of God."Here is an almost gentle evocation of F.W. Murnau's 1922 silent-film classic, "Nosferatu, a Symphony of Horror," which was, of course, based on Bram Stoker's 1897 novel, "Dracula." The new production is also Mr. Herzog's attempt to strip away some of the sensationalism that has been attached to the Dracula story over the years by those vividly grotesque Hammer films from England (which I've always liked), as well as the camp attitudes manifest in Frank Langella's "Dracula" productions, on stage and screen, and especially in something like the facetiously titled "Love at First Bite."Mr. Herzog has done what he set out to do, but when you come right down to it, one wonders if it's worth the trouble. Dracula, after all, is not Hamlet or Othello or Macbeth. He's not some profoundly complex character who speaks to us in more voices than most of us care to hear. Dracula is Santa Claus turned mean. He's a fairy-tale character. Though he represents something vestigially scary, he's not endlessly interesting.Having expressed these reservations, I must go on to report that Mr. Herzog's film seems well worth the effort to me. It's funny without being silly, eerie without being foolish and uncommonly beautiful in a way that has nothing to do with mere prettiness.His principal actors  Klaus Kinski as Dracula, Isabelle Adjani as the incredibly pure Lucy whose throat Dracula dreams of and Bruno Ganz, as Lucy's unfortunate husband  often employ the exaggerated gestures of silent films, though the purpose is not to make fun of sentiment but to recall a world of mythical innocence. There's a marvelous moment in the movie when Lucy, seeing the lunatic wreck her husband has become after a trip to Transylvania, goes into a faint that's both comic and touching. The point is that evil of the enormity of Dracula's can exist only in a world where ladies still seriously swoon. When such sensitivity is lost, evil is rendered impotent.Mr. Herzog and Mr. Kinski are somewhat less successful, I think, in their attempts to make moving for us Dracula's loneliness and longing for love. Mr. Kinski is a fascinating figure on screen, but his makeup is so heavy that it seems to remove the actor from his performance as effectively as if he were hiding behind a Greek mask. The makeup itself, however, is part of the entertainment and recalls that worn by Max Schreck in the Murnau film  dead-white face, bald, pointed head, two batlike fangs in the middle of his mouth, deformed, ratlike ears and fingernails that look like bat claws.Yet the film's penultimate sequence is as beautiful and erotic and peculiarly human as anything you've ever seen in a "Dracula" film: the virtuous Lucy offers herself to Dracula in order to destroy him. She lies on her bed, strewn with flower petals, serene in her sacrifice, as Dracula drinks. To make sure that he stays until the sun is well up, Lucy insists that he have some more. Dracula hesitates, then obliges, though it's clear he is quite full. It's as if he were being polite to a favorite hostess.Mr. Herzog works some odd variations on the sort of Dracula movies most of us are familiar with. The usually astute Dr. Van Helsing, the vampire specialist, is a foolish old fellow who refuses to think "the unthinkable." "We'll investigate this scientifically," he says with maddening self-assurance while pretty ladies are being found dead by the dozens, each with a small, unexplained puncture mark on the neck. This Van Helsing actually is a blood brother in ignorance to the doctor in Mr. Herzog's other new film, "Woyzeck.""Nosferatu" was shot mostly in the ancient Dutch city of Delft, which gives it the look of timeless legend except when you see the television aerials on the roofs of the buildings surrounding the city's magnificent old square. The city's fathers were not, apparently, very helpful to the film maker, though they did put up with thousands of more rats (who appear in the picture) than you or I would.As he always does, Mr. Herzog makes fine use of his musical score, especially in the extended sequence showing us the unlucky Jonathan making his perilous journey to Transylvania. As Jonathan crosses mountains so high they have no peaks and valleys that are beyond measurable depth, the film, largely through the use of music, achieves a kind of crazy grandeur singular in such movies. Another big virtue is Miss Adjani's startlingly perfect beauty, which is as unreal as the fellow who pursues her."Nosferatu" will be shown at the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center at 9:30 P.M. today and on Wednesday at 6:15 P.M. It opens its commercial run Thursday at the Cinema Studio, D.W. Griffith, Quad Cinema and other theaters.

title: New Bankruptcy Law
description: Federal courts are bracing for a flood of bankruptcy petitions today as a new law governing personal and smallbusiness insolvencies takes effect.

title: Extra Service Is Planned By M.T.A. for Pope's Visit
description: Getting into, out of and around Manhattan during Pope John Paul II's visit to New York City tomorrow and Wednesday will be a tricky and often exasperating experience  fraught with traffic jams, street closings, and changes in some publictransportation schedules.

title: Reagan to Raise Funds With a Sinatra Concert
description: BOSTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)  Frank Sinatra and Dean Martin will appear in concert at the Boston Music Hall Nov. 2 to raise funds for Ronald Reagan, the former California Governor campaigning for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: City Opera Suspends Schedule Indefinitely In Musicians Dispute
description: The New York City Opera announced last night that it was suspending its performances at Lincoln Center beginning tomorrow night as a result of a failure to bargain a contract with Local 802 of the American Federations of Musicians.

title: Ireland Shows Mettle on Visit By John Paul
description: KNOCK, Ireland, Sept. 30  Alfie Parke and his wife talked it over, and they decided they would travel from their home in County Sligo to see Pope John Paul II, because it was the one thing we could do for our children that they would surely remember all their lives.

title: Allegations of Libyan Bribery Plot Reportedly Will Go to Grand jury
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  A secret Justice Department investigation of possible bribery scheme involving Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, the Libyan Government and the Carter Administration Is expected to move into the grand jury phase by early November, according to sources close to the inquiry.

title: Sports Today
description: Packers vs. New England Patriots, at Green Bay, Wis. (TelevisionChannel 7, following President Carter's speech, which starts at 9 P.M. RadioWCBS)

title: The Editorial Notebook America's Lost Cutting Edge
description: Most leading corporate executives believe that the United States has lost the cutting edge in technological progress, according to a recent survey. In other words, America has changed from a can do to a can't do society. Keeping the cutting edge calls for many things, including money; but it also calls, first of all, for a cuttingedge mentality.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial 11st of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Deflating The Nuke Protest
description: The political significance of the recent antinuclear rally at the Battery Park City landfill has been overstated. Though there were nearly 200,000 people present and it was the largest antinuke demonstration ever held in the United States, it was obvious that the majority of people (most in their early teens) had come to take part in a giant music festival, not a political action.

title: Thousands on Public Payrolls Face Layoff When Training Ends Today
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  With the ax about to fall tomorrow on the jobs of thousands of federally financed public service workers, cities around the country are scrambling to cope with the political, economic and practical consequences of the layoffs.

title: The Region
description: NORWALK, Conn. (AP)  An 8foothigh blazing cross was placed against the home of a black couple in a predominantly white neighborhood during the weekend, the second such incident here in 10 days.

title: Trojan Comeback Shows Character
description: Any college football team reaching for a national title has to prove it can come from behind once or twice in a season and pull out a victory in game in which lesser teams would falter. Southern California did Just that Saturday night, under some of the most trying conditions a visiting team can experience  in front of a large crowd at Louisiana State University's Tiger Stadium.

title: Polo Postponed
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., Sept. 30  The championship match of the Wanamaker 10Goal polo tournament was postponed today because of wet grounds at Bethpage State Park. The match, between Melody Farms and Huntington, has been rescheduled for Tuesday at Hickox Field in Brookville, L.I. The starting time is 2 P.M.

title: James Mclver, Covered Police Beat for Times
description: James E. McIver, a reporter for The New York Tirnes covering local crime and police news for 30 years before he retired to live in Maine, died Friday at his home in Bridgton, Me. He was 67 years old.

title: Dance: 3 Generations Is Indian Family Affair
description: ONE of the most brilliant and joyful presentations of Indian classical dance in New York atttracted a full house and scores of prominent American dance figures Saturday night when Indrani, Sukanya and Ragini Devi appeared together at the New York University School of Education at 35 West Fourth Street.

title: Typhoon Strikes Japan, Killing 7 In Trail of Floods and Landslides
description: TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 1 (Reuters)At least seven persons were killed today as Typhoon Owen left a trail of landslides and floods across Japan. More than 30 were injured and three were missing.

title: Pass to Walker Secures Victory
description: The New York Jets finally played yesterday the kind of football game everyone. had thought they were capable of playing, rising up and knocking the Miami Dolphins from the ranks of the undefeated, 3327, before a crowd of 51,496 on an overcast and misty afternoon at Shea Stadium.

title: Suit Asserts M.T.A. Fails To Provide for Disabled
description: Disabled veterans are charging in lawsuit that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority illegally spends public money on transit facilities that are not accessible to the handicapped.

title: Diversity in Leasing Propels Gelco
description: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  Last May, the Gelco Corporation suffered a brulsing setback in its effort to broaden its base: The transportation leasing company lost out to the giant Transamerica Corporation in a bitter $200 million fight to acquire an interest in the Interway Corporation, a large containerleasing concern.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Advanced Micro Devices elected Steve Zelencik vice president of sales for North America.

title: Around the Nation
description: DENVER, Sept. 30 (UPI)  A passenger on an American Airlines DCI0 flying from Chicago to San Francisco became unruly today and began wielding a knife. Three persons were injured, none severely, and the flight was diverted to Denver.

title: Borg Beats Panatta
description: MARBELLA, Spain, Sept. 30 (AP)Bjorn Borg of Sweden won the first $200,000 European open tennis tournament today by defeating Adrian Panetta of Italy, 62, 62, 75. The match, held on a court in the bullring of Marbelle, was played before an estimated 5,000 spectators. Borg earned $100,000 and Panatta $40,000.

title: Two Men Are Charged With Slaying Girl, 17,On Rockaway Corner
description: Two Queens men, who, the police said, bragged of their escapade, were arrested late Saturday on charges of fatally shooting a teenage girl standing in a group outside of a Rockaways social club just after midnight Wednesday.

title: Norway's Ancient Mariner
description: FJOSANGER, Norway  Now all the proud old man can do is wait, surrounded by his magnificent collection of silver and carpets.

title: TV: Survey of American Musical Comedy
description: MUSICAL Comedy Tonight, scheduled to be shown tonight at 9 o'clock on WNETTV, Channel 13, following President Carter's national address, is described as an overview of the history of American musical comedy. The writer, producer and host of the series is Sylvia Fine Kaye. The cast includes Ethel Merman, Carol Burnett, Bernadette Peters and, discussing her choreography, Agnes de Mille.

title: DuPre Leaves His Skills Behind
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30  Tony Bennett was not the only one to leave something in San Francisco. Consider Pat DuPre, who left his overhands, volleys and returns of serves high on a hill last night.

title: Irish in Boston Await Pope With Pride
description: BOSTON, Sept. 30  Outside on a leafy and wellkept street of twofamily homes here in a prosperous section of Dorchester, the heart of Boston's Irish Catholic community, little girls wearing the Catholic school uniform of whiteblouses and dark plaid skirts walked home hand in hand. Blond boys and redhaired boys, dressed in blue blazers and grayslacks, traded punches on the corner.

title: Fire Kills Four in St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 (UPI) A fire that the authorities suspect was deliberately set swept through a twostory house early today, killing a woman and four members of her family. Details were sketchy, but the police also said that two men who had been shot and wounded were found outside the residence. Killed were Thelma Brown, 49 years old, two of her children and two grandchildren.

title: Bucs, Only Undefeated Team, Win
description: After three years of futility, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers are suddenly one of the big boys on the block. In fact, at the moment there is no one bigger.

title: Political Complexity Marks Cleveland Mayor's Race
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 29 Mayor DenMs J. Kucinich, who manages Cleveland  mismanages Cleveland, his opponents say  from four neatlypiled file boxes under his desk in an office on the second floor of City Hall, insists that the issues inthe city's Oct. 2 mayoral primary are economic.

title: FINAL PREPARATIONS ARE MADE FOR POPE
description: Workmen in Boston strung rope along a 20mile motorcade route, rolled out red carpets and put the finishing touches on a canopied altar on the Boston Common yesterday as lastminute preparations went forward for today's historic visit by Pope John Paul II.

title: Rangers Down Bruins, 53
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 30 (AP)  A goal by Anders Hedberg, his second of the night, with seven minutes to play proved to be the gamewinner as the New York Rangers defeated the Boston Bruins, 53, tonight in a National Hockey League exhibition game.

title: Ties to Blacks Are Noted In Yom Kippur Sermons
description: Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement and the most sacred holiday on the Jewish calendar, began at sundown yesterday as several prominent rabbis expressed in their sermons the hope that Jews and blacks would not allow recent differences to impede their long alliance in the cause of civil rights for all people.

title: C'est Fini for Sad Expos
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 30  And so the Miracle on Avenue Pierre de Coubertin never happened.

title: Inside the Supreme Court
description: It is certainly accurate to say, with such a change in its membership, that the institutional personality of the United States Supreme Court has greatly altered [since 1958]. But it is also accurate to say that the institutional character has changed remarkably little  in 21 years or in 50 years.

title: Violinist: Rosand At the Y
description: A ARON ROSAND'S violin recital Saturday night at the 92d Street Y was at its best when it was most trivial. In other words, in a Spanishy piece by Sarasate called Malaguena. The reason was that this is a delicate, spidery score, full of soft little harmonics and sensuous subtleties. This would seem to be the sort of music Mr. Rosand handles best, and he played it with a lovely assurance.

title: Mobil Oil Find
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Sept. 30 (Reuters)  The West German and Austrian subsidiaries of the Mobil Oil Corporation have discovered oil in the Medenine drilling concession in Tunisia, the German unit, Mobil Oil A.G., reported.

title: Finally, The Cowboy Rides Another Champion
description: ANAHEIM,CALIF. APERSONAL guest named Nixon was on his way to the ballpark from San Clemente, so The Cowboy didn't have much time to talk. I'm Gene Autry, said the owner of the California Angels, extending his hand as he entered the Golden West Room at Anaheim Stadium. My wife says you were wondering why I never got to kiss the girl.

title: Dave Anderson
description: DURING the interlude before the second quarter was about to begin, the chant interrupted the quiet between the thunderous vibrations of the jetliners taking off from La Guardia Airport yesterday. Wewant Robinson, we want Robinson, many in the misty rain at Shea Stadium were shouting. We want Robinson. They wanted Matt Robinson, and they did not want Richard Todd, because at that moment the New York Jets were trailing the Miami Dolphins, 107, and Richard Todd had misfired on his only two passes. One had been incomplete, the other had been intercepted, and now the Dolphins were on the Jets 30yard line. But less than three hours later, after the Jets had won, 3327, none of the Jets loyalists were complaining about Richard Todd, none were chanting for Matt Robinson anymore.

title: Chess:
description: There is always a question, in a bad position, of whether to play on or resign. Most players, annoyed with themselves for having been outplayed, sullenly drag out games that are routinely won for the opponent. There are also those who have given up in positions where a perfect defense or even a forced triumph was at their disposal.

title: Burns Cites Limits On Fed Powers
description: F. Burns, former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today.

title: Big Week for Treasury
description: The Treasury will dominate the credit markets this week as it sells $19 billion of bills, notes and bonds in an outpouring of Government financing made possible last Friday by the vote in Congress to raise the national debt ceiling to $879 billion. Some yields likely will be the highest on record.

title: GEORGE COWAN DIES
description: George Cowan, managing art director for The New York Times and a member of the newspaper's art department for more than 90 years, died yesterday at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., following openheart surgery. He was 69 years old and lived in Merrick.

title: West's Cambodian Aid Called Cover by Hanoi
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 30 (AP)  Vietnam accused the West today of conducting a smear campaign against Cambodia and said that international slid programs for that country were a cover for intervention and aggression.

title: Man at a Mass Shouts That He Is Jesus Christ
description: KNOCK, Ireland, Sept. 30 The first untoward incident of Pope John Paul's triumphal tour of Ireland, a minor one, occurred here today as he was celebrating mass.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON THOSE who are tracking the record call it another case where the product fails to live up to the advertising. The Government had to give a higher priority to exports, President Carter declared just a year ago. It was essential, he said, for this nation's economic vitality.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Alternateside parking regulations will be suspended throughout New York City today because of the Jewish holy day of Yom Kippur, which began at sundown yesterday.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How many years and games did Babe Ruth and Hank Aaron play, and how many times at bat did each have when they reached 714 career homers?

title: Herman E. Frenzel, 63, an Officer Of Government Securities Dealer
description: Herman E. Frenzel, a senior vice president of William E. Pollock and Company, Government securities dealers in New York, died Friday in New Smyrna Beach,Fla. He was 63 years old and lived in Upper Saddle River, N.J.

title: JetsDolphins Summary
description: Jets Notes

title: Policies of Pope Protested
description: About 50 homosexual men and women protested Pope John Paul II's policies on abortion and homosexual rights yesterday on me steps or St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Pope claims to be for the human rights of all men and women, said Andy Humm, a spokesman for the Coalition for Lesbian and Gay Rights.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets, deeply concerned about the dollar, inflation and the increasing volume of Treasury and corporate financing to be done, expect interest rates to climb higher  perhaps substantially higher  during early autumn.

title: Aid Program Will Be Too Late for Many Cambodians
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30 Sometime this week, Jacques Beaumont is due to leave Phnom Penh where he has been measuring misery and its relief for more than a month. He will come here to deliver a grim report to his chiefs at the United Nations Children's Fund.

title: The Race for Olympic Gold
description: The Race for Olympic Gold ABCTV obviously expects 1984 to be a banner year. With a bid of $225 million, the network has all but locked up American broadcasting rights for that year's summer Olympics in Los Angeles. It also all but counts the profits: the Games will allow time for 2,000 minutesof commercials at an average cost of $200,000 a minute, yielding a gross of $400 million and a profit of perhaps $50 million.

title: Mets Finish Year With 63d Victory
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30  The notsomagic number for the New York Mets was 100, 100 losses that is. They never made it. That was the reason for the joy in the Mets clubhouse today after they beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 42, in the final game of their 1979 season.

title: New Yorker Takes 55Mile British Run
description: LONDON, Sept. 30  Allan Kirik of Flushing, Queens, and the Central Park Track Club won the 55mile road race from London to Brighton today, declared that the last hill was the brute, and then slumped into the welcoming arms of his wife, Lynne.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A photo caption in the Metropolitan Report on Saturday incorrectly identified a musical instrument being played by an artist in residence at Wesleyan University. The instrument was a gamelan from Java.

title: VANCE SAID TO SEEK A PLEDGE ON TROOPS FROM SOVIET ENVOY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance held an unscheduled meeting with Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union today as President Carter worked on a draft for his address to the nation tomorrow night on the impasse over the Soviet troops in Cuba.

title: Advertising
description: HANES HOSERY, which introduced a new category in 1975 with Underalls (pantyhose and panty all in one) and in 1977 added Slenderalls (the previous qualities plus top control), went into test markets last week with the second line extension, Winteralls (cozy pantyhose and panties all in one).

title: High Court Set to Test Basic Laws on Business
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  Does printer violate the securities laws if he learns from his typesetting assignments which companies are about to become takeover targets and then buys those companies stock? Can local realestate brokers who charge a uniform commission be sued under the Sherman Antitrust Act? Can individual states tax the stock dividends earned by multinational corporations?

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FULL SAILS Intriguing piano sounds on New York's neon scene sometimes have a minimum of fanfare. Take, for example, the music of David Lahm and Charlie Cochran.

title: For Financier. a Year's Sabbatical at Home Yields Rewards
description: Well, it's over. And the astonishing thing is  to those Wall Street cynics who made bets and lost  he really stuck it out the entire year.

title: Koosman Notches 20th Victory for Second Time
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 30 (AP)  Jerry Koosman, who won only 11 games and lost 35 in his last two seasons with the New York Mets, became a 20game winner for the second time in his career when he defeated the Milwaukee Brewers. 50. today.

title: Bridge:
description: Bethe Repeats in Triathlon By Taking Individual TitleSuccessful defense of a team title is not at all uncommon. Successful defense of a pair title is rare. And successful defense of an individual title is almost unheard of.

title: Supreme Court Backs Amtrak Bid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)  The Supreme Court today overturned a lower court order that would have required Amtrak to continue running its New YorkKansas City train, the National Limited. The rail passenger service had sought to discontinue that run and three others in a costcutting move.

title: Jones Drives Hard To Win Grand Prix
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 30  Alan Jones of Australia drove his SaudiWilliams to victory in the Grand Prix of Canada today after a racelong battle with the hometown favorite, Gilles Villeneuve.

title: Ford Weighs a LowKey Drive for G.O.P. Nomination
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 30  Former President Gerald R. Ford has told political associates that he might enter the 1980 Republican Presidential race if convinced that he could do it with a reasonable chance of winning but without an exhausting load of personal campaigning.

title: Effects Of Pay Pact At Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  The second year of President Carter's pay and price guidelines begins tomorrow under a new agreement with organized labor that has drawn a wary, and sometimes outwardly hostile, reaction from American business.

title: Limits and Dates
description: The bag limit for woodcock in the Northeast is five birds daily. Repeating or automatic shotguns must be plugged, if needed, to limit them to three shells.

title: Civilian Leader Takes Over Today In Prosperous and Growing Nigeria
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 30  More than 13 years of military rule are scheduled to end tomorrow in Nigeria when Presidentelect Alhaji Shehu Shagari and a civilian government that is modeled on the American system are sworn in.

title: A School Finds Budget Cuts Costly
description: The principal of Public School 84 on Manhattan's Upper West Side began the school year several weeks ago by joining a demonstration that blocked traffic on the West Side Highway during the morning rush. Even a peaceloving, taciturn man like Sidney Morison is moved to shout when it comes to losine money for his classrooms.

title: Pope Prays at fish Shrine; Will Fly to the U.S. Today
description: KNOCK, Ireland, Sept. 30 Acclaimed for the second day of his visit by hundreds of thousands of the Irish faithful, Pope John Paul H prayed silently as a pilgrim today at a shrine to the Virgin Mary here in remote County Mayo.

title: At Carter's Call, They Represent U.S. at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 When Howard T. Rosen was asked by the Carter Administration to serve as a public representative on the United States delegation to the United Nations, he was skeptical.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: JOHN BARTH'S new novel  his first in 12 years  seems to have been written for graduate students and other masochists. If it is not one of those symbolfraught Swiss watches and Schwarzwaldcuckoo clocks of Modernism, it is at least a bathtub of alphabet soup, and every letter of the alphabet signifies something, and every signification has a mythic resonance, with or without consequences, according to the stage of a love affair or a cycle of a life, depending on whether the series is based on a set of fives (vowels in English, toes on a foot, tones of pentatonic music, bloods of Ireland) or of sevens (days of the week, deadly sins, symbols on a Seder tray, books by John Barth).

title: Students Protest a Beer Ban
description: PLYMOUTH, N.H., Sept. 30 (AP) Angry at a campus ban on beer parties, about 750 students and visitors at Plymouth State College threw rocks and bottles at the police today before they were subdued with fire hoses. We want kegs! We want kegs! the students chanted during the fivehour confrontation in which a lamppost was torn down and windows were broken on buildings near the campus. Five students and a local resident were arrested for disorderly conduct. One fireman was hospitalized.

title: Supplementary OTC Listings
description: Week Ended Sept. 28,1979

title: Pirates Win Division By Defeating Cubs, 53; And Then What?; Pirates Win Division Title; A Great Team
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30  Champagne foam burst from the chilled green bottle in Willie Stargell's hand, spraying the Pirate first baseman and the people clustered around him. In the disco din of the Pittsburgh clubhouse.Phil Garner was screaming. Everybody was screaming in the wake of the Pirates 53 victory over the Chicago Cubs that secured the National League's Eastern Division title, but the second baseman with Tennessee in his voice and on his Tshirt could be heard above them all.

title: Bishop With Chicago Roots Is Managing Pope's Travels
description: ROME  Wherever Pope John Paul II sets foot on his journey, Bishop Paul Casimir Marcinkus will have been there before him.

title: Prayer Vigils Focus on Decision Not to Allow Women to Help Distribute Communion
description: BOSTON, Sept. 30  They wore yellow armbands and sang hymns of love, and one woman staged a Hindu sacred dance at the altar of the borrowed Protestant church. They called the service A Celebration of Women, and they wanted it known that it was not a protest the day before Pone John Paul II arrives here.

title: Padres Drop Craig as Pilot
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30 (AP)  Roger Craig was the ninth man to become a former major league manager this season when he was dismissed by the San Diego Padres today. A successor is expected to be named tomorrow.

title: China Cuts Ethylene Plant
description: Combustion Engineering Inc. of Stamford, Conn., announced yesterday that China had indefinitely postponed plans for the building of one of four ethylene plants that had been ordered. Plans for the three others are moving ahead, according to a company statement. They will cost about $600 million and require three years to build.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Fog Possibility Stirs Worry on Schedule
description: The rain was pelting down at Yankee Stadium yesterday, turning the infield into a muddy swamp and creating huge puddles near the stands. But 68year old Lodovico Poggioli, protected only by a yellow slicker. continued to saw away at a piece of wood that will be a railing near the Yankee dugout by the time Pope John Paul II arrives at the Stadium tonight.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Chase Increases Prime to 131/2%
description: Chase Manhattan, the nation's thirdlargest bank, raised its prime lending rate yesterday by onequarter point to 13 percent.

title: Dance: Bhaskar of India
description: Sunday his company presented a program of pieces derived from Indian classical dance at the Provincetown Playhouse.

title: Patronage Chiefs in Chicago to Appeal Judge's Ruling
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 1  When a Federal judge ruled last week that the patronage system here was unconstitutional, he set off a wave of protest from the politicians who for years have dispensed tens of thousands of city jobs here and in surrounding Cook County.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Excitement Rises at U.N. Over Very Special Visit
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 1 Diplomats and international civil servants stationed here have worked themselves into a rare pitch of excitement over Pope John Paul H's visit tomorrow.

title: Judge Urged to Bar Papal Mass on Mall
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)  Judge Oliver Gasch of Federal District Court heard arguments today in a case brought by Madelyn Murray O'Hair to bar Pope John Paul II from celebrating Mass next Sunday on the Governmentowned Mall between the Capitol and the Lincoln Memorial.

title: Metal Concerns Increase Prices
description: Several metal producers said yesterday that they were raising their prices. The Asarco Corporation, meanwhile, said it was decreasing its base spot sales price of refined lead by 4 cents a pound.

title: EARNINGS Profits Cut in Half at Chessie System
description: The Chessie System, the nation's largest coal carrier, reported yesterday that its earnings for the third quarter declined 50.2 percent but said profits in the first nine months were four times larger than those in the corresponding period of 1978.

title: Science Library
description: Compiled by William R. Corliss. 710 pages. The Sourcebook Project, P.O. Box 107, Glen Arm, Md. 21057. $15.95

title: Packers Top Patriots
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct.1 (AP)  David Whitehurst passed 15 yards to Aundra Thompson for one touchdown and ran for another while Green Bay's secondary intercepted five New England passes as the Packers upset the New England Patriots, 2714, in a National Football League game tonight.

title: High Court Will Decide Con Ed Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 In a case almost certain to produce one of the most important First Amendment decisions of the new term, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Consolidated Edison Company of NewYork has a constitutional right to send statements of its views on controversial public issues along with monthly bills to its customers.

title: Quest for Equality in Church Dividing Catholic Women
description: I wish I didn't love the church so much, said Rosalie MusehalReinhardt, a Roman Catholic activist from Rochester, N.Y. But I love the church so much, I'm not going to leave.

title: Outbreak of Scabies Is Depleting A Herd of Bighorn Sheep in N.M.
description: SANTAFE, N.M., Oct. 1 (AP) About threefourths of the Desert Bighorn sheep in the San Andres Mountains of southcentral New Mexico have been wiped out by scabies, according to State Game and Fish Department officials.

title: Libya Cuts Oil Sales In LongTerm Pacts
description: Libya has notified most of the companies that buy its oil to expect sizable cutbacks in the quantities they purchase under longterm contract, oil buyers in New York and elsewhere said yesterday. In confirming the reports,company officials said the reductions would start once existing contracts expired at the end of the year.

title: KENNEDY BOOK TELLS HIS POLITICAL VIEWS
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy's forthcoming book, Our Day and Generation, originally designed simply to coin cide with the opening on Oct. 20 in Boston of the John F. Kennedy Library  the beneficiary of the book's royalties  hasturned out to resemble a Presidential campaign document that will be closely studied by friends and foes seeking to clarify or condemn his views on national and international affairs.

title: Prosecution Of Cornfeld Criticized
description: GENEVA, Oct. 1 Comments by the presiding judge in the fraud trial here of Bernard Cornfeld, founder of a now bankrupt group of offshore mutual funds, severely deflated the prosecution's case today.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Science Watch
description: A freak windstorm over the southern end of California's San Joaquin Valley two years ago has been implicated in an unusual sharp increase in cases of the fungus disease coccidiodomycosis last year as far as 400 miles farther north. New cases appeared in areas where the illness has been considered rare.

title: Senate Votes, 77 to 9, to Deny Automatic Raises to Members of Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  In the latest round in the fight over Congressional salaries, the Senate voted tonight to deny members of Congress the annual $7,400 pay increase that automatically went into effect at midnight last night.

title: Libraries Get $1.6 Million
description: For the seventh time, the National Endowment for the Humanities has made a matching grant to the research libraries of the New York Public Library. This year, the grant is $1.8 million. Under the terms of the grant, the?? Will have to raise $2 m unrestricted gifts for every $1 contributed by the endowment, or $3.2 million, to qualify for the $1.6 million. The research libraries consist of the Fifth Avenue central building, the performingarts library at Lincoln Center, the Schomburg center for research in black culture. and the Annex at 521 West 43d Street. Two million people use the facilities annually.

title: Pilot Dies, All on Jet Safe
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 (AP)  A Pan American Airlines pilot asked to be excused from the controls of a plane flying from Honolulu to Los Angeles, then died few minutes later of an apparent heart attack, an airlines spokesman said today.

title: U.A.W. Chief Asks Chrysler Aid
description: DETROIT, Oct. 1 (UPI)  Douglas Fraser, president of United Auto Workers, today urged the Government to take the initiative in drafting a timely aid package for the ailing Chrysler Corporation.

title: U.S. Defense Secretary Said to Plan China Trip
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  Secretary of Defense Harold R. Brown plans to visit China late this year or early in 1980 for talks with the country's top military authorities, Carter Administration officials said today.

title: McEnroe Defeats Fleming In Final by 46, 75, 62
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 (AP)John McEnroe, breaking his opponent's service .six times after a slow start, beat Peter Fleming last night, 46, 75, 6.2, and won the $175,000 Transamerica open tennis tournament.

title: Carter Reportedly Drops Objection to Large Carrier
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  President Carter has reversed course and decided to approve construction of the large nuclearpowered aircraft carrier advocated by senior naval officers and approved by the Congress, officials in Congress and the Administration disclosed today.

title: COMMODITIES Metals at New Peaks
description: All metals futures were bid up to historic highs yesterday by eager buyers on both sides of the Atlantic. As platinum, gold, silver and copper futures shot up their daily permissible limits, so did prices of basic foodstuffs as sellers held out for more money.

title: Paine Webber Set  to Buy  Blyth
description: Paine Webber Inc. and Blyth Eastman Dillon & Company, two of Wall Street's largest brokerage and investmentbanking firms, announced plans yesterday to merge through an exchange of stock valued at about $45 million. The combined entity would be one of the three or four largest firms in the securities industry, with capital of about $240 million.

title: South Africans Start Tour of Britain
description: LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP)  Fears of violence against an integrated South African rugby team that arrived today for a visit surged briefly when the team']s bus caught fire on a highway in Chippenham, west of London. But thepolice later ruled out sabotage, saying they were satisfied that the fire had been caused by a mechanical defect.

title: Substitution Fund Set By I.M.F.
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 1 (AP)  Finance Ministers from 138 nations agreed tonight to give priority attention to establishing an international substitution account, in which unwanted dollars in the world financial system could be exchanged for special drawing rights issued by the International Monetary Fund.

title: Pope's Host in Boston: Immigrant to Cardinal
description: BOSTON, Oct. 1 (UPI)  Humberto Cardinal Medeiros, the host for Pope John Paul II's visit to Boston, began his career in the church more than 30 years ago and became the fourth Archbishop of Boston in 1970. He was elevated to the cardinalate three years later.

title: Top Chilean Court Won't Yield 3 Army Officers Wanted by U.S.
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 1  The Chil. can Supreme Court rejected today an appeal by the United States for the extradition of three army officers indicted for the murder in Washington of Orlando Letelier, a Chilean exile leader.

title: Reprieve Keeps 200 CETA Jobs With the Police
description: A lastminute reprieve allowed more than 200 Police Department aides paid with Federal funds to remain in their jobs yesterday. They were to have been terminated by new rules affecting people hired under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act.

title: Benefits of Transsexual Surgery Disputed As Leading Hospital Halts the Procedure
description: AT a time when sexchange operations are on the increase at major medical centers around the country, Johns Hopkins  the prestigious hospital that started it all  has stopped doing them, using as its justification a study that has been widely attacked by others in the field. The study called into question the benefits of these drastic operations.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Carter's Aim: Balancing Politics and Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  President Carter may have told the nation tonight that politics and nuclear arsenals do not mix, but the steps he disclosed on the Cuban situation were designed to strike a balance between his domestic politicalneed to look strong and his foreign policy objective of saving a nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: HydroQuebec Debentures
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (Reuters) The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that HydroQuebec had filed for an offering of $100 million of debentures, series D, due Oct. 15, 1986,and $200 million of debentures, series D, due Oct. 15, 2009. The offering is underwritten by Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group, the First Boston Corporation, Salomon Brothers, Kidder Peabody & Company and A.E. Ames & Company.

title: About Education
description: My final decision is maybe says one popular legend on sale at souvenir counters. Intended to be funny, it actually describes how many adolescents and perhaps only slightly fewer adults arriveat decisions. While decisionmaking is taught in some special courses for graduate students, there is little, if any, such instruction for undergraduates.

title: Message For The Pope
description: If you know how to reach the Pope, please ask him not to visit the South Bronx and Harlem. I can see the point of view of those in charge of organizing the event. Why should the Pope meet only the rich and powerful? Why visit only the good places? And then, of course, poverty is educational  at least from one point of view, that of the visitor.

title: Rain a Factor in Baltimore
description: Rain in Baltimore hindered the Memorial Stadium grounds crew, the Orioles and the California Angels in preparation for tomorrow night's American League playoff opener. Page B19.

description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1979

title: SCM Challenges Bear, Stearns
description: The SCM Corporation, reacting to an estimate initiated by a dissident shareholders group that the company might be worth as much as $47 a share if liquidated, said yesterday that the evaluation was irresponsible.

title: Taxes
description: ALTHOUGH company reimbursement for employee moving expenses is now considered to be income to employees, this was not always the case. And a recent court decision may have a substantial impact on companies that battled the Internal Revenue Service before the issue was settled the early 1970's.

description: Q. Does ozone stay in a layer miles in the atmosphere?

title: Irish President Calls Visit Inspiration
description: LIMERICK, Ireland, Oct. 1 Pope John Paul II ended his joyous threeday pilgrimage to Ireland today with conservative reaffirmations of the Roman Catholic Church's opposition to abortion, contraception and divorce, then flew off to the United States for a sevenday visit.

description: BOSTON, Oct. 1  Pope John Paul II continued today to sound a spiritual and moral challenge to the values of Western society that he began over the weekend in Ireland.
