title: Screen: James's 'The Europeans,' at Film Festival:In Victoria's Time
description: THOSE were the days  when manners were as fixed as incomes, when a stroll around a perfectly manicured lawn might be as fraught with adventure as a journey over the Aips, and when a glance, untimely exchanged over teacups, could wreck a carefully planned matrimonial liance as effectively as a fatal fever.Well-bred Boston gentlemen, who had been at Harvard, might work at the law. If a gentleman was in trade, he wasn't expected to leave evidences of it around the house, unless they were objets d'art brought back from China. Ladies sewed, played the piano and dipped into a collection of sermons or, to keep abreast of things, a volume of Mr. Emerson's essays. When one spoke of "making love," as one often did, one spoke of the kind of delicate court a gentleman paid a lady in full view of approving society.These things certainly account for much of the charm still held for us by "The Europeans," Henry James's third novel, published in 1878, and one of his most effortlessly masterful, about the tumult caused in the Wentworth household when there appear in their midst two not-quite-forgotten, totally alien, European cousins.The cousins are the formidable, bewitching but not beautiful Eugenia, Baroness Munster, the morganic wife of a German princeling who now wants to ditch her, and Felix, her debonair younger brother, who's a second-rate artist but a first-rate fellow. Eugenia and Felix are the remains of a marriage contracted abroad by Mr. Wentworth's half-sister who, it's explained in the manner of scandal, many years before "turned Roman Catholic and then went to live in Europe."Eugenia, with Felix as her escort, has journeyed to the New World, as her ancestors did two centuries before, to seek her fortune and freedom from a very specific European tyranny.The 19th-century manners recalled by "The Europeans," with its confrontation between old and new cultures, are charming and funny, but the novel is illuminated  and made important  by the beauty and precision of James's prose that persuades us his characters are as alive today as they were in 1878. There's nothing quaint or picturesque or foolish about them. They are battlers.This is the feeling that's missing from the otherwise remarkably intelligent, careful screen version of "The Europeans" that has been adapted with skill by Ruth Prawer Jhabvala and directed with affection by James Ivory, whose earlier collaborations include "Shakespeare Wallah," "The Guru" and "Roseland." Their new film will be screened at the New York Film Festival in Lincoln Center today at 9:30 P.M. and next Sunday at 4:30 P.M. The film begins its regular commercial run here at the Paris Theater next Monday.The achievement of Mr. Ivory and Mrs. Jhabvala is their preservation of so much James, so purely, in what's thought to be a hostile medium. Though the performances range from excellent to barely tolerable, we always hear Henry James even when we don't see him, and when we don't see him it's because of discreet concessions that have been made to the enemy."The Europeans" isn't simply pretty, it's so relentlessly pretty it becomes almost boring to watch. Photographed in New England in autumn, it's the sort of riot of colors I associate with those gigantic Kodak photomurals in Grand Central Terminal. You've never seen so many blazing scarlets, golds, yellows and burnt sienas. One makes allowances for the fact that the film makers were forced to work in the autumn, instead of the green, dozy days of summer that, in the novel, counterpoint the action, those polite but deadly serious campaigns of the heart. Yet so much prettiness eventually works against the characters, the actors and the movie. James was not a landscape artist.The cast is also a mixed bag. Lee Remick, a very good actress and an enchantingly pretty one, has a firm jaw that can stiffen perceptibly but she lacks the hints of steel, authority, selfishness and foreignness that set Eugenia apart from her Boston cousins. She might more believably have come up to visit from New Haven. Robin Ellis, as the most worldly member of the Wentworth circle, a rich businessman who has been to China and the man for whom Eugenia sets her cap, moves and speaks with the proper skepticism but his personality has a way of fading into the landscape as soon as he leaves the screen.Much more successful are the performances of Tim Woodward as Eugenia's free-wheeling, exuberantly good-natured brother, Felix, and Lisa Eichhorn ("Yanks") as the more plain but more sweetly unconventional of the two Wentworth sisters whom Felix woos. They make a delightful couple. Wesley Addy is splendid as the patriarch of the Wentworth clan, as is Helen Stenborg as the resignedly invalid mother of the fellow Eugenia means to marry.It may not be fair to comment on other performances that don't seem to work as well. I've a suspicion that the way in which Mrs. Jhabvala has constructed some of the scenes and the manner in which Mr. Ivory has framed them sometimes undercuts what the actors are doing. The novel is composed of dozens of short scenes that one reads one after another even though they describe simultaneous action, a problem the script attempts to rectify by the kind of cross-cutting one sees in a chase sequence. Instead of creating a single impression, they form a series of tiny anticlimaxes.In scenes involving a number of characters, Mr. Ivory frequently directs our attention with close-ups of individuals, making it impossible for us to enjoy the interplay that is one of the delights of this kind of fiction. Those of us who enjoy James as well as films are old enough to make up our minds about where we want to look.This may well be nit-picking, considering how little James we ever see on the screen. One delights in the film's language, as when Mr. Wentworth says, with extreme gravity, of Felix's wish to paint his portrait, "You see more in a man's face than I should think of looking for." In the same way, some of us in the audience search for more in the images of "The Europeans" than others will ever miss.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Avery International, San Marino, Calif., manufacturer of labeling systems, has named Bernard A. Girod vice presidentplanning and business development.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1979

title: The Doctor's World: Gershwin's Illness
description: GEORGE Gershwin was playing his Concerto in F with the Los Angeles Symphony Orchestra in February 1937 when suddenly his mind went blank. He missed several bars, then recovered sufficiently from the fit to continue playing.

title: Dubious Surgery Reported Found In V.A. Hospital
description: An investigation or me veterans Aaministration Medical Center in Manhattan was said yesterday to have found evidence that some surgery had been performed by junior resident physicianswithout me supervision of senior attending physicians and without the required informed consent of patients.

title: Song: With Bassoonist
description: ANY song cycle that offers a solo bassoonist as accompanist begins with a certain amount of interest in the bank. Pianists, by tradition and mere force of composing habit, have monopolized thesupporting role in vocal recitals tor tne better part of 200 years. There have been exceptions to this tyranny of the keyboardists, however, and Daniel Pinkham joined a comparatively short list with his Transitions, which had its first performance Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Output of Steel Down by 0.3%
description: Production of the nation's steel industry slipped by threetenths of 1 percent last week from the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: OBSERVER The Golden Spouse
description: Everybody is buying gold by the ounce. It is the biggest thing since disco and, since the price is now $400 an ounce, much more expensive.

title: Fireman Dismissed a Day Before Pension Eligibilty
description: A man with 29 years of service with the Fire Department was dismissed yesterday, just one day before he would have become eligible for a pension, on charges of selling answers to a departmentadministered test for welders.

title: Notes on People
description: Striking St. Louis Symphony musicians sent a telegram last week to Mattslay Rostropovich, no doubt mindful that last year he had briefly joined the Washington picket line of fellow musicians against the National Symphony Orchestra  of which the Russianmigr cellist is musical director. The 102 St. Louis players, with whom he had previously performed as soloist, proposed that he do a benefit concert with them for their strike fund.

title: Brazil Is Seeking to Untangle Itself From Red Tape
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 1  Hllo BeItro's formal title is Extraordinary Minister for Debureaucratization, and if he succeeds in his task the adjective will be deserved.

title: Chilean Gas Reserves
description: SANTIAGO, Oct. 1 (Reuters)  The Chilean state oil company, Enap, has discovered new natural gas reserves in southern Chile. President AugustoPinochet said today. When fully developed, the new reserves are expected to be equivalent to 2.64 million barrels of oil a year. Chile now imports about 26 million barrels of oil annually.

title: U.A.W. Seeking Pact With Ford
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Oct. 1 (AP)  The Ford Motor Company presented a contract offer to the United Automobile Workers today, and the union said it seemed to provide a basis for a settlement.

title: Catholics Divided Over Leadership
description: Pope John Paul II has begun a pastoral visit to the Roman Catholic church in the United States, an aggregate of 49 million people sharply divided over many religious issues and looking to the Papacy for many different, often contrasting. forms of leadership.

title: Beech Aircraft Company Holding Merger Talks
description: The Beech Aircraft Company, one of the largest and most profitable members of the general aviation industry, announced yesterday that it was involved in merger negotiations with an unidentified company.

title: Peking Promises Profits On Foreign Investments
description: PEKING, Oct. 1 Peking will guarantee a profit for foreign companies investing in jointventure enterprises in China and will allow them to hire outside managers, engineers and accountants, two ranking Chinese officials have revealed.

title: China Gaining In Science but A Long Road Lies Ahead
description: CANTON AFTER declaring proudly that his factory in Zhang Zhou had turned out 120 million meters of cloth in 2,000 colors, patterns and textures last year, the director, Chiang Yashin, added: But we are still far behind advanced countries in variety and technology.

title: Voice of America Director, a Kennedy Ally, Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  R. Peter Straus, asserting that the Carter White House is hamstrung by a paranoia about a prospective challenge from Senator Edward M. Kennedy, has resigned as director of the Voice of America and is considering supporting the Massachusetts Democrat for President.

title: SixMonth Bills At Record Rate
description: Yields on Treasury bills climbed yesterday, and the average discount rate on sixmonth bills reached a record 10.327 percent as a noticeably small volume of orders were placed for the issue.

title: TV Imports Down 49.7%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) Imports of color television sets during this year's second quarter fell nearly 50 percent from the yearearlier level and were the lowest since early 1977, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Hoechst's Investing to Rise
description: SOMERVILLE, N.J., Oct. 1 (Reuters)  The American Hoechst Corporation, which produces fibers and pharmaceutical and agricultural chemicals, among other things, said today that the Hoechst Group planned to invest $1.14 billion worldwide in 1980, an increase of 21 percent over 1979. The company said about 50 percent would be spent in West Germany.

title: Transcript of President's Speech on the U.S. Response to Soviet Force in Cuba
description: Good evening. I want to talk with you about the subject that is my highest concern, as it has been for every President. That subject is peace and the security of the United States.

title: John Paul II, an Exuberant Philosopher of Many Facets
description: The church has never had a Pope like this man named Karol Wojtyla, this laborer turned actor, this multilingual poet and professor from Cracow, this skier, canoeist and swimmer who just built his own pool, this Slav with the high cheekbones who is, at 59, a good 10 years younger than the usual Pope of this century.

title: MOVE TO LINK PACT AND BRIGADE BEGINS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  A strong move to adopt a reservation stating that the strategic arms treaty cannot come into legal force until the President has certified that the Soviet troops in Cuba have no combat function or represent no threat to the United States appears likely in the Senate following President Carter's speech.

title: Text of Pope John Paul II's Homily at a Mass on Boston Common
description: BOSTON, Oct. 1 (UPI)  Following is the text of Pope John Paul II's homily at a mass today on the Boston Common:

title: Court Sets WorkerSafety Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Federal Government can forbid a private employer from retaliating against a worker who refuses to perform a dangerous job.

title: Dollar Aid Plan Weighed
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 1American and West German monetary officials are studying ways to intensify dollarsupport operations despite growing sentiment expressed at the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank here that little can be done except to try to make the dollar's retreat orderly.

title: Market Place
description: IN the recent stock market rally, many investors have achieved unrealized capital gains, so they would cash in their profits if it were not for the impact of the high income tax on shortterm gains. But investors who grimly decide to hang in there are taking a risk that the profits may dissolve in a falling market.

title: Mistress of Mussolini Told of Her Love at 14
description: ROME, Oct. 1, (Reuters)  Clara Petacci, the mistress of Benito Mussolini, began to bombard the dictator with love letters at the age of 14, according to a book to be published this week.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown.(N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Russell Baker, Lawyer, Dies at 78
description: Russell Baker, the founder and senior partner of Baker & McKenzie, an international law firm based in Chicago, died at his home in Santa Monica, Calif., on Friday. lie was 78 years old and also lived in Lake Bluff. Ill.

title: East Germans Honor Freed Spy
description: EAST BERLIN, Oct 1 (Reuters)  Klaus Fuchs, expelled from Britain in 1959 for spying for the Soviet Union, was today awarded East Germany's highest civilian honor, the Order of Karl Marx. Dr. Fuchs was granted the decoration in recognition of his services to the workers movement, the official press agency reported.

title: Kucinich Facing Crucial Challenge in Primary Today
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 (UPI)  Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich, battling for political survival in Cleveland's mayoral primary election tomorrow, has wrapped up his campaign by characterizing the election as a classic choice between government by men and government by money.

title: Carter Chose His Wife As Best Representative
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  Pope John Paul II was greeted by Rosalynn Carter in Boston today because President Carter considered her to be his most appropriate Personal representative.

title: TV: Chemical Industry Target of 2Hour Nova
description: NOVA, public television's science series, returns tonight with a twohour broadside against the business of toxic chemicals. Produced by Robert Richter, A Plague on Our Children begins on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock.

title: The Region
description: MORRISTOWN (UPI)  Morris School District teachers yesterday approved a twoyear contract that will raise salaries by eight percent the first year, and seven percent the second.

title: Letter: On Military Threats to Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Extension on Bid For Harnischfeger
description: The Mannesmann Machinery Corporation said it had extended the expiration date of its $27.50ashare offer for the Harnischfeger Corporation to Oct. 12 from Oct. 5.

title: Mayor in New Haven Closes a Struck Plant To Forestall Violence
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 1  Mayor Frank Logue shut down the Olin Corporation's industrial and research complex here this morning, a move reported to have infuriated company officials.

title: Tire Industry Facing Setbacks
description: AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 1  The tire industry, shaken by gasoline shortages, declining auto sales and labor troubles, has sustained a body blow that will be a year or more in the healing.

title: Court Overturns a City Law on Licensing
description: A New York City law requiring a license for live performances is an unconstitutional infringent on freedom of expression, a state appeals court has ruled. The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court said the law gave unbrided discretion to the Department of Consumer Affairs, the licensing agency.

title: Puerto Rican Unit Charges Undercount on CETA Funds
description: The National Puerto Rican Forum contends that New York City has lost money through a serious undercount of Hispanic people eligible for funds and services under new Federal rules for the administration of the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Verdi's Otallo, 8.

title: 21 Seized in Times Sq. Street Robberies
description: Twentyone persons, most of them 14 to 17 years old, were arrested after at least six persons were robbed by bands of youths roaming through Times Square just before midnight Sunday.

title: Rainy Prelude to American League Opener
description: Rain fell yesterday on Baltimore's Memorial Stadium, casting some complications on tomorrow's American League playoff: the first ever for the California Angels, the first in five years for the Baltimore Orioles and the first in four years without the New York Yankees.

title: Jesse Jackson Is Met By Sadat, Who Calls His Tour Important
description: CAIRO, Oct. 1  President Anwar elSadat of Egypt received the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson today and described the American civil rights leader's factfinding tour of the Middle East as very important.

title: The Federal Hand in Education
description: By approving the creation of a Department Education, Congress has given President Carter his first major domestic victory of the year. A defeat might have done more for the country and for education. A 13th Cabinet department seems hard to reconcile with Mr. Carter's pledge to streamline and reduce the Washington bureaucracy. That reform, it seems, will have to wait.

title: Giant Rookie Passer Stirs Team Spirit
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 1  It is a club that has lost 12 of its last 13 games, including all five this season. It is a club almost without a defensive line because of injuries. Often it has been a club divided. Now it is Phil Simms's club.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Minuet In G, Paderewski ; Variations on a Noel, Daquin; Ballade In B minor, Brahma; Siciliano, Francoeur.

title: Iran's Oil Chief Pledges Purge
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct.1 (UPI)Iran's new oil chief, All Akbar Moinfar, today pledged a purge of the oil industry as demanded by the clergy, who forced the ouster last week of his predecessor. Hassan Nazih.

title: Article on HBomb Is Made Public by Progressive A Clear and Present Danger
description: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 1  The Progressive magazine today made public the controversial article on hydrogen weapons that it had been restrained from publishing since March by Federal court orders.

title: Pirates Rely on Candelaria
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1  On the floor in the waiting room of the Greater Pittsburgh Airport this morning, John Candelaria was playing with Tim Foli's baby. Candelaria, the Pittsburgh Pirates big lefthander, was waiting for the fog to lift so that he and his teammates could fly to Cincinnati. There, at 8:30 tomorrow night, Candelaria will be on the mound for the opening of the National League playoff against Tom Seaver and the Reds.

title: Pontiff Brings U.S. a Plea for Rededication
description: BOSTON, Oct. 1  Pope John Paul II, exhorting Americans to fulfill completely your noble destiny of service to the world, came to the United States today, beaming at large and affectionate crowds in the streets and urging the nation's youth to accept discipline in place of materialism.

title: Building Down 1.5% In Month
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)  New residential, industrial and Government construction occurred at an annual rate of $229.2 billion in August, a drop of 1.5 percent from the preceding month, the Government said today.

title: EuropeanAmerican Cash
description: EuropeanAmerican Bancorp. said yesterday that its six owners had contributed another $60 million of equity capital, bringing total shareholder equity to $284 million. It added that theneed for added cash resulted from the growth of the holding company's two main subsidiaries, the EuropeanAmerican Bank and Trust Company and the EuropeanAmerican Banking Corporation.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FEELINGS Sterling A. Brown begins the new season's reading series of the Academy of American Poets tonight at 7:30 at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue and 89th Street. Admission is $2, and tickets are available at the door after 7 o'clock.

title: 50 Bucs and 05 Colts Are N.F.L. Surprises
description: For every surprise team in the monthold professional football season, there has been a disappointing one, in one case a disappointment turning into a disaster. The most surprising remains Tampa Bay, while the team going in the opposite direction with the greatest velocity appears to be Baltimore.

title: U.S. Navy Ships Arrive For Caribbean Exercise
description: NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 1 (AP)  Sixteen United States Navy ships arrived in the Caribbean today to begin what the Navy said was a 12day exercise unrelated to the issue of Soviet combat troops in Cuba.

title: Baseball Drew 43.5 Million Fans
description: Major league baseball drew a record total of 43,548,450 fans for the 1979 regular season, the fourth successive year attendance has grown, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's office said yesterday.

title: Firstmark Sells Merchandising Unit
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 1  The Firstmark Corporation said today it had completed the sale of 998 Broadway Inc., a subsidiary operating six Settler's department stores in western New York, to Plapinger Enterprises of Trenton.

title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices Accept Cases on Drug Agents and Informers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The Supreme Court opened its new term today by adding to the already sizable number of criminal law cases it will decide in the next nine months.

title: Lag in Telling of Damage At Reactor to Be Studied
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  Utility and Government experts suspected in the early hours of the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant that the reactor core had already approached a condition in which the uranium fuel could melt and thus sharply increase the danger of a large release of radiation.

title: Around the Nation
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Oct. 1 (AP)  Gov. Bob Graham broke ground today for Disney World's new $800 million EPCOT Center, billed as the largest private construction project in the nation and expected to attract 10 million visitors a year when it opens in 1982.

title: Coleman to Manage Padres
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 1 (AP)  Jerry Coleman, a former second baseman for the New York Yankees and a San Diego broadcaster for the last eight years. was named the Padres manager today. succeeding Roger Craig.

title: Living Well Naturally, Upstate
description: PARADOX, N.Y.  Before the energy situation reached its last peak, my family and I had decided to do something about it for ourselves. Many others have chosen this path, anti ninny will We believe that manymore should seek The Good Life they should go back to the land to live a simpler and less dependent style of life. We are taking measures to halt the gradual annihilation of our planet.and passive solar energy. Before we left, our energy expenses were about $400 per month. Now, they're about $20 per month. Next year we hope our ex

title: Du Pont Asks Bar To F.T.C. Action
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, charging that its rights to free speech had been restrained, filed suit yesterday against the Federal Trade Commission in a bid to block a complaint the agency filed last spring over the pricing of lead antiknock compounds.

title: Stage: The Banana Box, On ApartmentSharing
description: APARTMENTSHARING, like blind dating, can be a situation comedy. People who might not normally meet one another opposites accidently juxtaposed in close quarters  suddenly have important things in common, such as room, breakfast and busybody landlord. That The Banana Box, which opened the season last night at the Hudson Guild Theater, happens to be British, means that the roommates tune in the wireless, have a meal instead of dinner, and pop their shillings into the gas meter. But the territory is as familiar as it is predictable.

title: The City
description: A Federal judge yesterday dismissed a suit by State Sen. Vander L. Beatty to bring about a referendum on a proposal providing for recall of elected city officials.

title: Stocks Retreat Amid Uncertainties
description: The stock market retreated along a broad front yesterday in much slower trading, with some specialsituation issues incurring the biggest losses.

title: Italian Kidnapping Victim Freed
description: MILAN, Italy, Oct. 1 (Reuters)  A kidnapped Italian industrialist who had been held for 10 months was freed today after his family paid a ransom believed to be more than $1.25 million, the policesaid. Friends of the family said that Andrea Zenesini, owner of an electric appliances company, was in fair condition after his release in Piacenza, about 30 miles from his home in Milan where he was abducted last Nov. 28.

title: RollsRoyce: Britain Takes on the Unions
description: DERBY, England  Never before, not in 38 years with RollsRoyce Ltd., had he been idled by a labor dispute, Norman Minifie was saying as he stood picketing outside the low, whitebrickfronted Darts factory.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Dennis P. Long, who started as stock boy at AnheuserBusch Inc. 20 years ago, was elevated yesterday to the new post of president and chief operating officer of the nation's largest brewery. The 43yearold executive, who was formerly vice president and general manager of AnheuserBusch's beer division, will continue to run the company's beer business, which last year hit the 40millionbarrel mark

title: Rhodesians, Black and White, Are Worried
description: UMTALI, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Sept. 28  Optimism, indifference, skepticism, dismay and hope are all found in abdundance among black and white citizens of Zimbabwe Rhodesia, as the leaders of this country  elected and otherwisemeet in London to negotiate its future.

title: Instead of Helping Theft Victims, A Law in Jersey Is Hurting Them
description: NEWARK, Oct. 1  A section of New Jersey's Criminal Code that was supposed to enable theft victims to get back their property faster is instead creating new problems for the victims, who say it is slowing the return.

title: Growing Up in Two Languages With Views of Two Worlds
description: Lauren Rosenberg, Joshua Goldblum and Monica Geula have a lot in common. Each is less than 3 years old. Each is a New Yorker. Each is the child of pp is with no extraordinary foreign language ability. And each is being raised to speak a second language.

description: Deaths

title: CREDIT MARKETS Treasury Yields at New Highs
description: Yields on longterm Treasury bonds climbed yesterday to their highest levels in history, topping the records that were set on May 4, as the credit markets remained in a severe slump.

title: In North End: A Glimpse of Back of a Head
description: BOSTON, Oct. 1  The Italian North End, perhaps the most intensely Roman Catholic section of this most Catholic of all American cities, turned out in force today to greet Pope John Paul II.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANILA, Oct.1  The Catholic Bishops Conference of the Philippines today called on Filipinos not to rely on violence to solve the country's political and economic problems.

description: Draftsmen's Union Strikes General Dynamics Groton Plant

title: Movies of Victory Please Michaels; Pleased With Defense, Too; Jets' Michaels Gives Team Rave Review Getting Closer Griese Finishes Strong What Kicking Game?
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 1  Walt Michaels got up a little late for his usual Monday morning movies today, but the delay did not spoil his viewing. The Jets coach enjoyed what he saw on film of yesterday's 3327 conquest of the Miami Dolphins.

title: 7 Picassos Stolen in Paris
description: PARIS, Oct. 1 (AP)  Seven works by Picasso valued at about $100,000 were stolen Sunday by a robber who attacked the late painter's doctor in his Paris apartment, the police said today. They said the man bound and gagged Dr. J. Jaffe, 85 years old, and escaped with the paintings, which were gifts from Picasso.

title: U.S. Catholics Find Prejudices Waning
description: Christopher Columbus was a Roman Catholic. Another Catholic explorer, Amerigo Vespucci, gave America its name. Catholics of Irish, German, Polish and a variety of other ethnic backgrounds furnished the muscle and sweat and brains to help build an industrial superpower and provided men to fight its wars.
