title: Land, Sea, Air Travel To Let Koch Keep Up
description: For the next two days, Mayor Koch will be driven, flown by helicopter and ferried by police launch to all of the appearances in New York City by Pope John Paul II.

title: DOLLAR PLUMMETS IN HEAVY TRADING
description: The dollar tumbled against key foreign currencies in extremely heavy trading yesterday despite large support purchases by central banks, and gold prices surged to new records in a turbulent market.

title: Kuwait, a Persian Gulf Utopia, Is Adrift in Oil Money
description: KUWAIT  On the lace of it, the prosneritv of Kuwait is dazzling.

title: World Gold
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1979

title: Play on Convent School, AntiCatholic or Not?; In and Around a Convent School
description: LIKE the students in her British comedy hit Once a Catholic, Mary O'Malley attended a convent school for girls in suburban London in the mid50's and recalls feeling fearful but rebellious because the nuns deemed so much in life to be a sin. We were told not to do so many things, we went out and did a few, she remembers.

title: Tourists Who Survived Fire in Vienna Return
description: BOSTON, Oct. 1 (AP)  A group of Maine tourists who survived an Austrian hotel fire in which three of their companions and 22 Europeans died have returned home, tired and worn but unanimous in their praise of their tour director, who lost a daughter in the blaze.

title: Chemical Called Suspect In E.P.A. Cancer Study
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 1 (AP) Some cancer cases under study near an Army base in central Kentucky may be related to a chemical wood preservative used on ammunition boxes, The Louisville CourierJournal reported.

title: Talks Remain Stalled In City Opera Dispute
description: No further negotiations were held yesterday in the contract dispute that has led the New York City Opera to suspend its performances at Lincoln Center, beginning tonight. However, both sides  the opera and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians expressed hope the talks would resume shortly.

title: President Steps Down At American Express
description: The American Express Company, in a toplevel management realignment, yesterday announced the resignation of Roger H. Morley as president, effective Dec. 31, and the appointment of Alva O. Way as vice chairman.

title: It Is a Great Joy for Me,  Pontiff Says of His Visit
description: It is a great joy for me to be in the United States of America to begin my pastoral visit to the Catholic Church in this land, and at the same time to greet all the American people of every race, color and creed.

title: October Work for Seaver
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 1  For the first time since 1973 and for the second time since 1989, Tom Seaver is pitching when he most wants to pitch  in October. Tomorrow night the 34yearold righthander will open theNational League championship series for the Cincinnati Reds against the Pittsburgh Pirates, justas he twice started the first game of the playoffs for the New York Mets in the years before they leased lastplace. The opportunity to pitch in october, of course, was one reason why Tom Seaver was willing to be traded to the Reds during the 1977 season.

title: Backing Pact, He Says Atom War, Not Troop Issue, Is Bigger Threat
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  President Carter announced a series of measured political and military steps today to offset the presence of Soviet troops in Cuba, and he appealed to the Senate not to let the troop issue block approval of the nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: Poppycock Is Winner At Belmont
description: Poppycock, a filly who had not won since a triumph last June on a fast track, prevailed by a bead on a sloppy one yesterday in capturing the $87,450 Athenia Handicap in a driving rain at Belmont Park.

title: CIVILIAN PRESIDENT INSTALLED IN NIGERIA
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 1  Ending more than 13 years of military rule of Nigeria, black Africa's richest and most populous nation, a civilian President took office today and pledged to work for national unity and economic selfsufficiency.

title: Fouling the Budget to Clean the Streets
description: Mayor Koch and Sanitation Commissioner Norman Steisel have the right idea: New York City's streets are dirty when they should be clean. Therefore,they want to add 562 sanitation workers to a streetsweeping force that has been cut in half in recent years. The defect in the Mayor's plan is that this would surely leave the budget messier, without, as past experience with a larger sweeping force teaches, assuring cleaner streets.

title: Use of Reattached Arm Is Seen
description: A 30yearold Brooklyn woman whose arm was severed in an accident at Coney Island last week will be able to use the limb in about a year, the surgeon who reattached the arm said yesterday. Thewoman, Eileen Fitzgerald 01 185 Marine Avenue in the Bay Ridge section, had her left arm severed above the elbow when car driven by a 79yearold man who blacked out went into a counter area at Nathan's restaurant in Coney Island.

title: IN THE NATION The Amtrak Paradox
description: In June, thanks mostly to long lines at the gasoline pump, Amtrak ridership rose 24 percent over that of June 1978, to a total of 2,050,000. It was the first month in the system's brief history that it had carried more than two million passengers. About this, two paradoxes might be noted:

title: Lower Miscarriage Risk From Post'73 Abortions
description: BOSTON, Oct. 1 (AP)  Women who have abortions conducted with the latest medical techniques face little or no risk of suffering unusual numbers. of miscarriages in later pregnancies, a study shows.

title: Art Store Bookkeeper Is Robbed Of $7,365 on the Way to L.I. Bank.
description: GREAT NECK, L.I. (UPI)  A bookkeeper for a Great Neck art supply store was roughed up yesterday afternoon and robbed of $7,365 of her employer's funds as she was taking the money to a nearby hank

title: Friends Attend 3Hour Funeral for Last of Tolstoy's 13 Children
description: VALLEY COTTAGE, N.Y., Oct. 1 Life is only a dream, Alexandra Tolstoy used to quote her father, Leo, as saying. Death is an awakening.

title: 10 Holy Days for Jews End With Yom Kippur
Advertising
description: JOEL W. HARNETT is returning to the consumer magazine field, something he's been away from since he left the original Look magazine in 1968. That doesn't mean he's been away from print entirely since then. Hardly; he's been busy as a bird dog in the business press field, building a list of 10 titles. And, like a number of those, his new consumer magazine will have a communicationsfield thrust.

title: Speak From the Heart on Nuclear Risk
description: Is the Presidential commission investigating the Three Mile Island nuclear accident going to duck the hottest issue of all? Insiders say it has tentatively concluded that fundamental changes are needed in the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and in the nuclear industry. That may well be true  and worth saying. But it does not address the issue that is agitating the public.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Sarah Caldwell, founder and artistic director of the Opera Company of Boston, has been named music director of Wolf Trap Farm Park for the Performing Arts in Vienna, Va., near Washington. It is a new post, and Miss Caldwell will be responsible for programming opera, dance, symphony and chamber music for the park's summer festival. She will also conduct concerts and operas.

title: About New York
description: When Pope John Paul II sets foot in New York today, his first steps will be in the curious borough of Queens, the eastern march of the big city that seems at once so near and yet, in point of mind. so remote from it. Imagine, if you can: President Carter at Queens College last week and a Pope at Shea Stadium this week. The image of Queens as something merely to pass through en route elsewhere is fading.

title: Kennedy Visits Shooting Victim
description: BOSTON, Oct. 1 (AP)  After bowing to Pope John Paul II at Logan International Airport, Senator Edward M. Kennedy comforted a black football player paralyzed from the neck down as a resultof a shooting. Darryl Williams, 15, remains in critical condition. Three white youths have been arrested in the shooting. Mr. Kennedy was accompanied by his wife, Joan, and his daughter Kara, 19, and son Patrick, 12. All met the injured boy's mother, Shirley Simmons.

title: Frederic Most Costly Of All U.S. Hurricanes
description: PASCAGOULA, Miss., Oct. 1 (UPI)  Hurricane Frederic was the most costly storm ever to strike the United States, according to insurance adjusters.

title: Life's Dream Fulfilled For California Couple
description: BOSTON, Oct. 1 (AP)  Tom Tobin, a 23yearold California man who became paralyzed from the waist down in a car crash three years ago, used his insurance settlement to fulfill his parents lifelong dream to see the Pope.

title: Panama Takes Control of Canal Zone
description: PANAMA, Oct. 1  Amid fireworks, bands and blaring car horns, Panama took control today of the Canal Zone, which for the past 76 years has been the exclusive home of the Americans who operate and defend the Panama Canal.

title: Soviet Reported Worried Over Carter's TV Speech
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 1  A private American group that was received today at the Soviet Foreign Ministry reported tremendous concern on the part of officials about what President Carter would say in his report on the Cuban situation.

title: Frederick Nossal, 51
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  Frederick Nossal, a public affairs official for the World Bank, died in Belgrade, Yugoslavia on Saturday after falling from a window of his hotel bedroom. He was 51 years old and had been leading a Dress tour ofdevelopment project in Yugoslavia. A spokesman for the bank in Washington said it had not yet learned the exact circumstances of the death.

title: Brezhnev Is Said to Plan Policy Speech in Berlin
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 1 (Reuters)  President Leonid I. Brezhnev of the Soviet Union will make a major foreign policy speech in East Berlin on Saturday that is likely to include Moscow's response to the United States in the dispute over Soviet troops in Cuba, it was reliably reported here today.

title: Fascination and Prices for Netsuke Carvings Boom
description: TOKYO BEFORE the Japanese began to adopt Western garb for everyday wear in the early part of this century, the welldressed man carried a small purse suspended from his kimono sash by a braided silkcord to which an eggsized carved figure, usually of ivory or wood, was attached at the free end as a protective guard or toggle. The ornaments, called netsuke, disappeared from use decades ago, along with the purses they adorned, as suit pockets rendered the accessory superfluous.

title: WildHorse Roundup Begins on Idaho Range
description: CLAYTON, Idaho, Oct. 1 (AP)  Small herds of horses ran ahead of a Government helicopter today at the start of a longdelayed and controversial wildhorse roundup in the desolate mountains of central Idaho.

title: Officials Show Religion Is Not the Obstacle of 60
description: BOSTON, Oct. 1  When Senator Edward M. Kennedy bowed slightly at the waist and, before millions of television viewers, kissed the ring of Pope John Paul II this afternoon, it was a vivid confirmation of changes that have taken place in American political lifesince 1960, when the prospects of a Roman Catholic President raised widespread fears of papal control of the White House.

title: Bridge
description: Tournaments in New York City are almost invariably in Manhattan, but there is one current exception. It is not, as one might expect, in Brooklyn, which was home to a popular tournament in the 1950's, nor in Queens, nor in the Bronx, but in Staten Island.

title: Books: Hess and the Munich Revolt
description: WERE it not for Rebecca West's introduction, one would be inclined to dismiss a book that that maintains that Rudolf Hess, Hitler's deputy and last of the Nuremberg trial prisoners. is an imposter. The Four Powersstill guard the 85yearold Hess in Spandau Prison. By now he is a symbol more than an individual. The author of The Murder of Rudolf Hess is a British physician who examined the prisoner and found that his appearance did not check out against his medical history. Dr. Thomas builds up a case that is tantalizing but not quite convincing.

title: Today's New York Itinerary
description: Following is today's itinerary for Pope John Paul II. Times are approximate, with late changes possible. Letters alongside items refer to map.

title: U.S. Calls Ruling Disappointing
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  The Justice Department said today that the ruling of the Chilean Supreme Court was most disappointing and added: We will study the decision and consult with the State Department in regard to it.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 1 (AP)  The Boeing Company and All Nippon Airways, Japan's largest domestic airline, announced today an agreement for the All Nippon to buy up to 40 of Boeing's new 767 aircraft at a value of $1.5 billion.

title: Faulkner Memorabilia Is Shown in Missouri
description: A sampling of William Faulkner memorabilia, including inscribed books, unpublished manuscripts and legal documents, is being shown for the first time, starting today, at the University Museum of Southeast Missouri State University in Cape Girardeau.

title: Money
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1979

title: PovertyPanel Voting Delay Tied to Agency Friction
description: Friction at the top levels of the city's Community Development Agency may have had as much to do with the cancellation of last month's elections for antipoverty boards as the reason the agency gave: problems with the delivery of voting macnines to the polling places.

title: Pontiff Hailed for Vision Of. justice in the World
description: Your Holiness. We welcome you to our country with love.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, Oct. 1, 1979

title: Furs Take New Shapes And Patterns
description: With two major furriers parading their collections on the same day, the wellheeled customers who get the frontrow seats at shows were having a bit of a predicament the other day declaring their loyalties.

title: Tanaka Seems Sure of Winning Seat in Japan's Parliament Again
description: SANJO, Japan, Sept. 26  Kakuei Tanaka goes into a crowd with whitegloved fists out, crossing one hand over the other as he reaches for more flesh.

title: Koreans Find New York Is a Place of Opportunity
description: A group of KoreanAmerican dissidents staged a protest rally last month in front of the Park Avenue offices of the South Korean Consul General. The weather was sunny and the issue was hot  a recent wellpublicized police action by the South Korean Government.

title: Church Shows Growing Interest in Hispanic Americans
description: After decades of feeling like outsiders in their own churches, Hispanic Americans are beginning to receive more attention from the Roman Catholic hierarchy in this country.

title: Meadowlands Reveal A Treasure Of Lady Bugs
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. IN a parking lot at Giants Stadium, George Angalet, a 62yearold research entomologist, leaned over, grasped a branch of a small scotch pine and spread apart its needles to show a visitor the cluster of tiny scarletcloaked animals that nestled beneath them.

title: EDUCATION Medical Schools Try Out New Test
description: A recent college graduate is hired as the assistant to the local commissioner of health, who hands him a demographic report showing that the proportion of elderly people in the community is curiously below that of the state as a whole. Look at this and tell me if we have a public health problem, says the commissioner.

title: Pacific Phone In Tax Dispute
description: The Pacific Telephone Company of San Francisco said yesterday that the Internal Revenue Service had assessed the company more than $89 million in additional taxes for 1974.

title: Hollander to Be Soloist With American Symphony
description: Lorin Hollander will be the soloist in a concert by the American Symphony Orchestra on Sunday at Carnegie Hall. Sergiu Comissiona, who joined the company as music adviser last year, will conduct the first in a Sunday afternoon series by the orchestra.

title: 2 Men Shot to Death
description: Two men were found shot to death last night in a late model car in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn and short time later there was an exchange of gunfire nearby between an offduty Housing Authority police officer and two suspects in the killings, the police said.

title: Rhodesian Troops End Mozambique Incursion
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Oct. 1  Zimbabwe Rhodesian troops withdrew from Mozambique today, ending a fiveday operation against what a military spokesman called the main logistics base for Robert Mugabe's wing of the Patriotic Front guerrillas.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY OCTOBER 3, 1979

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: BARON  Benlamin. Congregation Beth Sholom of Lawrence, L.1. records with deep sorrow the untimely passing of our esteemed memberBenlamin Baron.

title: Firemen Suspend Slowdown
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 2 (UPI)  Firefighters have averted a confrontation with the city over working hours by agreeing to resume negotiations and suspending a work slowdown set for early today. decision, by Local 42 of the International Association of Firefighters, followed a lastminute offer from the city.

title: Topics
description: The sad story of the seven Russian Pentecostals reads like a fable from the pen of Nikolai Gogol, once the scourge of czarist bureaucracy. For 15 months, these pious dissidents have been in asylum in the American Embassy in Moscow. They want to leavethe Soviet Union; the Russians apparently want them to leave; but first there is the paper work.

title: Raytheon And Beech To Merge
description: WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 2  The Beech Aircraft Corporation, one of the country's largest manufacturers of general aviation aircraft, announced today that it had agreed to merge with the Raytheon Company, a diversified manufacturer of electronic equipment, military hardware, kitchen appliances and other products.

title: Pakistan Agency Blocks 2 Biggest Political Units
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Oct. 2 (Reuters)  Pakistan's two largest political groups, including the Pakistan People's Party of former Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto, who was executed, were effectively banned today from contesting next month's general election.

title: Baden, at a National Conference, Wins the Praise of His Colleagues
description: SNOWMASS, Colo., Oct. 2  Dr. Michael M. Baden, who was demoted earlier this year from Chief Medical Examiner of New York City to Deputy Chief when Mayor Koch declined to reappoint him, was praised today at a conference of his colleagues here.

title: A City Opens Its Heart To John Paul
description: Nasza Modlitwa Z Papiezem (Our Prayer Is With the Pope), read the Polishlanguage banners and badges, whether from Westchester County or Waukegan, III. Totus Tuus Papa (I Am All Yours, Pope), otherbanners promised in Latin.

title: High School Students Back Coaches Refusal to Work
description: Tens of thousands of high school students took to the streets yesterday in support of a job action by coaches that has sharply reduced competitive sports in New York City high schools.

title: Muting the BBC
description: A visitor from Thailand was recently asked if he took seriously the news reports of the Voice of America and the British Broadcasting Company. It's sometimes the only way we find out what's happening in our own courts and police stations, he replied. A Voice broadcast, he recalled, provided the first information that an international panel of Jurists was inquiring into alleged human rights violations in Thailand.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Project Under Way To Save the Muskies
description: An effort to increase the muskelunge population in the St. Lawrence River is being undertaken by the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Guards Break Up a Protest at Iranian Premier's Office
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 2 (Reuters)Islamic Revolutionary Guards fired into the air outside Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan's office today to scatter hundreds of demonstrators demanding work.

title: A Special Grace
description: At St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, Pope John Paul II said he considered it a special grace to be able to return to New York. To millions who saw and heard him, he was the one who brought a special grace to New York. The visit of any pope would bring out the curious in swarms, but there is an unusual magnetism in this pontiff's sturdy warmth and complexitv.

title: Abuse Cited In Minority Program
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  The Small Business Administration reported today that about one out of five companies it assisted under one of its projects appeared to be controlled by people other than the disadvantagedminority owners for which the program was intended.

title: Buffalo Herd Still at Large
description: HEUVELTON, N.Y. Oct. 2Duane Storie's home here is just 20 miles from Canton, the birthplace of the Western artist, Frederick Remington. And for the last five days, this rural upstate community has looked like a scene from one of his paintings.

title: Carter Says He Feels Soviet Will Alter Brigade in Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  President Carter, encouraged by what he regards as a mild initial reaction from Moscow to his speech last night, says he thinks that over time the Soviet Union may change the combat nature of its brigade in Cuba.

title: Release of Secret Weapons Data Traced to Neglect of Safeguards
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI)  The neglect of normal safeguards by overworked Government reviewers resulted in the mistaken release of secret data on nuclear weapons, Congressional testimony disclosed today.

title: Blacks and Jews Ending `Silence in New Rochelle
description: NEW ROCHELLE, Oct. 2  The resignation of Andrew Young as the United States Representative to the United Nations has provided an unexpected occasion for some blacks and Jews here to discuss their differences, ending what one community leader called a decade of silence.

title: 2 Reported Indicted In Fatal Race Crash
description: MILAN, Italy, Oct. 2 (AP)  An Italian driver and the starter of the 1978 Grand Prix of Italy automobile race have been indicted for the accident in which Ronnie Peterson, the Swedish ace, was fatally injured, reliable Milan court sources reported today.

title: Bird Scores 19 as Celtics Turn Back 76ers, 11798
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 2 (AP) Larry Bird scored 19 points and six teammates scored in double figures tonight as the Boston Celtics downed the Philadelphia 76ers, 11798, in a National Basketball Association exhibition game.

title: A Guide to the City's Specialized Libraries
description: FEW New Yorkers realize that spread across their city, in clubhouses, schools and institutions, are more than 800 special libraries: oases where hobbyists, students and the inquisitive can satisfy their curiosity in fields ranging from primitive medicine to Japanese flower arranging. A number of these libraries have expanded overthe years as parts of organizations and clubs. Others result from various individuals great interest in particular subjects.

title: The Lore Of Italian Monastic Cuisine; Cipolle Ripieno alla Plemontose (Stuffed onions); Pasta Pimonto (Red peppers with green pasta); Posto; Uova Filanti (Eggs filanti); Pesche Ripiene alle Ostie (Peaches stuffed with macaroons and haxlenuts); Agnello alla Moda di Scanno (Lamb in wine and rosemary)
description: SAVINA ROGGERO brushed aside her wavy red hair, gave the soup pot another stir, and began talking about her first visit to an Italian monastery, which was a year ago.

title: Bulls Release Boerwinkle, Ending Comeback Effort
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP)  The Chicago Bulls of the National Basketball Association have released 34yearold Tom Boerwinkle, ending his attempt at a comeback.

title: Times Completes TV Deal
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had completed the cash purchase of KFSMTV, a National Broadcasting Company affilate operating Channel 5 in Fort Smith, Ark. Title was transferred from Buford Television Inc. to Times Broadcasting Inc., A subsidiary of The New York Times Company. Earlier this year, the Federal Communications Commission approved the transfer of the VHF channel's license.

title: Rhodesia Military Acknowledges An Attack on Mozambique Dam
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Oct. 2 (UPI)  The military command acknowledged today that warplanes and demolition experts attacked a dam in Mozambique last month in its war against nationalist guerrillas.

title: TriStar Squeezes Lockheed Earnings
description: The Lockheed Corporation announced yesterday that its beleaguered TriStar program had run into more trouble and was creating a squeeze on earnings.

title: Money
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1979

title: Obituary 8  No Title
description: Deadths

title: Pakistan Takes Lead
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 2 (AP)  Pakistan took a 21 lead over South Korea in the Eastern Zone of the 1980 Davis Cup tennis competition today. Saeed Meer and Nadir All Khan beat the Korean doubles team of Chon Young Bae and Chon Chang Dae, 26, 64, 26, 63, 62. Pakistan needs to win one of the two remaining singles matches tomorrow to advance to the next round.

title: Advertising
description: IT is nice to know that while all around us advertising folks seem to be adopting a blind dependence on broadcastrating data for decision making, a man who has grown up with the research industry during the last half century says, Remember, ratings are only estimates.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Concerto Grosso No. 1, A. Scarlatti; Besse Danses, Susato; Legende, Wieniawski ; Impromptu, Roussel.

title: EARNINGS Parker Pen Net Up 55% In Quarter
description: The Parker Pen Company reported yesterday that it had achieved profit increases of 55 percent for the second fiscal quarter and 41 percent for the halfyear ended Aug. 31, reflecting gains made by most of its products plus the exceptional performance of its Manpower temporaryhelp susidiary.

title: News of the Theater Singer Play Due on Broadway
description: AFTER a long, delayed journey that began in Minneapolis 16 months ago, Teibele and Her Demon will arrive on Broadway this winter. The play, inspired by a short story by Isaac Bashevis Singer, was written by Mr. Singer and Eve Friedman. It will open in December at the Brooks Atkinson.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Some food experts recommend blending flour and butter in a sa ucepan and adding milk when preparing a white sauce. Others recommend bringing milk to the boil while adding a blend of butter and flour to the milk. To prevent the floury taste of a sauce, wouldn't it be better to start by cooking the butter and flour in the beginning?

title: A Skin Bank for Burn Victims
description: HOUSTON Burn specialists long ago stopped limiting the phrase skin deep with the word only. They are in the process of conducting a nationwide campaign to alert the rest of us to the value of the precious few thousandths of an inch that envelop our bodies.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as sham. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: TV: Miss York in Debut
description: SUSANNAH YORK, making her television debut tonight, demonstrates how an actress of skill and strength can transcend a production that stays right down at the usual rockbottom level of the medium. The madefortelevision film, The Golden Gate Murders, will be shown from 9 to 11 o'clock tonight on CBS.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Tells U.N. That Only Safeguarding Rights Can Insure Peace
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 2  In the great domed hall of the General Assembly, Pope John Paul II solemnly urged applauding representatives of the world's secular states today to sustain the human rights of all people.

title: SOVIET FORCE ON ISLE PROTESTED BY JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Oct. 2 Japan made a protest to the Soviet Union today about a reported Russian military buildup on a strategic island off northern Japan.

title: Joseph Gavrin, ChildCare Official
description: Joseph B. Gavrin, executive director or the New York State Council of Child Care Agencies, died yesterday morning while commuting from his home in Tarrytown, N.Y., to his office in Manhattan. He was 61 years old.

title: SENATE DEEPLY SPLIT ON CARTER'S SPEECH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  President Carter's words and actions on the issue of Soviet troops in Cuba left the Senate deeply divided today over what it should and would do about the strategic arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: EUROPEANS DUBIOUS ON CUBA TROOP ISSUE
description: PARIS, Oct. 2  For the first time, Europeans appear to be starting to take the issue of Soviet troops in Cuba seriously, but as essentially a domestic American political crisis rather than an international crisis.

title: Girl, 3, Found Drowned in Bathtub
description: A 32yearold woman drowned her 3yearold daughter in the bathtub of their home at 174 68th Street, in the Bay Ridge section of. Brooklyn, late Monday night, then tried to end her own life by slashing herself with a razor blade, according to the police.

title: Labor Officials Cite Concessions In Wage Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  Labor officials said today that the Carter Administration had made a series of unannounced concessions to help win the support of union leaders for its new wage and price guidelines. One such concession, they said, was an agreement not to use sanctions against offenders.

title: 13,000 Police Guard `Shepherd on Visit
description: From the time Shepherd landed in Algiers and until he retired for the night at Venice, a group of about 50 police officers and supervisors, working in an area that resembled the war room at an Army headquarters, kept close watch yesterday over the activities of Pope John Paul II and the police assigned to protect him  and, for that matter. over everyone else in the city.

title: Train in 30 M.P.H. Zone Derails at 78 M.P.H.
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 2 (AP)  A speeding Amtrak passenger train derailed in west Lawrence before dawn today, killing two crewmen and injuring 69 other persons aboard.

title: Needed: Inexpensive Hotels Here
description: I am not the chairman of the City Planning Commission, nor the president of the Convention and Visitors Bureau New York, nor the head of the Office of Economic Development, but I have a proposal to make that  with apologies my esteemed colleagues in city government  touches on the business of each of these gentlemen. I am suggesting, this year of inflation 1979, inexpensive hotels for New York City. I make this suggestion as an experienced traveler, one who still likes to go and stay cheaply when I can.

title: Soviet Press Says Carter Heightens Tension Over the Cuba Troop Issue
description: Moscow, Oct.2  The Soviet Union today attacked President Carter's decision to bolster American military strength in the Caribbean as contributing to a heightening of international tension.

title: Lawrence P. Bruenn, Was Head of a Service In Field of Investments
description: Lawrence Philip Bruenn, president of Business Health Inc., a financial and investment advisory service, died Monday at his home in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 75 years old.

title: Around the Nation
description: By The Associated Press

title: Father and Son Are Slain in Car In Coney Island
description: A Brooklyn man and his son, both said to be members of the organizedcrime family of the late Carlo Gambino, were shot to death late Monday night in the front seat of a car parked in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, the police reported.

title: Leaders of Dioceses in the Metropolitan Area
description: When the Rev. Terence James Cooke was secretary to his predecessor, Francis Cardinal Spellman in 1957, he learned a lesson. You can't say yes to everything, he quoted Cardinal Spellman as having told him. But whenyou say yes, say it quickly. But take a half hour to say no, so you can show your sympathy for the other fellow's side.

title: Senate Inquiry Says Atom Agency Misled Public on Three Mile Island
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  Senate investigators said today that seven hours after the Nuclear Regulatory Commission had strong indications that the core of the Three Mile Island reactor had been seriously damaged it handed out a misleading press release and incorrectly informed the White House that there never was a problem with regard to keeping the core covered.

title: Mets Rehire Torre for One Year
description: Joe Torre, after a friendly contract stalemate with the New York Mets for most of the season, was rehired yesterday as manager for another season. The team has finished last three years in a row.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: YOUR CHANCE Amateur musicians eager to polish their talent with ensemble playing are invited to attend tonight's openhouse meeting of Chamber Music Associates, now beginning its 29th season as the city's oldest inde, pendent workshop for pianists and string players. The group will be meeting every Wednesday through June 1, with members forming trios, quartets and quintets, supervised by professional artists.

title: Talk About Dollar Plan Buffets Gold
description: Gold bullion prices and currency values fluctuated wildly in hectic trading on world markets yesterday in response to rumors that the United States might announce strong measures to support the value of the dollar.

title: Music: Ormandy's 44th
description: IT was a nice, oldfashioned program that Eugene Ormandy brought to Carnegie Hall last night with his Philadelphia Orchestra. It was the orchestra's first New York concert of the season. It wasthe 44th year of Mr. Ormandy's tenure. And it also marked the beginning of his last season as music director of the great orchestra. After over four decades, Mr. Ormandy is calling it quits, to be succeeded by the young Riccardo Muti.

title: Pirates Win in 11 on Stargell Homer
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 2  Willie Stargell, the 38yearold hero of the Pittsburgh Pirates and the senior man on the field, was just trying to concentrate tonight when he went to bat in the 11th inning of the first game of the playoff for the National League pennant.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1979

title: OilTax Proposal Trimmed Further
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  The Senate Finance Committee continued to chip away today at the amount of revenue to be raised by President Carter's windfall profits tax on oil, although the erosion was not as large as it might have been.

title: Do What F.D.R. Did
description: While the rest of America mocked New York City for its profligacy, little attention was paid to the fact that the forces driving the city toward bankruptcy were doing the same to the United States. But the possibility ofbankruptcy does not exist for America since the Treasury can, and does, always print money. In reality, the United States debts are continually stretched out, to be repaid in the future with currency worth less and less. Economists call this inflation  a polite word for gradual bankruptcy.

title: NBC a Close 2d to ABC in TV Ratings
description: ABCTV resumed its winning ways in the television audiencepopularity contest last week, but what was notable in the national Nielsen report issued yesterday was NBCTV's strong showing for the second straight week of the new season. ABC led in the averages by only threetenths of a ratings point.

title: Gas Prices in Northeast Differ by Up to 25 Cents
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 (AP) A listing of estimated maximum retail gasoline prices for seven Northeastern cities by the United States Department of Energy shows the highest estimated retail price for premium unleaded gas at $1.20 a gallon in Buffalo and the lowest at $1.05 in Newark.

title: Carter Offers Privacy Bill On Credit and Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  The Carter Administration sent to Congress today legislative proposals aimed at increasing privacy safeguards for millions of Americans holding insurance policies or using credit cards.

title: Traffic Is Lighter Than Usual in Manhattan
description: Traffic was somewhat lighter than usual in the city yesterday as thousands of New Yorkers apparently heeded warnings to leave their cars at home to avoid traffic Jams because of the visit of Pope John Paul II.

title: 6 Killed in Nepal Bus Crash
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Oct. 2 (UPI)  A crowded bus overturned and fell 200 feet down a mountain cliff west of Katmandu, killing six persons and injuring 23, the national news agency reported today. The accident occurred near Banepa, 16 miles west of Katmandu.

title: World Gold
description: TUESDAY. OCTOBER 2, 1979

title: U.S. to Study Motor Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)  The Treasury Department said today that it was investigating whether industrial electric motors imported from Japan were being sold at less than fair value in the United States.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Alan J. Hirschfield, 44 years old, was named vice chairman and chief operating officer of the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation yesterday, and C. Joseph LaBonte, 40, was named president.

title: Hostility Breaks Into the Open at Talks on Rhodesia
description: LONDON, Oct. 2  Hostility that had been simmering beneath the surface at the Zimbabwe Rhodesia constitutional conference broke into the open today, as the two sides traded angry words.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: I KNOW you've heard all about the raptures of stirfrying vegetables in a wok . . . just a drop of oil .. rapid cooking . . . all the nutrients preserved. But chances are, if you're like many people of my acquaintance, you still haven't acquired a wok and have survived without one.

title: A Champion of Tea Crowned in Britain
description: AMBLESIDE, ENGLAND BRONWEN NIXON makes the best cup of tea in England not to mention scones, jams, crumpets, treacle tarts and gingerbread. That is the verdict, solemnly pronounced last week by a panel of judges, in a teatime competition of some 100 tea rooms, restaurants and hotels throughout England. The competition, cosponsored by the English Tourist Board and a London tea company, was aimed at restoring tea to the preeminent position it held two decades ago, before it was engulfed by a tidal wave of instant coffee and orange squash.

title: 60Minute Gourmet; Supreme de Volaille aux Poivrons (Chicken breasts with peppers)
description: ONE of the quiet but important advances of the presentday kitchen in the United States is the availability of readyboned chicken breasts in the nation's supermarkets. Twenty years ago it was necessary to ask your butcher to perform this task and some butchers would respond with a bit of irritability and hesitation. Boneless chicken breasts are, of course, a great boon to any cook with two hands on a saucepan and one eye on the clock. The cooking must be done quickly to avoid a dry, unpalatable taste.

title: House Balks at Ending Recess to Take Up Fund Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)  House members today refused to cut short their vacation to consider a Senate measure that would enable the Government to pay its bills and also revoke a pay increase for Congress and top Federal employees.

title: Careers
description: EVERYBODY likes to have a peek at tomorrow. Recently, to celebrate its 25th anniversary as a management consulting concern, the Diebold Group focused on what managers would be like a quarter of a century hence. Its findings were presented in a report and in a discussion.

title: TV: Mamet's A Life in the Theater
description: REPEATING the roles they created on an Off Broadway stage in 1977, Ellis Rabb and Peter Evans can be seen tonight at 9 on WNETTV, Channel 13, in David Mamet's A Life in the Theater. Using only two characters, theplay conjures up a funny, touching, searing portrait of that special egoobsessed specimen, the actor.

title: BorgWarner Offers New Motor Control
description: The BorgWarner Corporation says it has a new line of electronic devices for controlling the speed of alternatingcurrent motors. Its announcement yesterday added another twist to the debate over the Exxon Corporation's as of the Reliance Electric ComPany.

title: Letters
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Paraplegic Fan Convicted Of Creating Fire Hazard
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 2 (UPI) Thomas Turner, a paraplegic Baltimore Orioles fan, was convicted today of having created a fire hazard at Memorial Stadium by blocking an aisle with his wheelchair to protest what he felt was inadequate seating for the handicapped.

title: The City
description: Justice Burton B. Roberts of State Supreme Court in Manhattan acted too quickly when he awarded former Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan a taxfree pension of $42,500 a year in 1978, an appeals court ruled.

title: RangerIslander Tie Dominated by Fights
description: In case anybody needed to be reminded, the New York Rangers and New York Islanders do not like each other. The teams met in a memorable sixgame Stanely Cup semifinal series last May and they collided again at Madison Square Garden last night with an intensity seldom seen in preseason games. In the process of playing to a 11tie, they collected 70 minutes in penalties, staged three major fights and put four players out of the game, three on injuries and one on a penalty.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1979

title: In Harlem, a Visitor Talks of Joy and Hope
description: Against a backdrop of grimeencrusted buildings, Pope John Paul II brought words of spiritual uplift and rejoicing to the people of Harlem yesterday. In return, thousands of faithful and those barren of faith alike shed their ghetto armor and enveloped him with affection.

title: Text of Pope's Speech in South Bronx
description: Praise to Jesus Christ. Praise Jesus Christ.My dear brothers and sisters. One of the visits to which I attribute great importance and to which I wish I could dedicate more time is precisely the one I am making to the South Bronx.

title: Chess:
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation Tournament, being filmed in London for a series of television programs to be presented in January, has eight grandmasters divided into two sections.

title: Entertainment Events
description: DOOG'S HAMLET, CAHOOT'S MACBETH, a comedy by Tom Stoppard. Directed by Ed Berman; performed by the British American Repertory Company, at n Steps Theater, Broadway and 48th Street, 7.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS The Next Depression
description: For the excellent reason that the stock market has, for several years, been in the doldrums, anniversary freaks need not fear a replay of 1929, the Great Crash. These days the speculative action centers on gold and silver.

title: Marriage Announcement 1  No Title
description: Bruce Garrison Weds Elizabeth A. Westcott

title: Schwartz, Key Aide to Mayor, Stirs a Mixture of Politics and Law
description: One recent afternoon, Mayor Koch leaned back in the easy chair in his office and explained how close he was to Allen G. Schwartz, the city's Corporation Counsel.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Tales That Reach the High Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  Opening day of the Supreme Court term is a cross between a blitz and the first day of school.

title: Kyoto Is Losing Radical Image In Japan Voting
description: KYOTO, Japan, Oct. 2  Polite phrases in a feminine voice, enormously magnified by a loudspeaker in a small sedan, drowned out the lowkey sound of conversation and shuffling feet on Teapot Lane, a narrow street of ceramic shops and curio stands that leads uphill to Kiyomizu, the 17thcentury Buddhist temple complex overlooking the ancient city of Kyoto.

title: China Reports It Has Found Jobs For 4 Million Unemployed Youths
description: PEKING, Oct. 2 (UPI)  China has found jobs for four million unemployed young people and hopes to place nearly as many more by the end of this year, The China News Service said today.

title: A Tradition Set by Paul VI Continues
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 2In calling today for stronger efforts on behalf of human rights, Pope John Paul II gave dramatic witness to the rise in importance of the issues of justice within the Roman Catholic Church in recent years.

title: Weaver a Salesman With Winning Pitch
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 2  A baseball statistic that has somehow escaped inclusion in the record books tells us that in January 1965 Earl S. Weaver sold 23 new automobiles in Elmira, N.Y. The fact that he was manager of the Elmira team that had won the Eastern League pennant may have helped him in his offseason work, but his line of pattermust have been as persuasive then as the Baltimore Orioles find it now.

title: U.S. May Increase Gold Sales
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 2  The United States Government, weighing new plans to stabilize the dollar on exchange markets, suggested today that it might increase the amount of gold it offers at monthly auctions and that it was considering the possibility of internationally coordinated bullion sales.

title: GOVERNORS IN SOUTH REJECT 80 WARNING
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 2  Southern Governors, even those who favor President Carter, are scoffing at Carter campaign warnings that a contest between the President and Senator Edward M. Kennedy would divide and damage the Democratic Party.

title: Koch Has a Greeting For the First Citizen
description: Your Holiness, I am the Mayor, Edward I. Koch said yesterday, greeting Pope John Paul II at a long receiving line of secular and clerical dignitaries at La Guardia Airport. Thank vou for coming to New York City.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: My mother came up from Miami for her yearly visit, begins a communiqu from A. Broy. She started out alone to spend the day in Manhattan. She boarded the Queens bus and sat next to a pregnant woman who was on her way to an Alcoholics Anonymous meeting. My mother accompanied her to the meeting, then had lunch with her at Chock Full o Nuts.

title: Itinerary Today In New York And Philadelphia
description: Following is today's itinerary for Pope John Paul II. Times are approximate, with late changes possible. Letters alongside items refer to maps.

title: Bridge:
description: Representation in the world team championship scheduled to begin Monday in Rio de Janeiro is by continental zones. The South Pacific zone will be represented by Australia despite the fact that New Zealand was victorious when the two countries met recently in a playoff. The New Zealanders, itseems, cannot afford the considerable expense of sending a team to Brazil.

title: 80,000 Gather in Yankee Stadium for Historic Papal Mass
description: More than 80,000 cheering worshipers greeted Pope John Paul II at Yankee Stadium last night, a few straining to touch his waving right hand as he rode past the center field seats, the rest expressing their devotion with applause, flashbulbs and the chanting of his name.

title: Reactor Spews Radioactive Steam
description: RED WING, Minn., Oct. 2 (AP)Radioactive steam spewed into the atmosphere for up to 27 minutes today at the Prairie Island nuclear generating plant, but a Nuclear Regulatory Commission spokesman said that the radioactive emissions did not appear dangerous.

title: In the Bronx, Thousands Cheer John Paul
description: Your presence here tonight means that we count, the Rev. Neal A. Connolly, Vicar of the South Bronx, declared as he introduced Pope John Paul II to cheering thousands at the site of planned South Bronx housing project last night.

title: Transcript of Pope John Paul II's United Nations Address
description: Mr. President, my address today will be published in its entirety just as I wrote it. Because of its length, however, I shall now read it in a shortened form.

title: DraftKennedy Group Formed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2 (AP)  A coalition of California Democrats, predicting that Senator Kennedy would formally enter the Presidential race in November, announced today that they were forming a new draftKennedy campaign.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Bonds Swing Widely
description: As the credit markets swung widely yesterday amid rumors of a new support program to bolster the dollar, investment bankers disclosed that International Business Machine's $1 billion financing would be priced today for sale tomorrow.

title: Airline Chefs Go AllOut for the Pope
description: What does an Irish airline serve a Polishborn Pope on his way from Italy to Ireland to the United States? And what does an American airline's menu have to offer him, as he flies the breadth of the country and recrosses the Atlantic?

title: Nets King Traded To Jazz for Kelley
description: The New Jersey Nets, in need of more bulk, yesterday traded Bernard King, John Gianelli and Jim Boylan to the Utah Jazz for a 7foot center, Rich Kelley, and an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Orioles, Angels: Styles Conflict
description: If the American League pennant playoff that begins in Baltimore tonight were a morality play written by the baseball establishment, the Baltimore Orioles would be good and the California Angels evil.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Stadium Mass Varies a Little From Custom
description: The Apostles Creed at the mass offered last night by Pope John Paul II at Yankee Stadium was sung in Latin in the Gregorian chant that was once the familiar music in Roman Catholic churches.

title: 10% of U.S. Catholics Live in New York Area's Dioceses
description: When Pope John Paul II delivers his address at Battery Park today he will be speaking in the powerful Archdiocese of New York, the base of Terence Cardinal Cooke, the home of St. Patrick's Cathedral. But he will be able tosee the borders of two other Roman Catholic dioceses that are among the most populous in the United States those of Newark and Brooklyn. And he will be only of few miles west of the Diocese of Rockville Centre, covering Nassau and Suffolk Counties on Long Island.

title: Olin Seeking to Block Closing in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 2 The Olin Corporation went to court today in an attempt to obtain an injunction that would prohibit Mayor Frank Logue from continuing an unusual executive order that has closed the company's industrialresearch complex here for two days.

title: Baseball Achieving Popularity in China
description: PEKING  When the pitcher for the Tianjin City team sat down to rest between innings in the concrete dugout, a pigtailed young woman in baggy Mao jacket poured him a cup of steaming tea.

title: Askew Sworn In as Head of Trade Office
Sidewalk Capitalists Cash In on the Pope's Visit
description: Undeterred by the antimaterialistic messages Pope John Paul II, New York's street vendors were out force yesterday, hoping to cash in on the papal visit.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Skinner Memorial Oct. 25

title: For a Family From Nyack, A Brief Moment of History
description: The 7 A.M. commuter bus from Nanuet, N.Y., to New York City is one of those businessmen's specials that often seem to carry more briefcases and topcoats than passengers. Yesterday it carried Sally, Alex and Stephanie Caiti as well, bound not for the office, but for what they saw as a date with a bit of history.

title: Closes First of 2 Days at a Mass for 80,000 in Yankee Stadium
description: From the halls of world diplomacy to the mean streets of the city, Pope John Paul II swept through New York yesterday, preaching peace and pausing beyond the cheering crowds at hamlets of the striving and the poor.

title: American Ballet Theater Signs Godunov for 7980
description: Aleksandr Godunov, who sought asylum in the United States on Aug. 22, will join American Ballet Theater as a principal dancer for its 197980 season. Mr. Godunov will make his debut with the company during its fourweek engagement at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, which opens on Dec. 4. His appearance will mark his debut with an American company.

title: Nissan Car Prices Going Up in U.S.
description: TOKYO, Oct. 2 (AP) The Nissan Motor Company announced today it was raising the prices of all its 1980 exports to the United States except the Datsun 280ZX and 810 models.

title: Giants Drop Dixon; Jets Waive Pellegrini
description: The fact that their players had the day off yesterday did not prevent the Giants and Jets from making moves.

title: British Students to Join Protest of South Africans
description: LONDON, Oct. 2 (AP)  Britain's largest student group, the National Union of Students, pledged full support today for antiapartheid demonstrations at matches played by the Barbarians, a touring rugby team from South Africa. The demonstrations are being organized by a group called Stop All Racist Tours.

title: Collectors Are Collected, on Film
description: ELLEN LANDWEBER is a professional freelance photographer who collects collectors collectors of homeless Raggedy Ann dolls, collectors of Hawaiian sport shirts, collectors string and canning jars and maps of Transylvania and carnivorous plants.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Carl Beimiller, Founder And Editor of Holiday

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Notes on People
description: At the White House yesterday, it looked like the stage of the Grand Ole Opry. President Carter's guests for lunch were a passel of country music stars, including Johnny Cash, June Carter, Tom T. Hall, Bill Monroe, Glen Campbell, the Bluegrass Boys, the Oak Ridge Boys and Ronnie Milsap.

title: Miss Stevens Advances By Defeating Miss Casals
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 2 (UPI)  Greer Stevens showed an impressive serve in routing Rosie Casals, 63, 60, in firstround action today in the 71st United States women's indoor tennis championships at Met Sports Center.

title: Excerpts From Talk At Yankee Stadium
description: Social thinking and social practice inspired by the Gospel must always be marked by a special sensitivity toward those who are most in distress, those who are extremely poor, those suffering from all the physical, mental and moral ills that afflict humanity, including hunger, neglect, unemployment and despair.

title: Walter Hendricks Is Dead at 87; Teacher Began Marlboro College
description: Walter Hendricks, an educator, writer, publisher and founder of Marlboro College in Marlboro, Vt., died Saturday at Brattleboro Memorial Hospital in Brattleboro, Vt., at the age of 87. His home was in Putney, Vt.

title: Teachers in Morris District Return As 8% Raise Ends 11Day Strike
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 2  Teachers in the Morris School District returned to work today after agreeing to a new, twoyear contract and ending an 11day strike that had disrupted classes for 5,600 students.

title: Carter, Given Conflicting Advice, Chose a Middle Course on Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  Administration officials said today that President Carter, in responding to the discovery of a Soviet brigade in Cuba, had taken a middle position between proposals for doing very little and others for taking such steps as cutting off the export of advanced technology to the Soviet Union and initiating arms sales to China.

title: Dow Up 12.37 on DollarAid Possibility
description: Reports that the Government might soon take new action to bolster the sagging dollar sparked a sharp rally in stock prices yesterday. Meanwhile, gold prices gyrated in foreign exchange markets and ended at closing peaks.

title: 11 Indians Hurt in Demonstration As Gandhi Anniversary Is Marked
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 2 (AP)  The 110th anniversary of the birth of Mohandas K. Gandhi, the Indian leader who dedicated his life to nonviolence, was marred today by a clash between policemen and political demonstrators.

title: Witness Calls Alleged Payoffs to Anastasio Error
description: A witness testified under crossexamination yesterday that he had paid several extra kickbacks by mistake to Anthony Anastasio, the codefendant in the trial of Anthony M. Scotto in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Kidnapped Italian Girl Is Freed
description: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, Oct. 2 (AP)  The 17yearold daughter of a landowner was released by her kidnappers today after being held six weeks.

title: Marines Will Conduct Maneuvers And Fire Artillery in Guantanamo
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  A force of 1,600 to 1,800 marines scheduled to go ashore at Guantnamo Bay in Cuba in midOctober plans to maneuver in small units, fire artillery and run tank exercises, a Defense Department spokesman disclosed today.

title: 14,000 Cleared to Cover Visit by John Paul
description: Pope John Paul II exhorted journalists yesterday to be transmitters of truth and to use your best years, your finest talents and your most dedicated efforts to be instruments of tmderstanding among people and of peace among nations.

title: General Host Sets $45 Million Credit
description: The General Host Corporation said it had signed a $45 million revolving credit agreement with five of its major banks. The company said it intended to use this credit in its acquisition program.

title: U.S. Assails Chile Court's Refusal To Extradite Three in Letelier Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  The State Department today bitterly assailed the decision of Chile's Supreme Court to reject the United States appeal for the extradition of three former army officers indicted in this country for the murder of Orlando Letelier, a Chilean exile leader.

title: Home Video Recorders Ruled Lawful by Judge
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 2  Federal District Court Judge Warren J. Ferguson ruled today that the noncommercial use of home video recorders to record television broadcasts was lawful.

title: WASHINGTON The Pope's Eternal Message
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 2The visit of Pope John Paul II to the United Nations was a startling occasion. Even New York City, with its love of parades, theatrical openingnights and sports spectaculars, has seldom seen anything like this.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: No child could object to bundling up in a sweater that has the shapes of animals or people knitted into it, both front and back. Suzanne Russell, a Londoner who used to work for Mary Quant, has designed some charming sweaters, made by a cottage industry of British women who knit away as they watch the telly. The sweaters, with their bright figures, are great fun. Each pattern has a name (Rainbow Farm, for instance) and is signed by the knitter. They will fit children from 4 to 8 and are $75 at Jenny B. Goode, 1194 Lexington Avenue (81st Street).

title: Books of The Times
description: READERS apparently remember Ken Follett's first novel,Eye of the Needle, with pleasure, for although his second one will not be officially published until Oct. 22, Triple is alreadyin fifth place on the bestseller list. It is eminently qualified for such popularity, for its behindthescenes interpretation of contemporary events includes everything in the political and emotional spectrum, as well as what someone calls the hijacking of a holocaust.

title: Best Buys
description: IF you still believe that a penny saved is a penny earned, last week was a good week. The 41item market basket used by the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs to gauge inflation showed that the cost of feeding a family of four had declined by 2 cents.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Nelson C. Jackson, 72, ExUrban League Aide

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 2 (AP)  Directors of the Remington Arms Company have unanimously agreed to new terms for its proposed merger into E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation has elected Pieter J. Schiller vice presidentplanning and development; William A. Kebba vice president and controller, and Nicholas A. Cameron treasurer.

title: Clayborn Fined $2,000 by N.F.L.
description: Raymond Clayborn of the New England Patriots has been fined $2,000 by Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League for conduct involving members of the news media.

title: Sioux Leaders to Appeal U.S. Offer on Lost Lands
description: PIERRE, S.D., Oct. 2 (AP)  Sioux tribal leaders say they will appeal a Federal offer of $149 million in compensation for lands that white settlers took from the Sioux nation more than a century ago.

title: St. Patrick's Echoes With Greeting of Joy
description: At St. Patrick's Cathedral, 3,500 voices joined together in a deafening cheer, and for a moment the most famous church in America was enveloped in a joyous frenzy.

title: Castro Is Letting Rent For U.S. Base Pile Up
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (Reuters) Presumably gathering dust somewhere in Cuba is a stack of United States Treasury checks for $4.000 each.

title: HelpWanted Index Unchanged
description: The Conference Board reported yesterday that its helpwanted advertising index was unchanged in August, with increases in five regions of the country and decreases in four.

title: Kucinich Is 2d in Cleveland Voting: Runoff Is Seen
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 2  Lieut. Gov. George V. Voinovich, a Republican, outpolled embattled Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich by more than 11,000 votes today in the city's nonpartisan mayoral primary.

title: California Pistachios With Perfect Timing
description: SAN FRANCISCO This California pistachio is brought to you courtesy of the Internal Revenue Service and the Shah of Iran.

title: I.R.A. Rejects Pope's Plea
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 2 (Reuters)  The Previsional Irish Republican Army today rejected a plea by Pope John Paul II to abandon violence in its campaign against British rule in Northern Ireland, citing the church's doctrine that Christians may resist oppression.

title: Chrysler Van Rebate
description: DETROIT, Oct. 2 (Reuters)  The Chrysler Corporation announced a $400 rebate program for domestic vans, pickups and sport utility vehicles, starting now and running until at least Oct. 18. It wants to reduce dealer stocks before the new models are unveiled.

title: Real Estate
description: LANDMARK designation does not stop development, but it does require that all proposals for development go through a public process of review. Supporters and opponents of a proposed special historic district for the Upper East Side of Manhattan might agree on that observation but little else.

title: Packers Catch Fire And Scorch Patriots
description: There have been five major upsets in the National Football League this season and four came in the last nine days, including the startling 2714 victory by the Green Bay Packers over the New England Patriots Monday night.

title: Yale FundRaiser Joins Columbia As It Begins Its Own Campaign
description: Terry M. Holcombe, who directed Yale University's recent $370 million fundraising campaign, has been appointed vice president for development and alumni relations at Columbia University.

title: Callaghan and Labor Aides Suffer a Setback in Party
description: BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 2  Former Prime Minister James Callaghan and the Labor Party establishment were dealt a setback by the party conference today, and appeared almost certain to suffer another one tomorrow.

title: The Region
description: ATLANTIC CITY  A top executive of Caesars World Inc., who has been barred by New Jersey gaming authorities from participating in the concern's activities here while the state investigates his dealings with two Florida men with alleged organized crime ties, has purchased more than 130 acres for housing in two suburbs of Atlantic City.

title: The Best Of Brie: What To Look For
description: LATE autumn marks the beginning of the year's best season for such gustatory prizes as game, truffles, fresh foie gras and  especially  brie, France's king of cheeses and the No. 1 status choice in this country as well. Brie is popular for a combination of reasons, some genuine and practical, others more romantic and perhaps even imaginary.

title: Noncitizens to Work on 80 Census
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  Bowing to pressure from Hispanic groups, the Census Bureau has agreed to give equal consideration to people who are not citizens of the United States when hiring temporary workers for the 1980 census.

title: Boston Shooting Suspects Plead Not Guilty and Are Freed on Bail
description: BOSTON, Oct. 2 (UPI)  Three white teenagers were released today after pleading not guilty to charges related to shooting incident in which a black high school football player was left paralyzed from the neck down.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: RKO License Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)  The staff of the Federal Communications Commission has recommended the renewal the license held by RICO General for the Boston television station WNAC, despite the involvement of the company's parent, the General Tire and Rubber Company, in foreign payoffs.

title: REV. ARTHUR LOFTUS, EXHEAD OF COLLEGE
description: The Rev. Brother Arthur A. Loftus, former president of Iona College in New Rochelle and former Superior General of the Irish Christian Brothers, died of a heart attack Monday in Warwick, R.I. He was 75 years old and had been residing at the Bishop Hendricken High School in Warwick since 1972.

title: The `Capeman Reflects As Prison Release Nears
description: AUBURN, N.Y. Sept. 29  He was a real skinny kid, skinny in the flesh and skinny in the brain, or so he describes himself. A gang leader and 16 years old,he was as cocky and defiant of authority as he was proud of his exploits in crime with the Mau Maus of Brooklyn and the Vampires of the West Side of Manhattan.

title: World News Briefs
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 2 (AP)  Citing United States refusal to pay Mexico for damages resulting from the salting of the Mexicali Valley, President Jos Lpez Portillo says Mexico will pay nothing for the damage done to the Texas coast by oil from a runaway Mexican well in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Obituary 10  No Title
description: Deaths

title: PBS Starting National News Program
description: BOSTON, Oct. 2  Boston's publictelevision station will produce a nightly national and international news program for public stations across the country starting next month, WGBHTV announced today.

title: Prices Of Wine Surging Again
description: THE vast wine list at the Four Seasons restaurant, a barometer of wine prices, is now undergoing its semiannual revision, and it tells a tale of pain and woe for consumers. The average price of all of the estatebottled white burgundies on the restaurant's new list is a little more than $47, about 18 percent higher than the $40 average on the old list, already out of reach for most consumers.

title: An Auxiliary in Brooklyn Named to Florida Diocese
description: Pope John Paul II named Bishop John J. Snyder, Auxiliary Bishop and vicar general of the Diocese of Brooklyn, as the Bishop of the Diocese of St. Augustine in Florida, the Brooklyn Diocese announced yesterday.

title: U.S. Aids Hartford Project
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 2 (AP)  The Federal Government has approved a $4.5 million grant to pay 85 percent of the cost of renovating the Union Station here and turning it into a multipurpose transportation center, officials said yesterday.

title: French Flights Are Disrupted
description: PARIS, Oct. 2 (Reuters)  Fog and a strike by Air France employees combined today to reduce air services. A spokesman for the airline attributed much of the disruption to fog at Orly Airport, south of Paris. He said all supersonic Concorde services and most longhaul flights were operating normally.

title: Obituary 7  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543??00 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNT?? 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M.
