description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)  The Carter Administration proposed three possible ways today to enforce its promised oilimport allocation program, a move that might cut American dependence on the oil cartel, but could raise oil prices.

title: Rally at Hunter Urges Selecting Black Educator to Head College
description: A coalition of groups representing black students, faculty members and civic organizations held a rally yesterday at Hunter College and called on the board of trustees of the City University of New York to name Dr. Jewel Plummer Cobb, a prominent black educator, as the college's next president.

title: U.S. Entrepreneur's Soviet Ties
description: David Karr, a littleknown entrepreneur who was one of the leading American businessman in EastWest trade, spent last Fourth of July in Moscow celebrating the opening of an Americanstyle luxury hotel he had developed. A few days later he was found dead in his Paris apartment, at the age of 60.

title: CaveIn Kills Woman Who Won Miner's Job
description: OSCEOLA MILLS, Pa., Oct. 4 (UPI)  Marilyn J. McCusker, who sued for the right to be a coal miner, has been killed by falling rocks while working in a mine, officials announced yesterday.

title: Restaurants
description: It is easy to understand the everincreasing popularity of Indian food, given its savory counterpoints of spices, its decorative presentation and its contrasting crisp and silken textures. The newest restaurant presenting this subtle cuisine is Bombay Palace which opened just three months ago as a replacement for Tavoos, the interesting Iranian restaurant that unfortunately closed. Located on East 52d Street, just across the street from 21 Club, Bombay Palace has a handsome, atmospheric and spacious dining room, with comfortable seating and a civilized decibel level.

title: Colombian Mother of 8 Has Sound Quintuplets
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 4 (AP)  A 35yearold woman who makes 60 cents a day as a maid has given birth to quintuplets, and a doctor said today that all five all airis were healthy.

title: South Africans Cancel Ban on Gordimer Book
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. (Reuters)  The censors have lifted their ban on Burger's Daughter, novel by Nadine Gordimer that has been widely hailed overseas.

title: Suit Says Port of Call Is Off Limits
description: Piracy, ports of call and the Orient are words that evoke silks and spices and fearsome men with knives in their teeth  but few people would think of Bloomingdale's or Bergdorf Goodman's. Yesterday, however, one of Bergdorf Goodman's concessions, a boutique called Port of Call that specializes in Orientalia, charged Bloomingdale's with commercial piracy for using the words Ports of Call to designate its new model rooms.

title: Cambodia Denies It Gave Agencies Authorization to Help the Starving
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 4 (Reuters)  The Vietnamesebacked regime in Cambodia has denied that it authorized two international relief organizations to open offices in Phnom Penh or agreed to a largescale aid operation for the faminestricken country.

title: World Gold
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1979

title: Execution Date Is Set
description: LAS VEGAS, Oct. 4 (AP)  Jesse Bishop, who has consistently fought efforts to spare him, was sentenced yesterday to die in the gas chamber Oct. 22 despite his plea for an extra week of life to get his personal affairs in order. Mr. Bishop, 46 years old, has pleaded guilty to the December 1977 murder of David Ballard, a newlywed Baltimore tourist who was shot when he tried to break up a robbery at a Las Vegas Strip casino.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Joseph Magnin Adds A Veteran Retailer

title: In Polish Neighborhood: Spruced Up and Waiting
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 4  The autumn sun caressed Richmond Street on Chicago's Southwest Side at noon, raising honest sweat on the forehead of Randy Patka as he kneeled on the sidewalk methodically sweeoinrt a paint brush from side

title: Photographer Puts Her Career In Perspective
description: Ruth Orkin's whole life, from her earliest days, has been images rather than words.

title: Deaths
description: ADAMSDaniel G. Loving son of Sondra and Milton; beloved brother of Marc, Scott and Lewis; maternal grandson of Rhea Kranis; paternal grandson of Louise and Milton. Reposing at Colonial Funeral Home, 2819 Hyland Blvd, Corner Tysens Lane, Staten Island. Religious services Friday 10:30AM

title: Floods Ravage Central Vietnam
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 4 (Reuters)  The worst floods in 30 years have ravaged parts of central Vietnam, engulfing large areas of rice fields and destroying houses, schools and hospitals, the Vietnam News Agency reported today.

title: Elizabeth Cook, Researcher, Is Married to Sanford Postel
description: Elizabeth Cook, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Cook of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married yesterday to Sanford Postel, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Postel of New York and Atlantic Beach, L.I. The ceremony was performed in the chapel of the Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun by Rabbi Haskell Lookstein.

title: Carey May Call a Special Session on Heating Oil Cost
description: ALBANY, Oct. 4  Governor Carey said today that he would convene a special session of the Legislature after the Nov. 6 election, but only if his Democratic administration and the Democratic-controlled Assembly could get together with the Republicancontrolled State Senate on a program to help consumers cope with home heating costs.

title: Topics Aid to Suburbia, Help in Court
description: President Carter recently met with some Congressmen who think Washington ignores the suburbs. Representative John Wydler of Nassau, for instance, charged that his district gets only halt the general revenuesharing aid, per capita, given neighboring Queens. As urban blight spreads, others said, so do the troubles of adjoining suburbs. Their pleas may have fallen on sympathetic ears. Mr. Carter promised to consider establishing a national suburban policy to complement his urban one.

title: Film Festival: 'Best Boy,' Documentary:Love and Anguish
description: IRA WOHL'S "Best Boy" is a fine, unusually moving example of documentary film making  what Al and David Maysles, two of the most able practitioners of the method, call "direct cinema"  about three crucial years in the life of Mr. Wohl's cousin Philly, a stocky, cheerful man of 52 who has been mentally retarded since birth.When we first meet Philly he is living with his parents in the small, middle-class Queens house that has been his home all his life, except for two years spent in an institution when he was a boy. Prompted by his sister, his parents and Mr. Wohl, Philly remembers with a good deal of humor the awfulness of those institutional years, his mind, though it's said to be that of a child of 5, recalling events nearly 40 years in the past.That, as much as anything else, demonstrates how little we understand the phenomenon we call mental retardation. Minds so described can not only leap forward and back, making totally unexpected associations and connections, but they also accumulate life-times of memories.Mr. Wohl has given shape to the film as much in his family relationship as Philly's cousin as in his capacity as the film maker. It's at his suggestion that Philly's parents, Pearl, 72, and Max, 78, agree to send Philly to a day-training center and then, two years later, after the death of his father, to a home where Philly can live and continue the life of expanded interests and responsibilities that the school comes to mean for him. "Best Boy," as the film's program notes point out, is about a young man preparing to leave home for the first time. It's a common enough story unless the young man is 52."Best Boy" records Philly's first forays away from home, though he is always in the company of his cousin-the-film maker, who carries the camera, and other members of the crew. There are interviews with psychologists, teachers and couselors, all of whom, one understands, would be on their best behavior in front of the camera. I don't think, though, that the camera's presence is the only reason for this film's benign, almost sweet manner. There is Philly himself, whom Mr. Wohl obviously is fond of and concerned about. Philly is a special person, and his efforts toward some kind of self-sufficiency are material of genuine drama."Best Boy," however, is more than the story of Philly. It's about a family. Even more affecting than Philly's first days in school are the scenes we see played  sometimes at the side of the screen  between Philly's mother and father. At first, Max seems self-conscious in the company of the camera, at other times bored or maybe cranky. Slowly we come to recognize his dignity. When Max comes home from the hospital, thin, pale and exhausted after a cataract operation, his unexpected gesture of affection for his wife suddenly cuts through all the self-consciousness and uneasiness that have gone before.Pearl is more of a natural with the camera. Whether she's worried, tired, happy or sad, her spirit is never in doubt. "If God wants to punish somebody," Pearl says at one point, "He should do it with retarded children."Life is a confusion of love and anguish."Best Boy" will be shown at the New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall today at 6:15 P.M. and Sunday at 2.

title: DeJesus Outpoints Blevins
description: Estaban DeJesus, the former world lightweight champion, failed to show his former class tonight as he scored a 10round unanimous decision over Jimmy Blevins of Chicago at the Felt Forum.

title: West Berlin Seeks Better Future for Its Foreigners
description: WEST BERLIN, Oct. 4  I like school, and I want to be a teacher myself, said Aynur Celik, an 11yearold Turkish girl, here last week. She is one of 17 foreignborn pupils being taught along with 14 German children in a fourthgrade classroom at the Neumark elementary school.

title: Pop Music: Laughing Dogs
description: THE Laughing Dogs, who were at the Bottom Line Wednesday night, seem to be having a lot of fun doing what they're doing. Basically, what they're doing is playing power pop with jazz touches and acting like lunatics. Some listeners aria critics have found their manic humor sophomoric, and it's true that they once played backup for a reunion tour by the Monkees, but underneath the hilarity (which can get frantic, like a situation comedy that's trying too hard) are some solid musicianship and a fairly original late70's perspective on the music of the mid60's.

title: US. Sells 4Year Notes At 9.79% Yield, a Record
description: The depressed state of the credit markets became more pronounced yesterday and interest rates continued to climb to record levels, pushed higher by discouraging wholesale price figures, a tightening signal from the Federal Reserve and the absence of any forceful program to bolster the dollar.

title: Philharmonic: Leinsdorf and Dichter
description: FASHIONS in Mozart perfonnance seem to undergo 180-degree changes about every 20 years, possibly because of the push and pull of generational antagonisms as much as scholarly discoveries or artistic revisionism. imos unheard of nowadays is the stern, almost muscular Mozart that pianists espoused a couple of decades ago as a reaction to an ever older view of the composer as a salon entertainer. We have not yet reached the point in the circle where Mozart will again be chucked under the chin and fondled as if he were merely a charming child, but we may be only a few degrees away. or artistic revisionism. imos unheard of nowadays is the stern, almost muscular Mozart that pianists espoused a couple of decades ago as a reaction to an ever older view of the composer as a salon entertainer. We have not yet reached the point in the circle where Mozart will again be chucked under the chin and fondled as if he were merely a charming child, but we may be only a few degrees away.

title: Corky Corcoran, 55, Saxophonist With James and Dorsey Bands
description: TACOMA, Wash., Oct. 4 (AP)  Corky Corcoran, the tenorsaxophone player known for his work with the Harry James orchestra and other groups in the 1940's, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital here. He was 55 years old.

title: Regional Stages Spawn New Shows
description: IT has become a case of role reversals of sorts. When the regional theater movement began in force a decade or so ago, these professional companies operating outside New York City habitually scoured the Broadway scene for material to fill their seasons. But in recent years these theaters have become so acclaimed for their own proauctions of new plays and revivals that Broadway impresarios now carefully scour the regional theaters for muchneeded material to fill the New York season.

title: Bill Harrell's Virginians Open Bluegrass Season
description: Baseball executives are always talking about trades that will help both teams  that is, putting players where their skills will be best used. Bluegrass bands may be smaller than baseball teams, but they, too, need complemen tary skills. Bill Harrell, who opens the bluegrass season at New York University tomorrow night  followed by a square dance  is one musician who has gained from a shift in teammates.

title: In Chicago Chill, Pope Gets Warm Greeting From Crowd
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 4  Pope John Paul II descended upon Chicago tonight aboard the airplane Shepherd I to an enthusiastic greeting by more than 1,000 dignitaries who had been waiting for hours in the October chill at what is known as the military side of O'Hare International Airport.

title: ARMY CHIEF FAVORS EAST COAST REFINERY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4  Secretary of the Army Clifford L. Alexander today tentatively approved the building of the first major oil refinery on the East Coast in 22 years, overriding objections from environmentalists.

title: Plot to Slay the Pope Termed a Bad Joke
description: SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 4 (UPI)  A wealthy Salvadorean businessman, investigated and cleared by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of involvement in an alleged plot to kill the Pope, said today that the whole thing was a bad joke.

title: MRS. B. FRANKLIN FITCH
description: Mrs. B. Franklin Fitch, who had been prominent in social circles for many years, died last Saturday in Greenwich, Conn. Mrs. Fitch, who lived on Zaccheus Mead Lane in Greenwich, was 83 years old.

title: Slow Pace of Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4  Last Monday was New Year's Day for the fiscal year 1980. By that date the Federal budget was supposed to have been in place and the money to pay the bills was supposed to have been appropriated. But when the new year dawned, the budget was still snagged in a struggle between the House and Senate, and most appropriations bills were a long way from the President's desk.

title: 74th St. Block Party
description: Food, music and other entertainment can be enjoyed alfresco tomorrow from noon to 6 P.M. at a block party on East 79th Street, between Second and Third Avenues. Sponsored by the 74th Street Block Association, the day will feature performances by a chamber music ensemble and a brass quintet from the Mannes College of Music and chorale singers from the Light Opera of Manhattan. There will also be crafts demonstrations and a magic show. Proceeds benefit communitybeautification projects.

title: Semiconductor Earnings Surge
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation reported yesterday a 43 percent jump in earnings for the quarter ended Sept. 16 on a 31 percent sales gain.

title: Utilities Reduce Capital Outlays
description: Investorowned utilities continued to reduce appropriations for new plant and equipment in the second quarter of this year, according to a report by the Conference Board that will be released today. These lower appropriations will contribute to lower spending in months to come because capital appropriations are authorizations to spend money in the future.

title: Atheist Filing an Appeal To Bar Pope From Mall
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI)  Madalyn Murray O'Hair, the militant atheist, took her fight against Pope John Paul H to a Federal appeals court today, seeking to stop him from celebrating mass on Washington's public Mall next Sunday.

title: PONTIFF REAFFIRMS POSITION OPPOSING WOMEN AS PRIESTS
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 4  Pope John Paul came to the heart of the country today, emphatically reaffirming in his crosscountry tour that the Roman Catholic priesthood required a lifelong commit ment from men and was not a proper call inp for women.

title: Historical Linkage Cited For Gold and Oil Values
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 4South Africa's finance minister suggested today that there was a rough historical relationship between oil and gold prices under which either gold should fall sharply or oil rise again.

title: L.I.'s Weekday and Weekend Farmers Put On Big Country Fair
description: More than 2,000 farmers  of both the commercial and backyard variety  have entries in this weekend's Long Island Fair, the largest agricultural fair in New York State.

title: Funeral Marchers in El Salvador Occupy a Cathedral Over Killings
description: SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 4 (AP)  Hundreds of demonstrators slipped away from a downtown funeral march today and occupied the Metropolitan Cathedral, closing off rush hour traffic, according to witnesses.

title: Gold Drops And Dollar Strengthens
description: Widespread rumors that the Carter Administration was planning new measures to support the dollar led to a strengthening of the American currency yesterday in foreignexchange trading, while gold prices plummeted on world bullion markets.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Alternateside parking regulations will be suspended tomorrow throughout New York City for the Jewish holiday of Succoth. All other parking rules remain in effect.

title: There's Still a Uganda
description: LONDON  In the 1890's, the British fought tooth and nail to get hold of Uganda, the point of entry to the head waters of the Nile. Now nobody wants it. There are no Cuban soldiers there, no Russian technicians. If ever there was the archetypal notwanted, no-strategic-value nation, Uganda is it. As far as 99 percent of the world is concerned, Uganda can rot in its Tanzanian juice. The great hurrah that went up when Idi Amin was finally toppled by invading Tanzanian troops in April has subsided into an embarrassed murmur.

title: Seoul Opposition Leader Is Expelled From Parliament
description: TOKYO, Oct. 4  South Korea's opposition leader was ordered expelled from the National Assembly today by a vote in which only proGovernment legislators participated. The reason for the expulsion, the governing party said, was that he had violated an emergency decree by denouncing the Government of President Park Chung Hee as a minority dictatorial regime.

title: Roger K. Fawcett Is Dead at 69; Publishing Executive, Sportsman
description: Roger Knowlton Fawcett, who was president of Fawcett Publications, the company founded by his father, and an awardwinning sportsman, died Wednesday at Memorial SloanKettering Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: Schools After The Fall
description: For all too many autumns, our schools have been permitted to launch journeys to June in an environment of melancholy, hopelessness and fatalism. This autumn, can't we overcome such negative inevitability about teaching and learning by looking at some ideas that can lead to revision and renewal based on good, sound education ideas? The schools can and must accept responsibility for change by taking the following steps: 1. Abolishing the chronological singlestep admission policy to kindergarten.

title: Panel in Senate Said to Question Verifying of Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4  In a report to be issued tomorrow, the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence states that the United States has impressive ability to monitor many facets of Soviet military development. But, Senate sources said today, it draws no firm conclusion that the new strategic arms treaty can be adequately verified.

title: Deaths
description: FAWCETTRoper. The quarter century club of the New York Athletic Club records with sorrow the passing of a valiant member elected in 1937 and extends deepest sympathy to his bereaved family. James M. Cooke,President J. Donald Clune, Secretary

title: Deaths
description: BRYANTSylvester W. Reverend. Former Minister of Church of the People, 27 W 130 St. Passed away Sept 30, 1979. Services Friday, 11AM St. Paul Community Church, 256 W. 145 St. Burial Femcliff Cemetery. Survived by wife, Herlina, son, Sylvester, Jr., one sister, Rosalie Bryant Brown, one brother, Allen Bryant, 2 sister-In-laws, Mary and Ada Bryant, and host of other relatives.

title: The Sainted Anthropologist
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 4  John Lowenstein is a muscular anthropologist who was born in Wolf Point, Mont., now operates a dance studio in Las Vegas, Nev., and goes in for hobbies like riding a raft down the white water of Idaho's Snake River Canyon. He also plays left field, center field. right field, first base and third base for the Baltimore Orioles, doubles as a pinchhitter and serves as a pinchrunner when his gimpy left ankle permits. He is also a statistic and a deity.

title: Film: Banker Checked:Fall Guy
description: A FRENCHMAN in a gray flannel suit is the reluctant hero of "Other People's Money," which will be shown tonight at 9:30 and Sunday at 7 P.M. at the New York Film Festival.Played by the accomplished Jean-Louis Trintignant, he is a third-level executive in a private bank in Paris, a man who has spent 15 years  pleasant years  taking favored customers to lunch, following orders without question, and hurrying home to his pleasant suburban villa, his wife, played by Catherine Deneuve, and their two daughters.When the bank is involved in a scandal involving a real-estate development in which small investors lose millions, he is chosen to be the fall guy. Dismissed, psychologically unable to fight back and unable to find another job, he is one battered bourgeosie until his wife gets the bank unions to help defend him.Although "Other People's Money" has been adapted from a novel based on an actual event, it does not have the essential ring of dramatic truth. Points of conflict are blunted, the pace, as in so many recent European films, is glacial, and the narrative line keeps getting lost in side issue.The director, Christian de Chalonge, who also collaborated on the screenplay, has chosen to tell the story from the point of view of the executive, underscoring his state of mind at times by quasi-Surrealistic techniques. It would have been far better to rely on Mr. Trintignant's acting, which is eloquent in its control, and on a tighter script.The still lovely Miss Deneuve has far too little to do. Claude Brasseur, Michel Serrault and Francois Perrot provide accomplished support as, respectively, the con man who precipitates the scandal and two scarcely less rascally bankers.

title: Parties in City Opera Labor Dispute Meet Today in Hopes of Settlement
description: With their first joint meeting since performances were suspended Sunday set for today at 2 P.M., both sides in the labor dispute at the New York City Opera agree that their differences have been narrowed to $342.000.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, Oct. 4,1979

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: How Power Changed the Reformers
description: When Robert Abrams was a junior at Columbia University he feared that he would get the worst mark in his political science class.

title: Broadway
description: Oklahoma! comes sweeping up the plain from Florida.

title: TV Weekend Potpourri of Programs
description: Tomorrow at 9 P.M., CBS's Big Shamus, Little Shamus has its hero, hotel detective, being kidnapped with wealthy socialite. It seems the villains are seeking revenge on the woman's father. Does the detective survive?. I assume so, but don't know for sure. The episode was not available for viewing. However, judging from last week's premiere of this new series, it probably doesn't matter.

title: Shelving the Little Red Book
description: Mao Zedong died three years ago and this week the Chinese Communist Party put him in his place. It was not the pantheon. The Peking People's Daily declared that Mao was neither sage nor god, adding that no individual is free of mistakes or fails to make errors . . .

title: Larger Waterfront Board Voted
description: The New York City Council's Committee on Governmental Operations yesterday approved a measure that would enlarge the Waterfront Management Advisory Board from 17 members to 21. One of the new positions would be held by the city's Environmental Protection Commissioner and the three others by private citizens. The board advises the administration on the development of the city's waterfront and wharfs. The proposed expansion of the board must now be approved by the full Council.

title: Brezhnev Arrives in East Germany For 30th Anniversary Celebration
description: EAST BERLIN, Oct. 4  Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, arrived here today for celebrations marking East Germany's 30th anniversary as a Communist republic, meetings with Eastbloc lead. ers and a foreign policy speech in which he is expected to discuss strains in Soviet. American relations over Cuba.

title: Truck and Bus Output Off
description: DETROIT, Oct. 4 (AP)  Truck and bus production in the United States for September dropped 39 percent from the same period in 1978, the Motor Vehicle Association reported yesterday.

title: U.S. Awards $17.1 Million to Aid Park and Recreational Systems
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)  The White House press office today announced $17.1 million in grants to help 44 cities and counties finance the rehabilitation of urban park and recreation systems.

title: Dance: Umbrella Opens
description: IT didn't rain Tuesday evening. Yet an umbrella opened at 54th Street and 10th Avenue. This particular umbrella was the Dance Umbrella, which began a 10week season featuring 20 groups with an Event by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company.

title: IN THE NATION Will He Or Won't He?
description: Now that Edward Kennedy is a reasonably certain entrant into the 1980 Presidential race, Gerald Ford is providing the traditional willheorwon'the act for a variety of breathless (perhaps) audiences.

title: Screen: Burt Reynolds As Unmarried Husband:Post-Divorce Blues
description: THE newly divorced husband has long been Hollywood's forgotten man. If he ever turned up in a movie at all, chances are he was either hiring a mariachi band to serenade his ex-wife with her favorite song (he got her back that way) or trying to figure out how to run the vacuum cleaner (he got her back that way, too  she couldn't stand to see him suffer). But "Starting Over" depicts an abandoned man in all his misery, and still manages to be fast and funny while it breaks new ground. There's a kernel of truth here. There are a lot of good laughs, too.And there is also an important problem, but it doesn't manifest itself until the story is well under way. As the film begins, Phil Potter (Burt Reynolds) is being sent packing by his wife, Jessica (Candice Bergen), who wants to find herself and has the grievously misguided notion that she can sing.To the tune of one of his wife's screechiest compositions, Phil leaves New York and heads for Boston, where he immediately encounters excessive sympathy from family members, suspicious and/or predatory behavior from new women he meets, and a terrible loneliness. There is no question about the fact that Phil is still very much in love with his ex-wife.But because he is lonely, he strikes up a new romance  or, rather, he allows a woman to strike one up for him. Phil isn't enough of a heel to mislead Marilyn, a nursery-school teacher played by Jill Clayburgh. But neither is he self-sufficient enough to turn down the companionship she offers.The screenplay, by the television writer James L. Brooks (one of the creators of the "Mary Tyler Moore Show"), deals beautifully with Phil's cautiousness and his passivity. And Mr. Reynolds handles this part of the story quite gracefully, wearing an impenetrable, guarded expression and playing everything very close to the vest.The most stinging scene in the movie, and also one of the best-acted, shows Phil and Marilyn sharing a Thanksgiving dinner with Phil's brother, Mickey (Charles Durning), and his excruciatingly compassionate wife, Marva (Frances Sternhagen). Marilyn has spent most of the movie dressed in the kind of cute, padded clothing her little students wear  she always seems to be swathed in a snowsuit. But this time she appears, looking voluptuous, in something green and clingy  an indication of the extent and importance of her involvement with Phil. Then the phone rings, and there, out of the blue, is Jessica. Phil is surprised to hear from her, and excited, too. He tries to whisper, but he doesn't do a very good job of it  in any case, the others are eavesdropping without shame. Who's there? Jessica wants to know. Oh, says Phil, just Mickey and Marva and ... and...one of their friends.Their friend? It goes without saying that Marilyn is angry. But the movie stands or falls upon whether the source of that anger will be acknowledged, and it isn't. Instead of recognizing this, either tacitly or openly, as Phil's declaration that his ex-wife means more to him than Marilyn does, the couple just fight for a spell and then decide to move in together. If Mr. Brooks and Alan J. Pakula, the director, have spent the early part of the story establishing a complicated and difficult situation, they devote the second half of the film to pretending it's something that can be laughed away.Reynolds's performance begins very well, and very seriously  all the laughs are built around him, and he reacts calmly and cannily, with an eye toward self-preservation. When Jessica and Marilyn finally turn up in the same place, though, it's time for Phil to show the strain, or to show the conflict, or to show something  and still Mr. Reynolds lies low.After a meeting with Jessica in her motel room  a meeting that Phil is rescued from by a joke  Phil admits to his comrades in a church-run Divorce Workshop that he has never wanted a woman more than he wanted Jessica right then. If so, there's more of that desire in the script than there is in the performance. Mr. Reynolds plays the motel-room scene as coolly as he plays any other.Miss Clayburgh delivers a particularly sharp characterization that's letter-perfect during the first part of the story and unconvincing in the second, through no fault of her own. Nervous, demanding, high-strung and nevertheless charming, her Marilyn is all wrong for Phil  that's what makes their affair so unexpectedly touching and gives the story so much life. So when the movie begins to insist that these two were made for each other, it gives the lie to all that has gone before. This feeling is intensified by the fact that neither character changes much during the course of the story. It doesn't help that the only amorous interludes occur very early on.One of the comic masterstrokes in "Starting Over" is the casting of Candice Bergen as Jessica. New wives dreading ex-wives must invariably summon someone like Miss Bergen to mind.

title: Tiny Country Parish Gives Pope Quiet Joy
description: CUMMING, Iowa, Oct. 4  Pope John Paul II, the spiritual leader of 700 million Christians, became a simple country pastor for a few minutes today in a litle country church surrounded by the rolling green pastures and browning corn fields of Iowa. And his face glowed with the joy of the occasion.

title: Drama: Adapting Wiesel's Dawn
description: D AWN, a long oneact play based on an excerpt from a novel of the same name by Elie Wiesel opened Wednesday night at Theater East. This wellintentioned undertaking was a mistake.

title: Split Emerging Over Tactics of Antinuclear Forces
description: BOSTON, Oct. 4  The rapidly growing movement against nuclear power has become divided over tactics, with some moderates fearing there is danger in actions that court arrest.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown.(N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Stage: The All Night Strut!
description: THE teamwork is terrific. Then why isn't The All Night Strut! more fun? It turns out that teamwork isn't what we most want in the theater. What we want far more is the star breakthrough, the sudden surge of personality that leaps out of the chorus line to leave the team gasping somewhere in the background. As a matter of fact, the breakthrough doesn't have to be of star quality. Just an assertion of identity, the establishment of a personality - bold as brass, or quietly cunning that we'll recognize instantly the next time around.

title: Bridge:
description: The prospects of the United States team in the world championship beginning Monday in Rio de Janeiro are not easy to assess. The anchor foursome of Bill Eisenberg, Eddie Kantar and Paul Soloway, all of Los Angeles, and Bob Goldman of Dallas is fully capable of winning the world title, and the members have won nine such titles between them.

title: Algeria Oil Cut Expected Jan. 1
description: Algeria, the fifthlargest supplier of oil to the United States, is planning an additional cutback of 5 percent in contract sales of crude to major oil companies on Jan. 1, analysts said yesterday.

title: Art: Photography In U.S., 19001930
description: THE large exhibition called Photography Rediscovered at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street, is not  as the name may suggest  an account of the feverish revival or interest in pnOtograpny that has been one of the important artistic developments of the 1970's. It focuses, rather, on American photography in the years 19001930 when, for the first time, a selfconscious and highly developed sense of artistic professionalism made itself felt in this field on fairly significant scale. The first 30 years of this century are, in effect, classic period in American photography, and it is one of the purposes of this new exhibition  organized by David Travis, curator of photography at the Art Institute of Chicago  to give us new perspective on the achievements that grew from this rediscovery of the possibilities of the medium.

title: Britain Seeking More Spending For the Military
description: LONDON, Oct. 4  Defense Minister Francis Pym says a military threat from the Soviet Union demands an increase of 3 percent in the next British military budget. He believes, he says, that there is a very good chance of achieving it.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Memories of Pope
description: The Rev. Joseph Olinski had faith. He believed firmly  and for weeks had been telling anyone who asked him  that the Pope would show up at his church, St. Stanislaus Bishop and Martyr on East Seventh Street in Manhattan.

title: VANCE AFFIRMS BAN ON ARMS FOR CHINA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said emphatically today that the United States would not alter its policy of refusing to sell military eouiument to China.

title: Letters
description: We have read Judy Klemesrud's Sept. 26 report of Jane Fonda's remarks at a meeting sponsored by Women Office Workers. Unless Miss Klemesrud's account is inaccurate, which we doubt, Miss Fonda is muddying issues, not clarifying them, thereby hurting the very people she is trying to help.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Cleanup in City After Papal Stay Proves Easy Job
description: The areas of New York City that Pope John Paul II visited were clean by midday yesterday  some cleaner than they usually are  despite the crowds that had gathered to greet the Pope in the two previous days.

title: Top Concerns Must Account in Reports for Inflation
description: Some 1,200 major corporations in the United States will have to show the impact of inflation on their sales and earnings in 1979 when they issue their an. nual stockholder reports for the year, according to a new ruling to be issued today by the Financial Accounting Standards Board.

title: Excerpts From Homily by Pope to Priests, Nuns and Seminarians
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 (AP) Following are excerpts from the text of Pope John Paul II's homily as delivered to priests, nuns and seminarians this morning at the Philadelphia Civic Center:

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: MANHATTAN

title: Wages and Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 In light of the Carter Administration's national accord giving organized labor an ad_ visory role in establishing antiinflation policies, does the White House still have a voluntary pay standard?

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary of James MacInnis, a San Francisco lawyer, that appeared in The Times on Sept. 12 cited Mr. MacInnis's defense of Harry Bridges in 1945 and stated that Mr. Bridges, a West Coast labor leader, faced deportation because he had failed to disclose his membership in the Communist Party when he became an American citizen. A Supreme Court ruling held that the Government had not proved such membership.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) A psychiatrist who examined John W. Gacy Jr. to help prepare the defense to 33 counts of murder agreed today to turn over his interview notes to a judge for examination.

title: Celebration of Succoth Will Begin at Sundown
description: Succoth, the Jewish holiday that marks the gathering of the harvest and commemorates the desert wanderings of the ancient Israelites from bondage in Egypt to the Promised Land, begins at sundown this evening.

title: Dance: PeterSparling's'solo Flight
description: PETER SPARLING, best known as one of the leading dancers in Martha Graham's company in recent years, presented a concert of his choreography at the opening of the Riverside Dance Festival on Wednesday night at Riverside Church.

title: Political Succession in Japan Often a Family Affair
description: TOKYO, Oct. 4  When 81-year-old Estusaburo Shiina retired from politics this year after a long career as a member of Parliament, Cabinet minister and kingmaker in the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, he passed the political leadership of Iwate Prefecture in northeastern Honshu, to his 49-year-old son Motoo, an economist.

title: Valdez Takes $106,300 Rutgers
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 4 Aaron U. Jones was on a hunting trip in Idaho, so his wife and coowner represented him in the winner's circle tonight as Valdez, their 3-year-old colt, beat four rivals in the $106,300 Rutgers at the Meadowlands.

title: Washington Governor Closes Nuclear Dump Over Waste Packaging
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., Oct. 4 (AP)  Gov. Dixy Lee Ray has closed a lowlevel nuclear waste dump, one of three in the country, until she receives assurances from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that proper inspections of packaging would be made at the site of origin.

title: NATO Group Said to Back New Missiles in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4  A highranking Atlantic alliance group has recommended approval of an American plan for deployment in Western Europe of 572 nucleararmed missiles that would be capable of striking targets in the Soviet Union, Carter Administration officials said today.

title: Money Supply Up In Week
description: The narrowly defined money supply, M1, increased $800 million in the week ended Sept. 26 to a revised level of $377.8 billion, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Security Is Tight as Hell's Angels Face Trial in DrugsMurder Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4  Eighteen members of the Hell's Angels motorcycle club went on trial here this morning in a specially prepared courtroom under the tightest security ever imposed on the United States Courthouse in the San Francisco Civic Center.

title: About Harlem
description: Why are you going up there? an old friend asked. You don't even go to your own church.

title: Dancers Rediscover the Michio Ito Style
description: A tiny woman strode into the spotlight the other day at the Theater of the Open Eye and, as the rehearsal pianist played a tinkling Delibes theme, the woman began to swing her arms and twist her upper body in a strange, staccato ritual. Dressed in silken, black pajamas ana an orange sasn, tier readish hair gleaming in the white light and her face exotically glamorous, she resembled a latterday Colette.

title: New Face: Scotty Bloch
description: AS Esther Franz, the only woman in Arthur Miller's The Price, now at the Playhouse Theater, Scotty Bloch plays a middleaged woman who finds herself living out a life without fulfillment. She is the wife of Victor  a policeman who gave up a career in science to see his father through his last years. Victor's brother, refusing that responsibility, had gone off to become a successful surgeon.

title: House Unit Will Investigate Safety At Long Island MacArthur Airport
description: RONKONKOMA, L.I., Oct. 4  A Congressional investigation was ordered today into charges by air controllers that there had been many near collisions of aircraft at Long Island MacArthur Airport here and that the controllers complaints had zone unheeded.

title: Europe Bloc to Aid Cambodia
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 4 (Reuters)  The European Common Market Commission has approved emergency aid worth $7 million for starving Cambodians, it announced today. A Commission spokesman said it would account for nearly third of the most pressing needs of 2.5 million people over three months.

title: Origin and Effect of Tornadoes
description: While tornadoes sweep the earth with the most violent winds of any storm, each affects a narrow and relatively short band of territory. In Connecticut they occur somewhat more often than once a year and rarely in populous areas. In Oklahoma, a far larger state in the core of the tornado belt, the yearly average is 65.

title: Notes on People
description: James Stewart, an old hand at softspoken reassurances, kind of sounded like Tom Destry, riding again, the other night. The problem with the country these days, he was saying, is that everyone's talking so darn loud.

title: About Real Estate Jersey Builder of Subsidy Housing Stresses Management
description: HOBOKEN, N.J. The nightmare of officials involved in improving the housing of lowerincome people goes like this: newly built units will be poorly managed; maintenance will slide; subsidy needs will grow; localities will denounce new failures by subsidized housing; Congress will become alarmed; programs will be suspended or funds cut back further than they recently have been.

title: China Residents Now May Seek Millions in U.S. Pension Claims
description: PEKING, Oct. 4  The United States Government may have to pay a large sum to Chinese who have back claims for United States Social Security benefits and pensions that they were unable to collect before the United States and China normalized relations last winter.

title: John C. Traphagen, 90, ExBanker
description: John C. Traphagen, retired president and chairman of the Bank of New York, died Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 90 years old and was a longtime resident of West Nyack, N.Y.

title: Orioles Conquer Angels, 98
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 4  Doug DeCinces planted his feet just off third base, pounded his glove and stared intently at Brian Downing. It was the ninth inning, the California Angels had transformed a 91 Baltimore breather Into a 98 breathstopper, and now they had the bases loaded with two out and Downing. a .326 hitter. at bat.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Oct. 4 (AP) Construction workers accidentally blew a boulder 75 feet through the air, and it smashed into the Olympic bobsled run here and caused damage estimated at $50,000, state authorities confirmed today.

title: The Region
description: HUDSON FALLS, N.Y. (AP)  Several families from the nearby village of Fort Edward were evacuated from their homes for a short while last evening after a freight car began leaking hydrochloric acid, Washington County sheriff's deputies said.

title: Met Family Seen Split on Money
description: An event that may eventually determine whether the New York Mets are sold to John O. Pickett Jr., the New York Islanders' chairman of the board, apparently took place in a fatherdaughter conversation in Maine over the Labor Day weekend.

title: For Children
description: Harvest Day

title: Dow Adds 4.95 on Rise In Dollar
description: A plunge in gold prices and an increase in the value of the dollar against several major foreign currencies enabled the stock market to score a moderate advance yesterday in active trading.

title: U.S. Expects New Surge Of Indochinese Refugees
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)  The Carter Administration told Congress today that there might be another major surge of refugees in Southeast Asia caused by a new Vietnamese offensive in Cambodia as well as by resumed ejections of ethnic Chinese and others from vietnam.

title: Market Place
description: COUPLE of years ago, copper was selling for around 50 cents a pound and some copper issues took a pounding in the stock market as their earnings plummeted. The shares of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, for example, tumbled during 1977 from a high of 41to a low of 18. The Newmont Mining Corporation, another leading domestic producer of copper, saw its stock price cut virtually in half that same year, falling from 30 to 16.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: MONTMAGNY, Quebec, Oct.4 (UPI)  Premier Rene Lvesque said today that Quebec would move to expropriate the Asbestos Corporation, which is 54.6 percent owned by the General Dynamics Corporation.

title: U.S.Australia Tennis Draw Set
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 4(UPI)The United States team completed its preparation today for tomorrow's Davis Cup semifinal against Australia with a highlytuned workout on the White City Center grass courts.

title: Screen: '10' Spoofs Pursuit of Happiness in L.A.:Success Through Failure
description: GEORGE (Dudley Moore) is a very successful composer of popular songs, the kind that a member of the Pepsi generation calls "elevator music," though they've made him rich. He has a long-standing, apparently happy relationship with a good, intelligent woman named Sam (Julie Andrews), who has her own career as a singer. He lives in a lovely hilltop house in Los Angeles, lacks nothing, and is thoroughly miserable. George is 42 years old, and in Southern California you don't even have to be old to be ancient. Everything is too easy out there.Blake Edwards's frequently hilarious new film, "10," is the story of George's desperate efforts to come to terms with life in Southern California even though he knows he's inadequate. Everywhere he goes he sees youth, beauty and health. He drives casually down a street and feels assaulted by the sight of joggers. Nobody seems to drive anymore. They don't even walk. Everybody runs. It's as if their lives were on fire.The movie "10," a reference to the scale by which George rates beautiful women, is almost as much a celebration of the comedy talents of Dudley Moore as "Darling Lili" was a celebration of Mr. Edwards's admiration for his wife, Miss Andrews. Mr. Edwards, though deeply romantic, never lets that get in the way of comedy. Like George, he just can't help himself.This is the biggest, fattest role Mr. Moore has yet had in American films. Though he's already delighted us in "Foul Play" and "Bedazzled," and on the stage in "Beyond the Fringe" and, more recently, in "Good Evening," the revue with Peter Cook, he's never done such a relatively straight role in a film before. He's not entirely comfortable as a romantic leading man, but then "10" doesn't play its romance straight very much of the time.The frame of the film is George's pursuit of a phantom, a beautiful young woman he spots one day as her limosene pulls alongside his Rolls-Royce at a stoplight. The young woman, whom George rates conservatively as an "11," is dressed in a bridal gown and veil and is on her way to the church, which doesn't inhibit George. He sneaks into the ceremony, hides among the flowers and, just as the couple are exchanging vows, gets stung on the nose by a bee.In Mr. Edwards's comic world, noses are meant to be stung, heads to have hangovers, and beautiful women to be pursued at any cost.Learning that the young woman's father is, as someone says importantly, "the most exclusive dentist in Beverly Hills," George allows himself to have eight teeth filled at one sitting to find out more about his mysterious, temporarily lost love. When the usually understanding Sam loses her temper at his unstable ways, George goes on an epic bender and follows the honeymoon couple to their Mexican resort, an overpoweringly picturesque place with a beach too hot to walk barefoot on, rum drinks that look like fancy garbage cans and rope bridges that aren't easily navigated by someone who's been drinking brandy and is loaded with painkillers.George, who is short in stature compared to the rest of the population of Southern California, is most funny when most in peril, which is psychological as often as it's physical. His principal failing is to embark on an endeavor that, for one reason or another, he cannot complete. Success through failure, though, is the way comedies like "10" operate.The movie belongs very much to Mr. Moore, who manages to be funny without ever having to appear stupid. Miss Andrews is on screen for what seems like no time at all, though her no-nonsense presence is essential to much of the comedy, even when she doesn't participate in it. She is the light at the end of the tunnel of George's midlife crisis. A truly magnificent looking young woman named Bo Derek appears as George's phantom-mistress, and she turns out to be almost as funny as Mr. Moore, partly because the character she plays is the only person in the movie who has no doubts about herself.The excellent supporting cast includes Robert Webber as George's song-writing partner, Dee Wallace as a lonely woman who tries to pick up George at the Mexican resort, Max Showalter as the pastor of a fancy Beverly Hills Protestant church and a beautiful blonde named Deborah Rush, who plays the kind of assistant one might expect in the office of the most exclusive dentist in Beverly Hills. She doesn't handle the instruments or prepare the anesthetics. She just sits by the patient's chair and keeps up a running stream of sympathetic moans and winces as the dentist operates.Mr. Edwards's comic gifts haven't been blunted by his recent series of "Pink Panther" hits with Peter Sellers. The film "10" is loaded with odd surprises. It also contains a routine about a nearly blind old lady serving tea, a variation on a routine that Mr. Moore did in his Broadway show with Mr. Cook. It's classically funny no matter who does it.

title: Court Upsets Probation Sentence In Houston Police Brutality Case
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 4  A Federal appeals court today struck down as illegal the suspended sentences, with probation, that were imposed on three former police officers in Houston who were convicted last year of violating the civil rights of a MexicanAmerican who drowned after he was beaten and pushed into a downtown bayou.

title: Screen: 'Something Short of Paradise':Young Gentry?
description: "SOMETHING Short of Paradise" is about a romance so whimsical, so fey and so pointless that it almost doesn't exist. The movie confuses bittersweet rue with post-adolescent mopes, although it really is trying to celebrate the new, young gentry of New York. Where are the adults when we need them?The protagonists in this are a young woman who writes for a magazine and a young man who publicizes movies. She is taller than he is, which is supposed to mean they are adorable, but only makes them look awkward instead. Woody Allen and Diane Keaton get away with this, but they have chemistry going for them, too.Here, however, Susan Sarandon, as the magazine writer, and David Steinberg, as the publicist, share nothing except a desire to kill time. They meet, they dawdle, and one night in her darling studio apartment on the West Side the magazine writer says to herself, "I'm in big trouble." She means she is falling in love with the publicist. It also means she will have a dreadful time worrying about whether she is ready to make a "commitment" and have a "relationship."Consequently, the two of them will break up and make up again and again and again. Maybe the director, David Helpern Jr., and the writer, Fred Barron, are saying this is the new sexuality. Maybe they are saying New York is a place of no sexuality at all. Maybe they just made a dumb movie.Miss Sarandon is dewy and pretty in all this, Faye Dunaway, say, without the hard edges. The problem here, though, is that Mr. Steinberg's character is a klutz, or maybe it is that Mr. Steinberg plays him with such wooden solemnity that he only seems like a klutz. Either way, you will not have the slightest idea of why a woman was attracted to him in the first place. The film opens today at Cinema 2.This film is rated PG (parental guidance suggested), apparently because it has a few mild scenes of partial nudity, and some equally mild suggestive language.

title: At the Movies
description: IF Malcolm McDowell took a particular pleasure in ordering a $40 Pomerol after consultations with the sommelier at lunch one day recently, it was because not so many years ago he was the wine waiter at his father's restaurantpub, The Bull and Dog, in Burscong, a village outside Liverpool.

title: Students Meet With School Chancellor on Sports
description: Student leaders from high schools throughout the city agreed yesterday to give the School Chancellor a week to find a solution to the job action by coaches that has stopped all competitive sports but football.

title: Deaths
description: O'NEILLJeremiah on October 3, 1979. Native of Kenmare, County Kerry, Ireland. Beloved husband of Margaret, devoted father of Lorraine. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Visiting hours 2 to 4 and 6 to 9PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Chapel, Mary Manning Walsh Home, York Ave. at 72nd St. Saturday at 9:30AM

title: Energy Unit Voted By Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4  President Carter's plan to create an energy mobilization board to speed construction of energyproducing and energysaving projects won final approval in the Senate today by a vote of 68 to 25.

title: QADDAFI GREEN BOOK CHARTS LIBYAN PATH
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The notions that women are too fragile to compete with men and that a child belongs at its mother's knee and not in a nursery may not sound particularly progressive. But such convictions amount to revolutionary dogma in Libya today when they are voiced by Col. Muammar elQaddafi.

title: Bride on Honeymoon Dies in Hotel Plunge
description: A bride on her honeymoon was killed as she fell through a 20thfloor window of the Taft Hotel early yesterday. The victim, 20yearold Silvia Irribar de Manini Rios, the wife of a Uruguayan rancher, landed on a secondfloor recess roof of the hotel, which is at Seventh Avenue and 50th Street.

title: Black and Hispanic Police Say Hiring Test Is Unfair
description: The organizations that represent the city's black and Hispanic police officers charged yesterday that a recent Civil Service examination for new officers was unfair to minority members. They said they would take action to bring about police force that better reflected the ethnic composition of the city.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: RICHARD M. WATT tells us that once upon a time, in the 16th century: The Polish Crown ruled over a federation that stretched from the Baltic Sea in the north to the Black Sea in the south. In the east the Polish lands extended almost to the gates of Moscow. In all of Europe, the Polish kingdom was second only to France in size of population.

title: Indictment Charges Professor Used N.Y.U. Laboratory to Make Drugs
description: A prominent professor at New York University was indicted yesterday on charges that he used his university laboratory for the illicit manufacture of LSD, methacivalone and other drugs for profit.

title: Mortimer Moriarty, 62, ExIce Cream Executive
description: Mortimer D. Moriarty, who joined the Good Humor Corporation as a street vendor in 1937 and retired 38 years later as vice president and member of the board of directors, died Wednesday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 62 years old and lived in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Brazilian Police Routinely Torturing Criminal Suspects to Extract Confessions, and Few Citizens Object
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 4  Despite wellpublicized and effective campaigns against the physical abuse of political prisoners, the beating, torture and occasional murder by the police of ordinary criminal prisoners has increased in Brazil and few voices are raised in objection.

title: Family Is Building Plant For Hydropower Upstate
description: STOCKPORT, N.Y.  Adelaide Eckhoff stood at the edge of Stockport Creek the other day and watched the rushing waters tumble down Chittenden Falls on the way to the Hudson River and the sea. Look at all that water going to waste, she said. Her husband, Paul, added, Think of all the electric power it could generate.

title: 2 Rivals for Top Suffolk Post Agree on Most Issues
description: The Democratic and Republican candidates for Suffolk County Executive agreed on more issues than they disagreed on yesterday.

title: Five Robbers Take All At a Big Poker Game And MahJongg Party
description: The weekly mahjongg and poker party at the Towers at Water's Edge in Bayside, Queens, was crashed by five gunmen in ski masks Wednesday night. When the action was over, 37 players had lost $12,000 in cash and $53,000 in jewelry, the police reported yesterday.

title: Getting Away With Murder in Chile
description: Chile's Supreme Court has refused again and finally to extradite three former secret police officials be tried in Washington for the murder of Orlando Letelier. By so doing, Chile thumbs its nose at the United States, and at elemental justice. Strong evidence offered in American courts has shown the assassination was ordered by Chile's secret police. But the Chilean court now calls the evidence too slight to support prosecution even in Chile, let alone extradition. The State Department's prompt protest must now be followed by severe sanctions.

title: Moderate Response to I.B.M. Offer
description: The International Business Machines Corporation's recordsetting $1 billion of notes and debentures were formally offered to investors yesterday, and the securities, the only such I.B.M. debt on the market, evoked a less than hearty response. Late yesterday afternoon, the underwriters estimated that $200 million remained unsold.

title: GERT VON GONTARD, AIDED STAGE CROUPS
description: Gert von Gontard, who devoted the money he inherited as a grandson and heir of Adolphus Busch of the AnheuserBusch brewing company to bringing European theater and opera companies to America, died Saturday in Zurich. He was 73 years old and lived in Zurich and New York.

title: Music: Piano Recital By Magda Tagliaferro
description: WHEN the Brazilianborn French pianist Magda Tagliaferro gave a concert last March at the Salle Gaveau in Paris, it was bruited that her age was 87. Last night she played in Carnegie Hall, for the first time in some 25 years, and it turns out mat sne is 91. At the Paris concert, this listener heard playing that went back to a vanished age. Judging from her reception last night, including a standing ovation at the end, New York audiences are just as eager as Parisian ones to lavigh admiration on this approach to the piano and to Romantic music. some 25 years, and it turns out mat sne is 91. At the Paris concert, this listener heard playing that went back to a vanished age. Judging from her reception last night, including a standing ovation at the end, New York audiences are just as eager as Parisian ones to lavigh admiration on this approach to the piano and to Romantic music.

title: Obituary 9 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Deaths
description: GAVRINJoseph B., The Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York mourns with deepest sorrow the untimely death of Joseph B. Gavrin, close associate and valiant leader for the disadvantaged and the disabled. His was an eminently compelling voice on their behalf. We were honored by his friendship. We extend our prayerful sympathy to his wife Natalie antifamily. Msgr. James J. Murray, Exec. Director Msgr. Robert A. Arple, Director, Dept. of Child Care

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday Films

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Carter Clears Air Routes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)  President Carter approved authority today for 13 United States airlines to fly from American cities to Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

title: Ben Bella Says He Remains Reined Despite Release Order
description: ORAN, Algeria  Ahmed Ben Bella, the Algerian independence leader arrested 14 years ago by his revolutionary comrade, Houari Boumediene, remains under strict lice restraint dite an ostensible orderpo by President Chespad11 Benjedid for his release, according to a wellnlaced Alizerian who saw him recently.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, Oct.6

title: CanadianCuban Hijacking Pact
description: HAVANA, Oct. 4 (Reuters)  Canada and Cuba have renewed their antihijacking treaty for a second term of five years. The pact, signed in February 1973, applies to both planes and ships. There have been no incidents involving them since it was signed.

title: Judge in New Haven Upsets Mayor's Order Closing a Struck Plant
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 4  A state judge ruled today that Mayor Frank Logue had abused his authority in closing the Winchester gun factory here on Monday because he expected violence in connection with a company plan to bring in nonunion workers during a strike.

title: Art People
description: LAST week's announcement of a $210 million market, hotel and cultural complex for the South Street Seaport area brings to mind once again the ruckus over Schermerhorn Row. the historic block that's a Key component of the seaport scene. You may remember that in 1978 a group of artists, longtime residents of the seedy but lowrent houses of the 18th and 19th centuries that make up the Schermerhorn block, were doing battle with the New York State Office of Parks and Recreation, which had taken over the site from the city and planned to renovate its buildings to serve as a maritime museum.

title: Storm Victims Cope With the Unexpected
description: WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., Oct 4 Michael Jepeal, a 25yearold bowlingalley mechanic, was pleading with an elderly woman at the Bradley Bowl here as the roof buckled and then broke in several places.

title: Auctions
description: THE week ahead will see hundreds of 19thcentury European paintings change hands in an impressive run of auctions in at least four houses. In all of these sales the works are grouped by countries so that entnusiasts or, say, tne Italian arm Spanish schools may see what they are interested in without having to view the German and French works. The action begins next Wednesday at PB84, the uptown annex of Sotheby Parke Bernet at 171 East 84th Street, with an auction of 314 relatively modest works. They range in presale estimates from $200 to $6,000 and include art consigned by, among others, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Milwaukee Art Center.

title: World News Briefs
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 4 (Reuters)  Rightists opposed to Prime Minister P. W. Botha's policy of modifying race relations in South Africa stepped up their attacks today after setbacks for Mr. Botha's party in four byelections. The ruling National Party held its four seats in Transvaal region elections yesterday but its majorities were sharply reduced.

title: Mexican Oil Spill Continues, Still Baffling the Experts
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 3  Four months after an oil well in the Gulf of Mexico blew out its fittings, a torrent of oil is still pouring into the maritime environment, and attempts by the Mexican authorities and American contractors to cap the well appear to be floundering.

title: Aides Say Carter Will Enter Race On Dec. 4 and Make a 4Day Tour
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4  President Carter intends to announce his candidacy for a second term on Dec. 4 and set off the next morning on a fourday, nationwide fundraising tour that is expected to raise some $2 million, campaign officials said today.

title: Film: 'Cocaine Cowboys':Powdery Smugglers
description: I GOT no kick from "Cocaine Cowboys." For all the energy it generates, the white powder might just as well have been pulverized Sominex.The flimsy story involves members of a rock group that smuggles the nose candy from Colombia to Montauk, L.I., to make expenses while they're waiting for one of their albums to go platinum. Judging by their music, they're lucky to have gone vinyl.Jack Palance, the only professional in the cast, plays the father of a couple of members of the group. He looks fit and keeps his composure admirably as he tries to play scenes with obvious amateurs. Much of the dialogue seems to have been improvised, but it probably wouldn't have been any better if it had been written down.Andy Warhol, at whose white clapboard summer home in Montauk "Cocaine Cowboys" was filmed, plays himself, lurking around the premises with a Polaroid camera as though he were afraid his tenants were damaging the premises.Mr. Warhol used to be highly regarded as a film maker in some circles. His listlessness, detachment, anomie or whatever it's called, does not exactly light up the screen. Tom Sullivan, who plays the leader of the group, appears not to have a future in front of the camera.The direction, by Ulli Lommel, who has appeared in 13 R. W. Fassbinder films and directed the West German production "The Tenderness of Wolves," is rudimentary. Taken as a whole, "Cocaine Cowboys," which opens today at the Embassy 2 and other theaters, gives the impression of being less a film than the cinematic equivalent of those minimalist arrangements of bricks, cardboard boxes and bits of string.

title: Kim Stops Japanese Foe
description: TOKYO, Oct. 4 (AP)  Sang Hyun Kim of South Korea knocked out Masahiro Yokai of Japan with a powerful leftright combination to the head in the 11th round tonight and retained his World Boxing Council superlightweight championship.

title: Screen: Beauty Meets Beasts in 'Romantic Lover':Battle of the Sexes
description: JUST JAECKIN, the director of "The Last Romantic Lover," had previously established himself as a director of soft-core porn movies ("Emmanuelle"), with a particular fondness for bondage ("The Story of O"). But this time Mr. Jaeckin has made a battle-of-the-sexes comedy, and a relatively prim one by his previous standards. Can it be a sign of the times? Instead of chronicling the soft-focus exploits of a trussed-up heroine, Mr. Jaeckin now tells the story of a bitchy Modern Woman who is reduced  by the power of Love  to an old-fashioned bundle of pliable pulchritude.This heroine, who is supposed to be the editor of a sex magazine, begins the movie as a hard-working harpy in the Faye Dunaway "Network" mode, though the caricature is extreme enough to make Miss Dunaway seem a paragon of mental health by comparison. Elisabeth (Dayle Haddon) is running a beauty pageant for men, and so the first section of the movie follows a parade of reluctant beefcake, as a dozen finalists demonstrate their talents for smooching, dancing and keeping champagne corks from landing in their dates' faces. This is just idiotic enough to be funny, and Mr. Jaeckin handles it with a wit and flamboyance not demonstrated in his oh-so-solemn previous endeavors.The second half of the film follows Elisabeth's adventures after Pierre (Grard Ismael), the contest's surly runner-up, claims her as a kind of door prize. Awarded a 10-day vacation with the woman of his choice, he yanks Elisabeth out of her high-toned surroundings and carries her off to the circus-grounds he calls home. The circus has recently lost its lion, and Pierre has entered the contest only to win enough prize money to buy a new one.He just happens to be the lion tamer. Although he never exactly takes a whip and a chair to Elisabeth, the film's strong implication is that it takes pretty extreme measures to get a woman to act like a woman these days. It is necessary, in order to enjoy "The Last Romantic Lover" as a tender, amusing and perfectly fame-brained fairy tale, to let that notion glide right by.Miss Haddon is so much better here than she was in "North Dallas Forty" that her problem may simply have been one of a language barrier  she seems infinitely more relaxed speaking French in Mr. Jaeckin's film than she did speaking English. She and Mr. Ismael have similarly pouty good looks, and they make a very attractive team, even in the film's most ridiculous moments  like a torment-the-princess scene pilfered from "Freaks" or an episode in which Miss Haddon lies down under an elephant to prove she has spunk.Fernando Rey puts in a delightful appearance as Mr. Ismael's conniving boss, coaxing his young protg into the competition after weeping prodigious crocodile tears at the lion's funeral. The film opens today at the Gemini I.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1979

title: Quake Hits Central Yugoslavia
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 4 (Reuters)  Residents of central Yugoslavia fled from their homes early today when strong earthquake caused some damage but no casualties. The strongest tremors were felt in Sarajevo.

title: Bodies in Chilean Grave May Be Missing Leftists
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 4 (AP) Families of leftists missing nine years in Concepci6n, 300 miles south of here, have been ordered to go to a morgue to try to identify 18 bodies exhumed from a mass grave there.

title: Food Fair Debt Plan Approved
description: Food Fair Inc. received approval yesterday for its preliminary debtrepayment plan in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. The supermarket chain was also granted court approval to proceed with a fiveyear, $205 million capitalimprovements program.

title: Advertising
description: HAVING spent about $120 million in 40 latesummer days to move much of its remaining 1979 inventory, the Chrysler Corporation today will start the first advertising to promote its 1980 Chryslers, Plyrnouths and Dodges. The umbrella theme and one that is consistent with the corporation's past is Chrysler Engineering.

title: Canada Gas Price Expected to Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI)The Energy Department expects Canada to increase the price of natural gas it exports to the United States by about 60 cents per 1,000 cubic foot, senior officials said today.

title: Germans Hedge on Dollar Aid
description: BONN, Oct. 4  United States efforts to explore the possibility of a new international aid package for the dollar have met with only measured West German support, a reception that bankers .and moneymarket analysts consider certain to limit the extent of any such plan.

title: Rock: Shipley and Martin
description: THERE'S a school somewhere that has reduced rock singing, songwriting and stagecraft to series of easy lessons anyone can learn. In addition to gestural classes (Fist Raising. Advanced Crouching, and so on) there are more philosophically oriented courses such as Urban Angst, and of course practical songwriting (Beginning Intermediate and Advanced Melodic Hooks) and singing (Terminal Vibrato is a popular course in this department).

title: Retail Sales Flat in September, Extending a Trend
description: The nation's consumer buying showed further erosion in September, with retail sales running virtually flat in real terms in several of the largest chains, according to reports released yesterday. ne downward trend, which first appeared in May, has worsened in recent months as consumers reacted negatively to the gasoline squeeze, then to continuing inflation and most recently to the growing certainty of a recession.

title: Martin Cleared by MacPhail
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 4  Lee MacPhail, president of the American League, said today that he would take no disciplinary action against Manager Billy Martin of the New York Yankees for the recent incident in which Bob Kammeyer, a Yankee pitcher, hit Cliff Johnson of the Cleveland Indians with a pitch.

title: Publishing: A Heavy  Price for a Heavy  Book
description: BASIC BOOKS has sold the paperback rights to Douglas Hofstadter's Godel, Escher, Bach, to Vintage Books for $200,000. It was more money than Basic Books, a nonfiction publisher whose lists feature studies in the behavioral and social sciences, ever received for rights, and more money than Vintage, a quality paperback house, ever paid for a book. In the light of the sums that swirl around such bestselling authors as Judith Krantz ($3.2 million for Princess Daisy) and Marilyn French ($1.91 million for The Bleeding Heart), the figure for the Hofstadter book may not seem so imposing. But only if you don't know the book.

title: Papal Course For the Clergy
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 4  In his talks to priests and nuns, Pope John Paul II has apparently bolstered the spirits of many of those who have chosen a church vocation, but he has disappointed Roman Catholics who advocate revision of the church's concept of the clergy.

title: What to Know If You're Going
description: The Long Way to Boston will be at The Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam through Nov. 18. Performances are at 8:30 P.M. today, at 5 and 9 P.M. tomorrow and at 5 P.M. on Sunday. Tickets are $8 and $10.50. To reach the theater, take the New England Thruway to the Connecticut Turnpike; take the turnpike to Exit 69 which runs into Route 9; take Route 9 to Exit 7; signs indicate the location of the theater. are $8 and $10.50. To reach the theater, take the New England Thruway to the Connecticut Turnpike; take the turnpike to Exit 69 which runs into Route 9; take Route 9 to Exit 7; signs indicate the location of the theater.

title: Gaffney Injury Puts Pressure on Rookie
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 4  A rookie who has never started a game at wide receiver in high school, college or the pros emerged suddenly today as a critical factor at that position for the Jets contest with the Colts in Baltimore on Sunday.

title: Charges Are Reduced Against 2 Bronx Boys In Deaths of 7 in Fire
description: Two youths indicted for murder when they were 14 years old for a fire that killed seven persons last year in the South Bronx were permitted yesterday to plead guilty to the lesser charge of burglary.

title: It's Orchestra Season At Carnegie Hall
description: THERE is something inherently satisfying about the sight and sound of a symphony orchestra. So ingrained is the look of an orchestra  those neat rows of industrious string players, the rising tiers of winds and brass, the nervously attentive timpanist, the imperious conductor  that the mere sight of one deployed on a stage answers some basic need for order and tradition.

title: S.I. Antiques Fair
description: About 15 antiques dealers from Staten Island will exhibit their wares tomorrow from noon to 6 P.M. at a fair in Tappan Park, Bay and Canal Streets, in the Stapleton section. The fair is sponsored by a local branch of Chemical Bank. The rain date is Sunday. Information: 4428500.

title: Peat, Marwick Vote: It's a Race
description: The orderly world of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co. is being shaken by an unusual insurgent challenge in the election to name a successor to Walter E. Hanson as chairman of the nation's largest accounting firm.tude. An informal man, popular with his colleagues, he is known throughout the Big Eight as an expert in accounting methods and issues.

title: Death and Disease Haunt Thai Camp for Cambodians
description: BAN LAEM, Thailand, Oct. 4 In increasing numbers, skeletal victims of Cambodia's famine are trooping into this Thai border village.

title: AMTRAK PERMITTED TO ELIMINATE TRAINS
description: WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 4 (UPI)  A Federal judge, whose restraining order had forced Amtrak to keep three moneylosing trains running four days past their cancellation deadline, lifted the order today, allowing the railroad to eliminate the trains.

title: WASHINGTON Things We Forget
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 At the very least, Pope John Paul II has demonstrated something we have forgotten in America and even tend to deny: that a solitary individual with strong convictions and noble aspirations still touches the heart of a vast continental nation.

title: Pirates Return Home Seeking the Clincher
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4  The Pittsburgh Pirates came home today only one game short of winning their first National League pennant in eight years, and Manager Chuck Tanner offered a prediction: Affirmed will beat Spectacular Bid all the way Saturday at Belmont Park.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: To celebrate musical instruments and the people who make them by hand, the American Craft Museum, at 44 West 53d Street, has put together a remarkably varied exhibition. Finely crafted violins and lutes, calliopes, a harp strung across elk antlers and something made of a shovel, tin can and wire (for people who dig music) are to be found among the 75 playable objects. Workshops, demonstrations and performances are planned throughout the show, which continues through Dec. 30. William and Mary Buchen will be on hand daily. They work a lot with skulls, bones and gourds, but they will also tell how to make music with, say, a coffee can and string. The museum hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday through Saturday and 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Sundays. Admission is $1; 50 cents for children, students and the elderly.

title: News Summary
description: The Pope visited the heartland of the nation yesterday, emphatically reaffirming in his crosscountry tour that the Catholic priesthood required a lifelong committment from men and was not a proper calling for women. In hectic day of prayer, teaching and touring, Pope John Paul II raced from Philadelphia to Iowa and then to Chicago. [Page A1, Column 1.]

title: Federal Reserve
description: In millions

title: Fay's to Buy Chain
description: LIVERPOOL, N.Y., Oct. 4 (AP) Fay's Drug Stores, an upstate New York chain, said today that it planned to purchase Mann Drugs, a 28store chain in North Carolina.

title: Richard Leakey Ailing in Britain; His Brother Will Donate a Kidney
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 4 (AP)  Richard E. F. Leakey, whose fossil finds helped establish the concept that eastern Africa was the cradle of mankind 3.5 million years ago, is ill in London and will receive a kidney transplant from a brothel', the Leakey family said today.

title: John Paul and Flock of Pilgrims Celebrate Rural Life
description: URBANDALE, Iowa, Oct. 4  They were cold pilgrims, the throng that marched into the Living History Farms to hear Pope John Paul II tell them, The land is not only God's gift, it is also man's responsibility.
