But they were pilgrims, nonetheless, and, from the serious looks on the faces of the sons and daughters of the Middle West, it seemed that they were eager for the responsibility with which the Pope had charged them.

title: Engineers End Strike in Britain
description: LONDON, Oct. 4 (Reuters)  Britain's two million engineering workers today decided to end their one and twoday weekly strikes, which have cost industry hundreds of millions of dollars in lost production over the last 10 weeks.

title: O'Neal, I.C.C. Chairman, To Quit Post at YearEnd
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4  A. Daniel O'Neal Jr., chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, said today that he would not seek reappointment when his term expires Dec. 31. Instead, he said, he would leave the Government, after 13 years of service, for mostly nersonal reasons.

title: Texas County's Officials in a Stalemate With Troopers
description: JOURDONTON, Tex., Oct. 3  At the top of this state's police pyramid are the renowned Texas Rangers. On the next level, but still highly regarded, are the troopers of the Texas Highway Patrol, widely respected in the state for professionalism and evenhandedness in enforcing the law.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: F.T.C. Oil Rule Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI)  Ten oil companies and two oil refiners today asked Supreme Court Justice William Rehnquist to block the Federal Trade Commission's rule on disclosure of franchising operations from taking effect on Oct. 21.

title: London Times Reaches Accord With One Union on a Settlement
description: LONDON, Oct. 4 (UPI)  The Times newspaper group, shut down by a labor dispute since last November, reached agreement today with one of its most militant unions. But other unions must come to terms before The Times and its sister publications reach the streets

title: Paul Silas and SuperSonics Agree on a OneYear Pact
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 4 (UPI)  Paul Silas, the veteran forward, and the Seattle SuperSonics of the National Basketball Association have agreed on a oneyear contract, General Manager Zollie Volchok announced yesterday.

title: Art: The Sculpture Of Louise Bourgeois
description: TO be around in New York in the late 1970's and not know the sculpture of Louise Bourgeois is a considerable deprivation. Posterity may well think it peculiar, in fact, that it was on only on the very frontier of the 80's that her work of the 90's and 50's came to general notice.

title: Injuries Plague Browns, Steelers
description: Two intradivision American Conference games, Pittsburgh at Cleveland and San Diego at Denver, will hold the spotlight in the National Football League on Sunday while the local television watchers have another opportunity to view the home teams, the Giants and the Jets. The Giants are underdogs at home against the league's only remaining unbeaten team, Tampa Bay (Channel 2, 1 P.M.), while the Jets are the favorites for their game in Baltimore against the Colts, one of the N.F.L.'s four teams that have not yet won a game (Channel 4, 4 P.M.).

title: Charles Nehring, 83; RealEstate Executive Helped Start Concern
description: Charles A. Nehring, a realestate executive and cofounder of Nehring Brothers Inc., a New York City realty company, died Monday at a nursing home in Westwood, N.J. He was 83 years old and formerly lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: To Delay SALT Could Destroy It
description: Now that Soviet troops in Cuba no longer provide a pretext for delaying the SALT treaty, its path seems blocked mainly by those who would hold it hostage for a commitment to higher defense spending. Foremost and most clumsily among them stands former President Ford. again sacrificing arms control to his desire to regain the White House. When he shelved his SALT treaty in 1976 to outmaneuver Ronald Reagan, he cost arms control a valuable three years and still lost the Presidency. Yet here he is again, urging delay until Congress passes two larger military budgets.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Economy

title: The Pop Life
description: IN December 1976 the Eagles, a thenpopular rock band, released an album called Hotel California. It did well commercially, and even suggested an artistic growth on the part of the group. But now it's been nearly three years without an album, even though the Eagles haven't broken up or been otherwise traumatized. At long last, we now have The Long Run, the band's latest album. What's so surprising about it is that it gives very little sign of requiring three years labor to produce. album, even though the Eagles haven't broken up or been otherwise traumatized. At long last, we now have The Long Run, the band's latest album. What's so surprising about it is that it gives very little sign of requiring three years labor to produce.

title: Nixons Reported To Have Bought East Side House
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon has given up his plans to buy a $925,000 Fifth Avenue condominium apartment and has instead reportedly purchased fourstory, $750,000 town house at 142 East 65th Street, on one of Manhattan's most exclusive residential blocks.

title: Tentative Agreement Reached In Movie Studio Walkout
description: HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 4 (AP)  Striking office workers, whose walkout has stopped production by some major studios and film processors, have reached a tentative agreement on a contract and might return to work next week, Federal mediator said yesterday.

title: Alcan Price Increase
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 4 (Reuters) The Alcan Aluminum Corporation, United States subsidiary of Alcan Aluminium Ltd., said today that it had increased the price of 99.5 percent minimum purity ingot to 66 cents a pound effective immediately.

title: Rocket Car Flies, Then Falls
description: MORRISBURG, Ontario, Oct. 5Ken Carter's longdelayed international car jump took place today, but Mr. Carter was not at the wheel of his $250,000 rocketpowered vehicle as it took off from an 85foothigh ramp here and sailed into the air toward New York before it plopped down in the St. Lawrence River 50 feet from the Canadian shore.

title: Going out Guide
description: ALL KINDS Although Sotheby Parke Bernet's first auction of contemporary Latin American paintings and sculpture is not until Oct. 17, New Yorkers can see the complete display of art works through Monday, in a preauction showing elsewhere. The works, representing 90 artists from 13 camtries, among them Diego Rivera, Rufino Tamayo, Fernando Botero, Leonor Fini and numerous younger artists, are now on view at the Center for InterAmerican Relations, 680 Park Avenue at 68th Street. The forthcoming sale has been jointly organized by the center and Sotheby Parke Bernet.

title: Curb Asked On Soviet Ammonia
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5  The United States International Trade Commission recommended today that President Carter impose a threeyear quota that would halve previously forecast imports of ammonia from the Soviet Union.

title: Notes on People
description: Mayor Koch and met yesterday with six Soviet dignitaries at City Hall, and they exchanged pleasantries and small gifts while eating little green grapes.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: COMMODITIES Doubt on Dollar Aid Bolsters Gold Futures
description: Gold futures recovered from a threeday decline yesterday on speculation that the Carter Administration might not announce a dramatic dollarrescue plan.

title: KEN STRONG, EXSTAR FOR FOOTBALL GIANTS
description: Ken Strong, one of the first placekicking specialists in the National Football League while playing with the New York Giants, died of an apparent heart attack on a West Side street yesterday. He was 73 years old.

title: Stocks Up Broadly on Big Volume
description: Stock prices advanced along a wide front in heavy trading yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at its highest level in almost a year.

title: Offensive Line Gives Giants Some Cheer
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 5 Why is Ray Perkins smiling?

title: Mayor Approves Foreclosure Suit Over CoOp City
description: Mayor Koch authorized city attorneys yesterday to proceed with foreclosure action against Coop City, the huge, statefinanced housing complex in the Bronx.

title: Rules Changes Proposed On Credit to Consumers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP)  Federal bank regulators announced today that they were considering revisions in truthinlending regulations that would eliminate some of the protection that consumers have from credit errors made by banks and other financial Institutions.

title: Pirates Win National League Pennant in Sweep of Reds
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 5  While their wives danced to disco music on the dugout roof, the Pittsburgh Pirates swept the Cincinnati Reds out of the National League playoff today, 71, and won their first pennant since the days of Roberto Clemente.

title: Dance Theater Gets Grant
description: The Edna McConnel Clark Foundation has awarded a $25,000 grant to the Dance Theater of Harlem for artistic excellence and sound fiscal management. The annual award is the second given to a cultural organization by the foundation, which also provides grants for various judicial and employment projects. Last year's recipient was the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Text of Senate Committee's Findings on Ability of U.S. to Monitor Nuclear Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5  Following is the text of the nonsecret principal findings by the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence on the ability of the United States to monitor the treaty with the Soviet Union to limit nuclear weapons:

title: Knicks Fall To Celtics
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 5 (AP)  Larry Bird scored 19 points tonight, leading a balanced Boston attack as the Celtics defeated the New York Knicks, 111102, in a National Basketball Association preseason game.

title: Israeli Paper Hires Timerman
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 5 (Reuters)  Jacobo Timerman, the Argentine editor freed and sent abroad last week after more than two years under house arrest, has joined the staff of the Israeli newspaper Maariv. the paper announced today.

title: Dr. Anne Thurston Married at Harvard
description: Dr. Anne F. Thurston and Dr. Pat rick Gaynor Maddox, specialists on Chinese politics, were married yesterday in the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Charles Reinhardt, a Unitarian minister at Harvard, performed the ceremony.

title: Real 'son of Sam Dies In a Crash on Highway
description: A son of Sam Carr, the Yonkers man who owned the dog that David R. Berkowitz said had ordered him to kill, died in an automobile crash in Manhattan. the police reported.

title: Qualities of Pope as a Man: His Spontaneous Moments
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 5 What kind of a man is this Pope who is striding across America?

title: Senator Warns U.S. Regulators Of Stricter Scrutiny by Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP)  Government regulators, especially the Federal Trade Commission, were warned today that they would face tough, new scrutiny on Capitol Hill to make certain they were not overregulating.

title: Victory Is Sweet, as Pirates' Wives Dance
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 5  The quailandpheasant season opened for the Cincinnati Reds a few minutes after 5 P.M. today on a signal from Willie Stenzel!.

title: Carter Declares He Can Whip Kennedy in Test
description: President Carter told a group of New York State political leaders at the White House yesterday that he could whip Senator Edward M. Kennedy in a New York orimarv.

title: Plans for a Hotel At Times Square Nearer to Reality
description: Negotiations are reported to be nearing completion with a Londonbased organization to operate a proposed 52story, 2,020room hotel on Times Square between 45th and 46th Streets.

title: Cavaliers Trade Chones To Lakers for Robisch
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers, in need of center because of Elmore smith's aching knees, traded Jim Chones to the Los Angeles Lakers for Dave Robisch and a 1980 thirdround draft choice. The 6foot 11inch Chones started at forward or center the last five seasons with Cleveland. H was slated to play forward this season, with Smith, who underwent knee surgery In the offseason, returning to center. Smith has seen little action during the preseason.

title: The City
description: A group of religious, political and business leaders representing both blacks and Jews banded together to work for racial and religious harmony lathe city.

title: World Pact on Rubber Price Reached
description: GENEVA, Oct. 5  The countries that are the leading producers and consumers of natural rubber concluded an international pact today aimed at stabilizing the world price of the commodity.

title: 120 in Denver Police Night Shift Call in Sick in Protest Over Pay
description: DENVER, Oct. 5 (AP)  About 120 of the 142 patrolmen scheduled to report to work in Denver tonight called in sick to register their unhappiness with raises offered by the city.

title: Angels Win, 43
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 5  Teetering on the brink of elimination from their first postseason encounter, the California Angels dramatically rallied for two runs in the ninth inning tonight and edged the stunned Baltimore Orioles, 43.

title: In Thriving Land, East Germans Persist in Risky Escapes to West
description: WEST BERLIN, Oct. 5 On Tuesday night a 24yearold waiter dug his way out of East Germany with his bare hands. According to the West German border police, who watch over the 857 miles of wall, electrified fence and fortifications that the East Germans have built to separate themselves from the West, no one ever escaped that way before.

title: Back to Basketball and Bargaining
description: If Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn wants win the public school basketball championship again this year, it first has to field a team. But the school can't do that without a coach  and the coach, like his colleagues in other varsity sports, refuses to work until the Board of Education restores wages and workhours taken away four years ago. The coaches have made their point. They're overworked and underpaid. But the school system, faced this year with real financial troubles, can't do anything about it now. If, as the coaches claim, they care about the kids, the surest way to show it would be to go back to work.

title: Koreans Celebrate Harvest With a Parade
description: Members of the Korean community in New York parading down Broadway near 30th Street yesterday in celebration of the traditional harvest festival. Drums and cymbals accompanied the marching and dancing as did a light drizzle. The rain turned heavier as the day wore on, tapering off last night. Today should be breezy and mild.

title: Bill Rates Set Records at Sale
description: Rates on United States Treasury bills soared to records yesterday in an auction that drew a relatively small number of unusually widespread bids.

title: A Spear Carrier at Belmont
description: It was after 10 A.M., but the press still had not bothered to show up at Silent Cal's barn yesterday in the Belmont Park stable area.

title: Repertorio Espanol Offers La Casa de Bernarda Alba
description: La Casa de Bernarda Alba (The House of Bernarda Alba), Federico Garcia Lorca's play about a domineering woman and her five daughters, will be performed in Spanish by the Repertotio Espafiol in an openended run, beginning Oct. 16, at the Gramercy Arts Theater. 138 East 27th Street. The play, the first production this season by the company, will be joined in repertory through Dec. 16 by Te Juro Juana, Que Tengo Ganes, by Emilio Carballido.

title: Canadian Sees Lebanese Leader
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 5 (Reuters) Canadas special envoy to the Middle East, Robert L. Stanfield, met with President Elias Sarkis today and discussed the conflict in southern Lebanon in particular and the ArabIsraeli conflict in general. Lebanese officials said. The tour was organized after Arabs threatened a boycott against Canada if Prime Minister Joe Clark carried out an election pledge to transfer Canada's embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

title: Your Money
description: MANY people religiously observe a Friday riturushing to the bank to deposit their payroll checks. Then they cross their fingers and hope that the salary checks are credited to their checking accounts before the checks they wrote earlier in the week, when their balances were close zero. are processed.

title: 18 Saratoga Horsemen Begin Suspension Terms
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Oct.5 (AP)  Eighteen Saratoga harness horsemen who were ordered suspended last Aug. 11 for illegal use of a diuretic have dropped plans to appeal the penalty imposed by the State Racing and Wagering Board and have begun serving their suspensions.

title: South Africa's Censor Relieved of His Duties After a Literary Storm
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 5 (UPI)  The Government relieved South Africa's chief censor of his duties today.

title: W. RUSSELL ARRINGTON
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 5 (AP)  W. Russell Arrington, a top official with the Combined Insurance Company of America, died Wednesday. He was 73 years old.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times on Sept. 3 incorrectly indicated that the ballad The Town I Loved So Well was written by Paddy Reilley. Although Mr. Reilley sings the song on a record popular in Northern Ireland, the ballad was composed by Phil Coulter.

title: Bridge:
description: When the world team championship was last staged in Rio de Janeiro, decade ago, a sextet from the Far East stunned the badge world by taking second place, behind Italy but ahead of the United States, France and Brazil. Two of the Taiwanese players who achieved this result, Patrick un and Dr. C. S. Shen, will be trying to repeat their accomplishmet in the same location next week, or even improve on it.

title: GERTRUDE RAPPLEYEA
description: Gertrude Rappleyea, a schoolteacher in Kingston, N.Y., and the mother of the Rev. Robert Rappleyea, pastor of Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church on West 424 Street in Manhattan, died last Saturday at her home in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. She was 85 years old.

title: Polls Say Japanese Prime Minister Will Gain in Tomorrow's Elections
description: TOKYO, Oct. 5  As Japan prepares to hold general elections on Sunday, the latest polls indicate that Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira will emerge with stronger hold on power.

title: Minor Earthquake in California
description: PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 5 (UPI) The seismological laboratory at the California Institute of Technology today registered a minor earthquake centered nine miles southeast of Lake Elsinore. The quake measured 3.4 on the Richter scale. There were no reports of injury or damage.

title: All 3 Commercial TV Networks Shift Schedules Early in Season
description: The new television season has barely begun, and the three networks have already started the doctoring of their primetime program schedules.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5  The Senate Intelligence Committee said today that the strategic arms treaty enhances the ability of the United States to monitor the development and deployment of Soviet strategic nuclear weapons.

description: A waterfront businessman testified in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday that he had made unlawful labor payments to Anthony Scotto.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: TORONTO, Oct. 5 (AP)  Brascan Ltd., the Canadian hol company, said today that it had about 10 percent of Noranda Mines Ltd., the Torontobased gold, silver and copper producer, for about $160 million.

title: Woman Is Hurt By Fall Into Hole
description: A 20yearold Alitalia Airlines stewardess who was windowshopping on a midtown street suffered cuts, bruises and probable fractures at 12:50 P.M. yesterday when she plunged into a 20footdeep hole in the sidewalk at 17 East 45th Street.

title: The Way to Move Transit Forward
description: New York voters will have a chance to alleviate subway, commmuter and other state transportation problems by supporting a bond issue that will be on the November ballot. Despite its many good features, opposition to the transportation bond issue has arisen on the ground that it would not provide enough aid to New York City. A bigger bond issue might be possible in the future, it is argued, if this one were defeated. In fact, this bond issue would provide the city with vital help for subways and commuter rail lines; its defeat would probably make it harder, not easier, to pass another bond issue later. City, suburban and upstate New Yorkers have much to gain from the passage of this proposition and much to lose from its defeat.

title: I.B.M.'s Yield Hurts Issue Sales
description: I.B.M. notes, priced on Wednesday to give investors a little more yield than they could get on Treasury notes, now yield slightly less, and the reversal is hurting sales of the computer manufacturer's securities. A spokesman for Salomon Brothers, the managing underwriters, reported yesterday that I.B.M.'s $500 million of notes and $500 million of debentures were each about 80 percent cent sold, little changed from Thursday, though some institutional investors suggested that these estimates were too high.

title: Jazz: Highlights Concerts Begin
description: Jack Kleinsinger's Highlights in Jazz concert series began its new season Thursday night at New York University with a soldout auditorium and an irresistible program. Three bluesoriented, Texasborn saxophonists Arnett Cobb, Buddy Tate and Eddie (Cleanhead) Vinson  performed together and separately with various configurations drawn from an exceptlona 11 y accomplished rhythm section. Five of the eight musicians have been playing together as a unit, and some of them have known one another for decades. Their interplay was relaxed and polished, but it was never slick. In fact, for a program built around a proved combination and a basic jamsession repertory, the show was full of surprises.

title: Piano: Alexis Weissenberg
description: Alexis Weissenberg has his admirers, and they were vociferous in their approval of the pianist's recital at the 92d Street Y on Thursday night. And on purely pianistic grounds there were good reasons for applause and wonderment at his technical resourcefulness, an astonishing muscular control that allows him to toss off the scherzo of Chopin's B minor Sonata at breakneck speed with extraordinary accuracy and evenly accented articulation.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5  A sniper holding a woman hostage and warning that he held a cache of nitroglycerin fired shots from a rifle onto the streets of downtown San Francisco this evening, wounding a man and immobilizing a fiveblock area.

description: WHITE PLAINS  Consolidated Edison has spent $700,000 since January to defeat Proposition 1, a proposal to be placed before Westchester  County voters next month to authorize a county publicutility agency that would prepare the way for a possible county takeover of Con Edison's electric distribution facilities.

title: New York Regional Labor Statistics Give Little Indication of Recession
description: September uemloyment figures showing little change in New York State but a sharp decline in New Jersey provided no significant evidence of the much heralded recession, Herbert Bienstock, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said yesterday.

title: Dunne Quits Committee Post
description: ALBANY, Oct. 5 (UPI)  Warren M. Anderson of Binghamtonm, the State Senate's majority leader, said he had accepted the resignation of John R. Dunne as head of the Senate Insurance Committee. Mr. Dunne, Republican of Garden City, L.I., asked to withdraw from the nost because he had entered into a new professional association in his private law practice that he felt made it inappropriate for him to serve, a statement from Mr. Anderson said yesterday. A spokesman for Mr. Dunne said the Senator had recently begun work with the Long Island law firm of Rivkin, Left & Sherman, which represents several insurance companies.

title: Film: Australian 'Brilliant Career' by Gillian Armstrong:The Cast
description: "My Brilliant Career" marks the beginning of exactly that for both the film's daring, assured, high-spirited Australian director, Gillian Armstrong, and its rambunctious young star. Adapted from a semi-autobiographical novel of the same name, it offers a turn-of-the-century heroine who seems to have wandered from the pages of a Louisa May Alcott novel into the Australian Outback, where her buoyant sense of mischief takes on the same grand dimensions as the exotic, perpetually surprising terrain.Sybylla Melvyn (played by Judy Davis, making her movie debut) is supposed to be plain. And she's sufficiently strange-looking, by movie-star standards, to strike the viewer as being something less than a ravishing beauty. But that effect lasts only a short while  only for as long as it takes to realize that Miss Davis brings an unconventional vigor to every scene she's in, even in a film that's as consistently animated as this one. Her Sybylla is a coltish creature, creating a merry chaos wherever she goes.Because her mother has been married badly, Sybylla grows up in relatively impoverished surroundings. Then, at the age of 18 or so, she is sent to live with her wealthy grandmother, who is no great advocate of sprightly behavior. Nevertheless, Sybylla flourishes, especially after making the acquaintance of handsome Harry, the most eligible bachelor in the area. If this sounds like the backdrop for something like "The Thorn Birds," well, it plays a bit like an extravagantly old-fashioned romance, too. Sybylla, who has been well warned that someone like Harry (Sam Neill) can never marry someone like her, continues to defy social convention, with her flashing eyes and her wicked smile and her propensity for starting pillow fights in the middle of the afternoon. After a very sweet and feisty courtship, she lands Harry anyhow.However, and unfortunately, she does not want him  she wants to be a writer (hence the title). Never mind the fact that Sybylla has heretofore done her only writing while sitting on a tree branch, with a kitten in her lap. Miss Armstrong suddenly insists on Sybylla's independence, and tosses Harry to the vultures, and more or less knocks the audience on its ear. Is the viewer being hopelessly old-hat in feeling that Harry  who is handsome and nice, and says he would be delighted to see Sybylla pursue her career  isn't such a bad bet? Apparently so.Miss Armstrong does little to prepare her audience for such a radical wrench  especially because the best parts of her film have shown Sybylla to be intelligently, ecstatically, even magically infatuated with this man. Besides, "My Brilliant Career" doesn't need to trumpet either its or its heroine's originality this loudly. The facts speak for themselves  and so does the radiance with which Miss Armstrong and Miss Davis invest so many memorable moments."My Brilliant Career" will be shown tonight at 9 o'clock and next Saturday at 6 P.M., as part of the New York Film Festival.

title: Gerulaitis Pulls Out 5Set Cup Triumph
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 5 (AP) Vitas Gerulaitis scrambled from triple match point down to beat Australia's Mark dmondson in the first singles match of the 1978 Davis Cup semifinals today, giving the United States a 10 lead.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Stock exchanges and commodities exchanges in the United States will be open for business Monday, but most banks will be closed in observance of Columbus Day.

title: Vance Plans to Visit Yugoslavia, Rumania; Link to Troops Denied
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance may visit Rumania and Yugoslavia in December but State Department officials are stressing that such a visit would not be a response to the presence of Soviet troops in Cuba.

title: Classical Way Wins Futurity
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 5  Classical Way, a strongboned filly outtrotted eight male 3yearolds today in straight heats and won the $100,000 Kentucky Futurity, the third leg of the trotting triple crown. John Simpson Jr. drove the Speedy Scot filly to victories in 1:57 4/5 and 1:59 on the Red Mile track. Chiola Hanover, the winner of the first triple crown leg  the Yonkers Trot  chased the filly home in the deciding heat, losing by neck, after the Hambletonian winner, Legend Hanover, was second in the first brush by a length and a half.

title: Spill It, Buster
description: There is something very uncomfortable, almost humiliating, about taking a liedetector test.

title: Armani Triumphant: Italy Crowns Its Fashion King
description: MILAN, Oct. 5  Giorgio Armani, flanked by his assistants, walked somewhat wearily into the Saint Andrew's Restaurant at the fairgrounds here after presenting his spring and summer collection as part of the week of fashion showings. People at the table nearest him burst into applause. Those at the next table picked it up. It was a triumphal march as he moved to his place amid thunderous approval. Thus the fashion world annointed new king.

title: Criticisms Of Cardinal Are Muted
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 5 Earlier this year  group of priests asked that  Vatican observer come to this archdiocese to monitor the leadership of Its embattled John Cardinal Cody.

title: Gettin Outta Stir
description: Step out the door of this office at five o'clock for the very last time. Leave the yapping secretaries far behind. Say so long to my telephone. Kiss the water cooler (my only friend) goodbye. Blow kisses to the file cabinets, to the clock upon the wall.

title: $5 Billion Audit Gap In Nigeria
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 5 Perhaps $5 billion in Nigerian oil revenues is unaccounted for, creating a political storm for the civilian Government, so new its Cabinet has yet to be named.

title: Brooks Stanwood, Author of Thriller on Joggers, Is Really a Couple
description: The name, Brooks Stanwood, sounds so elegant, so proper, so literary. The perfect name to add a touch of class to a book jacket. Just one question: Is Brooks Stanwood a man or a woman? Answer: Neither. Brooks Stanwood is really a West Side manandwife writing team named Howard Kaminsky and Susan Stanwood Kaminsky.

title: Court Reprieves 3 Amtrak Trains
description: DENVER, Oct. 5 (AP)  The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit today reversed a lower court's decision and ordered Amtrak to continue operating three moneylosing trains until Oct. 26.

title: Cosmos Tie in Indonesia
description: DJAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 5 (UPI)  Giorgio Chinaglia scored the Cosmos goal in a 11 tie with an Indonesia allstar soccer team today. The tie gave the Cosmos a 222 wonlosttied record on their 13game tour, which resumes Sunday in Singapore.

title: Music: Singer and Calliope
description: An instrumental quartet that calls itself Calliope after the muse of heroic poetry really needs a singer to justify its name. The ensemble had such a guest artist Thursday night in its first concert of the season, at Abraham Goodman Hall. She was none other than Jan deGaetani, a soprano who is at home in all ages of music and lent her extraordinary artistry to this program of Renaissance works.

Truxton Hare, Bill Hollenback, Henry Miller, Bob Odell, George Savitsky or Chuck Bednarik. In fact, this year's Penn squad appears to be one of the most inept teams in the 103 seasons of Quaker football.

title: Vindication and the Addonizio Case
description: He was never a political prisoner, but his supporters in Newark waved banners saying Free Addonizio and contended that he was being discriminated against because of his Italian name. Now the United States Parole Commission has formally freed the former mayor of Newark. The commission had already won the important point that it is the job of the commission, not of the sentencing judge, to determine when prisoner should be set free. And it has decided in this case that there is no need to return the aging convict jail.

title: Pope's Statement on Women as Priests Is Praised and Resisted
description: Some approved, some disapproved, and some hedged, believing that as strong as the statement was, it was not the final word. Opinions were divided about equally but few were indifferent to the reaffirmation Thursday by Pope John Paul II that the priesthood was not a proper calling for women.

title: Ted Fritsch, 58, Played Fullback For Packers From 1942 to 1950
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 5 (AP)  Ted Fritsch, a former Green Bay star who scored both touchdowns when the Packers beat the New York Giants, 147, for the 1944 National Football League championship, died last night of an apparent heart attack. Be was 58 years old.

description: BAN LAEM, Thailand, Oct. 4 I am faithful to Pol Pot, a hardfaced but softspoken Cambodian soldier said. Everybody, military uring and civilianwas is for Pol Pot, because during his day all was well.

title: Growth In Credit Is Steady
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UPI)  The growth of consumer credit held steady at $2.45 billion in August, evidence that shoppers are still using their credit cards despite record high interest rates and signs of a deepening recession, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: About New York
description: New York is a city in motion, a difficult city to pin down. Yet there are those who check headway between buses, a controversial art, and there are those on vigil to assure that subway trains do not run too close to each other. Cars drive past monitors that keep count of how many are passing and at what time. The city in motion must always know what it is up to.

title: Business Records
description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1979

title: Film: A Young Egyptian Dreaming of Hollywood:The Cast
description: Yehia, a young Egyptian-Christian growing to maturity in World War II, is dazzled by American movies and movie stars, even by Leo, the lion whose roar announces the start of every M-G-M picture. He dreams of one day going to Hollywood and becoming a famous actor or writer or director. Why, he asks himself, did he have the rotten luck to be born in Alexandria? Hence the title, "Alexandria . . . Why?" for the mass-market Egyptian film that will be shown at the New York Film Festival in Lincoln Center today at 6 P.M. and tomorrow at 9:30 P.M.The festival program suggests that Youssef Chahine, the film's 54-year-old director, "proves that sheer energy and generosity are not inconsiderable virtues," though what are described as sheer energy and generosity look more like a confusion of narratives and an uncontrollable desire to snare the widest possible audience in this day of liberated Egyptian policies."Alexandria . . . Why?" is a commonplace mess that attempts to fuse the clichs of the popular cinema into a kind of pop epic, but Mr. Chahine doesn't have the talent or the discipline to fuse clichs into anything except a daisy-chain of peculiar events.In addition to the story of Yehia (Mohsen Mohiedine), who attends Victoria College and, like Judy Garland and Mickey Rooney in "Babes in Arms," decides to "put on a show," the plots of the movie include one about a family (Yehia's) that's about to be dispossessed because the father, a lawyer, refuses to take cases he doesn't believe in; one about an Egyptian-Arab patriot who falls in love with an Egyptian-Jewish girl; one about another young Egyptian fellow who falls in love with the English soldier he was planning to execute for political reasons, and one about the members of an ineffectual Egyptian underground organization who plan to assassinate Churchill.Mr. Chahine directs this material with all of the authority and humor of the driver of a runaway stagecoach. He helps himself to a lot of newsreel footage (shots of Hitler, Churchill, cities being bombed, the various battles of North Africa), which, instead of certifying the fiction, make it look more implausible.I suppose that a movie that includes a love affair between an Arab and a Jew might seem avant-garde in Cairo, but it has the air of something gratuitous to us, especially when the Jewish girl must, in effect, disassociate herself from Israel and Zionism. By way of explaining the troubles that Israel has brought to the world, someone says, "Every Jew now belongs to a country different from that of his birth." Even the refugees from the concentration camps.

title: Man Killed and 3 Hurt In Brooklyn Ax Attack
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested early today in connection with the death of his brotherinlaw and the wounding of his wife, daughter, and motherinlaw at 2055 Ocean Avenue in the borough's Sheepshead Bay section late last night. The police said the attacks were committed with what they described as an oldfashioned ax.

title: Deaths
description: BRUSHRobert H., on Oct 4, 1979. Son of the late Henry and Elizabeth Flagg Brush. Brother of the late Edward Neville. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home 8020 Roosevelt Avenue, Jackson Heights. Funeral service Saturday 10AM.

title: U.S, RIFT WITH SEOUL OVER RIGHTS WIDENS
description: Envoy Called Home for Discussion, but Brown Will Go to KoreaWASHINGTON, Oct. 5  The United States called home its Ambassador to South Korea today for consultations in response to the latest repression of the political opposition there.

title: Suspect in Sales of Guns Found Slain in Brooklyn
description: A 19yearold Brooklyn man who was arrested a month ago on charges of stealing and selling handguns was found strangled early yesterday morning in the Bay Ridge section of the borough, the police said.

title: Another Jet Rookie Will Get His Chance
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 5 Where were you at? Marvin Powell asked Greg Buttle after practice today.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1979

title: London's Exclusive Little Bank
description: LONDON, Oct. 5  Black top hats perch on a ledge overlooking an antique, coalburning stove. Behind oldfashioned brass grills sit tellers who can supply customers with snuff as well as cash. Liveried attendants mill about the rough stone floor, politely challenging strangers who might wander past the golden bottle hanging outside and into the venerable premises of Messrs. C. Hoare & Company, bankers.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (Reuters) The United States has resumed delivery of spare parts for Iran's Americanbuilt military aircraft, the Pentagon said today.

title: No BL Ltd. Rescue Plan
description: LONDON, Oct. 5 (Reuters)  The British Industry Secretary, Keith Joseph, told union leaders today that there was no hope of an immediate Government cash injection to save jobs at BL Ltd., according to Britain's domestic news agency, The Press Association. The stateowned company plans to close all or parts of 13 plants, laying off 25,000 workers.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Verdi's Otelto, 2, and Massenet's Werther, 8.

title: POPE FIRMLY DEFENDS CHURCH RESTRICTION ON CONTRACEPTION
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 5  Pope John Paul II, deploring onslaughts of materialism, rampant secularism and moral permissiveness, today issued the staunchest defense of Roman Catholic teachings on sexuality that he has made in his current visit to the United States. Included in that defense was the church's ban on artificial birth control.

title: I.C.C. Acts on Rail Line, Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a takeover by seven railtoads of service on the Western lines of the financially ailing Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad Company.

title: Letter: On Tax Indexing
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON INVENTORS seem to be as active as ever, working on everything from mousetraps to nuclear reactors, but they are receiving fewer patents these days. In the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, about 51,600 invention patents were issued, down from the yearearlier 65,963 and the lowest in 15 years.

title: Soviet and East Germans Sign an Economic Pact
description: EAST BERLIN, Oct. 5  The Soviet Union and East Germany signed an economic accord today that will provide East Germany with Soviet oil, gas and nuclear equipment until 1990 in exchange for ships, toolmaking machinery and chemical equipment.

title: Bonn and U S., Set Pact on Coal Plant
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) West Germany and the United States signed an agreement today to build a liquefied coal plant at Morgantown, W.Va., at a cost expected to reach nearly $1 billion. West Germany will pay 25 percent of the cost.

title: Webster to Get Cast on Leg
description: Marvin Webster, the ailing Knick center, decided yesterday to have his right leg placed in a cast rather than attempt to cure his tendinitis of the knee with antiinflammatory drugs. Dr. Norman Scott, the team doctor, will immobilize the right knee Monday by placing it in a hiptoankle cast.

title: Poles and Hispanics Join Pope in Prayers
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 5  Firm in the pulpit but gentle in the streets, Pope John Paul II completed his visit to the largest center of American Roman Catholicism today.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Gold Finishes Stronger After Day of Fluctuation
description: Gold prices fluctuated in hectic trading yesterday and closed higher for the first time in three sessions, at least temporarily halting a plunge that saw the price of bullion drop by $81 an ounce in less than four days.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, Oct. 6

title: CREDIT MARKETS Interest Rates Set Marks; Rumors Buffet Trading
description: The credit markets continued to deteriorate yesterday, pushing bond prices down and interest rates to records, as waves of rumor and fact unsettled trading.

title: OBSERVER A Farewell To Loins
description: Out of the attic where she had been rummaging among my secret treasures came a dear, sweet child with a novel published thirty years ago and tucked away almost ever since for clandestine reading on a dim night in February.

title: Deaths
description: LOEWHugo, Dr. on October 5, 1979. Devoted husband of Marie. Beloved father, fatherInlaw, grandfather, and greatgrandfather. Services ParkWest Chapel, 79th St & Columbus Ave, 12:00 noon, Sunday October 7.

title: Canada Raising NaturalGas Price
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 5 (AP)  Canada will raise the price of natural gas it exports to the United States to $3.45 (United States) per 1,000 cubic feet from $2.80, effective Nov. 3, it was announced today.

title: Fight on Inflation Vowed As I.M.F. Meeting Ends
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 5The annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund closed today on a note of grim determination that inflation in the United States and other countries must be brought under control even if it means higher unemployment and slower world economic growth.

title: Dozens Arrested in Nicaragua
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 5 (Reuters)  Dozens of people were arrested for questioning here today in what was officially described as a security operation by the Sandinist Liberation Army to weed out suspected counterrevolutionary elements.

title: Fisher Resigns as M.T.A. Head
description: Harold L. Fisher submitted his resignation yesterday as chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and Governor Carey accepted it.

title: Cubans Rally Near U.N. Against Absent Castro
description: More than 3,000 antiCastro Cubans demonstrated outside the United Nations today against the island's ruler, who had been expected to appear but did not. A smaller group of his supporters also were on hand.

title: The F.D.A.'s New Chief
description: If there's any surplus compassion around, part of it ought to be directed to the pharmacyschool dean who was recently named to head the Food and Drug Administration, Dr. Jere Edwin Goyan. He is leaving a prestigious and wellpaid University of California post for one of Washington's most controversial and politically sensitive jobs.

title: Books of The Times The Economics of Fame
description: ANNALSLS OF AN ABIDING LIBERAL. By; John Kenneth Galbraith. Edited by Andrea D. Williams. 384 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $12.95.

title: Nepal in Turmoil as Vote To Modernize Rule Nears
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  Early this week a group of men and women rolled boulders down a steep hillside, setting off an avalanche that they apparently hoped would crush the car of Nepal's leading liberal politician.

title: RADIOACTIVE WASTE MAY GET NEW DUMPS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) The Nuclear Regulatory Commission warned more than a year ago that disposal of radioactive wastes at commercial dumps posed urgent problems and asked the Department of Energy to make Government burial sites available if necessary.

title: Fairchild Bid a Bunker Ramo Problem
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 5There is no great mystery as to why Fairchild Industries is so persevering in its efforts to acquire the Bunker. Ramo Corporation. Among otheradvantages, the combination would help diversity Fairchild's heavy reliance on aerospace contracts.

title: Building a Bigger Paine Webber
description: James Waring Davant, chairman of Paine Webber Inc., was in London last week and on his way to the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund in Belgrade when a series of calls to his office convinced him to get back to New York. His sixyear, onagain, offagain pursuit of a merger with Blyth Eastman Dillon was finally bearing fruit, even sooner than Mr. Davant had anticipated.

title: No Title
description: Diana Erskine Westcott Wed To David Jeremy Paterson

title: Labor and Management: Cutting Costs to Save Jobs
description: The negotiations last month between the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union generated some of the usual thunder. But there was one issue  absenteeism  that was resolved with little apparent acrimony.

title: GARDENING
description: THIS is a critical time of year for house plants, especially those that spent the summer outdoors. If left outside too long, obviously, they will freeze. Less obvious is that even chilled plants may be damaged.

title: Where Have You Gone, Joe DiMaggio?
description: IF you like to take your baseball with a glass of Pouilly Fuiss or the images of LeRoy Neiman, you'll love everything about this book.

title: Austin Artificial Moonlight Towers Cast Shadows
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 6 (AP)  Since May 6, 1895, lights on the tops of a series of towers have provided a warm, moonlightlike glow over Austin. Romantics say the towers are historic. The man who has to keep the lights working on the 165foot structures is not so sentimental.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WITH cold weather fast approaching, and with fuel costs almost certain to keep rising, homeowners continue searching for ways to keep fuel bills from climbing excessively. One of the first things most people think of is adequate insulation in walls and ceilings  without realizing that as much heat  and sometimes even more  can be lost through cold air infiltration.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: As the Pope talked to the people, in Ireland and the United States, the charisma of the office and the charm of the man fused into one remarkable, and somewhat inscrutable, phenomenon.

title: Jeanne W. Campbell Is Married
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset, L.I., yesterday, Jeanne Warren Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Campbell of Plandome, L.I., was married to Walter Cabot Sedgwick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellery Sedgwick Jr. of Cleveland. The Rev. Frank N. Johnston performed the ceremony.

title: CHILDREN'S BOORS
description: TUE WITCH'S GARDEN

title: Princeton Ceremony Dedicates a Memorial To Kent State Victims
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 6  Princeton University yesterday dedicated a memorial to the four Kent State University students killed by National Guardsmen nine years ago.

title: Blacks Fear Loss of Stake In Spinney Hill Business Project
description: MANHASSET THE three new buildings about to be put up in the Spinney Hill section of Northern Boulevard are intended to revitalize the area commercially. But local residents and community leaders fear that little of the money generated by new business will remain in the neighborhood and that the development's major effects will be increased traffic and congestion.

title: WASHINGTON A Revival Of Hope?
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  Pope John Paul II arrived in Washington just when we needed him. In recent days, this city has been down in the dumps, thinking about oil, prices, and politics. an unholy trinity  but at least for a little while he has turned our minds to different and nobler things.

title: Dance: Hannah Kahn's 5
description: Hannah Kahn is a dancer of taste and intelligence. She works with dancers of equal quality so that her concerts are dependably well and imaginatively danced. On Friday at Larry Richardson's Dance Gallery, however, Miss Kahn presented new moderndance works that were fully as rewarding as their performances.

title: Jerry Bregstein, a Realty Official, Dies Following Virginia Air Crash
description: Jerry Bregstein, a partner in the CooperBregstein Realty Company in Manhattan, died Tuesday at Washington Hospital Center in Washington. He was 63 years old and had recently been injured in a crash in Norfolk, Va., involving his own airplane.

title: NASSAGE THERAPY
description: There is no doubt that a relaxed person looks and feels better than someone who is tense. The difference is apparent in their facial expressions, carriage and disposition. The contrast becomes even more dramatic when that tension turnsto pain  headaches, back aches, stiff necks and throbbing calves.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Eddye Pierce Berry displayed a voice of unusually promising quality at her New York recital debut Friday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. The young soprano, who studied at the University of Colorado and has sung with a number of opera companies in this country, also chose a program that sensibly did not overtax the essentially light, lyrical nature of her instrument.

title: Temple Quarterback Routs Rutgers, 4120
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Oct. 6  Temple insisted on making itself an unwelcome guest today, and defeated Rutgers, 9120, for the first time in Rutgers Stadium, before a disappointed homecoming crowd of 20.245.

title: Julia S. Rose Bride Of Joseph Nocera
description: At the Cathedral Church of St. John in Wilmington, Del., yesterday, Julia Stuart Rose, a Foreign Service officer who has been assigned as a vice consul to the Embassy in Paris, was married to Joseph Nocera, an editor of Washington Monthly. J. Brooke Mosley, Assistant Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Pennsylvania, performed the ceremony.

title: Interest Is Renewed in Plight of the Salmon
description: Some Atlantic salmon experts feel that the abysmally small spawning runs of the fish throughout much of its range this year, have for the first time, generated an awareness of the fish's plight and a desire to do something about it.

title: 2 More Cholera Cases in Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 6 (Reuters) Two more cholera cases were reported in Jordan today, raising to 81 the total since an outbreak was detected in August. The Ministry of Health said that 12 patients were still in hospitals but that there had been no deaths.

title: FROST ABANDONING KISSINGER INTERVIEW
description: David Frost withdrew from an hourlong television interview project with Henry A. Kissinger yesterday, charging that NBC News had agreed to let the former Secretary of State review and modify responses he gave to Mr. Frost last Wednesday in a taped session devoted primarily to the Nixon Administration's Cambodian policies.

title: Baugh Has a 5Touchdown Day
description: Kevin Baugh scored five touchdowns to lead Deer Park High School to a 900 Conference I victory over Ward Melville yesterday.

title: Female Coaches Set Merger Vote
description: Female public high school coaches are scheduled to vote next week on a motion to merge with the male members of the Public Schools Athletic League Coaches Association. Charlene Jaffe, the basketball and volleyball coach for girls at Bayside in Queens said, The time is finally right.

title: Agenda for Change in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN NEW HAVEN faces problems that go to the heart of the city's economic and social development. Those problems, and their solution, are of equal concern to numerous other mediumsize cities in Connecticut and elsewhere.

title: Juilliard School Planning 200Events Celebration
description: More than 200 events will be sponsored by the Jullliard School this season to help celebrate the 10th anniversary of its move to Lincoln Center. The initial event will be a concert by the Juilliard Orchestra, led by Sixten Ehrling, head of orchestral conducting, on Oct. 19 in Alice Tally Hall. Other concerts in the orchestra's series will be directed by guest conductors  James Conlon, James Levine, Massimo Freccia. Jorge Mester and Jose Serebrier.

title: IMPROVISING UNDERS STALIN'S BATON
description: Throughout his career, Dmitri Shostahovich pursued a precarious course. Many of his works were banned because of their formalistic perversions and he was periodically denounced for his con tinued antidemocratic tendencies as a composer. Yet he was never physically punished for his offenses and Stalin even asked him to take special assignments. The difficulties of surviving in Russia during the Stalin era are recounted in the following excerpts from Testimony: The Memoirs of Dmitri Shostakovich, as related to and edited by Solomon Volkov, which will be published this month by Harper & Row.

title: Philadelphia Papers Reach Pact
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 (AP)  A tentative agreement was reached before dawn today on a threeyear contract for employees of The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Philadelphia Daily News represented by the Newspaper Guild. Terms were withheld pending a vote on the contract on Tuesday.

title: Customers Feedback Hells the Wardrobe
description: THE buildabettermousetrap theory has proved itself at the Feedback Factory at 187 Ashford Avenue, where Elizabeth Ewing has worked out a practical method of individual dressing for the

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The Metropolitan Opera has not done well with Mozart's Die Entfiihrung aus dem Serail  The Abduction From the Seraglio  and will atone for its sins on Friday, when the Singspiel receives new production. For some reason the Metropolitan Opera through the decades ignored Mozart's charming comedy. It was in 1883 that the Metropolitan Opera opened, and Die Entfiihrung aus dem Serail did not enter the repertory until the 194847 season, with Eleanor Steber and Charles Kullman in the leading roles. Then, after a few performances, the opera was shelved. The new production on Friday la Iong overdue. Entfhrung was the first Mozart opera to become European hit in his own day. Its genesis starts in 1781. that year Mozart was living in Vienna, having broken from the Salzburg court (speeded away by a kick on the rear by Count Thun). He also was in the process of getting engaged to Constanze Weber, to his father's horror. The old man liked neither her nor her family.

title: Concert: Joseph Kubera, Pianist, Performs Hauer
description: Sometimes labors of love are perceived as more labor than love by even a sympathetic listener. Such was the case Friday night with a concert of music by Josef Matthias Hauer at the Kitchen.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: EVERYONE knows, writes John Cheever, that the first marathon, in the fifth century B.C., was run through some fairly uninteresting country west of Athens while the oldest and most famous marathon in the western world is mapped through the dreary suburbs north of Boston.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: The Kent cult. During this past August's dog days, we reported that John Jakes was on a cruise through Alaska's cool waters and would shortly head home Hilton Head Island, S.C., to read proofs of the eighth volume of his Kent Family Chronicles series. Within a few days we had a small shower of phone calls and letters from readers asking whether we didn't know that Mr. Jakes had died and that, alas, no further adventures of his fabulous Kent clan could be published. +

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last week on racquet sports gave incorrect details for the Winning Walls racquetball club at 300 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, 9395000. Membership fees range from $50 to $75.

title: Thieu Says U.S. Hurt His Bid to Win Vietnam War
description: LONDON, Oct. 6 (AP)  Former President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam said in a magazine interview yesterday that American troops were more trouble than help in the Vietnam War and that he would never associate with the Americans again.

title: Albums Commemorating Masters of the Organ
description: Helmut Walcha and E. Power Biggs were very different in their backgrounds, temperaments and, perhaps, abilities. But both were leading 20thcentury organists, and both did much to purify that instrument and its Baroque repertory of Romantic encrustations. And both are the subjects of lavish commemorative albums by their respective record companies.

title: No Title
description: Patricia Jayne Berger Engaged

title: Court Order a Key in Sparta Settlement
description: SPARTA COMPLYING with an unusual order issued by a Superior Court judge in Morristown, teachers at Sussex County VocationalTechnical High School here returned to their classrooms and technical shops last week after a twoweek strike.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterdays Walther at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Lisa Flint, Nurse, And Douglas Yarn Wed at West Point
description: Lisa Ellen Flint, a daughter of Col. and Mrs. Roy K. Flint of West Point, N.Y., was married yesterday to Douglas Hurt Yarn, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles P. Yarn Jr. of Atlanta. The Episcopai ceremony was performed by Lieut. Col. Colin P. Kelly 3d, of the Army Chaplains Corps in the Cadet Chapel at West Point.

title: Arbiters Dispute Frost On Neighbors; Declare Best Fence Is No Fence
description: SMITHFIELD, R.I. (AP)  Good fences make good neighbors, Robert Frost once wrote. New England fenceviewers disagree. They say that the best fence is no fence at all.

title: No Title
description: Mitchell Rapoport Marries Miss Sapir

title: Tornado Stricken Area To Be Aided by Builders
description: WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., Oct. 6 (AP)  Gov. Ella T. Grasso enlisted the aid of the state's construction industry today in a mounting volunteer effort to help the state's tornadostricken communities rebuild.

title: 4 on Newspaper's Staff Face Charges by County
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 6 (UPI) The Broome County District Attorney has charged that two reporters and two editors of The Binghamton SunBulletin broke the law when they gathered and prepared articles on a secret grand jury report.

title: Siberians Studying Reservoir's Impact
description: SIBITTYELLAKH, U.S.S.R.  In goldbearing valleys near this raw settlement in northeastern Siberia, Soviet crews have been working around the clock to extract the last grains of gold before their placer mines are flooded by a new hydroelectric dam on the Kolyma River.

title: Uganda Bans Some Gold Mining
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 6 (Reuters) Prospecting and mining for gold has been banned in seven districts of western Uganda, Radio Uganda said today in a report monitored here. No reason was given.

title: Darien Still Dominant
description: The Darien football team asserted its superiority in the Fairfield County Conference's East Division yesterday with a hardearned 150 victory over Wilton, last year's division winner.

title: In NATO Drill, Something Old, Something New
description: MARBURG, West Germany,  The night before the big attack, the Canadian commander, Brig. James A. Fox, sat in his trailer and thought aloud: The enemy probably thinks we'll attack across those open areas north and south of the woods. But we'll fool em. We'll go through the woods; plenty of loggers roads. And, after all, we're Canadians. Aren't we supposed to be good in the woods?

title: INVESTING
description: There is a widespread opinion that mines, oil wells and vacant land are good inflation hedge, and the view has been strengthened by the failure of stock prices to fully adjust to the declining purchasing power of the dollar.

title: Egypt Marks 73 War and Parades New U.S. Arms
description: CAIRO, Oct. 6  Egypt today showed off the first American weapons that it had received as a result of its signing a peace treaty with Israel.

title: CRIME
description: It is said that there are just so many plots. Two recently published books would certainly indicate that the saying is true. .tuhn D. MacDonald in THE GREEN RIPPER (Lippincott, $9.95) and Roderick Thorp in

title: BRIDGE
description: Most great bridge players make a start in the game when very young, usually as a teenager and occasionally even earlier. It is not easy for parents and friends to recognize that the youngster who is wasting his time at the cardtable is actually headed for stardom, but there are some clues for those who care to look for them.

title: SEEING NEW YORK ON THE RUN
description: There I am, No. 428, shoulder to shoulder with No. 1990, whoever he may be, my Union Jack shorts oddly sagging. We seem to be on Vernon Boulevard, in Queens; the traffic signal shows green, and paper cups are rolling along the street. It is a clear, bright day, the sun reflected in a thousand Manhattan office windows across the river. The Art Deco pinnacle of the Chrysler Building pushes into the sparkling bright blue sky, seeming to pierce a white cloud.

title: President and Pontiff Issue a Plea At White House for World Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  Pope John Paul II was welcomed to the White House today by President Carter in a confluence of church and state in which both leaders pleaded to the world for peace.

title: Movie: Sorority Rivalry
description: At 9 A.M.yesterday, as the morning sun beamed down on the scruff of West 42d Street, 17 cinema buffs, all men, several of them for some reason wearing raincoats, were lined up at the Times Square Theater, waiting to push their $1.75 through the wicket to see the premiere engagement of H.O.T.S.

title: ANTI-INFLATION PLAN BY FEDERAL RESERVE INCREASES KEY RATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, tonight announced a new package of measures, including higher interest rates, aimed at bringing inflation under control, calming financial markets and, indirectly, bolstering the dollar.

title: A Thinking Man's Diet
description: Dr. Arthur Upton, the director of the National Cancer Institute, stuck his neck out the other day and offered some dietary tips to reduce the risk of cancer: Don't gain excessive weight. Eat less fat. Eat a lot of fiber. Drink only moderate amounts of alcohol  one or two drinks a day.

title: The MX Express, or a Trojan Horse Rides the Rails Through the County
description: TO seasoned commuters on the New Haven division of Conrail it is staggering news indeed to learn that the Defense Department plans to build 200 MX missiles at a cost of $33 billion and deploy them on railroad trains.

title: Shipping / Mails
description: Incoming

title: Yale Conquers Colgate, 27 to
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 6  Coach Carmen Cozza said it best a few moments after his Yale football team had defeated Colgate, 270, at Yale Bowl today.

title: Medical Board Defends Policies
description: IAM appalled by the continued glaring ignorance displayed by Dr. John Winslow, author of the article, A Climate of Fear Among Doctors [Sept. 9], in which he said that the state's Board of Medical Examiners was responsible for that climate of fear and charged the board with creating a policestate atmosphere through an overzealous, selfrighteous role of enforcer on drugabuse regulations.

title: SHAPING UP THE CORPORATE IMAGE
description: For or many executives squash is replacing the Martini lunch. Other substitutes are running, swimming or tennis. In New York, many of the traditional private clubs with athletic facilities report a marked upsurge of noontime exercise, which is often followed by a simple salad for lunch. The newer health spas, gyms and fitnes centers which dot the city, as well as the medically oriented cardiofitness laboratories, are nearly jammed at the noon hour as more upper and middlelevel executives use the time to work up a sweat and pump up the pulse rate. Enthusiasts say that an hour of vigorous exercise works off the tensions of the morning and leaves them fresh to face the afternoon's business stresses. The medical director of one corporate fitness program points out that many nonathletic types have Joined fitness programs and are sticking to them.

title: Excerpts From Brezhnev's Address in East Berlin
description: EAST BERLIN, Oct. 6 (Reuters)Following are excerpts from the Englishlanguage translation of the speech by the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, in East Berlin yesterday as distributed by Tass, the Soviet press agency:

title: Master Animator Chuck Jones: The Movement's the Thing
description: In an early scene of the The Bugs Bunny/Road Runner Movie, a stoneage couple sits in their cave, trying to think of a way to combat boredom. What's on the wall tonight, dear? the wife asks. Turns out it's the same old drawing, but the couple, by moving their heads back and forth, transforms it into history's first animated short subject.

title: Presenting Russia's Best Kept Secret
description: Last October, Bella Davidovich left the Soviet Union. There was none of the fanfare that attended the defections of Mstislav Rostropovich, Vladimir Ashkenazy or Mikhail Baryshnikov, and not a fraction of the press coverage accorded this summer's shipjumping by three l3oishoi Ballet dancers and two Olympic ice skaters. Mme. Davidovi^h simply gave a few recitals in Europe and then settled down quietly in Queens.

title: Fuel Banks Seeking Funds for Winter
description: GOVERNOR GRASSO'S staff estimates that as many as 88,500 families in the state may need help this winter to pay their fuel bills. Of this number, 40,000 are expected to be covered by various Federal programs. The major hope for the remaining 4S,5uu amines is the system of voluntary fuel banks  which now have, according to their director, a total of less than $5,000 in funds.

title: Bumbry Gets Off the Hook
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 6  Al Bumbry had the pennant in his glove last night and dropped it. But when the Baltimore Orioles qualified for the World Series today, their 80 triumph over the California Angels took Al Bumbry off the hook he had been dangling on. I'm totally relieved, the little center fielder was saying with a sigh and a smile. I wouldn't want to live with this the rest of my life. If we had lost this series. I would've- had to live with it. Just thinking about it, I woke up three times last night before 7 o'clock. But now it's over. And now he's off the hook forever.

title: U.S. Labor Party: Cult Surrounded by Controversy
description: Last month in New Hampshire a mildlooking economic theorist named Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. began his 1980 campaign for President of the United States, escorted by expressionless security men from the U.S. Labor Party, the cultlike organization he has created over the last decade.

title: Displaying Mastery in Etching
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR Not too long ago, prints were viewed in art circles with some scorn as a medium inerior to painting and sculpture. Now, however, prints have become so popular that it is almost more fashionable to own an etching than an oil.

title: Philadelphia Puts Stay on Condominiums
description: PHILADELPHIA  Acting rapidly under pressure from demonstrators protesting the threat of condomania, the Philadelphia City Council has passed and Mayor Frank L. Rizzo signed an 18month moratorium on converting rental apartments into condominiums.

The Pope visits the Sanctuary of the Immaculate Conception and Catholic University, where he meets with priests, nuns, teachers of religion and representatives of the ecumenical movement. At 9:30 A.M. he addresses educators in the university gym. Continuous coverage by New York City's Channel 4 from 8 to 11:30 A.M.

description: AMONG the assortment of shapes on the run these days is a new one  longbodied, lowslung and with twice as many legs as an ordinary jogger. Dogs are accompanying their owners for exercise, adventure and, occasionally, other business.

Park, Route 7 near junction with Route 112. Gates open and registration begins both days at 7 A.M. Friday: practice and qualifying 10 A.M. Saturday: first race 9 A.M. Information: Henryk Szamota (212) 2292696.

title: Figure in Jordan Case Arrested at Studio 54 On DrugSale Charges
description: An alleged drug dealer who has contended that he gave cocaine to Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, at the discothque Studio 54 was arrested early yesterday on Federal narcotics charges.

title: Operas, Concerts and Recitals Open the New Season for Music
description: WITH the traditional latesummer lull over, the New Jersey music scene is again on the upbeat, and there is an abundance of concerts and recitals to herald the new season. Following is a sampling of performances taking place in the state in the coming weeks:

title: Daughter of ExSlaves Who Made Good on Broadway Recalls Life
description: PITTSBURG, Kan., Oct. 6 (AP)Eva Jessye, at the age of 84, is writing four books, producing the oratorios she comnosed and founding another choir.

title: The YoungFashioned Max Roach
description: Max Roach, the celebrated jazz drummer, composer, and teacher, hasn't stopped growing. The past year fow.d most of Mr. Roach's surviving contemporaries, musicians who matured between 1945 and 1955, either continuing to play in the idiom they developed 30odd years ago or dabbling in fashionable disco rhythms and electronics. Meanwhile, Mr. Roach made the most adventurous and surprising record of his career, Birth and Rebirth, an album of duets with the very contemporary saxophonist Anthony Braxton. In Italy, where it was recorded and originally released, Birth and Rebirth recently won the Premio Della Critica Discografica Italians 1979 for Jazz D'Avanguardia. In 1977, Mr. Roach won the French International Gran Prix du Disque for Modern Jazz for an album of duets with another avantgarde saxophonist, Archie Shepp. And this Thursday night, Oct. 11, at Columbia University's Wollman Auditorium, Mr. Roach will be performing duets with another inconoclast, the pianist Cecil Taylor. To paraphrase a traditional blues lyric, Mr. Roach may be an elderly statesman (he'll be 55 in January) but he's got youngfashioned ways. the idiom they developed 30odd years ago or dabbling in fashionable disco rhythms and electronics. Meanwhile, Mr. Roach made the most adventurous and surprising record of his career, Birth and Rebirth, an album of duets with the very contemporary saxophonist Anthony Braxton. In Italy, where it was recorded and originally released, Birth and Rebirth recently won the Premio Della Critica Discografica Italians 1979 for Jazz D'Avanguardia. In 1977, Mr. Roach won the French International Gran Prix du Disque for Modern Jazz for an album of duets with another avantgarde saxophonist, Archie Shepp. And this Thursday night, Oct. 11, at Columbia University's Wollman Auditorium, Mr. Roach will be performing duets with another inconoclast, the pianist Cecil Taylor. To paraphrase a traditional blues lyric, Mr. Roach may be an elderly statesman (he'll be 55 in January) but he's got youngfashioned ways.

title: Problems of Business
description: HARRY K. SCHWARTZ, a member of the domesticpolicy staff of the White House, recently praised Westchester County for the diversity of its economic community and its sizable number of small businesses.

title: Questions/Answers
description: We have a border of handsome greenleaved plants along our driveway and have been told several names for them  plantain lily, daylily and hosta. Which is correct? They have been blooming with spikes of lavender flowers for several weeks. Mrs. L.P., New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Aden Official Rejects Oman Plan To Bolster Persian Gulf Security
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 6 (Reuters)The Foreign Minister of Southern Yemen, Salem Saleh Mohammed, was quoted today as having said that his country opposed a security plan by neighboring Oman for the Persian Gulf region because it involved foreign troops.

title: President Has Extended Controls for 4 Years
description: WASHINGTON  In denying an export license last week for a proposed sale of computer equipment to the Soviet Union, Defense Secretary Harold R. Brown invoked national security, the only ground in law for saying no. But Defense officials made plain that the decision was based on foreign policy grounds, to express to Moscow Washington's displeasure over the presence in Cuba of a Soviet brigade.

title: Affirmed Takes Gold Cup
description: AFFIRMED WINS JOCKEY CLUB GOLD CUP RACE: Affirmed, ridden by Laffit Pincay, leading the way to the finish line ahead of Spectacular Bid, ridden by Willie Shoemaker, during race yesterday at Belmont. Article, Section 5.

title: N.B.A. Preview: New Faces and Some
description: Bill Walton is a San Diego Clipper. Earvin Johnson is performing his magic act with the Los Angeles Lakers. Larry Bird is the newest hope of the Boston Celtics and their new coach, Bill Fitch. But all the players in the National Basketball Association will have one new gimmick in common  the 3point field Eoal.

title: The Boom on the Potomac
description: WASHINGTON  Just about anywhere he goes from his office on Connecticut Avenue here, David Childs runs into the rubble of demolished buildings and new ones going up. It's a bit like an earthquake, he says. The critical mass builds up for years and years and then it shifts. That is what is happening here. We've had minieruptions in the past, but now we are in for an enormous one.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: Dizzy Gillespie and a group of fellow jazz musicians will perform at a benefit concert at 7 P.M. at the John Harms Englewood Plaza, 30 Van Brunt Street, Englewood, the program marking the culmination of the first Bergen County Festival of the Arts. Mr. Gillespie, long an Englewood resident, recently completed an engagement at the Village Gate in Manhattan.

title: Collier Leads Irvington to 13th Straight Victory, 210
description: Colby Collier, a junior halfback, scored two touchdowns and ran for 200 yards as Irvington extended its winning streak to 13 games, the longest in Westchester County, with a 210 triumph over Valhalla yesterday.

title: Grasso's Support for Carter Causes Strain
description: HARTFORD GOVEFtNOR GRASSO'S reputation for keeping her commitments has again put her in a potentially awkward situation in a Presidential election campaign.

title: IN THE NATION Bumbling And Bravado
description: The mortician's art cannot disguise the fact that its subject is dead. And all the rouge and powder applied in President Carter's speech the other night could not conceal the demise of his efforts to force Moscow to downgrade its supposed combat presence in Cuba.

title: Runner Calls Wheelers Safety Hazard
description: THIS year, an estimated 14,000 foot racers will run the New York City Marathon under less than optimal safety because of misguided humanitarianism. The Commissioner of the New York State Division of Human Rights, Werner H. Kramarsky, ruled that wheelchair racers must be permitted in the Oct. 21 marathon, and I feel this violates the sport of footracing, the nature of athletic competition, and is a serious hazard to marathoners and spectators a like.

title: 5 Survivors of Expedition Return After 3 Are Killed on Annapurna
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Oct. 6 (UPI) Five survivors of an Americanled expedition that lost three of its members in an attempt to scale the 26,502foot Annapurna returned to Katmandu today from their base camp.

title: Discount Coupons Still Find a Market
description: Robert Ackerman, an official of a university in Manhattan, has a problem. I have two of the halfprice coupons that United Airlines distributed back in June, he said. I thought I'd be using them but now I would like to sell them. But now that the great coupon war is over, one doesn't hear anything about them, which means I have no idea who trades in them or what they're worth.

title: China and North Korea Hail Ties
description: TOKYO, Oct. 6 (Reuters)  The Foreign Ministers of China and North Korea, Huang Hua and Ho Dam, exchanged messages today hailing the 30th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between their two countries, the Korean Central News Agency reported.

title: Realty News
description: A recent survey or the ats otnce owiaings in Lower Manhattan that have more than 125,000 square feet each and demand rents of $6 a square foot or more has indicated that there are no large blocks, 100,000squarefeet or more, available in buildings erected after 1945 and only five in preWorld War II structures.

title: The Nation
description: Finally casting votes instead of just casting about, the Senate last week approved President Carter's demand for an Energy Mobilization Board, the panel that's supposed to keep red tape from tying up synthetic fuel plants and other new energy facilities.

title: LETTERS
description: After 25 years in the book writing business, I am naturally accustomed to simpleminded reviews. (In fact I have yet to see a review of any of my books, anywhere, that I couldn't have written much better myself.) But the review (Aug. 5) of my book Abbey's Road goes beyond simplemindedness into the higher realm of malicious falsehood. Your reviewer, Lucinda Franks, deliberately misrepresents the tone, manner and content of this book: e.g , her version of my views on the Indians of Mexico and the aborigines of Australia is exactly the opposite of what I actually stated, as any fairminded reader can easily discover for himself. (Or herself.)

title: Yale Throws a Party In Aid of Symphony
description: NEXT Sunday afternoon, Yale University will open to the public its quadrangles and greenswards, its Gothic and Georgian residences, baronial dining halls and antiquefilled masters houses to raise at least $100,000 for the New Haven Symphony, the principal tenant of Woolsey Hall.

description: Mary Ceresa Bride Of L.D. McGovern

description: MILFORD TWENTYSEVEN people, aged 14 to 45, sat listening attentively to Thomas Candia, a plainclothes policeman. Someone is going to make you do something you don't want to do, he said. Force is what makes it a rape.

description: WASHINGTON  Workers for the Tennessee Valley Authority engaged in a bit of light fishing last week and managed to take first 60 snaildarters, and then 23, from the Little Tennessee River. The effort to transfer them to nearby rivers will continue as long as possible, officials said.

description: IF there's a world of difference between opinion and fact, then it's equally true that between passion and objectivity lies a storm of discontent.
