description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Oct. 5 Alan Jones, the Australian who has dominated the second half of this year's Grand Prix racing, won the pole postion today for tomorrow's running of the United States Grand Prix.

description: PORT JEFFERSON CONVINCED that even in community theater stagnation will result from a lack of growth, Theater Three Productions will open its 10th season on Saturday in a permanent home, the Scrimshaw Theater, formerly a 19thcentury vaudeville house on Main Street here. Neil Akins, the troupe's general manager, said, We had done the usual community theater thinghigh school auditoriums, even Smith Haven Mall and, for the past six years, a church basement. And the steady increase in audiences indicated that our hard work was paying off, that people appreciated the kind of quality theater we had to offer.

title: Papal Envoy an Agent of Change in U.S. Church
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  While the Pope is on his United States visit, at his side is 69yearold Archbishop Jean Jadot, the papal delegate. It is through this thin, baldish Belgian prelate, who serves as a kind of cultural translator, that the Vatican learns the mood, concerns and cares of the American church

title: State Will Not Penalize Concerns For Sending Soured Milk Upstate
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 6 (AP) State officials say they will probably not impose penalties against Crowley Foods Inc. and Dairylea Cooperative Inc. for shipping thousands of gallons of soured milk two weeks ago. The milk, which presented no health problem, was allowed to become too warm and contained a high level of bacteria. state officials said.

description: As the fitness craze has spread, plain and fancy health clubs have sprung up everywhere. For the membership, the clubs are providing a wide variety or means to a healthy end. And for the owners, the facilities are doing a healthy business indeed.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  Amused observers dubbed it the Congressional banana war: an octogenarian deadlock that sent everybody from the President on down scrambling to find money to keep the Government operating.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  President Carter and Pope John Paul II joined in fervent appeal today for new limitations on nuclear weapons and a worldwide commitment to human rights. Without mentioning the strategic arms limitation agreement currently before the Senate by name, both men called in their remarks for weapons restrictions.

description: WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., Oct. 6 (AP)  A Federal program to help fueloil dealers who had gross earnings of less than $6 million last year obtain credit to raise their supplies this winter was announced here today.

description: GREENLAWN HUNTINGTON TOWN'S elderly people are not about to let a suspected act of arson come between them and their longanticipated move into the Paumanack Village Senior Citizens Housing Complex. They've already endured 10 years of legal battles, financial setbacks and community opposition, and the fire is just one more obstacle they plan to overcome before they start moving in on Nov. 1.

description: WHEN Pope John Paul II unpacks the gifts he received on his United States tour, he will find three porcelain statues that were created in Trenton, although one will be labeled A Gift From the People of Iowa and another will be from Philadelphia.

description: WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 5  The lawyers for a 29year old handyman accused of murdering a woman, her seven children and another child opened their defense here yesterday, seeking to overcome a graphic confession that was read to the fury six weeks ago.

We carry a big stick with a carrot. If the carrot doesn't work, then we take punitive action.

Brocksbank, manager of college relations and recruiting at the Mobil Oil Corporation in New York. The Rev. Hal C. Miller 3d performed the ceremony at the United Church.

description: PEKING, Oct. 6 (UPI)  Millions of Chinese went hungry during the rule of Chairman Mao Zedong because of his Government's mistakes and political instability, the Chinese Communist Party said today.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6 (UPI)  A sniper who held a woman hostage in a highrise office building, terrorizing a downtown area with gunfire for 23 hours, was captured today as he slept, and the woman was rescued unharmed.

title: 2 Men Guilty in Abduction of Jersey Banker's Wife
description: NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 6 (AP)  Two Paterson men were found guilty today of all charges in connection with the abduction of a Paterson banker's wife in July.

title: H.F. Kurz Jr. Weds Gloria Scott at U.N.
description: The marriage of Gloria Jean Scott, a lawyer with the New York firm of Burns Jackson Miller Summit & Jacoby, to H. Frederick Kurz Jr., director of marketing, fashions and cosmetics for Norton Simon Inc., took place in New York yesterday. The Rev. Joe O'Rourke, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the cermony in the chapel at the Church Center for the United Nations.

description: Lesley BushBrown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert BushBrown of Locust Valley, L.I., was married there yesterday to Thomas Suffern Taller Gimbel, son of Fern Taller Denney of Oyster Bay, L.I., and the late David Alva Gimbel. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony in St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church.

description: BALTIMORE, Oct., 6  Exasperated, Pat Leahy says simply, I blew 'em.

description: 11:30 (4) Newscenter Forum": James R. Brigham, in charge of the New York City Budget.

title: Pioneers Launch a Dream at South Street
description: Dust whirling around her, Judith Green held the power sander to the rudder and began shaping the edge. Some students measured and cut wood for the deck while others painted the frames with epoxy resin.

title: Fire Destroys GiftPaper Center
description: RIDGEFIELD PARK, N.J., Oct. 6 (AP)  Fire today destroyed the distribution center for a company that makes wrapping paper for gifts, the police said. The blaze, of undetermined origin, broke out about 1:30 A.M. at the StephenLawrence Company, which takes up a half block on Mount Vernon Street, off Main Street. No injuries were reported.

title: Changing Currents Along the Shore
description: THE longstanding debate over development a ong southern Connecticut shore seems to be heading into a new phase, spurred by increasing economic pressures on a dwindling number of potential building sites.

title: Agriculture Official Named
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI)  Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland has named Billy Ray Gowdy, an Oklahoma farmer, as Deputy Under Secretary of Agriculture. The job of Deputy Under Secretary has been split into two. Mr. Gowdy will be in charge of domestic farm programs and James Starkey 3d is in charge of international affairs.

title: I Become My Characters
description: Those who have observed the deeply furrowed cheeks and enormous, tormented eyes of Klaus Kinski, who is the star of two current Werner Herzog films  Woyzeck and Nosferatu, the Vampyre  are not likely to soon forget him. On the basis of these works by the German director, as well as Mr. Herzog's 1972 Aguirre, the Wrath of God, the Polishborn Mr. Kinski has established himself as an international star  and the sort of presence one might be wary of encountering, even on a sunny morning in the lobby of the Sherry Netherlands Hotel. And indeed, the almost trancelike intensity of the actor's Count Dracula in Nosferatu is no anomoly.

title: Growth of Legal Gaming Places Focus on Pathological Gamblers
description: RENO, Nev., Oct. 6 (AP)  James McGee remembers gambling at the age of 12, winning big at 19 and starting to borrow and steal to finance his addiction in high school.

title: Lisa F. Casey Becomes Bride Of Robert Brennan in Jersey
description: Lisa F. Casey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Gerard Casey of Smoke Rise, N.J., was married in Kinnelon, N.J., yesterday to Robert M. Brennan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Brennan of West Haven, Conn. The Rev. John Ryan performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Magnificat Roman Catholic Church.

title: Under the Greasepaint, The Tall Clown Is a Nun
description: CHICAGO (AP)  Sister Shirley Stockus is a 33yearold nun who uses makeup: the greasepaint of a clown.

title: P.L.O. Aide Charges Jesse Jackson Sought To Split Arabs Ranks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 6 (AP)  Beirut newspapers said today that a member of the Palestine Liberation Organization's Executive Committee had accused the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson of trying to split Arab and Palestinian ranks by seeking a freeze in the armed struggle against Israel.

title: Project in the San Antonio Barrio Is Teaching Spanish to Hispanics
description: Next door to Tony's Food Center on the west side of San Antonio it is backtoschool time for students of the Barrio Education Protect.

title: Molloy Scores 3 as Garden City Romps
description: Garden City High School won its second straight Nassau Conference II game yesterday, routing Great Neck North, 340. A senior fullback, Chris Molloy, scored three touchdowns for the Trojans.

title: Around the Nation
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 6 (UPI) Two students were killed today and five others were wounded by a gunman who drew pistol and fired repeatedly into a Kappa Alpha Psi fraternity homecoming party at the University of South Carolina.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia  There was nothing low about the profile of West German bankers who swept into this city like a whirlwind last week for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. While American concerns such as Merrill Lynch & Company and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company gave their share of parties, they were outshone by the lavish West Germans. At the Deutsche Bank reception, for example, the beer and sausages were all imported from Munich and the champagne flowed as if by pipeline from eastern France.

title: CHESS
description: Alexander Chemin, who captured second place in the World Junior Championship in Skien, Norway, was originally the Russians reserve player but became a participant when the Soviet Chess Federation pulled out its star, Garik Kasparov, a week before Hue tournament was to begin.

title: Theaters Seeking Recognition
description: FOR a long time, New Jersey's eight professional nonprofit theaters have existed in a limbo of audience apathy, critical neglect and the state government's indifference to their survival.

title: The Atrium Comeback Transforms Air Shafts
description: The air shaft is on its way out and its elegant Roman ancestor, the atrium, is in. This fashion, fueled by zoning incentives from the city's Planning Commission, was encouraged by Citicorp's highly successful Market, its restaurant and shop lined inner courtyard off Lexington Avenue, and continues in a new generation of buildings  as well as in some dramatic renovations.

title: FILM VIEW
description: When people say of a movie that it's talky, or that it has too much talk, or that it's all talk, they really mean that the talk isn't much good. Though we've long since stopped believing that the less talk in any movie the better it must be, talk (or dialogue or language) is generany unaerratea in slims, tieing notices only when it's unusually funny, as in Annie Hall, or witty, as in Claire's Knee, or horrendously pretentious, as in the concluding sequence of Francis Coppola's Apocalypse Now. People seldom mention the dialogue in a film like Don Siegel's Escape from Alcatraz, though the compressed, pareddown language in which its characters communicate is essential to that film's effectiveness.

title: Foliage: Where to Find a Golden Sea on a Tank of Gasoline
description: A spectacular tide of crimson and gold, scarlet and brown, yellow and purple is sweeping south through New York State and Connecticut toward the metropolitan area. The annual fall foliage display is once again nearing its peak.

title: A CrossCountry Success Story: Jersey Coach Keeps Harriers at Peak
description: In the winter of 1777, after crossing the Delaware River, George Washington passed through Bernardsville in Central New Jersey. In 1964, Ed Mather came to that suburban town in Somerset County and stayed.

title: Williams Pressing FuelAid Bill
description: WASHINGTON WITH winter winds just around the corner and despite the certainty that heating bills will be considerably higher than last year's, Congress still has not put together a plan of assistance for homeheating emergencies. Such a plan, almost everyone agrees, is vital.

title: Finding Unity in Wild Individualism
description: ARTISTS Space, in New York City, is so called because it is run by artists instead of civilians. The gallery was established to enable artists to qualify collectively for public funding and to alleviate the bottleneck caused by too many aspirants chasing too few galleries. So there's some irony in 10 of its brighter luminaries appearing at the Neuberger Museum at the State University College of New York at Purchase.

title: Constables in Dispute
description: ATTEMPTS by villages in Suffolk County to establish their own constabularies have raised a number of controversial questions, prompted an investigation by the County Attorney and raised the ire of the Suffolk County Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, but the villages plan to an ahead anyway.

title: Simon: On the Run And Maybe Running
description: LATELY, William E. Simon confides, a recurring dream has been disturbing his sleep. It goes like this, he says :

title: 97,000 Cords on Toy Phone Sets Are Recalled for Safety Reasons
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UPI)  The cords of 97,000 toy telephone sets have been recalled because they resemble regular electric plugs so closely that children may try to force them into wall sockets.

title: U.S. May Curb Geothermal Wells in National Parks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  The National Park Service, concerned that further development of geothermal power sources could disrupt geyser and volcanic activity in Lassen Volcanic National Park in northern California, has moved to take over the land on which the privately financed geothermal project is situated.

title: American Wood, Chinese Silver
description: IF an antiques show can be said to have a keynote speech, that is what Edgar deN. Mayhew will give Friday afternoon shortly after the opening of the 10th annual Stonington Antiques Show.

title: ALASKAN HAUL Roan TOUCH FOR TRUCKERS
description: PRUDHOE BAY, Alaska, Oct. 6 (AP)  Since the North Slope haul road was laid in 1974, to aid construction of the transAlaska pipeline and supply the camps at Prudhoe, it has been a lure to the adventurous. The road is off limits to all but a few humans, but that does not keep other humans away from it.

title: The Memory of Jasmine Lingers On
description: Years after I left my Texas birthplace for good, the very thought of jasmine evokes the deepest memories of my childhood there. In our Dallas garden, jasmine was a shrubby plant sprawling by the garage. It signalled spring, not aconites or crocus.

title: Music: Viennese Works
description: A modest concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night offered music composed by the Mahlers (Gustav and his wife, Alma) and the Weigle (Karl, who died in 1949, and his wife, Vally, who is still writing music in New York). The connection between the couples is that both were Viennese and that the two men were friends prior to Mahler's death, in 1911.

title: Measles Breaks Out in Salisbury As Refugees Flee Rhodesian War
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Oct. 6 (AP)  A measles epidemic has broken out in black areas of Salisbury, set off by the arrival of war refugees, health officials said in a report published today.

title: Deaths
description: ABBERLEYMary(Lyon), October 1, 1979. of Westport, Ct. Wire of the late Lester S. Abberley, mother of Jahn J. Abberley, Mrs. Jean Hunt. Also survived by six grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Private funeral services and Interment were held.

title: NuclearPlant Staffs
description: WASHINGTON IN AN effort to meet tougher testing and licensing rules for operators employed at nuclearpower plants, 40 employees at a nuclear generating station in Salem County are being trained to cope with the kind of events that caused the accident at Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania last March.

title: Company Doctor Sigoloff
description: LOS ANGELES  He's been called a hatchet man, and names like Ming the Merciless and the Skillful Scalpel as he labored to save failing companies. But Sanford S. Sigoloff has built a reputation as a man who can take an ailing operation and turn it around. The question is, what's an executive with that kind of skill doing in such a going business as the nation's No. 1 home builder, Kaufman & Broad?

title: 4 in a Philadelphia Radical Group Sentenced for Using Obscenities
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 (AP)  Four members of the radical group Move have been sentenced to one to two years in prison for disorderly conduct and criminal conspiracy for shouting obscenities and threats through a bullhorn at the police in June 1977.

title: Trojan Spirit Instills Bucs With Will and Way to Win
description: DAVE LEWIS will never forget the first time he walked on campus, when he stepped into a dream that began when O.J. Simpson ran across his television set and he decided he was going to go to the University of Southern California. That's what it became, a dream. He was part of a Rose Bowl team. He played in

title: Clinton Is Beaten By 1312
description: In a meeting between two unbeaten teams, Maurice Briggs scored on a 3yard run in the third quarter to lead Port Richmond to a 1312 victory over DeWitt Clinton yesterday. The Minstrels now are 40, while Clinton's record dropped to 31.

title: Penn Hits Milestone But Columbia Wins
description: The University of Pennsylvania football team reached a milestone of 1,000 games yesterday but only reached the Columbia goal line once as the Lions beat the Quakers, 127, at Baker Field.

title: STAMPS
description: Americans again have a choice as to the stamp they can use for their Yuletide mail: a traditional representation of the religious significance of Christmas, and a cheerful representation of the festive joys of the holiday.

title: I Want Kissinger to Think on Camera
description: This Thursday at 10 P.M. on NBC, David Frost will interview Henry Kissinger about the former Secretary of State's stewardship of foreign policy during the years of the first Nixon Administration. The hourlong interview is tied to the publication later this month of the Kissinger memoirs. In the great tradition of television, the author is making himself available about the time the book is in the stores, Mr. Frost says wryly.

title: On the Trail of the Great Detective
description: IF on some cold, windy day this autumn you espy a tall lanky figure riding Conrail's HarlemHudson line, clad in a deerstalker cap and Inverness cape, don't be too surprised. It's Bruce Kennedy, a 31yearold Mount Kisco resident who is the organizer of a group of Sherlock Holmes enthusiasts. The Westchesterbased society, which has about 20 members, is called the Three Garridebs, after one of the lesswellknown cases of the master Victorian sleuth.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: A Call for Confronting Smilers of Half Smiles

title: Nancy Foner, Anthropologist, Wed to Peter Swerdloff
description: Nancy Foner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Moe Foner of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday to Peter M. Swerdloff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Swerdloff of New York. State Supreme Court Justice Arthur E. Blyn performed the private ceremony at his home in Brooklyn.

title: Embracing a Mission Of Global Moral Authority
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.  When Pope John Paul II pleaded for peace and a general disarmament, for the defense of human rights everywhere and for rejection of materialism in his speech at the United Nations early in his American journey last week, he earnestly addressed himself to all men and women living on this planet. His choice of audience asserted, at least by implication, a papal claim to a world moral pastorate.

title: Top Lawyers Display Their Talents at Scotto Trial
description: Federal prosecutors and defense lawyers are matching their wits, skills and resources in a classic criminal trial to determine the fate of Anthony M. Scotto, the powerful dockunion leader who is accused of accepting $300,000 in illegal labor payoffs.

title: Zoning Fight on Reservation Stirs Anger in Idaho
description: BOISE, Idaho, Oct. 6 (AP)  Indians trying to enforce zoning regulations on their Fort Hall Reservation have notified a state legislator that they will take him to court unless he asks their permission to expand his trailer park. The warning has stirred up a dispute.

title: Bokassa Affair Hits a Nerve In the French African Policy
description: PARISDuring an impromptu television session with young West Germans in Bonn last week, Valry Giscard d'Estaing was asked whether France maintained its presence in Africa to seek economic advantage. The French President was visibly irritated. The countries where France has intervened, he said, are among the 24 poorest in the world. They have no natural resources, no mineral resources, and live on French aid. So, he concluded, the question was insulting and stupid.

title: George Q. Lewis, 65; Taught Comedians, Founded Laugh Week
description: George Q. Lewis, a modernday pioneer in promoting the art of laughter and comedy and was the founder of National Laugh Week, died Thursday of a heart attack at his home in Elberon, N.J. He was 65 years old.

title: U.S. Aides Link Move to Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  Carter Administration officials said today that Leonid I. Brezhnev's speech in East Berlin seemed part of a concerted Soviet effort to persuade West European countries not to go along with allied plans to deploy 572 new nucleararmed missiles in Europe.

title: Editors' Choice
description: THE EDWARD HOAGLAND READER, edited by Geoffrey Wolff. (Random House, cloth, $12.95. Vintage, paper, $4.95.) AFRICAN CALLIOPE, by Edward Hoagland. (Random House, $10.) Essays by a writer who, no matter what his subject, is personal, magisterial and persuasive. The first volume is a collection of short pieces, the second an account of a winter spent in a Sudanese village.

title: Consumer Guide Available
description: A New Jerseyan's Consumer Guide to Solar Energy Systems, a 219page book that includes construction details, cost analyses and a directory of architects, engineers, manufacturers and distributors involved with solar heating and cooling, is available for $3.60 from New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, 32 West Lafayette Street, Trenton 08608. The organization also offers a number of free pamphlets on alternative energy.

title: Sallie Spence Wed To a Naval Officer
description: Sallie Burton Spence, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George D. Spence of Charlottesville, Va., and Lieut. (j.g.) Stockton Newbold Smith, U.S.N., were married yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church in Charlottesville. The Rev. Dr. Arie D. Bestebreurtje performed the ceremony.

title: Other World Events
description: The dozens of recent political killings that have terrorizes Turkey apparently did not preoccupy the Minister of the Interior to the exclusion of everything else. Hasan Fehmi Gunes resigned last week after newspapers published reports of his affair with an actress who just happened to belong to the opposition Justice Party. The scandal broke before partial senate and lower house elections next weekend that could unseat the Republican Peoples Party Government of Bulent Ecevit, already shaken by two previous ministerial resignations.

title: Tax Dispute Erupts Over Coal Reserves
description: GRAFTON, W.Va., Oct. 6 (AP)  A century ago, land agents bought large tracts in the hills and hollows of West Virginia for their coalmining employers in New York and Philadelphia, often paying no more than the price of a sewing machine. Low taxes on those tracts led to bad roads and poor schools in a state with multibilliondollar coal reserves.

title: THEATER
description: WHILE other theater companies are getting ready for the new season, the Hartman Theater Company finds itself momentarily homeless as it prepares to move to a new location.

title: Issues That Go Beyond a Murder Are Raised in Runner Stumbles
description: THE STUDIO THEATER'S new season begins with The Runner Stumbles, a dark and brooding play about a priest who is accused of murdering a nun an incident said to be based on a trial that occurred in Solon, Mich., at the turn of the century.

title: Kristin M. Keitel, Michael Hem berg Marry at Bucknell
description: In the Hooke Chapel of Bucknell University yesterday, Kristin Marie Keitel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn H. Keitel of Lewisburg, Pa., and Michael Leo Hernberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Hernberg of Wellesley, Mass., were married. The Rev. David Bachelder of the United Presbyterian Church of Sandy Lake, Pa., performed the ceremony, which the couple wrote.

title: RETIREMENT AN ISSUE IN JAPANESE VOTING
description: TOKYO, Oct. 6  Compulsory retirement at the age of 55 was considered an enlightened and generous policy when it was first introduced by Japanese companies in 1885, an era when the average Japanese could expect to live only 90 years.

title: ATOMIC WASTE STIRS WORRIES IN VIRGINIA
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., Oct. 6 (AP) The increasing worry among many Americans over what to do with the nation's nuclear wastes has reached Virginia's Tidewater area, which receives about 10,000 pounds of such wastes from foreign countries annually.

title: Miss Polly Wogg Makes A NameDropper Happy
description: OGDEN, Utah (AP)  James Jacobs collects names, weird names.

title: Right to Run Advocated for Handicapped
description: WHEELCHAIR athletes belong in longdistance running. Wheelchair runners have made some recent headway although they have been temporarily banned from the New York City Marathon by the New York Road Runners Club. an organization whose leaders wish to retain complte control of all aspects of the sport of running. The State Division of Human Rights has ruled that the Road Runners Club must accept the entries of wheelchair runners for this year'' marathon on Oct. 21.

title: James Eagan, Lawyer From Queens, Is First To Seek Javits's Seat
description: James E. Eagan, a 38yearold lawyer from Richmond Hill, Queens, yesterday announced he would seek the 1980 Republican nomination for the United States Senate seat that has been held by Jacob K. Javits for 23 years. Mr. Eagan is the first person to announce his candidacy for the seat.

title: No Title
description: Engagements

title: I want to go ahead and do it
description: IT is one of those testimonies to the tenacity of selfregard in the literary life that large numbers of people remain persuaded that Norman Mailer is no better than their reading of him. They condescend to him, they dismiss his most original work in favor of the more literal and predictable rhythms of The Armies of the Night; they regard The Naked and the Dead as a promise later broken and every book since as a quick turn for his creditors, a stalling action, a spangled substitute, tarted up to deceive, for the big book he cannot write. In fact he has written this big book at least three times now. He wrote it the first time in 1955 with The Deer Park and he wrote it a second time in 1965 with An American Dream and he wrote it a third time in 1967 with Why Are We in Vietnam? and now, with The Executioner's Song, he has probably written it a fourth.

title: Music Notes: Enter Mackerras
description: The Met performances were nicely spaced out, and thought it was going to be nice to sit here, relax, enjoy the city and study some of the scores I'll have to conduct. Sir Charles Mackerras was speaking about his schedule at the Metropolitan Opera, where he is leading eight performances of Meyerbeer's Le Prophte between Sept. 25 and Oct. 26 (this week it will be given Monday and Saturday evenings).

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Theater

title: No Title
description: Jamie Sue Hoffman Married In Suburbs to Michael Arnow

title: Christian de Guigne 3d, 67, Dies; Former Stauffer Chemical Chief
description: Christian de Guigne 3d, a chairman emeritus and a member of the board of directors of Stauffer Chemical Company of Westport, Conn., died Friday at his home in San Mateo, Calif., after a long illness. He was 67 years old.

title: GARDENING
description: THIS is a critical time of year for house plants, especially. those that spent the summer outdoors. If left outside too long, obviously, they will freeze. Less obvious is that even chilled plants may be damaged.

title: Reporter's .Notebook: Covering the Pope From a Distance
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  Were this tour of the United States a military operation with Pope John Paul II and the traveling press on opposite sides, military historians would judge it thus: The press repeatedly outflanked the Pope, but seldom engaged the objective.

title: Israel and Egypt to Cooperate for the Handicapped
description: CAIRO, Oct. 6  Egypt and Israel are anticipating working together to help rehabilitate the handicapped in both countries, according to a prominent American physician who has just completed a working visit here.

title: HEALTHY HAIR
description: It doesn't matter whether the hairstyle of the moment is long, flowing tresses or a short crop of curls. The key to any style's beauty has always been healthy hair tamed with a good cut. And with the time crunch that most women face these days, balancing a family on one hand and a career on the other, there is little time to do much beyond keeping hair clean and healthy. Speaking to the heart of the matter, New Yorkbased hairdresser Christiaan Houtenbos says, If a hairstyle can't be done simply with three pins or less, forget it, it's too tricky.

title: Flaubert the Correspondent
description: IF there is one article of faith that dominates the Credo of Gustave Flaubert's correspondence, it is that the function of great art is not to provide answers. To suppose that art need respond only to such questions as we are capable of posing is, in Flaubert's view, a presumption, an egotistic fallacy. If art has a function, it is to extend us into unimagined shocks, experiences, pleasures, reflections. Art is discovery, as much as recognition.

title: Walinsky's Investigative Goals
description: WE'RE going to go where the money is, said Adam Walinsky, the former candidate for State Attorney General who was named chairman of the State Commission of Investigation by Governor Carey in May. and look very carefully at the system wnicn aflects the enormous stream of money passing through the government. We've seen very often that those receiving benefits are really the organized criminal element.

title: The States Are Becoming A Little More Sovereign
description: What may prove to be a profound change in American government has taken place so gradually that it has received little notice. Over the past decade, the states, for many years the shadow governments of the Federal system, have strengthened their position, and are now in range of regaining some of the authority they lost to Washington.

title: Work Stoppage Hurts Iona Meet
description: The effects of the work stoppage by coaches at the city's public high schools were seen yesterday in the Iona College Scholastic Cross Country Meet held at Van Cortlandt Park. It was the first local scholastic meet of the season and only three of the city's 83 public schools competed. The coaches of these schools represent a small group that has decided to stay on the job despite the widespread work stoppage.

title: Pope at Ease As Evangelist
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 6  In the land where evangelists have thrived, Pope John Paul II has made his mark as a preacher. As he moved from stop to stop, dwelling at first on human rights, then concentrating on church discipline, his manner in some respects resembled the style of a traditional American revivalist.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: ELMSFORD  Unsinkable Molly Brown. Daily, except Mondays. Through Nov. 25. Opens 8:15 P.M., buffet at 7, show at 8:30. Sundays one hour earlier. 818.15 to $20.35. Reservations. An Evening Dinner Theater, 11 Clearbrook Rd. 5922222.

title: Invitation to Join ASCAP Offered To John Paul for His Songwriting
description: NASHVILLE, Oct. 6 (UPI)  Pope John Paul II has been invited to join the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, which would put him in the company of Irving Berlin, Stevie Wonder and many country music greats.

title: Linda Martin, Actress, Wed
description: Linda Lisa Martin, an actress, was married yesterday to Valerio Louis Giannini, a White House aide. The ceremony was performed in the Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Weston, Conn., by the Rev. C. Michael Thornburg. He was assisted by the Rev. Dr. Arthur Caliandro of the Marble Collegiate Church in New York.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: BROOKVILLE Art sale, to benefit Arts Student Loan Fund; 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Friday, Saturday; Hillwood Commons, C.W. Poet.

title: TV VIEW
description: Adapting a novel for television is generally a thankless affair. The typical complaints are familiar: the story was butchered, too much was left out or rearranged, the spirit of the book was violated. Over the years, this column has had countless opportunities to become ever so properly indignant over such matters. Now, however, I am confronted with a television production whose only major fault is being too faithful to its source material. This rare bird is Love for Lydia currently being serialized on public television's Masterpiece Theater. The novel was written H.E. Bates. The adaptation was done for London Weekend Television by Julian Bond.

title: Joan Prescott, J. R. Busk 3d Plan to Marry
description: The engagement of Joan Gaye Prescott to Joseph Richard Busk 3d has been announced by the bridetobe's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd William Prescott of Cohasset, Mass., and Louds Island, Me. Mr. Busk is a son of Mr. Busk Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Gladys Terbell Busk. The wedding will take place next September.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: FINAL TOUCHES
description: I don't believe in overdressing or overdoing anything, and this goes doubly for a woman's face, says Rex Hilverdink, a prominent New Yorkbased makeup artist known simply as Rex. Though his clients include Faye Dunaway, Sophia Loren, Jacqueline Bisset, Ali McGraw and the Duchess of Windsor, his approach to makeup is equally applicable to the average woman.

title: Estelle Gains Quarterfinal In Havemeyer Golf Event
description: BAY SHORE, L.I., Oct. 6Chris Estelle, 45yearold president of Southward Ho Country Club, advanced to the quarterfinal round of the annual Horace Havemeyer Memorial tournament today over his home course.

title: Bridges, Jordan Lift Manasquan
description: Gary Bridges and Tyrone Jordan hooked up for a 78yard touchdown pass with 1:23 remaining to rally Manasquan (30) to a 107 victory over Rumson (11) yesterday at Rumson.

title: Pianist: Andreas Klein
description: Andreas Klein, a young German pianist and a student of Claudio Arrau's, began threerecital series Wednesday night in Carnegie Recital Hall, rather grandly entitled Andreas Klein Playing Masterworks. Warhorses is more like it, but at least Mr. Klein can't be accused of failing to meet the core repertory headon. Subsequent recitals in the series are Oct. 31 and Nov. 15.

title: WHITE HOUSE SPURS FUNDS FOR FLORIDA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  The White House has instructed Government agencies to expedite Federal grants earmarked for Florida in an effort to help President Carter defeat Senator Edward M. Kennedy in the state's county caucuses Oct. 13, White House aides acknowledged today.

title: Tax Law Lends Preservation a Hand
description: Like many of their neighbors, Paul and Belinda Apostol gave up Manhattan highrise living to invest in a beautiful but dilapidated Victorian house in the Park Slope Historic District in Brooklyn. They proceeded to renovate it as owneroccupiers, choosing the lower floors for themselves and creating a rental duplex apartment upstairs.

title: Study Sees Plight of Hispanics
description: YONKERS

title: Insurer Planning Policy to Cover Costs in First Amendment Cases
description: As a result cif the rapidly increasing number of First Amendment cases, the MutUal Insurance Company of Bermuda is drawing up an insurance policy to cover the legal costs of prosecuting or defending court suits and mandated appearances before Congress and Federal agencies.

title: Japanese Experimental Rail Car Sets Record 253 M.P.H. in Test
description: TOKYO, Oct. 6 (AP)  An experimental linear car, floating almost five inches above the track on a magnetic cushion, reached a speed of 253 miles an hour today, surpassing its record of 237 miles per hour set 10 days ago, Japan National Railway officials said.

title: China Will Give Japan A Replacement Panda
description: TOKYO, Oct. 6 (UPI)  China told Japn today that it would present a female giant panda to Tokyo during the visit to Peking in December of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira, the Kyodo news service reported. The panda will replace 10yearold Lan Lan, who died of a kidney ailment at Tokyo's Ueno Zoo on Sept. 4.

title: Money Shouts As Japan Gets Ready to Vote
description: CHIBA CITY, JapanThe chairman of Japan's Socialist Party, Ichio Asukata, was stumping his Tokyo constituency for today's general election. I picked up the morning paper at breakfast, he said, and I read that former Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda failed to pay his taxes. That could happen to all of us, I thought.

title: WORKING OUT THE KINKS
description: ForLydia Bach, owner of Lotte Berk Method Ltd. and author of Awake! Aware! Alive! (Random House), which explains that method, exercise is a way of life: a panacea for coping with bulges, sleeplessness, depression, advancing age and rattled nerves. Fitness is total, says Bach.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: IN Darien, Norwalk and Monroe, renting with an option to buy is being offered to close deals as tight money slows an already sluggish real estate market.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE FUGU PLAN

title: Marriage Announcement 27 -- No Title
description: Suzanne Ruth Waldron Is Wed

title: What's Behind Mushrooms on Toast
description: MULLICA HIU TO COMMERCIAL mushroom growers, a cookout is not what you do to steak and mushrooms on a grill, but what you do to compost to prepare it for mushroom spawn. You had better be particular where you buy your compost, said Alfred S. Caltibiano, because the cookout is the most important part of mushroom growing.

title: A Bookish Odyssey From Avid Reader To Rare Bookbinder
description: At the age of 3, she could read. Now she can read in four languages and has long had a taste for 17thcentury English Renaissance literature. But she doesn't just read books, she binds them.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: I GREW up in New Jersey, a child of Eastern European Jewish immigrants who gave up a hand laundry in New York City for the uncertain pleasures of a poultry farm in Farmingdale, in Monmouth Copunty.

title: U.N. Employee From Poland Disappears While Visiting Warsaw
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 6 Alicja Wesolowska, a 35yearold United Nations staff member with a wide range of friends from the East and the West, was ending her home leave in Poland and looking forward to promotion and an exotic United Nations job in Mongolia.

title: PHILIPPINE MAOISTS ARE GAINING SUPPORT
description: BANAUE, the Philippines  In a campaign to enlist rural support, the Maoists New People's Army skillfully exploits popular dissatisfaction with the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos to raise the political consciousness of largely apolitical people and gather support.

title: ART
description: AS THE first English gallery to open a branch in New Jersey, the Lower Nupend has found suitably picturesque surroundings in The Livery, on Cooper Avenue here. It has come all the way from Cradlesy, a small town near Malvern in Worcestershire, to accommodate, as the announcement says, a rapidly increasing appreciation of English painting from the 18th, 19th and early 20th centuries. vern in Worcestershire, to accommodate, as the announcement says, a rapidly increasing appreciation of English painting from the 18th, 19th and early 20th centuries.

title: Marriage Announcement 2 -- No Title
description: Joyce Litwin Is Fiance Of Lewis C. Zimmerman

title: South Carolina's Low Country
description: My family's idea of a vacation is a day crowded with emptiness. A leisurely afternoon blends into evening the way the sea meets the sky  almost imperceptiblyand the biggest decision to be made is what to read on the beach or eat for dinner. Over the years we have found that islands are especially wonderful places to do nothing, and one of our favorite havens for relentless lassitude is Pawleys Island, S.C.

title: Eilen e S. Villa To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. George W. Villa of Westfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eilene Sugen Villa, to Jeffrey Gilbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Gilbert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The wedding is planned for Dec. 1.

title: Clutch Play Recalls Feats by Robinson
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 6  As soon as Doug DeCinces had turned the double play that went a long way toward assuring the American League pennant for the Baltimore Orioles today, the instantaneous reaction was to compare the third baseman's clutch catch and throw with similar spectaculars performed by Brooks Robinson, his predecessor at third base.

title: Flow of Water in Nation's Rivers Is Heavy for Third Year in a Row
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)  For the third consecutive year, the flow of water in the nation's streams and rivers is abnormally heavy, according to the United States Geological Survey.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Watching the New York City Ballet perform George Balanchine's Union Jack in London last month, Nicholas Dramgoole of the Sunday Telegraph decided this ballet by English standards is pretty detestable. ... Strong men in the audience were uttering cries of disbelief as it happened; others were walking out. ... Outside his chosen area  dancers with expressionless faces and minimal costumes making movements to illuminate classical music Balanchine flounders.and other critics did find specific works to their liking, just as a few more sympathetic to the company disliked specific ballets (Deirdre McMahon in What's On in London found Mr. Robbins's Goldberg Variations the dud of the season).

title: McEnroe's Triumph Gives U.S. 20 Lead
description: SYDNEY., Australia, Oct. 6 (AP) John McEnroe was on his best behavior today as he defeated Australia's John Alexander to give the United States a 20 lead in the 1979 Davis Cup tennis semifinals.

title: Mark Monica, the Coach's Son, Does It All as Madisonboro Wins
description: Mark Monica, son of the head coach, Ted Monica, ran for two touchdowns, passed for another, and kicked five extra points as undefeated Madison Boroough beat Springfield, 416, at Madison. It was Madison Borough's 28th consecutive victory, the longest winning streak in New Jersey.

title: No Title
description: Amanda Ried Becomes Bride

title: BOOK ENDS
description: The National Air and Space Museum in Washington turns out to be the most popular museum in the world. More than 25 million people have passed through its doors since the museum opened, in 1976. Naturally, those impressive numbers have led to the creation of a book, which will be published later this month by Harry N. Abrams. Not surprising ly, it is to be called The National Air and Space Museum.

title: Royal Navy Battles Mal de Mer
description: LONDON, Oct. 5 (Reuters)  The British Navy, which once boasted that it ruled the waves, is looking for someone to cure seasickness. The navy, advertising through the Medical Research Council, wants a threeyear project to help end what it calls motion sickness. A Royal Navy spokesman explained: It's like the common cold. There is still no effective remedy for seasickness, which impairs efficiency.

title: The End of Joe Morgan's Year
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6  Joe Morgan cried, but not from physical pain. It was the pain inside that broke him down.

title: Transformer of the Arts
description: NOW, what do you do in the company? asked King Alfonso of Spain upon meeting the famed ballet impresario. You don't conduct. You don't dance. You don't play the piano. What do you do? Your Majesty, I'm like you, replied the tactful Sergei Diaghilev, I don't work, I do nothing, but I am indispensable.

title: On the Quick Fix and the Future of the Public University
description: IN these times when it is not fashionable, I find myself feeling deeply optimistic about the future relationship between the people of Connecticut and the state's public university  provided that we can all avoid society's increasing tendency to look for a quick fix.

title: Herbs and Lore With Lunch
description: COVENTRY

title: A Very European Story
description: CANDIDO

title: ANTIQUES
description: FOOKING at the unprepossessing front of the Freehold Antique and Craft Center at 27 Front Street, one would never know that there were 20 dealers inside. The rooms seem to extend, mazelike, to display a variety of antiques, collectibles (maybe a bit too many for some antiquers) and an array of crafts, including even cake decorating.

title: Pamela Fairbanks, a Bard Alumna, Married
description: At Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Manchester, Mass., yesterday afternoon, Pamela Wiley Fairbanks, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Rollin J. Fairbanks of Manchester, became the bride of Crawford Neal Kirkpatrick 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Kirkpatrick Jr. of Ruxton, Md. The Rev. Eugene Van Ness Goetchius, who teaches biblical languages at the Episcopal Divinity School in Cambridge, Mass., performed the ceremony. The bridegroom's uncle, the Rev. Edward B. Gross, a Presbyterian minister, assisted.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: Apparently there's something about tall that sends people antiquing. And antiquing everyone can go this week, taking advantage of seven really big shows on tap.

title: No Title
description: Miss Lividini Betrothed To Gerard John Inzerillo

title: THEATER
description: STAMFORD WHILE other theater companies are getting ready to open for the new season, the Hartman Theater Company finds itself momentarily homeless as it prepares to move to a new location. The Hartman, entering its fifth season as the only resident theater in Fairfield County, will be moving from the old Palace Theater at 61 Atlantic Street to the Stamford, currently a movie house at 307 Atlantic Street on the corner of Tresser Boulevard.

title: A Temple Is Not Just A Dream
description: NEW CAANAN ARON BRESLOW is nothing if not a practical man. After 21 years as a manager of his family's retail stationery business, he researched and wrote a children's history book and, finding no takers for the project, founded his own company to publish it.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology had no shortage of qualified and eager candidates to succeed Dr. Jerome B. Wiesner as president, but when all was said and done last week the job went to the Institute's own No. 2, Chancellor Paul E. Gray.

title: CAPITAL REPORT
description: MORE than half the members of the State Legislature  55 percent, to be exact  have disclosed in a survey that they now send, or have sent, one or more of their children to a private school.

title: An Interview With KHOMEINI
description: Last month Oriana Fallaci, the Italian journalist who is noted for her provocative interviews with world leaders, journeyed to Iran in hopes of meeting with the leader of the Islamic Revolution, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. For 10 days she waited in the holy city of Qum for her interview with the 79yearold Ayatollah, who is the de facto ruler of Iran. On Sept. 12, she was led into the Faizeyah religious school, where Khomeini holds his audiences. She was accompanied by two Iranians Nyho had helped set up the interview and who served as translators. Miss Fallaci, barefoot, enveloped in a chador  the headtotoe veil of the Moslem woman was seated on a carpet; when the Ayatollah entered, the taped interview began. Miss Fallaci returned the following day for a second audience. The text on these pages is an edited transcript of the sessions.

title: Dr. Joseph Raseta Is Dead at 95; Opposed French in Madagascar
description: ANTANANARIVO, Madagascar, Oct. 6 (AP)  Dr. Joseph Raseta, who was sentenced to death in 1947 for his activities against the French colonial authorities, died Friday at the age of 95, two days after he was named a Hero of the Revolution, it was announced today.

title: SAUDIS ALLOT BILLION TO DIG UP THEIR PAST
description: DURHAM, N.C.  Saudi Arabia, which has set aside almost $1 billion to find, study and preserve relics of its heritage, plans a campaign of archaeological field work that it hopes will yield information about the site of biblical Ophir, where gold was mined for King Solomon, and other mysteries of the Arabian past.

title: The World
description: After nearly a month of desultory maneuvers, the London talks on the future of Zimbabwe Rhodesia may turn decisive this week.

title: A Correction
description: An article in the Connecticut Fashion supplement on Sept. 16 incorrectly gave the town in which the Repertoire clothing shop is located. The shop is at 125 Main Street in Westport.

title: Nimble Visitors From Taiwan
description: We steal from everybodyand I'm proud to say that I'm a good thief  we only steal the best. Lin Hwaimin, the 32yearold founder, artistic director and chief choreographer of the Cloud Gate Dance Theater of the Re public of China (Taiwan), was forthright during a recent interview. The Cloud Gate troupe will make its New York debut Saturday night (with a repeat performance next Sunday afternoon) at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College.

title: Those Who Went to School Under Sputnik Reach MagazineBuying Age
description: By this time next year, readers will be able to choose their science magazines as they select their news of current events  from a field so wide that at least one periodical is bound to speak to their interests and their level of understanding.

title: Remarks by Pope at White House and Before Organization of American States
description: Following are a transcript of Pope John Paul II's comments upon departing the White House yesterday afternoon, as recorded by The New York Times, and excerpts from an English translation of his remarks in Spanish to the Organization of American States, as distributed by United Press International:

title: Plan for Drink Chests in Hotels
description: APROPOSAL by the State Liquor Authority to allow refrigerators stocked with alcohol and soft drinks in hotel rooms has drawn criticism from some Westchester organizations and medical experts. They see it as unnecessary and possibly dangerous temptation for solitary drinkers, and say the plan could lead to loss of control over the ages of people using the hotelroom liquor.

title: MobileHome Regulation Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)  After four and a half years of study and extensive hearings, a Federal official has concluded that buyers of mobile homes often have a hard time getting defects fixed and need Federal protection.

title: U.S. SPY PLANE TAKES PICTURES OVER CUBA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  The United States sent an SR71 reconnaissance plane over Cuba yesterday to take pictures of the Soviet brigade there, Administration officials disclosed today.

title: Europeans Buy Homes Of 2 Former Presidents
description: CHARLES CITY, Va., Oct. 6 (AP) Foreign investors have purchased the birthplaces of two Virginiaborn American Presidents.

title: No Title
description: Ivy Lisa Perlowin Is Affianced

title: Two Groups of Dissident Teamsters Plan a Merger
description: Two dissident organizations in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters are planning a merger that they hope will result in a strong movement to contest the leadership of the union and lobby effectively in . Washington for improved safety for truck drivers.

title: THE NEW FITNESS
description: As a result of the new emphasis on keeping fit, health clubs are booming, interest in sports is surging and a new crop of experts is devising methods for the care and protection of the body and the face. The prerequisites for beauty today are luminous skin, shining hair and a slender, welltoned body. The fashion and cosmetics industries are aware of this new healthconscious. ness: subtly shaped clothes reveal the body's curves, and translucent makeup products enhance  rather than hide a wellcaredfor complexion. oas for the care and protection of the body and the face. The prerequisites for beauty today are luminous skin, shining hair and a slender, welltoned body. The fashion and cosmetics industries are aware of this new healthconscious. ness: subtly shaped clothes reveal the body's curves, and translucent makeup products enhance  rather than hide a wellcaredfor complexion.

title: McCoy, Giles Pace Ramapo
description: Undefeated Ramapo, defeated a surprisingly tough Nyack team, 167, yesterday for its third victory.

title: U.S. School Meals Under Study
description: WASTINGTON Oct 8 (AP)  Two private companies have been awarded Government conirdcts totaling $4.5 million to review Federal school meal programs, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday.The System Development Corporation of Santa Monica, Calif., awarded a $3.5 million contract, is to issue a major study in January 1982. A $992,382 contract went to Mathtech Inc. of Atlanta, to study menu choice, food production and costs of school lunch and breakfast programs. A final report is due Dec. 1, 1980, the department said.

title: Iranian Students Divided in India
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 6 (Reuters) About 200 Iranian and Indian students, members of the AllIndia Iranian Stu, dents Association, demonstrated in New Delhi today demanding action against the Iranian Islamic Students Association, which supports Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. The IndiaIranian association said the Khomeini group had been attacking progressive Iranian students in the western Indian city of Poona.

title: Ann Stanton Maulsby Is Bride
description: The marriage of Ann Stanton Maulsby to Herbert W. Warden 3d took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers performed the ceremony. This is the bride's third marriage. Her first husband, Charles M. Post Jr., died and her second marriage ended in divorce. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Lee Stanton of New York and New Canaan. Mr. Warden's previous marriage ended in divorce. He is a son of Mrs. Warden Jr. of Santa Barbara, Calif., and the late Mr. Warden.

title: Headliners
description: You can't go home again, not before we are good and ready at any rate. That is what Czechoslovak border guards told Pavel Kohout, the playwright who has been identified in that country with human rights causes, when he tried to reenter the country from Austria last week. Mr. Kohout was traveling abroad on a oneyear exit visa but attempted to return before its expiration, in part because of rumors he and his wife, Jelena, have been stripped of citizenship. Bor- . der guards reportedly told him to return to Vienna to pick up a Czechoslovak embassy letter authorizing his entry. The embassy told him to come back later.

title: Louvre to Open 2 More Doors
description: PARIS, Oct. 6 (AP)  The Louvre, foremost museum of French art, has decided to open two more doors, because its existing three are insufficient to handle its average of 25,000 visitors a day, the museum announced today. The Louvre, built as a royal palace and fortress in the 12th century, was rebuilt in the mid16th century and now houses the works of many Italian and Flemish masters as well as a large collection of Greek, Roman and Egyptian art.

title: Soviet Ship Is in Greece For Repairs Under Pact
description: SIROS, Greece, Oct. 6 (Reuters)  A Soviet cargo ship arrived for repairs at this Aegean island today, the first under a new arrangement between Greece and the Soviet Union.

title: The Floating Hospital Is Ailing Financially; Benefit Party Planned
description: The lines have been tossed ashore and secured to Pier 15 South on Manhattan's East River the Floating Hospital's season of cruises around Manhattan season is over. But its reduced offseason crew and staff are still prepared to take aboard patients and visitors, young and old.

title: Southern California Wins Fifth, 50 to 21
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6 (AP)  Paul McDonald's passing and the running of Charles White and Marcus Allen staked Southern California to a 4314 halftime lead as the Trojans scored a 5021 victory today over Washington State.

title: A Hobo for 51 Years Sees a Dip in Quality Of Life of Riding Rails
description: SALT LAKE CITY (AP)  One rainy day in January 1928, when he was 14 years old, John Fisk's sister sent him to buy a loaf of bread. He didn't come back.

title: THE GLORY THAT WAS CHARLOTTE
description: It has been two years now since President Carter stepped out of his black limousine and, for 10 minutes, entered the world of Charlotte Street, making it a national symbol of urban blight. His visit was the final brushstroke of an 80year tableau of construction and demolition, a process that has caused the lonesome South Bronx block to be renamed by area residentsgarda vacia, the empty lot.

title: Smithsonian Extends Hours
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)  The six museums of the Smithsonian Institution, situated on the Capitol Mall, are staying open late during Pope John Paul II's visit to accommodate record crowds, the institution said. After Labor Day, the museums usually close at 5:30 P.M. But with thousands of people expected to gather on the Mall for the Pope's mass tomorrow, and thousands more expected to be caught in traffic jams afterward, the museums will remain open until 9 P.M. Eastem daylight time, the Smithsonian said.

title: New ChurchState Issue Is Raised in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 (UPI)  The American Civil Liberties Union, target of hate mail and bomb threats because of its opposition to spending tax money for the platform on which Pope John Paul II celebrated mass in Philadelphia, has asked the city to stop supporting a Jewish ceremony.

title: Canadian Premier Will Set His Course This Week
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 6  On the eve of the first session of Parliament to be controlled by Conservatives in 16 years, Canadians began a long Thanksgiving weekend today with cautious optimism.

title: F.B.I. Agrees to Cease Its Illegal Surveillance Of Research Institute
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation has agreed not to conduct illegal surveillance of a leftwing research institute that was the target of bureau spying in the 1960's and early 1970's, according to court records.

title: GARDENING
description: THIS is a critical time of year for house plants, especially those that spent the summer outdoors. If left outside too long, obviously, they will freeze. Less obvious is that even chilled plants may be damaged.

title: 1953 Defection by a Polish Flier: Fame, Success and Some Regrets
description: ERIE, Pa., Oct. 6 (AP)  Frank Jarecki, honored as the top young flier in Poland and entrusted with the most sophisticated Soviet aircraft of the day, abandoned career and country in 1953 in a 60mile flight over the Baltic Sea to Denmark.

title: German Rabbinical High School
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Oct. 6 (Reuters)  West Germany's first rabbinical high school will open in the city of Heidelberg in two weeks, it was announced here yesterday. The West German state governments will pay 70 percent of the cost, and the rest will come from the Central Council of Jews in Germany. The school will teach future rabbis and cantors.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BROOKLYN  Posters by Henri de ToulouseLautrec from the Lautrec Museum at Albi, France; Radka DonnellVogt, quilts and fabric art; Christina Olson Spiesel, oil paintings; Anne GreeneCloutier, paintings, watercolors, drawings. New England Center for Contemporary Art, Rte.169, through Oct. 31. Daily 1 to 5. Free. 7748899.

title: The Polls Don't Mean a Thing
description: Understandably, many publicopinionpoll watchers are leaping to the conclusion that with his spectacular lead over President Carter, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, if nominated, will be a surefire winner in next November's election.

title: GAINS ARE REPORTED IN CLEANAIR BATTLE
description: TRENTON, Oct. 5  A 10year effort to curb industrial air pollution in New Jersey is beginning to pay health dividends, according to a report by the New Jersey Economic Policy Coucil.

title: Donna L. Manheim Fiance of L.L. Reif
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Manheim of New York and Hemlock Farms, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna L. Manheim, to L. Leslie Reif, son of Mrs. Paul Reif of New York and the late Mr. Reif. The wedding is planned for the spring.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Grow Your Own Ginger Root
description: Those who enjoy Chinese or Indian cuisine know that fresh ginger root is a basic spice. Powdered ginger has been a kitchen staple for centuries, used in preparing such classic edibles as ginger bread and ginger snaps.The current popularity of cooking Eastern food has made many aware of the fresh form of this peppery spice. But it is difficult to locate in the markets and expensive.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Lime Rock Park in Lakeville closes its auto racing season Saturday with the North Atlantic Road Racing Runoffs from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. The event determines area champions in 18 classes and carries purses totaling $12,500.Bushnell Hall, Hartford's popular emporium of the arts, will celebrate its 50th anniversary next year. To mark this rite of passage, Trinity College has scheduled an unusual series of lectures focusing on the history and importance of the landmark.

title: THE POLITICS OF CHARLOTTE STREET
description: It was on Feb. 8 last winter that the Charlotte Street housing project, a 732unit dream that the Koch administration had pledged to make a reality, was wiped off the map of the South Bronx amid a welter of bad communications, ill will and deep misgivings. The $32 million project was envisioned as the keystone of an ambitious $1.5 billion redevelopment plan. But 16 months after President Carter had paused amid the rubble to affirm his cornmittment to rebuilding the area, the Charlotte Street development was defeated 7 to 4 by the city's Board of Estimate.

title: Sunday Observer
description: In New England the rear bumpers of automobiles kept ordering me to Think Bluefish. I do not like bluefish and, perhaps for this reason, rarely think about them except when invited out to dinner, in which case I usually submit a brief prayer that the hostess will not serve bluefish.

title: Poetry Is the Best Therapy I Know
description: ARTHUR DOBRIN stands there, tall, lean and bearded, with the face of a man who can hold a gift behind his back and look as though he has nothing to hide.

title: James Warnock to Wed Alison Branwood
description: Dr. and Mrs. A. Whitley Branwood of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, AlisonMary Branwood to James Warnock, son of Dr. and Mrs. John M. T. Warnock of Ayrshire, Scotland.

description: IF you've been hankering after a taste of kohlrabi or gooseberries or ichiban eggplant or fresh basil, but didn't know where to find them in this orepackaged age, look no

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: RIDDLE: How can you leave Hartford and travel southeast instead of southwest and still hope to arrive in Washington, D.C.? Answer: Move to the town of Preston and get elected to the House of Renresentatives.

title: Department of Consumer Affairs Regulates 66 Kinds of Enterprises in 35 Categories; Liberty or License? City Is Appraising Them Both
description: The City Department of Consumer Affairs, as its name suggests, is supposed to regulate buying and selling of commodities and services to prevent fraud and deception in the marketplace. But that is only one part of it. A good portion of the department's resources are Riven to another function that, over the years, has inflated its authority beyond what normally would be expected of a $4.4 millionayear agency. It now issues 66 different licenses for 35 sate gories of business and much of the licensing has less to do with protecting the public from fraud and deceit than with protecting public morality.

title: High Inflation, Less Rigid Controls Complicate Economic Policy
description: RIO de JANEIRO  Brazilian political cartoonists love his portly shape and owlish look, a wellknown comedian has made an impersonation of him the centerpiece of his weekly television appearances and the cover artists of Brazil's magazines dress him in everything from superman costumes to the boots and chaps of a Western lawman come to town to restore order.

title: Britain Steps Up Its Efforts to Bring Peace to Ulster
description: LONDON, Oct. 6The British Government moved on several fronts this week in its continuing effort to bring peace to Northern Ireland, but there was no particular sign that the goal had become any less elusive.

title: Tice Farms Roadside Market in Bergen, a Landmark Since 1920's, Is Damaged by Fire
description: WOODCLIFF LAKE, N.J., Oct. 5 The old, red roadside market at Tice Farms, which since the 1920's has attracted droves of people eager for autumn's fresh cider, handpicked apples and fat pumpkins, was extensively damaged last night by a fire that lasted five hours.

title: Adele Veri Is Wed To Stephen Haley
description: The marriage of Adele Margaret Veri, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank A. Veri of Lancaster, Pa., to Stephen Putney Haley, son of George Henry Haley of Rye, N.Y., and the late Anne Coleman Haley, took place yesterday in St. dames npiscopai Church in Lancaster. The Rev. Stanley Imboden and the Rev. Lawrence Gross of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Lancaster, performed the ceremony.

title: L.I. Law Firms Gain in Links To Politics
description: FOR the second'time in recent months, an Apppellate Division Justice will leave one of the state's most prestigious courts to join a politically potent law firm on the Island, thus focusing attention on the growing number of wellconnected law firms here. Indeed, Justice J. Irwin Shapiro is not only leaving the appellate bench a few months after his colleague, Joseph. Suozzi, but, even more unusual, is joining the same law firm, Suozzi, English, Cianciulli & Peirez, in Mineola. It is probably the most politically connected law firm on the Island, but not the only one.

title: A First for The Yale Daily News
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 6Ten years atter. women were first admitted to Yale University, the 101-year-old Yale Daily News last night elected its first female editorinchief. The new editorAnne Perkins, a 20-year-old history major from Baltimore  will hold the post until October 1980.

title: W. Virginia 10, Kentucky 6
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 6 (AP)  Robert Alexander, a reserve running back, ran 69 yards to set up the only touchdown of the game as West Virginia, aided by a thirdquarter goalline stand, defeated crippled Kentucky, 106, today.

title: Pol Pot's Peking Envoy Charges Vietnamese With Million Deaths
description: PEKING, Oct. 6 (UPI)  More than a million Cambodians have been killed by Vietnamese troops or have starved to death since Hanoi's forces invaded Cambodia in January, the Pol Pot regime's Ambassador to China charged today.

description: Today  Nimrod Farm, Weston Road, Weston, Conn. Junior working hunters, Ponies, Equitation. 8 A.M.

title: Winterizing Aid Being Stepped Up
description: A $200 million Federal appropriation to provide insulation for the homes of lowincome families was largely untapped during the fiscal year that ended last week, according to Department of Energy officials who said that a lack of qualified workmen and materials and limits on spending had stymied the program.

title: Flight Aide Says Downed Balloon Did Not Violate Rules of F.A.A.
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 6 (UPI) The DaVinci TransAmerica balloon did not require an instrument flight plan for its attempted crosscountry trip and, therefore, did not violate Federal regulations, the flight's codirector says.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: The Administration gave the Soviet Union permission to buy up to 25 million tons of grain last week, 10 million tons more than the Russians bought in the crop year just ended and seven million tons more than the surprise purchases in 1972 that sent domestic prices soaring.

description: INTEREST in solar energy, stimulated by everrising prices for sometimeshardtoget fuel and by the Three Mile Island incident in Pennsylvania last March, is warming up.

description: The fall blockparty scene in New York City began yesterday with a fair by a new entry  the 200 block of East 74th Street, between Second and Third Avenues.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Most Westerners will be totally unprepared for the Japanese ceramics exhibition that opened last week at Azuma Gallery, 192 Greene Street. For the Soho establishment of Norio Azuma is presenting a wealth of extraordinary material, selections that in their stark simplicity are a far cry from the highly decorative wares found in most Japanese ceramics shows. me majority of these 150 clay cups, plates, bowls, vases and caddies were made for the tea ceremony. It is understandable that the rough textures, deep coloring, primitive shaping and abstract patterning would increase the intensity of that experience for participants. These are works made to be touched from foot to rim. To fully ap

title: Heating Costs Further Peril State Projects
description: High costs for fuel on this winter will further strain the alreadyweak financial condition of many state housing projects and could cause a number to default, according to the state housing commissioner.

title: Giants: Old Bucs Tougher
description: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers may be undefeated this season, but they don't strike fear into the hearts of the Giants, not the way the old Tampa Bay Buccaneers, the franchise that began its National Football League history with 26 straight losses, did. Now there was a team to be feared, a team that couldn't be played without an adequate supply of antacid tablets.

title: Image vs. Reality On a Sudan Visit
description: Most Sudanese seen in the outside world, diplomats and employees of Sudan Air, for example, are northerners. Southerners do not complain about these things; they simply answered our questions: A 30-year-old member of the Southern Assembly told us, for example, that she was the first woman from the south to graduate from the University of Khartoum.

title: Can Burlesque Succeed on BroadwayAfter 50 Years?
description: He perches atop a folding chair in the bare rehearsal studio on lower Fifth Avenue. Portly, roundfaced, eyes the color of his torn blue sports shirt, Mickey Rooney is Andy Hardy turned middleaged Munchkin. He has flown in from the West Coast for the first reading of Sugar Babies, a burlesque show he is supposed to star in. But Mr. Rooney has heavy doubts about the material, most of which has been around even longer than he has. Oh, he groans. It's so terrible. So rotten.

description: Only one thing appears to be certain in Ivy League soccer this season Dartmouth and Harvard will not win the title.

description: The marriage of Shyamoll Sen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sudhir Sen of New York and Calcutta, to Moses Taylor Pyne, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Pyne of Far Hills, N.J., took place yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. John Young, also a Unitarian minister, and the Rev. Lair Gerard, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Gretchen Langstaff Bride of Eric Schaffer
description: Gretchen Marie Langstaff, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Don Langstaff of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, was married yesterday afternoon to Eric Matthew Schaffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Schaffer of New York and Westport, Conn. The Rev. Dr. David Pointer performed the ceremony in the Chagrin Falls Federated Church (United Church of ChristCongregational).

title: Saving Training That Works
description: NEWLY announced cuts for training programs financed under the Federal Government's Comprehensive Employment and Training Act, or CETA, culminate a year of uncertainty for the programs. Those of us who have worked to train needy individuals have been disturbed by the confusion surrounding the payment cuts because we know that the training works. The thousands of people who have trained for jobs under CETA and who now have better way of life are the greatest testament to its value.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: WHAT do women talk about at the hairdresser? The question may seem trivial, but the answer is not. At the hairdresser, during long hours of washing, cutting, curling, dyeing and drying, women talk about everything.

title: Carey Bids U.S. Act to Assure Ample Supply of HomeHeating Fuel
description: Governor Carey, citing early upstate snows and low stockpiles of homeheating oil and kerosene throughout the state, called yesterday for Federal action to insure that the fuels get to local suppliers.

title: Hearing Examiner Recommends A Takeover of Trenton's Schools
description: A hearing examiner has recommended the complete takeover of the Trenton schools by the New Jersey Commissioner of Education, Fred G. Burke, to correct gross mismanagement and runaway patronage hiring by the local Board of Education. Mr. Burke is expected to follow the recommendation.

title: The Moving Spirit
description: For the Gospel's sake, wrote St. Paul to the Corinthians, I am made all things to all men. As Pope John Paul II's whirlwind sevenday visit to the United States drew to an end, it was clear that the Pope who took one of his names from the apostle shared some of his adaptability to various audiences. Much as his messages and the power of his personality  delighted most of his audiences most of the time, however, it became equally clear that telling all men or all women just what they wanted to hear was not among the Pope's priorities. (The Pope as world moral leader, Page 7.).

title: A Plan to Revivify New Brunswick
description: IN JULY, everybody affiliated with Rutgers University in New Brunswick received a questionnaire from the school's Department of Transportation, which was considering providing busing as means of conserving gasoline.

title: Florida's Early County Caucuses on Saturday Draw Unprecedented Attention
description: WASHINGTON  In 1972 and 1976, school busing was the key issue in Florida's Democratic Presidential primaries. Next Saturday, buses will be only a means of transportation but still a critical element in the first CarterKennedy test (outside the public opinion polls) of the 1980 race.

title: Orioles Clinch Pennant, 80, Behind McGregor's 6Hitter
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 6  The Baltimore Orioles, a carefully constructed team with baseball's best record, succeeded the New York Yankees as American League champions today, with an assist from the Yankees.

title: Sabotage Found in Plant Blast
description: BOARDMAN, Ore., Oct. 6 (UPI)  An explosion at a coalburning power plant under construction by Portland General Electric injuring six workers was the result of sabotage, a company spokesman said yesterday. He said that a safety inspection Thursday showed that someone had tampered with a number of valves in the central piping system used to provide gas to welders.

title: National Security Starts at the Pump
description: It is good to have the President of the United States safely back from a phony confrontation over Cuba. It would be better still to get on with ratifying SALT, which at least bears directly on national defense. The palpable threat to the country, however, lies elsewhere altogether, and no President or Congress can pretend to be providing for national security until it is addressed more obsessively even than Cuba.

title: Klan Faction's Recruiting Efforts Pose a Policy Problem for the Navy
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Oct. 6  By declaring a military recruiting rally here offlimits to the area's 50,000 sailors and marines, the United States Navy last night restricted a Ku Klux Klan faction to an audience made up chiefly of hecklers and riotready police officers.

title: Europeans Warn Senate Not to Reject Arms Treaty
description: PARIS, Oct. 6  Representatives of parliaments in the Atlantic alliance have begun to deliver sharp warnings that failure of the SovietAmerican arms treaty could lead to refusal by the allies to accept new United States nuclear weapons.

description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 6 (UPI)  Hurricane Frederic has set a record as the nation's worst insurance catastrophe, according to an insurance industry official.

description: WHEN it comes to the basics  the raw materials  Kelly's, a relatively new steak house in Hicksville, doesn't fool around. Prime beef, fresh seafood and fresh vegetables are the stock in trade.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  With a religious outlook rooted in a woodframe Southern Baptist church in the land of June bugs, corn cobs and sassafras roots, Jimmy Carter could scarcely seem more different from Pope John Paul II, the august spiritual leader of millions of Roman Catholics worldwide.

title: Piano: ContiGuglia Duo
description: Richard and John ContiGuglia, twin pianists who have made several New York appearances since their Town Hall debut here 12 years ago, came to the 92d Street Y last Tuesday night to play Schubert's Grand March in E (Op. 40, No. 6) and Fantasy in F iminor (Op. 103), SaintSans's Variations on a Theme of Beethoven (Op. 35) and Bartok's Suite for Two Pianos (Op. 9b).
