title: 3 Groups Getting Grants On Legal Uses of Force
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI)  The Law Enforcement Assistance Administration has awarded $816,232 to three groups to investigate the use of deadly force in law enforcement, the agency's administrator, Henry S. Dogin, announced yesterday.

title: Once a Declining Asset, Guantanamo Gets New Life
description: WASHINGTON  Two years ago, theme was talk in the Carter Administration of closing down the United States Navy base at Guantanamo Bay and withdrawing the 2,000 or so military personnel there, as part of a move to improve relations between the United States and Cuba. The Guantanamo barracks had been allowed to run down, the commanding rear admiral had been replaced by a captain, and one could hear an occasional remark from Navy or State Department officials that the handsome anchorage discovered nearly five centuries ago by Christopher Columbus was no longer a strategic necessity.

title: No Title
description: Linda P. Morrison Is Married

title: Plainfield: Bedroom Backfire
description: PLAINFIELD IN ONE of the plays in Alan Ayckbourn's trilogy, The Norman Conquests, a woman suggests that games must have some basis in reality.

title: Michigan Downs Spartans, 217
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 6 (UPI)  B.J. Dickey, a junior quarterback noted more for his running than his passing, threw secondhalf touchdown strikes of 66 yards to Ralph Clayton and 6 yards to Anthony Carter today to give Michigan a 217 victory over Michigan State in a game between the defending Big Ten cochampions.

title: Fine Things Happen When He Sings
description: IT is, Philip Creech said, just sort of a natural gift.

title: Connally Is Hero Of Choate
description: A 21yard touchdown pass from B.J. Connally to Cliff Corso with 24 seconds remaining in the game gave undefeated Choate an 1816 victory over Philips Andover yesterday.

title: Demography
description: MOSCOW  When the municipal water and power lines need fixing on Ulitsa Yermolovoy, a downtown Moscow side street, a brigade of closecropped 18yearold boys with Asiatic faces, dressed in identical khaki uniforms, appears and heaves away at the manhole covers. Many of them speak not Russian but the Turkic languages of Soviet Central Asia. They are draftees in the Red Army, which not only defends the Soviet Union but does heavy construction and maintenance work for the civilian sector.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: CAMERA
description: Highcontrast litho films, originally created to serve the needs of the graphic arts and printing fields, have in recent years become popular with darkroom experimenters in their search for offbeat images. These high contrast films are designed to reduce a normal continuoustone photograph to two distinct tones: solid black and white. By exploiting this basic property the inventive photographer can create an unlimited range of abstract effects such as simple highcontrast prints, posterizations, line drawings and photograms.

title: Amy Atwell, C.R. Williams Have Nuptials
description: Amy Louise Atwell and Charles Rockwell Williams were married yesterday at the Fox Chapel Presbyterian Church in Pittsburgh. The Rev. Henry Lawrence Thompson 3d and the Rev. Willard Wellman performed the ceremony.

title: Detroit's Leadership Organizing For the G.O.P. Convention in 80
description: DETROIT, Oct. 6 (UPI)  The city's richest and most powerful citizens have teamed up to lay a giant welcome mat across Detroit for delegates to the 1980 Rebublican National Convention.

title: No Title
description: Francine Lynn Zarkin Engaged

title: LETTERS
description: Martin Reader, writing as a student (A Look at Business From the Bottom Rung Sept. 30) on his impressions of the character of the training being presented by faculties of graduate business schools, fears a strong bias toward developing a mefirst and dehumanized cult among future business managers. Unfortunately, Mr. Reader's fears have already been realized, and what he thinks the future may hold is now upon us.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: U.S. to Help Philippines On Center for Refumees
description: MANILA, Oct. 5  The United States has pledged to support a $80 million processing center for Indochinese refugees in the Philippines.

title: South Africa Lifts Ban on Gordimer Novel
description: Nadine Gordimer's Burger's Daughter, banned in July by the South African Directorate of Publications, has won an appeal and will be permitted on bookshelves, the Government announced Tuesday. Miss Gordimer, who lives in Johannesburg, is in the United States in connection with the publication of her book here by the Viking Press.

title: What's Doing in ALBUQUERQUE
description: CHECKERBOARD CITY  When you arrive at Wichita, St. Louis or Albuquerque, it is disappointing to realize that, hidden behind these magnificent and promising names, is the same checkerboard city, with the same red and green traffic lights and the same provincial look. So wrote JeanPaul Sartre in 1945.

title: Death of Pilot Stirs MandatoryRetirement Debate.
description: Last Sunday a Pan American World Airwys Boeing 747 was about to start its descent to Los Angeles on a flight from Honolulu when the 59yearold captain asked a company check pilot in the jump seat behind him to take over while he went to the lavatory.

title: Scientist Says Money Is Key in Boll Weevil Fight
description: SAN ANTONIO, Oct. 6 (UPI)  A scientist directing a boll weevil eradication experiment has predicted elimination of the pest from the Cotton Belt in the 1980's, provided the Government and cotton industry spend $700 million.

title: Another Shellacking For Mariners, 55 to 0
description: Lou Buschi completed three of four passes, two for touchdowns, yesterday afternoon and led C.W. Post to a 550 rout of the Merchant Marine Academy in the 20th meeting between the Long Island rivals.

title: A New Nonprofit Group Is Proposed by Gardner
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI)  John Gardner, the founder of Common Cause, the selfstyled citizens lobby, has announced the proposed formation of an organization to preserve the American traditions of giving, volunteering and notforprofit initiative.

title: State Fishermen Fail to Fill Void Left by Foreign Fleets
description: TRENTON SINCE March 1, 1977, life has been a bit more serene for the hundreds of millions of fish and squid that live in the Atlantic Ocean 12 to 200 miles off the United States coastline.

title: Poet and Teachers
description: THE hour is late, the hour rings with confusion  The novel opens with a welcoming party, a scene of jealous, strained, fairly poisoned attentiveness, the characteristic swarming of small academics around a Great Name. In his 71st year, the British poet Albert St. Dennis has come to Woodslee College as Distinguished Professor of Poetry. And he is indeed distinguished: The Times Literary Supplement says so. His reputation stands, reportedly, above Auden's, but below Eliot's and Yeats's. The presence of St. Dennis is many things to many men at Woodslee: a public relations boost to the college, a personal coup for the dean of humanities, potential source of advancement to the various scheming members of the English faculty and an object intense fantasy to almost everyone. The poet, we soon discover, is hardly up to it and, what's more, is so selfabsorbed that he hardly notices.

title: Stenmark Fit After Injury
description: UMEA, Sweden, Oct. 6 (AP)  Ingemar Stenmark has fully recovered from his head injury and can resume ski training immediately, doctors said after a final medical checkup here today. Stenmark, the world's top slalom and giant slalom racer, was injured Sept. 15 after taking a bad spill during downhill training at Schnalstal, Italy.

title: The Economy: A Quick Fix Won't Work
description: JUST a year ago, the American economy was in dire straits, with accelerating inflation and a declining dollar. As a result, in a hectic week culminating on Nov. 1, the Carter Administration launched a twin economic rescue mission.

title: Stevens Plant Votes for Union
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI)  Workers at a J.P. Stevens textile plant in High Point, N.C., have voted to have the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union represent them. The union said yesterday that the balloting, conducted by the National Labor Relations Board, had resulted in a 68to48 victory despite what it called a massive campaign of dismissals, coercion and intimidation by the company.

title: DINING OUT
description: IF you are looking for a comfortable, unpretentious restaurant that serves pleasant fare in quantities to satisfy the hearty appetite, the popular Nino's in Bedford Village is worth a visit.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as In bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: A New, Unified Army Is Rhodesia's Biggest Challenge
description: LONDON, Oct. 6  Inside Zimbabwe Rhodesia and scattered along its hilly border regions, more than 100,000 armed men are at war.

title: Army Cancels Gun Order After Surplus Discovered
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)  The Army has agreed not to spend $10.2 million for machine guns since Congressional investigators found thousands of the weapons that the Pentagon did not know it had.

title: Experts Call Acid Rain Growing Problem in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)  Acid rain is getting worse and more widespread in the United States as nature washes mankind's air pollution out of the atmosphere, the National Commission on Air Quality was told yesterday.

title: A Style All Her Own
description: Biographies of prima donnas are, as a rule, aoteriously toohen. Most biographers are it the nature of things, diva worshipers, ann spite of its long history, diva worship is among the most brainsoftening of human activities. So, what we generally get are breathless recitaaens of the lady's oper?? and social triumphs, and at best a few blurov attempts to describe the voice and the personality behind it. For spice there are ?? about rivats vendehas and perhaps some allu sions to sexual esacapades. Sad to say, few prima donnas are interesting enough to deserve much better.

title: Military Wages War on Racism's Persistent Shadow
description: WASHINGTON  In a report issued more than 40 years ago, the United States Army War College, a school attended by highranking staff officers, observed that: As an individual, the Negro is docile, tractable, lighthearted, carefree and goodnatured. If unjustly treated, he is likely to become surly and stubborn, though this is a temporary phase. He is careless, shiftless, irresponsible and secretive. He is unmoral, untruthful and his sense of right doing is relatively inferior....

title: Quantity Was Not the Point
description: ON Dec. 17, 1942, Anthony Eden, the Secretary for Foreign Affairs, speaking in the name of the Allied governments, told the House of Commons that the Germans were now carrying into effect Hitler's oftrepeated intention to exterminate the Jewish people in Europe by transporting Jews from all the occupied countries ... to Eastern Europe, where they were either worked to death in labor camps or deliberately slaughtered in mass executions. In short, he publicly revealed and denounced the holocaust.

title: Explosion Kills Plant Worker
description: COVE POINT, Md., Oct. 6 (AP)  A 31yearold Lexington Park man was killed today in an electrical explosion at the Columbia Natural Gas Company plant here. The victim, Charles Bromley, was an operations controller at the plant, a company spokesman said.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: The Three Mile Island nuclear accident was nearing a climax. Suddenly an urgent call went out for millions of doses of potassium iodide.

title: D and D Plus SciFi
description: EMERSON

title: Herbs as a Way of Life And Publishing
description: HERBS are very popular at the moment, said Gertrude Foster as she guided a visitor through her exquisite herb garden. It's very fashionable to give them as gifts, yet there's only a small circle of people who really care about them, who take the time to read about them and learn their history, who don't merely exploit them.

title: Navy Holds Off Air Force, 139
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 6  George Welsh, the 46-year-old head football coach at the Naval Academy, said, I have trouble sleeping these days, and on the night before a game I don't sleep at all. Maybe it's because I'm getting old and this coaching is more and more a young man's job.

title: Bridges Run Gives Hempstead Upset
description: A 93yard kickoff return in the third period by John Bridges gave Hempstead High School a 1410 upset over Carey yesterday in a Nassau Conference III game at Hempstead.

title: Cuban Refugee Tower Named as Historic Site
description: MIAMI, Oct. 8 (AP)  The Freedom Tower, the first United States stop for Cuban refugees in the 1960's, has been selected as a historic site by the National Register of Historic Places.

title: HEALTHY SKIN: A CLEAR ADVANTAGE
description: Nothing says fitness and health like clean, clear skin. What does it take to achieve this clear advantage? There are two separate processes, and it is important to distinguish between them. One is getting rid of makeup, oll and grime on the surface of the skin  and this a woman does herself. The other is getting rid of blackheads and pimples  and this should be left to an expert.

title: 180Acre Capitol Grounds Get Attention All Year
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI)  Forty tons of fertilizer are spread on Capitol Hill every year by the 77member grounds crew responsible for the 180 acres on which are the Capitol, the Supreme Court and the Library of Congress.

title: No Title
description: Shelley Ames Wed To Robert S. Hartz

title: Wilson Sets N.C.A.A. Record
description: PROVO, Utah, Oct. 6 (UPI)  Marc Wilson, Brigham Young quarterback, accounted for more than 300 yards for the eighth time in his career set a National Collegiate total offense record last night and power Brigham Young to a 3815 victory over Hawaii in Western Athletic Conference play.

title: Champion of the Woman Miner
description: OAK RIDGE, Tenn.  Tradition dies hard in the hills of Appalachia. A woman in a coal mine, so the superstition goes, brings bad luck. No women mined coal. No women went underground. But all that began to change two years ago after a coal operator in Tennessee wouldn't let a woman member of a local publicinterest roue loin a tour of the mine.

title: ART
description: THE remarkable 50year career of the artisteducator Victor D'Amico is the subject of a delightful and stimulating exhibition at Guild Hall through Oct. 21. The show is a tribute to Mr. D'Amico's imagination, energy and deeply humanistic attitude toward creativity.

title: PBS at 80 Conventions
description: The MacNeil/Lehrer Report, the Public Broadcasting Service's most highly rated program, will offer gaveltogavel coverage of the 1980 Democratic and Republican National Conventions  if it can raise $4 million to cover costs of the broadcasts.

title: Lost Souls, Lost Cause
description: ROM the beginning of his poetic career, Philip Levine has focused on two themes with ritual consistency: the tribulations of the powerless and the Spanish Civil War. A child of the working class who grew up in Detroit during the Depression, Mr. Levine has

title: At a Milford Shop, Christmas Is Here
description: MILFORD LONG New Haven Avenue, from Gulf Street to Milford Center, the houses look much alike. White shingles, painted shutters, some gingerbread, open porches. But one front is bedecked with three glossy yellow rockers, cushioned with ruffled yellow gingham, a round table with matching skirt, a white nail keg filled with marigolds and a school slate chalked: Welcome!

title: Charlie Smith, ExSlave, Is Dead; Believed Oldest American at 137
description: Charlie Smith, perhaps the oldest person in the United States  an assertion disputed by the editor of the Guiness Book of World Records  died Friday at the Bartow Convalescent Center, a nursing home in Bartow, Fla. He was said to be 137 years old.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The $2 bill may be viewed as a failure in some circles, but to Andrew J. Vero of Annapolis, Md., it's a source of enjoyment and inspiration. It is also the cornerstone of a new hobby specialty of which Mr. Vero is, indisputably, the chief architect: the collecting of postmarked currency.

title: Syracuse Triumphs; Csonka Record Falls
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 6 (UPI) Joe Morris rushed for three touchdowns and a school record 251 yards today to give Syracuse a 4527 victory over Kansas.

title: PRISON'S HEAD LOSES JOB OVER AN ESCAPE
description: ALBANY, Oct. 6  Robert McClay, who has been with the state's Department of Correctional Services for 28 years, has been removed as superintendent of the Downstate Correctional Facility in Fishkill, Dutchess County, and assigned to another facility.

title: Gas Prices Continuing Their Climb
description: THE price of gasoline at service stations on the Island continues to go up, even though supplies have increased, seasonal demand has eased and the Federal Government has frozen retail profit margins. There is no indication that the situation will change this month.

title: War of Clichs at a Flaming Cross
description: SOMETIMES I go to the library before dinner. From there enjoy walking home. I get a little exercise that way, and kill just enough time to have an excuse not to cook  one more TVdinnerandbeer night doesn't bother me. Eat. Forget.

title: Letter TO THE EDITOR
description: We're told the new, subdued Norman Mailer (Life With Mailer by James Atlas, Sept. 9) has lowered his literary expectations. But he just might be entering his greatest period.

title: Bar Association Urges Combining of 7 Courts In New York Into One
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 6 (AP)  The New York State Bar Association has called for the merger of seven existing state court systems into one and urged that judges be selected on the basis of merit.

title: CommonLaw Marriage an Issue In Unsolved Slaying of Prostitute
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 6 (AP)  Beulah Isabel Nettles, a woman of rare and enduring beauty, was still working as a prostitute at the age of 65, when, lawyers say, a bullet ended her life.

title: Deadline for Poetry Prizes For Translations Is Oct. 30
description: The deadlines for the Witter Bynner Poetry Translation prize of $1,000 and the Witter Bynner Poetry Translation grant, also of $1,000, have been extended to Oct. 30 by the Poetry Society of America, sponsor of the awards. The translation prize is for a volume translated into English and published in 197778. It is open to a single translator or a team of two. The single translator or one member of the team has to be an American citizen.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: A Journey Through Autumn is the theme of the unusually large Flowers and Gardens 79 show in New Rochelle Friday through Sunday.

title: INDOCHINESE FINDING JOBS IN ELECTRONICS
description: SAN JOSE, Calif. (AP)  My dream is I will become a lawyer in America, said Hiep Do. But in the shorter run, I need a job.

title: Public School Stars Play Waiting Game
description: Athletic talent goes unnoticed without competition, and with the present work stoppage by coaches in the Public Schools Athletic League, there is little competition. The athletic futures of many of the city's students are being jeopardized while the Board of Education and the Coaches Association haggle over an agreement on money. In addition, scholarship possibilities and student morale are slipping away.

title: Peking Schools Foster Campaign for Courtesy
description: PEKING, Oct. 6 (UPI)  Fighting, swearing and spitting are on the decline in Peking primary schools as a result of a courtesy campaign, The New China News Agency said today.

title: Pleasures of a Garden Pond
description: FOR the homeowner who seems to have everything, there are still new horizons, and one of the things that can be put on them is a garden pond. Hundreds of Westchester families  even those who don't have everything  have built them over the past few years.

title: Letters
description: In common fairness, some one should make the case for Jimmy Carter. His low standing in the polls which the polls themselves have no doubt partly caused  represents the most unjust judgment ever passed on a President of the United States.

title: No Title
description: Sophia Chandras Sets June Nuptials

title: DINING OUT
description: NEW CANAAN

title: SAUDIS BOLSIERING LINKS WITH EUROPE
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Oct. 4  Saudi officials are pursuing a closer relationship with West European countries with the aim of nudging the Common Market closer to open support of the Palestinian cause, senior Saudi officials and Western diolomats here say.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE GULAG ARCHIPELAGO THREE, by Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn. (Harper/Perennial, $2.95.) In this final volume of his trilogy about the Soviet laborconcentration camp system between 1918 and 1956, the Nobel Prizewinner describes cases of individual bravery and uprisings that occurred after Stalin's death. Particularly moving is the account of a 1959 revolt at Kengir. Our reviewer, Hilton Kramer, called it a masterwork that will live as long as there is still a free society. This volume, together with the preceding two, is also available in a boxed set for $7.50.

title: GROUP IN SALVADOR TAKES RIGHTS CASES
description: SAN SALVADOR  Every afternoon, groups of peasants and workers bring their problems to a tiny office in a Jesuitrun high school here. They tell of relatives who have disappeared, unfair dismissals from factory jobs, low wages in the country and evictions from slum dwellines.

title: Pirates, Basking in Sweep of Reds, Await Bigger Test
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6When Bert Blyleven fired strike three past Cesar Geronimo fOr the final out and the pennant, Dave Parker said his first thought in right field was: Hey, I'm in the World Series. His second thought was: Hey, how am I going to get into the clubhouse?

title: A Man Who Treated Thousands Is Arrested As Unlicensed Doctor
description: A 34yearold Manhattan man who has worked as an intern, resident and staff physician at four metropolitanarea hospitals in the last three yearswhile allegedly failing medicalqualifying tests nine timeswas arrested at Boulevard Hospital in Queens yesterday and charged with practicing medicine without a license.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 6 (UPI)Supporters of deposed President Anastasio Somoza Debayle shot and killed a nephew of the former leader who joined the ranks of the Sandinist guerrillas, according to Nicaraguan authorities.

title: LOS ANGELES POLICE CRITICIZED IN KILLING
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6  At 4:15 P.M. on Jan. 3, two police officers were sent to a home in the predominantly black district of Watts to deal with a business dispute. At the house on Orchard Street, the officers found the owner, Eulia Love arguing with two men from the gas company over a $66 unpaid bill; a money order for a partial payment was later found in her purse. The 39yearold widow was brandishing an 11inch butcher knife and some moments later threw it 68 feet; it landed harmlessly.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: In 1976, the Italian architect, Aldo Rossi, created one of the most compelling images in architecture today with his competitionwinning design for the Modena Cemetery. A rigidly rectangular space was surrounded by an endless, walllike structure in which the architectural components were reduced to an elemental simplicity; repeated voids of blank, empty windows suggested a place tram which all life had fled forever. Once seen, the project is unforgettable. Its spare, surreal geometry invokes a haunting and timeless symbolism of death and the eternal with an extraordinary intensity, far beyond architecture's more usual effects. In avantgarde circles, the Modena Cemetery achieved instant status as an almost legendary work of art.

title: Discovering Dental Truths
description: SITTING in his windowless office at the State University here, Dr. Israel Kleinberg picked up a memo pad and a new, freshly sharpened pencil, quickly sketched a graph and labeled the horizontal axis time and the vertical axis pH. With the narrow pencil lead, he drew a line that ran parallel to the horizontal axis and dipped periodically into a small v.

title: Experts Assay Maximum Peril of Nuclear Accident
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  Two nuclear experts at Princeton University have concluded that, if the worst possible accident had occurred at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant near Harrisburg last

title: CORRECTION
description: County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, for an article published last Sunday (When One Becomes Old, Poor and Cold), was quoted as describing the middle classes in today's economy as the nearly poor. Because of a transmission error, the phrase was printed as merely poor.

title: Chiropractors Campaign to Win Approval by Health Care System
description: Believers call it a natural, drugless healing art. Detractors brand it quackery. For nearly 85 years, chiropractic, with its controversial theory linking disease to spinal blockages of nerve energy, has pitted fervent practitioners and a growing public following against a scornful medical establishment and other critics.

title: Rugby: Relish For Rugged Sport
description: With the chill returning to the air, the ruggers of Westchester  college teams and area club teams  are back again with fists and boots, grunts and groans, in the English sport of rugby. Article, page 14.

title: Brezhnev Says Soviet Will Cut Forces in East Germany
description: EAST BERLIN, Oct. 6  Leonid I. Brezhnev said today that the Soviet Union will withdraw up to 20,000 troops and 1,000 tanks from East Germany during the next 12 months, but he warned that the deployment of new American nuclear missiles in Western Europe would change essentially the strategic situation on the continent.

title: Carter's Pastor Asked to Resign Over Allegations on His Conduct
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 6 (UPI)  President Carter's pastor has been asked to resign by the deacons of the First Baptist Church because of allegations of questionable conduct.

title: Music as a Hobby Strikes Up Harmony
description: MUSIC is a great leveler, said Mary Lou Kidder, a librarian who, with her husband and two daughters, is a member of the Northern Westchester Community Symphony Orchestra. The generation gap disappears.

title: Merklinger Sets Three Records
description: John Merklinger, a 58, 170pound allstate halfback, broke three records as Seton Hall extended New Jersey's longest unbeaten streak to 37 games by shutting out Eastside, 550, at South Orange. Merklinger accounted for 37 points with 5 touchdowns, 5 extra points

title: Army Trails at Half But Ties Duke, 1717
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 6With a sophomore quarterback operating the veer offense of Coach Lou Saban, Army drove 80 yards in 11 plays in the fourth quarter to gain a 1717 tie against Duke before 33,874 fans in sundrenched Michie Stadium today.

title: Coonskin Coats, Hip Flasks
description: NEW HAVEN TEENAGE girl, lured by the Yale Football exhibition at the venerable New Haven Colony Historical Society Building, stared at a coonskin coat inside one of the glassenclosed showcases.

title: Correction
description: Two editorial errors appeared in Joseph Lelyveld's review of China Scapegoat: The Diplomatic Ordeal of John Carter Vincent by Gary May (Sept. 2). The name of the city of Chungking is now spelled Chongqing, and John S. Service's collection of wartime diplomatic dispatches is entitled Lost Chance in China: The World War II Dispatches of John S. Service, edited by Ja seph W. Esherick.

title: The Region
description: When Kenneth A. Gibson was elected mayor of Newark in 1970, City Hall was a political cesspool in need of cleansing after the conviction of Mr. Gibson's predecessor, Hugh J. Addonizio, for conspiracy and extortion. Last week it appeared possible that Mr. Gibson, for all his success in stemming Newark's economic decline and promoting racial peace, may also have been tainted by scandal.

title: A Soviet I
description: OPENING any issue of Soviet Monthly, that punctual periodical which, whatever else the state of the mails may be, always arrives on my doorstep with a sort of ghastly fidelity, I am struck by the same revelation. In none of the welltailored, adequately written stories, which range conscientiously over all the peoples and activities of the U.S.S.R., is there such a thing as an I, a real I. The main figure is usually a he or a she, a sound representative type whether old or young; but even if the tale should be in the first person the I might just as well be a we.

title: Best Sellers
description: This Week

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.

title: BROOKLYN MUSICIAN FACES JAIL IN TEXAS
description: In 1968, a drummer named Clyde Brice fled Dallas after being convicted of possessing what he says were 21 marijuana cigarettes, or less than an ounce of the substance. He was sentenced in absentia to life in prison, and an arrest warrant was issued for him.

title: Funk: Earth, Wind, Fire Give Concert at Garden
description: Earth, Wind and Fire's Friday evening concert at Madison Square Garden was the best this writer has seen the group give, and that's saying a lot. For several years now, Maurice White and his band have been putting on some of the most musically solid, rhythmically diverse and extravagantly theatrical stage shows in popular music, and while their recordings haven't really lived up to what they do in person, as a live act they just keep getting better.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Harold Prince is known to be a courageously innovative director, virtually a musicalcomedy buccaneer. He dares to tread where his angels fear to follow. Lyricist Tim Rice and composer Andrew Lloyd Webber are dashing upstarts as well. Their Jesus Christ Superstar seemed startlingly impertinent at the time it was written, and Evita, which has at last come to Broadway after taking an unwary London by storm, has the effrontery to make songanddance principals out of Argentina's onetime dictator, Juan Peron, and  more importantly  his controversial wife Eva. It all sounds quite adventurous, doesn't it?

title: Deployment of the Pershing II Missile Causes Uneasiness in Some Countries
description: LONDON  In the capitals of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, there is a clear lack of confidence in the United States reliability as a military ally. For the next several months, in many of the capitals, the American commitment to protect Western Europe from the Soviet Union is likely to figure sometimes heated debate over a United States proposal for deploying mediumrange missiles in Europe, a plan endorsed a few days ago by a NATO advisory group.

title: Choral Works From fach to Britten
description: There are so many ways of performing Bach's great choral works that any conductor who undertakes the task must make dozens of practical decisions before thinking about his own subjective interpretation. Should he approximate Bach's own modest forces and use copies of authentic instrumerits? If not, how large should the performing complement be? What about tempos and expressive indications, scarcely any of which are notated in the score? These questions are only a few of the most obvious and they only begin to scratch the surface of the problem.

title: A Good Fourth Quarter Propels Westfield, 100
description: Undefeated Westfield, one of New Jersey's top teams, struck for all its points in the fourth period yesterday and shut out Elizabeth, 100, at Elizabeth.

title: THE MARKETS
description: Reports that the Federal Government may soon act to bolster the ailing dollar and try to curb gold speculation sent the stock market sharply higher last week.

title: Jerrybuilt Coalition in Essex In Turmoil Over Indictments
description: About 25 years ago, a Democratic candidate for Essex County office could come out of Newark with 20,000 vote plurality and gradually lose the contest as the returns from the 21 towns around it turned the election for his Republican opponent.

title: Strategic Arms Treaty Now Hangs in the Balance
description: WASHINGTON  For months, the Carter Administration has been touting foreign policy as the President's strong suit. But in a political season when he desperately needs to score points, Mr. Carter's handling of the Soviet brigade in Cuba has become something of a selfinflicted embarrassment.

title: Topics Missing Trains, Dancers, Rocks
description: The plainlanguage movement is having trouble taking hold in government and it appears to be a complete failure on such fringes of government as the quasipublic Conrail Corporation.

title: Widow Held in Arsenic Deaths
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 6 (UPI)  A Louisville woman has been indicted on murder charges in the arsenic poisoning deaths of two husbands in the last 12 years. Verne O'Bryan, 42 years old, was indicted yesterday by a Jefferson County grand jury on two counts of murder in the deaths of John O'Bryan last July 5 and of Harold Sadler in December 1967.

title: Birth Notice 1 -- No Title
description: Births

title: Robert Kopple, 68, Dies; Former Realty Executive
description: Robert Kopple, former executive vice president of the Midtown Realty Owners Association and an early campaigner for the 196465 New York World's Fair, died Friday at his home in Roslyn, L.I. He was 68 years old.

title: Editor of Underground Journal Speaks Out in Peking
description: PEKING, Oct. 6  Lu Lin looks much like other young Chinese factory workers. He dresses in a white undershirt and baggy dark trousers, with a wisp of a mustache shading his upper lip.

title: News Summary
description: Thousands of Soviet troops and tanks will be withdrawn from East Germany, Leonid I. Brezhnev announced in an address in East Berlin observing the 30th anniversary of the founding of East Germany as a Communist state. He said the Soviet Union would withdraw up to 20,000 troops and a 1,000 tanks over the next 12 months. The Soviet leader also offered to reduce the number of mediumrange missiles aimed at Western Europe if no new similar weapons are installed by the North Atlantic alliance. [Page 1, Columns 35.]

title: Pilot Is Killed as Copter Crashes 20 Feet From Expressway on L.I.
description: A helicopter pilot was killed yesterday when his craft plunged to the ground about 20 feet north of the Long Island Exoressway. a mile east of Glen Cove Road.

title: Where the Fed Has Gone Awry
description: IT is incredible that there has been virtually no general public discussion or debate in financial circles so far this year over the targets for monetary policy that the Federal Reserve has employed in its attempts to foster orderly economic growth. Something, after all, has gone wrong in the monetary mechanism. Our economy is being buffeted by high rates of inflation and is engulfed by deeprooted fears of future economic instability.

title: Other Ideas & Trends
description: Where is Catlettsburg, Ky.? It used to be at one end of an Amtrak rail route whose other end was Boston. But no more. Amtrak's Hilltopper made its last run between the two cities last week. Four other routes also were to have been erased, as the National Passenger Rail Corporation cut 5,000 miles from its 27,000mile network. But only the Hilltopper and the National Limited (New YorkKansas City) actually were terminated. The others  the Floridian (ChicagoMiami), the Lone Star (ChicagoHouston) and the North Coast Hiawatha (ChicagoSeattle)  were reprieved, at least temporarily, by a Federal appeals court pending hearings in a lawsuit to save them.

title: Brown Starting Drive in Northeast To Eliminate Carter as Candidate
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6  Undeterred by the looming figure of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, poor poll ratings and a tight money situation, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. sets out tomorrow for his first extended Presidential campaign sortie into New Hampshire and the Northeast.

title: Off the Beaten Path in Baja California
description: We zipped out of sleeping bags, shivered into jeans and jackets and made our way through the thick fog to a row of folding tables where Alan Ehrgott and Butch Carber, our professional guides and outfitters, were preparing breakfast. We were 25 Americans of various ages who had made a rendezvous the day before in Riverside, Calif., for a 10day trek to Puerto Escondido, 750 miles south of the border in Baja California.

title: Mistakes in Notice Prompt Delay In Georges Bank OilLeases Sale
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 6 (UPI) The United States Bureau of Land Management has postponed until Nov. 6 the sale of leases for oildrilling rights in the Georges Banks fishing area off the New England coast. The sale had been scheduled for Oct. 30.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: As Stanley Marcus sees it, quality is dead  or at least on its last legs. It still wobbles on in a few of his favorite things, such as Bic lighters, linen bedsheets from Claridge's, Sara Lee pound cakes, felttip pens, Kleenex, Hermes ties, Oxford suits, Galanos dresses, Chateau Petrus 53, Levi's jeans, service at Hong Kong's Peninsula Hotel, Scotch tape, Evian water, Peugeot pepper mills and Oranges Orientales the way they serve it at Le Grand Vfour in Paris.

title: Nadine Mary Isaacs Married to Dr. Juan Alberto Bailey
description: Nadine Mary Isaacs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alban B. Isaacs of New York and Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday morning to Dr. Juan Alberto Bailey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Juan Bailey of New York and La Romana, Dominican Republic. Msgr. Lawrence J. Cahill performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: Dance: Works for 2 Men
description: According to choreographic convention, dances for two people are usually dances for one man and one woman. But convention was amiably defied Friday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio when Gary Lund and Ric Rease presented Short Subjects, a program featuring duets for two men.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WITH cold weather fast approaching, and with fuel costs almost certain to keep rising, homeowners continue searching for ways to keep fuel bills from climbing excessively. One of the first things most people think of is adequate insulation in walls and ceilings  without realizing that as much heat  and sometimes even more  can be lost through cold air infiltration.

title: Louise Thorson Wed to Richard Gregory 3d
description: Louise Hagen Thorson, an assistant personnel officer, and Richard Harrington Gregory 3d, a tax lawyer, were married yesterday in Christ Episcopal Church in Georgetown, Washington. The Rev. Sanford Garner Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: CATHOLIC U. HOPING FOR A LIFT IN STATUS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  The attention being drawn to the Catholic University of America by Pope John Paul II's impending visit tomorrow is welcome at a school that has long sought to free itself from the shadows cast by some of the nation's better known Roman Catholic institutions.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Senate

title: Miss King Leads by Shot
description: WHEELING, W. Va., Oct. 6 (AP) Betsy King survived wind, rain, cold and a hilly golf course today to shoot a second straight par 72 and take a oneshot lead after two rounds of the $100,000 Wheeling Classic.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: WHAT with the advent of autumn, not only the leaves are turning but stomachs are, too. Now that everyone is out of swimsuits and shorts, and now that the outer person is once again cloaked against close scrutiny by others, the appetite is whetted. The Long Island social season is upon us and Long Island ducklings had better take cover. The topics on the table are restaurants and cooking and entertaining and, even more so, the consequences of good living.

title: Antinuclear Protest Bogs Down in Mud
description: SEABROOK, N.H., Oct. 6  About 2,000 antinuclear protesters slogged through a muddy salt marsh at dawn today in an attempt to occupy the site of two nuclear power plants under construction here.

title: Other Ways to Trim Costs
description: Overhead expenses are similarly coming under renewed scrutiny as profit margins erode. Some of the more imaginative costcutting approaches include:

title: Sporting Gear
description: Football Diagram Kit

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PATIO OPERA These Monday evenings at the Citicorp Center, the free entertainments will feature arias, duets and ensembles from popular and seldomheard operas, rendered by a vocalist group from Vincent La Selva's Grand Opera Company. The unit is known to thousands oI New YorKers IOr its fully staged operas performed each summer in Central Park.

title: NIGERIANS IMPATIENT TO JUDGE PRESIDENT
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 7  In the shadow of Dodun Barracks, where Nigeria's new civilian President, Shehu Shagari, has set up residence, four men were lunching the other day on fried chicken and cold beer in a small roadside food shack. It was very warm, the chicken was spicy and the conversation animated.

title: Can Morgan Stanley Cling to Sole Managing?
description: Morgan Stanley & Company is on the spot.

title: Ralph Carlos Estrada of Phoenix; Won Civil Rights Cases in 1940's
description: Ralph Carlos Estrada, a longtime Phoenix lawyer who in the late 1940's was the chief trial attorney in a series of civil rights cases involving MexicanAmericans in Arizona, California and Texas, died Wednesday of a heart attack in Phoenix. He was 76 years old.

title: CLARENCE CAMPBELL CONFERENCE
description: Islanders  There's only one goal left for the club that finished last season with the best record in the regular season: the Stanley Cup. The Islanders have the league's best center in Bryan Trottier, who won the league's scoring trophy and was named the N.H.L.'s most valuable player. They have Mike Bossy, the league's top goalscorer, and Clark Gillies, the league's No. 1 left wing. They own two of the top goaltenders in Glenn Resch and Bill Smith, as well as the league's top defenseman in Denis Potvin.

title: Jazz: Paul Motian's Trio
description: PAUL MOTIAN, whose drum ming has sparked jazz groups as diverse and important as the Bill Evans Trio and the Keith Jarrett Quartet, seems to know what he wants from his trio of drums, bass. and saxophone. The group's performance at the Public Theater on Saturday night was carefully plotted and featured fastidiously clean playing by Mr. Motian; J. F. JennyClark, the bassist, and Charles Brackeen, the saxophonist. But somehow the ensemble never seemed to catch fire, and one was much more impressed by the individual players than by anything they accomplished as a unit.

title: $390,000 Gift Expected to End Coaches Action Private Donors Offer Way to Restore School Sports
description: Pledges from private donors to give the school system the $390,000 it needs to pay its athletic coaches are expected to end the coaches fourweek job action sometime this week, a source close to the coaches association said last night.

title: Syracuse Is Playing Like Teams of Old
description: Finally, the Syracuse football team believes in itself.

title: Business Aided by African Trip
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania When George S.Y. Fan, a New York City architect and engineer, recently accepted an invitation from Andrew Young to accompany him on an official United States trade mission to seven black African countries, he expected to make some valuable contacts abroad and see places he had never been before.

title: Commuter Lines to Worsen Without Aid, a Panel Says
description: A citizens' study group says service on New York's commuter railroads is likely to worsen in the next two years unless there is an increase in fares or an increase in governmental aid to offset continued inflation and new labor costs that are anticipated on the lines.

title: Realism In Foreign Policy
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The bipartisan unity of the foreignpolicy establishment, which adhered for a generation on the understanding that Soviet intentions were not benign, is being restored.

title: October Gas Shortage Predicted By Man Who Foresaw Last Crisis
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7 (AP)  Another nationwide gasoline shortage is possible this month, according to the industry analyst who accurately predicted the days of line and hoses last spring.

title: Decision Limiting Airport Noise Threatening Small Coast Facility
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Oct. 7  Bill Hirsch gestured at his company's cavernous hangar at the Santa Monica Airport, crowded wing to wing with light aircraft, and said, angrily, If something doesn't happen, this airport is going to be completely shut down; this hangar will be empty.

title: Around the Nation
description: RED WING, Minn., Oct. 7 (AP)  Investigators today found a break in a steamgenerator tube the width of a quarter that caused a 27minute leak of radiation from the Prairie Island nuclear power plant, utility officials said.

title: Datsun Trying to Pass Toyota
description: Back in 1972 C. P. (Chuck) King, vice president and general manager of the Nissan Motor Company, U.S.A., found himself standing in front of a parking lot filled with 13,000 Datsun cars. They had just been shipped from the parent company in Japan and were intended to be sold in this country.

title: POPE ENDS U.S. VISIT WITH CAPITAL MASS AFFIRMING DOCTRINE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  After a final flourish of celebration and worship, Pope John Paul II headed home for Rome tonight, leaving American Catholics with his strongest admonition to stand up every time human life is threatened by abortion, weakened marital standards and the limiting of family size for material comfort.

title: Villeneuve Winner Of U.S. Grand Prix
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Oct. 7The Italians broke out a huge flag of Italy, the French Canadians brought out the flag of Quebec, and at long last a reluctant sun emerged from its hiding place in the clouds. It was all a well deserved salute to Gilles Villeneuve, the 27-yearold darling of Qubcois motorracing fans, for his victory today in the rainplagued United States Grand Prix.

title: Television
description: Morning

(516) 669.1800; CONNECTICUT (203) 349.7767.

title: Mexico Is Rushing to Cash In on Oil Boom Despite Hazards
description: CIUDAD DEL CARMEN, Mexico, Oct. 5  The squalls of approaching winter have begun hammering Mexico's Gulf Coast, hurling big waves through the fragilelooking oildrilling platforms proliferating offshore.

title: No Title
description: Melissa Elfenbein Bride Of George Bockelmann

title: Sharp Rise In Rates Expected
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 7  Interest rates will rise sharply as a result of the restrictive money measures announced Saturday night by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker, according to bankers at the annual convention of the American Bankers Association here.

title: Paterson Priest Cleared Of Assaulting an Officer
description: PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 7 (AP)  A Paterson priest has been cleared by a grand jury of charges that he assaulted a police officer during a demonstration outside his church in support of abortion on May 30.

title: 300 Handicapped People Receive Special Greeting From the Pope
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI)  As the song, He's Got the Whole World in His Hands, played, Pope John Paul II got out of his car and blessed a group of 300 handicapped people assembled outside Trinity College today.

title: Lou Graham Rallies to Take Texas Golf
description: SAN ANTONIO, Oct. 7(AP)  Lou Graham, the hottest golfer on the PGA Tour since July, made two birdies in his final four holes today and won the $250,000 Texas open by one stroke.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON

title: Alfred Dunhill to Sell Men's Wear in U.S.
description: Alfred Dunhill of London, which in its American retail stores has been selling fine tobacco products and gifts to the affluent for more than half a century, is going to try marketing men's clothing in the United States as well.

title: Miss Goolagong Indoor Victor
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 7 (AP)  Evonne Goolagong Cawley won the $100,000 United States women's indoor tennis championship with a 63, 64 triumph tonight over Dianne Fromholtz.

title: The City
description: Girl, 5, Fatally Shot; Mother Wounded

title: New Music: Susan Allen On the Harp
description: HARP music is popularly conceived in terms of arpeggios and glissandos, elegance and gentility. But Susan Allen's concert of recent music for solo harp on Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall offered nothing of the sort. The eight works on the program were predominantly spare and angular, and their frequent mood was eerie, never genteel.

title: Keeping Score on Big Oil
description: Remember the tankers parked off the New Jersey coast during the Arab oil embargo? Or the gasoline trucks hidden in the California desert last May while Los Angeles drivers lined up at the pumps?

title: 50 Students III From Fumes
description: JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., Oct. 7 (AP) About 50 high school students were treated at hospitals after inhaling exhaust fumes on buses, the authorities said. A spokesman for Memorial Hospital said that 37 students from Claiborne County High School in Tazewell were treated last night but that no one was admitted. Another 12 students were treated and released from North Side Hospital, a spokesman said. The students were on the way home from a band festival at East Tennessee State University.

title: Israelis Arrest 18 Arab Students
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 7 (Reuters)  Israeli troops today arrested 18 Arab high school students who were protesting a ban by the military Government on students from other villages attending their school. Military authorities said the youths threw rocks at Israeli military vehicles and set up a roadblock in the town of Bir Zeit in the occupied West Bank of Jordan.

title: Dollar Opens Higher Abroad
description: TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 8 (AP) The dollar opened higher on the Tokyo foreignexchange market today, at 225.50 yen, following Saturday's announcement by the Federal Reserve that it would adopt a package of restrictive monetary measure, including an increase in the discount rate by a full point to a record 12 percent.

title: J. P. Narayan, a Revolutionary Hero in India, Dies
description: NEW DELHI, Monday, Oct. 8 (Reuters)  Jaya Prakash Narayan, India's preindependence hero who led the opposition to Indira Gandhi's Government in the mid1970's, died today at his home in Patna in eastern India, the Press Trust of India reported. He was 76 years old and had long suffered from chronic kidney failure.

title: Colts Down Jets, 108
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 7  The Jets were given one opportunity after another today against the Baltimore Colts, a club that had lost its first five games, and each time the New Yorkers found a way to lose them.

title: S.B.A. Loans For Oil Dealers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)  The Small Business Administration has declared fueloil dealers and jobbers in all 50 states eligible for special lowinterest S.B.A. loans, saying they are caught in a crunch between high wholesale oil prices on the one hand and lack of credit on the other.

title: 2,500 Protesters Are Driven Back at Seabrook Facility
description: SEABROOK, N.H., Oct. 7More than 2,500 demonstrators attempting to occupy the two nuclear power plants under construction here were driven back today by clubswinging policemen and National Guardsmen as they tried to charge en masse through a hole in the fence surrounding the site.

title: Notes on People
description: Broadway feuds are hardly unusual, but a current one has the makings of a shooting war. The principals are Martin Charnin, the director, and Liv Ullmann, the actress, although Jos Quintero, the director, has chosen to enter the fray.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Stock exchanges and commodities exchanges in the United States will be open for business today, but most banks will be closed in observance of Columbus Day.

title: N.H.L. Preview: More Teams, Games, Problems
description: The longest season of any professional team sport gets under way the day after tomorrow when 21 National Hockey League clubs start their record 840game schedule, 80 contests to a team. By the first week of April 1980, only five clubs will have failed the ultimate test  making the playoffs  while the remaining to Wlu continue DaLLUng [L um for up to 73 more postseason games before determining the Stanley Cup champion, perhaps in June.

title: ESSAY Economy In Meltdown
description: WASHINGTON  The impossible is happening: the soaring rate of inflation (an 18.5 percent annual compound rate in the latest producer price index) is intersecting with the plunging rate of support for the President (19 percent in the latest APNBC poll).

title: Report Card on a Rookie QB
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Marketplace
description: FOR the last two months, the Dow Jones industrial average has defied such forces as recordhigh interest rates, soaring gold prices and painfully high inflation rates as well as recurring weakness of the dollar. Normally, such adverse developments would be expected to send the Dow running for cover.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American International Group Inc., has announced that Theodore F. Heller has joined the insurance holding company as vice president and controller of the following member companies; the American Home Assurance Company; the National Union Fire Insurance Company of Pittsburgh; the Commerce and Industry Insurance Company; Lexington Insurance Company; the Birmingham Fire Insurance Company of Pennsylvania; the Landmark Insurance Company, and the Insurance Company of the State of Pennsylvania.

title: COLLEGES MAY LOSE
description: Threequarters of the standardized college and graduate school admission tests covered by the socalled truth in testing law in New York State will probably not be given in the state after the law goes into effect Jan. 1, the State Education Department says.

title: Israeli Rebuts Report Carter Wanted Begin To See Jesse Jackson
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 7  A spokesman for Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that no request had been received from President Carter, either directly or indirectly, asking that Mr. Begin meet with the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, who completed a tour of the Middle East yesterday.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Oct. 7 (UPI)  Wayne Gretzky scored a goal and added four assists and Blair MacDonald knocked in three goals to spark the Edmonton Oilers to an 86 victory tonight over the New York Rangers in a National hockey League preseason game.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Concert: Nygaard Leads His Jupiterfans in Debut
description: RARE as it is for major new orchestras to have debut performances, it's even rarer for one to survive in the jungle of deficit financing that defines the realities of largescale performingarts institutions today. Yet, Jens Nygaard has taken the plunge, and although the debut of his Jupiter Symphony on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall leaves some questions as yet unanswered, one thing is sure: the concert was imaginatively programmed and executed with a really joyful stylishness.

title: Broncos Stop Chargers, 70
description: DENVER, Oct 7.  The fallibility of forecasting in the National Football League was underscored again today when the league's two highestscoring teams, the Buffalo Bills and the San Diego Chargers, both failed to score point. After the Bills had been unpredictably shutout, 70, in Buffalo by the Chicago Bears, the Chargers were blanked here by th Denver Broncos, also by 70.

title: Army Is Linked To Contaminant In Upstate Tests
description: WASH1NGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI)  The Army used contaminated homing pigeons and turkey feathers in biological warfare tests over oat crops in upstate New York and the Virgin Islands in 1950, according to declassified documents released today.

title: ABROAD AT HOME Troubling Our Own House
description: Two headlines, on the front page of the same paper, together carry a message about where the world is going. The first: Continuing Mexican Oil Spill Baffles Industry Experts. And the second: Army Chief Favors East Coast Oil Refinery ... Fought by Environmentalists.

title: Muhtar Kent Marries Defne Ltem in Istanbul
description: Defne Ltitem, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Ilhan Ltem of New York and Istanbul, was married yesterday to Muhtar Kent, son of Mr. and Mrs. Necdet Kent. The civil ceremony was performed at the home of the bridegroom's parents in Istanbul.

description: Deaths

title: TV: James marl Jones Portrays Paul Robeson on WNET
description: BEFORE it opened on Broadway in 1978, Paul Robeson was attacked in a statement of conscience manifesto signed by more than 50 prominent blacks, including Robeson's son. The production was then defended vigorously on WNBC's NewsCenter 4 by Carl Stokes, the former Mayor of Cleveland and himself a prominent black man. As whites sat nervously by, the controversy did not help the box office.

title: Bridge:
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 7  Very few of the 36 players who will be competing for the world team title here during the next two weeks realize that but for a trifling chance they would be in Caracas, Venezuela.

title: Koch Making Run Around Badillo For New Ties to City Puerto Ricans
description: With his relations with one of his departing Deputy Mayors, Herman Badillo, badly strained, Mayor Koch is establishing new links with the city's Puerto Rican residents. In effect, he is making an end run around Mr. Badillo,

title: Departing Remarks by John Paul
description: Mr. Vice President, dear Cardinal Baum, my dear friends in America, and my brothers and sisters in the faith of our Lord Jesus Christ:

title: British Cut Workweek By 1 Hour
description: LONDON, Oct. 7 In a major breakthrough that may affect bargaining elsewhere in Europe, British unions have won a national agreement to cut the length of the standard work week, now 90 hours.

title: Kathleen Sullivan Wed to John Leubsdorf
description: The Appleton Chapel of Harvard University was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Kathleen Ann Sullivan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Sullivan of Tucson, Ariz., to John David Leubsdorf, son of Bertha Leubsdorf of New York and the late Karl Leubsdorf. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Maurice Zigmund.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: 53 Nuns, After a Night of Prayer, Stand in Silent Protest to Pontiff
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 7  In the midst of 5,000 nuns, with much of the United States watching on television, Sister Maureen Fiedler braced herself to stand in silent protest only a few yards from Pope John Paul II.

title: Lutz, Smith Lose Cup Doubles
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 7 (AP) John Alexander and Phil Dent accomplished today what no other Davis Cup doubles team has managed. They beat the veteran American team of StanSmith and Bob Lutz, 97, 64, 64, and in the process kept alive Australia's hopes in the semifinals of this international tennis competition.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an obituary in The Times on Friday the name of Dr. Jordi FolchPI was spelled incorrectly.

title: Irving Maidman, 82, a Major Real Estate Developer
description: Irving Maidman, a major owner of properties around Times Square and the dean of West Side development, died yesterday in Nyack (N.Y.) Hospital of a heart attack. He was 82 years old and lived on North Broadway in Upper Nyack.

title: U.S. Money Plan Called Reaction To Speculation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  Worries over increasing speculation in financial and commodity markets was as much the reason for the new package of economic restraint measures imposed by the Federal Reserve Board as was excessive growth of money and credit, according to officials familiar with the board's deliberations.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: The Federal Government is embroiled in a counting crisis. Although it counts many things well, and often, there are arguments that many other things aren't being counted nearly well enough.

title: For 80 Million Eligible Japanese, Voting Process Is Kept Simple
description: TOKYO, Oct. 7  After voting as a good citizen of Japan should even if it is raining, Yuriko Kamo walked home in the storm and changed from her rainsoaked clothes to a comfortable lieht cotton kimono.

title: Lloyd Russell Day, 57, Specialist In Electronics Research for I.T.T.
description: Lloyd Russell Day, an electronics research specialist with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and before that with RCA, died Saturday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. Mr. Day, who lived in Chatham, N.J., was 57 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Some in Business Hail Antiinflation Measures
description: Wall Street and financial specialists yesterday applauded the Federal Reserve's antiinflation steps, but not without some reservations.

title: Tests Now Given in New York
description: The following tests are expected to continue to be offered in New York State after Jan. 1:

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: John K. Evans, the 72yearold selfmade petroleum millionaire, was basking in the realization late last week that he may have overcome the final big hurdle to his longdelayed $650 million oil refinery at Portsmouth, Va., with the tentative approval of construction by the Secretary of the Army.

title: Grenade Kills 3 in Bangkok
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 7 (Reuters)  A grenade explosion killed three people and injured about 20 others in the heart of Bangkok's most popular bar area last night. The police said the grenade was

title: So viet Troop Withdrawals: Part of an Effort to Maintain Military Superiority in Europe

title: Advertising
description: ESIDENT Carter has turned to the advertising industry  that great encourager of spending for some help in beating inflation.

title: Mua Indicates Radical Ganz of 4 May Face Trial Soon
description: PEKING, Oct. 7  Chairman Hua Guofeng indicated today that the country's disgraced radicals, known as the Gang of Four, might soon be put on trial for their alleged crimes during the Cultural Revolution and in the early 1970's.

title: Balloons Over Albuquerque
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 7 (AP) About 350 colorful hot air balloons filled the sky over Albuquerque early this morning during a mass ascension at the 1979 International Hot Air Balloon Fiesta. About 40,000 people came to the launch site.

title: Rescue Cambodians From Cambodians
description: The tragedy of Cambodia is almost complete. Many thousands of its people continue to starve to death. Yet the Vietnamesesponsored government of Heng Samrin says it may refuse massive aid from UNICEF if aid is also sent to starving civilians under tha rnntrnl of the rival forces of Pol Pot. To sustain this cynical posture, the regime even denies that there is famine  this in a country whose weakened and displaced population has cultivated barely 5 percent of the arable land.

title: Steelers Win, 5135, as Running Prevails Over Browns Passing
description: A capacity crowd of 81,260 at Cleveland's Municipal Stadium saw Brian Sipe of the Browns throw five touchdowns passes yesterday to tie the team record. The only trouble for the partisan crowd was that Sipe's gallant air achievements were not enough to overcome the Pittsburgh Steelers, who rushed for a club record of 361 yards while pounding out a 5135 victory. me tnumpn sett the Steelers alone atop the American Football Conference's Central Division, with five victories and one defeat. The Browns and the Houston Oilers are tied for second at 42.

title: JetsColts Summary
description: Scoring

title: Ill Winds Drove Columbus
description: Columbus Day poses a dilemma for me as an American and a historian. Despite both major and minor criticisms about how matters are run here, I am thankful that my greatgreatgrandparents, fleeing European pogroms and conscriptions for senseless wars, picked this haven and land of opportunity. Like other American dissidents I vote for the United States every day with my feet: I will never leave. On Columbus Day all who feel this way are supposed to rejoice, because Christopher Columbus beat the first path.

title: OHIRA'S PARTY LEADS WITH BARE MAJORITY IN JAPANESE VOTING
description: TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 8  The Liberal Democratic Party, which has governed here for 24 years, will control a bare majority of the seats in the 511member House of Representatives after yesterday's general elections, computer estimates indicated today.

title: Report Sees A Weaker Recession
description: In a report that tends to lend support to the need for the Federal Reserve's justannounced antiinflation package, the nation's industrial purchasing agents say there are no signs of a spreading business recession as was seen in 1974.

title: Opera: Two New Leads Sing in Met's Werther
description: LAST season's Werther at the Metropolitan Opera was graced by the mature, subtly nuanced artistry of Rgine Crespin as Charlotte and Alfredo Kraus as Werther, each giving unforgettable lessons in what French vocal style is all about. Massenet's opera returned to the repertory Saturday night, and this year the Met is offering a totally different approach. Tatiana Troyanos and Neil Shicoff assumed the roles, both for the first time with the company, and the presence of two such personable, freshvoiced singers automatically put a stamp of youthful ardor and impetuosity on the work.

title: An Israeli Spy Plane Is Shot Down by Syria
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 7 (AP) Syrian warplanes shot down an unmanned Israeli reconnaissance plane today as it flew through Syrian airspace north of Damascus, a military spokesman reported.

title: Polish Pride Is Abundant In Parade on Pulaski Day
description: Four days after Pope John Paul II captivated New York City, the Pulaski Day parade moved up Fifth Avenue yesterday beneath swirling red and white banners in a grand display of renewed ethnic pride.

title: Stage: Shelagh Delaney And Marital Tensions
description: THE House That Jack Built is made up of the small talk of marriage, in this case a marriage consecrated 10 years before in an industrial town in England, and surviving, not without strain, into the suburbs of today. The play is by Shelagh Delaney, who also wrote A Taste of Honey, and it is at the Cubiculo.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHY does Bloomsbury continue to fascinate us? Is it that Virginia Woolf, Lytton Strachey and her friends cultivated a habit of grace and civility now largely vanished from the world? That they managed to seem both ares

title: Letters
description: We agree with sentiments expressed by Gerard Smith (letter Sept. 27) that nuclear weapons should not be proliferated. Yet the position of the U.S. Government is not conducive to stopping the spread of such weapons. In his letter, Smith argues for an unenforceable reliance on technology denial, overestimates the technical sophistication of the Morland article and the Hansen letter and fails to recognize the proliferatory role of U.S. nuclear arms. Selfrestraint in testing and deployment of nuclear weapons would be far more effective against weapons propagation than anachronistic policies or lawsuits against the press.

title: No Title
description: Thomas H. Frankel Weds Evelyn Wolff

title: As We Said Back in 1971
description: CAN we ever have too much of a good thing? asked Don Quixote, or maybe it was Sancho Panza. Whatever minor gods supervised baseball evidently feared that we could, and they brought the manysplendored dramatics of the pennant playoffs to a grinding halt.

title: Divorce Lawyer's Slayer Eludes Police
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 7  Frank Melville, a lawyer, had clients  the men and women he represented In his heavy-volume divorce business and the indigent defendants he was assigned in City Court. He had tenants, as owner of an office building in Manhattan, and he had friends as well as acquaintances.

title: SCHMIDT VELCOMES PULLBACK BY SOVIET
description: WEST BERLIN, Oct. 7  Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said today that he welcomed the announcement by Leonid I. Brezhnev of a unilateral Soviet troop withdrawal from East Germany, but added that the Soviet leader's overall disarmament proposals required careful examination.

title: At a Catholic College, Sexes Differ in Views of Pope
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  One Georgetown University student said that Pope John Paul II has the courage to lead the church like it is supposed to be led. Another said that the strict tenets espoused by the Pontiff could make your life miserable.

title: Sports World Specials
description: From Mikes to Spikes

title: Castro Expected to Arrive in U.S. This Week for Speech at the U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)  President Fidel Castro of Cuba is expected to arrive in the United States this week to address the United Nations, a State Department spokesman said today. He will be speaking in his role as head of the movement of nations professing nonalignment.

title: A Lesson for the Board of Education
description: Yet another school bus strike has been settled, but it's been a bad year for school busing in New York City. A good impulse, to save money, has misfired and the only thing now is to learn the proper lesson.

title: Andrea Lull Diehl Bride Of Harry J. Katz, Editor
description: The marriage of Andrea Lull Diehl and Harry J. Katz, editors of The National News Bureau, a newspaper syndication company based in Philadelphia, took place yesterday in the Colton Chapel of Lafayette College in Easton, Pa. Philadelphia Municipal Court Judge Lynne Abraham performed the ceremony.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 7 (UPI)  At least nine people died and 26 were injured in clashes and bombings in western Iran, and demolition experts dug up 27 mines planted on the IranEurope railroad, press reports said today.

title: Both Reagan and Rivals Are Depending on Early Victories
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  For Ronald Reagan, the Republican contender who all the others say is leading the pack, the fundamental 1980 nomination plan is simply, as John P. Sears, the Reagan strategist, puts it, If we don't get licked early, we don't get licked.

title: 2 Union Leaders Urging Kennedy to Enter Race
description: AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 7 (AP)  The presidents of the United Rubber Workers and the International Chemical Workers Union are urging Senator Edward M. Kennedy to challenge President Carter for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Brzezinski Questions Motive of Brezhnev Initiative
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser, said today that the United States welcomed Soviet troop and tank withdrawals from East Europe but suggested the motive behind the announcement was to impede deployment of new American missiles in Western Eurove.

title: GOV, BROVN BEGINS 80 SWING IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 7  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California outlined the basis of his campaign for the Presidency today and assailed President Carter, calling his reaction to the Soviet presence in Cuba political hype and nothing more.

title: Supplementary OTC Listings
description: Week Ended Oct. 5, 1979

title: Europeans Mixed Over Fed Action
description: BONN, Oct. 7  European bankers greeted the new American antiinflation package today with a mixture of praise for its reaffirmation of the nation's tightmoney policy and doubt about its ability to bring any nearterm calm to overheated currency and gold markets.

title: No Title
description: Kathleen Bennett Wed to C.G. Bastis

title: Outrageous Wins Hudson Powerboat Race
description: Outrageous, a 30foot offshore powerboat driven by Larry Smith of New Haven, roared across the slategray chop yesterday to an impressive victory in the first annual Hudson River Powerboat Race.

title: Treasury Rates Expected to Rise
description: The Treasury will continue to dominate the credit markets this week as they respond to the Federal Reserve Board's decision Saturday to raise the discount rate to 12 percent and take other credittightening measures.

title: San Francisco Sniping Suspect Jailed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7 (AP)  A sniper who virtually shut down the city's Civic Center district for 23 hours was in jail today, captured after he and his hostage fell asleep.

title: Text of Fed's Announcement On Measures to Curb Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  Following is the text of the Federal Reserve Board statement released yesterday on actions to achieve better control of the economy:

title: Wage Rises Near Company Targets
description: Most major American companies are negotiating labor contracts they can live with, according to a Conference Board study of 778 cornnanies. The study notes that about half of the companies in the survey came in at or below their target level in their most recent negotiation of wages and benefits. Most of the others missed their target by less than 1 percent, the business study group said.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON (UPI)  While the number of state and local government employees is increasing, the number of police officers and firemen is declining, according to figures released by the New Jersey Taxpayers Association.

title: Painters Fancies That Wear Well
description: Offthewall and onto the back are the words that summarize the latest in fashion: painted clothes.

title: 8 People Killed in Fire After Jet Skids to Halt On Landing in Athens
description: ATHENS, Oct. 7 (AP)  Fire gutted Swissair DC8 jetliner tonight, killing at least eight of the 154 persons on board after the plane skidded to a halt on a rainswept runway at Athens international airport, according to authorities.

title: News Summary
description: The party that has governed Japan for 24 years again won a working majority of more than half the 511member House of Representatives, according to early election returns. As vote counting continued, the Liberal Democratic Party, which is conservative despite its name, was expected to capture about 256 seats and the support of 10 independents. [Page Al, Column 1.]

title: Chiropractic Drawing Increasing Scientific Interest
description: Send me your backs, Dr. Charles M. Godfrey of Wellesley Hospital in Toronto urged his colleagues. Over the following months, more than 100 Canadians suffering from back ailments were referred to the physician's rehabilitative medicine unit to participate in an experiment. The aim: to test a fundamental claim of chiropractors  that spinal manipulation is an effective treatment for back pain.

title: Dutch Publisher Acquires Data Concern
description: In a major acquisition, Elsevier, a Dutch publishing company specializing in books and journals, has reached an agreement to purchase Congressional Information Service of Washington, a private business that provides access and retrieval material for library and research use, much of it derived from governmental sources.book publisher in the Netherlands. Industry analysts said Elsevier outbid McGrawHill in acquiring the information service.

title: Fred T. Saporita, Leader Of Transit Union Group
description: Fred T. Saporita, the president of Division 11811061 of the Amalgamated Transit Union, died Saturday night at St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Smithtown, L.I. He was 62 years old and lived in East Northport, L.I..

title: Naomi Rosenblum Bride of David Remes
description: Naomi Lee Rosenblum, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Rosenblum of New York and New Preston, Conn., was married yesterday to David Harry Reines, executive director of the Ken. nedy Foundation's Council on Law and Ethics in Cambridge, Mass. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Remes of New York.

title: U.S.Israel Group to Salute Juilliard at Gala on Nov. 11
description: The AmericaIsrael Cultural Foundation will salute the Juilliard School in its 40th anniversary gala concert on Nov. 11 at Carnegie Hall. The school has provided training for many young Israeli musicians brought here by the foundation on scholarshins. Also to he honored will be Ethel S. Cohen, Leon L. Gildersgame and Paul Wyler, who have supported and worked for the foundation.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Officer Killed in Jersey Accident
description: SAYREVILLE, N.J., Oct. 7 (UPI) An offduty Spotswood, N.J., policeman was killed early today when his motorcycle collided with a pickup truck, slightly iniurine its occupants, authorities said. The dead man was identities as Jonn Watham, 33 years old, of South River, N.J., who had been on the Spotswood force for nine years.

title: Wide Corruption in Immigration Service Suspected
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7  Shortly before Christmas last year, a young Oriental woman, newly arrived in the United States, dutifully produced her green card at the request of an immigration officer in Reno.

title: Theater: OneonOne at Henry Street
description: LATE at night two men are trapped in a freight elevator. One is a black maintenance man, the other a white business executive. In common with the elevator, the play Suspenders by Umar Bin Hassan stands still  stalled between floors. Watching Suspenders, which opens the season at Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater, we are reminded of two prototypical plays about a pair of strangers in close conflict, LeRoi Jones's Dutchman and Edward Albee's The Zoo Story. In contrast, Mr. Hassan's effort lacks tension. The evening is short, but seems attenuated.

title: Israeli Cabinet Approves Temporary Plan for Monitoring Treaty in Sinai Without U.N.
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 7  Israel's Cabinet approved in principle today a temporary plan to monitor the peace treaty with Egypt using Israeli, Egyptian and American observers in the Sinai Peninsula to replace a United Nations force that is being dismantled because of objections by the Soviet Union.

title: Events
description: Theater

title: Moral Issues In Ecumenism
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  In a move that has major implications for interfaith relations, Pope John Paul II declared today before the leaders of American religious groups that ecumenical progress must be linked to a resolution of differences over moral and ethical matters.

title: Flanagan to Start for Orioles
description: Mike Flanagan, the Baltimore Orioles 23game winner, was named by Manager Earl Weaver yesterday as the starting pitcher for the first game of the World Series, to be played at Baltimore's Memorial Stadium tomorrow night.

title: One Man Leads U.S. Labor Party on Its Erratic Path
