description: While the philosophy of the U.S. Labor Party has shifted dramatically over the last decade  from its roots in the leftwing student movement of the late 1960's to the cultlike rightwing political organization that it is today  one man has al

title: Chess:
description: LONDON, Oct. 9  Lothar Schmid of West Germany won the British Broadcasting Corportion Tournament by defeating Walter Browne of the United States in a playoff game after they each triumphed in their qualifying sections with 2 scores. Schmid's prize was 2,500 and Browne's 2,000.

title: Berkeley City Council Cuts Police Jobs and Budget
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 7  Political radicals clashed with the police here recently, but the confrontation took place in the City Council chamber, not in the streets.

title: Hunger Is Spur to Fleeing Cambodians'
description: SISOPHON DISTRICT, Cambodia, Oct. 6  About 1,000 more hungry, tired and bedraggled men, women and children limped painfully into a large open area of fallow rice fields near the Thai border today and settled down where about 25,000 others are already camping.

title: Uniroyal Expects Loss
description: Uniroyal Inc. expects to report a loss of $10 million for the third quarter ended last Sept. 30 because of a decline in replacement tire sales, the slowdown in automobile output and strkes at its Mexican plants, the big rubber company announced yesterday. The anticipated loss would compare with one of $3 million in the third quarter of 1978.

title: A Disputed Ending to Apple Lap Bike Race
description: In the tight and sometimes byzantine little world of bicycle racing, there are certain courtesies and traditions that must be observed  but not to the exclusion of disputes or even jealousies.

title: De Gustibus
description: During my college days I was told once that French is the most concise language on earth. The French, my professor said, use a minimum of verbal space to express an idea.

title: Screen: Graphic Treatment of a Violent Crime:Rape Dissected
description: OF the two films about rape that have opened in the last two weeks, "Primal Fear" is the more serious, the more ambitious and the more outrageous. In this latest New York Film Festival entry, as well as in the tepid and talky "Rape of Love" (which opened commercially two weeks ago), a rape is depicted graphically early on. Then it is dissected, discussed, plumbed and otherwise analyzed in common-sense terms that, by nature of the crime's very unreasonableness, make no sense at all."Primal Fear" also does a lot more. It shows two women filmmakers as they watch footage of the rape, and wonder whether it will have an erotic effect on men in the audience. They raise this vital question but do not satisfactorily answer it, except to say: "Maybe domination is part of man's sexual power. We must get to know this. Learn to live with it. Make use of it in a positive way."It also interjects brutal newsreel footage of members of an African tribe as they ceremonially mutilate the sex organs of a prepubscent girl  footage that seems both irrelevant to the crime at hand and, because it is utterly removed from its context, wildly irresponsible.In the same vein, the Canadian director Anne Claire Poirier draws upon scenes of Nazi collaborators as their heads are being shaved, and a chorus of Vietnamese women in wartime, whose situation is identified with that of the Canadian heroine, a nurse. There is also a sequence, with the tenor of a school play, in which masked rape victims address a male judge, telling him of the nature and extent of their suffering. The men who raped these woman are all portrayed by one very unattractive actor, the better to suggest that all men are beastly and all men are the same.In conversation, especially in scenes that show the original rape victim (Julie Vincent) trying to describe her feelings, "Primal Fear" deals effectively, if overgenerally, with the shame and confusion associated with the rape victim's experience. Still, any stirrings of sensitivity are quashed by the regular appearances of the Director (Monique Miller) and the Editor (Micheline Lanctot), whose debates about how to present their material are both chilly and unproductive. Their conversations make it eminently clear that "Primal Fear" is more eager to seek the solace of platitudes than it is to answer even those questions that it bothers to raise.

title: Commodities
description: WHILE much of the frenzied activity in the commodity mar kets last week was said to be driven more by emotion than logic, professional analysts found that the wild price moves were based on solid fundamental and technical factors. They cited the performance of the grain and preciousmetals futures markets as examples.

title: Concert: American Symphony
description: THE American Symphony Orchestra inaugurated what promises to be its most successful season ever yesterday in Carnegie Hall  success as measured in numbers of tickets sold, at least. The program was conducted by the orchestra's music adviser (i.e., head conductor), Sergiu Comissiona, and drew a large and enthusiastic audience.

title: The Pope as Humanist
description: Among the explanations for the public's wish to be physically present at the Pope's stops around America, instead of watching him on television, there is one that doesn't seem to have been made. A great many people went not only because they wanted to see him, but also because they wanted him to see them.

title: Elizabeth Bishop, Won a Pulitzer For Poetry and Taught at Harvard
description: Elizabeth Bishop, a Pulitzer Prize-winning poet who wrote sparingly but was lavishly praised for the elegance and precision with which she evoked the natural world, died of a ruptured cerebral aneurism Saturday at her home in Boston. She was 68 years old.

title: Venezuela Finds Debt Up by 45%
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 7  The Venezuelan Government now estimates its external debt at a record $12.2 billion, or $4.5 billion higher than figures issued by the previous administration when it left office six months ago, officials said over the weekend.

title: Negotiations Resumed In Jersey School Strike
description: Negotiations resumed yesterday with teachers in the Morris Hills Regional School District in efforts to end a strike that has disrupted education for 3,500 students in the North Jersey system.

title: Mood at NOW Conference Is Businesslike as E.R.A. Is Pushed
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7  At the 12th annual convention of the National Organization for Women, many of the nearly 3,000 members who attended were struck by the corporate tone that prevailed, which was underlined by the similarity in dress of the delegates. All wore green and white on Saturaay, me unofficial colors of NOW, which were the colors of the suffragist movement 50 years.

title: Film: Fassbinder's 'Year of 13 Moons':Unalterable Condition
description: VERY early in Rainer Werner Fassbinder's "In a Year of 13 Moons," Christoph prepare to leaves his hysterically weeping mistress, Elvira. As Christoph gathers his things, Elvira follows him around their flat demanding love and caresses, and receiving, instead, filthy abuse. "You have no ideas, no will, no interest in anything," Christoph yells. "Your brain is getting smaller and smaller. Somebody should step on you. You're like a bug. Nobody would ever miss you."Christoph is not entirely wrong, but it's obvious they've had these scenes before, that Christoph has slammed out of the apartment before, that Elvira has wept buckets of tears, and that, eventually, Christoph has returned. This time he doesn't.Every seven years, Mr. Fassbinder tells us in a title card at the beginning of the film, we experience a year with 13 moons, a time, he says, that can lead to catastrophe.Such a year is 1978 for the unlucky Elvira, but then Elvira has known little except catastrophe since she was born, unwanted, as Erwin, raised by nuns, became a butcher, married, fathered a daughter and then decided  more or less on whim  to have a sex-change operation in Casablanca.Erwin had fallen in love with another man who had told him, jokingly, "Too bad you aren't a girl." Erwin, as impulsive as the later Elvira, paid the supreme sacrifice to correct the situation, but then never saw the fellow again, that is, until "In a Year of 13 Moons."The new movie, which will be shown at the New York Film Festival in Alice Tully Hall today at 9:30 P.M. and tomorrow at 6:15 P.M., is quintessential Fassbinder, a roller-coaster ride through the last unhappy days of Elvira Weishapt, whose quarterback physique can't be transformed by any number of hormones. Elvira fancies she looks like Marlene Dietrich  "Men are drawn to me, like moths around a flame"  though when she walks down a street, she more closely resembles a gigantic, very dowdy suburban matron on her way to a white sale."In a Year of 13 Moons" is not a film to recommend to anyone who isn't familiar with other work by this most bitterly funny, talented and prolific West German director of such films as "Katzelmacher," "The Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant," "Effi Briest," "Fox and His Friends" and, most recently, "Despair." Without adequate preparation, the uninitiated movie patron might think he was having a nightmare about a nightmare.The movie is grotesque, arbitrary, sentimental and cold as ice. Its only redeeming feature is genius. The 32-year-old film maker has now made more than 30 feature films, most of them in the last 10 years. He has made so many, so quickly, that it's difficult to separate them, as we easily do with the work of lesser talents. Each Fassbinder film is another explosion in what appears to be a single, continuing eruption of talent that shows no signs of subsiding.Though "In a Year of 13 Moons" is about humiliation, mutilation, degradation and despair that are beyond the experience of most of us, Mr. Fassbinder takes almost as dim a view as Christoph does of Elvira/Erwin. She/he, magnificently well played by Volker Spengler (who was the red-haired artist in "Despair"), is a monster. All the reasonable explanations in the world about how she/he got that way are finally beside the point of the present experience. What Mr. Fassbinder is dealing with is an unalterable condition, and the first step toward salvation is the recognition of that condition. That's about as close as I can come at the moment to making a generalization about the collected Fassbinder work."In a Year of 13 Moons" is not as easy a film to categorize as even "Despair." Scenes of unbearably graphic brutality are mixed with scenes of serene beauty and some of utter nonsense. Because Mr. Fassbinder works so rapidly, one can't always be sure that the nonsense is intentional or a mistake. One has to trust him, even while realizing that one of his methods of operation is to disorient us as thoroughly as possible.There's one very funny, deadly serious scene in which Elvira comes upon a man casually preparing to hang himself because, as he says, "I don't want things to go on simply because I perceive them." Elvira notes logically, while turning attention to herself, that even if he does kill himself, she'll be left to carry on the process of perceiving.The movie contains several monologues as extraordinary as anything in the work of Jean-Luc Godard, though they are the unmistakable work of Mr. Fassbinder. One that is especially memorable  by a man who has stood on the same street, on the same corner, looking up at the same 16th-floor window for over a year  goes beyond Godard to evoke Pirandello's "The Man With the Flower in His Mouth."Behind and around these curiosities we perceive Mr. Fassbinder's picture of contemporary West Germany, a land of plenty produced by the most devastating war in history, going merrily to hell with every modern comfort, gadget and appliance know to modern man.In addition to Mr. Spengler's eerily perfect performance, there are other notable contributions by Ingrid Caven, as the jolly hooker who takes care of Elvira/Erwin long after she/he has gone around the bend; Gottfried John, as the man whose casual remark to Erwin sent him to Casablanca; Elisabeth Trissenaar, as Erwin's pretty, unusually understanding wife; Eva Mattes as his daughter, and Lilo Pompeit, as the nun who knows the secret of Erwin's furious childhood."In a Year of 13 Moons" is one of the highlights of the festival.

title: Kissinger Assays Swings In Policies Under Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, in the third installment of his memoirs excerpted in Time magazine, writes that Richard M. Nixon's Presidency marked a period when most Americans deplored the exercise of power and believed this country's strength came from the purity of its motives.

title: Excerpts From Nun's Greeting and Pope's Remarks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)  Following are excerpts from Sister M. Theresa Kane's greeting to Pope John Paul II today at the sanctuary of the Immaculate Conception, and from the Pontiff's remarks to female religious at the shrine:

title: Runaway Locomotives Halted by a Marksman
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 7 (UPI)  Dale Green's marksmanship paid off yesterday when he used his shotgun to stop two runaway locomotives.

title: GiantsBuccaneers Summary
description: Scoring

title: This week, invite someone to dinner
description: 8 large eggs

title: Giants Attain First Victory, Beat Bucs, 1714
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 7  Billy Taylor made his first start today also. Though Phil Simms was the man the crowd of 72,841 greeted with cheers, Taylor was the man who carried the Giants to a 1719 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: Transcript of Pontiff's Homily at Mass
description: Dear brothers and sisters in Jesus Christ: In His dialogue with his listeners, Jesus was faced one day with an attempt by some Pharisees to get Him to endorse their current views regarding the nature of marriage.

title: China Restores Small Businesses to Provide Jobs
description: PEKING, Oct. 7  The entrance to the Balizhuang Hotel is an unobtrusive flight of concrete steps leading down into the ground. It may be the world's only hotel built in a subterranean bomb shelter.

title: Orioles March Ahead At Steady Pace
description: DON'T ask me for any secrets on how to beat the Orioles, because I don't know of any. If there was an easy way, then Baltimore wouldn't have had the best record in baseball this year. All I can say to the Pirates is, you better have two things going for you when you play the Orioles. First, your pitching has to be up. Second, you have to be able to cope with their pitching.

title: Theater: 1940's Radio Hour
description: AH, where does it hurt you? murmurs a crooner called Johnny as he listens to a superior trombonist interpolate a spectacular riff into the number he's been doing, which just happens to be I'll Never Smile Again. The song just happens to be I'll Never Smile Again because the new evening at the St. James, The 1940's Radio Hour, is, I'm sure to no one's surprise, a 1940's radio show, complete with the tunes and the intimate verbal doodles associated with the big bands, the big Bings, the big Frankies and the big everybody else of the period.

title: Three Plays by Mamet Open Circle Rep Oct. 18
description: Reunion, 3 Plays by David Mamet, directed by the playwright, will open the season at the Circle Repertory on Oct. 18. Previews will begin Wednesday.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1979

title: Wilmarth S. Lewis, 83, Horace Walpole Expert
description: Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis, who devoted most of his adult life to amassing the largest single collection of works by and about the 18thcentury writer Horace Walpole, died yesterday at the Hartford Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Farmington, Conn.

title: Slade's Valentine to Romantic Comedies
description: FOR a year Bernard Slade had been writing a play about a romance between two playwright collaborators. Then one Sunday afternoon nearly two years ago he opened a copy of The Los Angeles Times and saw an ad for a new musical by Neil Simon, about a romance between two collaborators.

title: Connecticut's Dempsey Hospital Still the Leader in Medical Rates
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 7 (AP)  The John Dempsey Hospital of the University of Connecticut continues to have the highest rates for adult medical and surgical patients even though room rates rose this month at all of the state's general hospitals except Dempsey, it was reported today. New budgets for the 35 hospitals took effect last Monday.

title: Renewal Project On the West Side Affirmed by City
description: Nearly a quarter of a century after the West Side Urban Renewal Area was conceived, the city has reaffirmed its controversial commitment to provide more than 2,500 dwelling units of lowincome housing in the 20block neighborhood.

title: East Germans Display Might In Big Parade
description: EAST BERLIN, Oct. 7  Augen geradeaus! came the command. Im gleichschritt, marsch! Heads snapped to the front, boots banged down on the pavement and the East German Army goosestepped forward today in Berlin's biggest military parade since the Hitler era.

title: Fans Lift Their Good Wine To the Incomparable Jane
description: Who is the owner of Pemberly? How old is Emma Woodhouse?

title: Federal Reserve's Move Signals a Shift in Policy
description: The actions to tighten bank liquidity that were taken by the Federal Reserve Board over the weekend signaled the recognition by the nation's central bank of the failure of its own past monetary policies and the necessity of adopting new methods of operations if the dollar is to be rescued and domestic inflation curbed.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Many years ago, before World War I, a major league player caught a baseball dropped from the top of the Washington Monument. Who was he and when did he accomplish this feat?

title: Pirates Attack With Abandon
description: IF you want to beat the Pirates, then you better make sure they don't leave the ball park on you.

title: New Fire Rules in Boston Hotels
description: BOSTON (AP)  All hotels in the city will have to install smoke detectors, alarms and other warning devices, the Boston Fire Commissioner, George Paul, has announced. He made the announcement Friday, shortly after about 1,500 guests fled the Park Plaza hotel when a fire on the fourth floor filled the 14story building with smoke. Several persons complained that they had not heard an alarm sound.

title: Smart Angle, $7.80, Takes Frizette
description: Smart Angle virtually sewed up the 2yearold filly honors for the year by outracing Royal Suite yesterday in the $110,400 Frizette Stakes at Belmont, but she had to survive a foul claim to do it.

title: Italy Raises Key Rate
description: The Bank of Italy and the Treasury Ministry announced that the nation's discount rate was increased to 12 percent from 10.5 percent, Agence Prance Presse reported.

title: Orioles Remember Clemente
description: Jim Palmer remembers Roberto Clemente. Brooks Robinson remembers Roberto Clemente. Earl Weaver remembers Roberto Clemente.

title: Outdoors: How to Perpetuate Your Myth
description: IF, plagued by the various ills that aging flesh is heir to, you wonder how to sustain your reputation as a rockhard, immensely clever hunter or fisherman, do not despair, for there are some only slightly dishonest ways of perpetuating the myth.

title: No Title
description: Deaths

title: Weekly Lotto Numbers Drawn
description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 12, 13, 33, 19, 17 and 21. The supplementary number was 3.

title: Three Troikas Wins Paris Race
description: PARIS, Oct. 7  Three Troikas, a 3yearold filly, easily won the prestigious Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe today by running away from the three horses who were supposed to settle the question of which was the best 3yearold thoroughbred in Europe.

title: New Head of Gimbels Unit
description: M. Ronald Ruskin has been named president and chief executive officer of the 19store New York division of Gimbel Brothers Inc., the Brown & Williamson Industries Retail Group announced yesterday. Mr. Ruskin, who is 98 years old, has been president and chief executive officer of the May Company, a group of Denver department stores, since 1979. The Gimbels group here, one of the metropolitan area's largest retailers, had been without either a chairman or a president since midJune.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: TO a degree, Freud, Biologist of the Mind has been packaged, and will probably be reviewed in most places, as revisionist biography. Frank J. Sulloway  a 32yearold postdoctoral fellow in psychology at the University of FREUD, BIOLOGIST OF THE MIND. Beyond the Psychoanalytic Legend. By Frank T. Sulloway. Illustrated. 612 pages. Basic. $20.

title: Poor Nations Outlook Bleak
description: GENEVA, Oct. 8 (UPI)  Developing countries face bleak economic prospects through the end of 1980 with huge increases both in their foreign aid debts and trading deficits, the United Nations Commission on Trade and Development said today.

title: OBSERVER Come Back., Dizzy
description: The American language, like the American dollar, seems to be losing vitality. The evidence is everywhere. The once brisk American spoken by OBSERVER Come Back, Dizzypoliticians has decayed into a tongue that can only be called mushmouth. The young cult of sociology, needing a young language, has invented one. There are many dead languages, but the sociologists is the only language that was dead at birth.

title: SovietEast German Communique Affirms Plans to Cut Moscow's Forces
description: WEST BERLIN, Oct. 8  The Soviet Union and East Germany issued a communique today reiterating a Soviet proposal to withdraw troops and tanks from East Germany and warning that the deployment of new Americanmade nuclear missiles in Western Europe would enhance the risk of nuclear war.

title: Radio Music
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Moldau, Smetana; Sinfonietta in C, Bach; Sonata in E minor, Quantz; Hejre Kati for Violin and Orchestra, Hubay; Six Dances and Variations, Schulze.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The invocation of the Monroe Doctrine and the public posturing on the issue of the Soviet troops in Cuba betrays nostalgic naivet at best, dangerous simplicity at worst.

title: Deaths
description: MOSSAW I RLinda, on October 8. Beloved wife of the late George, devoted mother of Albert, loving grandslother of John, dear sister of Bertha and Emile Abouchar. Reposing at the E.C. Waldeck Home for Funerals, 7614 4th Avenue, Brooklyn until Thursday 9:30AM. Services 10AM at St. Mary's Orthodox Church, 81st Street and Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn.

title: Kuwait Said to Lift Oil Cost 10%
description: Kuwait has raised the official price of its oil by 10 percent to $21.43 a barrel, according to oil company sources in the United States. They said they were notified of the surprise move yesterday and were told it would be retroactive to Oct. 1.

title: Divin4 for Sponges Near Greek Island Flourishes Despite Hazards
description: KALYMNOS, Greece  Sponge diving by Greeks dates from ancient times and can be traced to Homer's writings in the ninth century B.C., but today only a few scores of the socalled sfougarades remain and Kalymnos is their home.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Commodity futures prices gave way on a broad front yesterday as the markets reacted to the Federal Reserve Board's latest campaign to rescue the dollar and slow inflation.

title: Program to Promote Fiction in Spanish
description: In recognition of the active life of the Spanish language in New York and of the Spanish literary heritage throughout the Spanishspeaking world, the New York Public Library is beginning an experimental program to acquaint readers with some of the most acclaimed modern works of fiction in Spanish.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What is the orbit of Halley's  Comet?

title: Medieval Ship Found in Sweden That Dates From 13th Century
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 8 (Reuters)  Archeologists have unearthed a medieval ship, built on a Viking design, in the center of Stockholm in front of the old Riksdag or parliament building, the state Maritime Museum Director, Per Lundstrom, said today.

title: City Chemists Testing Contents of 75 Drums Found in Field on S.I.
description: About 75 drums of unidentified chemicals were found dumped in a forest clearing on Staten Island over the weekend, and municipal chemists are making tests to determine if the contents are dangerous.

title: Cuban Refugees Towed to Shore
description: ISLAMORADA, Fla., Oct. 8 (UPI)  A boat with 18 Cuban refugees, spotted yesterday by a pleasure boat 15 miles east of Largo Sound off the Florida Keys, was towed to shore today by the Coast Guard.

title: Pop: Van Morrison Blends 2 Traditions
description: VAN MORRISON'S singing is one of the glories of rock. At the very beginning of his career he was an Irishman imitating black Americans, but even on his earliest records with the group Them, he managed to transcena ootn innuences and his environment and create style that was distinctly his own.

title: Former South African Official Sentenced to 6 Years
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 8 (AP) Eschel M. Rhoodie, the former chief civil servant in South Africa's defunct Information Ministry who directed a secret multimilliondollar campaign to improve South Africa's image abroad, was sentenced today to six years in prison for fraud.

title: Dr. Joseph Park, 89, Retired N.Y. U. Dean Specialized in History
description: Dr. Joseph H. Park, dean emeritus of New York University's Graduate School of Arts and Science, died Saturday at Morristown Memorial Hospital in New Jersey. He was 89 years old.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 8 (AP) Hanoi accused the United States today of working with China against Vietnam and said that talk in Washington about normalizing AmericanVietnamese relations was just a farce.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Amid All the Pomp, Fallibility
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  After long days of the type of public acclaim that could give a divinity complex to an ordinary person, Pope John Paul II redeemed himself in the eyes of some in his entourage when he forgot where he was in Iowa.

title: Holiday Limits Trading
description: Several analysts said in New York yesterday that the full impact of the Reserve's moves might not be felt on Wall Street until today because many financial institutions were closed for yesterday's holiday. The holiday also limited foreignexchange and gold trading in New York.

title: Text of Remarks by Pope John Paul II on Arrival of Plane in Rome
description: ROME, Oct. 8 (AP) Following is an unofficial translation of Pope John Paul It's statement delivered in Italian upon his arrival today at Leonardo da Vinci Airport:

title: Paper Critical of U.S. Is Softened In an Apparent Rebuff to Castro
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 8 Representatives of the thirdworld bloc, meeting here at the weekend, watered down a Cuban draft of a document sharply critical of the United States.

title: TV: Nova Spins a Web
description: IF you're the sort of person who goes eeck 1  when you feel the delicate filaments of a spider's web across your nose, you might be wise to skip Life on a Silken Thread, which will be seen on WNETTV at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: Steel Output Down in Week
description: Steel production fell to 2.9 million tons last week, down 1.4 percent from the previous week's 2.44 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: World Series Is Fun Again
description: Sports of The TimesThe charm of the World Series, which begins tonight, is that the Baltimore Orioles and the Pittsburgh Pirates play baseball the way it is meant to be played  for fun, not finances.

title: Now It's Name Jeans For the Under10 Set
description: Sometimes it's hard to believe that only two years ago my oldest girl was happy just to buy a pair of new blue jeans  any blue jeans, Joan Martinelli said the other day as she watched her youngest daughter, Judi, age 6, wiggle happily into a pair of blue denim jeans boasting Gloria Vanderbilt's signature stitched on a back pocket.

title: Ickx, at 34, Is Retiring From Formula One Racing
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 8 (AP)  Jacky Ickx said over the weekend that he was retiring from Formula One auto racing.

title: War Plan, Secret 25 Years, Creates Dilemma for U.S.
description: For 25 years, the American strategic plan for fighting a global war has called for the United States to shift forces from Asia and the Pacific to Western Europe in the event of a Soviet attack there, accoraing to a Defense Department study recently obtained by The New York Times.

title: 3Week Strike Ends At L.I.U. in Brooklyn; Classes Resume Today
description: A threeandahalfweek strike by 223 professors and instructors at the Brooklyn Center of Long Island University was settled yesterday, and classes are scheduled to resume this morning for 7,000 students.

title: Lloyd Russell Day, 57, Specialist In Electronics Research for I.T.T.
description: Lloyd Russell Day, an electronics research specialist with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and before that with RCA, died Saturday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. Mr. Day, who lived in Chatham, N.J., was 57 years old.

title: Kozlovs Thank U. S. For Warmth and Liberty
description: Leonid and Valentina Kozlov, the former Bolshoi Ballet dancers who defected in Los Angeles on Sept. 16, thanked Americans for their warmth and understanding at a news conference yesterday.

title: Knicks Top Nets, 115107, In Final Preseason Contest
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Oct. 8 (AP)  Ray Williams scored 16 of his 20 points in the fourth quarter and directed a New York comeback as the Knicks defeated the New Jersey Nets, 115107, at Monmouth College in their final National Basketball Association preseason game tonight.

title: About New York
description: There is probably some gentle irony in the fact that memories of what was once a flourishing institution of the impoverished Jewish Lower East Side and Brooklyn are finding a home in the 1914 brick and limestone mansion, designed after the fashion of a French chateau of the days of Louis XIII, at Fifth Avenue and 86th Street.

title: Evidence of Fetal Defense Mechanism
description: EAST GRINSTEAD, ENGLAND EVEN to your own mother, you are an immunological alien. She would almost certainly reject a skin graft from you, because part of you comes from your father, whose tissue is incompatible with hers. So why didn't she reject you as foreign tissue months before you were born?

title: To Sylvia Plath's Mother, New Play Contains Words of Love
description: WELLESLEY, Mass.  Aurelia Plath thinks the literary world views her as an oere.

title: New Challenge for U.S. Catholics
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  During his stunning sevenday visit to the United States, Pope John Paul II attracted new interest in Christian faith and human rights but, as he left, it was uncertain in what ways his pastoral call would benefit the Roman Catholic Church in America.

title: Assets of a Hospital Patient Sold in an Error by County
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 8 (AP) County officials concede that their bungling left a retired mechanic with an empty house after his possessions were inadvertently sold at a yard sale while he lay in the hospital.

title: Jesse Jackson Urges U.S. To Confer With P.L.O.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, the black activist leader who returned this weekend from a twoweek tour of the Middle East, urged today that United States officials meet with representatives of the Palestine Liberation Organization in an effort to bring peace to the region.

title: Golden Gate Leap Pact, With Strings Attached
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 (AP)  Five Britons who call themselves the Bungee Jumpers leaped from the Golden Gate Bridge today, their falls broken by thick rubber bands that stopped them short of the water and snapped them back toward the bridge.

title: Jewel Sees Big Rise In Annual Profits
description: The Jewel Companies net income for the fiscal year ending Feb. 2, 1980, should be substantially ahead of the 1979 fiscal year's $41.1 million, or $3.59 a share, Donald Perkins, chairman, told securities analysts.

title: Daddy Goodness Musical Closes in Washington
description: Daddy Goodness, a musical that had been scheduled to open at the Winter Garden on Oct. 25, closed Sunday at the National Theater in Washington.

title: High Fashion Warms Up To Quilting
description: Quilted clothes have invaded the streets of the fashionable big city.

title: The Ballet: Les Trocks
description: THE Trocks  or allmale Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo, as they are called more formally  will probably always be hated by curmudgeonly purists who get queasy over confused sexual identities and object to their ballet classics being tinkered with. But a performance on Sunday at Camera Mart/ Stage One, under the auspices of the Dance Umbrella festival, proved that the Trocks have an enthusiastic following, all the same. And they are in top form these days.

title: F.B.I. Move to Discredit Former Agent Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI)  The Federal Bureau of Investigtion under J. Edgar Hoover tried to discredit William Turner, a former agent who had written about the bureau critically.

title: About Education
description: EVERY week, groups of three or four airline stewardesses set out on schedules, not to serve passengers on planes but to entertain and teach children in hospitals and other institutions across the United States. Once every month, similar teams check into Indian reservations to bring word from the world of travel to several thousand youngsters. And next year, an even more ambitious healthnutritioneducation venture will belaunched in Kenya as the first program in an international outreach of aid to handicapped or needy children.

title: The BlackInking Of America
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  I recently received in the mail, first class, special delivery, a copy of the Tenth Anniversary Report of the Harvard and Radcliffe Class of 1969. What the urgency in delivery was I do not know, for the information in the document was not news.

title: GUERRILLAS REJECT BRITISH COMPROMISE AT RHODESIA TALKS
description: LONDON, Oct. 8  The Zimbabwe Rhodesia conference moved toward a deadlock tonight with Britain and the guerrillas apparently in a basic conflict over orovisions of a new constitution.

title: NOW Puts Focus on Illinois In Rights Amendment Drive
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8  The National Organization for Women, the nation's largest feminist organization, appears to have chosen Illinois for its major effort to gain ratification of the equal rights amendment.

title: Tax on Corporate Loans Suggested
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 8  The president of the Chase Manhattan Bank suggested today that the United States consider imposing an 8 percent tax on borrowing by American corporations from the overseas offices of foreign banks.

title: Gail Hathaway, Engineering Aide
description: Gail A. Hathaway, a former special assistant to the Chief of Engineers, United States Army, died of a stroke yesterday at Mount Vernon Hospital in Alexandria, Va. He was 83 years old and lived at the Cosmos Club in Washington.

title: Dr. Harry A. Naumer, 85
description: Dr. Harry A. Naumer, former chief of pediatrics at Brooklyn Hospital, died Saturday after a long illness at the Rockland Nursing Home in Port Clyde, Me. He was 85 years old.

title: TurnofCentury Music Set for Brooklyn Academy
description: A celebration of popular turnofthecentury American music will be offered Oct. 22 by William Bolcom, pianist, and Joan Morris, mezzo, in the Helen Carey Playhouse of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Pope's Spirit Filled With Gratitude, Joy and Emotion
description: ROME, Oct. 8  Pope John Paul II, his eyes puffed and his face reddened with fatigue, stepped from the airliner Shepherd One in midmorning here today and Special to The New York Timestold a welcoming delegation that the indelible emotions of more than a week of liturgical celebrations and encouners had filled his spirit with gratitude, joy and emotion.

title: Market Place
description: TREASURY securities, ranging from shortterm bills to longterm bonds, fetched the highest rate of return in modern times last week. Prices were battered by such developments as sharply rising producer prices and the falling unemployment rate reported for September, an indication that economic activity is still brisk. This tends to keen interest rates in general high.

title: The City
description: Two persons, locked in an apartment in the South Bronx by antiburglar devices, died during a fire that was deliberately set in the building, fire officials said. One jumped to his death and the other died of burns and smoke inhalation, they said.

title: NBCTV Bars Revisions by Kissinger
description: NBC News is going ahead with plans to present its edited version of an interview with Henry A. Kissinger on Thursday, but the network will not give Mr. Kissinger an opportunity to amend his answers or deliver a monologue on his role in the bombing of Cambodia.

title: 20% Rise in Auditing Costs Feared With S.E.C. Plan
description: Rules on internal accounting controls proposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission could make audit costs rise as much as 20 percent a year, according to a study released by the Financial Executives Institute. It represents 11,000 financial officers of 5,600 American corporations.

title: Chinese Communist Party Chief To Visit Four European Nations
description: LONDON, Oct. 8 (Reuters)  The British Government today formally announced that the Chinese Communist Party Chairman, Hua Guofeng, will begin a sixday visit to Britain Oct. 28.

title: Taxes
description: ALTHOUGH the urge to get as much education as possible before starting to work full time may be admirable, it can have disastrous tax conseauences. as a young lawyer recently discovered.

title: Papal Leadership, Means and Ends
description: It was a splendid verdict that a Protestant minister expressed to Joe Hays, the farmer who invited John Paul II to Iowa: You got a Pope who knows how to pope. The Bishop of Rome demonstrated the truth of that judgment repeatedly during his spectacular American visit. Far from their sometimes dry, ascetic image of the papacy, Americans found John Paul II as virile and selfconfident as his voice. For anticipated events, he was carefully prepared. For the unexpected, he was equipped with a warm, deft wit. Consider one rare moment: The first Pope ever to be received in Washington informs his White House audience: The Pope wants to bless you  with the permission of the President of the United States.

title: Another Hospital on the Edge
description: The Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn is again teetering on the edge of financial collapse. The state says it can't afford to subsidize the hospital any longer. A hopedfor merger with the more prosperous State University hospitals has apparently fallen through. And the state is now seeking emergency Federal funds to keep the hospital going for six months while a longterm solution is sought. If no aid is provided, Brooklyn Jewish may have to shut down. It would be a tragic victim of the social and economic forces that are bankrupting city hospitals across the country.

title: Bowl Game Triumphs; Coastal Is Retired
description: He's going to steal the race! Jorge Velasquez screamed at Jean Cruguet as they rode into the first turn of the Man o War Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. He was referring to Native Courier, who at the time had a threelength lead.

title: Policeman Accused of Taking Bribe
description: A 31yearold police officer was arrested in Brooklyn last night and charged with taking a bribe after he allegedly sought and accepted $1,000 from an undercover investigator who was ostensibly seeking to avoid arrest for possession of cocaine.

title: Fed Acts as High Rates Prove Inadequate
description: The Federal Reserve Board's decision to directly limit credit availability by increasing bank reserve requirements and limiting the growth of the monetary base came after it found that record levels of interest rates did not appear to discourage borrowing or to slow the economy.

title: Bomb Explodes Near Holy Tomb On West Bank, Injuring 2 Youths
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 8 (AP)  A bomb exploded today in the Israelioccupied West Rank city of Hebron, injuring the two Arab youths who were attempting to plant the explosive near the tomb of the Patriarchs, an army spokesman said.

title: Bridge:
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 8  The tipsters here, who are about as reliable as at a race track, predict a threeteam race in the 1979 world championship, which starts here tomorrow. One favorite is the United States, which won the Bermuda Bowl title in 1976 and 1977.

title: Koch Promises Hispanic Officials He Will Name Aide to Help Them
description: Mayor Koch told a group of elected Hispanic officials yesterday that he would appoint a special mayoral assistant for Hispanic affairs and invited the group to sueeest candidates.

title: Letters
description: TO SCIENCE TIMES: In Freud's Work Is Thriving [August 14] Dr. Nathan S. Kline is quoted as saying, Insights are the raisins in the rice pudding of psychotherapy. A raisin is a real delight, but for types of illnesses that respond to medication, you need insight about as much as you do with penicillin.

title: Deaths
description: BENZIGER Zoraida Laing, at Greenwich, Conn. October 7,1979. Wife of the late John King Benzioer. Mother of Mrs.Donald T.Massey, Leslie S.L. and Christopher K. Benziger. Sister of Malcolm B. and John S.Laing. Mass of Christian Burial at St.Michael's Church, North St., Greenwich on Wednesday at 11AM. interment St.Mary Cemetery.

title: Brooklyn Heights Area Is Due to Get a Face Lift
description: Nearly 25 years after Robert Moses unveiled a plan to call it a slum and demolish the buildings on it, a block in Brooklyn Heights has been promised a $7 million future that is to include 100 apartments, trees, gardens, a playground and strong ties to the neighborhood's historyrich past.

title: Protesters Rally Peacefully Outside Seabrook Plant
description: SEABROOK, N.H., Oct. 8  Frustrated in their repeated attempts this weekend to occupy the two nuclear power plants under construction here, several hundred antinuclear protesters today staged a peaceful demonstration outside the plant's main gate.

title: Afghan Leader Eases Sentences Of ExAides Convicted of Treason
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Oct. 8 (Reuters)  President Hafizullah Amin of Afghanistan has commuted death sentences imposed on two former ministers for treason, according to a radio broadcast from Kabul, the Afghan capital.

title: Overhaul of Federal Pollution Control Program Urged
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 8  Affirming that the national objective of universally cleah water by 1985 was overly ambitious and is not achievable, a leader in the field of water pollution control said today that the eightyearold National Water Pollution Abatement Program needed technical, financial and administrative restructuring.

title: WILLIAM J. RIGNEY
description: William J. Rigney, a former assistant comptroller of Citibank in New York, died Saturday at the Princeton Medical Center in New Jersey after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ACADIA (Italian Line ContainershIP Agency, Inc.). Barcelona Oct. 25, Fos 26, Leghorn 27 and Genoa 29; sails from Global Marine Terminal, Jersey City, N.J.

title: Around the Nation
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 8 (AP)  A cornmuter airplane lost power in one of its two engines during takeoff from the Greater Cincinnati Airport today and plunged 200 feet onto a field, killing the pilot and all seven passengers.

title: Players Union Signs IndoorSoccer Pact
description: A landmark agreement in labor relations in professional team sports was announced yesterday by the yearold Major Indoor Soccer League and its invers union. It is a collectivebargaining contract with no reserve system, no first refusal privilege and no provision for compensating a team when a player leaves.

title: Tourism, Not Cuba, Worries Key West
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Oct 8  As the last rooster tail from the morning's power boat race melted into the blue surface of the Gulf of Mexico, a few dozen vacationers receded into the shoplined streets of Old Key West.

title: U.S. Reaches Davis Cup Final
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 8 (AP)Vitas Gerulaitis beat John Alexander, 57, 64, 86, 62, today to clinch victory for the United States over Australia and advance the defending champion to the 1979 Davis Cup tennis final anainst Italy.

title: Denver Police Protest Ends
description: DENVER, Oct. 8 (AP)  The city's police department reported 100 percent attendance today after a two and a half day sick call protest by dozens of officers angered by the amount of a proposed pay increase.

title: Deaths
description: CARLEVAROMarie V.(Nan) Aunt of Mrs. Marie Smonig. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81st St, Tues 2.5 & 79PM. Funeral mass St. Michaels Church, 424 W. 34 St, Wed 10AM

title: Notes on People
description: Like locusts over the cornfields, tourists are sweeping into the other St. Patrick's visited by Pope John Paul H the little chapel in Cumming, Iowa  in search of a souvenir shop. The Rev. John Richter, pastor of the smallest church in Iowa's smallest diocese, has been offering them free postcards and brochures. The parish plans some memorial of the visit, he said, but, as for having any mementos for sale, We don't and won't.

title: Union at Garden Is Found Biased On Job Referrals
description: Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers has discriminated against black and Hispanic cleaners at Madison Square Garden who have sought better jobs as laborers, a Federal judge ruled yesterday.

title: Soviet Is Wavering in Its Rejection of Freud's Ideas
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 8  The Soviet scientific establishment may be reconsidering its 50year rejection of the psychoanalytic concepts associated with Sigmund Freud, according to two Western delegates to an International Symposium on the Unconscious held in Tbilisi, Soviet Georgia.

title: HOUSES QUEENS SALES RENTALS(111)
description: HOUSES QUEENS SALES RENTALS(111)

title: Brooklyn Theater Series
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music's new resident theater company will open its first season Jan. 29 with Shakespeare's The Winter's Tale. The season, which will continue through June 1, will present five plays in rotating repertory.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation, a metals producer with extensive oil and gas interests, announced yesterday that according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Third Crescent Investment Company, a subsidiary of the Placid Oil Company, had acquired 9.7 percent, or 687,560, of Gulf Resources's outstanding common shares solely as an investment.

title: Ammonia Curb Protested
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8 (Reuters)  The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it would vigorously resist plans by the United States to set quotas until 1982 on ammonia imports from the Soviet Union.

title: Nun Hopes to Meet With Pontiff
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  She was applauded by many of her fellow nuns for standing up to Pope John Paul II yesterday, but Sister Mary Theresa Kane made it clear today that she had no intention of leaving the Roman Catholic Church over the touchy issue of priesthood for women.

title: Japan Election Results Hurt Business Confidence
description: TOKYO, Oct. 8  The failure of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, a conservative party that has ruled Japan since the mid1950's, to fulfill its campaign pledges to increase its majority in Parliament in elections yesterday has damaged business confidence here. although not disastrously.

title: Deaths
description: DOMNITCHGoidie. Membership of the Great Neck Synagogue extends its deepest feelings to past president, active member Harold Domflitch upon the loss of his dearly beloved mother. May the family be granted comfort. Dr. Ephraim R. Wolf, Rabbi Israel Slochowsky, President

title: GOING OUTGuide,
description: FRINGE GALLERY Dostoyev ski's Forgotten People is described as a solo performance suggesting some of the novelist's minor characters, tied together by a running chronicle of events in the author's life.

title: Steel Case Said to End
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)  The Justice Department has dropped a criminal investigation into alleged pricefixing in the steel industry and has resumed inquiries that could lead to a civil suit, a department official said today.

title: World Gold
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1979

title: CHARLES FRANK BENBOW
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C., Oct. 8 (AP)  Charles Frank Benbow, former senior vice president and secretary of R.J. Reynolds Industries, is dead of an apparent heart attack. He was 55 years old.

title: SIMON CERTNER
description: Simon Certner, who taught English in New York City high schools for 42 years, died Sunday at La Guardia Hospital in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 70 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: City Plans to Repair Jogging Path
description: A cinder road circling the Central Park reservoir will be reconditioned by the city with public funds supplemented by contributions from the joggers who pound around the 1.58mile course day and night, Mayor Koch and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: LaRussa to Pilot White Sox
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP)  The Chicago White Sox signed Tony LaRussa to a oneyear contract today to manage the club in 1980. Terms of the contract ware not discholed.

title: Sports Today
description: World Series, first game, Orioles vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Baltimore (TelevisionChannel 7, 8 P.M. RadioWCBS, 8 P.M.).

title: Telly Hill Meadowlands Victor
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct.  Telly Hill, owned by Francis S. Barna, scored a fivelength victory in the $53,800 Glassboro Handicap for New Jerseybred horses tonight at the Meadowlands.

title: Judge Backs Guilty Plea Bargain By Scientology Church Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI)  A Federal judge today upheld a disputed agreement under which nine leaders of the Church of Scientology would plead guilty to a single count in connection with an alleged conspiracy to steal Government documents.

title: News Summary
description: A deadlock on Zimbabwe Rhodesia seemed increasingly likely, with Britain and guerrilla leaders in an apparently basic conflict over the provisions of a new constitution. As the London conference entered its fifth week, neither group offered a way out of the impasse. [Page Al, Column 4.]

title: U.S. Debate Delays Aid to Poor Nations
description: DUBROVNIK, Yugoslavia, Oct. 8 Congressional constraints on foreign aid have forced donor nations to delay pledging new money to the affiliate of the World Bank that provides the most help to the poorest nations.

title: Newsday Price Is Raised to 25
description: MELVILLE, LJ., Oct. 8 (AP)  The newsstand price of the Long Island newspaper Newsday was raised today to 25 cents. Officials of the newspaper, a tauloid published in the afternoon, cited sharply rising newsprint and energy costs in announcing the increase. The new price of the daily is the same as that of the three New York dailies based in Manhattan: The Daily News, The New York Times and The New York Post. The price of the Sunday Newsday remains 50 cents.

title: Jersey Takeover Of Bus Concern Appears Stalled
description: TRENTON, Oct. 8  State negotiations to buy Transport of New Jersey appear to be stalled over the purchase price, the fate of the company's employees and an underfinanced pension system. Last summer's gas shortage has complicated the negotiations, because it prompted an increase in bus ridership that the company's owners believe has increased the value of the company.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: MITIGATING CIRCUMSTANCES: Wesley Walker (85) of Jets dropping pass from Richard Todd Sunday atter Dwight Harrison of Colts poked a finger in; Coach Hopes Errors Will Be Aid to Todd
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 8  Richard Todd will make mistakes next Monday night against the Minnesota Vikings at Shea Stadium. Coach Walt Michaels expects him to.

title: Battered Taylor Savors Victory
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 8  Billy Taylor's parents didn't believe it either.

title: Three Mile Island Plant Operator To Seek a Rate Rise of 10 to 12%
description: EASTON, Pa., Oct. 8 (AP)  The Metropolitan Edison Company, operator of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant, will ask the Public Utility Commission for a rate increase ranging from 10 to 12 percent effective Jan. 1, a company official said today.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: Corporate Earnings

title: Transport Allowances In SchoolBus Walkout
description: In response to a weekold strike by drivers of the Christmat and Glide Bus Companies, affecting the transportation of 500 handicapped children to and from schools in Queens, the Board of Education has announced that parents may arrange to be reimbursed for auto mileage or taxi service beginning today.

title: Miller Defends Fed Over Tighter Credit
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 8  Treasury Secretary G. William Miller said today that the restrictive monetary measures announced Saturday evening by the Federal Reserve System would not worsen the present economic downturn.

title: Fury of the N.A.S.L. Sign Firmani as Head Coach
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 (UPI)Eddie Firmani, the only coach in North American Soccer League history who has won three Soccer Bowls, has been named the new head coach of the league's Philadelphia Fury, me CIUD confirmed today.

title: The Gamble of Tighter Money
description: Smarting at rising prices and a sagging dollar, the Federal Reserve is changing both the form and content of its monetary policy. To exert greater control over the creation of credit, it is requiring banks to retain traditional reserves for previously excluded types of liabilities. At the same time, the Fed is signaling a determination to reduce still more sharply the amount of credit it makes available to the economy.

title: Miss Bellamy Plans Inquiry Into City Foster-Care Setup
description: Citing a death rate among the city's foster children that is nearly twice the national average, Carol Bellamy, the president of the City Council, announced yesterday that her office would investigate the city's fostercare system. She also noted that 18 foster children in the city's program had died since January, with at least five of the deaths attributed to abuse or neglect.

title: Tax Refund To Insurers Questioned
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)  The Federal Government could save at least $270 million in tax refunds to life insurance companies by trying to reopen a 1977 Supreme Court case in which Government lawyers made a crucial mistake, according to Justice Department memorandums disclosed today.

title: IndependentMinded Czechoslovak Plavwri4ht
description: The Czechoslovak Government's decision to strip Pavel Kohout of his citizenship and forbid his return fulfills a threat made to the playwright almost three years ago, and follows a series of clashes he has had with the regime.

title: A Fast-Spinning Young Earth Is Described
description: DURING the Late Precambrian Era, 1.5 billion years ago, the Earth is thought to have spun two or twoandahalf times faster than it does now. A day then might have been as short as nine hours, with 800 to 900 days in a year.

title: City's Most Precious Forest Is Dying
description: Avirgin hemlock forest that has been called New York City's most precious natural possession and has existed in the Bronx since the end of the Ice Age 20,000 years ago is threatened with slow extinction unless drastic measures are taken to save it, according to botanists at the New York Botanical Garden.

title: Westchester Drums Beat Over Vote on Con Edison
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 8  A threeyear campaign by Westchester County to take over Consolid'ted Edison's electric distribution network has been stepped up, with both sides turning to prime publicity in attempts to sway the electorate on Proposition 1.

title: Johnson Returns to Bucks
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 8 (AP)  Marques Johnson, the Milwaukee Bucks top scorer and rebounder last season, ended his threeweek holdout and joined the National Basketball Association team tonight for final preseason game, scoring 11 points in a 121109 loss to the Indiana Pacers.

title: Executive Tells of Paying Scotto $210,000
description: Walter D. O'Hearn Jr., the head of major waterfront company, testified yesterday that he had given $210,000 in cash payoffs to Anthony M. Scotto to reduce accident claims by longshoremen in Brooklyn.

title: The New York Times /Vic DeLucia
description: New York City's Columbus Day parade yesterday was less the customary annual celebration of the navigator's birthday than it was a curious happening dominated by unruly winds.

title: Kison Going Against Flanagan In PiratesOrioles Series Opener
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 8 Bruce Kison, who was with Pittsburgh in the 1971 World Series, will play a different role in the 1979 Series, which begins at Memorial Stadium here tomorrow night.

title: 7th Birthday of Missing SoHo Boy Is Marked Sadly
description: Today is Etan Patz's seventh birthday, but there will be no celebration in his family's loft apartment in SoHo.

title: Communist Leader in Iran Foresees Unrest, but Not a Military Coup
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 8 (Reuters) The leader of the Iranian Communist Party, who returned from exile in Eastern Europe after the revolution that overthrew Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, today predicted a winter of unrest in Iran but dismissed the possibility of civil war.

title: Come On, Give em A Lift
description: During the early 60's and 70's, I did a lot of traveling back and forth from college near San Franciso to family in L.A., with nothing but a backpack, a homemade sign, and a faith that I would make it home. It was one of the golden ages of American hitchhiking, realized this summer, when through little fault of my own I went back on the road for the first time in five years, thumbing through Hollywood Hills into Los Angeles  a great place for flagging a ride, you would imagine. Not so.

title: U.A. Pays $2.5 Million For Book by Gay Talese
description: For the record sum of $2.5 million, United Artists purchased film rights yesterday to Thy Neighbor's Wife, nonfiction book by the journalist Gay Talese about sex in America.

title: Executives to Quit Merrill Lynch Unit
description: Four executives of Merrill Lynch & Company's government securities subsidiary have tendered their resignations, a spokesman for the parent company confirmed yesterday.

title: 3 Amtrak Trains Lose Reprieves
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)  Justice Byron R. White of the Supreme Court today cleared the way for Amtrak to stop running three moneylosing passenger trains.

title: Moderate Quake in California
description: BRIDGEPORT, Calif., Oct. 8 (UPI) A moderate earthquake rumbled through a sparsely populated area of the Central Sierra yesterday but caused no damage or injuries. The University of California's seismographic station at Berkeley said that it measured 4.6 on the openended Richter scale.

title: Argentine Prices Surge
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 8 (AP)  The cost of living in Argentina rose 6.8 percent in September, the Economic Ministry reported today. The consumer price index now stands at 35,082.7.

title: Deaths
description: BANKSElisa Cross, in Providence, R.I. October 5, 1979. Wife of Talcott M. Banks, Chairman of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. A memorial service will be held in Providence on Tuesday, October 9. Contributions may be sent to R.I. Hospital, Providence R.I. or the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Boston, Mass.

title: The Moment Is Golden To Buy 14Karat Gifts
description: If you've been thinking about buying a gold watch  or gold necklace or bracelet or wedding ring  now's apparently the time to do it.

title: Research on Marijuana Finds Many Risks, Some Benefits
description: MORE potent types of marijuana and alarmingly greater use among young teenagers require new attitude of concern toward the substance, some experts believe.

title: Gasoline Shortage Seen Next Summer
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  Petroleum experts here are warning that an accumulation of announced or likely cuts in oil exports by the main producing nations will mean gasoline lines across the United States again next summer.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets, despite being partially inactive because of the Columbus Day holiday, moved decisively toward higher interest rates yesterday, while the Treasury postponed until Thursday its sale of 15year bonds that had been scheduled for today. The developments marked the initial reaction to the Federal Reserve Board's latest antiinflation measures that were announced Saturday evening.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The dollar rebounded sharply in value on world markets yesterday and the price of gold declined as European governments and central banks applauded the Federal Reserve Board's economic restraint measures. The dollar rose strongly against the German mark, French franc, Swiss franc and Japanese yen, while gold dropped to $374 an ounce in London from Friday's level of $387.50. European economic sources welcomed the package as a sign that the Fed and the Carter Administration had braced themselves for a sustained assault on the nation's inflation rate, which is seen as the basic cause of the dollar's weakness. [Page A1.]

title: EDUCATION
description: TEN years ago Neil Postman was a prominent figure in the movement to open up American elementary and secondary education. In Teaching as a Subversive Activity, coauthored with Charles Weingartner, he called for reforms such as more elective courses, individualized instruction and a more tolerant attitude toward nonstandard English.

title: Dow Falls 13.57 After Fed Action
description: Concern over the Federal Reserve Board's move late Saturday to fight inflation and bolster the dollar sent the stock market down sharply yesterday in much lighter trading.

title: EARNINGS
description: The International Paper Company reported an almost tenfold increase in thirdquarter profits yesterday to $225 million, or $4.69 a share, from $23.7 million, or 50 cents a share, a year ago. The diversified paper and resources company said most of the gain was attributable to the sale of some oil and gas properties.

title: Ohira Set Back In Japan Voting But Keeps Reins
description: TOKYO, Oct. 8  The governing Lib- 1 eral Democratic Party of Japan maintained its perilously thin hold on power in the national elections here yesterday, but the failure of the party to Increase its strength in Parliament was a setback for Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira.

title: Film: Failed Marriage In Postwar Poland:Politics and Bedfellows
description: BECAUSE there have been several rather drastic changes in the Polish political scene since World War II, it's absolutely essential to a complete understanding of a Polish film that we have some idea when it's supposed to be taking place. This is an omission that nags our attention throughout Andrzej Wajda's otherwise involving new film, "Without Anesthesia," which will be shown at the New York Film Festival in Lincoln Center today at 9:30 P.M. and tomorrow at 6:15 P.M.The movie was made last year. Its cars and clothes look completely contemporary though, according to the festival's program notes, the story is based on events in postwar Poland that have been updated to the 1960's. However, there's nothing in the film to indicate this isn't 1979. Since "Without Anesthesia" is as much about politics as people, the result is as disorienting as a room that has a built-in tilt.At the center of "Without Anesthesia" is Jerzy (Zbigniew Zapasiewicz) an urbane, witty, self-assured political pundit who has gained a good deal of fame at home by traveling abroad to report wars, revolutions and guerrilla movements in the Third World.When we first see him, he is the charming celebrity-guest on a dreadful Polish television program that mixes so-called serious discussion with audience-participation pratfalls. As he has apparently always done to survive, Jerzy accepts the ridiculous situation with grace.Later that evening, when he returns home, he is confronted with a disaster of a sort he's never before faced. His wife has walked out on him, taking their daughter with her, to live with a younger man.On its surface, "Without Anesthesia" seems to be about Jerzy's attempts to win back his wife, Ewa (Ewa Dalkowska) and to come to some understanding about what went wrong with their 15-year marriage. But what went wrong is inextricably bound up with politics. Jacek (Andrzej Seweryn), Ewa's lover, is a furious young radical who looks upon the members of Jerzy's generation as "coffeehouse liberals," people who have always known just how far they could go without feeling official heat. Because it's this quality that Ewa loves in Jacek, it's necessary that we know at what point in his career Jerzy began to make adjustments to survive.The events of "Without Anesthesia" may be taking place in the 60's, but they reflect the darker days of the early 1950's. As Jerzy's marriage goes down the drain, so does his job. The first inkling Jerzy has that he's no longer considered "safe" is when he doesn't receive the office's weekly copies of Newsweek and Stern.There are also hints of the pre-Khrushchev era when Ewa's lawyer tells Jerzy that Ewa will have no trouble getting her divorce even if it's contested. "It's been my experience," the lawyer says blandly, "that anything can be proved." In one of their failed attempts at reconciliation, Ewa, laughing, remembers how Jerzy was once very depressed by Polish weather after a long stay in Ethiopia. As she recalls it, Jerzy said testily, "I can't bear such an inconsistent climate."Jerzy's growing panic is beautifully illuminated in Mr. Zapasiewicz, who manages to find heroic stature in a character who has always compromised. Miss Dalkowska is lovely as the reticent, intelligent wife.Like Mr. Wajda's "Man of Marble," which was seen in New York briefly this year, "Without Anesthesia" may be more fuzzy in its politics than the director would have wished. Yet enough of substance remains to make it one of the more provocative movies of the year to date.

title: Advertising
description: What 7Up did for the soft drink with its Uncola campaign, RPM, a division of Cluett, Peabody & Company that makes slacks, is going to try to do in men's wear.

title: Syrian Leader to Visit Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 8 (UPI)  President Hafez alAssad of Syria will visit the Soviet Union later this month, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

title: News Parley Scheduled By President for Today
description: President Carter will hold a news conference in Washington at 3:30 P.M. today. It will be broadcast live by the three networks (ABC, CBS and NBC), and by their radio networks, the National Public Radio and the Mutual Broadcasting System.

title: Despite I.M.F. Aid, Jamaica Still Lags
description: KINGSTON, JamaicaA few weeks ago in Washington, a small group of international banks met with representatives of the Jamaican Government. On the agenda was a refinancing of the $450 million in commercial debt coming due in the early 1980's and a new loan package of $200 million.

title: Czech Writer Is Deprived of Citizenship
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 8 Pavel Kohout, a leading Czech writer, was stripped of his Czechoslovak citizenship today and barred from returning from a stay in Austria.

title: Resorts Win Down by 15%
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 8 (AP)  The Resorts International Hotel Casino here took in an average of $651,961 a day during September. The figure was 15 percent lower than in August and about 1 percent less than in September 1978. hotel officials said today.

title: Retzer, 96, a Wrestler In 1912 Olympic Games
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Oct. 8 (UPI)George Retzer, who competed as a wrestler for the United States Olympic team at the 1912 Games in Stockholm, died yesterday at the Huntington Drive Convalescent Home. Mr. Retzer was 96 years old and is believed to have been the oldest former American Olympian.

title: IN THE NATION 'A Special Obligation
description: Pope John Paul II's comments on behavioral questions and the condition of women have excited much comment. But the most impassioned theme of his visit to the United States was that in the light of the parable of Christ, riches and freedom create a special responsibility  a special obligation to those people and nations who have too little of either.

title: Viktor Korchnoi's Son in Soviet Is Reported to Be a Draft Evader
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 8 (UPI)  The 20yearold son of Viktor Korchnoi, the migr chess grandmaster, has gone into hiding to evade service in the Soviet Army, a friend of the family said today.

title: Basque Gunmen Step Up Efforts To Block the HomeRule Statute
description: MADRID, Oct. 8  Stepping up efforts to derail a Basque home rule statute that will be put to a referendum this month, gunmen in San Sebastian sprayed a bar frequented by policemen with gunfire, wounding 11 persons.

title: The World Bank Holdup
description: Every dollar paid into the World Bank by the United States has been matched by three dollars from other rich countries and $46 from private lenders  to generate $7 billion in loans to poor countries in the past year alone. This successful credit machine provides critical aid to the developing nations, whose oil bills have raised their annual payments deficits from $31 billion to $43 billion. It is threatened, however, by an irrelevant condition that the House has attached to American contributions and which only the Senate can now remove.

title: From the Subtropical Neem Tree, a Natural Insecticide
description: BELTSVILLE, MD. NATURALLY occurring extracts from the subtropical neem tree have recently been shown to have unusual potential as general purpose insecticides. The neem tree is one of a number of plants that have attracted the interest of scientists who are seeking substances that destroy insects without harming man.

title: James Woods: Angry Young Man as Killer
description: Los ANGELES SHAVING cream has congealed on James Woods's neck, but he is too angry to notice. I have learned a cardinal rule, he says. Don't do anybody a favor. Now understand why stars are as arrogant as they are. The big guns get deferred to. I've never missed a day's work in my life, never been a minute late to work in my life. John Savage was two hours late the first day on The Onion Field, so, for the next eight weeks, they had him picked up by a driver.

title: CITY OPERA SETTLES MUSICIANS DISPUTE
description: The New York City Opera and its orchestra's musicians reached a tentative settlement of their contract dispute early this morning, after a sevenhour bargaining session that ended at 12:15 A.M. Terms of the settlement were withheld pending ratification by the full orchestra. A meeting for that purpose was scheduled for Thursday afternoon.

title: Deaths
description: LEONARDJuliet Carleton, at Southampton, N.Y., on October 5, 1979, after a long Illness. Wife of Thomas D.Leonard. Long a resident of New York City and Dublin, New Hampshire. She is survived by her husband, a son, Andrew Varick Stout Jr., of Hanover, New Hampshire, and a daughter, Juliet Carrington Perkins, of Nantucket, Mass. and 8 grandchildren. She was born in Chestnut Hill, Mass, July 4,1906, the daughter of Richard High and Juliet Buck Carleton. She was active in the Red Cross during World War II and in the Garden Club of America. A private memorial service will be held in Dublin, New Hampshire.

title: Events Today
description: POTHOLES, musical by Elinor Guggenheimer, composed and arranged by Ted Simons, Cherry Lane Theater, 38 Commerce Street, 6:30.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Once again the Stanford University Graduate School of Business has turned for its dean to someone who has met a payroll. Yesterday Stanford named Rene C. McPherson, 55 years old, chairman of the Dana Corporation, as its dean. He succeeds Arjay Miller, who resigned from the deanship last June and who had come to Stanford from the Ford Motor Company.

title: Pet Lion Killed in Escape Upstate
description: FARMINGTON, N.Y., Oct. 8  A rural family's 225pound pet lioness broke its chokechain leash and ran off near this Ontario County community last night, touching off a 15hour hunt that ended this Special to The New York Timesafternoon when the beast's carcass was found near where it had been shot by its owner in the dark.

title: Foreign Policy Set by Managua Called Realistic
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 8 Jaime Wheelock Roman, a longtime guerrilla leader and now Minister of Agrarian Reform, could not restrain a broad smile as he marched into the United States Ambassador's residence here Friday evening. I hope you're taking note of this, he said.

title: Three More Streets in Manhattan Closed to Cars Beginning Today
description: The city will create three more automobilefree zones today by closing one street in midtown and two in lower Manhattan from 7 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: Concern Agrees to Give Refunds And Halt Claims About Acne Kit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI)  The manufacturer of a mailorder acne treatment kit has agreed to offer refunds to dissatisfied consumers and to stop making claims that the medicine will cure acne, the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday.

title: The U.N, Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Financial Committee 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Northeast Seeks Help From U.S. to Upgrade Urban Water Systems
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  Charging that the Northeast has for too long received too little Federal water money, a consortium of'the region's development groups called today for extensive Government aid with which to clean up and repair urban water systems and dispose of mounting piles of hazardous wastes.

title: Jaya Prakash Narayan Dies; He Led Foes of Mrs. Gandhi
description: NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 8 (AP) Jaya Prakash Narayan, a disciple of nonviolence who united opposition forces to defeat Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in 1977, died early today of a heart ailment at his home in Patna, his doctor said. He was 76 years old.

title: Sketches of Series Players
description: The Starting Eight

title: Stage: Sugar Babies, Burlesque Is Back
description: EVERY once in a while during the new scholarly disquisition on the art of burlesque, Sugar Babies, I found myself humming Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas, and for a while I couldn't figure out why. I knew it wasn't because I'd heard the tinkly old song in another show earlier in the week. I can clear my head when I want to. Then, at last, I figured it out. It's because Mickey Rooney now looks like Santa Claus.

title: Don Magnuson, an ExReporter; Served Washington in Congress
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 8 (UPI)  Don Magnuson, a former newspaper reporter who went on to become a fiveterm United States Representative, was found dead last Friday in his apartment, the apparent victim of a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

title: The Arms Treaty Debate: Carter Is Meeting Roadblocks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  A respectable argument can be made that the prospects for Senate approval of the nuclear arms treaty are today about as good as before News Analysisthe furor, now diminishing, over the presence of a Soviet brigade in Cuba arose five weeks ago. But a respectable argument can also be made that this is not necessarily good news for proponents of the arms control pact with Moscow.

title: TV: World
description: THE series World returns tonight on WNETTV at 10 o'clock, with that favorite of public television commodities, the British import. Who Killed Georgi Markov? was produced by Phil Hardy for Panorama, an ou weekly news program of thentinst Broadcasting Corporation.

title: Raiders Defenders Stop Dolphins, 133
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 8 (AP) Ted Hendricks, a linebacker, scored a touchdown on a 23yard interception return and Reggie Kinlaw, a rookie, sacked the Miami quarterback, Bob Griese, four times tonight as the Raiders won their eighth consecutive Monday night National Football League game by beating the Dolphins, 133.

title: Science Watch
description: Breast cancer patients who respond to their plight with anger, anxiety and depression are likely to live longer than those who more quietly accept their illness, according to a study by psychiatrists at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. The researchers administered psychological tests to 35 women with advanced breast cancer who were just starting drug therapy at the hospital. The women were also interviewed and their doctors were quizzed about patient attitudes and prognosis.

title: DOLLAR UP SHARPLY; EUROPEANS APPLAUD U.S. ECONOMIC CURBS
description: PARIS, Oct. 8  The dollar rebounded sharply in value on world markets and the price of gold declined today as European governments and central banks applauded the Federal Reserve Board's economic curbs that were announced over the weekend.

title: The Region
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn.  The city is preparing for a confrontation this morning between striking workers at the Olin Corporation's Winchester arms plant here and new employees that the company has hired to work in the plant.

title: Jacobson Trial May Be Put Off
description: The murder trial of Howard (Buddy) Jacobson was scheduled to begin today, but a spokesman for Jacob Evseroff, the former horse trainer's lawyer, said the case probably would be postponed because Mr. Evseroff was trying a case in United States District Court in Brooklyn and could not be free until next week. Mr. Jacobson has been charged with slaying John Tupper, allegedly for having replaced him in the affections of Melanie Cain, a fashion model.

title: Unheralded Kinlaw Does job on Dolphins
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 9 (AP) Reggie Kinlaw, a 12thround draft pick out of Oklahoma who has helped revive the Oakland defense, played a key role Monday night in the Raiders 133 victory over the Miami Dolphins.

title: World News Briefs
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 9 (AP)  Former Prime Minister Thorbjorn Falldin, the leader of the Center Party, which was the main loser in Sweden's general election last month, was asked today to form a new nonSocialist coalition government.

title: Sports Today
description: World Series, first game, Orioles vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Baltimore (Television Channel 7, 8:30 P.M. Radio  WCBS, 8:30 P.M.)

title: McCannErickson Gets Pabst Brands
description: McCannErickson, the largest unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is back into hops.
