The Pabst Brewing Company of Milwaukee has selected the agency to handle three of its beer brands, which, according to Leading National Advertisers, accounted for $12.5 million in measured media in 1978, excluding newspapers and soot radio.

title: Executive Says He Made Contributions to Carey at Scotto's Request
description: Walter D. O'Hearn Jr., a waterfront businessman, testified under crossexamination yesterday that he had made political contributions to Governor Carey at the request of Anthony M. Scotto, the Brooklyn leader of the International Longshoremen's Association.

title: Food Units Cited In Price Violations
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) Thirtyeight major food companies appear to be violating the Carter Administration's antiinflation guidelines, the Government said today.

title: BUSINESS
description: The full force of the Federal Reserve's new strategy to control inflation burst upon the financial markets yesterday, pushing interest rates upward and spurring the steepest stock market decline almost six years. In a tumultuous day that experts warned might typify a volatile new monetary era, the nation's commercial banks raised their minimum lending rates a full point, to a record 19% percent. Hundreds of millions of dollars of borrowing was postponed states and corporations decided to wait for the financial markets calm down. [Page Al.]

title: WASHINGTON Pressures On Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  The Federal Reserve Board's stern antiinflation measures have pleased a lot of people, maybe even President Carter, but with their threat of more unemployment in an election year, they are putting new pressures on Senator Kennedy to get into the Presidential race earlier than he had planned.

title: Retail Sales Data Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (Reuters) The Commerce Department said today that the report on September retail sales, originally scheduled for release tomorrow, had been delayed until Thursday or Friday because of computer problems.

title: Police and U.N. Plan Protection For Castro Visit
description: Although still uncertain about precisely when President Fidel Castro of Cuba will arrive this week and where he might go besides the United Nations, New York City and United Nations security officials have drawn up elaborate plans for his protection.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Au bord d'une source, Liszt; Impromptu No. 4, Chopin; Overture to Gypsy Baron, J. Strauss Jr.; Act III Prelude to Tristan and Isolde, Wagner.

title: Racing's Bargain Basement
description: The chant of the horse auctioneer echoed through the catacombs of the Belmont grandstand yesterday, a gibberish kind of siren call for those seeking a bridlepath shortcut to the American Dream. It's the flea market for people looking for passedup treasures. It's called the FasigTipton Sales.

title: Two Fund Bills Voted by House To End Impasse
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  Seeking to break a deadlock with the Senate, the House passed separate appropriations bills today, one including strict limitations on abortions, the other providing a 5.5 percent raise for members of Congress and for top Federal officials.

title: The Cult of LaRouche
description: If this is an age of false messiahs, one of them surely is Lyndon LaRouche Jr. A former professor economics and Wall Street analyst, he is running for President of the United States as the candidate of the U.S. Labor Party. Two articles in The Times this week by Howard Blum and Paul Montgomery make clear that his party is a cult worth watching closely.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: When you lower your thermostat this winter, you might like to have a teddy bear to cuddle in bed. You may have outgrown your toy bear phase, but this bruin isn't a toy. It is a hotwater bottle from Italy, modeled like bear wearing a neat bow tie. It comes in pink and blue and is priced at $9.50 at Jenny B. Goode. It was probably meant originally for children, but Mrs. Goode says a lot of people are buying the bottles to give as presents to adults. The shop is at 1194 Lexington Avenue (81st Street).

title: How Senator Long Shapes Oil Tax Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  If the White House finds it puzzling how the Senate Finance Committee is handling its windfall tax bill, it may be because President Carter and his aides do not fully comprehend the character and technique of'that panel's chairman, Senator Russell B. Long.

title: Koch Signs a Measure To Allow Credit Cards For City Parking Fines
description: A measure that allows motorists to pay parking fines or towing charges with credit cards was signed into law yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Kentucky Justices Limit State's Role in Accrediting Private Schools
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., Oct. 9 (AP)  The Kentucky Supreme Court ruled today that the state could not force private schools to meet the accreditation standards regarding courses, teachers and textbooks that it sets for public schools.

title: CARTER, IN RESPONSE TO BREDINEV, URGES BUILDUP OF MISSILES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  Responding to an offer by the Soviet Union to scale down military forces in East Germany, President Carter said today that the Atlantic alliance should proceed with the modernization of its own missiles in Western Europe.

title: Disgruntled PilotAuthor Buzzes Midtown 3 Hours
description: A disgruntled 61yearold author buzzed midtown Manhattan in a small rented plane for more than three hours yesterday, prompting the evacuation of the United Nations complex and the offices of the publishing company that had incurred his wrath.

title: The Region
description: WHITE PLAINS  Advocates of a proposal to establish a county agency to study a proposed takeover of Consolidated Edison's Westchester County distribution network, experienced another setback yesterday when the League of Women Voters of Westchester announced its opposition.

title: News Summary
description: Upgrading missiles in Western Europe  should proceed and then the Atlantic alliance should negotiate with Moscow a mutual and balanced cut in forces and arms, President Carter said in a televised address. Responding to an offer by the Soviet Union to reduce the number of its nuclear mediumrange missiles aimed at Western Europe, Mr. Carter said that the offer in effect is to continue their own rate of modernization, provided we don't modernize at all. [Page Al, Column 1.]

title: Bridge:
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 9  The United States team made a strong start in the World Team Championship here this afternoon, seeking to defend its Bermuda Bowl title. The powerful American lineup of Eddie Kantar, Bill Eisenberg, Paul Soloway and Bob Goldman, all reigning or former world champions, overwhelmed the strong Brazilian team, which also has four world champions.

title: Narayan Cremated After Funeral Attended by India's Top Leaders
description: NEW DELHI, Oct 9 (Reuters)  The Indian elder statesman Jaya Prakash Narayan was cremated on the banks of the Ganges today after a state funeral in Patna. his hometown.

title: Six Cities Visited by Pope Estimate That They Spent Nearly $7 Million
description: They are still counting the costs in the six cities that Pope John Paul II visited on his American tour, but local governments estimate that they spent nearly $74 million to serve as hosts.

title: TV: The Dream Ballet
description: THE DREAM, created for Britain's Royal Ballet in 1969 by Sir Frederick Ashton, based on Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream. Using music by Felix Mendelssohn, Sir Frederick pared down the play to its forest scenes. The dance, which has become a fixture in the company's repertory, can be seen tonight at 9 on WNETTV, Channel 13.

title: Mrs. Bower Takes Playoff For W.M.G.A. Title on 80
description: PELHAM. N.Y., Oct. 9  Bea Bower of Pelham, playing over her home course, shot an 80 today and defeated Jean Cici of Classic by three strokes in an 18hole playoff for the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association senior championship. The players were deadlocked with 159's when the regulation 36hole event was postponed last month.

title: SCHOOL BUS DRIVERS STRIKE 3D COMPANY
description: A strike against two school bus companies by the union that represents 2,000 drivers spread to a third company yesterday, stranding 1,800 public school students in Brooklyn and Queens.

title: New Canadian Regime Promises Better Relations With Provinces
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 9  Canada's first ProgressiveConservative Government in 16 years said at the opening of Parliament today that it would pursue a policy of consultation and cooperation rather than confrontation between the national Government and the 10 provinces.

title: Stabbed, She Fights Off Rapist
description: A 21yearold woman, en route to school in Manhattan, was stabbed several times in Brooklyn yesterday during an attempted rape, the police said. The woman, Wanda Boykins, was listed in stable condition at Brookdale Hospital. The police said a man asked her for a match on Strauss Street, between Livonia and Dumont Avenues, near her home in the East New York section, about 8:15 A.M., then dragged her into an abandoned building where she was stabbed in the head and back. Despite four to six knife wounds, Miss Boykins fought off her attacker and staggered back to her apartment where she telephoned the police.

title: Student Questions and Answers On Truth in Testing Provisions
description: The College Entrance Examination Board announced yesterday that it would reduce the number of sessions at which the Scholastic Aptitude Test would be offered in New York State after Jan. 1 and would raise testing fees in the state by as much as $5. The College Board said the action was necessary to enable it to comply with the state's new Admissions Testing Law. [Page B3.]

title: New Employees Report at Olin; 5 Pickets Seized
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 9  With policemen in riot gear clearing a path through taunting pickets, 85 new employees reported to work today at the Olin Corporation's Winchester arms plant here in a steady predawn rain. The 1,350member union at the plant is in the 12th week of a strike over the company's effort to set production standards for workers.

title: Kaiser Aluminum Net Climbs
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation reported yesterday that thirdquarter earnings rose 55.3 percent to $52.8 million, or $1.28 a share, from $34 million, or 83 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $704.8 million from $602.3 million.

title: Inmates Stage a Protest On Dismissing Guards
description: GOSHEN, N.Y., Oct. 9 (AP)  More than 150 inmates at the Orange County Jail staged an unusual protest here over the dismissal of temporary guards at the facility.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Q. Do you think you have defused the problem, or issue, of the Soviet brigade in Cuba and satisfied those who seek a bigger defense budget enough now to win SALT's ratification this year? And if so, how?

title: Where to Get Scores on Series
description: Scores of World Series games will be available during the game from the New York Telephone Company at 9991313. The final scores will be carried at that number for several hours after the game.

title: Ghana Looking To New Leader For Better Life
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 7  Jamestown is a neighborhood like dozens of others in this West African city. Small but tidy shacks are squeezed behind narrow, rutted roads, and in scores of tiny stalls mounds of smoked fish and kenkey, a delicious snack made of ground corn, are displayed for sale.

title: Careers
description: NEXT week is Women in Business Week in New York City promotional gettogether of people in small business and big business to promote career opportunities in the region for women. The sponsor is the New York Association of Women Business Owners.

title: Business Records
description: GREAT SHAPES LEOTARD INC., 336 Fifth Ave., N.Y. The petitioners are H. Warshaw 8 Sons Inc., the Darlington Fabrics Corporation and the Bitlex Corpora. tion. Debts amount to 599,978.

title: Walton Is Unlikely To Play in Opener
description: Bill Walton's highly publicized return to National Basketball Association play will most likely be delayed past Friday night's season opener against the Los Angeles Lakers at San Diego.

title: Roasting a 40Pound Lamb
description: ROASTING a lamb had become something of a standing joke among the friends of Robert and Elaine Schaeffer. Although the young couple live only 12 miles from downtown Boston, the house they rent in the wealthy Boston suburb of Lincoln, Mass. is set on seven acres of semiwooded property, which neighbors use to graze a herd of 80 sheep.

title: For Mickey Rooney, Happiness Is Broadway
description: WHEN he was a toddler trouping in smalltime vaudeville with his parents, Mickey Rooney was saying, the closest he ever got to Broadway was Buffalo and Albany. That isn't very close, he sax'. Now I've finally made it.

title: A Memorable Guest's List Of Great Dinner Parties
description: AS the days grow crisp and the nights lengthen, my thoughts turn to dinner parties and my memories dwell on some of the special occasions of years past. My idea of a good dinner party is when I don't remember the food, but I do remember at least a few of the guests and most of the conversation. When I can tell you what we had eat, it is because for some reason something was wrong.

title: Wine Talk
description: WITH great stealth, almost furtively, they slip through the doors of wine shops and begin browsing through the California racks, feigning disinterest when they come across their quarry, suppressing the excitement of discovery. They are searching for bottles of cabernet sauvignon and zinfandel of the great California vintage of 1974, noble reds of extraordinary quality that linger on the shelves simply because so many consumers do not recognize them.

title: One Man's View Of CutUp Vegetables
description: His mother was a model, his father wellknown stilllife photographer, and by the time Michael Somoroff was 19, he had already opened his own studio.

title: Jets Want Hull to Return; Star, 40, Delays Decision
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Oct. 9 (UPI)  The Winnipeg Jets general manager, John Ferguson, has asked Bobby Hull to return to the Jets for their first National Hockey League season. replied that he will give the Jets his answer soon. I might know what I'm doing in the next couple of weeks, he said. The N.H.L. season opens this week.

title: Justices to Hear Dispute on Trial That Excluded Public and Press
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  The Supreme Court agreed today to hear a constitutional challenge to a judge's order that excluded the public and the press from a Virginia murder trial.

title: Housing Policeman Shot
description: A 35yearold Housing Authority police officer was shot in the shoulder yesterday when he responded to a family dispute at the Johnson housing project in Harlem. The officer, Brendan Brophy, was listed in good condition in Metropolitan Hospital and Elias DelValle, 47, was charged with attempted murder.

title: Jury Hears Suicide's Tape
description: BREVARD, N.C., Oct. 9 (AP)  Three days after she killed herself, the anguished voice of Rebecca Coleman cried out in a Transylvania County courtroom yesterday, condemning the man accused of raping her and killing her friend.

title: ParkeDavis Plant to Close
description: MORRIS PLAINS, N.J., Oct. 9 (Reuters)  The WarnerLambert Company announced today that it intended to proceed with the gradual phaseout of the Detroit plant operated by its ParkeDavis division. The company previously had said that it was reviewing the possibility of relocating the facility's production at existing plants that were more modern.

title: After the Vote, Ohira Is Target of Criticism
description: TOKYO, Oct. 9  The governing Liberal Democratic Party has turned in its worst performance ever in terms of the number of seats won in Parliament, nearly losing its working majority in the lower house and raisins auestions about the political future of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira.

title: Talmadge Said to Yield On Senate Denunciation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP)  Senator Herman E. Talmadge has agreed not to wage a long fight against the findings of the Senate Ethics Committee that he should be denounced for financial misconduct. Senate sources said today.

title: CITY TO BROADCAST VICE CLIENTS NAMES
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the names of those convicted of patronizing prostitutes under a twoyearold state law would be broadcast soon by the cityowned radio station, WNYC.

title: Best Buys
description: THE venerable proposition that what goes up must come down was demonstrated at the city's supermarkets last week. There, according to the city's Department of Consumer Affairs, the price of the 41item market basket used as a gauge of the cost of feeding a family of four, fell .85 percent.

title: Plastics Output Rise Seen
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, Oct. 9 (Reuters)  Worldwide plastics output should grow 5 percent a year through 1986, a spokesman for Bayer A.G. told reporters in advance of tomorrow's opening of the annual West German Plastics Fair.

title: Doctor Asserts Tate Will Fight on Oct. 20
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 9  John Tate's doctor said today that the tendinitis in the heavyweight's left wrist would not postpone his World Boxing Association title fight against Gerrie Coetzee in Pretoria on Oct. 20.

title: A Big Question For Europeans: Tactical Arms
description: LONDON, Oct. 6  Endorsement of the pending SovietAmerican nuclear arms treaty by the European members of NATO has not diminished mounting concern over the alliance's inferiority in tactical nuclear weapons.

title: For a Vodka Boatman, A Headache in Japan
description: TOKYO, Oct. 9 (AP)  The Japanese police today arrested a 29yearold Soviet coal miner who said he had drunk too much vodka, fallen asleep in his boat and drifted across 100 miles of ocean from Siberia to Hokkaido, the northernmost of Japan's main islands.

title: Van Kills Daughter of Candidate; Cleveland Mayor Campaign Halts
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 9 (AP)  All activity was suspended today in the Cleveland mayoral campaign after the death of the 9yearold daughter of Lieut. Gov. George V. Voinovich, who led the fiveman field in last week's primary.

title: C.A.B. Delays on Pan Am
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI)  The Civil Aeronautics Board postponed a scheduled final decision today on whether to approve an application by Pan American World Airways to take over National Airlines.

title: Deaths
description: DAYJames Rowland on October 9, 1979 of Baldwin L.I. Beloved husband of the late Florence G., uncle of George R. Gabel and Carolyn D. Wynne. Friends may call at the Clayton & Forbell Funeral Home, 20 Lincoln Ave. Rockville Centre, L.I. 79PM Wednesday,and 24 and 79PM Thursday. Service at St. Mark's United Methodist Church, Rockville Centre L.I. Friday 10AM. Interment Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: DEAFSCHOOL STRIKE BACKED BY PARENTS
description: Several dozen parents and students joined teachers yesterday in a protest outside the Lexington School for the Deaf in Jackson Heights, Queens, where a weekold strike by the teachers has canceled classes for 370 students.

title: Pirates Not Under the Weather
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 9  It's not an irritation, Chuck Tanner said tonight after the opening game of the 76th World Series was rained out. It's not a disaster. It's an inconvenience.

title: G.M. Chief Eases Chrysler Aid View
description: DETROIT, Oct. 9  The General Motors Corporation chairman, Thomas A. Murphy, today softened his earlier hardline stand against Federal aid to his financially ailing competitor, the Chrysler Corporation. Mr. Murphy said he would favor it if that were the only possible way to save the company from collapse.

title: C.A.B. Action Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP)  President Carter approved a Civil Aeronautics Board decision today to reject most of the requests by Eastern Air Lines and four Latin American carriers for fuelrelated fare increases. Eastern had proposed increases of 6 percent for the Caribbean and Mexico while the foreign carriers asked for raises of up to 12 percent to some Caribbean and South American destinations.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: Airlines Are Preparing For Business Downturn
description: The major airlines, after turning in disappointing traffic figures for September, are preparing for financial turbulence in the months ahead. Some have already started to tighten their belts with big layoffs and flight cancellations.

title: E.F. Hutton Group In Alaska Venture
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 9 (Reuters)  The Alaska Interstate Company said today that the Alaska Petrochemical Company, a 75 percent owned subsidiary, had agreed with the E.F. Hutton Group to develop, build and operate a 150,000barreladay refinery and petrochemical facility for Valdez, Alaska.

title: World Gold
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 9. 1979

title: INJECTION OF A GENE CURES FLAW IN CELL
description: Successful injection of a single gene into a defective living cell, curing that cell's fatal genetic flaw, has been reported by a team of scientists at the National Institutes of Health and Rockefeller University.

title: Fidelcor Dividend
description: The board of directors of Fidelcor Inc., parent of the Fidelity Bank, approved the reinstatement of the company's quarterly dividend at a special meeting yesterday. The sixcentashare payout will be payable Nov. 15 to holders of record Oct. 30.

title: Dow Corning Plans Price Increases
description: MIDLAND, Mich., Oct. 9 (Reuters)  The Dow Corning Corporation, venture of the Dow Chemical Company, and the Corning Glass Works, said today that it was raising industrial product prices 9.5 to 14.5 percent effective Nov. 1.

title: Blues Capture Season Opener
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Oct. 9 (UPI)  Wayne Babych scored one goal and added two assists tonight to lead the St. Louis Blues to a 52 victory over the Vancouver Canucks in the opening game of the 197980 National Hockey League season.

title: Stennis Favors Prompt Senate Debate of Arms Treaty
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 9  Senator John C. Stennis of Mississippi, the chairman of the Armed Services Committee, made clear today that he was opposed to suggestions that the Senate postpone action, on the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union until next year.

title: Bank to Offer Market Rates
description: The East New York Savings Bank announced yesterday that it would be the first bank in New York to offer market interest rates on deposits of less than $10,000 in 26week certificates.

title: Rock: Carlene Carter Brings a Country Inflection
description: WITH her stepfather (Johnny Cash) and mother (June Carter Cash) at a frontcenter table Monday night, Carlene Carter returned to the Bottom Line to give a performance that in its own slightly peculiar way was very good indeed.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AMERICAN ARGOSY (U.S. Lines). Rotterdam Oct 25, Bremerhaven 27 and LeHavre 29; sails from Howland Hook, Staten Island.

title: Deaths
description: KOBREIsaac. Members of the Elizabeth S. Williams Club records with profound sorrow the loss of the beloved husband and father of our lifelong and devoted members, Lena Kobre and Laurette Herman. Our deepest sympathy to all the family.

title: Rights Panel's Fund Bill Signed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI)  President Carter has signed a bill authorizing $14 million for the Civil Rights Commission for the fiscal year 1980, the White House said today.

title: Around the Nation
description: LANSING, Mich., Oct. 9 (AP)  The people of Michigan carry small amounts of the toxic fire retardant PBB in their blood and fat but are generally healthy in spite of it, researchers said today in their final report on one of the nation's worst chemical disasters.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Ecomomic and Financial Committee  10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Roosevelt and St. Luke's Merge Into One Hospital
description: New York City's largest private, voluntary hospital was created yesterday with the merger of St. Luke's and Roosevelt linsnitals on the West Side.

title: Jersey Panel Orders Casino Audit
description: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission issued an emergency order yesterday directing Resorts International to conduct an immediate audit and inventory of its credit files.

title: Columbia Soccer Victor
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Oct. 9 Tommy Panayotidi scored early in the second overtime period to provide Columbia (71) with a 21 soccer victory over Rutgers (211) at Rutgers Stadium today.

title: S.A.T. Schedule Will Be Reduced Beginning Jan. 1
description: The College Entrance Examination Board announced yesterday that, beginning Jan. 1, students in New York State will have fewer chances to take the Scholastic Aptitude Test and that, when they do, they will pay as much as $5 more than the $8.25 fee paid by students elsewhere in the country.

title: Impact of Female Cadets Assessed by West Point
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 9 (AP)Female cadets here adopt traditional masculine personality traits to be accepted as leaders. They also want both marriage and a fulltime military career. And they are more conservative than other college women about sex.

title: The City
description: A program that provides tax benefits to eligible owners who rehabilitate apartment buildings would be extended under a measure approved by the City Council's Committee on Housing and Buildings. The bill still faces a vote by the full Council.

title: Report by a Nader Group Measures Dollar Benefits of U.S. Regulations
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  Government health and safety regulations provided Americans with more than $35 billion in benefits last year and will produce $80.6 billion in benefits in 1985, according to a report issued today by a group affiliated with Ralph Nader. In most cases, the report indicated, the benefits of Federal regulation outweigh the costs.

title: AIMEE ORNSTEIN
description: Aimee J. Ornstein, assistant manager of the Chemical Bank's risk management department at 140 Broadway, was struck and killed by a car Monday night at 84th Street and Second Avenue. She was 26 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Associated Press
description: SATELLITE ANTENNA RECEIVES NEW COAT OF PAINT: Workmen painting an 82foothigh antenna near Crystal River, Fla. The antenna, with a 105footwide dish, receives cable television signals relayed by satellite.

title: Honeywell Offers Big Computer
description: Honeywell Inc. moved into the market for large computers yesterday when it unveiled four new machines, including one that competes headon with the largest data processing units offered by the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: URGENT INSPECTIONS ORDERED FOR DC9'S
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  The Government today ordered urgent inspections and repairs, if needed, of more than 100 more DC9 jetliners to forestall another emergency like the one in which an Air Canada DC9 lost a rear cabin wall and tail cone over the Atlantic last month.

title: Q&A
description: Q I have before me a recipe for salmon to be poached in champagne. I wonder why the champagne luxury is necessary. When the bubbles disappear don't you wind up with a still white wine? Would you use a $20 bottle of champagne to make this dish?

title: Notes on People
description: Musicians as Artists, a benefit exhibition opening tonight at Harkness House Gallery, shows that music need not be the allconsuming artistic outlet of some of the world's bestknown composers and performers.

title: Personal Health
description: JERRY suffered a stress fracture, Kathy got hit by a car, Tess activated an old knee injury, Sidney suffered a heart attack, and I knocked my back out. They were all casualties of the most pervasive and persistent fad in America  jogging.

title: Real Estate
description: FOREIGN investment in Manhattan commercial real estate has by all accounts been modest so far in comparison with American institutional investment, especially by life insurance companies. Probably the most notable foreign entry into Manhattan came with the $330 million purchase by Olympia & York Developments, bases in Toronto, of the postwar Uris Development Corporation office buildings in 1977. The Canadian company is no mere passive investor. It manages the properties and has moved into development activity.

title: Volcker Urges Restraint By Banks on Loan Rates
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 9  Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, urged the nation's bankers today to show restraint in raising interest rates and cautioned them against lending to finance speculative or purely financial activities.

title: 3 Banks Aid Mexican Loan
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9 (Reuters) The Bank of America said today that it was one of three banks that led in arranging a $75 million loan to Grupo Industrial Alfa S.A., a diversified private company in Mexico. The other banks were Deutsche Bank A.G. and Grindlay Brandts Ltd.

title: Animators Loss Shakes Disney
description: LOS ANGELES, OCt. 9  It is saia around the Walt Disney Productions studios in Burbank that 13 years after Walt Disney's death the entertainment empire still runs by his visionary blueprint. The strict Disney standards, including hair length and dress, remain in force, and loyalty to Walt Disney's memory approaches reverence. Small wonder, given the extraordinary Disney success.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The Pope's visit to this country was extremely well received, a fitting response to a world leader who is, at the same time, a charming man with a magnetic personality.

title: Advertising
description: SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda, Oct.  Business will be good, but you can't expect the last three years to continue, said Robert J. Coen, senior vice president of McCannErickson, as the Magazine Publishers Association began its 60th annual meeting today at the Southampton Princess Hotel with a record turnout.

title: Loving Mother, At Last
description: She had always been an ultimately fastidious person. As a child I wondered at her perfectly manicured fingernails, whose polish never seemed to chip. As if her will were strong enough to dominate anything that touched her person, her stockings never had runs, the seams were always exclamationpoint straight, and even the leather heels on her shoes never ran down. Did the wind blow her hair? I search my memory for images of a tousled head just once  but all I can conjure up are perfect curls, sculpted waves or the bouffant style that saw her through to the end.

title: Uncle Sugar
description: Hey, buddy, can you spare a dollar? That's all the sugar farmers are asking this year from every consumer to provide added protection for the domestic sugar industry. But the farmers don't ask for voluntary contributions. They lobby Congress for higher price supports, as well as a direct cash subsidy from the Treasury. A vote on their current request is imminent in the House; we hope it has the stomach to say no.

title: Wilkens, Coach of Sonics, Is Hurt in Traffic Accident
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 9 (UPI)  Coach Lenny Wilkens of the Seattle SuperSonics escaped with minor injuries today when he was involved in a traffic accident on the Mercer Island Floating Bridge across Lake Washington.

title: $50 MILLION SLATED FOR CITY FROM CETA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall will announce later this week the reallocation of about $500 million in unused public jobs funds, a sizable portion of which will go to New York City as a high unemployment area.

title: Series Opener Is Postponed by Rain
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 9  Rain, which Earl Weaver says has not been good for his vegetable garden, was not good for the World Series tonight. It forced postponement of the first game for the first time in the 76year history of the Series. So the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Baltimore Orioles will play the opener tomorrow night.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BorgWarner Corporation, a Chicagobased diversified products company, has elected Clarence E. Johnson vice presidenthuman resources.

title: Chamber Concert: Musical Elements
description: THE program on Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, where the chamber ensemble called Musical Elements gave the first of three concerts scheduled for this season, offered no information about the four works being played, not even their composition dates. But a slip sheet did provide texts or six poems that Daniel Asia, the group's conductorcomposer, had used in his Sand II, a 20minute piece that he led in its first performance. In view of the puerile nature of the poetry, a total blackout of program notes might have been a blessing.

title: Deaths
description: ORNSTEINAimee. The Officers, Board of Governors, and Staff of the Greater New York Committee for State of Israel Bonds note with profound sorrow the untimely passing of the beloved daughter of their colleague and friend, Franklin H. Ornstein, Chairman of the NassauSuffolk Division. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to him and the entire family.

title: 58 Vietnamese Refugees Saved
description: MANILA, Oct. 9 (Reuters)  Two boatloads of Vietnamese refugees were picked up in the South China Sea last night and early today after they were spotted by United States Navy planes, a Navy spokesman said. The Greek vessel Pfilif picked up 12 refugees about 150 miles southeast of Cam Ranh Bay and the American tanker Arabian Sea saved 46 about 250 miles northeast of Singapore.

title: Machinists Complain on Corporate Political Action
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  The machinists' union today filed a complaint with the Federal Elections Commission charging that some United States corporations were violating election laws by using threats and intimidation to get employees to contribute to corporaterun political action committees.

title: Cowboys Get Dutton for 2 Top Draft Picks
description: DALLAS, Oct. 9 (AP)  The Dallas Cowboys, who had not parted with a No. 1 draft choice in 12 years, did so with delight today, acquiring John Dutton from the Baltimore Colts for No. and No. 2 choices next year. Because of a contract dispute, Dutton refused to olav for the Colts this season.

title: $30,000 Disappears From Maxwell's Plum
description: Thirty thousand dollars in cash disappeared yesterday from Maxwell's Plum, a restaurant on Manhattan's ,East Side, after a secretary left it on a desk in a locked office there, the police said. They said the money represented the restaurant's receipts for the last four days.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Gold Prices Up Sharply; Dollar Finishes Mixed
description: Gold prices climbed yesterday, but the dollar was mixed, gaining strength overseas from the antiinflation moves announced over the weekend and falling at home on fears of high oil prices.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The incoming president of the National Association of Business Economists traditionally presents the group's consensus economic forecast at its annual convention. So, at the 1979 convention of the association, which began last Monday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel in New York, the forecast was presented, as scheduled, by Robert T. Parry, senior vice president and chief economist of the Security Pacific National Bank of Los Angeles.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: A band of clouds extends along a cold front stretching from New England to the Plains States. Broken, low clouds are visible in the lake region and thick low clouds blanket eastern Colorado. High clouds are apparent in the Southwest Desert region.

title: Howe Stays With Whalers; One of Sons Is Sent Down;
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 9 (UPI)  Gordie Howe has ended the speculation and has decided to play his 32d season, but one of his two sons will not be with him on the Hartford Whalers roster.

title: Brooklyn Jazz Musician Who Fled Texas 11 Years Ago Is Released
description: A Brooklyn musician who fled Dallas 11 years ago after being convicted of possessing onehalf ounce of marijuana was released without bail in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday pending talks between members of the United States Attorney's office and representatives of the State of Texas.

title: Russian Urges Rise in Births
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 9 (AP)  A Soviet population expert has called for a rapid rise in the country's birth rate because of what he says will be a sharp decrease in the growth of labor resources in the next decade.

title: Now Pitching  Lefty Gomez
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 9  There was rain with thunder and lightning during the night. Morning was fairly clear but after noon the climate turned Kuhnish with temperatures plunging, rain spitting and a Bowie wind ripping out of the Northwest. Bowie Kuhn weather is the contribution the baseball commissioner and the television programmers made to the World Series when they decided that players and customers preferred raw October nights to autumn sunshine and that coldstiffened fingers would improve the quality of competition.

title: U.S. Warships Sail for Cuba Base
description: NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 9 (UPI) Three Navy warships headed south in the Atlantic today en route to the United States naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, for a month of maneuvers as part of President Carter's response to the presence of Soviet troops in Cuba.

title: Who Might Pay for Zimbabwe
description: Two issues seem to be blocking progress in the once hopeful London talks about a settlement in Zimbabwe Rhodesia. Both concern land. The black leaders the Patriotic Front are resisting a British plan to limit for a period of ten years Zimbabwe's power to take land from whites. And they complain about the proposed requirement that fair value be paid for all transferred property.

title: Letters
description: We enjoyed the article Seltzer: Renaissance in Fizz [Sept. 26] and found the point made, about people refinding seltzer, wonderful.

title: COMMODITIES Futures Prices Rebound For Gold and Silver
description: Gold and silver futures prices rebounded yesterday from Monday's losses that followed Government moves to fight inflation and bolster the sagging dollar.

title: Scott Decides to Unretire
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Oct. 9 (AP)  James Scott, the Rahway State Prison inmate recently stripped of his No. 2 lightheavyweight ranking the World Boxing Association, said today that he had unretired and would fight at the prison this year in two bouts that had already been scheduled.

title: Thailand Gets U.S. Credit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP)  A financing package totaling $25 million has been approved to help Thailand buy United States cotton and tobacco, the Agriculture Department said today. A $15 million credit line at commercial interest rates may be used by Thailand to buy an estimated 23,078 bales of cotton and 1,098 metric tons of tobacco, the department said. Private exporters will be offered $10 million in guarantees for the sale of cotton to Thailand.

title: Dr. Carroll C. Pratt, a Professor Taught Psychology at 4 Colleges
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 9  Dr. Carroll C. Pratt, professor emeritus of psychology at Princeton University, died yesterday at the Princeton Medical Center. He was 85 years old and lived in Pennineton. N.J.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  An appeals court's decision lifting a contempt of court order against the Attorney General of the United States was allowed to stand today when the Supreme Court refused by a narrow margin to hear an appeal by the Socialist Workers Party.

title: Wood, Field and Stream New Books Point Up Joys of the Outdoors
description: Today's campers, hikers, canoeists and amateur naturalists enjoy advantages that were beyond reach of outdoorsmen 30 years ago.

title: The Magic of Irish Cookery
description: HIS face is slightly satyric, but he is unmistakably a leprechaun. He has a jaunty brogue and his palaver is random, allencompassing and tireless, as the palaver of Irishmen is supposed to be.

title: U.S. to Publish Diet Guides for Consumers
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Government will soon publish dietary guideines for the American people. Many of the nutritionists crusading for better American eating habits agreed last week that the Federal Government should do so. And some members of the food industry who will be affected also agreed.

title: Rouse Now Rebuilding Downtown Retail Areas
description: COLUMBIA, Md.  The Rouse COMpany, one of the foremost commercial developers of suburban America, has turned its attention to central cities with retail areas in need of redevelopment.

title: Carey Names Justice Greenblott To 3d Term in Appellate Division
description: ALBANY, Oct. 9 (AP)  Governor Carey has reappointed Justice Louis M. Greenblott of Binghamton to the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court for the Third Department. Mr. Carey announced Justice Greenblott's reappointment today. His new term expires Dec. 31, 1980, at the same time as his 14year term as a State Supreme Court justice.

title: Kitchen Equipment Marble Slabs and Rolling Pins
description: MARBLE is naturally cool. If you touch a slab of marble and then a piece of wood next to it, you get the impression that the wood has been absorbing heat while the marble has been repelling it. That makes marble a desirable material for working with pastry dough.

title: Economic Scene
description: WITH its new economicrestraint plan, the Federal Reserve has initiated an experiment in money management more or less along the lines urged by its monetarist critics. The monetarists have been telling the Fed to stop manipulating interest rates and instead concentrate on controlling the supply of bank reserves, which they say is a far more reliable way of promoting a steady, moderate growth in the money stock.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (AP)  The Allstate Insurance Company is extending a 10 percent to 30 percent rate reduction for collision and comprehensive coverage to 18 car models.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: WHEN we visit France, it takes a while to get our French going. Ordinary phrases come easily enough, but it may be weeks before we become accustomed to the style of the language and to its peculiar genius. This is the way it is, too, with Roland Barthes. His books occur in the intimate recesses of the French language and the French style.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: WHEN the telephone rang the other day, writes Jeanne Guise, my husband answered it to hear a woman's voice say: This is Gimbels Home Shopping Center. We wonder whether you would be interested in having your furniture reupholstered.

title: E.P.A. Head, Conceding Errors, Reports Gain on Water Pollution
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 9  The head of the Environmental Protection Agency acknowledged today that the nation's eightyear effort to abate water pollution was behind schedule and that mistakes had been made. But he said that there had already been noteworthy results and that we are turninz the corner.

title: Hispanic Officials Propose Guidelines for Koch Adviser
description: Elected officials of Hispanic origin, heartened by, though wary of, Mayor Koch's plan to appoint a special adviser for Hispanic affairs, said yesterday that the appointee would have to be acceptable to Hispanic political figures, have no past or future in elective office to protect, and be able to act as both gobetween and advocate.

title: Judge Bars Bid for Doctor's File In Trial of Sex Slayings Suspect
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (Reuters)  Judge Louis Garippo today decided against handing over to prosecutors extensive notes made by a defense psychiatrist in 65 hours of interviews with John Wayne Gacy, who goes on trial in January on charges of murdering 33 boys and young men.

title: Deaths
description: JOLLESSamuel. The Officers, and Board of Directors of Public Service Mutual Insurance Company record with deep sorrow the passing of Samuel Jolies, a good friend who was a Director of the company for many years. Our sincere sympathy to his wife, Ethel, and family.

title: MAJOR BANKS RAISE LOAN RATE TO 14%; STOCKS OFF BY 26.45
description: The full force of the Federal Reserve's new strategy to control inflation burst upon the financial markets yesterday, causing interest rates to spiral upward to record levels and sending the stock market to its heaviest loss in nearly six years.

title: Nine Injured in Fire in Queens
description: Nine persons, including four firemen, were injured early yesterday in a fire of suspicious origin in Queens, the Fire Department reported. A department spokesman said the fire started in a twostory frame house at 9318 109th Street in Corona and quickly spread to a house next door at 4314 104th Street.

title: Malta, an OftConquered Isle, Seeks a Few Good Friends
description: VALLETTA, Malta, Oct. 5  While cannons boomed and cathedral bells pealed, British forces that held this Mediterranean island for 180 years sailed away on March 31.

title: Defendant Is Given 8 to 25 Years For Sexual Attacks on 5 Women
description: A 27yearold man was sentenced yesterday to a minimum of eight years and four months in prison, with a maximum of 25 years, for sexually assaulting five women. The attacks took place in Central Park.

title: Dow in Worst Drop In Nearly Six Years
description: The stock market sustained its worst setback in almost six years yesterday, falling sharply across a broad front on heavy volume.

title: On Electric Rates
description: CHICAGOSkyrocketing fuel costs and persistent energysupply problems cloud America's future. People are confused by Government pricing regulations, concerned about their leaders inability to find solutions and convinced that someone is getting rich at their expense. It is not surprising therefore that the setting of electric rates is being subjected to public reexamination.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: THE two most important elements in fine cooking are, of course, flavor and texture. Naturally, flavor is the more critical of the two, but a lumpy sauce, a gummy bread or an undercooked vegetable can mar a fine cook's best efforts. The subtleties of describing a desired texture are at times a bit tricky. That is why you will often encounter the phrase cook until crisptender in recipes printed here. It usually pertains to vegetables that are to be cooked just until they have lost their raw taste yet retain a crunchy texture.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown.(N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Forecast Cut On OPEC Oil
description: PARIS, Oct. 9  The United States and its allies now believe the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will export much less oil in the future than was expected only a few months ago because of soaring official prices plus the premiums many members charge for secure supplies, senior energy officials disclosed today.

title: Events Today
description: ONCE A CATHOLIC, comedy by Mary O'Malley, starring Rachel Roberts and Peggy Cass, Helen Hayes Theater, 210 West 46th Street, 6:45.

title: Israel Lodges Terrorism Charges Against an Arab Held in Chicago
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 9 (Reuters)  Israel has lodged formal charges of terrorist activities against a West Bank Arab who is being held in the United States.

title: George Ryall Dies
description: George Francis Trafford Ryall, known as Audax Minor to more than five decades of readers of The New Yorker magazine, died Monday in a nursing home in Columbia, Md., after a long illness. He was 92 years old and had lived in Ellicott City, Md., in recent years.

title: Carter to Nominate Labor Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP)  President Carter announced today that he was nominating John N. Gentry to be Under Secretary of Labor, succeeding Robert Brown, who has resigned. Mr. Gentry, who headed Mr. Carter's 1978 board of inquiry on coal strike issues, is adviser to Alfred E. Kahn, chairman of the Council on Wage and Price Stability, on labormanagement relations.

title: Liberals Echo Carter In Backing Fed Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  President Carter declared firm support today for the Federal Reserve's weekend package of measures raising interest rates, and his stance was generally echoed by traditionally liberal Capitol Hill legislators and private economists.

title: Gorman Wins in Brisbane
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Oct. 9 (AP)  Tom Gorman of the United States defeated Phil Davies of Australia today, 64, 64, in the opening round of the $50,000 South Pacific tennis tournament at the Milton Courts. Another American, Matt Mitchell, advanced to a secondround match against topseeded Geoff Masters of Australia.

title: Boy,16, a Convicted Killer, Gets Nine Years for Subway Robbery
description: A I6yearold boy who, according to a prosecutor, had been convicted of killing a man and who had worked as a prostitute was sentenced yesterday to nine years in prison for robbing a teacher last November in a Manhattan subway station.

title: Heating for Poor Seen as Costlier Than Predicted
description: A new study conactuated for the new England Congressional delegation suggests that the need of the poor for financial help to heat their homes this winter may be far greater than anticipated by Congress and officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Islanders Potvin Will Miss Week With Hurt Shoulder
description: Denis Potvin of the Islanders, winner of the Norris Trophy last season as the National Hockey League's top defenseman, will miss the first week to 10 days of the season with a bruised right shoulder.

title: Aids to Hearing Being Tested at LuntFontanne
description: A sound system for the hardofhearing has been installed at the LuntFontanne Theater, where Peter Pan, starring Sandy Duncan, is playing.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Learning From Japan
description: TOKYO  The death of an actress can prompt retrospection. Along with many Japanese of my generation, was prompted to a moment of silence last Monday, when the lateevening television announced the death of Yaeko Mizutani. Having never dared speculate on tne matter, I was surprised to learn that she died at the age of 74. Just as I was awarding myself consolatory patontheback at having witnessed her prime days, I learned that those performances I had so avidly watched actually had come in the evening of her life.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 34900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN HEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 747.0500. SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691000; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Market Place
description: THE Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil enterprise, is getting some favorable recommendations in the investment community. However, yesterday's stock market decline was the most damaging in nearly six years and no respecter of companies, big or small. Exxon's shares, for examole. fell 1 noints to finish at 58.

title: Deaths
description: BIRCHChristopher H., suddenly on Oct 7, 1979 at ape 47 of Shoreham, L.I., survived by his half brothers, William D. Birch and George Ross Birch and a half sister Damper Anne Gorman. Memorial service will be held at his home, Tagliabue Rd. Shoreham, L. I. Thursday, 4PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Charles Hospital, Port Jefferson,NT. For further Int: 0.B.Davis Funeral Home, 5164730360

title: Private Lives
description: WHILE I am not, of course, recommending them for everybody, second marriages are generally fun, and these days seem to last longer, as if the veterans foreign wars, their scars glowing in the dark, had turned in their swords for ploughshares. Innocence overrated. The second time around, we know who can be expected to burn the coffee and who can be relied on to fall asleep in the middle of an argument about structuralism or bad faith. Defects of character have already been identified. Time is running out. Amateur hour is over.

title: U.S. Company Buys Ad in Bid to Free 2 in Salvador
description: In response to demands of leftist guerrillas who kidnapped two of their employ. ees late last month in El Salvador and are holding them, Beckman Instruments Inc., of Fullerton, Calif., has agreed to pay for the publication of a long political statement in newspapers in the United States, Central America and Europe, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: A Tough New Drive On Births in China
description: USING a variety of contraceptives, including vacation pills for couples who are rarely united and paper pills prepared in perforated sheets like postage stamps, China is making an allout effort to stem its population growth.

title: Chess:
description: LONDON, Oct. 5  Grandmaster Lothar Schmid of West Germany has been known in recent years as the patient, longsuffering referee of the world championship matches in Iceland in 1972 between Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky and in the Philippines last year between Anatoly Karpov and Vikfor Korchnoi. It may have been forgotten that he also plays the game.

title: Topics Reflections of Arafat and Thieu
description: The black leaders who raced to embrace Yasir Arafat to avenge the dismissal of Andrew Young have finally got their answer from the P.L.O. To the extent that the Rev. Joseph Lowery and the Rev. Jesse Jackson thought they needed merely to get Moslems and Jews to sit down and talk things over like Christians, they fell victim to one of the oldest and most bitter jests about the Middle East.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EYEFUL TOWER There is a different look on the 65th floor at Rockefeller Center, across the hall from the Rainbow Room. And it is quite a look indeed, along with that legendary panorama outside.

title: U.S. Steel Is Charged With Excess Pollution At Pennsylvania Plant
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  The Justice Department disclosed today that it was suing the United States Steel Corporation over its failure to curb emissions of soot and smoke at the company's huge Fairless Works plant in Bucks County, Pa.

title: Greek Prosecutor Accuses Pilot Of Negligence in Swissair Crash
description: ATHENS, Oct. 9 (AP)  Preliminary charges of multiple manslaughter through negligence were filed today against the pilot of a Swissair DC8 that plunged off the runway on landing here Sunday and burst into flames, killing 14 passengers and injuring 10.

title: Raleigh, N.C., Mayor Is Defeated
description: Mayor Isabella W. Cannon of Raleigh, N.C., was defeated in a reelection bid today, and a black City Councilman in Birmingham, Ala., led the field in a preliminary mayoral contest.

title: David Izenzon, Bassist; AntiMarijuana Adviser
description: David Izenzon, a former jazz musician and the founder of Pot Smokers Anonymous, was pronounced dead from a heart attack Monday on arrival at Bellevue Hospital. He was 47 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Tonight Show Special Helps NBC Top Ratings
description: NBCTV, the leading contender against ABCTV in the season rating competitions, won handily last week, the second time in the new season it has beaten the firstplace champion.

title: Parent Will Be Honored In Philadelphia Tomorrow
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 (AP) Thursday will be Bernie Parent Day in Philadelphia, complete with city proclamation.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Touch of Yiddish in Soviet Far East
description: KHABAROVSK, U.S.S.R.  The organizers of the Pacific Science Congress, which met recently in this Far Eastern city, provided unusual field trips for participants, but none to an unusual area just west of the city, the socalled Jewish Autonomous Region.

title: Phone Workers Agree to Return After a Walkout
description: A dispute that led to a oneday work stoppage by thousands of teiephone installers and repairmen in Manhattan and the Bronx employed by the New York Telephone Company was settled last night, Morton Bahr, a vice president of the Communications Workers of America, announced.

title: Foreign Investing In U.S. Increases
description: The United States, still the leading nation in terms of investing overseas, has also become the favorite site for investments by other industrial countries, the Conference Board, a business research group, said yesterday its stuay anaiyzea 1,500 toreign manufacturing investments in the last 27 months and found that almost half of them were made in the United States. Onefourth of them were made by American companies overseas.

title: Veeck Denies Plans To Sell White Sox
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (AP)  Chicago will have an American League team in 1980, and that team will be the White Sox, not the A's, Bill Veeck said today.

title: President, in Rebuttal to Kennedy, Calls Florida First Significant Test
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  President Carter, taking issue with Senator Edward M. Kennedy and evidently eager to play up an expected advantage, said today that he regarded the outcome of the Florida Democratic caucuses on Saturday as the first significant test of their relative strength.

title: South African Sentenced In Scandal Freed on Bail
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 9 (Reuters)  A South African judge today released on bail Eschel M. Rhoodie, the chief civil servant in the nowdefunct Information Ministry, who was sentenced yesterday to six years in prison for fraud.

title: News of the Theater
description: USTIN PENDLETON is ready to star as Adam in Arthur Miller's new musical, Up From Paradise. He has been ready, in fact, for a little over two years. He is still waiting for the rest of the production to fall into place so can open on Broadway  this season, he hones.

title: South Korean Fishing Boat Held
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Oct. 9 (UPI)  The Coast Guard and agents of the National Marine Fisheries Service have seized a South Korean stern trawler for violations of United States fishing regulations.

title: NewYorkers, etc
description: IT isn't easy to resist cheesecake, lasagna, or blini with caviar and sour cream, but it's possible. It isn't easy to resist picking up a good book when work is waiting, or not to take a taxi when it rains, or to stay home in a snowstorm, but it can be done. But some things aren't possible and can't be done, no matter what quantities of will power, determination and mod intentions are summoned up.

title: The Timeless Styles Of Mme. Grs
description: Back in 1966, a fashion critic noted that the Mme. Grs collection just unveiled* in Paris could have been confused with dozens that she has done in the last decade. It was not a startling pronouncement then, and nothing has changed since. The widely revered symbol of haute couture did not invent timeless clothes; she merely executes them with unparalleled skill. Her own staff often finds it impossible to determine the year of a design.

title: Senate Panel's Oil Tax Half What Carter Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  The Senate Finance Committee all but completed action today on the revenueproducing provisions of the windfall profits tax, with its anticipated proceeds fall. ing far short of what President Carter is seeking to finance his energysufficiencv oroeram.

title: A New High for Disco in Toronto's Tower
description: TORONTO, Oct. 9 For triree years finis city has laid claim to the highest freestanding structure in the world, an 1,815foot concrete spike looming so far above downtown that the ton often disappears in the clouds.

title: CREDIT MARKETS In Rates Soar,. FixedIncome Issues Fall
description: Interest rates soared, prices of fixedincome securities plunged and several major debt offerings were postponed yesterday in the first full business session since the Federal Reserve's latest credit restrictions were imposed late last Saturday.

title: BRITISH TRY TO SAVE PARLEY ON RHODESIA
description: LONDON, Oct. 9  The British Foreign Secretary, trying to avoid a breakup of the conference on the future of Zimbabwe Rhodesia, appealed to the guerrilla leaders today to reconsider their rejection of his proposals for a new constitution.

title: Stake: Potholes, a City Official's Longtime Dream
description: ELINOR GUGGENHEIMER, the former Commissioner of New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs, has worked in a multitudinous number of areas of public life, with, up to now, the notable exception of the theater. But just as John V. Lindsay was stagestruck, Mrs. Guggenheimer, so it would seem, has had a secret desire to write a musical comedy. The result, Potholes, opened last night at the Cherry Lane Theater.

title: Rhodesian Job Gives Floridian New Life at 71
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, Oct. 5  As he tells it, Harold P. Auslander has always been something of a maverick, so he is not that surprised to find himself, at the age of 71, starting over in Salisbury.

title: Aga Khan Searches for Islamic Architecture's Roots
description: THE Aga Khan is 42 years old, slightly portly and impeccably dressed; he was educated at Harvard, and is the owner of an immense estate outside Paris, a collection of racehorses and a lavish resort in Sardinia. What is preoccupying him right now, however, is not the fortunes of his stables or his real estate, but the problems of Islamic architecture, which has been severely buffeted by the deluge of Western money that Middle East oil has brought.

title: Man Seized in Rome As He Tries to Deliver Letter From Sindona
description: ROME, Oct. 9 (UPI)  A messenger was arrested here today trying to deliver letters from Michele Sindona, the missing financier, and his alleged kidnappers.

title: City Opera Gears Up; Musicians Ready to Vote
description: The New York City Opera started preparing yesterday for the resumption of its season tomorrow night, confident that its orchestra musicians would ratify the tentative contract agreed upon by negotiators early yesterday morning. The ratification meeting is set for 11 A.M. tomorrow at the New York State Theater.

title: Lights Go Out Throughout Israel After a Short Circuit at Tel Aviv
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 9 (AP)  Electricity went out throughout Israel today as a result of a short circuit at a Tel Aviv power station, officials said.

title: Stars ReSign Miss Gwyn, Acquire Another Center
description: In separate transactions, the New York Stars of the Women's Basketball League have resigned Althea Gwyn, their 6foot2inch allpro center, and acquired Gail Tatterson, 61 allstar center for the New Jersey Gems last season. Miss Tatterson was a free agent.

title: Dance: Three Premieres From Jennifer Muller
description: THEY bounce, they run, they jog, they fling. Jennifer Muller's choreography is nothing if not controlled abandon. Last night, Miss Muller and her dance company, the Works, opened a weeklong season at the City Center55th Street Theater, their first appearance in New York in a year.

title: Bank Rate In Canada Rises to 13%
description: TORONTO, Oct. 9  The Bank of Canada today announced an increase in its official lending rate  the equivalent of the Federal Reserve Board's discount rate to 13 percent, a historic high here.

title: Bank Earnings
description: bAfter unrealized foreign exchange losses of S4.7 million In current quarter and and $6.1 million in yearago period. cAfter unrealized foreign exchange losses of S7.3 million this year and S9.5 million a year earlier.

title: Sniper Who Paralyzed Central San Francisco Found Hanged in Cell
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9 (UPI)  A sniper who paralyzed downtown San Francisco for 23 hours while holding a hostage hanged himself today in his jail cell with a twisted mattress cover, the police said.

title: White House Is Firm in Support of Hamilton Jordan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  After some indecision, the Carter White House appears to have decided that a strong offense is the best tactic against the political ramifications of charges that Hamilton Jordan used cocaine.

title: Deaths
description: SCHECHTMANSandy, beloved husband of Marlene. Devoted father of Jane and Robert. Loving brother of Ralph. Services Thursday,12:45PM at The Riverside 180 W. 76 St,NY.

title: Fort Dix Gets a Reprieve For a Year to 18 Months
description: TRENTON, Oct. 10  The Army Training Center at Fort Dix will remain open for at least 12 to 18 months longer, Clifford L. Alexander, Secretary of the Army. announced today.

title: Music: Moscow Pops
description: THANKS to the astuteness, energy and longevity of the late Arthur Fiedler, the word Pops, when associated with music in this country, came to stand for easytolistento symphonic concerts featuring an international mix of classical, operetta and pop selections performed by the Boston Pops Orchestra or one of its imitators.

title: About Hillsdale
description: HILLSDALE, N.Y.  Route 22 is rustic ribbon that Jogs leisurely northward hugging the eastern New York State border. At this hamlet, little more than a hundred miles north of the Bronx, it comes as no surprise to see horses, cows and cornstalks in settings of breathtaking rural splendor.

title: Bank Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. ( N ) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10  A Colorado computerproducts company said today that it had proposed a merger with the Memorex Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif. However, Memorex's chairman, Robert C. Wilson, said he would recommend rejection of the proposal to his board of directors.

title: E.P.A. PLANS A DRIVE ON SEWAGE CLEANUP
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 10  Officials of the Environmental Protection Agency today announced plans to crack down on communities throughout the country, numbering possibly in the thousands, that have dragged their feet on cleaning up their sewage discharges.

title: Budget Chief Says 1981 Outlay May Top $600 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10  James T. McIntyre Jr., the Federal budget director, said today that President Carter's next budget, the one on which he is expected to run for reelection, was likely to exceed $600 billion unless there were some cuts in nonmilitary programs.

title: Buzzing Near U. N. Sets Editors To Asking What Is a News Story
description: Can a publicity stunt be a genuine news story?

title: More to the Bugattis Than Legendary Cars
description: LONDON, Oct. 10  Bugatti means cars to most people, but the family name first achieved fame with Carlo Bugatti, the designer of flamboyant furniture. Carlo begat Ettore, the automobile designer, and Rembrandt, a successful sculptor of animal bronzes who committed suicide at the age of 30.

title: World News Briefs
description: STRASBOURG, France, Oct. 10 (Reuters)  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel today criticized European governments that have not fully backed his country's peace treaty with Egypt.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY OE TELEPHONED TO 3544900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 34900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 94300; NASSAU CO. (516) 747.0500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3497767.

title: Knicks Drop Gondrezick, Rudd
description: The Knicks placed further emphasis on their rebuilding movement yesterday by putting Glen Gondrezick and John Rudd on waivers.

title: Talmadge Accuser Gets 4 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)  Daniel Minchew, a former aide to Senator Herman E. Talmadge and his chief accuser in the investigation of the Georgia Democrat, received a fourmonth prison term today for submitting a false $2,289 expense voucher to the Senate.

title: Hot Air Balloon Falls 2,000 Feet, Killing 2, Before Shocked Crowd
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 10 (UPI)  A hot air balloon buffeted by winds caught fire and plummeted 2,000 feet to earth today, killing two balloonists as horrified spectators watched.

title: 15,000 Flee Cambodia To Thailand in Shelling
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 10 (AP) About 15,000 Cambodians fled into Thailand to escape a Vietnamese mortar and artillery attack today as the Phnom Penh regime conceded that more than half the nation's population was in danger of starving.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: VERTICAL storage items allow one to take advantage of tall, narrow spaces. For wine and liquor bottles, there is a hanging rack from Spanek Company, made of chromed steel, that holds six bottles. The rack is a steel rod with loops coming out of it that suspend bottles at a slight tilt to keep the corks from drying out. The rod has a hook at the top and bottom to enable several racks to be joined together, and to suspend the rack from the ceiling. Each wine rack is 20 inches high, so most rooms could accommodate three raCKS vertically. The chrome rack costs $20 and is available at Bloomingdale's and First Stop Housewares, 1025 Second Avenue. Abraham & Straus has it painted black, for $15.

title: Frenzy Marks Stock, Bond Trading
description: In a severe break that dealers de-scribed as one of the worst in market memory, bond prices sank yesterday and some interest rates soared to unprecedented levels in active, nervous trading.

title: Where to Get Scores on Series
description: Scores of World Series games will be available during the game from the New York Telephone Company at 9991313. The final scores will be carried at that number for several hours after the game.

title: Plea Entered in Death of Girl
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 10 (AP)  A 19yearold man pleaded not guilty today to a charge of aggravated vehicular homicide stemming from the traffic death of the 9yearold daughter of Lieut. Gov. George V. Voinovich. George S. Horacek of Seven Hills, who entered his plea in Municipal Court, was charged with the death of Molly Voinovich.

title: Silver Ornaments Stolen from Synagogue Scrolls
description: Irving Pinhas, left, and Solomon D. Altchek of Sephardic Jewish Center in Forest Hills looking at torath strewn on floor after burglars stole their silver ornaments. Value of items was put at $40,000. Vandals forced window to enter.

title: 7 Seized on S. L In a Raid on Site Of Toxic Wastes
description: Seven persons were arrested yesterday as 40 state policemen and environmental specialists swarmed onto a tank farm on Staten Island, where millions of gallons of toxic wastes and possibly explosive chemicals were reportedly being stored illegally. Charges against those arrested included violating city and state environmental and fire laws.

title: Sindona Letter Intercepted in Italy Urges Speedy Talks on His Release
description: ROME, Oct. 10  The Italian police have intercepted a letter allegedly sent from Michele Sindona, the missing Italian financier, telling his lawyer that his health has deteriorated and that negotiations for his release should be expedited.

title: Sports Today
description: World Series, second game, Orioles vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Baltimore. (Television Channel 7, 8:30 P.M. Radio  WCBS, 8:30 P.M.)

title: Market Place
description: DURING the bull market of the 1950's and early 1960's, customers of Merrill Lynch were often content to leave their idle cash in the firm's free credit balances without drawing a penny of interest. If a customer later reinvested his funds, an interest payment of 1 percent was credited for this amount to his account.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table in Business Day yesterday gave an incorrect date for a 26.99point decline in the Dow Jones Industrial average in 1974. It occurred on Jan. 9.

title: Senate Unit Studies Aid To Chrysler
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10  The Senate Banking Committee opened three days of hearings today on the merits of granting Federal assistance to the financially ailing Chrysler Corporation amid growing indications that Congress might not act on the matter at all this year.

title: H.E.W. OFFERS GUIDE ON BAKKE DECISION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10  The Federal Government told the nation's colleges and universities today that they could establish numerical goals to increase minority enrollment without violating the Supreme Court's ban on strict racial or ethnic quotas in admissions.

title: ESSAY The John Hour
description: The Mayor of New York, eager to prove how ardent a feminist he can be, announced this week that men convicted of patronizing prostitutes would have their names broadcast over the cityowned radio station, WNYC.

title: Waterfront Executive Says Delivery Union Chief Demanded Payoffs
description: Walter D. O'Hearn Jr., president of the McGrath Services Corporation, testified yesterday that he had made illegal payoffs that were allegedly demanded by Douglas LaChance, president of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union of New York.

title: B.P. Adds to Sohio Stock
description: LONDON, Oct. 10 (Reuters)  The British Petroleum Company's interest in the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) has risen to 33.1 percent from 52 percent on Dec. 31, following a rise in Sohio's share of Alaskan North Slope oil production to 600,000 barrels a day, after royalties, a B.P. spokesman said. He noted that 53.1 percent was the maximum under B.P.'s 1970 takeover agreement with Sohio.

title: ARCHBISHOP LEO BINZ
description: ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 10 (AP)  Retired Archbishop Leo Binz, former head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of St. Paul and Minneapolis, died yesterday in Maywood, Ill. He was 78 years old.

title: Bear, Stearns Is Penalized
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)  Two California brokers were disciplined today by the Securities and Exchange Commission for their roles in failing to alert customers to the real risks in trading transactions.

title: News Summary
description: Senate debate on the arms treaty with the Soviet Union may begin about Nov. 1, according to the majority leader, Senator Robert C. Byrd. But there is still doubt about the schedule for committee and floor debate. Senate Republicans expressed doubt that there were enough votes to approve the treaty even though the Administration pledged to provide an outline of future military spending plans before the Senate vote. [Page Al, Columns 23.]

title: Rangers Win on 4 in Third, 63
description: TORONTO, Oct. 10  For two periods tonight, the New York Rangers and the Toronto Maple Leafs played exhibition hockey, sluggish and sloppy, with only flashes of the kind of play that makes these two clubs among the most respected in the National Hockey League.

title: Russian, Russian,
description: MUNICH, West Germany  At a time when ethnic and linguistic minorities in disparate parts of the world  Kurds in the Middle East, Basques and Catalans in Spain, and Bretons in France  are asserting their rights against dominant majorities, the Soviet Union is aiming at linguistic uniformity in its multinational community, in which about 130 languages are spoken.

title: L.I. Gunman Holds 8 Women Hostage for 41/2 Hours
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 10  A former town employee armed with a shotgun and distraught over being unable to qualify for an apartment in a housing complex held eight female employees hostage in the Town Clerk's office for four and a half hours tonight before releasing them unharmed and surrendering to the police after being assured that his family would have a place to live.

title: McEnroe Subdues Vilas
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 10 (AP)  John McEnroe, the United States Open champion, scored a 76, 62 victory over Guillermo Vilas of Australia today in the Super Challenge tennis tournament at Festival Hall.

title: Money
description: Prime Rote:13-14 Discount rate:12. Broker call loan rate:14

title: Senator Byrd Now Expects to Start Arms Treaty Debate About Nov. 1
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10  The Senate majority leader said today that he hoped to be ready to begin debate on the strategic arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union by about Nov.!, and the Carter Administration promised to give Congress an outline of future military spending plans before the Senate votes on the pact.

title: Dance: The Takei Light
description: LIGHT may never end. Light may just go on and on, always harsh, always cold this particular Light being the monumental work that Kei Takei, a Japaneseborn modern dancer, has been choreographing since 1969.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: Article 3 -- No Title

title: Unger Goes to Flames
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 10 (AP)  The Atlanta Flames of the National Hockey League signed Garry Unger, who was a free agent, to a multiyear contract today, enabling him to compete in the Flames season opener in Quebec and continue his record streak of consecutive games played.

title: Snow, Rain, Fog and Waterspouts Combine in a Rare Day
description: Autumn storms swept through the New York metropolitan area yesterday, spinning out a freakish combination of thick fog, rain and the season's first snowfalls in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: NEW BILL WOULD AID VIETNAM VETERANS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10  A major legislative effort to assist Vietnam veterans was announced today by a bipartisan Congressional group who urged broader assistance in employment, health care and education benefits to men and women who served in the Vietnam war.

title: Beathe
description: DRAKENathaniel (Nell). 68, formerly of New York City and retired from the Consulting Firm of Drake, Sheehan, Stewart, Dougall of New York City. Passed away October 9, 1979 in Miami, Florida. Member Princeton Club of New York. Brother of Philip W. Drake, East Dennis, Massachusetts and Mrs. W.C. Hughi, Grosse Pointe, Michigan. Funeral service and burial 2PM Friday, under direction Joseph B. Cofer Funeral Home, 10931 N.E. 6th Avenue, Miami, Florida. Omit flowers and make contributions to National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Andrew J. Melton Jr., the 59yearold president of the Dean Witter Reynolds Organization, has been elected to the additional posts of chairman and chief executive officer. He succeeds William M. Witter, 56, who resigned for personal reasons and who will become honorary chairman.

title: Record Volume Buffets Back Offices
description: Brokerage house employees were buffeted by an avalanche of orders yesterday as trading on the New York Stock Exchange soared to a record 81.6 million shares.

title: G.M. Loses $2.4 Million Case
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 10 (AP)  A former Houston steelworker who suffered brain damage 14 years ago when his 1962 Corvair went out of control and turned over won a $2.4 million judgment from the General Motors Corporation today. The Texas Supreme Court upheld a Houston jury verdict in favor of Harold L. Bryant, 48 years old. The jury found the right rear suspension of Mr. Bryant's car was defectively designed and manufactured.

title: Design Notebook
