description: THE word attic means the story above the cornice of a classical facade and refers to the room within the framework of the roof. Whatever its purpose or interior design, the attic has always offered an ideal place for seeking solitude, removed as it is from the mainstream of family life.

title: Troy Decides to Enter Guilty Plea, Averting GrandLarceny Trial
description: Matthew J. Troy Jr., once one of New York City's most powerful politicians, pleaded guilty to grand larceny yesterday just before he was to go on trial.

title: Deaths
description: BISHOPEdith L. Beloved wife of Charles, devoted mother of Barbara a MacLean and Charles Jr. and the late Richard. Adored grandmother of Lynn, Rebecca, Michael and Katherine Bishop, Andrew and Scott MacLean. Memorial service Rossmor Community Church, Rossmor, Jamesburg, N.J. 2pm Monday, October 15. Please omit flowers. Contributions to the American Cancer Society will be appreciated.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Panic selling by small investors swamped the New York Stock Exchange and sent volume to a recordbreaking 81.6 million shares. But the market's losses were trimmed when cashrich pension funds and other large investors began bargainhunting. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down only 8.27 points at 849.32, although it had been down almost 25 points at one point. People were scared by the moves by the Federal Reserve this weekend, and no one knows what's going to happen next, said Nathan Gantcher, head of sales for Oppenheimer & Company. [Page Al.]

title: Mrs. Thatcher Weathers a Tory Storm Over Rhodesia
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 10  The Conservative Party's annual conference today weathered the threat of a debilitating split over Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Zimbabwe Rhodesia policy, but only after an outbreak of heckling and recriminations that shattered the usual decorum of Tory gatherings.

title: Bridge:
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 10  After scoring the maximum points in the first two rounds of the world team championship, the American players ran into trouble here today and lost to Australia by 30 international match points, worth 155 in victory points to the Australians.

title: Arizona Delay in Taking Atom Plant Is Explained
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 10 (AP)  Gov. Bruce E. Babbitt of Arizona knew of the potential for release of lethal radioactive tritium from a factory two weeks before he declared an emergency and ordered a state takeover of the plant, his executive assistant confirmed today.

title: Iran to Increase Caviar Prices
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 10 (UPI)  Iran announced yesterday that it would raise the price of the caviar it exports by 6 to 10 percent in an effort to increase its foreign exchange earnings. The best Iranian caviar now sells in New York for about $250 a Russian pound. The Russian pound contains only 14 ounces.

title: Groundskeeper Wins the Battle
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 10  The battle against the elements in the World Series began at 7 o'clock this morning when Pat Santarone, chief groundskeeper for the Baltimore Orioles, drove to work in Memorial Stadium from his home in suburban Jacksonville, Md., and found it was snowing like hell.

title: Deaths
description: KRAN ISMary. Beloved wife of the late Sol, cherished mother of Myron and Janet, devoted motherInlaw of Celina and Marvin. Adored grandmother of Richard and Ellen, loving sister of Jack, Anne, Sam, Cella and the late Sophie and David.

title: HEATING OIL TARGET FOR WINTER IS MET, A CARTER AIDE SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10  The Carter Administration has met its goal of increasing stockpiles of home heating oil and diesel fuel to 240 million barrels, virtually guaranteeing that there will be no shortage in supplies of the vital fuels this winter, according to a senior member of the White House staff.

title: Sound
description: AUDIO designers are argumentative. Maybe it's the natural byproduct of their passionate interest, but they always seem to be debating, and the technical nature of the discussion doesn't always prevent some vigorous twisting of logic. At times, the discourse of audio engineers recalls the style of medieval scholastics in hairsplitting abstruseness. But luckily their highflown theorizing often leaves a mundane residue in the form of workable hardware, making the musicminded listeners the ultimate beneficiary of all this fervent disputation.

title: Other U. S. and Foreign Stock Exchanges WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1979
description: FFinancial Times. iii Sole. dDow Jones. sSwiss Bank Corporation. nTokyo new. oTokyo old.

title: Screen: 'The Young Girls of Wilko,' From Poland:A Dark Comedy
description: WIKTOR, the hero of Andrzej Wajda's fine new comedy, "The Young Girls of Wilko," is as exasperating as he is appealing. He's the kind of man who, in all seriousness, regrets that everything that has passed can be seen only in hindsight. He demands the impossible so that he can reject the possible. Having fought on the Russian front during World War I, he dates his alienation from that time of horror, yet it becomes increasingly clear during "The Young Girls of Wilko" that Wiktor has always been slippery in his relations with those he loves. Foremost among these are the five surviving sisters of the six he once courted before the war, discreetly, during lazy summer vacations in the country.Now, after 15 years of absence, Wiktor returns to Wilko. The death of a friend in Warsaw has prompted him to question his own life. Though in his late 30's, Wiktor (Daniel Olbrychski) is still a handsome man. He's trim, fair-haired and has the heavily lidded eyes that often suggest he has mysterious longings when he's really nothing more than bored, detached from the immediate scene.Wiktor's detachment, which even he is beginning to suspect is a certain emptiness, still fires the hearts of the once-young girls of Wilko who, by chance, are all at their country estate when he walks in one evening unannounced. All except Tunia, the youngest, have married, if none too happily. Julia, plump and sweetly pretty in the way that suggests she was ravishing as a girl, is married to the estate manager, a crass, opportunistic man whom Chekhov might have created; Yola is married to a Warsaw businessman from whom she is separated and who writes letters to her that read like official memorandums ("Please be advised that . . ."), while Zosia is the wife of a diplomat who is away most of the time.The girls have not done especially well but they have one another, their children, their elderly mother and an ordered existence.As "The Young Girls of Wilko" proceeds in its beautifully circuitous way, Wiktor takes up with each of the sisters, in turn, as, it is apparent, he did many years earlier. The virginal Tunia, who was a small child when he was last there, becomes the surrogate for the missing sister whose death, we come to understand, Wiktor caused without knowing it. It's also apparent that Wiktor has loved them all, as a unit, together, as if each were a different aspect of the same person, much in the way that Antoine Doinel, as a youth, used to fall in love with a nice, middle-class family unit consisting of the girl, her mother and her father."The Young Girls of Wilko," which will be shown at the New York Film Festival in Lincoln Center today at 9:30 P.M. and tomorrow at 6:15 P.M., is one of the wisest, most civilized comedies in a long time. Although it is quite different in tone from "Without Anesthesia," Mr. Wajda's political drama seen at the festival earlier this week, both films are about extremely complex relationships that reveal themselves in subtle ways beyond the reach of most film makers.It was a canny festival decision to show the two films more or less back-to-back. Mr. Wajda, after making a brilliant splash here in the late 1950's and 60's with "Generation," "Kanal" and "Ashes and Diamonds," has recently not received the attention he deserves. Not all of the later films have been equally good, though the director who made them always exhibited the same talent. Lately his reputation has been that of someone who makes political films so disguised (and sometimes edited) that Polish authorities cannot take offense. This, however, is to underrate the gifts that are abundantly evident in "The Young Girls of Wilko."Among other things, Mr. Wajda is terrifically good with actors. Two of the best performances you're likely to see this year are those of Mr. Olbrychski (who had the lead in Mr. Wajda's elegant "Landscape After Battle") as Wiktor in "Wilko" and of Zbigniew Zapasiewicz in "Without Anesthesia." (Mr. Zapasiewicz also appears in "Wilko" as the estate manager.) In addition, "The Young Girls of Wilko" features a string of superlative performances by the actresses who play the unlucky sisters, especially the one by Christine Pascal, the French actress, as the beautiful Tunia.Though "The Young Girls of Wilko" is a dark comedy about a man who, in the description of one of the sisters, appears to have wilted, it leaves one feeling invigorated, almost like new. Such are the astonishments of art.

title: Indonesia Frees 2,000 Prisoners Held Since Coup Attempt in 1965
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 10  The Government released 2,000 prisoners from the prison island of Bum today. Many of them had been held without trial for 13 years.

title: COMMODITIES Gold and Silver Futures Score Limit Advances
description: While gold and silver futures scored limit advances again yesterday and prices of longterm financial contracts crumbled, most other commodities responded largely to their particular market influences.

title: Calendar: Antiques Show
description: Antiques Show and Sale, New Jersey State Museum, 205 West State Street, Trenton, N.J.

title: I.B.M. Debt Issue Ends in Huge Loss
description: The International Business Machines Corporation's $1 billion financing, begun with such fanfare last week, ended yesterday with the largest underwriting loss in Wall Street's history. Investment bankers estimated that the overall loss may have run as high as $30 million.

title: Blue Cross to Test Expanded Coverage for Drug Abuse
description: A federally financed $1 million experiment to determine whether to include comprehensive drug abuse treatment and therapy in ordinary health insurance benefits was announced yesterday by the nation's Blue Cross plans.

title: I.M.F. Gold Brings $412.78 an Ounce
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)Gold sold for an average $412.78 an ounce at the International Monetary Fund's monthly auction, the agency announced today.

title: Associated Press
description: OPENER: Nell Komadoski (20) of Blues checked Jere Gillis of Canucks as they pursued loose puck during opening game of N.H.L. season Tuesday night in Vancouver. Blues defeated Canucks, 52.

title: Nationalists on Taiwan Mark 68th Year of Republic
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 10  For the first time since the United States withdrew its diplomatic recognition, the Chinese Nationalists on Taiwan celebrated their national day today, placing renewed emphasis on selfreliance.

title: Syncopate First In Boojum Cap
description: Elmendorf Farm's Syncopate charged from last place in a field of six horses to win the $53,950 Boojum Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: Associated Press
description: EARLY SNOWS BLANKET THE EAST COAST: In Harrisonburg, Va., police officers helped a snowbound motorist yesterday as that town was paralyzed by more than eight inches. Surprise snowfalls along the Eastern Seaboard from Maine to Virginia caused power interruptions, shut schools and briefly threatened start of the World Series in Baltimore, postponed once because rain. In many areas, it was the earliest recorded snow.

title: Psychiatrist Rejects Public View That Cult Survivors Are Crazy
description: After the interviews with the police and the reporters and after the television cameras had finally been shut off, those who survived Jonestown began quietly trying to find a place in American society.

title: Industrial Design As the True Modern Art
description: THE was born in Cardiff, Wales, in 1951. When he was 17, Stephen Bayley wanted to become an architect. Instead he studied art history for three years in absolute misery, finally deciding that he was most interested in modern design. Encouraged by Lord Reilly, an eminent design spokesman, he decided to write a textbook. The underlying theme of the book, Mr. Bayley said, is that a lot of modern design is more rewarding than modern art. It is refrigerators, typewriters, cars, pens, shavers, television sets, lamps, hair dryers, and telephones  the functional objects of contemporary everyday life  that Mr. Bayley celebrates as industrial design as the legitimate art of the 20th century. His book, In Good Shape: Style in Industrial Products 1900 to 1960, has just been published by the Design Council in England. An American paperback edition (Van Nostrand Reinhold, $12.95) will be available here later this month. Now Mr. Bayley is working on a new book on the Albert Memorial, and looking into the feasibility of an international center for the study of design.

title: Sadat Reported to Fault Lavish Life of the Saudis
description: CAIRO, Oct. 10  President Anwar elSadat was quoted today as having said that Saudi Arabia was experiencing popular resentment over the lavish life style of its ruling family.

title: Judge Bars Bid for Doctor's File In Trial of Sex Slayings Suspect
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (Reuters)  Judge Louis Garippo decided Tuesday against handing over to prosecutors extensive notes made by a defense psychiatrist in 65 hours of interviews with John Wayne Gacy, who goes on trial in January on charges of murdering 33 boys and young men.

title: Howard Johnson Sale Hits a Snag
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 10 (AP)  A California liquor law may stand in the way of the proposed $630 million sale of the Howard Johnson hotelrestaurant chain to a British brewery, a state lawyer said today.

title: U.S., in a New Use of Law, Cites Plant for Fertility Risk
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10  The Government, in its first action to protect worker fertility and the health of the unborn under the occupational health and safety law, today cited the American Cyanamid Company for violations of health standards at a plant in Willow Island, W.Va.

title: 2 in Nationalist Party Seized in Plot to Bomb An Elementary School
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 10 (UPI)Two brothers, both leaders of the American White Nationalist Party, were arrested today hours before they allegedly planned to bomb an elementary school attended by the 12yearold daughter of the Federal judge who had ordered the desegregation of the Columbus schools.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have an old bed with a high headboard and I usually lean my head against this when I read in bed. The spot where I rest my head has taken on a cloudy, milkygray appearance. There are several other cloudy spots  all small, and all in places I do not habitually touch. The wood is stained a dark color, something like a mahagony. Can you suggest how to restore the uniform dark color without sanding down and refinishing the whole headboard?C.C., New York City.

title: Artist Creates a Garden for Ward's Island
description: GARDENING is an attempt at breeding order out of chaos. Viewed in this light, the graceful terraced garden of flowers, rock and sculpture on Wards Island is close to a masterwork. For the original project seemed to have nothing going for it.

title: Western Governors Fear Plunder Of Region's Rich Energy Stocks
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 10 President Carter's meeting here tonight with Western governors came against a backdrop of heightened fears that the West will become an energy colony of the rest of the country.

title: New York Thanks Congress With a Gala
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10New Yorkers threw a gala tonight to thank Congress for helping the city survive its financial crisis, and so many Representatives and Senators clamored for so many of the scarce tickets that the party's headquarters looked like the box office of a Broadway hit the morning after opening night.

title: Court Backs Bank's Rules
description: ALBANY, Oct. 10  The New York State Court of Appeals has ruled unani, mously here that regulations of the Dime Savings Bank in Manhattan requiring nine days to clear a local check and 21 days to clear an outoftown check are legal.

title: NBC Reveals Transcript Of Kissinger's Interview
description: NBC News released yesterday what it said was the complete and unedited transcript of a 52minute interview with Henry A. Kissinger conducted by David Frost on Oct. 3. It concerns the Nixon Administration's Cambodian policies.

title: New Look on Corporate Boards
description: The changing of the guard on corporate boards is not going entirely according to script.

title: Tampering Effort Seen In Jersey Murder Case
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 10 What appeared to be an attempt at jury tampering by mail developed here today in the murder trial of Robert R. Reldan, a 39yearold house painter accused of strangling two women four years ago.

title: For Consumer, Tighter Money Has Two Faces
description: It may take a while, but the new antiinflation program announced by the Federal Reserve Board over the weekend going to hit consumers wallets.

title: Changing Wheels at the M.T.A.
description: Harold Fisher, an attorney intimately acquainted with many of New York's political leaders, has resigned as the parttime chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. His replacement had been urged by the City Club and others who found him too remote from the lowly problems of the subways. Clearly, the M.T.A has troubles. But we doubt that they were primarily caused by Mr. Fisher. Most of all, they stem from a fallacy in the M.T.A. charter: the nave hope that passenger rail lines, even in a highdensity region like New York, can cover all their operating costs with the money they collect from fares.

title: Technology
description: FIRST it was the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation, then the Mostek Corporation, both frontranking semiconductor companies.

title: Stage: From Britain, Once a Catholic
description: ONCE a Catholic is twice a bore. Mary O'Malley's British comedy, now installed at the Helen Hayes, is neither play nor parody but a halfhearted, structurally haphazard, stab at making total recall somewhat funny. I say somewhat funny because, as Miss O'Malley remembers the obtuse nuns and automated priests and woefully undereducated fellowpupils of her childhood, she's never quite certain how much of a comic strip she intends her satirical salute to the grim convent school days of 1952 to be. She is, I think, a bit tonedeaf.

title: VOLUME 81.6 MILLION
description: Panic selling by many small investors swamped the New York Stock Exchange yesterday following two days of sharp drops in stock prices and violent jumps in interest rates.

title: Harding, at Liberals Dinner, Formalizes His Role as Party's. Leader
description: The man who has quietly taken control of the Liberal Paarty over the last few years, Raymond B. Harding, publicly proclaimed his leadership role last night and said it was time for liberal politicians to become stubborn.

title: Adolescence Poses A Hurdle for Adults
description: ADOLESCENCE can often be diagnosed by inappropriateness of dress, inability to comprehend reason and a determination to turn the brain to jelly by bombarding it with raucous noises. One symptom, however, is incontrovertible Proof the Stage has arrived.

title: U.S. and I.B.M. Meet Over Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti has held his first meeting with lawyers for the International Business Machines Corporation in an effort to seek settlement of the Government's 10yearold antitrust suit against the computer giant.

title: It's Much Too Cold For Summer Game
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 10  Now it can be told. Bowie Kuhn is not only commissioner, but he is also a magician. By allowing the World Series to open tonight, he turned baseball into iceball. Although the temperature at gametime in Memorial staaium was announced at 41 degrees, the Pittsburgh Pirates handled the ball in the first inning as if it were an ice cube. Bruce Kison, their starting pitcher, couldn't put it in the strike zone often enough. Phil Garner, their second baseman, tossed a doubleplay grounder onto the soggy outfield grass. And then Doug DeCinces of the Baltimore Orioles hit one of Bruce Kison's few strikes into the leftfield bleachers for a threerun homer and a 50 lead, the most runs ever scored in the first inning of first game in World Series history.

title: Peat, Marwick Vote For Chairman a Surprise
description: The partners of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co. issued a stunning rebuff yesterday to the outgoing chairman, Walter E. Hanson; and his handpicked choice for a successor, Charles H. Davison, by passing over Mr. Davison and electing Thomas L. Holton as the top executive in the nation's largest accounting concern.

title: Louisiana Teachers Ratify Pact
description: METAIRIE, La., Oct. 10 (UPI)  Jefferson Parish teachers formally ratified a new twoyear contract today, ending the longest teacher strike in the nation this year. About 98 percent of the teachers voted to approve the contract. Their strike lasted 26 days.

title: CHESTER FRENCH, 71; FORMER EXXON AIDE
description: Chester 0. French, a longtime Exxon Corporation official who helped create advanced electronic homing missiles for the Army Air Force during World War II and assisted in the first reconstruction of German V1 and V2 buzz bombs, died yesterday at the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Weston, Conn.

title: Carter Opens Western Swing in Bid For Backing on Energy and Politics
description: ALBUQUERQUE, Oct. 10 President Carter met here tonight with 10 Western Governors to assure them that his new energy program would not usurp their authority over the water and natural resources in their states.

title: John N. Brown, 79, an ExAssistant Navy Secretary
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10  John Nicholas Brown, a former Assistant Secretary of the Navy and a member of one of Rhode Island's leading families, died last night of an apparent heart attack aboard his yacht in Annapolis, Md. He was 79 years old and was a resident of Providence.

title: Mental Test Is Ordered For Pilot in U.N. Stunt
description: Robert Baudin, whose airborne publicity stunt prompted the evacuation of the United Nations Building and a 27story Manhattan building occupied by a book publisher, was held in $25,000 bail yesterday and ordered to undergo a psychiatric examination.

title: ABROAD AT HOME Hope For Rhodesia
description: BOSTON, Oct. 10  The London Conference on Rhodesia, now a month old, is at a moment of peril. But it still offers reason for hope  the best hope Rhodesia has had for a very long time. Consider what has been achieved in London.

title: Snow White Getting Ready for Music Hall's Stage
description: SEVERAL floors above the cavernous theater of the newly resurrected Radio City Music Hall, serious business was at hand: a witch was trying to get Snow White to eat a poisonous apple. Howwas not in costume except for a hideous mask, cackled in such a wonderfully horrible manner that onlookers laughed out loud, though they knew a The setting was, of course, a rehearsal studio, a long room with mirror and barre where the characters of Walt Disney's 1937 animated film classic, Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, were coming alive for a Radio City stage spectacular due to open next Thursday, run through Nov. 18 and then go on a national tour.

title: WagePrice Curbs Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (Reuters)Alfred E. Kahn, chairman of the President's Council of Wage and Price Stability, and the council's director, Robert Russell, said today that a recession would not solve the nation's high inflation rate and called for a continued effort by labor and management to voluntarily restrain wages and prices. They made their pleas in testimony before the House banking subcommittee.

title: Numb Hands Leave Pirates Out in Cold
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 10 Even after a hit, two walks, and a doubleplay ball that did not become a double play, the Pittsburgh Pirates had their chance to escape the first inning of the World Series without a Baltimore run.

title: Victim's Alleged Role in Drug Case Called Boon to Jacobson's Defense
description: The Bronx District Attorney's office suffered an apparent setback yesterday in the murder trial of Howard Jacobson, a former race horse trainer and Manhattan real estate entrepreneur, when it was disclosed that the man he is accused of killing had been named posthumously as an unindicted coconspirator in a multimilliondollar Federal narcotics case.

title: World Series Schedule
description: Oct. 10Baltimore 5, Pittsburgh 4.

title: Advertising
description: SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda, Oct. 10  Some of America's most important magazine publishers heard some very frank words today from some of the industry's top editors as the annual conference of the Magazine Publishers Association/American Society of Magazine Editors moved into its second day here. They also heard from the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, the American civil rights activist who had recently returned from the Middle East where he met with officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization and others.

title: American Upsets Masters In Pacific Tennis Classic
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Oct. 10 (AP)  A littleknown American, Matt Mitchell, defeated topseeded Geoff Masters of Australia today, 75, 62, in secondround match of the South Pacific Tennis Classic.

title: THOMAS J. M'BREEN 2D
description: NORTH BERGEN, N.J., Oct. 10 (AP)  Thomas J. McBreen 2d, a former news editor of The Dispatch in Union City, died today in Palisades General Hospital of stroke at the age of 63.

title: Expanding Space Up Into the Attic
description: NEW HAVEN ATREASURE is tucked away in the spacious attic of William and Lucille Celentano's Victorian home. It isn't hidden in grandma's trunk or lying unrecognized beneath accumulated dust. It's the attic area itself.

title: The Region
description: NEW HAVEN (AP)  A second consecutive day of cold rain and a heavy show of police force kept picketing under control yesterday at Olin Corporation as new workers were brought in to replace strikers.

title: Bokassa Order Sending Diamonds to Giscard Reported
description: PARIS, Oct. 10  Reports that the former ruler of the Central African Republic ordered 30 carats of diamonds sent to Valery Giscard d'Estaing were published today in French newspapers, and the opposition Socialist Party called for a parliamentary inquiry.

title: Touch O Speed Pays Track Record of $227.20
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Oct. 10 (UPI) Touch 0 Speed returned a track record $227.20 on a $2 win ticket today when he scored a halflength victory in the El Rio Rey Stakes at Santa Anita Park.

title: Windfall Tax Proposal Gets Added Exemptions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10  The Senate Finance Committee voted today to eAempt oil profits received by states, localities and public colleges and universities from the windfall profits tax, a move that will further reduce the dwindling proceeds of the levy by an estimated $4.5 billion or more over 11 years.

title: Japan's NoVerdict Election
description: Winston Churchill's epigram had it that democracy was the least satisfactory form of government, save for all the others. The latest Japanese election underscores his point. Prime Minister Ohira hoped to win an effective parliamentary majority for his conservative Government so that it could better cope in a world economy deformed by soaring oil prices and the foundering American dollar. He wound up with about the same number of seats he held before, hobbled by dependence on minority votes.

title: Notes on People
description: Pfc. Alexander Small of the Army was home on leave last Aug. 17, visiting relatives in the BedfordStuyvesant area of Brooklyn, when he spotted a burning building at 1293 Fulton Street. There was much confusion, with women and children screaming on the sidewalk. Firemen hadn't arrived. Private Small noticed a man at a thirdfloor window, holding an infant, and the man dropped the child into the soldier's arms. The infant was unhurt.

title: Tristate Commission Criticized at Hearing Called by Task Force
description: Local legislators, town planners ana citizens criticized what they called the bigcity orientation and insensitivity of the Tristate Regional Planning Commission yesterday before a gubernatorial task force considering whether to abolish, change or strengthen the commission.

title: F.B.I. IS LIBERALIZING DISCIPLINE OF AGENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)  William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, is liberalizing the bureau's long tradition of harsh punishment for agents who engage in sexual relationships outside marriage.

title: GiffordHill, Amcord Tie
description: GiffordHill & Company, a Dallasbased construction material concern, and Amcord Inc., a building products company with headquarters in Newport Beach, Calif., jointly announced yesterday that their boards had approved the previously announced proposed tender offer by GiffordHill for all of Amcord's common stock for $34 a share.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10 (AP)  The State Court of Appeal has ruled that people awaiting trial in jail are constitutionally protected from indiscriminate secret monitoring of their conversations with visitors.

title: Events Today
description: THE MOST HAPPY FELLA, book, lyrics and music by Frank Loesser, directed by Jack O'Brien, with Gior glo Tozzi, Sharon Daniels, Louise FlanIgam, Adrienne Leonetti, Richard Muenz and Dennh Warning, the Malestic Theater, 44th Street west of Broadway, 6:15.

title: The City
description: A $49.6 million issue of bonds of the New York City Housing Development Corporation has been given higher ratings by two independent financial agencies than the corporation received for any previous issue.

title: GOING OUT Gulde
description: RHAPSODIE ESPAGNOLE In Beethoven Symphony No. 9, one of Juan Gyenes's photographs in his new collection at the Spanish Institute, the strong, brooding countenance of the composer peers from a cloudbank over distant peaks. There is a dramatic, fulllength silhouette of the dancer Manuela Vargas frozen in motion. In 2,000 Years of Theater, a bird soars high above the pillar remnants of an ancient amphitheater.

title: Rome Thieves Get $4 Million
description: ROME, Oct. 10 (AP)  Five bandits broke into the apartment of Mordechai Fadlun, a jewel dealer, took him to his office and made off with 66 pounds of gold and gems the victim said were worth $4.2 million, the police reported today.

title: U.S. Pay Is Threatened by Impasse
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10  A SenateHouse impasse that threatens payless or reducedrate paydays for millions in the military and in Federal agencies intensified today as the Senate held firm against a Congressional pay increase and strict limits on Federal funds for abortions.

title: Explosions and Fire Sweep a Factory In Brooklyn, Killing One and Injuring
description: At least one textile worker was killed and two others were injured yesterday afternoon as a fire swept through a sixstory Brooklyn building. The blaze touched off a series of explosions that rocked the Fort Greene neighborhood and sent two dozen workers scurrying to the street.

title: Gold Climbs Sharply In London Trading
description: LONDON, Oct. 10  Gold leaped back above the $400 mark today as it became clear that Washington's weekend antiinflation package had neither restored broad confidence in currencies nor broken the recent speculative fever.

title: Stock Fall Squeezes Margin Accounts
description: Falling stock prices, along with the abrupt rise in interest rates, has created a dilemma for some of the nearly one million investors who maintian margin accounts at brokerage firms.

title: Deaths
description: CHASEKatherine T. of Clifton, NJ, on October 9, 1979, beloved daughter of the late Dr. Henry and Adelaide Truesdale Chase, devoted aunt of Mrs. Katherine Chase Higgins. Past Regent and 50 year member of Claveradc Chapter Daughters of the American Revolution. Funeral Friday, 10am, at St. Peter's Episcopal Church of Clifton, NJ. Visiting at the Mason and Porter Funeral Home, 470 Clifton Ave, Clifton, NJ, Thursday 24, 79pm.

title: Carter to Address Fund Dinner
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)  President Carter will address a $125aplate fundraising event for the District of Columbia Democratic Party on Saturday night. The annual dinner is held in memory of President Kennedy, Robert F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: At TKTS, It's SRO Despite H2O
description: It was matinee day yesterday and the first sign of it appeared during the morning in Duffy Square where two rainsodden queues began shaping up between 47th and 46th Streets waiting for the Times Square Theater Center, which calls itself TKTS, to start selling halfprice tickets.

title: Oil Price Register Expected
description: PARIS, Oct. 10  The United States and other oilconsuming countries intend to introduce next month a reporting procedure through which they hope to curb soaring energy costs, energy officials disclosed today. The plan is to identify buyers and sellers of oil at levels above the official world price.

title: Corporate Earnings UNITED TELECOMMUN.(O) WARNER ELEC BRAKE (O) WESTINGHOUSE ELEC (N) WINTER (JACK) (N)
description: DESOTO (N)

title: Deaths
description: QUEENANDoro thy A., (nee Ford) on Oct 9, 1979 loving wife of the late Reginald, devoted mother of Reginald Arthur, William Ford, Mrs. Teresa Frei, Mrs. Cecilia Holley, Mrs. Michelle Pisacano, Mrs. Susan Resate, also survived by thirteen grandchildren and a sister Mrs. Vera Jones. Reposing at the O.B. Davis Funeral Home, Nesconset. Highway (Route 347) Port Jefferson Station, NY. Visitation Thursday 25, 710pm. Funeral mass Friday, 11am St. Marks R.C. Church, Shoreham, NY. Interment 2pm, Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Birth Right of LI, 21 Chestnut St, Centerreach NY

title: The Architect's Role in Saving Energy
description: AN N awful lot of architects aren't responding at all to the energy crisis, said the architect John Cable, director of building systems at the United States Department of Energy.

title: Toronto Stocks Fall Along With Wall St
description: TORONTO, Oct. 10  The Toronto Stock Exchange, picking up the shock waves generated by sharply rising interest rates, again followed United States markets sharply downward today.

title: NeimanMarcus Plans Chicago Store
description: A 200,000squarefoot NeimanMarcus specialty store will occupy part of a 60story tower to be built on North Michigan Avenue, Chicago's fashion shopping area, it was announced. The $120 million project, scheduled to begin early next year, will also include condominiums and office space.

title: Nicaraguan Soldiers Arrest 120 In Drive on Somoza Sympathizers
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 10 (UPI)  Soldiers have arrested 120 people in weeklong campaign to root out sympathizers of the ousted President, Anastasio comnva nehav.

title: Higgins Novel Auctioned
description: Although hardcover rights to books are not usually sold at auction, Stein & Day has paid $605,000 for the rights to Jack Higgins's next novel, tentatively titled The Cretan Lover, in a threeday auction conducted by Claire Smith of Harold Ober Associates, the author's agent. Eight publishers participated. Mr. Higgins is the author of more than 20 thrillers, including The Eagle Has Landed and Storm Warning.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: THE least interesting person in Thomas Powers's splendid new book is Richard Helms himself. He was, for 30 years, a dedicated spook, a good soldier who took orders from one President at a time, someone so disadvantaged that he could not resign on principle and live on dividends. A compromiser who knew you have to go along to get along. He buckled no swashes. From his beginning in the Office of Strategic Services during World War II until the end in November 1972, when Richard M. Nixon dismissed him as Director of Central Intelligence for having been insufficiently loyal to the team that gave us Watergate, he opposed covert operations while doing almost exactly what he was told to do: the man in the empty suit.

title: Peak Rate Set For 1Year Bills; (000 omitted in dollar figures)
description: The Treasury auctioned oneyear bills yesterday at a record average rate of 11.508 percent, up from the previous high of 9.893 percent in the September sale.

title: Recital: Lilian Kaffir Plays Chopin Program
description: THAT familiar artifact, Chopin recital, was played by Lilian Kallir last night at the 92d Street Y. Building her program around the Bminor Sonata, Miss Kallir also played a pair of nocturnes, six mazurkas, the Fsharp Impromptu and the Aflat Ballade. tens to add. Emotion is held somewhat in reserve; the ground plan of the music is more important than its color; literalism supersedes imagination. The music stands bare, each strand distinct, without the washes of sound that should give it light and shade.

title: Volvo Will Sponsor Grand Prix of Tennis
description: Men's professional tennis solved its most immediate problem with the announcement yesterday that Volvo of America would pick up the sponsorship of the Grand Prix tournament, which is being dropped by Colgate after the Masters in New York in January.

title: Associated Press
description: PEKING, Oct. 10  More than 2,000 students from People's University staged a protest march and sitin in front of Communist Party headquarters here today to demand the withdrawal of an army artillery unit from their campus.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Oct. 10,1979

title: A Forlorn Jonestown Slumbers As Guyana Seeks Only to Forget
description: JONESTOWN, Guyana  Nearly a year after the deaths of more than 900 Americans here, the commune that Jim Jones built dozes quietly in the tropic sun.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Declines Sharply; Gold Passes $400 Again
description: The dollar fell sharply on foreign exchange markets at home and abroad yesterday as enthusiasm for the dollarsupport program announced last weekend waned and the price of gold soared back over the $400anounce level.

title: More Noranda Stock Bought by Brascan
description: TORONTO, Oct. 10 (AP)  Brascan Ltd. said today that it had bought an additional 250,000 shares of Noranda Mines Ltd. in a continuation of heavy buying that started last Friday when it acquired almost 9 million shares, or about 10 percent of the mining companv's outstanding common stock.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: 3 Near Crashes Over New York Prompt Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10  Federal officials are examining air traffic operations in the New York area following three recent incidents in which airliners came close to midair collisions.

title: Home Beat
description: MAYA Romanoff has earned a reputation as a textile innovator. But his floor cloths, his wall hangings in leather, canvas silk and velvet tapestry and the furniture he has had upholstered in patterned Chinese silk, leather or cotton suede are all meant to be used. Eight months ago, Gordon J. Davis, a friend from high school who is now New York City's Commissioner of Parks and Recreation, asked Mr. Romanoff to exhibit his work in the Arsenal, 830 Fifth Avenue. Mr. Romanoff went one step further and made a special piece to hang on the outside of the brick building, naming it Kimono. Made up of eight panels and measuring about 4,000 square feet, it combines several resistdye techniques. Designed to soften and dress up the structure, the panels are supposed to move in the wind and Mr. Romanoff (standing atop the building in the picture) hopes that they will change color because of exposure to the elements along with the surrounding leaves in Central Park. The textiles will be on exhibit at the Arsenal through Nov. 21. The show is open to the public, Monday through Friday, 9:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Admission is free.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Armco Inc., Middletown, Ohiobased steel producer and fabricator, has named Alvin J. Mistier a senior vice president and T.C. Rogers a group vice president.

title: Felt Forum Features Cup Boxing Tonight
description: An 11man boxing team that includes four Pan American Games champions will represent the United States starting tonight in a weeklong competition known as the World Cup championships. The event, which is being held for the first time, is looked upon as tuneup for next summer's Olympic Games in Moscow.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Edith Sampson, 1st Black Woman Elected to Bench in Illinois, Is Dead
description: Judge Edith Spurlock Sampson, 76 years old, the first black woman elected to the Illinois bench, died Monday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago.

title: A Warning To the Democrats
description: LOS ANGELES  Whatever the outcome of Saturday's prizeless political Armageddon in Florida  in which neither the October caucus elections nor the November state convention will choose a single delegate to the 1980 National Democratic Convention  it now seems highly probable that Senator Edward M. Kennedy will soon thereafter announce his decision to become a Presidential candidate.

title: Lebanon Acts to Halt Killings by Christians Among Rival Families
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 10  The Lebanese Government announced today that it was taking extra security measures in the country's northern region after the murder of five members of the family of a former President in a wave of kidnappings by rival Christian factions.

title: 2 Officers Shot, One in Harlem, Other in Bronx
description: Two police officers were shot yesterday, one while attempting to make an arrest in Harlem and the second while offduty and driving a taxi in the Bronx. Both were reported in stable condition.

title: U.S. Pledges $7 Million in Emergency Cambodian Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10  The United States will supply $7 million in emergency food and money to an international effort aimed at saving the lives of millions of Cambodians facing starvation, crate Denartment officials said today.

title: Dibley Beats Nastase
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 10 (AP)  Topseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania was eliminated from a professional tennis tourney today when Colin Dibley of Australia beat him, 76, 75, in the second round.

title: Philips and Pertec Sign Merger Accord
description: The North American Philips Corporation and the Pertec Computer Corporation announced the signing of a definitive agreement whereby Philips will acquire up to 45 percent of Pertec's common stock.

title: Morgan's 3Month Earnings Up 10.7%
description: J. P. Morgan & Company reported yesterday that its earnings in the third quarter rose 10.7 percent from the yearearlier level. This was a slower rate of increase than it achieved in earlier auarters of 1979.

title: 2 Indicted in Beating of Mexican Aliens
description: WASHNGTON, Oct. 10  A Federal grand jury in Tucson, Ariz., indicted two members of a wealthy and prominent cattle ranching family today on charges of robbing and beating three Mexicans who entered the country illegally in Aum ict 1978 in search of work.

title: Simpson Still Aims High in Final Season
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 11 - There can be no jay to O.J. Simpson's final season, not after the death of his infant daughter, his divorce, his pain. Nor can there be much winning, not with the San Francisco 49ers. But there can be success, a final 1,000yard season  that much is still probable, the oncegreat halfback said today.

title: Michaels Defending Jets Stress on Youth
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 10  Somehow the Jets seem to defy the aging process. As the season goes along, they're becoming younger if not better.

title: Deattha
description: BACKHOUSEJean (nee Wilson) at Chatham, N.J. on October 9, 1979, formerly of Stuyvesant, New York. Devoted widow of Archibald Backhouse. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Graveside service at the Maple Grove Cemetery, Kew Gardens, Queens on Wednesday, October 17, 1979 at 11AM.

title: Security Is Intense as Castro Arrives for Speech at U.N.
description: Tipping his hat and declaring himself happy to be in the United States, President Fidel Castro of Cuba arrived early this morning at New York City's Kennedy International Airport and was taken under tight security to the Cuban mission to the United Nations in Manhattan.

title: Susan B. Anthony Coin Receives a Poor Rating
description: Reaction to the Susan B. Anthony dollar coin has been overwhelmingly unfavorable, with 66 percent of the national population disliking it, according to the latest Gallup poll.

title: Black Is First in Birmingham Race
description: Mayor David Vann of Birmingham, Ala., who based his political career on appeals for racial harmony, was defeated Tuesday in an election led by a Councilman trying to become the city's first black Mayor.

title: Hers
description: SUSAN'S memory problem was driving her to distraction. If I get any more distracted, she said to me one day as she rummaged around her kitchen, someone will mistake me for an amnesia victim. That's strange. I just had the honey. Now where is it?

title: ORIOLES WIN OPENER OF WORLD SERIES, 54
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 10  After having been delayed 24 hours by rain, the World Series opened in 41degree weather tonight and developed into an embarrassing start and frustrating finish for the Pittsburgh Pirates, who were beaten, 54, by the Baltimore Orioles at Memorial Stadium.

title: Public Is Quiet, Skeptical
description: For all the poetic aptness of the halfcentury anniversary, Wall Street 1979 is really not Wall Street 1929.

title: Hughes Network to Show Number of Hockey Games
description: The Hughes Television Network will televise some regularseason National Hockey League games as well as the league's AllStar Game and some playoff contests, John Ziegler, N.H.L. president, has announced.

title: BRZEZINSKI EXHORTS ALLIES OVER MISSILES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10  Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser, said today that failure of the Western allies to go ahead with plans for new intermediaterange missile systems in Europe could lead to political intimidation from the Soviet Union at best, and even war at worst.

title: Boeing in Credit Accord
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 10 (Reuters)  The Boeing Company said today that it had established a $1.25 billion standby credit agreement with a group of commercial banks. Boeing said the agreement provided for the credit to become available at the time of peak program investment in its 757 and 767 jets.

title: White House Sets Up Art Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) Rosalynn Carter announced a project today to raise $25 million over five years to buy paintings and other historical objects for the White House.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: Sensation of the 20's Back in New York to Dance
description: THE Greatest Program on Any Stage, trumpets a 1928 newspaper advertisement for a program at the palatial Roxy Theater. See Van Grona in The Spirit of Labor. The Sensational Dancer All New York Is Cheering. Dynamic  Daring  Different. that a cocky teenage dancer, just off the boat, strolled into Rothafel's office, perched on his desk and demanded that the colorful producer do something for modern dance.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Ballade No. 3, Chopin; Canon de Versailles, Philidor; Concerto for Violin in C II Piacere, Vivaldi; Salon Polka, J. Strauss Jr.; Minuet, Boccherini.

title: EARNINGS G.E. Profits Rise 14%; CBS Up 9.5% in Quarter
description: The General Electric Company, one of the nation's largest diversified electronics and consumerappliance companies, reported a 14 percent gain yesterday in thirdquarter earnings on 15.9 percent rise in sales.

title: Money Managers Confident on Stocks
description: Despite the stock market tumult of the last few days, Dave Williams, chairman of Alliance Capital Management Corporation, said yesterday that we plan to stay fully invested in common stocks.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Gold mania has become metal mania. Silver, copper, platinum and other metals are all experiencing erratic bursts in price. As in the tulipbulb mania of the 17th century, the economic rules of supply and demand have ceased to apply. Instead, professionals in the metals markets use words like speculation and sheer madness to explain what is going on.

title: Home Improvement
description: BUILDING a raised wood deck similar to the one illustrated here is an ideal way to create an outdoor living area that will be easy to maintain, will drain quickly after a rain and will be on the same level as the back or side door that connects it to the inside. Raising the deck to the level of the door not only makes it a natural extension of the indoor living areas, it also provides an ideal solution to the problem of how to build a level patio on sloping ground, or on top of soil that normally drains poorly during wet weather.

title: Algeria to Raise Refined Sales
description: ALGIERS, Oct. 10 (AP)  Algeria will increase sales of refined petroleum products in 1980 to compensate for a cutback in exports of crude oil, the official press agency Algerie Presse Service reported.

title: Roughing It: Stucco Triumphs as Texture
description: THEY came from sunny California to a dark, inhospitable space in New York's garment district. But Jerry Van Deelen and Charles Swerz, partners in Chas. Swerz & Associates, a space and lighting design firm, were hardly unhappy.

title: Screen: Facts and Propaganda in 'The Wobblies':'One Big Union'
description: "THE Wobblies" is a history of the Industrial Workers of the World, researched lovingly and corroborated by the reminiscences of some of the union's former members, who are now in their 80's and 90's.Along with filming interviews with these stalwarts, the directors  Stewart Bird and Deborah Shaffer  have collected songs, posters, portraits and animated and live-action footage of the period. In assembling these ingredients, they divide their attention between actual and exaggerated images of the labor movement  between the facts of its history and the propaganda. The propaganda is so compelling that, even now, it seems to exist on a bolder scale.It works both ways: in addition to all the pro-I.W.W. graphics and the rousing songs, the film makers have unearthed the kinds of anti-Wobbly material that eventually led to the union's decline. One cartoon shows a farmer, drawn to look like Abraham Lincoln, protecting bags of produce from a large rat, identified as an I.W.W. "Bolshevist."Another, this one from the Disney studio, is about life at Alice's Egg Plant after the Little Red Henski arrives, direct from Moscow and wearing a cap and beard like Lenin's, to organize the other chickens. The animated hens, with cries of "Shorter hours!" and "Smaller eggs!" are soon rebelling against Alice. Alice is played by a real little girl, to emphasize either the innocence or frivolousness of management, depending on one's point of view."The Wobblies" is particularly vivid in detailing what life was like in the lumber camps. There is footage of lumberjack teams felling trees that are wider than the workers are tall; one still photograph shows a man lying sideways in a cavity in a tree trunk. The loggers are also seen at mealtimes, while one man  in voice-over  recalls that the plates were kept nailed to the tables, so they couldn't be stolen. They couldn't be cleaned, either.The film, for all its accounts of strife, proceeds gently. The film makers have no real access to the passion and violence that marked the turbulent history of the union, which flourished in the early years of the century, except through spoken anecdotes and newspaper headlines. And their organization of information is more diligent than dynamic. The film itself is less spirited than the music on its soundtrack, less grandiose or melodramatic than the posters that call urgently, and overpoweringly, for "One Big Union."But this mood, though less fiery than it might have been, is more temperate, more generous, perhaps better suited to the subject in a way. The Wobblies, whose courage and tenacity is documented here over and over again, stood for an egalitarianism that may be better served by research than by rhetoric. When the facts are presented as fully as they have been here, the feelings that accompanied them aren't difficult to imagine."The Wobblies" will be shown tonight at 6:15 and tomorrow night at 9:30 as part of the New York Film Festival.

title: The Sale of a Newark Church Brings Memories and Bargains
description: NEWARK, Oct. 10  It was a church sale to end all sales. People who had not been in the building in decades returned here today to St. James Roman Catholic Church to reminisce tearfully in its Gothic interior and to remember the baptisms, weddings and funerals they had attended.

title: Winter Arrives, Fuel Aid Doesn't
description: About the best thing to be said about the Northeast's unseasonable dose of snow and icy rain is that nobody froze in bed. But unless Congress gets moving on heating oil aid, this winter is certain to be grueling for millions of poor Americans.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The recent call by 14 Congressmen for Logan Act prosecutions of the Rev. Jesse Jackson and other black activists highlights the absurdity and danger inherent in this 180yearold law'. Passed in 1799, the Logan Act was a response to the action by one Dr. George Logan, who traveled to Paris to speak with French Government officials in an attempt to improve relations between America and France. Congress, resenting such action, passed the Logan Act, giving the Government a monopoly on international negotiations.

title: Frankfurt Book Fair: A Blow To Dtente
description: FRANKFURT, Oct. 10  Detente on the book front between the United States and the Soviet Union received a setback as the 31st Frankfurt Book Fair opened here today.

title: Gov. Brown Brings His Campaign to New York City
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. ot Catitornia yesterday made his first serious incursion of the campaign season into New York City on his quest for the Presidency, laughing away the characterization of him as Governor Moonbeam and proposing that oil companies be put under Federal control.

title: Jersey Utility in Offering
description: NEWARK, Oct. 10 (Reuters)  The Public Service Electric & Gas Company said today that it had completed negotiations for the sale of three million shares of common to a group of underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. and Kidder, Peabody & Company at $19.12 share. The shares were being offered to the public at $19.75 apiece, the cornpanysaid.

title: Rights Group Lawyers See F.B.I. Charter Bill As Seriously Flawed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10  Lawyers from the American Civil Liberties Union testified today that a proposed law to define the powers and duties of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was seriously flawed because the legislation largely relied on the bureau to police its own behavior.

title: Harvester Expects Softer Truck Sales
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (Reuters)  The International Harvester Company has begun to see some softening in the truck market, but its truck and agricultural equipment plants continue to operate at or near capacity, Archie R. McCardell, chairman, told a news conference today.

title: Synagogues Mark Holiday of Succoth
description: THE succah at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue may be indoors, but it is exposed to the sky by a roof that opens with an electric switch. The succah at Congregation Rodeph Sholom stands, for the first time, in the synagogue school's new playground. The one at the Jewish Center is high up on the roof.

title: Furor Over 78 Cup Soccer Game Resumes
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 10 A charge that Peruvian soccer players were paid to throw a semifinal game of the 1978 World Cup that enabled Argentina to reach the final instead of Brazil has reopened a lively debate in South America.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: After their pronounced break on Tuesday and Wednesday, the credit markets attempted to recover yesterday but the effort did not take hold. In the afternoon, prices gave up their gains and continued downward as uncertainty and pessimism dominated trading, pushing interest rates higher once again.

title: At Bond Desks, Trying Times
description: Craig Coats, he 32yearold bond trader who heads the Governmentbond trading desk at Salomon Brothers, was sitting in his shirt sleeves yesterday afternoon. In front of him. lights flashed constantly on the 120phone console at his desk, with its direct lines to the Federal Reserve, Merrill Lynch, Citibank and dozens of other major bondtrading desks.

title: Islanders Lose Opener to Flyers
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11  For 101 seconds tonight, the team with last season's best record in the National Hockey League looked like this season's worst team. That is all the time the Islanders needed to drop their opening game, 52, to the Philadelphia Flyers at the Spectrum.

title: Lloyd's Sees Chance of Slump Despite Profitable 76
description: LONDON, Oct. 11 Lloyd's of London provided grim new evidence today that its halcyon days of the early 1870's had given way to a slump.

title: Music: City Opera Is Back With Falstaff in English
description: BACK in business after the strike, the New York City Opera resumed operations last night with its new production of Verdi's Falstaff. It was new to the City Opera, that is. Several years ago, it had its premiere under the auspices of the Boston Opera Company, that doughty company directed by Sarah Caldwell, who conducted last night's perormance.

title: Judge Dismisses 4 on Jersey Jury In Murder Trial
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 11  Five of the 16 jurors in a murder trial in State Superior Court here have been the targets this week of letters containing $100 in cash and a note offering $900 if the defendant. Robert R. Reldan. is convicted.

title: Koch Cites Rikers Improvements
description: Mayor Koch assured a City Council committee yesterday that the State Department of Corrections would increase security at the Rikers Island prison compound when it took over the facility and called for quick action on the plan by the Board of Estimate.

title: SIHANOUK PREDICTS HE'LL REGAIN POWER
description: PEKING, Oct. 11  Prince Norodom Sihanouk said today that he believed the Vietnamese dryseason offensive in Cambodia would wipe out most of the remaining forces of the Pol Pot Communist regime, opening the way to power for a new federation of Cambodian exiles formed under his leadership last month.

title: Staten Island Offers Sunday Afternoon Rodeo
description: Cowboys from across the country will converge on the Charleston section of Staten Island on Sunday for an afternoon of riding broncos and bulls and wrestling steers at the last in a series of rodeos at the Abilene Frontier, Sharotts Road. The participants, almost all professional rodeo riders, will demonstrate their skills from noon to 3 P.M. An exhibition of barrelracing will include amateur riders.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: Mercier and Camier will be performed in preview at 8 P.M. tonight and 8 P.M. on Tuesday at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. Opening night is Wednesday, Oct. 17, at 7 P.M. Tickets are $7 for seats, $4 for pillows. Telephone 5987150.

title: The City
description: Cold Spell Brings Heating Complaints

title: Pop: Pioneer of Funk
description: GEORGE CLINTON is one of the betterkept secrets of presentday popular music, at least insofar as white concertgoers are concerned. The leader of an amalgamated musical organization known as ParliamentFunkadelic, Mr. Clinton has pioneered funk, the 1970's form of black popular music that shares a bassheavy repetition with disco, but offers communal energy rather than strictness of structure as its primary characteristic.

title: Pirates Dedicated to Clemente
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 11  After tying the World Series at one game apiece, the Pittsburgh Pirates flew home tonight with a dramatic reminder of their links to the late Roberto Clemente, who dominated their 1971 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Fuel Stocks Rose Sharply in Week
description: Stocks of heating oil and diesel fuel surged once again last week, rising 3.8 million barrels to 230.8 million barrels from 227 million the week earlier, according to figures released yesterday by the American Petroleum institute

title: Town Shows It Has a Heart for Man in Need
description: FRAMINGHAM, MASS., Oct. 11 Fred Kelley will have a shadow of chance of a few more years of life because this town voted last night to include a new item in its municipal budget: $60,000 for a new heart.

title: EARNINGS
description: Plant startup costs and losses from foreign currency translations combined to cut thirdquarter earnings of the Reynolds Metals Company by 24,9 percent from the levels of a year earlier, the company said yesterday.

title: Talmadge Got Support From 2 Parties in Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  Eight Democratic Senators and seven Republicans voted against the resolution that denounced Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, for his financial conduct.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: THE hardware stores are out of old Madrid. The restaurants are Runic. The haberdasheries are Punic ... there isn't a chili con came counter in the city that isn't under the impression that it is the spit'n image of the Alhambra, Taj Mahal, Morro Castle, St. Paul's. or the Doges Palace In Venice.

title: Phils Offer Green Managerial Post
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 (AP)  Dallas Green has been offered the job of managing the Philadelphia Phillies next season, Paul Owens, the club's personnel director. said today.

title: Scotto Witness Is Pressed Hard By the Defense
description: The crossexamination of Walter D. O'Hearn Jr., a waterfront businessman, continued yesterday as the defense attacked his key assertion that he had made illegal payoffs of $210,000 to Anthony M. Scotto of the International Longshoremen's Association.

title: Toy Festival Takes Over Madison Sq.
description: The great, leafy trees are still green in Madison Square Park, where the squirrels play on bright turf, but around the periphery the plastic Christmas trees are already blooming in display windows. Long before city foliage changes color or block parties are out of season, Santa's sales elves are finishing their work (whether you're ready or not) in the wholesaletoy district clustered around this triangular square, where Broadway and Fifth Avenue cross at 23d Street in front of the Flatiron Building.

title: Paul Dumont, Early Announcer And Radio Pioneer, Is Dead at 90
description: Paul Dumont, a singer and radio announcer who pioneered in early radio programs, died Aug. 24 in Daytona Beach, Fla. He was 90 years old.

title: JACK J. KATZ
description: Jack J. Katz, a lawyer who represented Paul Whiteman, Perry Como, Pat Boone and Howard Hughes, among others in the entertainment field, died Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital at the age of 67. He was a resident of Manhattan.

title: Nagoya 88 Bid Approved By Japan Olympic Group
description: TOKYO, Oct. 11 (UPI)  The Japan Olympic Committee today approved the city of Nagoya's plan to bid for the 1988 Summer Olympic Games.

title: Deaths
description: ADLERMarguerlte. 76. Resident of GoldensbrIdge and New York, N.Y. Died Thursday, October 11, at Doctor's Hospital, NYC, of a heart attack. She is survived by her daughter, Lilllane Litton, and her three grandchildren, Karina Lion, Nicole Brunner, and Ronald Lion. Funeral services will be held Friday. October 12, 1 p.m. at the Riverside Chapel, 180 W 76 St.

title: Water Malone Captures $107,400 Queen Charlotte
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct.11  Laffit Pincay, the leading jockey at Belmont Park, made a trip across the Hudson River tonight that proved worthwhile, for he went on to guide Mrs. Morton Rosenthal's favored Water Malone to victory in the $107,400 Queen Charlotte at the Meadowlands.

title: Senator Church Asks Carter Pledge on Troops in Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  Senator Frank Church, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, formally proposed today that the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union not be ratified until the President gives an assurance that Soviet troops in Cuba are not engaged in a combat role and will not become a threat to any nation in the Western Hemisphere.

title: 34 More Airports to Get WindShift Safety Units
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)  The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it would equip 34 more United States airports with a safety system to warn of potentially dangerous wind shears. Twentyfour airports now have the system.

title: Stage: The Most Happy Fella
description: DEEP in the second act of The Most Happy Fella, which opened last night at the Majestic Theater, the young mailorder bride confesses her love to the aged vineyard owner whom she has married. The two embrace and sine the duet, My Heart Is So Full of You. The magnificent voice of Giorgio Tozzi fills the stage, and Sharon Daniels is his equal partner. For a moment there is not only music, but real emotion in the theater, but it is an isolated moment in a show that, for all its sentiment, seems to be short on feeling.

title: FiveHour Bronx Concert
description: Music from the Renaissance to the present will be performed in a fivehour concert on Sunday at the RiverdaleYordcers Ethical Society, 4450 Fieldston Road. Beginnine at 3 P.M.. the performance will featuie the Bronx Arts Ensemble, individual musicians and a singalong with the audience. Contributions accepted. Proceeds will benefit the Bronx Arts Ensemble. Information: 5484445.

title: Auctions
description: IT is anything but a coincidence that two major auctions specializing in material from South of the Border will be held at two different New York houses next week. Auction concerns discovered long ago that everyone gains when sales that offer similar material are scheduled to take place within days or hours of each other. That's because two sales have a tendency to attract twice as many bidders as a single event. The first important auction in this city of Latin American art takes place Wednesday at 8 P.M. at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street. And what is described as the largest and finest collection of LatinAmerican literature outside of an institution goes under the hammer in a threeday dispersal Wednesday, Thursday and Friday at 1 P.M. at Phillips, Son & Neale, Madison Avenue at 72d Street.

title: Restaurants
description: AS hot and spicy foods become increasingly fashionable, they also are becoming decreasingly hot and spicy. Just as there are people who want to order Scotch whisky but abhor its traditional smoky flavor, or who want to have Italian food but do not like garlic and olive oil, so there seems to be a market for north Chinese and Indian dishes minus the fiery and pungent spicing that is their most distinguishing characteristic; and just as producers of Scotch came up with light blends that were slightly sweetened, and Italian restaurateurs switched to corn oil and held the garlic, so Indian and Chinese chefs are gradually beginning to temper their seasonings to appeal to the most timid palates.

title: Advertising
description: SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda, Oct. 11  The publishers of some of America's bestknown magazines are preparing to look a gift horse in the mouth. The horse in question is Timothy Joyce's new Magazine Research Inc. Yesterday it released in New York its first syndicated study of magazine audiences.

title: WASHINGTON;One Vote For the Orioles
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  Except for our friends who live in and around Pittsburgh, it is hard to imagine why anybody could possibly hope for the defeat of a team called the Orioles, especially when they are in combat for the baseball championship of the world against a team called the Pirates.

title: TV Weekend
description: MOST of the more ambitious entertainment action this weekend is being offered on Sunday evening. Flesh and Blood, based on a novel by Pete Hamill, begins a twopart presentation on CBS at 9 P.M. (the second half will be shown Tuesday at 9). On NBC at 8, William Gibson's The Miracle Worker is being revived for television, where it began as a Playhouse 90 production in 1957. And at 11 on Channel 13, an Adolescent Rites series is opening with an independent film called Good Girl.

title: A Fair and a Parade in Brooklyn
description: Two annual and giddy street events are scheduled in Brooklyn on Sunday, and if wouldn't be hard to attend both. You can dance in a bank at the 10block festival known as the Atlantic Antic. And in Bay Ridge, you can watch band of ragamuffins march in preHaloween getups.

title: Elayne Boosler Cuts Up at Pace
description: There are two kinds of comedians: those you laugh at and those you laugh with. Elayne Boosler is the second kind. Elayne Boosler, age 26, with her Farrah Fawcett fluff and her Bain de Soleil tan, does not make jokes about how ugly and old she is. Elayne Boosler, who has gone in six years from waiting tables to the Johnny Carson show, does not make jokes about what a failure she is. Elayne Boosler, who for some time was the girl in a clutch of funny men, does not make jokes about how female she is. Nor does she go for the laughs of selfdepreciation; she goes for the laugh of recognition. Her jokes have happened to everyone.

title: Deaths
description: PUTTERMANHazzan David J. and Mrs. Club mourna the sudden Passing of its beloved friend, Hazzan David J. Futterman. His beautiful voice and hazzanic artistry In terpreting the sacred liturgy with devotion has brought innermost emotion to our religious prayers. Our deepest sympathy to his loved family.

title: Off Broadway Offers Yeats And Beckett
description: TWO bold and unusual ventures in theater  both premieres in their respective ways  are on view this weekend. At the CSC Repertory, five littleperformed plays of William Butler Yeats have been brought together in a cycle of Celtic history and legend called Cuchulain, the Warrior King. And at the New York Shakepeare Festival's Public/ LuEsther Hall, Mercier and Ca

title: Deaths
description: ROTHSarah. Beloved aunt of Henry Roth, beloved sister of the late Morris Roth, Helen Roth and Margaret Hermel. Services were held Wednesday, October 10, 1979.

title: President Vows He Won't Sacrifice Construction Jobs
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 11  President Carter, whose tightmoney policies seem certain to increase unemployment, promised officials of the politically active building trades unions today that he would not sacrifice the jobs of their members in his battle against inflation.

title: Presidential Hopefuls Far Ahead Of the 76 Pace in Raising Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  Presidential campaign contributions are coming in more than twice as fast as they did four years ago, with more than $16.5 million raised already, according to reports prepared for the Federal Election Commission.

title: Israel Expels 30 Settlers From Arab Olive Grove
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 11 (AP)  Israeli troops expelled about 30 Jewish settlers from an Arabowned olive grove beside their outpost in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan today, the Israeli radio reoorted.

title: New Safety Plan For Nuclear Site In Jersey Sought
description: SALEM, N.J., Oct. 11  Officials of the states of New Jersey and Delaware and representatives of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company have been given five weeks to come up with a new emergency plan designed to protect residents within 10 miles of the Salem generating station in the event of a nuclear accident.

title: About Real Estate
description: In Brooklyn Heights as in Manhattan, rundown old hotels are going the way of conversion into apartments. The Towers Hotel was taken over by the Jehovah's Witnesses, a large Brooklyn Heights property owner, for apartments. The Pierrepont Hotel has become housing for the elderly under the auspices of Catholic Charities. The St. George Hotel is converting to rental apartments.

title: Sea Cliff Chamber Players 10th Season
description: Two concerts are planned this weekend by the Sea Cliff Chamber Players to open their 10th season.

title: Market Place
description: Margin Calls: Today and in 29

title: Notes on People
description: Ali, on Canvas, on Mend After Taking One on Chin

title: Screen: A Killer Returns in 'When a Stranger Calls':Killer on Little Cat Feet
description: THE gimmick behind "When a Stranger Calls" is a scary one, but it's been played for more than it's worth. A babysitter begins receiving annoying phone calls, so she calls the police. Everyone gets annoying phone calls, the police say. Later she complains again, and the calls are traced, and they turn out to be originating at the very house she's in. This time, the police are willing to take the matter more seriously, but it's too late for the children in the house. The man who's been tormenting the babysitter, an escaped mental patient, has long since torn them limb from limb.This isn't the film's denouement, it's just the beginning. Seven years later, the same babysitter has children of her own and the killer is on the loose all over again. He hasn't gotten any nicer with age."When a Stranger Calls" is the first feature to be directed by Fred Walton, who originally told this same story  with Steve Feke, his co-screenwriter  in the space of a 20-minute short. But for the sake of a full-length format, they've broadened the plot considerably without digging any deeper. The killer, whose craziness is quite unexplained, now spends the mid-section of the film being pursued by an ex-cop with an all-purpose motive: he saw the first murder, he'll get this guy if it's the last thing he does, and so on. The cop is played by Charles Durning, an excellent actor who looks awfully tubby for the chase scenes and who specializes in less monomanical roles than this film's version of Dirty Harry.Mr. Durning is miscast, but he's not alone. The movie is full of fine actors, but they all seem to have been wedged into the wrong roles. Tony Beckley, a slender, edgy-looking Englishman, doesn't look physically capable of having committed the crime. (It is never explained, incidentally, how he accomplished anything so brutal without making a sound.) Carol Kane does a fine job as the quavery-voiced, terrified babysitter, but when she grows up into a suburban Mom all is not well. Colleen Dewhurst, as a sodden barfly whom the killer begins stalking, looks aglow with a very unbarflylike beauty. She also looks perfectly capable of breaking the arm of Mr. Beckley, who seems much frailer than she.Miss Dewhurst gives a coolly glamorous performance, but hers is the character that makes the least sense of all. Why does this woman spend her days in a place called Torchy's, and why does she make a habit of walking home alone, through the most deserted streets in all of Los Angeles? The first time Miss Dewhurst makes this trip, Mr. Walton fills the soundtrack with echoes, the clickety-clack of her high heels on the pavement as she wends her way through the night. This might pass for style if it didn't later develop that she has been followed home by the killer, whose own footsteps are conveniently soundless. Mr. Walton diminishes his own suspense by letting this already harmless-looking figure pad about on little cat feet.Nevertheless, "When a Stranger Calls" is an energetic first film; if Mr. Walton hasn't yet learned his lessons well, he's certainly chosen the right teachers. The frightened-babysitter opening of the movie is marvelously modern, as Mr. Walton demonstrates that a haunted house with an ice-making refrigerator is intrinsically scarier than a house without one. He also makes the most of that fearsome modern weapon, the telephone.The screenplay, by Mr. Walton and Mr. Feke, contains about twice as much small talk as it needed. When a man hires a private detective to find the murderer of his children, and the detective has already said, "Maybe not tomorrow, maybe not this week, but I'll find him," why wait for the client to add, "My accountant will contact you"? Is it absolutely necessary for a doctor to ask the detective, "Do you want to know how much we really understand of the human mind"?"When a Stranger Calls" opens today at the National and other theaters.

title: City Hall Attempts to Lure Foreign Plants
description: New York City, having largely stemmed the industrial exodus of the last decade, is beginning a campaign to encourage selected industries in West Germany, Britain and Japan to build new plants here.

title: Tour of Historic Jamaica
description: Historic buildings in Jamaica, Queens, will be covered in a free walking tour tomorrow at 10 A.M., sponsored by the Friends of Jamaica History. Beginning at the Tabernacle of Prayer, Jamaica Avenue at Parsons Boulevard, the tour will include stops at Grace Episcopal Church, built in 1862, and King Manor, the former residence of Rufus King, the first United States Ambassador to Britain. The tour will go on rain or shine. Information: 6587439.

title: Richard Signs FourYear Pact
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 11 (AP)  J.R. Richard, this year's major league strikeout leader, has signed a fouryear contract with the Houston Astros extending through 1983.

title: Senators Back Energy Concern; Shift in OilTax Use Is Favored
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  President Carter's program for largescale development of synthetic fuel to reduce reliance on imported oil moved one step forward, and another sideways, in the Senate today.

title: Performers To Recreate Period Art
description: Accompanying the American Renaissance exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum will be a special presentation next Saturday and Sunday, Oct. 20 and 21, of music, dance, art and theater in a nostalgic recreation of the period.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The stock market calmed after three days of turbulent trading and plunging prices. Volume shrank to 47.5 million shares, still heavy, from 81.6 million on Wednesday, and the Dow Jones industrial average slid 4.70 points to 844.62 after skidding 48.29 points in the previous three sessions. Aggressive buying by big institutional investors stabilized the market. [Page A1.]
