title: Coal Company Wins $1.2 Million In Suit Over 7778 U.M.W. Strike
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 (AP)  A Federal jury awarded $1.2 million today to a nonunion stripmine concern that had sued the United Mine Workers for an alleged secondary boycott and violence in the 197778 national coal strike.

title: Plans for Hospital
description: Delafield Hospital, which has been closed since 1975, is to be converted into a federally subsidized housing project for elderly people, it was announced.

title: DAVID PUTTERMAN, A RETIRED CANTOR
description: David J. Putterman, cantor emeritus of the Park Avenue Synagogue, which he served for more than 90 years, died of heart attack Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: The Region
description: Court Rules Odor Can Justify a Search

title: For Parents of Hospitalized Children, a Place to Stay
description: It was the sort of activity that often brings on neighborhood crises  delivery trucks blocking the avenue, painters and plasterers scurrying about with their work tools, carpenters drilling and hammering long after the normal workday. Nevertheless, Yorkville residents looked on goodnaturedly as the former Convent of St. Josenh at 419 East 86th Street was transformed into Ronald McDonald House.

title: In Moscow, Uncertainty on U.S. Policy
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 11  The Soviet leadership, uncertain about the direction of United States foreign policy as the 1980 election campaign approaches, has now shown readiness to deal separately with Washington's West European allies if the Americans cannot be relied on as a partner in dtente.

title: Business Records
description: Thursday, Oct. 11, 1979

title: New York to See 4 TV Games
description: This weekend's two most important pro football games, each involving two firstplace teams, will be televised here on Sunday.

title: Carter Outlook in New York
description: It was an unusual scene: President Carter holding hands with most of New York's top Democrats as they prayed before luncheon at the White House last Friday. One of the luncheon guests, Representative Mario Biaggi, described the mood as warm and supportive.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Deaths
description: FREEMANWilliam Adrian. The members of Zeta Boule mourn the passing of our Brother Adrian. We will miss his devotion and friendship and offer our deepest condolences to his wife, Mildred.

title: Cambodian Reporter Who Fled True Hell Tells of 4Year Ordeal
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 11  A Cambodian journalist employed by The New York Times has reached safety in Thailand after four and a half years of disguise and deprivation that included once being beaten almost to death for stealing a pocketful of rice because be was desperately hungry.

title: Books: Rosie, a Death
description: ROSAURA JIMENEZ died in pain Oct. 3, 1977, in McAllen, Tex., at the age of 27, leaving behind her a 5yearold daughter and an uncashed scholarship check. Hers was the first recorded death by illegal abortion after a cutback in Federal Medicaid funds for abortions.

title: French Unveil Major Picasso Show
description: PARIS, Oct. 11 (AP)  The French Government unveiled a sweeping retrospective of Pablo Picasso's work today, including several masterpieces from his private collection.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Japan's Wornen Vote
description: TOKYO, Oct. 11  A Communist candidate in last Sunday's elections stood in front of a loudspeaker truck in Chiba city to speak about corruption. Chiba Prefecture has what are alleged to be the dirtiest elections in the country, stemming from huge land deals in the 1960's involving Tokyo's new airport at Narita; no one was stopping to listen to the woman's views.

title: A Salute to Brooklyn's Past
description: It'd take a guy a lifetime to know Brooklyn t'roo an t'roo. An even den, yuh wouldn't know it all, wrote Thomas Wolfe in Only the Dead Know Brooklyn. But as far as the Brooklyn Academy of Music is concerned, that's no reason not to try to get to know and understand the rich history of that tract of land on the other side of The Bridge.

title: Carnival of Culture Across the River
description: BROOKLYN has an opportunity this weekend to show why it is among the nation's most lively arts centers. The Brooklyn Academy of Music will be playing host to the Aman International Folk Ensemble, one of the world's leading folk dance companies, and also will present the premiere of Ballad of Brooklyn, a celebration in prose, poetry and song of the work of some of the bor ough's favorite sons and daughters, including Hart Crane, Walt Whitman, Henry Miller and Thomas Wolfe. Two colorful street fairs will attract thousands to Atlantic Avenue and to Bay Ridge. And most significantly  the Brooklyn Museum will offer a major art exhibition called the The American Renaissance.

title: U.N. Wasn't All Ears for Him, But a Visit Satisfied Mr. jameel
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11 The public gallery was bare. On the floor of the cavernous General Assembly chamber, a handful of delegates were scattered among rows of yawning seats. At the rostrum, Fathullah Jameel of the Maldives was speaking to an all but empty house.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 11 (Reuters) Guerrillas supported by Kurdish villagers destroyed a frontier post at Hanigarmeleh last night after its Government defenders had retreated to surrounding mountains, the provincial governor general said today.

title: Senate Panel Told of Falsified Data in Drug Studies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)  Researchers testing new drugs sometimes alter laboratory results, improperly use human subjects and falsify patient records, a Senate subcommittee was told today.

title: London Parley on Rhodesia Adjourns in Deadlock
description: LONDON, Oct. 11  The Zimbabwe Rhodesia conference adjourned indefinitely here today in a deadlock over the provisions of a new constitution.

title: Giants Gamble With Hammond
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 11  The Giants, at the point of no return on kickoffs and punts, placed Bobby Hammond on waivers today in the hope that no other club in the National Football League claims him.

title: U.S. Money Supply Up $2 Billion
description: The nation's money supply soared by an unexpected $2 billion in the week ended Oct. 3, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday, underlining the central bank's difficulties in controlling this key factor in the economy.

title: Cost Cuts Never Get A Nobel
description: The Nobel Prize Committee yesterday delivered a major blow against the bureaucrats in Washington who would like to halt, or even to reverse, the current technological revolution in United States medicine.

title: Senator Who Avoided Limelight
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 Unlike his gallusespopping father, the late Gov. Eugene (Ol Gene) Talmadge, Herman E. Talmadge has never been much for public political spectacles.

title: Economic Scene
description: IF the Federal Reserve's object in switching operational monetarism was to scare consumers, business and the stock market, it has succeeded gloriously. The sickening swings in the market and the record volume of trading have awakened not merely 50yearold memories but a brandnew fevered sweat.

title: Bridge:
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 11  The world team championship continued here this afternoon with the United States players defeating their old rivals from Italy and maintaining the lead they established in the first two days of the tournament.

title: Aman Presents World of Folk Dance at Brooklyn Academy
description: Folk dancing is a popular recreational pursuit throughout the world, and many countries have their own national folk dance ensembles that present their native dances in more or less slickedup versions. But there is no company quite like Aman, the Los Angeles troupe that makes its New York debut tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 2 in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Opera House.

title: Rock Island Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today that it would hold public hearings from Oct. 22 to Nov. 1 in 17 cities to consider whether another cornpany should serve the routes of the financially ailing Rock Island Railroad. Last month, the commission directed the Kansas City Terminal Company, a switching concern owned by 12 railroads, to provide service over the Rock Island's 7,200 miles of lines for 80 days. That period ends Dec. 3, but the I.C.C. can extend it for an 180 days more if necessary.

title: Around the Nation
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 11 (AP)  A Federal district judge today denied a petition by a teacher of Hebrew to delay county Democratic caucuses in Florida because they fall on the Jewish sabbath.

title: Chrysler Aid Bill Planned in House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  A Congressman from a suburban Detroit district with several Chrysler plants said today that he would introduce legislation next week to provide Federal assistance to the troubled Chrysler Corporation. The announcement was made by Representative James J. Blanchard, a Democrat.

title: London Fashions: Control, Exuberance, Everything in Between
description: LONDON, Oct. 11  In one corner, there is Jean Muir, with her quiet, controlled, nowclassic look; in the other, Zandra Rhodes, wildly exuberant, full of splendid fantasies. They are the two pillars of the London fashion establishment.

title: Getty Bids $631 Million For Reserve
description: The Getty Oil Company offered to buy the Reserve Oil and Gas Company for $631 million yesterday.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Carey Asks Richard Ravitch to Be Head of the M.T.A.
description: Governor Carey has asked Richard Ravitch, a prominent real estate developer who formerly headed the State Urban Development Corporation, to replace Harold L. Fisher as chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Murder in Record Numbers Is Worrying Houston
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 11  Joann Huffman was 16 years old and Robert Spangenberger was 18, and they planned to be married. Last week they went out together for the evening. The next morning, Thursday, her body was found in a city park, shot once through the head. His body was discovered in the trunk of a car some distance away. His head was missing.

title: A Peking Scene: Pimps and Prostitutes at the Peace Cafe
description: PEKING, Oct. 11  Several young men in army uniforms are sitting around a large new Japanese cassette tape recorder, transfixed by the beat of a pop love song. Stacks of other cassettes, adorned with pictures of pretty Hong Kong recording stars, are spread on the table in front of them.

title: A Warning About Straight and Narrow Paths
Tokyo Stocks Fall In Hectic Trading
description: TOKYO, Oct. 11 (Reuters) Prices plunged on the Tokyo stock market in hectic trading today, in a rush of selling touched off by yesterday's sharp fall on Wall Street.

title: Rogers Gains in Golf by 4 and 2
description: WENTWORTH, England, Oct. 11 (AP)  Bill Rogers tamed the damp English weather and beat Britain's Sandy Lyle, 4 and 2, today in the first round of the World Match Play Championship.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Regains Ground; Price of Gold Tumbles;
description: The price of gold plummeted on jittery European and American bullion markets yesterday as the dollar strengthened against foreign currencies.

title: Monitoring Set On Oil Imports
description: PARIS, Oct. 11  The United States and other major oilconsuming nations agreed today to start monitoring their oil imports next month. They hope to learn how much oil is bought at prices higher than the official level set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: Hospital Is Due To Close as U.S. Refuses to Aid It
description: The Federal Government yesterday turned down the Carey Administration's request for $4 million in emergency Federal aid to prevent the closing of the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn.

title: Pay Issue Snags Key Money Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  Senate and House negotiators failed to reach agreement tonight on a crucial money bill that has been caught up in a bitter stalemate over abortion and a Congressional pay increase.

title: Venezuelan Price to Rise
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 11 (AP)  Venezuela will raise the price of exported residual fuel oils by an average of 8.3 percent effective Sunday, the Energy and Mines Ministry announced today. This country has daily exports of 562,000 barrels of residual oil, and 56 percent of it goes to the United States. The price increase is the 11th this year.

title: Murray Caught in Pivotal Plays
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 11  Ready to assume the role of World Series hero after his home run and double had driven in his team's two runs, Eddie Murray of the Orioles instead became trapped in a series of circumstances that helped the Pittsburgh Pirates win the second game of the World Series tonight.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Broken, stratified clouds with some rain clouds stretch from New England through the lake region to the Middle Atlantic States and the Ohio Valley. Broken cloudiness covers the plateau region and the Southern Pacific States. Clear skies prevail elsewhere.

title: Leaders of 2 Black Groups Seek Amity With Jews on P.L.O. Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  The black leaders of two major civil rights organizations have decided to break their silence on the recent rift between blacks and Jews and will make public appeals for reconciliation, partly by warning against black overtures to the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Davis of Cosmos Injured
description: Ricky Davis, a midfielder for the Cosmos, has left the soccer team's Far Eastern tour because of a torn muscle in his left thigh, a Cosmos spokesman said yesterday. Davis will be sidelined for at least two weeks.

title: Critic's Notebook
description: THE phrase film festival falls into the same category as celebrity roast  it's a term that has strayed quite a distance from its original meaning. However much chatter or excitement this year's New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center has generated, it hardly seems a festive occasion.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Picks Acting Aide
description: Former Mayor Theodore M. Berry of Cincinnati will be appointed acting general counsel to the National Association for the Advance of Colored People, the civil rights group announced yesterday. Mr. Berry, 73 years old, will be named acting general counsel until a replacement can be found, it was said. Nathaniel Jones, general counsel since 1969, is leaving to accept an appointment to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

title: United Way Backs Plan To Relax Hold on Drives
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)  Responding to complaints from dozens of competing charities, the United Way of America acknowledged today that its virtual hold over contributions from Government employees should be relaxed.

title: Stage: A Jewish Musical
description: IT is tunefully musical and a delightful comedy, so for everyone who keeps asking where the new musical comedies are, a visit to the Harold Clurman Theater to see King of the Schnorrers is a must.

title: U.S. Drugs Chief, in West Berlin, Warns of New Mideast Opium Threat
description: WEST BERLIN, Oct. 11  A tremendous harvest of about 1,000 tons of raw opium from Middle East countries, primarily Pakistan, Afghanistan and Iran, is expected to hit illicit drug markets this year, posing grave new problems for Western Europe and the United States, Peter B. Bensinger, head of the Drug Enforcement Administration in Washington, said here today.

title: IN THE NATION
description: When President Carter held his first Washington news conference in three months, he was asked not a single question about the energy crisis, one of the major preoccupations of the period  particularly for those who sat in long lines at the gas station. The reporters did not even ask Mr. Carter to comment on the harsh treatment the Senate Finance Committee is giving his heralded windfall tax on oil company profits.

title: Dance: Umbrella Series
description: SEVEN dancers offered A Celebration of Dance Wednesday night at Camera Mart/Stage One. Their program was part of the Dance Umbrella series and the participants included Martine van Hamel, Kristine Elliott and Kevin McKenzie of American Ballet Theater; Gary Chryst and Cynthia Anderson of the Jot frey Ballet; Naomi Sorkin, formerly of American Ballet Theater and the Eliot Feld Ballet, and Jeffrey Sherwood of San Francisco's Pacific Ballet. Unfortunately, the dances at this gathering did not show off the performers at their best.

title: Area Stores Report Sales Gains
description: Bolstered by an improved city economy and a high influx of tourists, retail sales in New York City continued strong last month, although the gains were well below those of August.

title: Rock:BramTchaikovsky
description: BRAM TCHAIKOVSKY combines sweet, countryflavored threepart harmony singing with the sort of instrumental bashing usually reserved for late sets in noisy pubs. It's a combination that's peculiarly characteristic of a lot of contemporary English rock, and Mr. Tchaikovsky, a singer, songwriter, guitarist and leader of an eponymously named band, is very English, broad accent, rowdy stage presence and all.

title: Control Board Head Bids City Trim Spending More
description: The executive director of the Financial Control Board, noting disturbing trends, has suggested that Mayor Koch put into effect a contingency plan now to cut back on the city's spending.

title: DR. WILLIAM A. FREEMAN
description: Dr. William Adrian Freeman, retired chief of traumatic surgery at Harlem Hospital, died Monday at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 79 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: MARKET OFF BY 4.70, BUT GAINS OUTPACE DECLINES IN STOCKS
description: The stock market cooled off yesterday after three days of turmoil marked by unusually heavy trading and broad price declines. Aggressive buying by large financial institutions stabilized prices and enabled the market to close with only a modest loss, as trading slackened.

title: In Washington, Rebuff to Brezhnev ArmsCut Offer
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  In rebuffing Leonid I. Brezlmev's plea for halting an American plan for deploying mediumrange nuclear missiles in Western Europe, the United States has evidently decided to risk another altercation with Moscow to pursue a program that it believes will preserve the solidarity of the Atlantic alliance.

title: Broadway
description: A IN'T MISBEHAVIN will play Jerusalem. Many American musicals get done in Israel, but usually they are done by Israelis, and usually the production is at a far remove from the one on Broadway. Ain't

title: AutoTrain Looks to Recovery
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  The AutoTrain, an idea so elegantly sensible in theory that it swept up an excited traveling and investing public eight years ago, has come on hard times.

title: Old Planet, New World
description: The entire world is at the beginning of a historic turning point. We are moving up to the postindustrial age. The last time such a major changeover unfolded was around 200 years ago when a few communities in Europe and North America began shifting from the feudal to the industrial age. Today the transition is far more rapid and global. The whole industrialage complex is phasing out  family, school, industrial transportation, postal service, fossil fuels, capitalistsocialist economics, industrial agriculture, assembly line, fulltime employment, representative democracy, centralized city, nationhood.

title: Gulf and Western Stock Talks End
description: Gulf and Western Industries, a diversified financialservices concern, said that it had informed the Securities and Exchange Commission that discus sions with the SherwinWilliams Company regarding the exchange of SherwinWilliams stock owned by G.& W. had been terminated on Sept. 18.

title: At the Movies
description: WHEN it went into general release this week Apocalypse Now got back its apocalyptic ending, and Martin Sheen, for one, wishes that it hadn't.

title: Canada G.M. Outlay
description: General Motors of Canada Ltd.'s capital expenditures will reach more than $2 billion in 1979 and the following three years, according to the company's president, F. Alan Smith. He said the outlay was about three times the amount spent over the last four years and that $1.5 billion of the total would be spent on plant facilities.

title: Nets Obtain Newlin; Jackson Made Coach
description: The New Jersey Nets, seeking a backup playmaking guard, came up with a shooter instead yesterday when they acquired Mike Newlin from the Houston Rockets on the eve of their National Basketball Association opener tonight against the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Indian Summer Game
description: Eight years ago tomorrow night, Bowie Kuhn, prodded by Carl Lindemann of the National Broadcasting Company, dipped a timid toe into prime time. On Oct. 13, 1971 a date that lives in infamy  the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Baltimore Orioles, 43, in the fourth game of the World Series and squared the tournament at two victories each. On that date, these words were written:

title: Deaths
description: KUCICHFrances. Beloved wife of the late Domenick D., devoted mother of Ann Mann, Louis D. and William J. Reposing at the Morisco Funeral Home, 3012 Astoria Blvd, Astoria. Mass at Mt. Carmel Church Saturday 9:30am.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Resorts International Names Finance Chief For Its Jersey Casino
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 11  Resorts International, under fire from New Jersey for multiple violations of credit regulations, announced the appointment today of Robert J. Fiore, controller of Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, as senior vice president of finance for the Resorts hotel and casino here.

title: Forum's Cup Boxing Fails to Draw Crowd
description: The first World Cup amateur boxing championships came up short of fans as well as boxers last night at the Felt Forum as the weeklong Olympictype series began.

title: Board of Estimate Blocks Funds for Sanitationmen
description: The Board of Estimate refused yesterday to approve funds for the hiring of 562 additional sanitationmen, handing stinging defeat to Mayor Koch, who had contended the manpower was necessary to clean what he described as the filthy streets in the five boroughs.

title: Anglican Leader to Be Installed
description: CANTERBURY, England, Oct. 11 (Reuters)  The Anglican Church's new leader, Bishop Robert Runcie, will be installed as Archbishop of Canterbury next March 25, the church announced today. He succeeds the Most Rev. Donald Coggan, 70 years old, who is retiring Jan. 26.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: American and Briton Get Nobel Prize for XRay Advance
description: An American and a Briton won the 1979 Nobel Prize for physiology and medicine yesterday for developing a revolutionary Xray technique that gives doctors an astonishingly clear look inside the living human body.

title: Concert: Philharmonic
description: ONE of the protests made against 12tone and other varieties of Serial composing techniques is that they seem incapable, possibly by nature, of expressing happiness, humor and other light musical moods. Serialism, that is, can make perfect sense in such grim SWIMS as Berg's Lulu, but does not offer the wide emotional range necessary for, say, a modern version of Cosi fan tutte. Another way i:)f looking at the matter, however, is Co appreciate the tortured atmosphere that sometimes can be evoked so effectively by the use of Serial devices. Last night's performance by the New York Philharmonic of Luigi Dallapiccola's Variations for Orchestra, under the direction of Erich Leinsdorf, impressed this listener once again with this frequently undervalued fact.

title: Fish vs. Fuel on the Georges Bank
description: At first glance, the commercial fishermen and environmentalists who are resisting a search for oil and gas in the Georges Bank off Massachusetts seem to make a compelling case. The area is one of the world's most productive fishing grounds, and no one expects to find more than modest amounts of oil and gas there. Why risk contaminating a fishery that has provided food and jobs for 350 years just to power our cars and heat our houses a few days longer?

title: Unions Stage J. P. Stevens Protest
description: Pickets from most of the major labor unions in New York City set up what they called a human billboard along 12 blocks on Park Avenue yesterday in a demonstration protesting the labor policies of J. P. Stevens & company and the continued service on the Stevens board of the chairman of the Seamen's Bank for Savings. A similar demonstration was conducted along Broadway in the downtown financial district.

title: Bank Earnings Reports
description: For perlods as shown. (N ) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Losses Calculated in I.B.M. Issue
description: The 227 investment banking firms that helped underwrite International Business Machines Corporation's $1 billion of notes and debentures lost significantly less than $10 million, John H. Gutfreund, managing partner of Salomon Brothers, the firm heading the syndicate, estimated yesterday.

title: Female Doctors Assess the Problems of Their Profession
description: BALTIMORE  Female doctors show emotion in public more often than male doctors do, and then feel embarrassed about it. And they worry whether they will find a husband who will be a help to them in pursuing both a career and motherhood.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: Buddhist Art Of Japan At Asia House
description: ART that is intensely religious must always remain, in one degree or another, beyond the reach of the secular mind. For the believer, religious art forms a bridge between two worlds, the earthly and the spiritual, and it is the latter  the world of spirit and transcendence  that necessarily dominates. For the nonbeliever, the world of spirit so vividly evoked in the greatest religious art is, at best, a fable or a metaphor  in other words, a fiction. In the absence of belief, even the most magnificent religious art loses a portion  often a very significant portion  of its power.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Campbell Soup Company has elected Milton A. Zimmerman to the newly created post of vice president and special assistant to the president.

title: SENATE DENOUNCES TALMADGE, 81 TO 15, OVER HIS FINANCES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  The Senate took the rare step today of passing judgment on the conduct of one of its most senior members by denouncing Senator Herman E. Talmadge for mishandling his financial affairs.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: U.S., in Shift, May Sell Arms to Morocco for Sahara War
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  The Carter Administration is nearing a decision whether to change its policy and supply arms, and possibly counterinsurgency training, to help Morocco in its conflict with guerrillas in Western Sahara.

title: 5 Films Based on O'Neill Plays Free at the Public Theater
description: As part of many cultural events commemorating the birthday of Eugene O'Neill, the Public Theater will offer free showings Sunday of five films based on O'Neill plays.

title: U.S. Panel Finds Problems Persist On Atom Plants
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  The special group hired by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to make an independent investigation of the accident at the Three Mile Island reactor has informed the commission that the agency's emergency response team remains inadequate, more than six months after the incident.

title: Why More Housing Aid for the NonPoor?
description: Rental apartments around the country are in short supply, and because vacancy rates are low, rents are soaring. Yet developers are reluctant to build new apartments and many landlords are abandoning old ones. At every income level, tenants complain that they can't find apartments they can afford.

title: Amtrak Unveils a 'superliner Fleet Of Rail Cars for Its Western Routes
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 11  Amtrak unveiled its new fleet of Superliner luxury trains here today, and officials said they hoped the fleet would be able to do what years of inflation and fuel shortages have been unable to do  tear the American public away from the automobile.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Alternateside parking regulations will be suspended tomorrow throughout New York City for the last day of the Jewish holiday of Succoth. All other parking regulations remain in effect.

title: Sadat Gives A Warning On Bribery
description: CAIRO, Oct. 11 President Anwar elSadat said today that any company that pays commissions to any Egyptian official will be blacklisted, and we will stop dealing with it. Although the Arabic word used repeatedly in his speech is usually translated as commissions, it was clear he was referring to bribes.

title: Pirates Win, 32, On Sanguillen Hit
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 11 Manny Sanguillen, a perpetually smiling Panamanian, was sent to the Oakland A's almost three years ago so that the Pittsburgh Pirates could obtain Chuck Tanner's manaeerial freedom from Charlie Finley, the Oakland owner. Tonight, 18 months after he was reacquired from the A's, Sanguillen won the second game of the 76th World Series for Tanner and the Pirates.

title: Topics Giants Lost and Found
description: Soviet theorists used to condemn Sigmund Freud as a nonscientific fraud. A generation ago they made him at least a discussable curiosity, despite his unMarxian determinism. Now the Soviets seem to be taking Freud even more seriously.

title: Publishing: From Holocaust to Brooklyn
description: READERS with warm memories of Sam Abelman, the curmudgeon doctor in Gerald Green's 1957 novel, The Last Angry Man  their name must be legion  will be pleased to learn that they can meet him again, this time in a supporting role, in Mr. Ureen's next novel, The Chains, to be published by Seaview Books next March. Chains is a family name and not a series of links, although the novel does connect three generations as it chronicles the volatile fortunes of the family from their beginnings in Brooklyn's Brownsville, an area that Mr. Green, son of a Brownsville doctor, knows firsthand. Sam Abelman is the family doctor to the clan.

title: House of Morgan Names Preston Its Next Chief
description: Lewis T. Preston will culminate a 28year rise to the pinnacle of the House of Morgan at the end of this year by succeeding Walter H. Page as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Castro Visit All but Stops Activity In Usually Bustling Midtown Area
description: Fidel Castro's presence at 38th ptreet and Lexington Avenue has all but stopped activity on several normally bustling blocks of midtown Manhattan.

title: Skyline Drive Section Closed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)  The National Park Service announced today that a large segment of the Skyline Drive through Virginia and some visitor facilities in the Shenandoah National Park would be closed until next week because of storm damage. The Park Service advised visitors to postpone their trips at least until Wednesday.

title: Screen: Divine Nymph, With Laura Antonelli
description: THIS week's Good Taste in Movie Advertising Competition ends in a dead heat. Ordinarily, the ads that have encouraged potential bank robbers to treat A Man, a Woman and a Bank as a trainme manual would win hands down. (They'd also leave this city full of irritated crooks, since the movie's heist plot requires a lot of expertise. It would also take about a year to execute.)

title: Bid Likely to Run in Jersey
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 11  Bud Delp, trainer of Spectacular Bid, said today that if the weights satisfy me the 3yearold colt will race In next Thursday's $250,000 added Meadowlands Cup, the richest race of the New Jersey track's meeting.

title: Brooklyn Factory Fire Under Control but Still Burning
Margin Debt Declines
description: Margin customers reduced the indebtedness to brokers slightly in September, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday. The exchange said

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: The Mayor, the Johns and the Judges
description: Mayor Koch's attack on judges for being soft on johns, the male customers of female prostitutes, makes us wonder once again what license he claims for his repeated assaults on the city's judiciary.

title: Kennedy Shifts Have Put Fire in Carter Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  Senator Edward M. Kennedy stirred enormous political excitement a month ago with his dramatic switch from noncandidate to nearcandidate for the Presidency in 1980, but paradoxically, President Carter's reelection campaign since then has done more to seize the political initiative, at least for the short run.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Technology column in Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported the disposition of the stock in the Unitrode Corporation held by Schlumberger Ltd. Schlumberger has agreed with the Federal Trade Commission to dispose of its holdings in Unitrode within one year or to seek approval of a plan to sell off certain product lines of the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation that may compete with Unitrode.

title: Dorothy Collins;Sings Sondheim
description: She was America's singing sweetheart in the midI950's, when she wore her trademark highnecked blouse with the little black tie and sang such simple songs as Too Young, Shrimp Boats and Harbor Lights.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as shown.(N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Dance: Two Premieres By Jennifer Muller
description: JENNIFER MULLER and the Works presented two dance premieres by Miss Muller on Wednesday night at the City Center 55thStreet Theater. One was passable, and the other was impossible.

title: Tight Money: How and Why Of New Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  Last Saturday, in a dramatic evening news conference, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, disclosed a package of steps, including higher interest rates, intended to curb inflation, rescue the dollar and halt rampant speculation in commodities. Since then, financial markets both at home and abroad have been in turmoil.

title: London Times Talks Are Stalled
description: LONDON, Oct. 11  The Times of London management and one key union remained deadlocked tonight on the terms under which the paper would resume publication after nearly 10 months.

title: Balloonists Ignore Warning And Die in Plunge to Earth
description: Two balloonists participating in the eighth annual International Hot Air Balloon Fiesta in Alburquerque, N.M., on Tuesday were killed when their craft ran into gusty wind currents, causing it to collapse and catch fire upon impact. Richard Temple and Kathy Wiley, both of California, were reportedly warned about unstable winds before attempting their flight.

title: War Tragedies Focus
description: FRANKFURT, Oct. 11  A number of publishers at the International Book Fair are banking on the hope that the reading public still desires serious nonfiction on major themes and personalities. Among the newsmaking titles are books on political figures, the Pope, economics, Fascism and freedom, and peace and war  including the horrors of the Nazi era and the atomic bomb.

title: COMMODITIES Gold Futures Wane; Copper and Lumber Off
description: Gold futures fell yesterday after large gold auction attracted less bidding than expected and bullion prices dropped on world markets. Copper, lumber and interest rate futures fell for the fourth straight day in anticipation of tighter credit.

title: DelBello Asks Inquiry On Con Ed Campaign Against New Agency
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 11  The Westchester County Executive, Alfred B. Del. Bello, asked the New York State Board of Elections today to investigate whether Consolidated Edison was bringing improper pressure on its employees to contribute funds to defeat his plan to create a new agency to study a public ownership of the utility.

title: I.B.M. Net Falls 18%
description: The International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday an 18 percent decline in thirdquarter earnings on a revenue increase of only 1.9 percent.

title: For Children
description: THE MUSICAL STORYTELLER; a program of original stories and classic fairy tales, told by Vivian Farrell, with background music, including selections by Beethoven, Paderewski and others, Saturday at 12:30 P.M., at The Library and Museum of the Performing Arts, Lincoln Center, in the Bruno Walter Auditorium. Free.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 11 (AP)  Subcontracts totaling more than $1 billion were signed today with four companies that will help the Boeing Company build its newgeneration 757 airliner, the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company said.

title: Award to Tomjanovich Is Reduced by $125,000
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 11 (AP)  Judge John V. Singleton of United States District Court cut $125,000 yesterday from the $3.25 million that a jury awarded Rudy Tomjanovich for injuries suffered when he was hit in the face by Kermit Washington of the Los Angeles Lakers during a basketball game two years ago.

title: Dorothy Arzner Is Dead at 82; Directed in Hollywood in the 30's
description: Dorothy Arzner, Hollywood's lone woman director in the 1930's and 40's, who guided such stars as Katharine Hepburn, Ruth Chatterton, Clara Bow, Rosalind Russell, Fredric March, Sylvia Sidney and Merle Oberon in many notable films, died Oct. 1 in La Quinta, Calif., where she lived in retirement. She was 82 years old.

title: The Pop Life
description: BLONDIE is an interesting band, and its fourth record, Eat to the Beat, does nothing to diminish that interest. One thing that calls attention to the group is its origins in the netherworld of Manhattan underground punkart rock, its ascension to commercial predominance and the way it stills retains its connections to vanguard status.

title: Bert Lance's Fraud Trial On Jan. 14 Is Proposed
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 11 (UPI)  A Federal magistrate today recommended a Jan. 19 trial date for Bert Lance, the former United States Budget Director, and three codefendants charged with bank fraud, and denied a motion to dismiss the case under the Speedy Trial Act.

title: Kuwait Oil Is Expected To Be Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  Administration officials are saying privately that they expect Kuwait to join other major producers in cutting exports and reducing oil output next year, thus posing a new threat to world petroleum supplies.

title: Connally Urges Israelis to Leave Occupied Lands
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 John B. Connally, urging a new approach in the Middle East, today proposed a broad plan that seeks Israeli withdrawal from virtually all of the West Bank, Gaza Strip and Golan Heights, as well as Palestinian selfdetermination in the region.

title: Eilberg Loses Insurance License
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 11 (AP) The state today revoked the insurance license of former Representative Joshua Eilberg of Philadelphia. Mr. Eilberg has already been disbarred by the disciplinary board of the State Supreme Court after his guilty plea to charges of receiving illegal compensation for services rendered before a Federal agency.

title: Sindona Seeking Cash, Police in Rome Report
description: ROME, Oct. 11 (Reuters) Police sources said today that Michele Sindona, the missing Italian financier, had asked his Rome lawyer for a passport and a large amount of money to free him from his kidnappers. But the police still give little credence to the kidnap claim, which followed Mr. Sindona's disappearance in New York on Aug. 2

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Robert Dingilian, worldwide vice president of publicity and promotion at the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation, has informed the company that he will leave when his contract expires on Dec. 31. According to Hollywood sources, Mr. Dingilian intends to join the Ladd Company, an independent filmmaking corporation established by Alan Ladd Jr., who resigned recently as president of Fox in a conflict with its chairman and chief executive officer, Dennis C. Stanfill.

title: Philippine Tribesmen Said to Kill 29 Farmers in Mountain Uprising
description: DAVAO, the Philippines, Oct. 11 (AP)  Ata tribesmen wielding spears, knives and arrows have killed 29 settlers in the mountains of Mindanao, the southernmost Philippine island, according to Government spokesman.

title: Deaths
description: BROWNJohn Nicholas, October 9, 1979 In Annapolis, Md. Husband of Ann Kinsolving Brown. Residence Harbor Court, Ha!Won Ave, Newport, R.I., and Providence, R.I. Funeral services will be held Friday, October 12 at 4:30 in Emmanuel Church, Newport. Funeral services will also be held on Saturday in Providence, R.I. In St. Stephen's Church, George St, at noon.

title: Opera: Sarah Caldwell Conducts Falstaff
description: Back in business after its labor dispute, the New York City Opera resumed operations Thursday night with its new production of Verdi's Falstaff. It was new to the City Opera, premiere under the auspices of the Boston Opera Company, that doughty company directed by Sarah Caldwell, who conducted Thursday night's perormance.

title: Joyce Trisler, 45, Choreographer, Modern Dancer and a Teacher
description: Joyce Trisler, modem dancer, choreographer and teacher, was found dead of a heart attack Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 45 years old.

title: A Rise in Disbarments In New York Reported
description: ALBANY, Oct. 12 (UPI)  More lawyers were disbarred or reprimanded in New York State in 1978 than in 1977, according to the State Bar Association.

title: Wagner Chosen A Deputy Mayor Quietly by Koch; He Will Retain, for Now, His ?lanning Unit Post
description: Robert F. Wagner Jr. will quietly move in Monday as the new Deputy Mayor for Policy while remaining, at least for a short time, the chairman of the City Planning Commission.

title: Juanita Castro Comes to Town To Portray Brother as a Tyrant
description: Juanita Castro, younger sister of the Cuban President, denounced her brother today as a tyrant and exhorted Cuban exiles to continue the struggle to free their homeland.

title: French Postcards Movie To Open at the Baronet
description: French Postcards, a film about a group of American students spending their junior year in Paris, will open Friday at the Baronet Theater. Marie France Pisier and Jean Rochefort are the stars of the film, which also features a cast of young American and French actors.

title: Alice Helpern Wed To Dr. Elliot Gross
description: Alice Helpern of New York, daughter of the late Dr. Milton Helpern and the late Ruth Vyner Helpern, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Elliot M. Gross, Chief Medical Examiner of New York. He is a son of the late Dr. Samuel Gross, a police surgeon in New York, and the late Mrs. Gross.

title: Turks Vote Tomorrow May Decide Whether Ecevit Can Stay in Power
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 12  Troubled by continued political violence and increasing economic ills, Turks vote Sunday in five lowerhouse byelections that could determine whether the Government of Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit can stay in power.

title: State Union Installs Officer
description: James J. Gripper Jr., a supervising electrician at the Brooklyn Development Center, was installed last night as president of the Metropolitan Region of the New York State Civil Service Employes Association.

title: The New York Times
description: Earl Weaver, of Orioles, bottom left, seeking explanation from Russ Goetz, plate umpire, after a balk was called on his pitcher, Scott McGregor.

title: LateTax Interest Up
description: WASHINGTON. Oct 12 (Reuters) The Internal Revenue Service, taking note of inflation, today doubled from 6 to 12 percent the interest rate taxpayers must pay if they are late with their payments, effective Feb. 1, 1980.

title: Town Is Divided on How to Rebuild After Hurricane
description: GULF SHORES, Ala., Oct. 10  Mike Miceli, whose grocery store was damaged by Hurricane Frederic, just couldn't keep quiet when the architect from Birmingham proposed a 90day study on how to rebUild this resort town and several Town Councilmen nodded approvingly at the architect's suggestion.

title: Helping the Handicapped in Daily Life
description: How do you put on stockings when you can't bend over to pull them up? What is the easiest way to clean a bathtub if you are unable to bend down? Can you waterski if you are blind? If you are on crutches, can you keep an exuberant toddler from running free on the street?

title: Letters The Fed's Road to Depression
description: To the Editor:

title: Australia Seeks U.S. Settlers
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 12 (Reuters)  Australia wants to attract more migrants from the United States, especially professional people and entrepreneurs, Immigration Minister Michael MacKellar said here today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BERRY BONANZA With a harvest nip in the autumn air, one of Brooklyn Heights most picturesque byways, Cranberry Street, will take on a countyfair ambience today, with a Cranberry Festival. The public is invited, from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., to the rustic familystyle activities enlivening the threeblock area extending from Henry Street to Columbia Heights, which runs into the waterfront esplanade. There will be various produce booths, live music and entertainment, children's activities  with an emphasis on cranberry products. Scheduled for noon is a competitive bakeoff, with homemade cranberrybased entries from 30 proud male cooks who reside in the area. Squaredancing will go on throughout, climaxed by the crowning of a cranberry queen from the neighborhood. There will also be free cranberry drinks and refreshments, with an assist from Ocean Spray Cranberries Inc., the Farmers Cooperative, which has donated products to the event. Proceeds from the fair will aid in the beautification of Cranberry Street.

title: BabyFood Industry Agrees to a Curb On the Promotion of Infant Formulas
description: GENEVA, Oct. 12 Representatives of the babyfood industry, at a conference sponsored by the World Health Organization and the United Nations Children's Fund, subscribed today to a call for a ban on all sales promotion that would discourage breastfeeding.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Senate Panel Defeats Attempt to Delay Arms Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12  In an unannounced vote, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee defeated yesterday a motion that it postpone action on the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union. Senate sources said today.

title: Credit Pinch Is Hurting the Plans Of Sellers and Buyers of Homes
description: With mortgage credit tightening in the New York metropolitan area, sellers and buyers of homes have begun to feel the exasperation, disappointment, inconvenience, uncertainty and worry that are the inevitable human corollaries of a credit squeeze.

description: NNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY II TELEPHONED TAD 3544900 urrni. 5:30 P.M. F011 WEEKDA)94. MONS. UNTIL :30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. EIRINDAY THROUGH ATE RIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 34900; WESTCHISTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) P1JJNS 94300; NASSAU CO. (516) 74741600; SUFFOLK CO. (316) 66941100; CONNECT1CVT (203) 348475T.

title: Mexico, U.S. and Canada Linked By 4.6Mile Road Completing 15
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 12 (AP) More than 3,000 people streamed to ceremonies today opening the final link in a 1,380mile freeway that stretches from Mexico to Canada.

title: K.G.B. Is Said to Search 2 Dissident Apartments
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 12 (AP)  The Soviet security police have searched two apartments of dissidents here, raising fear of a new crackdown against human rights activists, Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet dissident leader, said today.

title: Investors Leave Credit Markets To the Traders
description: The bond market recovered perhaps a sixth of its recent severe losses yesterday as traders assessed the severe batterin2 it had taken this week.

title: Castro Costs New York $170,000 in Two Days
description: The cost of overtime for 2,000 New York City policemen assigned to guard President Fidel Castro of Cuba totaled $170,000 for Thursday and yesterday, the first two days of his visit to the United States, a Police Departmept spokesman reported. The Secret Service, citing security considerations, declined to comment on its costs.

title: Opera Terms Are Delineated
description: Although the ratification vote by the orchestra musicians of the New York City Opera was again postponed yesterday, this time to the first intermission of tonight's performance of Rigoletto, the terms of the tentative agreement between the company and its orchestra were revealed yesterday by Max Arons, president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians.

title: GERMANS UNCERTAIN ON BREZHNEV OFFER
description: BONN, Oct. 12  A week after Leonid I. Brezhnev's speech in East Berlin on European security, the first signs are appearing in West Germany of divergences on how to deal with the Soviet initiative.

title: Orioles Win, 84, and Lead Series, 21
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12  The wet and windy weather that has hounded the 76th World Series all week interrupted game 3 for more than an hour tonight, but it did not prevent the Baltimore Orioles from overpowering the Pittsburgh Pirates, 84, and moving one game in front.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Compromise Is Voted On a Key Money Bill; Senate Accepts Raise
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12  Congress narrowly averted a severe curtailment of some Government operations today by approving a compromise money bill that had been stalled for weeks in a deadlock over abortion and Congressional pay.

title: Chargers Benirschke Ill, Won't Play This Season
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 12 (AP)  Rolf Benirschke, a placekicker with the San Diego Chargers, learned today that he's out of professional football this season after surgery that removed a diseased portion of his bowels.

title: Spectacular Bid In Jersey Stakes
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct 12 (AP)  Spectacular Bid, runnerup to Affirmed in last Saturday's Jockey Club Gold Cup, will run in next Thursday's $350,000 Meadowlands Cup.

title: Ballet: Puerto Rico Troupe
description: The Puerto Rican Dance Theater, which opened at Riverside Church on Thursday night for a run through tomorrow afternoon, has changed remarkably since its founding nine years ago by Julio Torres.

title: United Press International
description: BIRD SCORES IN DEBUT: Larry Bird of Boston scoring his first regularseason basket as a professional last night. He triggered a crucial secondhalf surge in Celtics 114106 victory over Houston.

title: Senate Passes Measure For $8.1 Billion in Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI)  The Senate approved an $8.1 billion foreignaid money bill today after voting to prohibit giving help to any country in the Western Hemisphere that does not oppose hostile foreign combat troops on its soil.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, Oct. 12,1979

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Broken multilayered clouds, Including scattered rain clouds, extend In a band from northem New England over most of the northeastern states through the Intermountain region. Streaks of high and midlevel clouds are visible over Florida and the Southwest.

title: The U.N.N.Y. Marriage
description: Some foreign diplomats want to move most, if not all, of the United Nations out of New York and into the new United Nations complex in Vienna or elsewhere, the press has reported. Some New Yorkers would say good riddance.

title: A Familiar Jewelry Emporium Arrives On 5th Ave.
description: Max and Clara Fortimoff started it all under the elevated subway tracks in Brooklyn in 1922. Now Fortunoff, the jewelry and silver retail emporium, has moved to Fifth Avenue, where it opened yesterday.

title: Memorial at Juilliard
description: A memorial tribute to Renee Longy, who died last May at the age of 81, will be held next Thursday at 5 P.M. In the JuilBard Theater at Lincoln Center. For more than 30 years she taught many famous musicians at Juilliard and the Curtis Institute. Two former students who are now conductors, Leonard Bernstein and James Conlon, who is also president of Juilliard, will take part in the service, along with Peter Mennin and the Athena String Quartet.

title: NATO Group Backs Missile Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12  The Atlantic Treaty Association, made up of representatives from the 15 Western allies, gave its approval today to the alliance's plans to deploy new mediumrange nucleararmed missiles in Europe.

title: Concert: Parnassus Performs 2 Davidovsky Pieces
description: Parnassus, a contemporary chambermusic ensemble led by Anthony Korf, came to the Abraham Goodman House Concert Hall on Thursday night to present the first of the three concerts it is giving there this season. The pro gram offered the first New York performance of Mario Davidovsky's Pennplay plus his Synchronism No. 3, Wolpe's Chamber Piece No. 2 and First Quartet and Milhaud's Scaramouche in a windsextet version.

title: Deaths
description: BELCOURTLieut Colonel Paul L. At his residence, suddenly, an Otto. ber 9, 1979. Lieut Colonel Paul L. Beicourt In his seventy:fourth year. Beloved husband of Maud Holland. Residing on Beattie Rd., Cowansvl He, Quebec. Son of the late honorable N. A. Belcourt. The two successive increases were by far the largest this year, with the August figure representing a dramatic revision of an earlier estimate of seventenths of percent.

description: Something is happening in Florida today that has to do with politics. Don't ask me what. It doesn't matter.

description: Mayor Koch deserves praise for stirring New York City officials into action on Coop City's delinquent taxes. None have ever been paid by the Bronx project for middleincome families because residents have for years refused to pay rent increases that are clearly necessary to cover costs. The huge statefunded housing project, which enjoys important tax exemptions, owes the city between $28 million and $38 million.

description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana  Prime Minister Forbes Burnham is facing the gravest challenge in his 15 years of rule, with diverse opposition groups calling for his removal, accusing him of corruption, mismanagement and dictatorlike behavior.

description: DETROIT, Oct. 12 (AP)  The Chrysler Corporation announced prices for its 1980model cars today that it said were about 5.1 percent, or an average of $359, higher than final 1979 sticker prices.

title: Screen: 'The Black Stallion'
description: "The Black Stallion" is a suffocatingly gorgeous adventure movie, which means it isn't very adventuresome at all. A small boy befriends a large horse during a sea voyage, by placing four sugar cubes very, very neatly on the port-hole window of the horse's cabin. The horse eats three. Then their ship sinks, and the horse saves the boy's life, and they wind up on the most picturesque island you've ever seen. The sea shimmers. The rock formations are fabulous. When the horse peers out to sea from atop a high cliff, as the camera sweeps around him to a trumpeting score, he has all the magnificence of a new Buick atop a promontory in Monument Valley.On the beach, the horse gallops and the movie crawls. The director, Carroll Ballard, and the cinematographer, Caleb Deschanel, have captured so many lavishly beautiful images that the cumulative effect is one of repetition. In another context, this sort of glamour might prove more useful  but the source material for "The Black Stallion" is Walter Farley's novel about a young boy's amazing escapades. And it requires more action in the telling, plain and simple.Mr. Ballard's direction, of a story designed to excite the viewer's imagination and curiosity, instead stifles these feelings by emphasizing the cosmetic value of every frame. For all its pretty glimpses of the desert island, the film never offers a clear, overall sense of what the place looks like; neither the camera nor the boy really goes exploring. The boy, played by Kelly Reno, remains quite passive throughout the tale.Later, back home with his mother (Ten Garr) in some unusually perfect version of Small Town, U.S.A., he accepts the loss of one family member (his father, who drowned in the shipwreck) and the addition of another (the horse, now living in the back yard), with so much equanimity he seems a little strange. Freud notwithstanding, the kid ought to be feeling some twinges over the death of his Dad.The best part of "The Black Stallion," which will be shown twice today as part of the New York Film Festival, is the second half, which introduces Mickey Rooney as a retired horse trainer who helps the boy and stallion prepare for a climactic race. Mr. Rooney lends humor and humanity to the proceedings, and he fits surprisingly well into Mr. Ballard's careful scheme."The Black Stallion," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") contains a few mildly violent episodes that might frighten very young children.

description: In a highly emotional setting yesterday in which a formal bankruptcy proceeding turned into a virtual pep rally, a Federal judge postponed the closing of the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12  An Interior Department scientist who asked a local restaurant to stop serving rattlesnake steaks from a possibly endangered species has suddenly found that his own lob is endangered.

description: EL PASO, Oct. 12 (AP)  A 21Yearold soldier, David Leon Wallace, was convicted today of capital murder in the death of Lee Chagra, an El Paso lawyer who was known for his successful defense of narcotics defendants.

title: In Cajun Land, Molytones
description: They's not a man alive can beat my molyfones, says Alcide Verret over his stove. I cooks them nine different ways and they all dilicious. I take two servings of this strange fruit, which hangs in green softballs from a vine outside Alcide's door, and they are delicious. Like most Acadian men, Alcide Verret is a cook and proud of it. The only thing different about Alcide is that he lives in the middle of the Atchafalaya Swamp in south Louisiana, and he has lived there all his life.

title: Coal Company Wins $1.2 Million In Suit Over 7778 U.M.W. Strike
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 (AP)  A Federal jury awarded $1.2 million Thursday to a nonunion stripmine concern that had sued the United Mine Workers for an alleged secondary boycott and violence in the 197778 national coal strike.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12  Senators Howard H. Baker Jr. and Bob Dole today accused John B. Connally, a fellow Republican Presidential hopeful, of seeking. to trade Israeli security for Arab oil.

title: In Dallas, Big Party Precedes the Big Game
description: DALLAS, Oct. 12  There wasn't a stick of furniture, a potted palm or a standing ash tray in the lobby of the Adolphus Hotel by midafternoon today. Workers had put away anything that was not tied down. Nearby stores and restaurants along Commerce Street hired special guards to protect life and property tonight.

title: The Man From Havana
description: It's a long time between Cuba libres. Five American Presidents have served and gone since Fidel Castro last turned Manhattan into a policeman's nightmare. His visit in 1960 signaled a dramatic shift. He arrived a still ambiguous revolutionary but left an avowed ally of the Soviet Union, whose Prime Minister, Nikita Khrushchev, he embraced in a Harlem hotel.

description: ALBANY, Oct. 12 (AP)  A state board today rejected plans to build two huge nuclear generating plants at New Haven, N.Y., on the shore of Lake On tario, marking the first action in the Carey administration's moratorium on the development of nuclear power.

title: U.S. Accused of Spy Flight
description: TOKYO, Oct. 12 (UPI)  North Korea, accused the United States today of flying a highaltitude spy plane over its tenttory in a grave military provocation. The official North Korean press agency said that an SR71 plane made two flights yesterday over the eastern coast of North Korea near the demilitarized zone at the border of the two Koreas.

title: Bridge:
description: RIO DE JANIERO, Oct. 12  The lead changed hands in the sixth round of the World Team Championship here this afternoon when the United States lost 7 to 13 against a Brazilian squad that rallied after a bad start. It was a match of wild slam deals that included an American small slam that succeeded, with help from the defense, with two aces missing, and an American grand slam missing the ace of trumps.

title: For Bushwick Kids, Year of the Child? Ha.
description: I thought it would be a good idea to ask some children what they thought about their year  the International Year of the Child. I began by interviewing children I knew. Unfortunately they were all cute, white, mid dleclass Upper East Siders whose responses were fairly predictable. So one humid day in late June I took my tape recorder and list of questions to Central Park in search of a crosssection of city kids.

title: New I.C.C. Chief Selected

Gaskins Jr., an economist he nominated to the Interstate Commerce Commission earlier this year, as I.C.C. chairman, succeeding Daniel O'Neal, who is to resign Dec. 31. Mr. Gaskins, 40 years old, previously served as deputy assistant Energy Secretary for policy analysis, director of economic analysis for the Civil Aronautics Board, director of economics for the Federal Trade Commission, and professor of economics at the University of California at Berkeley.

title: Forgotten Veterans Remembered

A recent study, financed but only grudgingly released by the Veterans Administration, seems to confirm their anguish. This week, four senators introduced a modern version of the G.I. Bill. The measure goes a long way toward paying an obvious debt.

title: What Is a Kent Tekulve?
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12  Relief pitchers come in all shapes, sizes and styles. Goose Gossage cuts down batters the way a lumberjack cuts down trees. Stu Miller was so small that a wind once blew him off the mound. Mike Marshall lectures on kinesiology. Ryne Duren could just about see the plate through his bottlethick glasses. Rothe Fingers waxes his mustache. Hoyt Wilhelm fluttered his knuckleball until he was 49 years old. Sparky Lyle wrote his memoirs. And now there is Kenton Charles Tekulve of the Pittsburgh Pirates, gaunt and gangling, who throws as if he were slipping $5 to a maitre d under the table. Including his two hitless innings in the Pirates 84 loss tonight that moved the Baltimore Orioles into a 21 lead in the World Series, he has appeared in 98 games this year without any apparent distress in his thin right arm.

title: Defeat of Koch's Sanitation Plan Laid to Politics and Fiscal Fears

description: Dr. Katharine Burr Blodgett, a retired General Electric scientist who helped develop a nonreflecting film for glass now used on virtually all lenses in cameras and other optical equipment, died yesterday at her Schenectady home. She was 81 years old.

description: Paul Paray, the French conductor who appeared frequently in New York as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic and other orchestras and was music director of the Detroit Symphony from 1952 to 1963, died Wednesday in Monte Carlo. He was 93 years cid.
