description: The Rev. Dr. Lewis Allen McGee, United States Army chaplain at Bastogne in the Battle of the Bulge, died Wednesday at Memorial Hospital, Pullman, Wash., after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

title: Charter Opens Up Glen Cove Election
description: GLEN COVE, L.I., Oct. 12  Last November the residents of this city on the North Shore of Nassau County narrowly approved a referendum that substantially altered its Charter and opened up elective office to a broader segment of the community.

title: Knicks Inexperience Brings 121104 Loss
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 12  The Atlanta Hawks are no longer a ragtag collection of bargain rejects, as they were once characterized. In beating the Knicks, 121104, in the opening game of the teams National Basketball Association season tonight, they showed themselves to be cohesive, a team that knows how to claw and scratch to victory.

title: Other Nassau Contests Are Safe
description: There may be few safe bets on the results of the City Council race in Glen Cove, but there is little doubt of the outcome of the contests for most major offices in the rest of Nassau County.

title: Illinois Official's Trial Delayed
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (UPI)  The starting date of Attorney General William J. Scott's income tax evasion trial was pushed back today to Jan. 8 to avoid inconveniencing jurors during the holidays. Federal District Judge John Powers Crowley ordered the delay after a status hearing. Lawyers had expected the trial to start in December. Mr. Scott is charged with understating his income on Federal tax returns from 1972 to 1975.

title: Heating Oil Goal Met, Carter Says
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) President Carter announced today that enough home heating oil had been stockpiled for the nation's winter needs and said that he would ask C for $1.2 billion to ease the burden nsosf higher fuel prices on poor people.

title: 60 to Question Carter on Radio
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI)  More than 10,000 people have written to National Public Radio officials asking to be allowed to question President Carter tomorrow, a spokesman for the network said today. The spokesman said that 60 would be selected before the program begins at 2 P.M. tomorrow. Each will be teldphoned and told to stay home for a possible call. The interview will be in the Oval Office.

title: Pact Buoys Hopes of Rural Poor Under Brazil's New Labor Policy
description: RECIFE, Brazil, Oct. 9 Sugar mill owners and fieldworkers in Brazil's impoverished northeast, combatants in violent encounters before the military takeover of 1964, have signed their first labor agreement.

title: A Gamble By Giants Succeeds
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 12  Bobby Hammond is staying home. The Giants gamble of placing their leading punt returner on waivers paid off today when no other National Football League club claimed Hammond. The little halfback from Bayside, Queens, was immediately activated so he can play in Sunday's game here against the San Francisco 99ers.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO END FEDERAL CONTROLS ON GASOLINE PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The House of Representatives voted narrowly today to abolish price controls on gasoline, but House leaders predicted that the issue would be brought up again in an attempt to reverse the action.

title: Dispute Ends on Legacy Of Jersey Murder Victim
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 12  A man who has been questioned as a possible suspect in a triple murder last March in Fair Lawn, N.J., abandoned a court fight today to retain control over the estate of one of the victims, an authority granted him in the victim's will.

title: CRIME
description: Martin Mayer, who writes about banks, television, Madison Avenue, education, the law, Wall Street and a passel of other weighty subjects, has now turned his attention to the suspense novel. In TRIGGERPOINTS (Harper & Row, $9.95) he tells the story of a sniper, an F.B.I. man detailed to break the case, and a varied assortment of characters who may or may not have something to do with the basic plot.

title: A Scholar And a Mystic
description: IN one of Isaac Bashevis Singer's most haunting stories, Yentl the Yeshiva Boy, Yentl, a girl who has been initiated into the pleasures of sacred scholarship by her father, runs away after his death to continue her Talmudic studies at a Yeshiva. Disguised as a boy and calling herself Anshel, she falls in love with her study partner, Avigdor, and he with her. Tragic complications ensue.

title: U. S. Magistrates Get New Powers
description: WASHINGTON THEY are a rare breed in the Federal court system, usually little noticed but now on the threshold of expanded responsibility to help clear dockets more efficiently.

title: Cornell Routs Harvard, 41 to 14
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 13  Cornell's alert defenders blocked one Harvard punt, recovered two fumbles and intercepted two passes today at windy Schoellkopf Field as the Big Red overwhelmed the Crimson, 4114, in an Ivy League game.

title: Mrs. Thatcher's Stern Will Is Respected if Not Yet Loved
description: BLACKPOOL, England  Five months after she took office, British newspapers have settled on nicknames for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Those that like her call her The Headmistress; those that don't call her Attila the Hen. Both names reflect the stern determination with which she has approached her task, and both suggest that she arouses more awe than affection in the nation she leads.

title: The Key to Potting Plants Lies in the Soil
description: WHILE spring is usually a better time to divide and repot house plants, there is always some of it to be done in the fall. Perhaps a plant has outgrown its container during the summer, or a new division or cutting from a plant that has grown too large to be brought indoors may be starting. Whatever the reason, the choice of potting soils is important.

title: Victory Brings Revenge for John Jay
description: Victory was sweet for Coach Ron Lyons of John Jay yesterday. His undefeated Indians not only stretched their winning streak to 11 games with a 170 triumph over Sleepy Hollow, but in doing so they also avenged their only loss in two seasons

title: Mayor Lost Last Week in Battle
description: Seven years ago, with considerable fanfare, Jerome Kretchmer, who then controlled the city's Sanitation Department, stood in Times Square and introduced a 470pound concrete trash basket that was hailed as a major step in controlling that persistent and irritating urban problem street litter.

title: WASHINGTON How Not To Fight Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  President Carter was asked at his latest press conference whether he was prepared to persevere with tightmoney policies even if it began to hurt him politically. Yes .. ., he replied. There's no doubt in my mind . . . that the number one threat to our national economy is inflation. . . . So whatever it takes to control inflation, that's what I will do. .

title: White Students Rally in Boston
description: BOSTON, Oct. 13 (UPI)  White students from English High School charged yesterday that the city had neglected their safety in school and protested against what they called racial violence by blacks.

title: Notes
description: In the old days, couples eager to tie the matrimonial knot might have shuffled off to Buffalo, but in today's Jet age increasing numbers are going much farther afield  to the island of Kauai in Hawaii.

title: Furnishing a Mansion With Flea Market Finds
description: RUMSON IF you live in a 25room mansion, do you have to furnish it with finds from flea markets and furniture outlets? Of course not. But bargain hunters cannot easily change their shopping habits and oh, the thrill of the hunt, when the eye lights on something good, really good, perhaps hidden under years of grime, maybe chipped a bit, but still a find. And now  keep cool  to see how cheaply it can be bought!

title: Radio
description: Today: Leading Events

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BRITTEN IN NEW HAVEN

title: PARIS ON THE DIAGONAL
description: While there are those who would say that Parisian fashion has always been somewhat offcenter, many readytowear collections for spring and summer 1980 are purposely that way. Asymmetrical lines,fabrics cut on the bias, offcenter geometric patterns and accessories With a bit of tilt are the primary elements of what may be the strongest new look of the fashions to be introduced this week in Paris when the French designers take the wraps off their warmweather clothes for next year.

title: Hua Gaoling Criticized In a Peking Wall Poste;
description: PEKING, Oct. 13 (Reuters)  A writer for the most radical of underground journals today accused Prime Minister Hua Guofeng of interfering with the judiciary and prejudging important trials.

title: A Refugee Now Helps Others Begin Anew
description: BRIDGEPORT NANG BOUALOM has lived here for seven years now, first as a student at Sacred Heart University, then, when her native Laos came under a Communistoriented government in 1975, as refugee.

title: Cordless Wall Clocks
description: THERE has been a quiet revolution in the wall clock. Once it was a necessary presence in the kitchen, where it reminded the absentminded cook to time the roast, or on the schoolroom wall, carefully monitored by restless students. But now, often devoid of Arabic numbers and appearing in a range of unusual shapes, the wall clock has become the latest design accessory.

title: A Company's Last Rites
description: WATERFORD, N.Y.  How much am I bid for this tub? asks the auctioneer pacing in front of a huge garment washing machine inside a cavernous factory, deserted except for flocks of pigeons and two dozen bidders who are following the auctioneer from roomtoroom.

title: A.C.L.U., After Defections Over Nazi Case, Is Threatened by Deficit
description: Hy The Associated Press

title: World Series Schedule
description: *if necessary.

title: A New Museum For Children
description: Delilah Lopez celebrated Columbus Day by helping her classmates at Robert F. Wagner Junior High School build a wooden geometric structure at the New Manhattan Laboratory Museum for children under the watchful eye of her instructor, Gerald Segal. The class was demonstrating some of the uses school children throughout the city can make of the facility.

title: Cruise Liners: Resort Hotels That Travel the World
description: AFTER years of being able to pick and choose among cruise ships, and usually on rather short notice, travelers this year are finding that they outnumber the available cabins. They are also finding that if they are luckyenough to get space on the ship of their choice, they are having to pay more about 15 percent more on averagethan they did last season.

title: Orioles Rally to Defeat Pirates, 96, for 31 Edge
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13  The Baltimore Orioles erupted with six runs in the eighth inning today in a remarkable display of pinchhitting to overpower the Pittsburgh Pirates, 96, and move within one game of winning the 76th World Series.

title: Arum Believes Participation, Not Boycotts,
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 13  It is hardly insignificant that barring injury or the unforeseen the World Boxing Association will fill its heavyweight title vacated by the retirement of Muhammad Ali, a week from tonight in Pretoria.

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Pressure on South Korean Chief Grows as 70 Assemblymen Quit
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 13  The leader of the South Korean opposition said today, following the mass resignation of all 70 opposition members from the National Assembly, that their action reflected the will of the majority of Koreans.

title: Families Given Help In New Environment
description: PRIVATE, community and official organizations are giving pragmatic as well as emotional aid to the families of foreign executives, who often have the least to say about a job transfer, but are the most affected by it.

title: Old Bomb Defused in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Oct. 13 (Reuters)  Nearly 2,000 people were evacuated from their homes in a Tokyo suburb today while a World War II bomb was defused. A squad of soldiers took about 30 minutes to defuse the rusted 550pound bomb, found 20 feet underground at a drainage work site. It was the third bomb found near the site of an aircraft manufacturing factory that was a frequent target of American bombings during World War II.

title: What Breaking Away Has Done to Bloomington, Ind.
description: BLOOMINGTON, IND. In a few weeks, 200,000 alumni of Indiana University will receive something unusual in the mail: a 24by30inch color poster, suitable for framing, of scenes from this pastsummer's surprise hit movie, Breaking Away. On the reverse side, positioned so that it is the first thing to hit the eye when the poster is pulled from its envelope, is the following slogan designed to prepare the recipient for the fundraising pitch inside: Breaking Away is pulling us together.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Ramapo Kennel Club allbreed and obedience, Ramapo College of New Jersey, Rte. 202, Mahwah, N.J.; 1,992 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: 8 Million Turks Vote Today in Midterm Elections
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 13  An estimated eight million voters will vote tomorrow in 29 of Turkey's 67 provinces to elect onethird of the Senate and fill five vacancies in the National Assembly.

title: Preservation Movement Comes of Age
description: Last year, an estimated 32 percent of all construction activity in the United States involved rehabilitation, according to a study by Landauer Associates, the real estate consulting firm. While only a small portion of this work involved historic structures, the scope of preservation activity is widening.

title: Stoddard Succeeds On Mound and at Bat
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13  After grabbing John Lowenstein's bat and Ken Singleton's helmet, Tim Stoddard strode to the ondeck circle in the eighth inning of the fourth game of the World Series today.

title: Chamber Ensembles Enjoy a Boom
description: It seems like only yesterday that chamber music was considered boxoffice poison. Now the art is flourishing  not just string quartets, which have always enjoyed a prestige ranking with audiences, but chamber ensembles of all sizes and with a diverse personnel that can perform music composed for any number of unusual instrumental combinations. Lincoln Center's Chamber Music Society is the most visible and successful in our midst, but there are dozens of others in New York and, indeed, all over the country.

title: 2 Bonn Aides Favor Missile Plan But Also Talks Brezhnev Offered
description: BONN, Oct. 13 (Reuters)  West Germany's defense and foreign ministers said today that the Atlantic alliance should continue with plans to develop and deolov new mediumrange missiles.

title: Portia B. Gordon, Dr. A.K. Ketosugbo Marry in Brooklyn
description: Portia Beverly Gordon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius F. Gordon of Elmhurst, Queens, and Dr. Anukware Kodzo Ketosugbo, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Kwami Ketosugbo of Accra, Ghana, were married yesterday. The Rev. Alfred Harper performed the ceremony in John Wesley United Methodist Church in Brooklyn.

title: County Study Shows Housing Lack in 80's
description: WHITE PLAINS WESTCHESTER in the 1980's will have somewhat fewer residents than does today, especially among those of school age, but with a bigger share of men and women in their working years. They will be looking more and more to towns and villages in the north for housing, and finding it still a scarce commodity.

title: Garcia Runs, Passes New Dorp to Victory
description: New Dorp is one of the last of the New York City teams to play a singlewing offense, and Mike Garcia is the singlewing. He stands a few feet behind center and takes the snap already in passing position. Yesterday, Garcia was a oneman show as he ran for four touchdowns, passed for another and rushed for 215 yards on 28 carries as his undefeated New Dorp team won its third straight, defeating Lehman. 4212.

title: Community Theater Becoming a Hot Ticket
description: OCEANSIDE ANOTHER opening, another show. Anthony Puglise is on stage at Boardman Junior High School here rehearsing for the Theater Guild of Oceanside's production of Mame. But the 26yearold retailer is perplexed. He'shaving trouble with motivation  he can't figure out why he, a messenger delivering a package to Mame, would know that there is a guest room in her apartment.

title: Detroit County Unsure About Pay Next Week
description: DETROIT, Oct. 13 (UPI)  Wayne County, which has been living from weektoweek financially, paid out virtually its last nickel to meet its payroll this week and comply with a court order designed to keep the county courts running.

title: In New York, a Hope for Modest Gain
description: THE 1970's were in many ways the worst of times for finding jobs in the New York area, and while the 1980's are not likely to be the best, they certainly will be better, according to a consensus of experts. These experts, economists from the national and city governments, private banks, and econometric forecasting services, think that the number of jobs in the area will remain about the same or increase slightly.

title: The Marketing of
description: She was born blessed: beautiful, clever and rich, with a family name akin to Croesus. Her birth, on Feb. 20, 1924, was heralded by a headline in The New York Times  R. C. VANDERBILTS HAVE A DAUGHTER  and an article that chronicled her distinguished lineage: greatgreatgranddaugnter of Commodore Cornelius vanderbilt, founder of a vast railroad fortune, and granddaughter of Cornelius 2d, who built The Breakers, the most sumptuous of Newport's summer cottages.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Emil Gilels is giving a piano recital tomorrow night in Carnegie Hall. Perhaps the only unusual thing about his recital is that he is giving a recital. The Soviet leadership seems to be uneasy these days, what with the recent wellpublicized defections, and the authorities are cancelling performances of visiting organizations. Only a few weeks ago the American tour of the Moscow State Symphony was cancelled at the last minute.

title: This Land Is Our Land, Say Both Rhodesia's Blacks, Whites
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia  The African people were removed from their land, Joshua Nkomo, coleader of the Patriotic Front guerrilla alliance, said in London last week. Land Is what we have fought the war over.

title: Belief in the Goodness of People
description: ONE day last week my husband asked me to read a letter from David Goldberger, the American Civil Liberties Union lawyer who defended freedom of speech for the people in Illinois who call themselves Nazis. The letter presented adetailed explanation of the reasons the organization had for defending the right to march in Skokie, and asked us to continue our support.

title: INSIDE IRAN'S CULTURAL REVOLUTION
description: It was 4 o'clock in the morning, but hundreds of men and women crowded the stark, gray departure terminal of the Mehrabad Airport, waiting for the call to board their flight out of Iran. The young Iranian banker tried desperately not to show his nervousness. He studiously avoided the eyes of the fearsome, bearded Pasdars. the Islamic Revolutionary Guards, who roamed the terminal. In his khaki trousers and white shirt, a dayold stubble covering his face, he blended well with the crowd. His Pierre Cardin suit had been left at home.

title: New Law On Drugs Looms
description: OYSTER BAY PROMPTED by the failure of the State Legislature to pass statewide laws restricting the sale of drug paraphernalia, the Town of Oyster Bay is moving to adopt strict ordinances against socalled head shops.

title: Clown Describes the Laborious Side of His Trade
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 13 (AP)  Clowning around is one part greasepaint and 99 parts elbow grease, says Frosty Little, the 52yearold boss clown for the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus.

title: Can the United States Afford Bigger Defense Obligations?; Big Plans, Small Budget
description: WASHINGTON  Zbigniew Brzezinski gave a lecture at the Atlantic Treaty Association last week. Since 1945, the United States has been the pivotal element in the maintenance of global stability, he declared.

title: Topics Running Past Reason
description: Wheelchair athletes often train their upper bodies until they more than compensate for lost legs. Bob Hall, for instance, wheeled through a 26mile marathon this year in 2 hours 7 minutes 11 seconds, running an average mile in less than 5 minutes and beating every footracer.

title: Stage: Nightingale
description: NEW BRUNSWICK TOBACCO ROAD, the Depressionera play that was the third longestrunning show in Broadway history (surpassed only by Fiddler on the Roof and Life with Father),is receiving a crisp and sleekly professional revival at the George Street Playhouse.

title: Broncos, Chiefs Set For Battle of Basics
description: There will be few subtleties in the offensive game plans of the Denver Broncos and the Kansas City Chiefs, opponents today in the contest to be televised here by Channel 4 starting at 4 P.M. The two teams are tied with San Diego for first place in the Western Division of the American Conference, each sporting a 42 wonlost record. Both sides will probably elect to slug it out on the ground and Kansas City almost certainly will.

title: In Losing Clubhouse, A Helpless Feeling
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13  Earth, Wind and Fire played on the stereo system under the Pirate skullandcrossbone flag in the center of the clubhouse: party music without the party.

title: Clue to Oil From Sunken Tanker Off U.S. Coast Points to Scotland
description: NARRAGANSETT, R.I., Oct. 13 (AP)  Almost three years after the Argo Merchant sank off New England, a clue has turned up in Scotland that may indicate where the tanker's 7.7 million gallons of oil went.

title: SportsMedicine Center Comes to the Area
description: STORRS WHETHER by broken records or broken bones, sports and medicine are becoming more closely linked every day. Worldclass athletes are not the only ones pursuing physical superiority through science. More andmore people with the serious goal of selfimprovement are talking not only of good food, equipment and conditions, but also of muscle biopsy, aerobic capacity and pulmonary ventilation.

title: Other Ideas &Trends
description: An administrative law judge for the Federal Trade Commission has ordered BristolMyers Co., the makers of Bufferin and Excedrin, not just to stop saying their tablets are gentler or more effective than plain aspirin but to proclaim that they are not. BristolMyers has said it will appeal the decision to the full F.T.C., but if Judge Montgomery L. Hyuns ruling is upheld, future Bufferin and Excedrin ads will have to include such statements as Bufferin has not been proved to be gentler to the stomach than aspirin. The original F.T.C. complaint against BristolMyers was filed in February, 1973.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The upcoming sale of the John Work Garrett Collection is being hailed as a numismatic landmark  it will be a fourpart auction during which records could be shattered at almost every rap of the gavel. Even if no records are actually broken, the sale's place in history is still secure.

title: Golf Club's Tradition Undergoing Change
description: HASTINGSONHUDSON ST. ANDREW'S GOLF CLUB, the oldest in the country, takes pride in its traditions and customs, passed on as pleasant reminiscences from year to year, generation to generation and member to member.

title: Letters TO THE EDITOR
description: Alan Riding's article (Facing the Reality of Mexico, Sept. 16) was a thoughtful and stimulating analysis of an ex citing country, which those of us who live here find endlessly fascinating.

title: Marriage Announcement 14  No Title
description: Kathleen Pottick Has Bridal

title: DUMPING OF SLUDGE IN SOUND CRITICIZED
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 13  The director of a Federal agency that evaluates marine pollution warned today that the continued dumping of toxic dredged materials in Long Island Sound by the Army Corps of Engineers could have longterm consequences.

title: Rogers, Aoki in Golf Final
description: WENTWORTH, England, Oct. 13 (AP)  Bill Rogers of the United States and Isao Aoki, the defender from Japan, posted victories in lengthy matches today and advanced to the 36hole final of the World Match Play championship tomorrow. First prize is $64.500.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I don't know about the price of real estate in your town, but in Manhattan it has become laughable, unless you are a buyer, in which case it is cryable. A New Yorker I know recently offered the $450,000 asking price for a row house he had been renting, only to be told a few days later that somebody else had topped his bid with an otter of $600,000. This was not stage money they were talking about. It was legal tender.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today  TAB Corvette Association swap meet; at T.A. Byrne Chevrolet, 175 North Bedford Road (Route 117), Mount Kisco, N.Y., starting at 10 A.M.

title: Focus on Orient In Newark Show
description: NEWARK ASHOW called Collector's Choice: Chinese Export Porcelain from New Jersey Collections will open at the Newark Museum on Oct. 27.

title: The Ups and Downs Of Window Painting
description: PAINTING conventional doublehung windows (the kind that slide up and down) has always been somewhat of a problem for the doityourself painter. Not only do you have to worry about trying to keep paint off the glass, there is alsothe oftenconfusing problem of figuring out what sequence to follow so that all parts of both the upper and the lower sash will get painted without skipping any strips of molding  and without getting paint all over your hands as you repeatedly move the sash frames up and down.

title: Letters
description: Play the China Card

title: Arizona State U. Dismisses Kush
description: PHOENIX, Oct. 13 (UPI) Frank Kush, in his 22d year as football coach at Arizona State University, was dismissed today as a result of a $1 million lawsuit naming him and the university as defendants.

title: Living in a Garage: Challenge on a Small Scale
description: IN the days when the rich had both numerous automobiles and numerous servants, they often built spacious garages for the one and cramped quarters above for the other. But in the last 15 years the big estates in the suburbs of New York City have been subdivided, and increasingly the garages are being sold separately from the large main houses they once served.

title: Poland Reported to Try a Priest For Illegal Building of a Church
description: WARSAW, Oct. 13 (AP)  A Roman Catholic priest, the Rev. Adam Michalski, went on trial today on charges of erecting a church illegally in his diocese at Przemysl in southeastern Poland, dissident sources here said.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: Twenty years ago, this book would have seemed ludicrous. With the very term radicala scare word in the 1950's, the notion of a resurgent Left in America would have seemed absurd.

title: The Newark of Old: It Continues to Live
description: AT THE New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue, an autobiography about growing up in Newark in the 1940's and 50's can be found in the Travel Section, nestled there among other reminiscences of exotic and longlost places.

title: RECRUITING INQUIRY BY ARMY NEARS END
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 The Army is nearing an end to a nationwide investigation of recruiting abuses that has already resulted in three officers and 162 sergeants being relieved of duty, a drop in enlistments in some areas and the beginning of reforms.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, Oct. 13 (UPI)  Rhodesia's former Prime Minister, Ian D. Smith, flew back to London today and accused Britain of pandering to the Patriotic Front at the constitutional conference.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Sprawled on a sofa in his suite at the SherryNetherland Hotel, Hunter Thompson recounted the deeds he had perpetrated a couple of days before at another of New York's luxury hotels.

title: A Life Of Purpose
description: MARVELLA BAYH, the wife of Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana, died of bone cancer in Washington, D.C., on April 24, 1979. She was 46 years old. Those who saw her, even near the end, described her as radiantly beautiful, uplifted by a faith that gave her serenity and the courage to go on. As late as March 2, 1979, Mrs. Bayh spoke on behalf cancer patients before an audience in Charlottesville, Va. In October 1978, with half a year of life left to her, she protested that she had never, ever said, as had been reported, that she was dying of cancer. What she said was, I am living with the knowledge that I have cancer. And my life is rather normal.

title: Carey Wins New Hyde Park Rivalry by Extra Point
description: Carey and New Hyde Park are both in the Sewanhaka Central District. That's where the closeness ends. A bitter rivalry exists between their athletic teams and yesterday was no exception when they played a Conference III game on Carey's field in Franklin Square. The result was a come frombehind 76 victory for the Carey Seahawks, who now have won four of their last five meetings.

title: Long Island / This Week
description: BROOKVILLE  Collages by John Digby; noon to 5 P.M. weekdays; 2 to 5 P.M. weekends; through Oct. 28; Hutchins Gallery, Schwartz Library, C. W. Post Center.

title: Farmingdale Record Is Still Unblemished
description: Undefeated and unscoredupon Farmingdale yesterday notched its 12th straight shutout, routing Massapequa, 360, in a Conference I game at Farmingdale. The Dalers last loss was in 1977 when they bowed to Syosset, 146. It was also the last time they gave up a point.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Bergen Catholic Rallies, 129
description: John Azelby cracked 4 yards in the fourth period to cap a nineplay, 71yard drive that boosted undefeated Bergen Catholic past previously unbeaten Montclair, 129, at Oradel.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  Overpack Riding Center, Fort Lee Road, Leonia, N.J. Local, novice, adult amateur and children's working hunters; equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: A Scorecard on Affirmative Action
description: IN that midsummer of the mid1960's, when almost anything seemed possible, President Johnson declared that the Federal Government was moving beyond the opening of opportunities for minorities to seek equality as a fact and equality as a result. And so there followed, after the CivilRights Act of 1964, which outlawed discrimination on the basis of race, sex, national origin or religion, a barrage of executive orders and federally induced affirmativeaction programs designed to give minorities and women a special boost in their climb from the bottom of the economic barrel.

title: PRESIDENT STRESSES FUEL CONSERVATION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  President Carter said today that the No. 1 reliance of United States energy policy was on conservation and that the nation was being forced to turn to increased production of domestic energy sources as a last resort.

title: Drug Search by Dogs Is Allowed While Use by School Is Appealed
description: HAMMOND, Ind., Oct. 13 (AP) Federal district judge has ruled that the Highland school system may continue to use dogs to search for drugs while the American Civil Liberties Union appeals the case.

title: The Big Apple Is Keeping Pincay Fat
description: Ten minutes before the race, the bettors at Belmont Park were flocking to Laffit Pincay's mount like moths to a light bulb. They had already made an evenmoney favorite out of Dance Scout, a $14,000 claimer claimed by Frank (Pancho) Martin. But Martin looked a little worried in the soggy paddock as he gave Pincaysome lastminute instructions. This was not Affirmed, the golden champion whose victory in the $375,000Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont a week ago yesterday sent Pincay's 1979 purse earnings spiraling to a record $6.3 million. This was just another cheap horse, one more warm body on the merrygoround of everyday racing. Dance Scout would be competing against other ordinary claimers for the winner's share of a $10,000 purse.

title: A Guide for Using Wood Stoves Safely
description: WITH the cost of fuel rising so dramatically, the heating of private houses this winter has become a major financial burden. For this reason, as well as for ecological and aesthetic ones, many people have traded their kilowatts for woodpiles, and portions of their central heating for an oldfashioned wood stove.

title: Bonnie Butcher Wed to Lawyer
description: The Wilton (Conn.) Congregational Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Helen Catherine Butcher to John Stebbins Bennet. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Zdenek Bednar.

title: Urban League Chief Assails Blacks Who Made Overtures to the P.L.O.
description: Vernon E. Jordan Jr., in a speech scheduled for delivery tomorrow, castigates other black civil rights leaders for their recent approaches to the Palestine Liberation Organization, calling such initiatives sideshows compared with vital survival issues that blacks face.

title: Updating a Bathroom With New Fixtures
description: THE mere thought of remodeling a bathroom, which costs a minimum of $3,500 and a month's patience, can hurl a homeowner into the slough of despond.

title: Guidelines Board: Eight Citizens In a NoWin Job
description: Before the hearing, angry demonstrators waved picket signs and chanted protest slogans. Later, when one of them was testifying, the committee's lawyer pulled the plug on the microphone, saying the man's time had run out. Finally, after a policewoman was brought in, the man stepped down, shouting, You're pulling the plug on America.

title: Guarding Notables Makes Secret Service Very Public
description: WASHINGTON  Wherever the President and the Vice President go, they are there, in the crowds, behind dark glasses on sunny days or soberfaced under grim skies, so unobtrusively dressed it is impossible to miss them. Secret Service agents, with their tiny earphones and identification buttons and a watchfulness that rarely focuses directly on their charge, see Amy Carter to school. They watch over Mrs. Cartergiving speeches, Mrs. Mondale at art exhibits, the Vice President in China and an increasing number of foreign dignitaries visiting this country.

title: The Other Albers
description: HARTFORD ANNI Albers was recently made an honorary doctor of fine arts at the University of Hartford. Appropriately, her degree is now being confirmed  and the campus enlivened  by a show of her prints.

title: I Can Sit and Cry All Day
description: When Naomi S. was 83 years old, she decided she was a burden to her children. She stopped eating, went to bed and got weaker and weaker. Eventually, she said she wanted to go into a nursing home. She had a little money from the sale of her home, and her children were able to get her into a nursing home immediately as a private paying patient.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: OF the $700,000 that Consolidated Edison has spent so far to defeat County Proposition 1, $8,300 has gone for communications to its employees, management personnel and stockholders, asking for their support on the issue, according to the utility's filing with the Board of Elections.

title: Chrysler's No. 2 Driver from Ford
description: DETROIT  In his 30 years at the Ford Motor Company, J. Paul Bergmoser compiled a respectable record. He rose to the position of vice president for purchasing before he called it a day in 1976 and moved to Palm Springs, Calif., to retire.

title: Bilingual Class Offers Lesson in Enrichment
description: HEMPSTEAD THERE was a line at Carmen deLopez's desk at the Fulton Avenue Elementary School in Hempstead. Some of her thirdand fourthgrade students held papers with the title Bus Safety Rules. Others had written in careful script letters the top, Reglas de Cuidado en el Bus. They were all doing the same assignment, some in English and others in Spanish, as part of a bilingual program that educators rank as the most progressive on the land

title: Soviet Grain Sale May Be A Universal CrowdPleaser
description: WASHINGTON  When President Carter offered to sell the Soviet Union 25 million metric tons of American corn and wheat in the coming 12 months, he was like a highstakes poker player holding three aces and trying to draw for a full house. It was a gamble, but not a big one.

title: Americans Up in the Air and Above; Flight
description: INITIALLY, one may wonder what a writer of the stature of C. D. B Bryan, the author of Friendly Fire  a subtle work about a middle American family's growing disaffection with the Vietnam War  is doing writing The National Air and Space Museum.which, as its name might suggest, is a sort of institutional biography. There are at least two good reasons. First, the Air and Space Museum in Washington  a spectacular subsidiary of the Smithsonian, where manyof the nation's most famous flying machines are Kept  is the only museum devoted to the history of aircraft. Second, although the heady, barnstorming, pioneering days of aircraft are well over, and although the nation's space program is currently in the doldrums, more than 10 million people a year have been

title: CALENDAR
description: Today. Stonington Antiques Show. Community Center, Cutler Street. Take North Main Street Exit from I95. Noon to 5 P.M. 30 exhibitors.

title: Satellites Expand Research Into the Mysteries of the Sea
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13  On long, often tedious voyages, Dr. Robert L. Bernstein has ranged over much of the world, measuring currents, surface winds, temperatures and other qualities of the sea from the pitching deck of an oceanographic research shin.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE old ErieLackawanna Railroad station in Hoboken, the final New Jersey stop for thousands of commuters on their daily trip to Manhattan, is being rescued from its grimy, dreary state of the last few years and transformed, as closely as possible, into its original appearance. The station, which serves about 40,000 commuters a day, was built in 1907.

title: Imports Ride High, But Change Is Seen
description: ANTASTIC! said Vincent Farella, a salesman at a Datsun dealership in New York City, when asked about business. And the same reply came from Jack Moses as he watched customers inspect new cars at the Toyota dealershin where he works

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: Today

title: Gasoline: A Cautious Optimism
description: WITH the driving season well past its summer peak and lines at service stations now mostly a memory, oil experts are saying that gasoline supplies will probably remain adequate for the foreseeable future. But they are hedging carefully, aware that the line between surplus and shortage could easily be crossed if, as has been rumored lately, the oilexporting countries were to initiate a new round of production cutbacks to tighten the market once again.

title: Both Sides Use Many Tricks to Bring Out Florida Voters
description: TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 13  The day of the Democratic caucuses began early for Lorenzo Mendoza, who likes President Carter; for Samuel P. Watt, who detests the man, and for Lillian Carter, who is his mother.

title: ISAAC STERN: THE POWER AND THE GLORY
description: Isaac Stern tells a wonderful twoliner about himself. A man meets a friend and says, I heard Isaac Stern last night. Yeah, the friend replies, what did he have to say?

title: Szaro Joins Jets as Kicker
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 13 After taking a redeye overnight flight from San Francisco, Richie Szaro toted a bag of footballs onto the practice field today and won the job as the Jets placekicker for at least the next four games.

title: Rooms on Wheels: Van Owners Add All the Comforts of Home
description: WHEN his wife decided to buy a van for the family back in 1976, Robert J. Shippee did not approve. In fact, Mrs. Shippee now recalls with a chuckle, He almost died.

title: Vietnam Reports Many Are Killed In Fighting on Border With China
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 13 (UPI) Fighting erupted along the border be tween China and Vietnam with many killed on both sides, the Vietnam new agency reported today.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1979

title: Westchester/This Week
description: THEATER

title: Songs by Sondheim by Real People
description: HEMPSTEAD STEPHEN SONDHEIM'S scores are so integral and artistically true to their theatrical sources that one would not have imagined a potpourri of them packaged and marketed for instant consumption.

title: Amid the Hoopla, Uncertainty Is the One Sure Thing
description: AS American automobile manufacturers roll their 1980 cars and trucks into showrooms, an air of uncertainty prevails. And, as in such times past, Detroit is spending vast amounts promote its handful of truly new models as well as the much larger group of warmed over cars.

title: Suit Weighs Liability on Asbestos Peril to Workers
description: NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 13 (AP) A case is under way in Federal District Court here that could establish who faces liability for millions of dollars in damages sought by hundreds of shipyard workers exposed to cancercausing absestos.

title: Karen Andes, Editor, Is Wed To a Director
description: The chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Karen Lovett Andes, daughter of Charles Lovett Andes of Villanova, Pa., and the late Garretta Long Carlin ofCarversville, Pe., to michael ?? son of Mrs. Richard Borden of Concord, Mass., and the late William H. Sweney Jr. of St. Paul. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Fred Northup.

title: COLETTE'S PASSIONATE PALATE
description: Some of the most mouthwatering descriptions of food are not found in cookbooks but in literature. An important case in point is the work of Colette, the great French writer, author of such famous novels asGigi, Cheri, The Vagrant, The Cat. While she is known the world over for her writings on love and lovers, Colette is rare among French classicists in giving an important place in her work to the subject of food.

title: Crafts Galleries Are Thriving Amid
description: WHEN Minda Shein of East Brunswick, N.J., was hunting for a very special thankyou gift, she headed for the Lillian Kornbluth Gallery in Fair Lawn, where she purchased an unusual ceramic landscape plate by Albert Green. Lucy and Dick Feller ofWestport, Conn., made a similar beeline for the Elements Gallery in Greenwich, where they were seeking a oneofakind gift for a oneofakind friend.

title: Jazz: From Hard Bop To Ballads
description: As if there weren't enough formidable jazz saxophonists in New York, Sweet Basil has been bringing them in from out of town. Two weeks ago, James Moody played a memorable engagement at the club, and last week, through last night, the longlost Lou Donaldson led a quartet.

title: Carter Approves Agency Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)  President Carter has signed legislation authorizing $8 million for the United States Travel Service, a Federal agency that he is trying to eliminate. In approving the appropriation Wednesday, Mr. Carter said I have not changed my view that the agency's function of enticing foreigners to come to the United States as tourists should be performed private business. The President said he had signed the bill because the appropriation was enacted as part of a larger money bill.

title: Morris Knolls Triumphs
description: John Giannaula sneaked 1 yard for a touchdown with 3:30 remaining, and then tossed a 2point conversion pass to Nick Schmidt yesterday to rally undefeated Morris Knolls past Morristown, 87, in Rockaway. Giannaula's touchdown capped a sixplay, 28yard drive following a short punt. Morristown (22) moved ahead in the third quarter on Rene Bendel's 5yard burst and Cash Cappell's extra point.

title: CARTER'S DELEGATES TAKE LEAD AS PARTY CAUCUSES IN FLORIDA
description: MIAMI, Oct. 13  The wellorganized, Administrationmounted campaign effort for President Carter, showing unexpected strength in the Miami area, rolled up a commanding and apparently unbeatable margin over a draft movement for Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts today in Florida's statewide Democratic caucuses.

title: Philadelphia Will Sell Papal Cross for $5,000
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 (AP)The city will sell to a suburban restaurant owner for $5,000 a 37foothigh cross that was erected for Pope John Paul H's visit, according to City Representative Joseph LaSala.

title: 2 Blue Ribbons for Devon
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 13 Devon, owned by Philip Siegel of Mount Kisco, N.Y., won two blue ribbons and captured a section of the junior working hunter championship today at the Pennsylvania National horse show.

title: Radioactive Train Derailed in Jersey Tunnel
description: NORTH BERGEN, N.J., Oct. 13 (AP)  A Conrail freight train pulling at least one car containing lowgrade radioactive materials derailed tonight in a tunnel connecting Weehauken and North Bergen shortly after leaving the Conrail yard in Weehauken. authorities said.

title: Marriage Announcement 6  No Title
description: Camilla Moss Smith Plans Jan. 26 Bridal

title: Peete Shoots 67 and Gains Shot Lead in Southern Golf
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Oct. 13 (UPI) Calvin Peete vaulted into a onestroke lead in the $200,000 Southern open today when he overtook a faltering Mike McCullough by shooting a threeunderpar 67 for a 206 total.

title: Looking Back At The Miracle Worker on TV
description: Tonight at 8 on NBC The Miracle Worker will be broadcast in its second television incarnation. Set in 1887, the play recounts the critical events in the first months of Annie Sullivan's struggle to teach the young deaf, mute and blind Helen Keller how to communicate with the rest of humanity. Its first telecast was live. I wrote that version 23 summers ago when all television was live, rehearsaltime was scant, unwritten pages were improvised, actors went blank over missing props, cameras photographed each other, and everthing was sprightlier. So, for example, our first chance to hear the score was in dress rehearsal, violins sobbing away in another studio piped in to us in the controlbooth; our director, Arthur Penn, groaned, This music is killing us! and an hour later on the air was  unbeknownst to the musicians giving their all  dialing most of it out adlib, while talking his headphoned cameramen in and out among the actors.

title: Chinese Observatories Trying to Refine Warning System for Quakes
description: DAHUICHANG, China  For 14 months before the greatest natural disaster of modern times, the Tangshan earthquake of July 28, 1976, an observatory here recorded increasingly ominous movements along the earth fault that it straddled precisely, so as to watch for such deformations.

title: Connally Helps Choate to Snap a Taft Jinx
description: Choate School overcame a jinx yesterday against Taft, its traditional rival. For the third straight year, Choate went against Taft with an unbeaten record. But what happened the past two seasons didn't happen yesterday. Yesterday, the visiting Choate team won.

title: WORRY ON INFLATION VOICED BY KENNEDY
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 13  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, putting verbal and physical distance between himself and today's caucus voting in Florida, campaigned for a Kentucky gubernatorial candidate and attacked doubledigit inflation and doubledigit interest rates.'

title: MUSIC
description: IT is not surprising that the bigname orchestras and choirs, with their bigname soloists, tend to corner most of the attention of the news media, but it would be a pity to overlook some fascinating musical happenings that normally operate with purely local support.

title: For the Minority Youth, a Labyrinth
description: FRANK MOJICA was explaining the way of the world for a black or Hispanic youth who was unskilled, untrained and seeking work. I get up every morning, get dressed and go out and look for a job, said 18yearold Mr. Mojica, who was seated in the office of a New York City jobplacement service. He explained that his odyssey through the realm of unemployment began when he was ex;pelled from school at the age of 15.

title: Banking: A Somewhat Different World
description: EIGHT THOUSAND bankers gathered here last weekend for their annual convention. They got things rolling With feasts, cocktail parties, visits to the Bourbon Street bars. But late that Saturday, night, after most of the bankers had checked in, the entire world of finance, like the economy in general, found itself in the path of a hurricane named Paul.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Crossing country people is like crossing a barbedwire fence. You may get over it, but you are going to get scratched.

title: Supporters Resist Effort to Soften StripMining Act
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona, the principal author of the 1977 stripmine control act, drew a line this week against a new attempt by some fellow Democrats to soften the law's impact on the coal industry. He was resisting the first important Congressional drive to weaken a major environmental law in the name of energy.

title: As Boat Speeds Increase, So Do Accidents;
description: Since 1925, when it was developed by Harold (Pappy) Seaman to outrun the Coast Guard during Prohibition, the deep V hull has ruled the seas at high speeds. But now, the day of the tunnel or catamaran hull is at hand.

title: P.L.O. Wins Friends and Influence At the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. The busiest and most conspicuous figure in the delegates lounge last week was Zehdi Labib Terzi, the representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization. From midmorning until deep into the cocktail hour, his portly, blueeyed, bearded figure could be seen hurrying from group to group, from diplomats to journalists to United Nations officials, talking, listening, shaking his head.

title: Price of Home Heating Oil Jumped Twice as Fast as the Cost of Crude
description: The retail price of home heating oil rose nearly twice as fast as the price of crude oil from January 1977 to May 1979, according to statistics from the Federal Department of Energy. And industry analysts say growing refinery and dealer profit margins are continuing to add heavily to prices.

title: Marriage Announcement 8  No Title
description: Miss de La Bruyre Sets May Wedding

title: Lack of Affordable Housing Plagues Elderly
description: THERE is a 5to10year waiting period for elderly people on limited incomes who are trying to get into one of the Town of Hempstead's 10 lowincome housing projects for the aged. Only 50 more apartments are under construction, according to Winifred Ward, executive director of the town's Housing Authority.LONG ISLAND HOUSING

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: AS big as the tornado that hit a fivemile stretch of Windsor, Windsor Locks and Suffield was, it is getting bigger in the retelling, and nothing it did was small.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: Just about the best and funniest article to appear in your section was Edward Fiske's The MX Express [Sept. 7]. To add to the humor, which has many serious implications, was the contrast between the truth in Mr. Fiske's article and the fantasy of another article, Conrail Promises Better Service This Winter.

title: Greenwich Debates Policy on Outsiders
description: GREENWICH ADEBATE over the acceptance of Federal funds at the Greenwich Representative Town Meeting last week turned into a dispute over the perennial issue of protecting Greenwich beaches from use by nonresidents. In the wranglethat ensued two of the town's prominent black citizens spoke sharply on the issue of race, and what many saw as the first round in the November election campaign took place.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets. as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Privileged Characters
description: PPERCLASSprotestant women may not be as sophisticated as the Hopi or as lively as Hasidim, but for a long time they were considered as interesting. We have read more about them than about most other groups of women, for they stroll through the novels of Edith Wharton, Henry James, Virginia Woolf and John P. Marquand, decorously displaying their psyches and mores.

title: Why Must We Exploit Them?
description: LATE one evening, we were watching a rerun of Casablanca. Ingrid Bergman had just asked Dooley Wilson to play it again, Sam. Hauntingly, in a raspy voice over the tinkling piano, Sam implored, You must remember this, a kiss is still a kiss . . . . .

title: Finding a Place in a Shaky Future
description: AN URBANE advertising executive, tormented with knowing that he will never head the Manhattan agency he helped to build, murders the newly named chairman at a cocktail party. The chairman was a homosexual.

title: Furniture Mishaps
description: THE long winter months ahead can mean trouble for furniture, but only because it may get too much care and attention. Then comes summertime, and the problems appear.

title: General Jones in Tokyo For Defense Discussions
description: TOKYO, Oct. 13  The Chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. David Jones, arrived here today for discussions with Japanese officials before proceeding to Seoul on Tuesday for the annual meeting of American and South Korean defense chiefs.

title: Wake Forest Stuns N. Carolina
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 13 (UPI)  Jay Venuto threw for 236 yards, including a 60yard, fourthquarter touchdown that gave Wake Forest 2419 upset victory over North Carolina in the Atlantic Conference today. The Wake Forest defense stopped a late drive by the Tar Heels.

title: 56% in States Thiat Lowered Age For Drinking Would Raise Limit
description: Fiftysix percent of adults surveyed in states where it is legal for 18 and 19yearolds to drink alcoholic beverages favor raising the legal age to 20 or 21, according to the Gallup Poll released today.

title: Crafts Shops Thrive In Suburban Settings
description: WHEN Minda Shein of East Brunswick, N.J., was hunting for a very special. thankyou gift, she headed for the Lillian Kornbluth Gallery in Fair Lawn, where she purchased an unusual ceramic landscape plate by Albert Green. Lucy and Dick Feller ofWestport, Conn., made a similar beeline for the Elements Gallery in Greenwich, where they were seeking a oneofakind gift for a oneofakind friend.

title: Miss Navratilova Gains Final With Mrs. Lloyd
description: PHOENIX, Oct. 13 (AP)  Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd advanced today to the final of the $100,000 Phoenix women's tennis tournament.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: THE program is on a firstcome, firstserved basis, and Mount Vernon got there first, a Federal housing official said after the recent announcement that Mount Vernon will be the first city in Westchester and one of the few in the United States to rehabilitate large apartment buildings with Federal loans.

title: The Great Crash of 79
description: THE Federal Reserve's Saturday night assauit on inflation may take months to do its intended work on the economy: But its impact on the nation's stock and bond markets was immediate, setting off a turbulence that reminded some on Wall Street of the Great Crash of 1929.

title: The Liberal Arts Come Out of the Shadow
description: VOCATIONALISTS, take note: the liberal arts are fighting back. In a period when a recessionary economy promises an even tougher job market, the pressures on higher education to provide training for jobs rather than education for life have been intensifying. Who needs the liberal arts? educators are asked almost everywhere. In fact, they're asked. who needs college?

title: Planner Asserts Pious Remarks Won't Eliminate Bias in Housing
description: The chief executive officer of the Tristate Regional Planning Commission told a conference on housing discrimination last week that segregation existed in his own community, that most of the others at the conference probably lived in similar areas and that pious remarks would not eliminate the problem.

title: How a Trio Of Cheever Stories Made It to TV
description: American writers of the first rank have long been ignored by television  to the impoverishment of the viewers, who rarely get to see the more important fiction written in their time brought to dramatic life. Nowpublic television is about to broadcast dramatizations of three John Cheever short stories, on successive Wednesdays at 8 P.M., adapted by playwrights who have already made their mark in the theater  not mere conscientious carpenters  and using directors and actors of real stature.

title: Carter Turns Dining Room Into a Lobby
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  For lunch most days, Senator William V. Roth eats a tuna sandwich at his desk. Yesterday he lunched with President Carter at the White House and the menu included crab cakes, seasoned with a healthy serving of Presidential persuasion.

description: ALLAH, observed Sir Richard Burton, the 19thcentury explorer, traveler and linguist, afflicted me with a love of travel. He has afflicted Jonathan Raban, the author of Arabia: A

description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  Richard III, in an Actor's CafTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through Nov. 10). $3.50$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$4.50; group rates. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: Government Jobs Slacken
description: WASHINGTON FROM the White House to the firehouse, Government offers a kaleidoscope of jobs that range from the sublime to the pedestrian. Government, however, is no longer a growth industry. The days of rapid expansion of public payrolls have faded into the mists of the early 1970's. Atlast count, in 1978, there were 12.7 million jobs state and local government, up barely 100,000 from a year earlier. Similarly, Federal civilian employment hovers around 2.9 million, as each President tries prove that he runs the tightest Administration ever to pilot the ship of state.

title: The World
description: In Summary

title: Cohalan, Feldman Find Few Issues After Scandal
description: WITH the Southwest Sewer District issue fading into the background, Peter F. Cohalan and Martin J. Feldman are finding few issues to divide them in their contest for Suffolk County Executive.

title: One Small Flight for a Pilot.
description: BOONTON IT WAS here last month that big names in aviation, including Jimmy Doolittle, assembled at a little grass airport to witness the reenactment of a short flight to nowhere that revolutionized air travel.

title: Richard Ridgway, Teacher, Is Fianc Of Susan Widmark
description: Susan Meacham Widmark and Richard Walter Ridgway plan to be married Dec. 29 in St. James Episcopal Church in Upper Montclair. N.J.

title: Clothespins: China, Trade and a Factory in Maine
description: WILTON, Me.  The legacy of Charles Forster survives in this small town, the headquarters of the Forster Manufacturing Company.

title: MISSILE MAY LAUNCH DESERT BOOM TOWNS
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Oct. 13 (AP)Chaotic, boomtown growth looms on the desert horizon in Utah and Nevada as a result of plans for man's largest project, the controversial MX missile system.

title: A Whole New World....
description: DALLAS JOHN J. ALLAN 3D seems to talk two languages, one the electronic newspeak of the burgeoning microcomputer world, the other the language of almost evangelical entrepreneurial optimism of someone who is convinced his only problem is not if he will succeed but how big and how soon.

title: Flooding in India Leaves 13 Dead And At Least a Million Homeless
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 13 (UPI)  At least 13 persons were drowned in flooding of the Brahmaputra River in the northeastern state of Assam, Indian officials said today.

title: Slamming Brakes
description: WASHINGTON  When historians look with the clear gaze of hindsight, perhaps they will readily see how the economy progressed to the condition where the Federal Reserve felt compelled to take last weekend's dramatic actions. Their view will be particularly useful, because recent events have perplexed economists. They were not only unprepared for much of what occurred, many agree. Perhaps more important, they concede misreading how decade of radical changes have pushed the economy in new directions.

description: John Owen, Audit Manager, Marries Ellen Treacy Galway

description: The hardcover connecdon. The following announcements came within a few days of one another, three variations on a single theme:

title: BACKTOCITY MOVES DISPLACE THE POOR
description: DENVER, Oct. 13 (UPI) The revitalization of some of the nation's innercity neighborhoods by young white professionals is creating hardships by displacing the poor and the elderly, a number of authorities concerned with the problem have concluded.

title: Kiko Moves Into the Spotlight
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13  Kiko Garcia, the second most celebrated baseball player born in Martinez, Calif., had only 24 runs batted in for the Baltimore Orioles during the season. But in the World Series he has knocked in six runs. He has had sixhits, including a tworun double in the third inning and a single thatopened the Orioles sixrun eighth inning today in their 96 victory. He is batting .600; his slugging average is1.000, with 10 total bases in 10 officiai times at bat. Those are numbers to make a man feel he belongs, even though he is also the second most celebrated shortstop on his team.

title: NETWORKS OPPOSING POLITICAL ADS NOW
description: Although the political season has begun considerably earlier than usual, highranking officials of the television networks have indicated that they would prefer to wait until after the first of the year to sell air time to candidates requesting it.

title: Detroiters Ponder Life After Chrysler
description: DETROIT  There's a twist on an old saw that says that when the nation's economy has a cold, the Detroit economy has pneumonia. So far, however, this city is more like someone trying to fight off case of flu. It feels out of sorts, it suffers sharp aches and pains, but it is unwilling to consider the possibility of taking to bed and pulling up the covers. Despite the bad news  a rocky national economy, the de

title: Splurging on a Sink: Unusual Designs
description: IF you are thinking of sprucing up your bathroom and you can afford a small splurge, replace the sink with one of the many unusual designs now on the market.

title: ... and End of an Old One
description: WHO do you blame. The jobs just aren't there, said Vincent Sgroi as he rubbed one massive hand over the other. I consider myself a victim progress.  Mr. Sgroi, who is 58 years old, used to dance his ?? ?? the ?? ?? linotype machine with what he considered the style of a ballerina. Then one day he woke up to find himself an unemployed and unemployable printer, with skills that no one wanted or needed.

title: A New Angle for Surveyors
description: VALHALLA it YPICAL surveying weather! exclaimed Dr. Joseph Hankin, president of Westchester Community College here, in mock consternation as he and 150 others, many of them professional land surveyors, sloshed through puddles in the lowlying grassy areas of his campus during a recent rainy day.

title: Six States Will Share Grant for Pilot Projects in Rural Health Care
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)  Six states will share in a $450,000 Federal grant to develop pilot projects aimed at improving health care services in rural America.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The outpost that the Boston Museum of Fine Arts opened in the Faneuil Hall Marketplace last June is now in its fifth month of operation, and the museum is soon to install its second show. This means that almost onequarter of the twoyear period has passed during which the museum is scheduled to occupy the top floor of the South Market Building in that fabulously successful recycled Boston landmark, a space that has been generously donated, rentfree, by the Rouse Company of Maryland, the developer of the Marketplace. After the twoyear period, the museum's future is in the lap of the real estate business.

title: Marriage Announcement 11  No Title
description: Maud D. Iselin To Be a Bride

title: Lake Waramaug: Foliage With Distinction
description: New PRESTON IN the fall, one's fancy often turns to the fiery and fantastic foliage available free for the viewing throughout New England. Connecticut can be overlooked in the great rush northward, which is too bad, for there are several areas of the state where the viewing is spectacular.

title: Splurging on a Sink: Unusual Designs
description: IF you are thinking of sprucing up your bathroom and you can afford a small splurge, replace the sink with one of the many unusual designs now on the market.

title: John Doe Redux
description: It used to be that the only creatures who wore the names and trademarks of other creatures were cattle and household pets. But then branding became fashion, and real people found pleasure in sharing their identities with the likes of Pierre Cardin, Louis Vuitton and Gloria Vanderbilt. They even paid premium for the honor.

title: POLITICS
description: MEMBERS of the House of Representatives went back to Washington last Tuesday after taking the pulse of the folks back home during their 10day recess, which Congress orefers to call a district work period,and for Representative William R. Ratchford, at least, there was only one issue that dominated his talks with constituents.

title: Updating a Bathroom With New Fixtures
description: THE mere thought of remodel ing a bathroom, which costs a minimum of $3,500 and a month's patience, can hurl a homeowner into the slough of despond. A good alternative, though, is simply to update the room with a bright new fixture or two, making the space more efficient at the same time. Trade the tubin for a whirlpool bath, install a marriagesaving lavatory with two basins, or add a functional novelty a bidet or a urinal.

title: A Shift In Science
description: AFEW years ago, the common joke among physicists was that they had to be careful what they said in taxicabs because they were apt to find that the cab driver was as learned as they were  he was probably a physics Ph.D. suffering from the effects of a glut of physicists in the United States.

title: The Ups and Downs Of Window Painting
description: PAINTING conventional doublehung windows (the kind that slide up and down) has always been somewhat of a problem for the doityourself painter. Not only do you have to worry about trying to keep paint oft the glass, there is alsothe oftenconfusing problem of figuring out what sequence to follow so that all parts of both the upper and the lower sash will get painted without skipping any strips of molding  and without getting paint all over your hands as you repeatedly move the sash frames up and down.

title: Over65'ers Float Back Into Job Pool
description: THE sharp expansion of the over65 population already under way (with more projected for the 1980's) coupled with the current squeeze made by rising inflation on the fixed budgets of many older people has led to a growing phenomenon in the job market  second careers for retired people.

title: ANTIQUES
description: WILTON MOST of us cannot leave our homes and families or businesses for several days to travel to distant cities to attend antiques forums, said Ruth Wolfe, an editor and writer on American art, and that is why we have organized a oneday lecture program in Wilton.

title: A Suburban Bloc In Washington
description: WASHINGTON JUST about this time two years ago, Representative John W. Wydler, conservative Republican from Garden City, L.I., found himself in an unusual position: He was sitting on the Democratic side of the House chamber.

title: STRAINS IN DAMASCUS TESTING ASSAD RULE
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 13  As President Hafez alAssad of Syria approaches the ninth anniversary of his seizure of power, a remarkable record of stability in this country, his Government is facing its most serious problems, diplomatic and local analysts here say.

title: Marriage Announcement 1  No Title
description: Jo Ann Hirshhorn Wed to A.F. Bultman 4th

title: Field Goal by Yale Defeats Dartmouth
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 13  A 24yard field goal by Dave Schwartz, a former soccer player, was the only score today in the DartmouthYale game won by the unbeaten Elis, 30. It was their fourth victory and one achieved with good defense.

title: Vietnam Assails U.S. Maneuvers
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 13 (UPI) Vietnam's army newspaper, Quan Doi Nhan Dan, has accused President Carter and the United States of gunboat diplomacy for conducting the military exercises now going on in the Caribbean. The official Vietnamese press agency told of the newspaper's editorial comments in a report monitored today in Bangkok.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: The historian and biographer Fawn N. Brodie is writing a book about Richard M. Nixon that promises to provide a perspective that differs from the subject's books about himself. Her startling story of Thomas Jefferson's relationship with his quadroon slave, Sally Hemings, Thomas Jefferson: An Intimate History, published by Norton a fewyears ago, sent shudders through the First Families of Virginia. Her Nixon biography, which will also be published by Norton, is now in the researching and writing stage. She is certain that Mr. Nixon knows she is writing the book, but he has not volunteered to see her.

title: Updating a Bathroom With New Fixtures
description: THE mere thought of remodeling a bathroom, which costs a minimum of $3,500 and a month's patience, can hurl a homeowner into the slough of despond. A good alternative, though, is simply to update the room with a bright new fixture or two, making the space more efficient at the same time. Trade the tubin for a whirlpool bath, install a marriagesaving lavatory with two basins, or add a functional novelty  a bidet or a urinal.

title: Cordless Wall Clocks
description: THERE has been a quiet revolution in the wall clock. Once it was a necessary presence in the kitchen, where it reminded the absentminded cook to time the roast, or on the schoolroom wall, carefully monitored by restless students. But now, often devoid of Arabic numbers and appearing in a range of unusual shapes, the wall clock has become the latest design accessory.

title: The Facts of Life and Death
description: THAT Ronald Blythe listens with acuity and empathy was amply demonstrated in his Akenfield: A Portrait of an English Village, a book that has already been acclaimed as a classic of its genre. While it is rash to pronhesy. it does not takemuch imagination or courage to predict that The View in Winter, a wise and beautiful book, splendid in its conception, lyrical in its prose, will become aclassic in the literature of old age. Like Muriel Spark's Memento Mori, which is in some ways its fictional counterpart, Mr. Blythe's Reflections on Old Age reminds us that, as our ancestors said, in the midst of life we are in death; what his book also tells us  exhilaratingly  is that in the midst of death the old are In life. They the old  are not pther: The old are us.

title: Splurging on a Sink: Unusual Designs
description: IF you are thinking of sprucing up your bathroom and you can afford a small splurge, replace the sink with one of the many unusual designs now on the market.

title: Television ThisWeek
description: OF SPECIAL INTEREST

title: Paxton Pits Music Power vs. Nuclear Power
description: EAST HAMPTON WHEN Tom Paxton appears Tuesday night at the Westbury Music Fair, he is sure to perform several new songs he has written about stopping the spread of nuclear power, an issue he says has captured my interest more than anything else since the days of the antiwar movement.

title: Jet Running Backs Leading League in Anonymity and Yardage
description: The Jets running backs  four free agents and a pair of notsohigh draft choices  have made a game of being pro football's best anonymous unit.

title: Medical Masseurs Urge Court to Stay New Curb
description: A New York City antiprostitution law forbidding anyone to massage a person of the opposite sex was challenged in court yesterday by an organization of professional masseurs.

title: A Guide for LeafWatchers
description: THE the best way to see fall foliage? On foot. Stroll down the nearest country road. Spend a day in a park or nature preserve. Hike along miles of the state's trails.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: It is with a deep feeling of outrage that I reply to some of the statements in the recent article How Blacks Can Build Political Influence [Opinion Page].

title: CHESS
description: LONDON Three minor pieces are too much for a queen to tackle. If there is no other material on the board the queen should normally be able to draw by perpetual check, but give each side several pawns and that resource is canceled.

title: Detroit Is Looking At the Cars to Come
description: CAR ENTHUSIASTS got an unexpected glimpse of things to come recently when General Motors, with much fanfare, unveiled a muchimproved battery for the loneawaited electric car.

title: A Monetarist Looks at the Federal Reserve
description: For the third time in a year, the United States has a new policy to slow inflation and strengthen the dollar. This time, we are at last on the right track. The Federal Reserve Board pushed market interest rates to levels as high as the current rate of inflation, raised some reserve requirements and announced its intention to control the growth of money by controlling bank reserves.

title: U.S. Ends Ban on Foreign Trade In Hides of American Alligators
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 12 (Reuters)The United States yesterday lifted a decadeold ban on international trade in American alligator hides and hide products.

title: Marriage Announcement 17  No Title
description: Charles Morgan Jr. to Wed Wendy Milosh

title: ABOUT CARS
description: NINETEENEIGHTY will not be much of a year for new cars because most of the decade's first models are warmedover 79's. Still, there are five or six that will draw second glances. They include the Ford Motor Company's Lincoln, the latest milestone in Detroit's route to better overall economy.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: For several weeks I have been reading the suggestions in the Connecticut Weekly section of The New York Times about public transportation. May I contribute some ideas from an enthusiastic user of this mode of travel?

title: Fossils Found in a Gift Shop Shake Dinosaur Theories
description: PRINCETON FOSSILS that a Princeton University geologist and his associates found in a gift shop in Montana last year might help to explain how dinosaurs ruled the earth fot. 190 million years.

title: Film: Michael Powell's 'Peeping Tom':The Cast
description: When Michael Powell's "Peeping Tom" was originally released in England, in 1960, the critics rose up like a bunch of furious Reverend Davidsons to condemn it on moral grounds. "It stinks," one critic wrote. Another thought it should be flushed down the sewer, and a third dismissed it haughtily as "perverted nonsense." There is nothing angrier than a critic when he can be safely outraged.Mr. Powell's film is about a voyeur, a fellow who is obsessed by his movie camera, which he uses to make his own private "snuff" films, pictorial records of wanton young women just at the moments of their deaths. The movie's release was one of those rare occasions that allow critics, who are so often accused of promoting smut, righteously to proclaim their decency. The movie died.Now "Peeping Tom," which had an aborted release in this country in a shortened version in the 60's, has been rediscovered, and what was yesterday's garbage is now being heralded by two of today's critics as "powerful and moving" and "at once mischievous and compassionate, ironic and evangelistic, comic and tragic." The movie was shown at the New York Film Festival yesterday, and will be re-released commercially in the near future by Martin Scorsese and Corinth Films, the billing to be in that order."Peeping Tom's" rediscovery, I fear, tells us more about fads in film criticism than it does about art. Only someone madly obsessed with being the first to hail a new auteur, which is always a nice way of calling attention to oneself, could spend the time needed to find genius in the erratic works of Mr. Powell  "One of Our Aircraft Is Missing," "The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp," "The Red Shoes," "Tales of Hoffman" and so on, all directed with Emeric Pressberger, and "Peeping Tom," which he directed alone."Peeping Tom," written by Leo Marks, may be one of the limper suspense movies you've ever seen. The audience knows virtually from the first frame that poor Mark Lewis (Carl Boehm), skulking around London with his trusty little movie camera, is a nut and a killer, and no amount of psycho-analytical exposition can make him endearingly complex.We are told that his father, a famous psychologist, "was interested in the reactions of the nervous system to fear" and warped his son forever by such tricks as dropping lizards on him in the middle of the night and then photographing the boy's terror. The movie talks about fear in the same way that we heard in William Castle's "The Tingler" (1960), much of which was set in a tacky movie theater where fear, in the physical form of something that looked like a soft, white lobster, crawled around under the seats attacking the paying customers.What seems to fascinate "Peeping Tom's" new supporters is Mr. Powell's appreciation of the idea that the act of photographing something can be an act of aggression, of violation (of the object photographed), an idea shared by some film makers (including Alfred Hitchcock in portions of his classic "Rear Window," made in 1954), professional thinkers and members of certain other primitive tribes.This fascination dates back to the movie-mad 60's, when movies became Art, film schools began to flourish, and the taking of moving pictures seemed to offer an easy way to self-expression and possibly celebrity. The last word on the foolishness of those times is contained in Jim McBride's uproariously funny and wise pseudodocumentary "David Holzman's Diary," about a fellow who is so preoccupied by filming everything that it becomes a substitute for living. Like the morose Mark Lewis in "Peeping Tom," David Holzman eventually comes to an absolute standstill.I am, perhaps, somewhat prejudiced. As interested as I am in films, the properties of the movie camera are not, for me, a subject of endless fascination. The movie camera is not magical. It's a tool, like a typewriter.I find it difficult to become morally outraged by "Peeping Tom" and even more difficult to see this movie as anything more than an excruciatingly schematic, very solemn melodrama, quite badly acted by everyone.
