Chief among these are Mr. Boehm, who plays the mad killer as an Englishman with a Peter Lorre accent that makes "birthday" come out "birsday"; a very young Anna Massey, who plays Mark's girl in a fashion that evokes all of the worst mannerisms of the theater that gave us "The Reluctant Debutante," and the beautiful Moira Shearer, without her red shoes and thus earthbound, as one of Mark's surprised victims.

title: Productivity Gap: A Better Gauge
description: There may be a better measure of the health of the economy than the usual ones  the gross national product, the consumer price index, the unemployment rate. It's the productivity gap, a gauge that now shows that the country could experience a deeper and longer reccession than the one of 197375.

title: The High Court Will Decide When Safety Is Too Costly
description: WASHINGTON  Anyone who set out to design a hypothetical case to dramatize the current debate over the Federal Government's role as a regulator could hardly beat real case that was argued before the Supreme Court last week.

title: Marriage Announcement 5  No Title
description: S. S. Stone 3d Is Fianc of Laura Limbocker

title: Army Recruiters Allege Harassment Over Quotas
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 13 (UPI)Eighteenhour days, harassment from superiors, divorce and even mental breakdown often go with the job of being a recruiter for the nation's allvolunteer Army, some recruiters say.

title: C. Arnholt Smith Is Found Liable For Damages From Bank Failure
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 13 (AP) After 31 days of testimony and six days of deliberations, a Federal jury has decided that C. Arnholt Smith, members of his family and associates are liable for financial damages stemming from the col lapse of the United States National Bank.

title: Alleged Robbery Victim Chases, Slays Suspect in Subway Station
description: A man who had been robbed of his radio by three men pursued one of the suspects into the subway station at 125th Street and Lenox Avenue and shot him to death about 6:30 P.M. last night, the police said. The police were seeking the robbery victim for questioning. The slain man was identified as Alphonso Flood, but the police had not determined his age or address.

title: Senator Percy Says He Will Back Treaty with Two Understandings
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (UPI)  Senator Charles H. Percy said today that he would vote for the strategic arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union if the Senate accepts two understandings that he said would reassure the Atlantic allies.

title: Rosalie Maury To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. John M. Maury of Rowayton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rosalie Gordon Maury, to William Astor Chanler 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chanler of Camden, Me.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: NORTHPORT IT is bittersweet to see all the old baby clothes out from storage and on display there on the table in the driveway. A yard sale isn't easy; it's like a scene from Our Town  mundane activity, perpetual intimations, snapshot emotion.

title: West African Ports of Call: Sleepy Banjul to Stylish Dakar
description: Banjul, decaying sleepily in the hot sun, looked more like a set from the old movie Sanders of the River than a tourist port of call. Our gleaming white cruise ship struck an odd note of contrast, but it was no odder than the music that greeted us. No throbbing drums, even if this was West Africa. Rather, there was the Gambian Police Band  courtesy of the local tourist board  blasting away at Colonel Bogey. A few yards away on the small quay, two longshoremen slumbered undisturbed.

title: Foster Care Once Again Is Enveloped In Scandal
description: Once upon a time, foster care conjured up images of the poor orphan with the longing eyes, just waiting to be cuddled. According to the legend, it would take almost no time for a parent to come along, be instantly captivated and take the child into a loving home. Such were the happy stories of a system that worked.

title: THIS WEEK IN SPORTS
description: The Knicks meet the Houston Rockets Tuesday at 7:30 P.M. and the Philadelphia 76ers Saturday at 8 P.M. at Madison Square Garden. The Nets play the 76ers Wednesday and the Knicks Friday, both at 8 P.M. at the Rutgers Athletic Center in Piscataway, N.J.

title: Miss Dohan Plans Bridal
description: Caroline Russell Warburton Dohan, a member of the technical staff of Bolt, Beranek & Newman, a Cambridge, Mass., research and development concern, and Timothy Henry Buchman, technical coordinator for the Opera Company of Boston, plan to be married in June.

title: Coast Ford Plant Lays Off 1,480
description: MILPITAS, Calif., Oct. 13 (UPI)The Ford Motor Company has given twoweek layoff notices to 1,480 assembly line workers to reduce its inventory of pickup trucks. Seven other Ford plants have stopped production in recent weeks because of unsold inventories. Those seven plants will resume production Monday, a company spokesman said.

title: Mr. Volcker's Verdun
description: When the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Paul Volcker, talks, Wall Street listens. That, so far, is the only conclusion to be drawn from the turmoil in the financial markets that followed the Fed's decision to raise its own lending rate by a full percentage point andto encourage banks to raise their rates by even more. But having listened, what do bankers, traders and housewives hear? It will take months to find out whether Mr. Volcker's shock treatment will dispel American expectations about inflation or simply make an already depressing economic condition worse. The odds, unfortunately, are against Mr. Volcker.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: HARTFORD THE ghost in the Victorian house on Sigourney Street needed no prompting from the telephone company's TV commercials in order to reach out and touch someone.

title: In Coownership, Few Dull Moments
description: When two people, tied not by love, blood or passion, but by a common vision of property values, decide to buy a vacation house together, what starts as a cleareyed investment can turn into a melodrama. Consider two bankers who bought a house in Southampton, Long Island.

title: A Knock on the Door  Suddenly a Song Rings Out
description: OH, I'm from Witty Ditty with a message just for you. Please gather round and hear my song, attention is my cue. Four times one recent weekend, those lyrics were delivered to the tune of Turkey in the Straw. Eachtime, an earnest young man with an operatic voice, dressed like onequarter of a barber shop quartet in black pants, red and white striped vest and straw boater, knocked on someone's door and announced: This is a singing telegram. Each followed it with a song that was a madetoorder oneofakind creation.

title: Security Around Cubans Restricts Even Protectors
description: The area around the Cuban Mission to the United Nations, which consists of two red brick buildings at the corner of 38th Street and Lexington Avenue, has been turned into an armed camp, with hundreds of Secret Service agents, Cuban guards and uniformed policemen guarding the area with bazookas and heavy machine guns.

title: The Trials of Bernard Cornfeld
description: The threeweekold fraud trial of Bernard Cornfeld, founder of the I.O.S. Ltd. mutualfund empire that collapsed in the early 1970's with a crash heard round the financial world, is nearing an end in Geneva. Final prosecution and defense statements are scheduled for tomorrow, but the small turnouts at the trial indicate that infamy is equally as fleeting as fame.

title: Toth, Soccer Star, Seeks U.S. Asylum
description: Zoltan Toth, who defected from Hungary and its national soccer team while on a visit to Spain, is in the United States and will ask for political asylum in Bethlehem, Pa., tomorrow.

title: Dr. Johnson's Middle Age
description: WHAT a rare creature is a great criticl English literature has a plethora of matchless poets, novelists and playwrights, but until this century, which is too new for the process of sifting to have been completed, there have been only four unquestionably major critics: Coleridge, Hazlitt, Arnold and the subject of the present study, Samuel Johnson.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING Livinz With Energy From the Sun
description: SUSSEX IT'S been explained to me 15 times, and I still don't understand it, but it seems to work just fine, said Charles Mercer, who since last May has lived in an apartment in a building here known as The Creamery.

title: Hassan's Sahara Gamble
description: MADRID  It was an ominous sack of gifts that Moroccan King Hassan H, Commander of the Faithful, solemnly bestowed upon a ragtag clutch of Saharan notables gathered at the royal palace in Rabat to mark the addition of a new province to Morocco. As their women uttered piercing cries of celebration, the Moroccan monarch distributed M16 assault rifles to the robed tribal chiefs.

title: ART VIEW
description: Surrealism flourished in Paris in an atmosphere of provocation and scandal in the period between the two World Wars. It then suffered a notable decline in intellectual prestige in the 1950's, especially on this side of the Atlantic. But in recent years the wheel has turned again, and Surrealism has been enjoying a considerable revival and revaluation.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: As a direct descendant of David Demarest and a native of Hackensack, I found the recent historicalgenealogical article on the Demarests most interesting.

title: Steppingstones to Getting Hired
description: BETWEEN every Job opening and job applicant stands one inevitable hurdle the interview. Of the 14 factors that most often lead to rejection of a job applicant, seven are interviewrelated, according to a Northwestern University survey of 186 companies. Chief among these pitfalls are the inability to demonstrate selfconfidence, enthusiasm and a clear set of goals.

title: Sports Medicine Taking Stride Forward at UConn
description: STORRS WNETHER by broken records or broken bones, sports and medicine are becoming more closely linked every day. Worldclass athletes are not the only ones pursuing physical superiority through science. More and more people with the goal of selfimprovement are talking not only of good food, equipment and conditions, but also of muscle biopsy, aerobic capacity and pulmonary ventilation.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: NINETEENEIGHTY will not be much of a year for new cars, because most of the decade's first models are warmedover 79's. Still, there are five or six that will draw second glances including the Ford Motor Company's Lincoln, the latest milestone in Detroit's route to better overall economy.

title: Robbers Take $7,800 At 2 Banks in the City
description: Robbers invaded banks in Brooklyn and Queens yesterday and escaped with more than $7,800, the police reported. There were no arrests or injuries, but the two holdups brought the number of bank robberies in New York City to 720 for the year.

title: Warren Artist Puts His Viewers at Ease
description: SO MUCH of today's art is unbearably intellectual. It takes itself sc seriously that one wonders whether it is serious at all. Rather than dealing with sensuous and formal considerations, art presumably deals with lofty concepts. It attempts to appeal to the mind rather than to the eye, and ends up appealing to neither.

title: Marriage Announcement 7  No Title
description: Patricia Joy Lown Wed To William P. Creighton

title: QUEENS LAW SCHOOL IN CITY U'S BUDGET
description: The City University of New York has asked the state for $500,000 in startup money for a new law school at Queens College at which students could work toward law degrees while also working on bachelor's or master's degrees.

title: Marriage Announcement 4  No Title
description: Patricia Prial Wed To James Gillooly.

title: Thirteen Stories
description: HERE mostcollections of short stories represent an omnium gatherum of the previously published, Albert Haley's Home Ground is an impressively unified work. Like James Joyce's Dubliners, it accumulates through selfcontained narratives an ambitious nearnovel rich in meaning and as poignantly understated as its epigraph: Nowadays it seems like no one dies or is buried on home ground.

title: Swedish Author Tours Pot Pot's Area of Cambodia
description: His visa, Jan Myrdal said, was signed by Pol Pot, the deposed Prime Minister of Cambodia, now reported heading a government somewhere in the Cambodian jungles. Mr. Myrdal, a Swedish writer and anthropologist, was met at the ThaiCambodian border by two elephants and several Cambodian guerrillas.

title: Moratorium Urged on Midtown Building Incentives
description: In the continuing debate and battle over future construction in the fastgrowing midtown section of Manhattan, Community Board 5 has called for a sixmonth moratorium on variances for new buildings until a study by the Planning Commission determines whether the city is giving too many incentives to developers in that area and losing too much tax revenue, a board member said yesterday.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Foreign Factories Flock Here
description: MANY of the same qualities that made Connecticut the cradle of American massproduction century and a half agoa pool of skilled labor, good transportation and the nearby markets New York and Boston  are attracting foreign manufacturers to the state today in record numbers.

title: A Guide for Using
description: WITH the cost of fuel rising so dramatically, the heating of private houses this winter has become a major financial burden. For this reason, as well as for ecological and aesthetic ones, many people have traded their kilowatts for woodpiles, and portions of their central heating for an oldfashioned wood stove.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Pope Sides With St. Paul In Debate on the Priesthood
description: After Pope John Paul II's repeated displays of affection and benevolence to Americans at large, including those of other faiths, it seemed strange to many observers to see him deal summarily with the aspirations of those closest to him in the organized church  the priests and nuns themselves, many of whom favor putting an end to the Roman Catholic priesthood as a celibate, male preserve.

title: FILM VIEW
description: My colleagues and I might as well admit it publicly: there is a difference between people who write about movies and the members of the public for whom we write. It isn't thought to be good form to say so. We're supposed to pretend that we're like everyone else, just folks, except that we get into theaters free and the members of the public have to stand line, pay through the nose and then sometimes sit so close the screen, and so far to one side, that the actors looks like walking sticks.

title: A Guide for Using Wood Stoves Safely
description: WITH the cost of fuel rising so dramatically, the heating of private houses this winter has become a major financial burden. For this reason, as well as for ecological and aesthetic ones, many people have traded their kilowatts for woodpiles, and portions of their central heating for an oldfashioned wood stove.

title: DINING OUT
description: WESTPORT THE dining room of The Inn at Longshore looks very much like the dining room of a good country club, as indeed it should. Longshore is the country club purchased some years back by the town of Westport for its residents. After a hiatus, The Inn has been refurbished and recently reopened. Although still owned by the town,the restaurant and inn proper, with its 14 guest rooms, are leased by an outside management group.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: World Series, fifth game, Pirates vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Pittsburgh. (Television  Channel 7, 4:30 P.M. Radio  WCBS, 4:30 P.M.)

title: Foes of Equal Rights Plan, Buoyed by Success, Intensifying Efforts
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 13  Buoyed by its success in beating back efforts to ratify the proposed equal rights amendment in nine gates this year, the Stop E.R.A. Committee said today it would widen and redouble its efforts in the battle for God, family and country.

title: New Materials Help Cut Vehicle Weight
description: WEIGHTCONSCIOUS automobile makers are relying on a new diet of light materials to produce a more fuelefficient machine for the 1980's and beyond.

title: Westfield Captures 4th Straight
description: Fred Kessler plunged for two short touchdowns yesterday to spark undefeated Westfield to its fourth victory, a 280 triumph over Scotch Plains at Westfield. Westfield, ranked as one of the top schoolboy teams in New Jersey, opened the scoring on Dean Jajko's 57yard sprint in the first quarter. Kessler helped make it 140 moments later with the first of his 1yard plunges. Dondi Chambliss closed the scoring for Westfield when he bulled across from 1 yard out in the fourth period. Scotch Plains fell to 13.

title: After One Ride, I Love the L.I.R.R.
description: IHAD always believed that there was a place reserved for me in the Guinness Book of World Records. After all, who else has lived on the Island for more than 16 years and has never been a passenger on the Long Island Rail Road?

title: Cordless Wall Clocks
description: THERE has been a quiet revolution in the wall clock. Once it was a necessary presence in the kitchen, where it reminded the absentminded cook to time the roast, or on the schoolroom wall, carefully monitored by restless students. But now, often devoid of Arabic numbers and appearing in a range of unusual shapes, the wall clock has become the latest design accessory.

title: Brick Lands Heavily In Toms River, 286
description: Ray Jandoli rushed for 131 yards and one touchdown and Bob Bonavito twice plunged 2 yards for scores as Brick (301) trimmed Toms River South, 286, yesterday at Toms River.

title: Rooms on Wheels: Van Owners Add All the Comforts of Home
description: WHEN his wife decided to buy a van for the family back in 1976, Robert J. Shippee did not approve. In fact, Mrs. Shippee now recalls with chuckle. He almost died.

title: Armenians Cling to Bitter Memories
description: PARAMUS THE writer William Saroyan, who was born Fresno, Calif., of Armenian parents, once said: An Armenian can never not be an Armenian. For those Armenian families who emigrated, first, to New York City in the early 1920's and then, later in the decade, to the communities of Bergen County, the heritage includes the memory of a genocidal campaign against Armenians in World War I. It is a memory that is passed, like a burning ember. from one veneration to the next.

title: CORRECTION
description: The photograph accompanying last week's art column was incorrectly identified. The work, at the Neuberger Museum of the State University of New York at Purchase, was Of Previous Dissipations by Ree Morton.

title: Last of the Great Train Robbers Enjoys Life in Rio
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 13  Twice a week, a 50yearold man with dancing blue eyes and a merry smile must sign in with the federal police here. He is forbidden to hold a job, go to nightclubs, stay in bars after 10 P.M., get married or obtain any civil documents such as a driver's license.

title: Political Announcements
description: The second most confusing part of politics this week is the intricate, probably meaningless election in Florida yesterday. If 35 states, including Florida, are having Presidential primaries next year, then it would be logical to describe the goingson yesterday as the first Presidential secondary.

title: What Went Up
description: EVER since last July, when the President and his assistants warned us that a recession was coming  even though they assured us it would only be mild  the approaching 50th anniversary, on October 24, of Black Thursday has become disturbingly relevant. Can it happen again? The authors of these three books do not pretend to offer an answer. But the nagging question remains. It is what concerns us most when we look back to 1929.

title: West Islip Stout Defense Halts Deer Park's Baugh
description: West Islip and North Babylon, Conference I powers, won their fourth straight games yesterday. West Islip blanked Deer Park, 100, and North Babylon routed Brentwood Sonderling, 270.

title: Heigh Ho! Heigh Ho! Here Comes a Staged Snow White
description: Radio City Music Hall is preparing to embark on a new facet of its ambitious role as an entertainment center  legitimate theater. A fulllength, $750,000 production of Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, an ascloseaspossible theatrical translation of the 1937 Walt Disney film, will open at the Music Hall this Thursday for a limited run through Nov. 18.

title: How to Find Cheaper Rail Fares
description: A few alert college students and other budgetconscious travelers have discovered a cheaper way to go from New York to Philadelphia by train. They are making the round trip for only $12.40.

title: Parents at Rutgers Keep Tight Liaison
description: EAST BRUNSWICK WHEN Lily Tu's husband, a chemist, told her that he was going to take a job in New Jersey  they were living in West Virginia at the time she put all her efforts into finding a house near Douglass College in New Brunswick.

title: Newark: Microcosm of Society Adrift
description: OVERSHADOWED by New York City for three centuries, Newark finally came into its own in the late 1960's and early 70's, but in the worst way imaginable. Two calamities  the riots of 1967 and the indictment and conviction of its Mayor and other high officials in 1970  gained it sensational media exposure.

title: Dance: By Mary Overlie
description: So why was Hero called Hero? That's hard to say. But there are things that can easily be said about the work for 15 dancers that was presented Friday night at the Kitchen. Choreographed by Mary Overlie, with the assistance of Nina Martin and Wendell Beavers, it lasted 45 minutes and emphasized blocs of dancers. Devoid of gestural frills, it was rugged in movement quality and invigorating to watch.

title: Coast Mayor Appeals To Parents in Attempt To Curb Bus Attacks
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 13 (AP)  Saying that discipline must begin at home, Mayor Dianne Feinstein is appealing to parents for help in curbing attacks by groups of black youths on white bus passengers.

title: How to Remedy Furniture Mishaps
description: THE long winter months ahead can mean trouble for furniture, but only because it may get too much care and attention. Then comes summertime, and the problems appear.

title: Tips on Planning the Job Hunt
description: ACRUCIAL part of any successful and efficient job search is the preliminary planning phase. Although it gives focus, structure and coherence to a complex effort, job hunters often neglect it. The following strategies are designed to save wasted time and scattered efforts.

title: Reynolds Key as Princeton Beats Columbia
description: PRINCETON, N.J. Oct. 13  Columbia's football team, which managed to mar Pennsylvania's 1,000th game last week, could not even put a blemish on Princeton's 900th today, falling to the Tigers by 350.

title: What's Doing in BRUGES
description: BRUGES LA MORT  The Dead City, Erich Korngold called it in his opera, and for a span of centuries, Bruges was just that.

title: Jobs: The Skills, Then the Place
description: WASHINGTON IF you want to be a lawyer, you'd better face the fact, experts say, that your chances of finding work will be much better if you avoid California and most of the big cities on the East Coast. In the next decade, openings for new lawyers should be relatively more plentiful in small towns and suburbs.

title: Bonn Is Annoyed at Brzezinski on Arms Budget Issue
description: BONN, Oct. 13  The Government of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt is irritated with what it considers interference by Zbigniew Brzezinski, the White House national security adviser, in West German domestic affairs, according to an aide close to the Chancellor.

title: Lag in Happiness Found Among Young of Today
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 13 (UPI) Young Americans, especially the affluent and welleducated, are not as satisfied with their lives as were their counterparts of the 1950's, a University of Michigan study says.

title: The Key to Potting Plants Lies in the Soil
description: WHILE spring is usually a better time to divide and repot house plants, there is always some of it to be done in the fall. Perhaps a plant has outgrown its container during the summer, or a new division or cutting from a plant that has grown too large to be brought indoors may be starting. Whatever the reason, the choice of potting soils is important.

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: Beattie

title: Negro Colleges Receive Kresge Fund Challenge
description: The United Negro College Fund Inc. has been given a $6 million challenge grant by the Kresge Foundation. It is the largest grant in the foundation's 55year history.

title: Two Colorado Coaches Assailed for Recruiting
description: AURORA, Colo., Oct. 13 (AP)  The Colorado High School Activities Association has restricted the boys basketball programs at Wasson and Palmer High Schools because of alleged player recruitment tactics. The association action bars both schools from competing in district and,state basketball tournaments this season.

title: INVESTING Reform and the Milan Stock Exchange
description: MILAN  The frenzied baying of the stock traders two floors below is just audible through the heavy wooden doors. Giorgio de Gaspari, the new, seriousminded president of the stock exchange in Milan, the country's financial and industrial capital, leans across a huge wooden desk and vows, This time I really intend to reform the market.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:30 A.M. (Channel 4) Newscenter Forum: Norman Steisel, New York City Sanitation Commissioner.

title: TV VIEW
description: Television news has rarely been more robust  on the surface. Major events still manage to generate images of healthy activity and competition. The recent journey of Pope John Paul II was graced with some spectacular special coverage, including memorable satellite transmissions from Ireland and, affording local stations an opportunity to shine, saturation reporting in New York City. Now, the medium is gearing up for a Presidential election year. The inflating of details has already begun. NBC, for example, called a special conference to announce that it has hired Theodore H. White away from CBS for election commentary. CBS will probably parry soon with its own publicrelations coup. Meanwhile, however, behind the scenes, all is not a frenzy of onwardsandupwards jubilation. There is an unusual preponderance of long faces and nervous smiles in the corridors of television news these days.

title: Hollywood's Kids Are Becoming Cherubs Again
description: Cute, lovable movie kids are back. In a dramatic break from their portrayal in recent years as little and sometimes fiendish monsters, Hollywood's children are again behaving admirably, as they did in the films of the 1930's. In The Black Stallion,which was screened at the New York Film Festival last night and enters commercial release on Thursday, the young hero who befriends the horse of the title is shown as resourceful and determined against forces that might defeat grownups. In the current Rich Kids, about children suffering through their parents marital miseries, and A Little Romance, an updated Romeo and Juliet, the protagonists react to love with a fervor that adults have presumably outgrown. And in last summer's tearjerker, The Champ, the emotional focus is on the hearttugging little boy who was first played by Jackie Cooper in the original, more than four decades ago.

title: 11,000 in U.S. Found 100 Years Old or Older
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)  At least 11,000 Americans are 100 years old or older, the Social Security Administration said Tuesday. But the Government agency is not sure who is the oldest.

title: Agents Track Down Timber Rustlers on U.S. Land
description: ZIGZAG, Ore., Oct. 13 (AP)There a new kind of rustler abroad in these woods, and a new kind of posse is on their trail. The rustlers are after expensive fir trees and centuriesold cedar in the Mount Hood National Forest. Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States Forest Service are out to stop them.

title: Correct Tipping Will Help Make the Passage Smoother
description: What should I do about tipping? Whom should I tip, how much, and when?

title: What Happened to the Tax Revolt?
description: ON June 6, 1978, Californians approved Proposition 13, a measure that reduced by twothirds the average resident's property tax. The first effects of Proposition 13 started a nationwide tax revolt.

title: Darien Downs Westhill To Remain Undefeated
description: After five weeks of play, Darien is the only unbeaten team in the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference. The Blue Wave recorded its fifth straight victory yesterday, a 140 decision over Westhill. Combined with a 2413 upset triumph by Wilton over previously undefeated Greenwich, Darien's victory gives it the league's best record.

title: Temple Stops Syracuse On Myers Scoring, 4917
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13  Temple, led by Sherman Myers, overpowered the Syracuse defense and routed the Orangemen, 4917, in chilly Veterans Stadium tonight.

title: Joan Casey Is Wed To Peter Kearney
description: Joan Mitchell Casey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Douglas Casey Jr. of LaJolla, Calif., and Peter Augustine Kearney, son of Mrs. Edward F. Kearney of Manhasset, L.I., and the late Mr. Kearney, were married here yesterday. The Rev. William Scully performed the ceremony in St. Jean de Baptiste Roman Catholic Church.

title: Bringing a Home Into the 18th Century
description: DURHAM CCUSE Bill Norton of being behind the times and you'll make him a happy man. As the owner of the Eighteenth Century Company in Durham, he has made a career of restoring antique buildings to their original style and condition with a maximum degree of authenticity.

title: A Venturesome New Album From Fleetwood Mac
description: Fleetwood Mac's new Tusk is probably the most eagerly awaited pop album of the year, all things considered. That's hardly to say that for everybody it's the album they've been most expecting. Newwavers wanted the new Talking Heads record, folkies andother vanguard eccentrics looked forward to the Roches, hardline rockers have Neil Young and now look on to Bruce Springsteen, and disco boogiers can look forward to a new Donna Summer album every three months or so.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Gardeners love short cuts. Here's one. Prepare the soil now for the vegetable garden. It will be improved by winter's freezing and thawing and will dry out early next spring when peas, lettuce and spinach can be planted. These cool weather crops always benefit from a head start.

title: Birth Notice 1  No Title
description: Births

title: GARDENING
description: WHILE spring is usually a better time to divide and repot house plants, there is always some of it to be done in the fall. Perhaps a plant has outgrown its container during the summer, or a new division or cutting from a plant that has grown too large to be brought indoors may be starting. Whatever the reason, the choice of potting soils is important.

title: Cordless Wall Clocks
description: THERE has been a quiet revolution in the wall clock. Once it was a necessary presence in the kitchen, where it reminded the absentminded cook to time the roast, or on the schoolroom wall, carefully monitored by restless students. But now, often devoid of Arabic numbers and appearing in a range of unusual shapes, the wall clock has become the latest design accessory.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: NINETEENEIGHTY will not be much of a year for new cars because most of the decade's first models are warmedover 79's.

title: U.S. Bridge Team Leading in Rio
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 13  Two big victories in the seventh and eighth rounds of World Championship Team play here have put the United States contract bridge team firmly in command at the midpoint of the qualifying stage.

title: Future Events
description: Royal Occasion

title: A Chance to Stretch the Muscles and the Imagination
description: MONTAUK THE onset of the disease comes when you peruse the brochure for Gurney's International Health and Beauty Spa.. The spa logo, Venus rising sylphlike from the sea, beckons you to follow her slender example.

title: Theater: Guare's Bosoms and Neglect at Yale Rep
description: NEW HAVEN  When John Guare's Bosoms and Neglect was first presented on Broadway last season, seemed an unsettling mlange of absurd comedy and dramatized hysteria,a play on a challenging subject  our malign neglect of ourselves and others  that was defeated by the playwright's lack of seriousness. Despite a general dissatisfaction  it closed after four performances  it had many ardent admirers.

title: Energy Pavilion Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)  The House has authorized $20.8 million for the construction and maintenance of a United States pavilion at the internatonal energy exposition in Knoxville, Tenn., in 1982. The bill was passed by voice vote Tuesday and sent to the Senate.

title: Marriage Announcement 9  No Title
description: R.A. Carlson Weds Laura A. DeAngelis

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BETHEL  J. Pindyck Miller, mixedmedia wall constructions, freestanding sculpture, today through Oct. 28. Bethel Gallery, 186 Greenwood Ave. Noon to 5:30 Wednesdays through Sundays. 7436644.

title: How Industry Can Help Job Seekers
description: THE gap, between jobs and available skills in Southwestern Connecticut is an acute problem. I originally thought the problem was easily defined and would lend itself to difficult but workable solutions. But I am not nearly so sure that this is only a single problem, or that there are any easily structured solutions.

title: Birth Notice 3  No Title
description: Births rence on Oct 4, 1979. Grandparents are Mr & Mrs Max Shlam and Mr & Mrs David Mehler. Great grandparents are Mr & Mrs Leon Mettler.

title: Amid Prayers for Its Survival, A Brooklyn Hospital Goes On
description: Dr. P. Harvey Chase did not want to hear about the possible closing tomorrow of the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn by a Federal bankruptcy judge. Dr. Chase, the hospital's director of medicine, was too busy leading a score of residents and interns through their rounds.

title: The Ups and Downs Of Window Painting
description: PAINTING conventional doublehung windows (the kind that slide up and down) has always been somewhat of a problem for the doityourself painter. Not only do you have to worry about trying to keep paint off the glass, there is also the oftenconfusing problem of figuringout what sequence to follow so that all parts of both the upper and the lower sash will get painted without skipping any strips of molding  and without getting paint all over your hands as you repeatedly move the sash frames up and down.

title: How to Remedy Furniture Mishaps
description: THE long winter months ahead can mean trouble for furniture, but only because it may get too much care and attention. Then comes summertime, and the problems appear.

title: International Year of the Child: A Small Impact but Great Furor
description: Officially dedicated to improving the wellbeing of children, the International Year of the Child has reportedly had little national impact and is being criticized by many people who work with children's programs.

title: Resolve the Testing Dilemma, Go to the Head of the Class
description: The battle in Albany last spring over the socalled truth in testing bill had the appearance of a DavidversusGoliath matchup. On one side, looking relatively weak, were representatives of a coalition of student and consumer groups. On the other was the giant, $150 millionayear testing industry, represented by some fancy Albany lawyers.

title: An American Spy Story
description: RICHARD HELMS gave the best 30 years of his life to the spy business. He joined the Central Intelligence Agency's precursor, the Office of Strategic Services, in 1943 during World War Ii. He attended the C.I.A.'s birth in 1947, became chief of operations of its clandestine arm in 1952, and finally head boy in 1966, at the age of 53 its first inhouse director. As Thomas Powers rightly says, nobody else's career, not even that of Allen Dulles or William Colby,

title: Gas at 10 a Gallon If Paid in Silver Coins
description: BERWYN, III, Oct. 13 (AP)  Gasoline is selling for 10 cents a gallon at Harold's Super Shell station, if you pay for it in pre1965 silver coins  dimes, quarters, halfdollars or dollars.

title: Editors' Choice
description: CANNIBALS AND MISSIONARIES, by Mary McCarthy. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $10.95.) A plane filled with liberals and art collectors, on their way to the Shah's Iran for their particular purposes, is hijacked by terrorists: a novel that assesses the temper of our times.

title: Giants, 49ers: Few Strong Suits
description: John McVay is going to be at Giants Stadium for O.J. Simpson's farewell appearance in the New York area today, watching a game between two firstyear National Football League coaches, one he works with and one he was replaced by. Between them, the two new coaches have won one of 12 games this season.

title: A LowKey Heir to George Meany
description: WASHINGTON  Up close, Lane Kirkland hardly seems the sort to man the barricades of a class war. Slowspoken and quietvoiced, his chosen rhetorical weapon is sardonic wit rather than flamboyant oratory. He has a taste for contemporary art and fine wines and his range of interests has carried him to a wide variety of activities outside the labor movement, including service on the Rockefeller Commission's investigation of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: THE BRITISH PARTIES AVOID ULSTER ISSUE
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 13  For three weeks, the British political parties have been congregating by the seaside the Liberals at Margate on the North Sea, Labor at Brighton on the English Channel, the Conservatives at Blackpool on the Irish Sea.

title: Sen. Jackson Sees Risk Of ChinaSoviet War Over Vietnam Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (Reuters) A new conflict between Vietnam and China could lead to a war between China and the Soviet Union, Senator Henry Jackson said today.

title: A Native Returns to Explore the Old Streets of Providence
description: Thomas Wolfe was wrong. Sometimes you can go home again. I did recently, to Providence, R.I., and found it not at all the dreary, provincial place of my youthful perceptions, a place I could not wait to escape a quarter century ago, but a vibrant, charming city,one of the most attractive mediumsize cities in the country, rich in history and culture and uniquely rich in beautiful dwellings and public buildings of the late 18th and early 19th centuries.

title: Queens Man's Horse Comes In, And He Wins $1 Million Lottery
description: A Queens men's wear salesman won $1 million yesterday in the New York lottery horse race game, and immediately led his family and assembled officials in chorus of When Irish Eyes Are Smiling.

title: Seoul Government Bars Visit by a Times Reporter
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 13  The South Korean Government said today that it had decided to ban the entry of Richard Halloran of The New York Times to report on a visit to Seoul next week by Secretary of Defense Harold Brown.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Whether one travels by haughty camel, the inefficient auto or any of the other 14 modes of locomotion described here, Guy Billout is a superb companion and guide. Throughout the text and in his spectacular illustrations he always has reins, wheel or stick firmly in hand.

title: Tubbs and Russian To Meet in Semifinal
description: Tony Tubbs has not stopped thinking of the night three years ago, when he lost a decision to Khoren Indzhayan of the Soviet Union. Like a bad dream, the memory is hard to erase.

title: Letters Not to the Editor
description: Doorstep News Delivery Service: Dear Sirs,

title: A Rare Look at The Mythic Plays of Yeats
description: In the early years of the century, when Ireland was little more than an impoverished backwater of the British Empire, William Butler Yeats created a theater that was deliberately intended to raise the dignity of Ireland. The Abbey Theater ofwhich Yeats was a founder, was a people's theater, a theater that sought to explain the Irish to themselves critically and imaginatively. In the words of Yeats's friend and coworker, Augusta Lady Gregory, the Abbey was to have a basis in realism and an apex in beauty.

title: Stanford and U.S.C. in Tie, 2121
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13 (AP) Turk Schonert threw two touchdown passes and ran for one score today as Stanford came back from a 210 halftime deficit to earn a 2121 tie with topranked Southern California.

title: Mailbox: Wheelchair Dispute Continues
description: To the. Sports Editor:

title: Marriage Announcement 13  No Title
description: Kathleen Agnes O'Shea to Be Bride Dec. 29

title: Marriage Announcement 15  No Title
description: Margaret Sullivan Has Bridal

title: La Fontaine in English
description: IT is hard to think of any important writer of recent centuries who much resembles Jean de La Fontaine. The nearest, in some respects, might be his contemporary La Rochefoucauld, whose maxims aimed, as did the morals of La Fontaine's fables, at brisk and witty general observations upon a human nature assumed to be unchanging. The uniqueness of La Fontaine's undertaking lay in his adopting as hismatter the fables of Aesop and others, which everybody knew in prose, and transforming them into delectable narrative poetry calculated, as he said, to please the taste of his age. In his hands, the fables were not merely mises en vers but indeed transformed: A minor and instructive genre became flexible enough to include gaiety and subtle play, the finest psychological nuance, shrewd social and political

title: CARTER TRIP SHOWS STRENGTHS AND WOES
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 13  After a dinner meeting with Jimmy Carter in Albuquerque the other night, the governors of eight Western states emerged with nothing but warm words for the President. He had been attentive and responsive to their concerns, they said, and they had come away very reassured.

title: Western Questions, Eastern Answers
description: CHINESE ENCOUNTERS, the log of a trip the playwright Arthur Miller and his photographer wife Inge Morath made to China a year ago, reveals the blueprints of Miller's mind as much as the outlines of China. It is through Miller's political understanding and sense of esthetics that China comes to life.

title: Headliners
description: How sharper than a serpent's tooth, to have a thankless boss! C. Kenneth Dodd, a herpetologist in the Department the Interior's Office of Endangered Species, thought he was doing a favor for all concerned when he wrote a letter (on Department stationery) to Dominique's, a chic Washington restaurant one of whose specialites is rattlesnake saut au vin rouge. Dr. Dodd pointed out that in Pennsylvania, where the rattlers came from, the rattlesnake is endangered, and asked the restaurant to desist. The letter was reported to The Washington Star, which dealt with it lightly. But Cecil B. Andrus, Secretary of the Interior and a frequent patron of Dominique's, was not amused. Mr. Andrus apologized to Dominique's owner, and Dr. Dodd was fired. Dominique's says it is now selling rattlesnakes from Texas, and lots of them.

title: Texas Tops Sooners On Field Goals, 167
description: DALLAS, Oct. 13  John Goodson, a barefooted placekicker from Houston, finally got an athletic scholarship at Texas two weeks ago, after kicking eight field goals in the first two games of the season. He proved today that he was well North the cost as he kicked three more field goals and provided the margin that gave the undefeated Longhorns a 16.7 victory over previously unbeaten Oklahoma.

title: Knicks Down Bullets In Overtime, 125118
description: Michael Ray Richardson, who made a move from the rookie doghouse to a spot in the starting backcourt, scored 6 points in 1 minute 5 seconds of overtime last night to pave the way for the Knicks 12.5118 victory over the Washington Bullets before a crowd of 10,798 at Madison Square Garden.

title: World Musky Hunt Attracts Anglers in Pursuit of a Tough Catch
description: MINOQUA, Wis.  If you have a friend who is beginning to boast of his angling ability, take him in quest of muskelunge, an endeavor that might be likened to raking leaves with a fork.

title: Yagiello Passes Lift Livingston Over Roxbury
description: Stan Yagiello, a junior quarterback, passed for 331 yards and four touchdowns as Livingston handed Roxbury its first defeat, 2821, yesterday at Livingston. Yagiello, who completed 16 of28 passes, connected with George Alpert on touchdown strikes of 63, 8 and 50 yards. Yagiello also passed 7 yards to Mike Inga fora a score.

title: U.F.O. FILES: THE UNTOLD STORY
description: The Defense Department message bears the classification CONFIDENTIAL. Subject: Suspicious Unknown Air Activity. Dated Nov. 11, 1975, it reads:

title: One of the Late Bloomers
description: HE grew up thinking a woman had only to marry a good man, and she could stay home and have children and never have to worry about the outside world again. So she never bothered to get a college degree, and when she married she left behind any thoughts of a career  forever, she thought. She settled down contentedly to having and raising eight children. Then her husband died of cancer,and Mary Ellen Gordon's life turned around. At 49, she had to take responsibility for supporting herself and providing for her children.

title: Boatworks Strike Drifts Alone.
description: HUNTINGTON NEW York State's only large, recreational boatbuilding concern has been hitting rough seas. Production has been almost at a standstill since the company's workers abandoned ship 11 weeks ago.

title: ANTIQUES
description: period posters  indeed, all posters  are enjoying phenomenal success these days, spawning more and more gallery shows, specialty auctions and books on this commercial art medium. And this fall there will be more activity in this field in New York than at any time in memory.

title: Union Opposes Leyland Closings
description: BIRMINGHAM, England, Oct. 13 (Reuters)  Union officials voted today to oppose plans by British Leyland, the automotive company, to close 13 plants and eliminate 25,000 Jobs. Nearly 250union officials voted against the proposals, aimed at improving efficiency and reversing a slump in sales. Sir Michael Edwardes, the Leyland chairman, has said that a refusal to accept the plans could lead to the closing of the stateowned company.

title: Production and Demand Increase, but Diesel's Future Is Cloudy
description: THE hottest thing in auto showrooms this year is an item that was clattering along when the Gay 90's were tuning up for their first waltz. It is Rudolph Diesel's Rational Heat Engine, and after more than 80 years as a cart horse, the diesel has become the front runner in the race for better mileage.

title: IN THE NATION Is This Trip Needed?
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12  When the Senate recently voted to create an Energy Mobilization Board, Senator J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana remarked that it was necessary to get away from the slowmoving, ponderous bureaucracy of the Department of Energy and to create a small, elite group ... and give them some real powers to cut some red tape.

title: In Fall, the House Is a Home Again
description: RANDOM thoughts to ponder, while waiting for my daughter Katie to finish her ritual in the bathroom:

title: Birth Notice 2  No Title
description: Births

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: FIRST, the muffler fell apart. Then the battery went dead. Next, our Halloweenorange hatchback began to develop an insatiable thirst for oil.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Deaths

title: A Forecast for a Dry Halloween
description: Unless conditions change, as the end of October rolls around, look out. Thus spoke Dan Lundberg, warning that a repeat performance of last summer's gas lines could be in the offing later this month. Mr. Lundberg made the morning news last week with his prediction, published in the Oct. 5 issue of his weekly Lundberg Letter.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: A bracing hike and a spectacular view of the Hudson River and autumn foliage are the bonuses in store Saturday for those who participate in the annual hawk count at Hook Mountain in Nyack. As the birds fly south, some may pause briefly to attack a stuffed owl decoy, affording their audience a closer look. Bill Ephriam of the Yonkers Audubon Society will supervise and submit the statistics to the National Audubon Society and the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: Buying Used? Talk to LeRoy; Buying Used?
description: ONCE I owned a new car. In precisely three years it ran itself and my credit rating into the ground. Every month, I budgeted hundreds of dollars, letting the rent go to make the previous month's payment. Or I'd let that go, and I'd stride outside, keys in hand, to an empty driveway. Repossession elves pay their visits at night, and in the morning, the neighbors laugh.

title: The Opera: Mozart's Abduction From the Seraglio
description: It is hard to believe that Mozart's Entfiihrung aus dem Serail  The Abduction From the Seraglio  until Friday night had received only four performances at the Metropolitan Opera, the last being during the 194747 season. This Singspiel by Mozart is, after all, a repertory item in most opera houses of the world. But for some reason Entfiihrung was avoided at the Metropolitan.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: NINETEENEIGHTY will not be much of a year for new cars, because most of the decade's first models are warmedover 79's.

title: Women Improving in Marathon
description: Ten years ago, there were 72 finishers, none of them women, and the winning time in the first New York City Marathon was 2 hours 31 minutes 38 seconds.

title: Best Sellers
description: This Week

title: Whitman Wins In Cross Country
description: Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday was filled by more than 5,000 runners from 261 schools competing in the Manhattan College interscholastic crosscountry meet, the largest high school crosscountry meet in the nation.

title: Once Again, the Family Question
description: President Carter is still worrying. about the American family. As promised early in his Presidential climb, he is sponsoring a White House conference to put the family question firmlyon the national worry list. He is responding to popular and scholarly debate about what many call the crisis in the American family. Whatever. doubts one may have about the validity of the judgment that there is a crisis, the debate itself is lively. Many people are worried about the family, and many others are worried about those who worry about the family.

title: Rock: Ian Gomm's Songs
description: The great majority of the rock groups with onesyllable names that seem to be crawling out of the woodwork these days would give their string ties and sneakers to write just one song as melodious and memorable as almostanything by Ian Gomm. His tirst album, which comes after a long apprenticeship and associations that link him with Nick Lowe, the Rumour and other English rock favorites, is simply brimming with catchy hooks and lovingly crafted arrangements, and his show at the Bottom Line on Thursday night was a delight.

title: INDIA LOSES GROUND IN FAMILY PLANNING
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 12  When representatives of major women's groups in India met here two weeks ago to draft a manifesto of goals for political action, Rami Chhabra rose to suggest a plank urging improved family planning programs. It was soundly defeated. Later a substitute motion calling for better family welfare was adopted.

title: JUVENILE JUSTICE: A PLEA FOR REFORM
description: On July 27, 14yearold Luis Bonilla sat impassively in the starkly modern courtroom of the Bronx Supreme Court, waiting for the jury to return. He was accusedof shooting and killing a teenager who had resisted Luis's attempt to steal his portable radio; at the time of his crime Luis was 13 years old. If the jury convicted him on charges of seconddegree murder, his sentence would be mandatory life imprisonment, with no chance of parole for at least five years.

title: Marriage Announcement 12  No Title
description: Linda B. Poor Is Fiance of Dale Nicholls

title: Cauliflower Season: Using One's Head
description: WHEN it comes to vegetables, the colors of autumn run to purple, green and white. These are the tones of the cabbage, cauliflower and broccoli maturing in neat rows in Suffolk County fields and piled on the backs of trucks or at farm stands along the highways. They are selling for about 50 cents apiece from the trucks and many of the stands.

title: The Seventh Decade
description: M. KOSTER'Strio of novels about the Republic of Tinieblas, a mad little country that occupies a slice of the lost continent of Central America, weds Nabokov, Grass and Garcia Marquez to Machiavelli. All three books The Prince (1972), The Dissertation (1975) and now Mandragon  explore the seventh decade of our utterly unreal century, with Machiavelli's command of politics and the frail leanings of men. Kiki Sancudo, the crippled hero of The Prince, seems like a stepchild to Oskar Matzerath in The Tin Drum. The central text and long, chatty notes of The Dissertation play on the sad lunacies of Pale Fire. And Mandragon, with its corrupt and magical dictators, could have been torn from Garcia Marquez.

title: The SutherlandHorne Gala
description: LONDON It's something special, an accident of nature, said Marilyn Horne. A kid from the sticks in Pennsylvania and a kid from the bush in Australia come together.

title: Marriage Announcement 10  No Title
description: Miss Keady Bride Of H. V. Zehner Jr.

title: Islanders Bow in Home Opener
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 13  The Islanders lost their second straight contest in the new National Hockey League season tonight when the Buffalo Sabres beat them, 52, ruining a standingroom only, openingnight celebration at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Realty News
description: The Bank of Tokyo Trust Company has leased the entire ground floor and mezzanine and half of the second floor at 360 Madison Avenue at 45th Street.

title: HOUSE UNIT ATTACKS LAG ON TOXIC WASTE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  A House in. vestigative subcommittee charged today that the Government's efforts to deal with dangerous wastes dumped by industry were totally inadequate. The commit. tee said that the waste problem posedan imminent hazard to man and the environment that cannot be overstated.

title: Rooms on Wheels: Van Owners Addy All the Comforts of Home
description: Panel trucks, to Mr. Shippee, evoked images of hippies and rednecks. Outfitted with heavy shag carpeting, floor mattresses and psychedelic murals, the slabsided vehicles suggested altogether the wrong image for a Kidder Peabody stockbroker living in upperclass Short Hills, N.J.

title: Nixons Tied to House With Unusual Style
description: The house that former President Richard M. Nixon is reported to have bought at 142 East 65th Street is a rowhouse that was built 108 years ago for $15,000, not counting land cost, about 50 times the $750,000 that Mr. Nixon is said to have paid for it.

title: Crafts Shops Thrive In Suburban Settings
description: WHEN Minda Shein of East Brunswick, N.J., was hunting for a very special thankyou gift, she headed for the Lillian Kornbluth Gallery in Fair Lawn, where she purchased an unusual ceramic landscape plate by Albert Green. Lucy and Dick Feller ofWestport, Conn., made a similar beeline for the Elements Gallery in Greenwich, where they were seeking a oneofakind gift for a oneofakind friend.

title: The Wild West in an Upstate Museum
description: The Wild West lives on in Ogdensburg, N.Y., and the busy port on the St. Lawrence River is looking forward to some heavy visitor fallout from the 1980 Winter Olympics at Lake Placid, 105 miles to the ea.st. Feb. 1224.

title: Building Cleaning Washes Off Years
description: Some people look at an agedarkened building facade and see tradition, venerability and history. Others see dirt. In New York City, where buildings are being cleaned by the blockful these days, both groups say they are seeing the focus of their debate washed away.

title: It's Japanese and It's Excellent
description: WITHOUT question, Tsubo in Syosset is the best Japanese restaurant on the Island. It has been open just a few months but already seems to have established a loyal clientele of both Japanese and Americans. At lunchtime especially, about twothirds of the patrons are likely to be Japanese enjoying the typical and authentic lunch dishes featured on the menu.

title: Decorating Informally to Suit A Busy Family
description: INFORMAL, said Kathryn Rice without hesitating, when she was asked to describe the home in which she, her husband Joseph, and their two children live. Effortless, one is tempted to add, thinking of the cheerful and relaxed feeling inside their converted schoolhouse in Westchester County.

title: In China, Army Defies Government Orders
description: PEKING, Oct. 13  A professor who was bicycling out of People's University this morning paused to look at a truckload of greenclad soldiers going in through the school Rate.

title: Miss Koo Wed to W. Grey Terry
description: Katherine ChiLien Koo, daughter of Mrs. Gertrude Yang Renaud of New York and TehChang Koo of Taipeh, Taiwan, was married yesterday to W. Grey Terry, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. P. Baldwin Terry of Laurel Hollow, L.I., and Small Point, Me. The ceremony was performed in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest by the Rev. Beatrice Blair.

title: GETTING A KICK OUT OF CALVADOS
description: Remember those wartime pictures of Ernest Hemingway? Not Hemingway the novelist but Hemingway the war correspondent, in full battle dress, rolling across France in a jeep, with two canteens of cognac strapped to his side.

title: Tips From A Maverick Adviser
description: IN the booming careerconsultant business, John C. Crystal is at once the most simple and most enigmatic of men. He relies on traditional, Americansalesman qualities: a commanding voice, bluff good humor, common sense. But there is also an unorthodox Side to this 57yearold former Artily intelligence man. He is regarded as one of themost influential career consultants in the United States today, largely because he believes successful choices can grow only from profound selfknowledge.

title: On Finding a Cab to Get Home After the Cruise Is Over
description: Mo Goodstein closed the door behind a woman and a back seat full of luggage, watched the yellow taxicab pull away from the curb, waved forward another taxi, hollered next to an elderly couple and soon had them on their way home, too.

title: Five Wounded in 3 A.M. Shootout In Brooklyn's Park Slope Section
description: Five men were wounded, three seriously, in a 3 A.M. shootout at a social club in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn yesterday.

title: Film: 'Maria Braun' From Fassbinder:The Cast
description: Hitler's Germany is not just collapsing; it's being pulverized from above, though life goes on. Hermann Braun (Klaus Lowitsch), a private in the German Army, and his pretty young fiance Maria (Hanna Schygulla), are exchanging their vows in a registrar's office when the air raid becomes increasingly fierce. The small room shudders and shakes, but the ceremony continues. There is an especially loud boom and, when a window shatters, the witnesses bolt for the door, followed by the registrar.The furious Hermann, followed by Maria, runs after the registrar, and together they tackle him. Lying flat on the pavement, the terrified registrar between them, bricks and mortar falling all around them, Hermann and Maria are at last made man and wife.It's a monstrously funny scene  Armageddon as screwball comedy. Only Rainer Werner Fassbinder, the prodigiously talented young West German director ("In a Year of 13 Moons," "Effi Briest" and so on) would dare begin a movie about total dissolution with with a sequence dramatizing the end of the known world. Where can one go from there?Mr. Fassbinder's "The Marriage of Maria Braun" goes on in epic  and epically funny  fashion to trace the rise of postwar Germany in the story of the single-mindedly faithful Maria Braun who becomes, in the words of one of her friends, "the Mata Hari of the economic miracle." Never underestimate the power of a woman who loves her husband.After their marriage, Hermann returns to the Russian front where he is reported missing in action. Maria, at first, refuses to believe it. She gets a job in a bar catering to American G.I.'s, but stays true to Hermann until her brother-in-law returns from a prisoner-of-war camp to testify that Hermann is, indeed, dead.Maria drifts into an affair with a black American soldier named Bill, a generous, cheerful, pudgy fellow by whom she becomes pregnant. But wait  Hermann is not dead!As such things tend to go in the realm of farce, Hermann returns one evening just as Maria and Bill are preparing to make love. Maria, with the logic she uses in all crises, explains that although she likes Bill, she loves Hermann. There is a scuffle. Maria hits Bill over the head with a bottle, and in less time than it takes to write these words, Hermann has been packed off to prison and Maria has set off to make a fortune, which the two of them will share when he is released.Watching "The Marriage of Maria Braun," you come to realize that the economic miracle couldn't have happened without either United States aid OR Maria Braun. Her steadfast loyalty, her determination and her total disregard of consequences can move mountains of economic and emotional debris."The Marriage of Maria Braun" may be Mr. Fassbinder's most perfectly realized comedy to date, though the movie's last three minutes remain, for me, utter confusion. Everything I have to say about the movie excludes those final moments, about which I will say nothing out of respect for (and fear of) those letter-writers who don't go to see "Hamlet" because they know how it all turns out."The Marriage of Maria Braun" is both an epic comedy and a romantic ballad, two not especially friendly forms that become seamlessly one in the sweet, tough, brilliantly complex performance of Hanna Schygulla, who is becoming for Mr. Fassbinder what Stephane Audran once was for Claude Chabrol and Anna Karina was for Jean-Luc Godard.Miss Schygulla, the bored, gumchewing amateur tart of "Katzelmacher" and the elegantly doomed heroine of "Effi Briest," is the kind of enchanted actress who, at any one moment in a Fassbinder movie, is the sum of all its parts, plus a little more. Though she always remains inside the film (she's not a bravura sort), she effectively represents everything it's about. This, I suppose, has as much to do with her looks and gestures as it does with the mechanics of a particular performance. Whatever it is, it's splendid and mysterious.Something of the same can be said for the film, which, though it often proceeds as if it were a slapstick comedy, is frequently touching in a way that isn't a Fassbinder characteristic. One reason, I suspect, is that there isn't a single, easily defined villain in the entire film. Maria, Hermann and Oswald (Ivan Desny), the rich textile manufacturer who becomes Maria's lover and her introduction to the world of Big Business, are, each one, coping as well as they can with absolutely terrible fates. It's not as if they were sentimental optimists. They are, instead, rather like children who are determined to believe in Santa Claus long after they know better.The German-language screenplay, written by Peter Marthesheimer and Pea Frolich, with additional dialogue by the director, is the most accomplished of any Fassbinder film I've yet seen, with the exception of Tom Stoppard's for "Despair." It's of that incredible sharpness that cuts through to the bone without giving immediately apparent pain. Very scary though funny."The Marriage of Maria Braun" will be shown at the New York Film Festival in Avery Fisher Hall tonight at 8:30, thus ending this year's festival in the most appropriate way  by reminding us of the still immense possibilities of movies made by masters.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY,Oct,14 VOLENDAM (Holland America). Lett Bermuda Oct. 12; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Stalking the State's Auction Trail
description: PLAINFIELD IT'S one of those beautiful, brisk, colorsplashed fall days, and out in the backyard of an old Hunterdon County farmestate the auctioneer's singsong drones above the noise of the crowd. Arms wave andnumbers are called out. As the gavel raps for a third time, you feel the exhilaration of having topped the bidding: an extravagantly carved Queen Anne headboard is yours.

title: CITY UNION LEADERS TALK OF WAGE GAINS
description: Leaders of New York City's municipal unions are talking of demands for big wage gains and urging an early start of bargaining, even though current contracts run until June 30, 1980.

title: A Guide for Using
description: WITH the cost of fuel rising so dramatically, the heating of private houses this winter has become a major financial burden. For this reason, as well as for ecological and aesthetic ones, many people have traded their kilowatts for woodpiles, and portions of their central heating for an oldfashioned wood stove.

title: Hayes Adjusting to Prison Life
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., Oct. 13 (AP) Bob Hayes, the former Olympian and star Dallas Cowboy receiver, says its tough, but he is very satisfied with the way he has adjusted to prison life.

title: Women: New Opportunity, Old Reality
description: IT has surprised everyone, outstripped all projecttions, and continues to grow with no sign of letup. It is the vast influx of women into the labor force, which a leading economist calls the single most outstanding phenomenon of our century. According to the economist, Eli Ginzberg, chairman of the National Commission for Employment Policy, It's a radical order of change, and we must not underestimate what the cumulative implications are.

title: POPE'S TRIP PRAISED BY CATHOLIC PAPERS
description: While most major Roman Catholic journals praised Pope John Paul II's journey to this country, The National Catholic Reporter said in an editorial that the Pope did not grasp the pluralism of this society on his trip.

title: A History of Our Histories
description: UNTIL recently, this book shows, primary and secondary school textbooks in American history were written on the assumption that all Americans were Protestants  and elected ones at that. But then came a period, still embarrassing the publishers, when the texts took a sudden and overwhelming interest in peanuts and the United Nations Secretariat  or so one might conclude, given the multiple appearances of George Washington Carver and Ralph Bunche. These black instant celebrities seemed to have come from another country or another planet, since there was otherwise no mention of blacks in America.

title: Medicare Patients to Pay More For Hospital Treatment in 1980
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)  The Department of Health, Education and Welfare said this week that Medicare patients would pay at least $20 more for a hospital stay starting Jan. 1.

title: Used Car Market Begins a Recovery
description: IN 1978 and the early part of 1979. the nation's used car market was booming. It's excellent, much stronger than it's been in a long time, Harmon Leiman said at the time. And the views of Mr. Leiman, manager of Galves Auto Supply in New York, the largest usedcar broker in the Northeast, were echoed around the country.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: IT doesn't take much questioning to get both Huntington Supervisor Kenneth C. Butterfield, a Democrat, and Town Highway Superintendent Henry J. Murer, a Republican, to concede that their current squabble has much more to do with politics and patronage than principle.

title: THE CASE AGAINST THE OIL COMPANIES
description: Ever since Jimmy Carter arrived in Washington he has been trying to convince the American people that the periodic oil and naturalgas shortages are not contrived deceptions used by the industry to squeeze more profitsfrom consumers. In his first major speeches to the nation in 1977, when he put on a sweater and declared moral war on the energy problem, he said, I realize that many of you have not believed that we really have an energy problem. He seemed sympathetic. But then, there he was again, during the great gasoline shortage of 1979, back on television, giving his fifth energy speech, still with the same theme. This time he had obviously lost patience. The energy crisis is real, he said, going up half an octave. It is worldwide. It is a clear and present danger to our nation. These are the facts  and we simply must face them.

title: CAMERA
description: Most people have a tendency to trip the shutter on their camera as soon as a pleasing picture or composition comes into view. They willshoot spontaneously without realizing that in many cases a slight change in camera position or angle of view will make important differences  and often improvements  in the final picture.

title: Detroit Works to Wring Out Mileage and Performance
description: DETROIT THE 1980 model year is an important symbolic watershed in the redevelopment of American cars, opening the decade when the strictest Federal standards of economy and exhaust cleanliness fall due, and ringing down a tumultuous decade that gave the auto business its best times along with some of its worst.

title: Norway Jails Hundreds of Lapps Protesting Hydroelectric Project
description: OSLO, Oct. 12 (AP)  Policemen cut chains and padlocks linking Lapps who demonstrated outside Parliament today to block a hydoelectric project, and carted hundreds off to jail. But some returned after they were released, and mounted policemen charged and seized them again.

title: BRIDGE
description: Some remarks in this column last year about unicorns and degrees of uniquity provoked an interesting reaction from Alec Traub of Cape Town, South Africa, who has a world reputation as a bridge mathematician and a composer of tricky deals. He writes: A unicorn is quite unique

title: Japan's Communist Party Has Some Fine Old Italian Styling
description: TOKYO  Two smiling men met the press last week the Yoyogi headquarters of the Japan Communist Party Tokyo. They were Chairman Kenji Miyamoto, at 71 the party's grand old man, and Tetsuzo Fuwa, 20 years his junior, the party's secretary general and the Chairman's handpicked successor to lead one of the more independent Communist parties in the world.

title: Politics Ascribed to an Ouster by Byrne
description: TRENTON, Oct. 13  Governor Byrne has dismissed the chairman of the State Board of Psychological Examiners in a move that board members called politically motivated.

title: During the Fall, the House Once More
description: RANDOM thoughts to ponder, while waiting for my daughter Katie to finish her ritual in he bathroom:

title: On Language
description: Most of us are proud of two things we ought to be ashamed of: illegible handwriting and poor spelling. If our scrawl makes no sense, we assert defiantly, Einstein had terrible handwriting (he did not); when we are caught writing miniscule or embarassing, we congradulate ourselves as if busy writers have no time to be bothered with silly corrections to minuscule, embarrassing and congratulations.

title: Excerpts From Questions and Answers in Carter's Telephone CallIn Program
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of questions and answers in President Carter's callin radio program yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of radio station WNYC:

title: A New Look for Brielle
description: BRIELLE HERE, at the northern tip of the Intracoastal Waterway, some $20 million in waterfront development projects are under way.

title: Storm Threatens in Caribbean
description: MIAMI, Oct. 13 (UPI)  A tropical depression, sometimes the forerunner of storm, has formed in the Gulf of Honduras off Central America, forecasters said today.

title: Heating Oil Issues Unsettled
description: IN June, Governor Grasso was at the White House talking about the need for action to overcome the heatingoil problems that were expected this winter. The summer also brought jarring warnings from other state leaders. Representative AnthonyToby Moffett, chairman of an energy subcommittee in the United States House of Representatives, talked about an emergency of the first order. Benjamin Andrews, head of the Connecticut chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, spoke of a looming crisis.

title: We're All Rabbis, Says Hofstra Rabbi
description: HOFSTRA University has a new Jewish chaplain. The rabbi is also the director of the Hofstra chapter of the Hillel Foundation, the campus ministry of B'nai B'rith, the national Jewish service organization.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: LADYHOUSE BLUES Jo Henderson is in Kevin O'Morrison's play, opening tonight at St. Peter's Church.

title: Shows and Events
description: Tuesday through Thursday  Annual show and sale of antiques sponsored by the New Providence United Methodist Church, 1441 Springfield Avenue, New Providence. Hours: Noon to 9:30 P.M., Tuesday and Wednesday, and noon to 5 P.M. on Thursday. Admission: $1.50. Appraisals will be given Tuesday for a nominal fee. For information, call (201) 4645535.

title: In Summary A Second Review Of Trial Closings By High Court
description: Ideas &Trends

title: Expansion Of Franchises In Rapid Rise
description: WESTCHESTER municipalities have begun award franchises to cabletelevision companies with renewed vigor. In the last 18 months, nine Westchester communities have granted franchises to cable television companies, 11 more are involved negotiations, and 25,000 county residents have become cable television subscribers.

title: Marriage Announcement 16  No Title
description: J.F. Mullin Fianc Of Alison Cooper

title: Man Charged With Trying to Kill Infant by Putting Her on Highway
description: BANGOR, Maine, Oct. 13 (AP)  The father of a 2weekold girl is being held on charges of attempted manslaughter after he allegedly placed her, wrapped in a pink blanket, on a busy highway. A car passed over her, but she was uninjured.

title: HEAT AID FOR POOR IS ELUSIVE IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  The Senate Finance Committee finds itself in a highly unusual position for a group of Congressional politicians. The members, both Democrats and Republicans, want to give $25 billion to $30 billion of Government money to a clearly worthy cause but cannot figure out how to do it before winter nears its end.

title: Couple Leaves Tradition Behind For a New Home on the Water
description: ALMOST two years ago, Mel and Elaine Finkelstein came to a classic crossroad: Their three children had grown up and moved away from home and the large house where they had lived for more than 21 years was too big for just the two of them.

title: Rooms on Wheels: Van Owners Add All the Comforts of Home
description: WHEN his wife decided to buy a van for the family back in 1976, Robert J. Shippee did not approve. In fact, Mrs. Shippee now recalls with a chuckle, He almost died.

title: G.O.P. Woos Kean
description: THOMAS H. KEAN, a former Republican leader in the State Assembly, a former candidate for Governor and a former campaign manager for President Ford, is resisting  thus far, at least efforts aimed at getting him involved in next year's Presidential campaign.

title: Buying a Home With a Partner
description: ACCUSTOMED to living in elegant surroundings for most of their married lives, neither Jane Avery nor Barbara Williamson cared for the idea of ending up alone in a small apartment after they each got divorced six years ago.

title: The New Employer
description: LIKE Broadway, the rockrecords industry and the movies, the nation's retailing industry, the largest employer in the United States, is embarked on a quest for superstars in the light of recent, spectacular successes by individuals.

title: Music Notes: Here Come the Canadians From Ottawa
description: Ten years ago as of last Sunday, the National Arts Center Orchestra of Canada gave its first concert in Ottawa. At the time, no one seems to have thought much of its chances. Canada's capital had had no orchestra of its own; none had been deemed necessary. It was just that the city had acquired a new performing arts center, and it was felt that it ought to have a resident ensemble. so an orchestra was formed, but with a difference. The powers that be had planned wisely rather than in grandiose terms. They decided that a 45piece group would suit the community's needs nicely. As it turned out, it was the ideal size. It has been successful from the start. It observed its 10th anniversary with a gala concert on Oct. 4, presenting Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, and among other celebratory events will be its concert in Carnegie Hall next Friday night.

title: The New Employer
description: IF it. has taken varying degrees of hard work, natural ability, good connections and discreet political maneuvering to get ahead in a career in the past, it may take much, much more for people beginning careers to do the same In the 1980's.

title: Where Jobs Will (and Won't) Be in the 80's
description: Listed below are the job prospects in selected categories through the mid1980's. The list is based on unpublished data from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. The growth in the number of jobs expected in the coming decade in each field is indicated in bold type next to the Job titles. In cases where Job opportunities will drop  such as for secondaryschool teachers  the change is shown with a minus sign.

title: 2 CONGRESSMEN VISIT CASTRO AND REPORT HE FAVORS U.S. TIES
description: Two Democratic member of Congress met with President Fidel Castro of Cuba for more than two and a half hours yesterday and reported that he stood firm against changing his stand on issues irritating to Washington but wanted, nonetheless, to improve relations.

title: Marriage Announcement 18  No Title
description: Kim Elizabeth Whittemore Bride of Edmund Anderson

title: Minnesota Defeated By Michigan, 3121
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 13 (UPI)  Butch Woolfolk, a sophomore tailback from Westfield, N.J., scored two touchdowns, including a gameclinching 91yard burst with 4:51 to play, and Lawrence Reid added two scores to help Michigan score a 3121 Big Ten victory over Minnesota today.

title: SCOTTO PROSECUTION IS NEARING ITS END
description: A prosecution team has presented three waterfront businessmen, several supporting witnesses and numerous tape recordings in an effort to prove that two officials of the International Longshoremen's Association obtained illegal cash payoffs.

title: Lucille Hardin de Zalduondo Is Married To Richard Henry Briance, Bank Manager
