description: The credit markets, emerging from what appears to have been their most harrowing week on record, do not think that interest rates have yet reached their peaks.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Marriage Announcement 6  No Title
description: Marriages

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Paul Kolton, 56 years old, a former chairman of the American Stock Exchange, has been named chairman of INA Investment Securities, a closedend investment company traded on the New York Stock Exchange. J. Robert Douglas, 42, has been named president and chief executive officer. The appointments follow the death last month of Edward D. Little, who had held all three posts.

title: Barking Geese and Butternuts
description: Last spring's pigs have grown so big they're already having trouble peering out from underneath their ears. Maples are turning scarlet and orange, beech trees bronze and blackberry leaves winedark. Poplars are slower to change because they try to squeeze every last growing day out of the year. The oaks are slow both in the fall and spring.

title: Sports Today
description: World Cup championships, semifinals, at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 8 P.M.

title: Giants49ers Summary
description: FIRST QUARTER

title: Books of The Times
description: USSELL BAKER, the Observer columnist of The New York Times, once thoughtfully provided for uneventful days a list of newspaper headlines suitable for use at any time. One such headline was Scientists Discover That Enjoying Yourself Causes Cancer. Itwas a typically trenchant Baker absurdity, the humor tempered by the shock of a nasty underlying truth.

title: Deputy Mayor Wagner Treads Familiar Path at City Hall
description: Robert F. Wagner Jr. had been there before.He was there in 1949, when his father was sworn in as Manhattan Borough President and his brother Duncan nearly bashed Mayor William O'Dwyer in the head with a window pole during the ceremonies.

title: Japan's Economic Influence Is Everywhere in South Korea
description: SUKWANG, South Korea  The aged potter was led into the room, leaning on a stick. He wore a diaphanous linen robe and his shiny nose stuck out from beneath a mass of white, floating hair.

title: Northern Tier Oil Line Is Endorsed by Andrus
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP)  Interior Secretary Cecil D. Andrus endorsed today the proposal of the Northern Tier Pipeline Company as the best of four competing proposals to move excess Alaskan crude oil eastward from the West Coast.

title: Kush Ouster Laid to CoverUp
description: TEMPE, Ariz., Oct. 15  The Arizona State University athletic director said today that Frank Kush was dismissed as head football coach because he was attempting to cover up his alleged striking of a team member in a game last year.

title: N.A.S.L. Backs 3 Teams Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15  The North American Soccer League opened its annual meeting here today by unanimously approving the sales of the Memphis Rogues, Portland Timbers and Seattle Sounders.

title: Plan Would Aid Mortgage Supply
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP)  The nation's largest supplier of home mortgages today proposed a new way to expand the availability of mortgage money to homeowners.

title: Managua Junta Warns of Steps By Extremists
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 10Eleven weeks after the Sandinist victory over the Somoza dictatorship, the initial mood of euphoria has given way to new nervousness and uncertainty.

title: Issue and Debate Evenhanded Treatment of Moscow and Peking Faces Test
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15  Sometime in the next two weeks, the Carter Administration plans to send Congress the text of a trade agreement signed with China last July. If approved, the accord will give Peking the commercial advantages assigned almost all of America's trade partners.

title: Fugard Hello and Goodby Opens Oct. 31 at St. Peter's
description: Hello and Goodby, a twocharacter play by Athol Fugard about a brother and sister relationship, will be performed in English and Spanish by Miriam Colon Edgar's Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, beginning Oct. 31 at St. Peter's Hall at 326 West 20th Street.

title: Patent Official Named
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) President Carter today named Sidney A. Diamond, 65 years old, a lawyer with the New York City firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, to be Commissioner for Patents and Trademarks.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: Death

title: Panel in Riverside Church Offers Strategy to Combat Arms Race
description: Religious people should work for disarmament by combining knowledge, political action and moral fervor, panelists at a How to Reverse the Arms Race convocation declared yesterday at Riverside Church.

title: 1,000 Israelis Set Up Temporary West Bank Outposts
description: OFRA, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Oct. 15  More than a thousand members of the zealous Gush Emunim tanned out before dawn today from 25 settlements on the occupied West Bank and set up illegal, makeshift outposts at 40 sites to demonstrate their demand for expanded Jewish settlement on land owned by Arabs.

title: No Arms for Morocco's War
description: King Hassan II of Morocco, long an ally of the United States, has gotten himself into trouble by trying to annex the former Spanish Sahara. Guerrillas of the Polisario Front, backed by Algeria, have thwarted the expansion, driven the King's Mauritanian ally from the war and attacked Morocco itself. Fearing that a compromise would destroy him politically, the King is trying instead to get American military aid. Officials of the Carter Administration are now weighing the request.

title: RHODESIA REBELS GET BRITISH ULTIMATUM
description: LONDON, Oct. 15  Britain said today that it would resume the Zimbabwe Rhodesia conference tomorrow, but that the Patriotic Front guerrillas would be welcome only if they agreed to British proposals for a new constitution.

title: Use of Tobacco By Nation Sets A 46Year Low
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP)  The per capita use of tobacco by Americans is at a 46year low, an Agriculture Department report said today, even though the use of chewing tobacco has shown modest increases in recent years.

title: Belmont Ends Meet; Pincay Is Top Jockey
description: Laffit Pincay rode three winners yesterday and clinched Belmont's meet championship, but victory in the closingday feature eluded him.

title: Around the Nation
description: POPE AIR FORCE BASE, N.C., Oct. 15 (AP)  Capt. Robert Coronado, an avowed homosexual who was convicted of conduct unbecoming an officer, was dismissed from the Air Force today. The dismissal, equivalent to a dishonorable discharge for an enlisted man, will be automatically appealed.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Deaths
description: SLATERFannie, beloved wife of Nathan for over 60 years, dear mother of Mildred and Ben, Jean and the late Irwin, devoted nanny of Barbara, Susan, Amy and Diane and greatgrandmother of Jason, sister of Jeannette Miller and sisterInlaw of David and Evelyn Slater and Miriam Slater. Service Tuesday. Oct 16, 11:45AM, The Riverside, 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. Family will be at the chapel Monday evening, 7:309 PM.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Soar Above 11%
description: Rates on Treasury bills, the shortterm securities that are sold every week by the Federal Government, soared yesterday to their highest levels in history  well above 11 percent as the credit markets resumed their trend toward lower prices and higher interest rates.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: THE first volume of Henry A. Kissinger's memoirs is longer than Leo Tolstoy's War and Peace, and we don't even get to Watergate. The question is, is it worth the time it takes to read it? The answer is yes. Of course. it is selfserving  especially on Cambodia and Chile and the Christmas bombings of North Vietnam in 1972  but the principal purpose of almost any memoir is to serve the self. St. Augustine's Confessions may be an exception.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Where does ear wax come from?

title: Film Shows Simms Had Excellent Day
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 15  Ray Perkins saw the Giants 3216 victory over the San Francisco 49ers yesterday, but he still found some revealing things on the game films about Phil Simms's performance.

title: 3 Americans, German and Pakistani Cited
description: At 10 A.M. yesterday morning, Dr. Glashow, his hair tousled and his grin broad, walked into his undergraduate course in particle physics at Harvard University and apologized to his students. I told them I had to cancel the class and explain particle physics to the press, he said. He left the lecture hall to the accompaniment of applause.

title: Tubbs Gains Final For Heavyweights
description: Even as controversy about the playing of the United States national anthem swirled around the Felt Forum last night, Tony Tubbs, a heavyweight from Santa Monica, Calif., battled his way into the final of the World Cup amateur boxing tournament.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press in Business Day on Friday inaccurately reported on the participation in a $44.5 million project to improve farmland in northern China. Dekalb Agresearch Inc. of Illinois has not yet agreed to participate.

title: Navy Changes Its Policy On Hispanic Applicants
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP)  The Navy has agreed to change a recruiting policy that was said to discriminate against Hispanic applicants, Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, who pushed for an investigation that led to the new policy, said today.

title: United Technologies Reports Rise in Net
description: The United Technologies Corporation, one of the nation's largest aircraft manufacturers, reported yesterday that it had a 37.7 percent increase in earnings for the third quarter. Harry J. Gray, president, said that the Hartfordbased company had a business backlog exceeding $10 billion for the first time in history.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: World News Briefs
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Tuesday, Oct. 16 (Reuters)  Afghanistan's armed forces have crushed an attempted coup and seized half a dozen rebel leaders, Radio Kabul said today.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY. OCTOBER 16. 1979

title: New Drugs Offer Help for Severe Pain
description: FOUR new synthetic drugs, members of a class of compounds known as antagonistanalgesic opiates, promise to improve significantly the treatment of chronic and severe pain, as well as offering patients some path to safety, according to researchers.

title: Market Place
description: AS interest rates kept climbing this summer and autumn, a number of Wall Street analysts cited the merits of deepdiscount bonds, those fixedincome instruments with a potential capital gains kicker.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FOOTLIGHT SWITCHES These Wednesday afternoons the cast of the longrunning Mummenschanz is adding a postmatinee bonus: an informal explanation of the visual mysteries and magic in their miming, with questions invited from the audience. And in a welcome splash of Off Off Broadway color, two new productions of classic dramas, The House of Bernarda Alba and The Diary of Anne Frank are geared for Spanishspeaking audiences.

title: Volcker Says Rates Might Fall
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 In his first Congressional appearance since the Federal Reserve Board made its new credittightening moves, Paul A. Volcker, the board's chairman, stressed today that the current period of high interest rates could end almost as abruptly as it had begun.

title: James Pollard, 84, of Ohio State
description: Dr. James E. Pollard, professor of journalism emeritus at Ohio State University and former director of its School of Journalism, died Saturday at Mount Cannel Medical Center in Columbus, Ohio. He was 84 years old and lived in Columbus.

title: BUSINESS Digest .
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1979

title: Notes on People
description: My new book is being published in New York this month, but I wouldn't dream of being there for it, Peggy Guggenheim was saying by telephone from her palace in Venice yesterday.

title: About New York
description: New York may not exactly be the Vienna of American music, but it has, over the years, made America sing along to the tunes it called. Talk of pop and you talk of the old Paramount theater and the big bands; of Tin Pan Alley, near Broadway in the West 20's, wherethe writers tried to get a rhyme for love, moon, Alabama or Massachusetts, according to current market demand; of the Brill Building on Broadway north of Times Square, where composers issued songs with the frequency of a threeedition daily newspaper.

title: Oksana Yablonskava's Saga
description: IF you want to know how it feels to go from being somebody to nobody and back to somebody, all in two years, ask Oksana Yablonskaya. Miss Yablonskaya, a Moscowborn pianist, underwent that unsettling experience aver applying tor permission to leave the Soviet Union in 1977 as a Jewish emigre. But now that she finds herself back working at her profession and about to become a United States citizen, she can smile and say: I feel my hand, like this, to tell myself it is all true. When I was in Russia, I couldn't believe I would ever play another note. Soviet officials had deprived her of all concerts and teaching opportunities for two years, apparently for asking to be allowed to leave the a country. I had to sell my piano, a Bechstein, to live.

title: ExLineman Sues Bears For Negligence on Iniury
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP)  Roger Stillwell, formerly a defensive lineman with the Chicago Bears, filed a suit today that charged that the team and its physicians were negligent in treating a knee injury that forced him to retire.

title: Mr. October Says: Birds Win in Six
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 15  In other years, he was Mr. October, the slugger who thrived on the World Series stage. This time Reggie Jackson is not even a TV voice. In choosing its commentators, the ABC networkpreferred Don Drysdale, who worked its regularseason games, to the Yankee slugger, who had analyzed the1976 American League playoffs. But, on the premise that viewers should not be deprived of Reggie Jackson'sopinions and observations, a phone call was made to him today at his hilltop home above Oakland, Calif., where he created the foundation of his October reputation with the A's prior to his Yankee scenarios.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: McCormick & Company, the world's largest seasonings producer, disclosed yesterday that Sandoz Ltd., a diversified Swiss company best known as the maker of Ovaltine, had accumulated 465,000 shares, or 9.8 percent, of McCormick.

title: Toyota, Nissan Raise Exports
description: TOKYO, Oct. 15 (AP) Japan's two major automobile producers reported today that exports rose in September.

title: Americans at Harvard and Purdue Win  German and Pakistani Cited
description: Chemical research as downtoearth as arthritis medicine and a theory of physics so profound as to affect man's perception of existence were both honored by Nobel Prizes yesterday.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: A Murder Defendant Escapes From Court
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 15 Robert R. Reldan, whose murder trial is nearing completion here, escaped from a thirdfloor courtroom today by immobilizing a guard with Chemical Mace, leaping 35 feet from a window ledge and then stealing a car from a nearby parking lot. He was retaken about an hour later.

title: Democracy For Latins
description: WASHINGTON  If the Caribbean, especially Cuba, deserves United States attention, then Latin America deserves it even more, because the time is ripe for us to support and encourage the peaceful restoration of democratic government there. The successful transitions in Portugal and Spain from authoritarianism to democracy illustrates that there can be a similiar change in some LatinAmerican countries without extremism and revolution.

title: Forest Hills Event Reset
description: A $500,000 World Championship Tennis tournament at Forest Hills Tennis Club, which has suffered from poor attendance by players and the public the last two years, has been rescheduled and renamed.

title: N.B.A. Notes: Free Gets AllWorld Start
description: Lloyd Free, sometimes known as AllWorld, at other times known as the Prince of MidAir, is off to an outstanding start. After a 46point performance against the Los Angeles Lakers in a National Basketball Association opener last Friday night, the 6foot2inch San

title: EDUCATION U.S. Study Assails Vocational Courses
description: EACH day of the school year, millions of high school students learn about auto mechanics, data processing, medical technology and other vocational skills that are supposed to enhance their chances of success in the job market.

title: The Doctor's World
description: SHORTLY after I became an epidemiologist at the Center for Disease Control in Atlanta in 1963, one of my bosses, Dr. Donald A. Henderson, startled me at lunch when he said that smallpox, an incurable, potentially fatal viral disease, could be eradicated if only new public health management methods were combined with traditional vaccinations.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar at High for Year Against Yen
description: The dollar gained in value against major world currencies yesterday, reaching a high for the year against the Japanese yen in Tokyo trading.

title: Kia Ngau Chang, at 90; Economist and Banker
description: Kia Ngau Chang, an economist, banker and former senior research fellow at Hoover Institution, Stanford University, died Saturday in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 90 years old.

title: Interedec to Increase Holding in Wallace
description: The Sam P. Wallace Company said that Carl P. Wallace, the company's former chairman, and six other stockholders had agreed to sell their holdings in the company to Interedec U.S.A., a company controlled by Ghaith R. Pharaon. the Arab financierfor about $5 million.

title: Anderson Says He'll Call A Session on Cost of Fuel
description: Criticizing an evident lack of leadership by Governor Carey's administration in addressing the soaring costs of heating fuel, the leader of the State Senate's Republican majority said yesterday that he would call the Senate into session on Nov. 8 to act on a Republican program.

title: COMMODITIES Sugar Futures Surge Amid Strong Demand
description: By The Associated Press

title: Advertising
description: ALFRED J. SEAMAN, who has been president of SSC & B for 18 years, was elected last month to the additional posts of chairman and chief executive by its board, and last week to the board and executive committee of the parent Interpublic Group of Companies by its board.

title: Jets Defeat Vikings by 147
description: The New York debut of Monday Night Football ended last night with a 197 Jets victory over Minnesota, with more than a dozen fans sent to hospitals, with three security guards injured, with two fans arrested and with more than 30 spectators suffering from cuts, bruises and more serious injuries.

title: Oct. 140 Auto Sales Fell 35.8%
description: DETROIT, Oct. 15 (UPI)  The Big Three auto makers reported today that combined sales in early October were down 35.8 percent from the level of a year ago, when newmodel introductions lifted sales to a record for the neriod.

title: Carter's Ironic Choice
description: Panicked by his poor showing in the polls, President Carter has turned his back on his own principles and on the most solid and organized constituency he has  the environmentalists  for illusory political gain. In a number of farreaching environmental decisions in the last few months, he has appeased major exploiters and developers and the politicians representing them. But they are the very ones least likely to support him in the long run.

title: The Tidies Who Cleaned a Harlem Street
description: There was a time when Rowena H. Mays's block in central Harlem was as dirty as any bad block in New York City. Graffiti headlined the neighborhood's deterioriation. Broken glass crunched underfoot. Garbage was airmailed, or tossed out the window, instead of being carried to the trash cans.

title: U.S. Blacks Visit Israeli Unionists And Stress Dislike of Terrorism
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 15  Black American civil rights leaders troubled by the strains in relations between blacks and Jews in the United States met with Israeli labor officials today and emphasized strong opposition to Palestinian organizations using terrorism.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE Chairman Resigns At Arthur Andersen
description: Harvey Kapnick, an outspoken maverick in the taciturn and traditionbound accounting profession, resigned unexpectedly yesterday as chairman and chief executive of Arthur Andersen & Company, the Chicagobased international accounting firm said.

title: KATHRYN B. MILLER, PHILANTROPIST, 83
description: Kathryn Bache Miller, one of New York City's most generous philanthropists and for more than 40 years a leading hostess here and in London, died last night at her home at 550 Park Avenue.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, Oct. 15, 1979 lavel??tary Pet???, Filed Ag??st:

title: TaxFree 8% Yields Spreading
description: Taxexempt bonds yielding 8 percent or even more  the highest such rates of return offered to investors since 1975  became widespread yesterday as the credit markets continued to react to the Federal Reserve's credittighteningmoves announced more than a week ago. Illinois postponed a $150 million bond sale, and bond dealers predicted that other issues would be reduced in size, postponed or canceled altogether.

title: Dance: Aman Ensemble
description: AMAN is a variant form of amen. It's also the name of the folkdance troupe that appeared Saturday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. That performance made one say, Amen, indeed! to the Aman International Folk Ensemble, for the company proved remarkable in many ways.

title: Aiello Is Still Under Consideration As Carter Aide, White House Says
description: The White House, commenting yesterday on press reports that Stephen R. Mello, president of New York City's Board of Education, might not be appointed a special assistant to the President, said Mr. Aiello was still being considered.

title: EARNINGS Chase and Bankers Trust Gain
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Bankers Trust New York Corporation yesterday reported strong gains in earnings in the third qarter.

title: Health Warning For Hair Dyes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP)  The Food and Drug Administration ordered manufacturers today to place warnings on the labels of permanent hair dyes containing a chemical known to cause cancer in animals

title: Uncertain Victory for Carter
description: MIAMI, Oct. 15  Statistically, President Carter is now assured of more delegates from Saturday's Florida Democratic caucuses than Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts. And the Carter camp now boasts that it has provedthe President's grassroots strength against Mr. Kennedy and dispelled any notion that the Carter reelection campaign is in danger of early collapse.

title: 11 on Ship's Crew Are Charged With Smuggling Haitian Aliens
description: MIAMI, Oct. 15 (AP)  Eleven crew members of a Panamanian freighter have been arrested by United States Border Patrol agents on charges of smuggling Haitian aliens.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: VERA DALLAS

title: IN THE NATION Not For the Asking
description: WASHINGTON  No matter who boasts of the best showing or claims a moral victory, the essentially meaningless caucus voting by about 40,000 Florida Democrats suggests only one thing  that a tough race lies ahead between President Carter and Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYC. Five Symphonies for Viols and Basso Continuo, L. Couperin; Sinfonia in E minor, C.P.E. Bach; Three Preludes and Fugues, Werner.

title: Fear and Anger Voiced in Wake Of Bronx Killing
description: Residents of the Pelham Parkway Houses in the Bronx expressed fear and anger yesterday in the aftermath of the slaying last Friday of 26yearold Francine Elverson.

title: EventsToday
description: LA CASA DE BERNARDA ALBA (The House, of Bernardi Alba), by Federico Garcia Lorca; directed by Rene Such; presented by the Spanish Repertory Company, Gilberto Zaldivar, producer. At the Gramercy Arts Theater, 138 East 27th Street, 8.

title: Music: Sutherland and Home
description: GREAT Performers at Lincoln Center had two great performers last night  Joan Sutherland and Marilyn Horne. One could stretch the point and say that Great Performers at Lincoln Center had well over 100 great performers on stage. The celebrated divas were accompanied by no less than the entire New York Philharmonic, conducted by Richard Bonynge. It was a glamorous event that was televised, and those who could not get into the hall could see it on the tube, or will be seeing it in reruns.

title: Book Fair Opens in Peking Park
description: PEKING, Oct. 15 (Reuters)  A book fair has opened in a Peking park with works ranging from dictionaries to children's stories on sale, the New China News Agency said. The buyers, mainly students, snapped up 750,000 volumes over the weekend, the agency added. Books on sale included works by Balzac, Dickens, Gorky and modern American writers.

title: Bequest of $3 Million to the Blind Faces Court Fight
description: HUNTINGTON, W.Va., Oct. 15 (AP)A county court has been asked to decide the validity of a will, scrawled on the backs of old business papers, that leaves most of a $3 million estate to aid the blind.

title: Petrocan Distribution Is Likely
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 15  Prime Minister Joe Clark's minority ProgressiveConservative Government is expected to give every Canadian citizen a shareholding interest in PetroCanada following the defeat tonight of the second attempt in five days to throw it out of office over the issue of dismantling the corporation. A noconfidence motion was rejected by a vote in the House of Commons of 137 to 128.

title: 1967 Theory Says 2 Basic Forces Are Part of the Same Phenomenon
description: The awarding of the Nobel Prize in Physics yesterday to two Americans and a Pakistani has come as no surprise to those who, over the last few years, have followed experiments that gave increasingly strong support to a theory that many view as among the most momentous of this century.

title: Rate War Grips RentaCars
description: Expensive World Series television commercials have proclaimed it, a scurrying about from counter to counter at airports has confirmed and recessionconscious executives are worrying about it. A bitter and expensive rate war has suddenly broken out in the S2.5 billion rentacar industry.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: You No Longer Have To Pay 52505400 for the designer suits you want to own The Working Woman. a division of PARIS FASHIONS manufacturer of leading designers. was created for today S woman on the go Coats, suds, raincoats, blazers, skirts at a fraction of the retail price 270 W 38 St 17th flr,2796019 Daily 104. Sat 103 Major Credit Cards Accepted

title: Harlem Lenders Cited In Survey as Violators Of Laws on Redlining
description: Financial institutions in Central Harlem are violating the state's law against redlining by practicing almost total geographic discrimination in mortgage lending against the area, the New York Public Interest Research Group charged in a study released yesterday.

title: Letter: On Egyptian Film Censorship
description: To the Editor:

title: Coops Leading Latest Renaissance in Brooklyn
description: Just under the Brooklyn Heights end of the Brooklyn Bridge, its strings humming with the passing traffic, Joe Albany is playing his imaginative jazz piano near the crackling fireplace in Olga Bloom'swalls admit the glittering dazzle of nighttime Manhattan, two or three apparently diamondstudded bridges, the lightstruck flow of the East River and the Statue of Liberty's distant torch.

title: Critic's Notebook Schoenberg: Musician And Sensitive Artist
description: HUMAN vanity has no bounds, as we know, but even so there are limits to its expression. I do not know, for example, of any living painter or sculptor who would hire Carnegie Recital Hall and expect people to nay to hear him play the Hammerklavier sonata. Ingres in the 19th century could take up his violin and play pieces that were in the virtuoso repertory until quite lately, and Henri Matisse believed that if ever his art went out of fashion, he could keep his family by playing the violin in the streets. But, generally speaking, that kind of duality is now out of style.

title: Chief of Social Security Warns on Benefits Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI)  The Commissioner of Social Security said today that any reduction of the Social Security tax increase scheduled for 1981 should be made up from general tax revenues, not reduced services.

title: Angels Resign Downing
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 15 (AP)  The California Angels announced today that Brian Downing, an AllStar catcher who was eligible to become a free agent this fall, has signed a multiyear contract with the American League baseball team. No other terms of the contract were announced.

title: Piano: Chester Fanning Smith
description: IT was a pleasure to encounter Aaron Copland's seldomplayed Piano Sonata (193941) at Chester Fanning Smith's recital Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall. With its chiseled contours and biting rhythms, it is a handsome work, reflective both of vast spaces and urban frenzy, fraught with loneliness but ultimately serene.

title: About Education
description: IN his annual report to the public and the profession, Verne Duncan, the Superintendent for Public Instruction in Oregon, asked the state's educators to make a firm commitment to excellence. A few days later, Dr. Duncan's views wereechoed by Dr. Franklin B. Walter, his counterpart in Ohio. The members of Ohio's State Board of Education concurred. And in New Jersey, State Education Commissioner Fred G. Burke recommended the introduction of high school graduation requirements that would include successful completion of four years of English, two years of mathematics, one year of science and two years of history.

title: Minis and the 60's: Paris Fashions Look Back
description: PARIS, Oct. 15  Remember the mini? That's what you were wearing in that old picture you laughed so much over when you showed it to some friends the other day.

title: Subway Trains Delayed by Fire
description: Subway service between Brooklyn an Manhattan on the IRT line was disrupte for about 45 minutes yesterday mornin by a fire on the tracks. The Transit Authority said that some ties had caught firaround 8:30 along the express track jus?? north of Nevins Street in Brooklyn. N?? trains were caught between station when the power was turned off in the are of the fire, a spokesman said. Service Wa suspended between Franklin Avenue j?? Brooklyn and stations in lower Manha tan until the fire was put out.

title: Brooklyn Jewish Gets a Reprieve Until Next Week
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge gave the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn another reprieve last night, delaying any move to close it for 10 more days.

title: The Power Behind the Government in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia Lieut. Gen. Peter Walls, supreme commander of the Zimbabwe Rhodesian armed forces, likes to portray himself as a professional soldier simply following orders.

title: Wolfe Book Brings $1.1 Million
description: The Right Stuff, Tom Wolfe's account of the United States first manned space program and the seven astronauts connected with it, has been sold for $1.1 million to United Artists and to Bantam, the paperback house.

title: Allied Has Large Loss In Quarter
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation yesterday reported a loss of $123.7 million for the third quarter ended Sept. 30, compared with a profit of $24.9 million in last year's quarter.

title: U.S. Hopeful on Rhodesian Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 15  American officials said today that they regarded the apparent deadlock between Britain and the Rhodesian guerrillas as just another of many crises rather than the definitive breakoff of negotiations.

title: TALKS ON PACT OPEN AT AILING CHRYSLER
description: DETROIT, Oct. 15  The United Automobile Workers started contract bargaining with the Chrysler Corporation today and agreed from the outset to accept less from the financially troubled automobile maker than it has already won from General Motors and Ford.

title: Tate Will Spar For 15 Rounds
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 15 (AP)  John Tate will take part in a full dress rehearsal Wednesday night for the World Boxing Association title fight against Gerrie Coetzee of South Africa Saturday night.

title: Stocks Off Broadly On OilPrice News
description: Unexpected increases in oil prices by two foreign producers, combined with the continuing impact of the Federal Reserve Board's push to higher interest rates, sent the stock market broadly lower yesterday on the heels of last week's huge selloff.

title: Koch Invites Direct Pressure By Financial Control Board
description: Mayor Koch urged the statecreated Financial Control Board yesterday to put pressure on the semiautonomous Health and Hospitals Corporation and Board of Education to act now to prevent budget deficits by the end of the year. Mr. Koch's move represented a subtle but significant shift in his approach to dealing with the citv's fiscal problems.

title: Supreme Court Roundup Judicial Immunity in Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15  The Supreme Court agreed today to hear an appeal by the Virginia Supreme Court from an unusual Federal court order requiring the Viginia court to reimburse a consumer group for more than $100,000 in attorney's fees.

title: Richard Weininger, 92, Financier;  Headed Premier Investing Corp.
description: Richard Weininger, a financier and industrialist, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 92 years old and lived in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Suit on Auxiliaries Thrown Out
description: A lawsuit to stop members of New York City's auxiliary police force from performing regular police duties was thrown out of court yesterday by Justice Nathanlei Heiman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan. He said the dispute between Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire and Samuel DeMilia, head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, was a matter for collective bargaining, not court action. Last month the Police Department instituted a 90day trial program under which the auxiliary policemen patroled the streets in spare police radio cars.

title: A Peripatetic Austrian Is a U.S. Citizen at 100
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 15 (AP) A judge administered the oath of citizenship here today to a 100yearold Austrian woman who first arrived on America's shores in 1899 but had to return to her homeland twice  first because of illness and again because she couldn't find work.

title: Syrian Leader Arrives in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 15 (AP)  President Hafez alAssad of Syria arrived in Moscow today on an official visit expected to include a full review of Syria's position in the Middle East situation. His arrival was announced in midafternoon by Radio Moscow.

title: Deaths
description: PEGLERIda, beloved wife of Karl, mother of Harry and Peg Candee, grandmother of Robert and Glen, greatgrandmother of Brian and Jason. Funeral services at The Riverside, 76th and Amsterdam Ave, Wednesday at 1 PM.

title: Students' Publishing Off Campus Is Ruled Beyond School's Control
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled yesterday that officials at an upstate New York high school violated the First Amendment rights of four students by punishing them for publishing a magazine off campus that was accused of being obscene.

title: Goldschmidt Says I84 to Proceed In Connecticut, but He Is Doubted
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 15  Federal Transportation Secretary Neil Goldschmidt today announced conditional approval for the completion of a major section of Interstate 84 between here and the Connecticut border with Rhode Island. But after the secretary made his statement, questions were raised about it by officials of both the Federal Environmental Protection Agency and Mr. Goldschmidt's own Transportation Department.

title: The Region
description: VALHALLA, N.Y. (UPI)  A man and a woman whose bodies were found Sunday morning in the woman's Mahopac home were bludgeoned and shot several times with a .38caliber pistol and their throats were slashed, the Westchester County Medical Examiner's office said yesterday.

title: How  and What  to Overcome
description: Thanks to the hard work and soothing words of Vernon Jordan, Benjamin Hooks, Alexander Schindler, Howard Squadron and others, the rift between American blacks and Jews has begun to heal. These responsible leaders have struggled to be heard above the resentful pronouncements of blacks who sought attentionas the tamers of the P.L.O. and of Jews who retaliated by withdrawing support from joint social action at home. This strife not only threatened an already strained political coalition for liberal causes. It also evoked some dangerous passions by encouraging blacks and Jews to think of each other as holding incompatible, stereotyped views on the Middle East. The tension has been hard to contain because it had so little to do with the issues actually being discussed.

title: Bush Easily Wins Iowa Straw Vote For Republican Presidential Choice
description: DES MOINES, Oct. 15  George Bush, who is counting heavily on a good showing in the Iowa precinct caucuses Jan. 21 to increase his chances for the Republican Presidential nomination, handily won a straw poll taken at a major party fundraising dinner in nearby. Ames over the wezkend.

title: Bank Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown.( N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Drama: Watch on the Rhine Revived
description: NEW HAVEN LILLIAN HELLMAN has said that the reallife models for characters in Watch on the Rhine were like people in a play who did not know that the scenery had changed to the edge of a volcano.

title: Shearson Profits Higher in Quarter
description: The brokerage firm of Shearson Hayden Stone Inc. said yesterday that its profits rose 26.5 percent and that revenues were up 36.5 percent in the quarter ended Sept. 30.

title: Hospital Costs Up 13.3%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI)  The latest figures from the hospital industry show costs for 1979 running at a rate 13.3 percent ahead of last year, the American Hospital Association said today.

title: Federal Prosecutors Finish Their Case Against Scotto and Anastasio
description: Federal prosecutors completed their case yesterday against Anthony M. Scotto and Anthony Anastasio, two dock union leaders charged with obtaining cash payoffs from waterfront businessmen.

title: Baryshnikov Quits Ballet
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov, who had said he planned to remain with the New York City Ballet for another year before becoming artistic director of the American Ballet Theater, has resigned from the City Ballet.

title: SALVADOR MILITARY DEPOSES PRESIDENT TO RESTORE ORDER
description: SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 15  The President of El Salvador was deposed today in a military coup, and the armed forces said they had acted to restore constitutional order to the Central American republic.

title: The City
description: Charles Biers, the $39,000ayear director of administration for the City Comptroller's office, was dismissed by Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin yesterday for taking a cityowned car to his Jericho, L.I., home during a twoweek vacation in August. It was believed to be the most stringent penalty ever imposed for the unauthorized use of a city vehicle.

title: A.C.L.U. Opens a Line To Help on Discharges
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI)  The American Civil Liberties Union today opened a tollfree phone line to help veterans who received less than honorable discharges to file for a review before a Dec. 31 deadline.

title: Chemist to Be Du Pont President
description: Edward G. Jefferson, a 58year old chemist who has been responsible for directing research and development at E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company since last January, has been named president and chief operating officer, effective Jan. 1, 1980. He will succeed Edward R. Kane, who will retire at the age of 61.

title: Tate Is Already a Winner in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 15  The American challenger for the World Boxing Association heavyweight championship stood in the arrival terminal of Jan Smuts International Airport here, waiting for a friend. He wore a baseball cap that said Big John Tate, a Tshirt that said Adidas and a demeanor that said very friendly.

title: Connecticut General Insurance Makes $480 Million Bid for ERC
description: The Connecticut General Insurance Corporation, one of the largest multiline insurers in the country, offered informally yesterday to pay at least $80 a share, or $480 million in cash, for the ERC Corporation, a leading reinsurer based in Kansas City, Mo.

title: Turkish Government to Quit After Election Defeat
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Tuesday, Oct. 16 With the opposition now strong enough to topple the Turkish Government, Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit announced early today that he and his Cabinet would resign.

title: Indian Point Security Inquiries Set
description: The United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, the New York State Power Authority and Consolidated Edison have begun separate investigations of the security at the Indian Point nuclear power complex on the Hudson River, 30 miles north of New York City, spokesmen for the organizations said last night.

title: City Marshals Said to Face Charges In Investigation of AuctionRigging
description: Ten or more New York City marshals and auctioneers face Federal criminal charges stemming from a threeyear investigation of auctionrigging practices, sources familiar with the investigation said yesterday.

title: Booming County on Coast Weighs Putting Brake on Industrial Growth
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Oct. 15  A new approach to planning for land use that is being fashioned here could dramatically alter the rate and pattern of industrial growth that has given Santa Clara County about 45,000 new jobs in the last year.

title: American Says It is Committed To Alter DC10
description: American Airlines, the carrier whose DC10 jumbo jet crashed in Chicago in May with a loss of 273 lives, has notified the Government that it has committed itself to extensive structural and system changes on its 30 other DC10's. But it was not clear yesterday how farreaching the changes would be or who would pay for them.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Music: Elaine Malbin Returns to Stage
description: ELAINE MALBIN was a soprano of established international standing when she decided, about a decade ago, to take a leave of absence and raise a family. She was not the first of course to dothat: Lili Chookasian, for one, returned to opera after a similar withdrawal, and enjoyed a major career at the Metropolitan and elsewhere. Still, it cannot be easy to keep alive the requisite professionalism and discipline during such a hiatus, not to mention vocal quality, so Miss Malbin's return to the New York stage on Sunday night atAlice Tully Hall had an air of suspense.

title: Tracking Cheetahs In North America
description: DANIEL ADAMS was stumped by the fossil skeletons that he and his fellow paleontologists had been calling a longlegged mountain lion. But he didn't know what else to make of these unusual cats that had been trapped 20,000 years ago at the bottom of an 80foot cave in western Wyoming.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Death

title: Blumenthal Is in Line To Head Burroughs
description: The board of the Burroughs Corporation, the computer manufacturer, yesterday elected W. Michael Blumenthal, former Secretary of the Treasury, to the position of vice chairman. Mr. Blumenthal, 53 years old, will replace Paul S. Mirabito, 69, in the chairman's job at the end of 1980. Burroughs said.

title: Powerful Quake at Mexican Border Rocks Much of Southern California
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15  An earthquake with a magnitude of 6.4 on the Richter scale shook a wide area of southern California and northern Mexico today, injuring at least 70 persons and causing extensive damage to buildings, roads and public utilities along a 150mile stretch of the United StatesMexican border.

title: Djilas, Yugoslav Dissident, Faces Jail in Underground Journal Case
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 15 Milovan Djilas, Yugoslavia's most prominent dissident author, was fined the equivalent of $525 today for having contributed three short stories to an unauthorized literary magazine.

title: Conflicts Seem Scarce in Suffolk Race
description: The two major party candidates seeking to succeed County Executive John V. N. Klein of Suffolk  Peter F. Cohalan, the Republican, and Martin F. Feldman, the Democrat  are in effect running against Mr. Klein in their efforts to portray themselves as the champions of change.

title: Surprise to U.S. Embassy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15  The State Department said today that officials of the United States Embassy in San Salvador had apparently been caught off guard by the ouster of President Romero.

title: A Marriage That Began In a TV Commercial
description: And now, a Manhattan fairy tale: Once upon a time there was a little girl named Finele Carpenter, who was born in the Ozark hillbilly country, as she calls it. She was the sixth and youngest child of a poor Baptist minister who was so strict that he made her quit the high school cheerleading squad because the skirt she had to wear was five inches above her knees.

title: Hua Guofeng Is in Paris at Start of Western Tour
description: PARIS, Oct. 15  Prime Minister Hua Guofeng of China arrived here today on the first stop of a threeweek tour of Western Europe in which, he has said, he hopes to reach a better understanding of the realities of your advanced countries so as to inspire me in the modernization program I have in mind.

title: Making Traffic Move in New Jersey
description: If New Jersey rejects a $475million bond referendum on the Nov. 6 ballot, says Transportation Commissioner Louis Gambacinni, it will be literally starving a public system worth billions of dollars that is vital to the state's economy and quality of life.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bowmar Instrument Corporation has elected to its board John H. Shaffer, president of Pioneer Van Lines and former administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Opera: Spanish Carmen
description: EXPECTATIONS ran high Sunday night at the City Opera. Victoria de los Angeles, favorite with vocal connoisseurs for more than three decades, made her debut with the company, andthis was the Spanish soprano's first operatic appearance in New York since Martha, at the Metropolitan, more than 17 years ago. Her role on Sunday was Carmen, a part Miss de los Angeles first sang onstage last season with the New Jersey Opera, although her recording of Bizet's opera, conducted by Sir Thomas Beecham, dates back to the late 1950's.

title: Chemical Dismisses Bond Head
description: Richard V. Adams, the executive vice president responsible for managing Chemical Bank's bondtrading and investment activities, was dismissed last week, a day after the nation's sixthlargest bank reported an $8.8 million loss in its bondtrading activities for the third quarter.

title: Science Watch
description: A highflying U2 research aircraft has collected dust particles that may come from a passing comet and could contain chemical information dating back to the beginning of the solar system, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced yesterday.

title: Grande Dame of Letters Holds Court at Frankfurt
description: FRANKFURT, Oct. 19  Observing the relays of editors and publishers from Europe coming to Room 300A at the Frankfurter Hof, it is evident why Helen Wolff is universally regarded as the grande dame of international letters.

title: IRAN AND LIBYA LIFT PRICES OF CRUDE OIL BY MORE THAN 10%
description: Iran and Libya each increased the price of their oil exports by more than 10 percent yesterday, piercing the ceiling that has held the official prices of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in check for the last three and a half months.

title: Trottier Signs
description: The New York Islanders announced yesterday that they had signed Bryan Trottier, their highscoring center, to a longterm contract that is effective immediately. The 23yearold Trottier,the most valuable player in the National Hockey League last season, had been in the final season of a fiveyear agreement although he would have had to play with the Islanders next season, anyway, in his old contract's option year.

title: Cornfeld Acquitted of I.O.S. Fraud Charges
description: GENEVA, Oct. 15  Bernard Cornfeld was acquitted here today of having defrauded employees of his Investors Overseas Services Ltd. by selling them shares in the multimilliondollar financial complex when it was nearing collapse.

title: Flooding Kills 2 in Northern Italy
description: NOVARA, Italy, Oct. 15 (Reuters)Torrential rains lashed northern Italy during the night, killing two persons and disrupting road and rail traffic by flooding, officials said today.

title: Price, Waterhouse Income Up 2.8%
description: The accounting firm of Price, Waterhouse & Company says that its worldwide pretax income rose 2.8 percent to $154.8 million in its 1979 fiscal year, ended June 30.

title: World Gold
description: MONDAY. OCTOBER 15. 1979

title: Cosmic Measurement:; Is the Yardstick Is the Yardstick of the Universe in Error? Red Shift Reveals Distance Anomalies in Deep Space Discovery of Quasars Different Shifts of Galaxies
description: COLD our present picture of the universe, pieced together during the past half century by means of agonizingly difficult scientific observations and analyses. turn out to be wrong?

title: Carter Woos Chicago Mayor In a Flying Tour of Midwest
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 15  President Carter came here tonight to woo the politically valuable endorsement of Mayor Jane M. Byrne for a second term  and almost got it.

title: Bridge:
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 15  For the second straight day, the United States team ran into the full power of Italy and emerged much the worst for wear. After losing, 515, yesterday in the 10th qualifying round of the world championship, the Americans fared even worsa today.

title: OBSERVER So Glad To be Recessed
description: Listening to the economics wizards talk about the recession, you get the feeling that things are going to get better as soon as they get worse.

title: 3 in Submarine Plunge 600 Feet To Probe Depths of Lake Tahoe
description: TAHOE CITY, Calif., Oct 15 (AP) The head of the first deepwater exploration of Lake Tahoe said today that the initial dive in the small Pioneer I submarine was marvelous but showed the damage that development is doing to the renowned lake.

title: J.I. Case's Top Officer Replaced
description: Jerome K. Green, the 43yearold president of the J.I Case Company, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer. He succeeds Thomas J. Guendel. 52. who resignedas both chairman and chief executive. No chairman has been named by the Racine, Wis.based manufacurer of agricultural and construction equipment.

title: Pirates Hitting Like Champions
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 15  If, as Dave Parker says, hitting among Pittsburgh's National League champions is contagious, then the Pirates have erupted in an epidemic that Jim Palmer must try to treat here tomorrow night in the sixth game of the World Series.

title: Senate Panel Begins Voting on ArmsPact Changes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today began considering modifications of the nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union and adopted two measures that opponents of the treaty dismissed as cosmetic.

title: Badillo Now a Partner In Law Firm Handling Labor Union Matters
description: Former Deputy Mayor Herman Badillo has become a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Cohn, Glickstein, Lurie, Lubell & Lubell.

title: People Mover for Los Angeles Gains
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15  After making dozens of studies on proposed mass transit systems over the last 25 years and then shelving them, Los Angeles appears finally to be edging toward construction of a transit line of at least moderate proportions.

title: Hanson to Acquire Barber Oil Shares
description: The Barber Oil Corporation and Hanson Industries, a subsidiary of the British holding company, Hanson Trust Ltd., said that they had executed a memorandum of intent to enter into a merger.

title: Taxes
description: JUST about the time the Internal Revenue Service succeeds in snuffing out one type of tax protest, another crops up in its place. Nonetheless, the agency is persevering in its fight against people who refuse to pay their taxes for personal or ideological reasons.

title: A SecondClass Solution for Rhodesians
description: LONDON, Oct. 15  The British Government has decided that, barring a political miracle, there is no chance of finding a way out of the Zimbabwe Rhodesia tangle that is acceptable both to the racially mixed regime in Salisbury and to theleaders of the Patriotic Front guerrilla group.

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: Deaths HARRISJanice Peltyn, In Albany NY October 9, 1979. Beloved wife of Rayreond. Loving mother of James, Grandmother, sister, aunt, great aunt. Services were held In Albany

title: Margaret Costanza, Former Aide To Carter, Backs Kennedy for 80
description: Margaret Costanza, who was eased out a year ago as a special assistant to President Carter after she had disputes with other Carter aides, yesterday endorsed Senator Edward M. Kennedy for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: 3Part Narcolepsy Report On WKCR This Week
description: WKCRFM, the Columbia University radio station, is broadcasting a threehour report this week on narcolepsy and the problems of the disease's victims

title: Cowboys Continue To Dominate Rams
description: Upsets are going to occur occasionally in the National Football League, such as Cincinnati's defeat of Pittsburgh on Sunday and Dallas's loss to Cleveland and Green Bay's victory over New England in Monday nightgames earlier this season. But such results are no particular gauge of a team.

title: Poles to Bring ;Dybbuk to U.S.
description: A company of 30 actors from the Jewish State Theater of Poland will come to the United States to perform in the Yiddish classic, The Dybbuk by S. Ansky. The troupe will open at the Belasco Theater in midFebruary for a sixweek engagement before a national tour

title: Supreme Court to Settle Issue Of Intent in Securities Violations
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15  One of the most hotly disputed issues in securities law  whether the Securities and Exchange Commission has to prove that someone acted with criminal intent, rather than carelessness, in violatingthe antifraud provisions of the securities lawsis to be resolved by the Supreme Court in a case it accepted for review today.

title: Marathon's Benefit To Heart Is Debated
description: AS 14,000 marathoners prepare for the 26.2mile New York City Marathon on Sunday, the question is raised anew: Are longdistance runners immune to atherosclerosis, the progressive buildup of fatty cholesterol deposits in coronary arteries that leads to heart attacks, the main cause of death in the United States?

title: Pan Am Asks Fare Rises
description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it had filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board for 5 percent increases on certain tare categories on transAtlantic and South Pacific routes, effective Dec. 10, to offset rising fuel costs.

title: U.S. May Send Habib to Mideast With Plan for Truce in Lebanon
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  The Carter Administration is planning to send a leading diplomat, Philip C. Habib, to Lebanon, Syria, Saudi Arabia, Jordan, Israel and the Vatican to promote an American initiative for a settlement of the conflict in Lebanon.

title: Meadowlands Cup Next In DelpBarrera Rivalry
description: Spectacular Bid drew the rail yesterday for the $350,000added Meadowlands Cup, but his trainer, Bud Delp, was more heartened by the fact that Laz Barrera's colt, Valdez, drew the outside post in the field of nine entered for tomorrow night's race.

title: Excerpts From Statement On CarterInquiry Report
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  Following are excerpts from a statement made here today at a press conference by Paul J. Curran, the special counsel who investigated President Carter's family peanut business:

title: Bond Tables Explained
description: Bonds, Interestbearing debt certificates, are quoted In percentage of the par or face value of the bond, which Is represented as 100. The name of the Issuing company Is followed by the original coupon or interest rate and the last two digits of the year of maturity.

title: Chrysler Offers New Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  The Chrysler Corporation, as expected, presented its modified financial rescue proposal to the Treasury Department today, amid indications that the company and the Treasury are still at odds over the amount of Federal assistance the company requires.

title: Gen. Jacob L. Devers Dies at 92; Top Commander in World War II
description: Gen. Jacob Loucks Devers, retired, whose 44 years in the United States Army included service as a West Point artillery teacher and as a top commander of Allied forces during World War II, died Monday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 92 years old.

title: Senator Disrupts Arms Hearing by Citing Rule on Committee Hours
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  A parliamentary objection today threatened to cause further delay in Senate action on the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union and several senators proposed modifications that, if adopted, could endanger final Soviet acceptance.

title: World Gold
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1979

title: Judge Rejects Suing of OPEC
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 (AP)  A Federal judge said yesterday that it was unfair to blame the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries for high gasoline prices. He refused to reopen an antitrust suit against OPEC.

title: Koch's Offer to Name Special Hispanic Aide Is Said to Be Rejected
description: Elected Hispanic officials are reported to have split over whether to cooperate with the Koch administration, which promised last week to appoint a Hispanic mayoral adviser. Many in the group of 11Puerto Rican Councilmen, Assemblymen and State Senators are expected to rebuff the Mayor at a news conference today.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Deaths

title: World News Briefs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: City Council Approves Bill That Would Ease Limits on Newsstands
description: The City Council approved a measure yesterday that would allow an increase in the size of newsstands and the range of items they sell.

title: Pollock Talks Continuing
description: Negotiations of four former Merrill Lynch Government Securities executives to acquire Wm. E. Pollock & Company, a Treasury securities firm, continued yesterday and are very close toconclusion, according to sources familiar with the talks. No deal has been completed yet, however. The four are Robert Meyerhoff, former president of the Merrill Lynch unit, and George Grimm, Morton Swinsky and David Quigley, all former executive vice presidents.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Letters
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: ThirdQuarter Earnings Increase at Major Banks
description: The major bank holding companies announced increases in thirdquarter net operating earnings yesterday. Citicorp reported a 16.6 percent gain, the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, a 17 percent rise, and the Continental Illinois Corporation, a 23.6 percent advance.

title: Industry Urged To Innovate
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 16 (AP)  Technology was portrayed as a potential rescuer of the economy today by a group of researchers who urged new emphasis on technological innovation in United States industry.

title: WASHINGTON Politics As Theater
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  The Presidential election campaign is likely to break our hearts unless we pick up a few giggles and get a little fun along the way. Taken seriously, itmakes no sense, but it makes news, and provides a few comic scenes beyond the imagination of Woody Allen.

title: A Chronology Of the Events In Carter Case
description: Following is a chronology of events leading up to the release yesterday of a report on loans made to the family peanut business of President Carter:

title: Knockwurst Tops Awards as Veteran Detective Retires
description: Sally, one of the Police Department's first explosivesdetection dogs, being presented a string of sausages by her handler, Officer Joseph Cipriano, during her retirement party yesterday at Police Headquarters. The 10yearold black Labrador Retriever, a veteran of eight years with the department's bomb squad, received an array of gifts, citations and honors in recognition of her faithful service. Her favorite awards, of course. were the edible ones

title: Personal Health
description: AT a family potluck party, the parents watched with pride as their 10yearold son chose one slice of ham, one slice of cheese, an assortment of fresh vegetables, rice pudding, a plain roll, melon and grapes. Among the items he bypassed were pastries, potato chips and fruitflavored gelatin with whipped cream. Before eating the ham, he carefully trimmed off the fat and pushed it aside.

title: Parker's Hit a Key Pirate Break
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 16  When Dave Parker hit the ball toward second base in the seventh inning of a scoreless game tonight, he didn't think the sixth game of the World Series, or maybe the entire Series, would turn on it. He thought he had just hit into a double play.

title: Net Higher at Hercules, Lilly, Pfizer, Cyanamid
description: Led by Hercules Inc., several of the nation's major chemical and pharmaceutical companies reported higher earnings for the third quarter yesterday. They included Eli Lilly & Company, Pfizer Inc. and the American Cyanamid Company.

title: Bank Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: 'superskates on Nov. 12 To Benefit U.S. Olympians
description: The performers include John Curry, British national champion and an Olympic gold medalist, and Charles Tickner, a United States and world champion.

title: Industrial Production Rebounds
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UPI)  The nation's industrial output, paced by automobile production, rebounded last month by rising fivetenths of 1 percent, the Federal Reserve Board said today. It was the largest increase since last May's 1.1 percent advance.

title: Guards Charge Security Is Lax At Indian Point
description: BUCHANAN, N.Y., Oct. 16 (AP)When the words Signal 30 come over the walkietalkies, the guards in Unit 2 at the Indian Point nuclear plant go on alert.

title: No Links to Peanut Warehouse Found in Carter Primary Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  The Gerald Rafshoon Advertising Agency Inc., which extended credit to Jimmy Carter's 1976 Presidential primary campaign, used no money from unknown sources, Paul J. Curran, special counsel to an inquiry into the Carter family's peanut warehouse business. said today.

title: CLARENCE MUSE, 89; ACTED IN 219 FILMS
description: Clarence Muse, the first black actor to star in a film  Way Down Way South  and who was Hollywood's perennial Uncle Tom in a career that included 219 movies, died last Saturday of a cerebral hemorrhage in the Community Hospital of the Valley in Perris, Calif. He would have been 90 years old the next day.

title: Market Place
description: FACET ENTERPRISES moved against the downtrend in yesterday's stock market on the strength of a higherthanexpected settlement in its pension dispute with the Bendix Corportion. Facet was spun off from Bendix in 1975 at the behest of the Federal Trade Commission.

title: CREDIT MARKETS 2Year Treasury Notes Expected to Top 11%
description: The Treasury announced plans yesterday to sell twoyear notes next Tuesday, and Government securities dealers estimated that the new securities would yield well above 11 percent if the credit markets did not change much by then. Yields above 12 percent on shorterterm Treasury bills attracted a flood of small investors yesterday.

title: Profits Cloud the City Marshal System
description: City Marshal Eugene Weisbrod was conducting a routine auction at an office on West 57th Street yesterday when he learned that he was one of 13 persons whose indictments on charges of receiving bribes for rigging auctions had been announced a few hours earlier.

title: MILLER IS LESS SURE SLUMP IS HALF OVER, HE SAYS IN CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  Treasury Secretary G. William Miller, citing the recent credittightening actions by the Federal Reserve System, backed away today from his own repeated assurances that the United States had come halfway through a business recession.

title: Associate Dean to Head Harvard Business School
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 16 After considering more than 100 candidates from the business and academic world, Harvard University announced today that it had chosen one of its own, John H. McArthur, to serve as dean of the Harvard Business School.

title: Around the Nation
description: SORRY, Va., Oct. 16 (AP)  Two selfprofessed saboteurs were convicted today of damaging a nuclear power plant in what was believed to be the nation's first trial involving the sabotage of a nuclear facility.

title: Hua Guofeng Is Given Formal Paris Welcome
description: PARIS, Oct. 16 (UPI)  Prime Minister Hua Guofeng of China. was formally welcomed to Paris today and, in an apparent allusion to the Soviet Union, said that China and France faced a common threat from aggression.

title: Kitchen Equipment A Versatile Yogurt Maker
description: THE war against bacteria in food has been so vast, employing extreme heat and cold as well as arcane chemicals, that it's easy to forget about the good bacteria  the allies, the microorganisms that make wine and cheese before expiring in our service.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Few dreams have foundered as often as that of the South Street Seaport in Lower Manhattan. The small.fragmented enclave of 19thcentury streets and piers on the East River is about all that remains of New York's sailing days, and bits and pieces of it keep slipping away even as efforts are made to save it. The South Street Seaport Museum, using Federal grants, is carefully restoring some buildings. But the museum's debts are mounting. Plans for the historic block called Schermerhorn Row disturb its artistresidents. The Seaport is being encircled by development. The smell of fish and the sight of somnolent cats on the cobblestones of the Fulton Market are among the area's only constants.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1979

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Lives
description: SINCE they stopped paying me to watch television, I don't do it much any more: M.A.S.H., maybe, and Lou Grant on Monday nights; The Rockford Files on Fridays. (I would like to think that James Garner is modern man. I used to like to think that Dirk Bogarde was modern man. Modern man is probably Captain Kangaroo. On the other hand, why is everybody always kissing Yasir Arafat? . . . and on a heath beneath winking stars a fox, red reek of rapine in his fur, with merciless bright eyes scraped in the earth, listened, scraped up the earth, listened, scraped and scraped, said James Joyce in Ulysses.) The Pope, of course, got me out of bed. But ordinarily I am upstairs listening to Joni Mitchell and reading Kierkegaard.

title: HighLevel Balloon Detects Antimatter Flow From Space
description: Using a highaltitude balloon carrying a 5,000pound package of ultrasensitive instruments, a team of scientists at New Mexico State University has detected a stream of antimatter from interstellar space  the first such matter ever found outside a terrestrial laboratory.

title: William Arthur Lewis
description: William Arthur Lewis teaches economics through ideas, not numbers. This nonmathematical approach endears him to the students who are enrolled in PA562, the graduate seminar on economic development he teaches atPrinceton, and, more importantly, carries his thoughts throughout the larger classroom of the poor and underdevioped countries, which havebeen Sir Arthur's lifelong concern.

title: Has the Nobel Prize Changed Singer's Life?; Prizes and Men's Characters; New Collection Next Month; Uses 1935 Typewriter; Everyday Crises; `These Reviews I Ignore
description: OH, you want the Nobel prizewinner, the handyman at the apartment house in the West 80's, said. Take the elevator at the next entrance.

title: Fox Aides Still Shifting
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16  We have painters standing by in the parking lot to wipe out the old names, said Mel Brooks of the game of musical executive chairs that has been played at 20th CenturyFox since the resignation of Alan Ladd Jr., the company's president, last June. It's a fulltime job, said Mr. Brooks, who produced Young Frankenstein and Silent Movie for Fox. This morning they're painting in Danny Meinick's name, I think.

title: Show of Force by U.S. Put Off for Television
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 16 (AP)Military officials have delayed a scheduled beach assault at the Navy base at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, in part to provide more light for television crews.

title: Szaro Is Dismissed by Jets And Replaced by Linhart
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 16 The New York Jets today dismissed Richie Szaro from his newfound job as placekicker. Szaro, who was signed only last Saturday to replace the injured Pat Leahy, missed both of his fieldgoal attempts in the Jets 147 victory yesterday over the Minnesota Vikings. He was cut today and replaced byanother wellknown kicker, Toni Linhart. Linhart, a former National Football League scoring champion, was cut in September by the Baltimore Colts after he missed three routine fieldgoal attempts against Cleveland in a 1310 loss to the Browns.

title: Fairchild Rebuffed By Bunker Ramo
description: OAK BROOK, III., Oct. 16 (Reuters)  The Bunker Ramo Corporation said that it had rejected the unsolicited proposal of Fairchild Industries to buy 1.7 million Bunker Ramo common shares for $33 each.

title: Giants Put Pisarcik On Injured Reserve.
description: Two days after Phil Simms had passed for 300 yards, Joe Pisarcik, the quarterback who had taken a brutal beating while the Giants waited for their prize rookie to get ready for the National Football League, was placed on the injuredreserve list by a team not acting as if it had a twogame winning streak.

title: What Led to Turkey's Torment
description: Turkey's present straits are deeper and darker than those of the Bosporus. Inflation has surged to an annual rate of 100 percent. One of five adult Turks is jobless. Incessant political violence has kept the country under martial law. Now social unrest has been compounded by political uncertainty, following an election in which Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit's Social Democratic Government has lost its slender majority.

title: Mets Rule Out Plan for Sale in Near Future
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 16  The New York Mets are not for sale now or in the foreseeable future, despite recent reports that negotiations were under way, the ruling family of the baseball team insisted today.

title: Chrysler Letters of Credit Ended by 7 Japan Banks
description: TOKYO, Oct. 16 (AP)  Seven Japanese commercial banks have stopped issuing letters of credit for the Chrysler Corporation because of its deteriorating financial position, clouding the future of the American company's imports of Mitsubishi automobiles from Japan.

title: 26 Shocks Strike Coast After Strong Quake Injures 70
description: EL CENTRO, Calif., Oct. 16  Ray Measures was walking on the sidewalk outside the LincolnMercury dealership where he works when the quake began. One minute everything was normal and the next it felt like the ground was coming up at me. he said. I jumped out to the middle of the street, but the ground was moving so fast you almost lost your footing.

title: A Season for ResolveDestroying Creations
description: With the fall eating season upon us and holiday tables in the offing, a report on some of the new and newly found food creations seems in order. If early signs are a reliable indication of what's to come, we are in for an autumn and winter of resolvedestroying temptations. Most of the news is good, with just a few sobering disappoint;ments.

title: Aides View the Town Meeting As the President's Best Format
description: DOLTON, III., Oct. 16  It was three months ago today, on another trip to the Middle West, that Jimmy Carter pledged to conduct the public aspect of his Presidency in a different way.

title: PRESIDENT PREDICTS INTERESTRATE DROP
description: DOLTON, ILL., Oct. 16  President Carter today asked a crowd packed into a high school gymnasium to have a little patience with his economic program, and he predicted that both interest and inflation rates would go down before the end of the year.

title: Autopsy on 3 YearOld Finds Clues of Cancer
description: TIJUANA, Mexico, Oct. 16 (AP) An autopsy failed to disclose what killed Chad Green, a 3yearold with leukemia whose parents had brought him here for Laetrile treatments. However, a medical team found indications that the boy may have died of cancer, an American doctor said today.

title: Pacers Defeat Nets, 113100
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct.16 (AP) Johnny Davis scored 26 points tonight, including 12 in the third quarter when Indiana built a 21point lead, as the Pacers coasted to a 113100 National Basketball Association victory over the New Jersey Nets.

title: 2 Big Waves Hit Riviera, Killing at Least 9 People
description: NICE, France, Oct. 16 (UPI)  Two large waves struck the French Riviera today, drowning at least nine people and tearing hundreds of boats from their moorings. Three people are missing and feared drowned.

title: Turkish Premier Quits And Bids Rival Leader Name a New Cabinet
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 16  Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit submitted the resignation of his social democratic Government today and urged that the conservative Justice Party be asked to form a Cabinet in view of its victory in parliamentary byelections on Sunday.

title: Synthetic Fuels Gain In Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  The Senate gave President Carter's energy program an important assist tonight by approving a $20 billion commitment for the first phase of a huge development of synthetic fuels as a substitute for imported oil.

title: Advertising
description: THE increasing emphasis by magazine publishers on singlecopy sales, the disappearance of neighborhood candy stores and the growing importance of retail chains as periodical outlets have all led to the creation of the Periodicals Institute by an amalgam of wholesalers, distributors and publishers of magazines and paperback books.

title: Pianist: Margaret Mills Offers French Program
description: IT was a wildly unusual program that Margaret Mills put together for her Alice Tully Hall concert last night, and a good sprinkling of the curious was on hand to see what she would make of it. She subtitled her program French Piano Music of Three Centuries (though two centuries would have been much more accurate), and about the only really familiar piece on it was Debussy's Pour le piano.

title: Tiny, Fast Moving Moon Discovered Near Jupiter
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  Two scienfists looking for something else have discovered a new moon orbiting the planet Jupiter that is the fastest moving natural satellite known in the solar system.

title: U.S. Alters Gold Sale Procedure
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP)  The Treasury Department, in another move to support the dollar and to deter speculation in gold, announced today that it would no longer hold its auctions of gold on a regular monthly basis and that it would vary the amounts to be sold.

title: A Book to Delight The Food Lover
description: Evan Jones's A Food Lover's Companion is an easy book to put down. Which is not to say that it isn't a thoroughgoing delight. But after all, this new collection of brief articles, excerpts, reminiscences, fiction, poems and whatnot is about food. And while reading about food is fun, it can't quite compare to eating.

title: Carter's Backers Begin Lining Up State Democrats
description: President Carter's supporters have begun lining up their own leading Democrats for a Carter campaign committee here in an attempt to counter the strong sentiment for Senator Edward M. Kennedy among top New York Democrats.

title: New Yorkers,etc.
description: LIKE a lot of other people, Jack Osborn isn't too crazy about personal questions. He tries to deflect them by answering with another question. Until recently, if someone asked his age, he countered with How old do you think I am? But that backfired.

title: Don't Mug Musicians
description: Manhattan musicians, sadly, are easy prey for muggers. Toting their instruments through streets and subways, conspicuously clad in tuxedos and black gowns. they are vulnerable.

title: Q&
description: Q. I have a great liking for the dish known as seviche. I am curious to know the origin of the word. Can you tell me?

title: 50,000 Road Fatalities Highest for Five Years
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 16 (Reuters) United States highway deaths last year exceeded 50,000 for the first time in five years, the Transportation Department said today.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Rises Against Yen In Heavy Tokyo Trading
description: TOKYO, Oct. 16  The dollar continued to rise sharply against the Japanese yen in heavy trading on the Tokyo currency market today, climbing above the Bank of Japan's resistence barrier of 230 yen.

title: Kirkland Attacks Moves Intended as Inflation Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  Lane Kirkland, who is expected to succeed George Meany as head of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today that recent actions by the Federal Reserve Board to curb inflation are the wrong move at the wrong time and will not solve the problem.

title: Defector's Secret Return to Soviet Is Puzzling West German Officials
