description: BONN, Oct. 16  West German authorities are described as virtually certaro that Soviet agents abducted a former Soviet Olympic gold medalist after he defected to West Germany and made known his plans to write a book exposing Soviet sports.

title: Piano: Emil Gilels Wins Ovation With a Schumann
description: IS it possible that almost a quarter of a century has passed since Emil Gilels first app9ared in this country? Yes, the record shows indisputably that he made his NewYork debut in 1955, leading the great postwar wave of Soviet pianists. Many a Sovjet pianist has flowed under the bildge since then, but Mr. Gilels has retained a special place in the affection of American concertgoers. First crushes are always hard to forget.

title: CARTER'S BUSINESS CLEARED IN INQUIRY ON CAMPAIGN FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  Paul J. Curran, a special Federal investigator, said today that an exhaustive inquiry into loans to President Carter's family peanut business by the National Bank of Georgia had turned up no evidence whatsoever that proceeds had been diverted to Mr. Carter's 1976 Presidential campaign.

title: Job Productivity Found Lagging
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 16 (AP)  A management survey indicates that United States workers are only twothirds as productive on the job as their grandfathers were. It alsoshows that the average worker is productive only during 55 percent of an eighthour workday and that total worker productivity in the 1970's has made only marginal gains.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: A Farm Is Saved  and Spreads Its Bounty
description: SHELBURNE, VT. IT is the ongoing lament among farmers, ecologists and urban planners almost everywhere there is any open country left: A farmer owns land near a boom town or an expanding city and can no longer afford the property taxes. So he sells outto developers and another suburb is born.

title: Plain Jane Captures Lead In Jumper Championship
description: HARRISBURG, PA., Oct. 16 Plain Jane, a bay mare owned by the Edition Farms of Purchase, N.Y., took the lead for the amateurowner jumper championship by winning the timed first jumpoff class today at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Erik Heirung is a 48yearold Norwegian naval architect who is president of one of Denmark's biggest shipping lines, DFDS. He was in the United States yesterday for ceremonies marking the start of his company's Omnicarrier service between the United States and the Mediterranean. This service uses specially designed cargo ships built to operate at their best at the relatively slow speed of 16 knots. That is much slower than the maximum of other big transAtlantic carriers, but the faster ships are now being forced to reduce their speeds because of the current oil situation.

title: VERA DALLAS
description: Vera Dallas, former First Selectman of Madison, Conn., died Sunday in Madison at the home of her son, Allen. She was 67 Years old.

title: Auto Crash Tests Hint Gains in New, Small Models
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP)  Crash tests of 20 automobile models indicate that occupants of 13 of them would die if the car hit a wall at 35 miles an hour, the Department of Transportation reported today.

title: New Salvadoran Junta Promises Elections and a General Amnesty
description: SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 16  E1 Salvador's new military junta today announced an ambitious economic and social program aimed at easing this country's grave political crisis.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: WE live in an age when almost any comestible can be purchased and cooked almost any season of the year. Foods that were once culinary treasures of spring or summer can now be bought in the middle of winter: asparagus, strawberries, even, at times, corn on the cob. As a consequence, the foods that I treasure most are those that are available at the precise moment of harvestPerhaps the greatest of foods in this category are the bay scallops that can now be had in abundance on the East Coast. And where this column is concerned, there is nothing that can be cooked with greater speed to produce more elegant and tasty results.

title: Mexican Oil Spill May Continue For Month Despite Cone on Well
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 16 (AP)  Officials of the Mexican oil company said today that despite the successful fitting of a cone that will capture most of the oil spilling from a runaway offshore well, the well would probably not be plugged until the end of the month.

title: EARNINGS Big Paper Concerns Report Profit Rises
description: Three of the nation's largest paper and packaging companies, the Union Camp Corporation, the Crown Zellerbach Corporation and the St. Regis Paper Company, reported significantly higher sales and earnings for the third quarter yesterday.

title: F.C.C. Staff Calls Agency Powerless Against TV
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  The Federal Communications Commission has the authority to regulate commercial network television, but the three networks are so secure and dominant that the commission appears powerless torequire tnem to respond to viewers interests, according to an F.C.C. staff report released today.

title: Brown Off for Talks in Seoul
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (Reuters) Defense Secretary Harold Brown left today for consultations on security in South Korea and Japan. He will attendthe annual military meetings of the United States and South Korea in Seoul tomorrow through Friday. He then goes to Japan where he will confer with mill. tary officials and visit Japanese air and ground military installations before re. turning home next Monday.

title: Midland Sells Shares Of Standard Chartered
description: LONDON, Oct. 16  The Midland Bank announced tonight it had disposed of the bulk of its 15.9 percent interest in the Standard Chartered Bank, another major institution. The deal was believed to be the biggest of its kind ever made in Britain,

title: A Gas Tax or Deeper Trouble Still
description: Already worried by the cost of oil, Americans had better worry some more. Libya and Iran have raised their prices 7 cents a gallon and other exporters will probably follow. What's more, supplies are so tight and the major producers are so reluctant to accommodate importers that even a recession is unlikely to relieve the pressure. Only a crash conservation effort  the kind Congress has bitterly resisted  can save the country from runaway energy inflation.

title: Buehning Topples Moore In Swiss Tennis Tourney
description: BASEL, Switzerland, Oct. 16 (AP)Fritz Buehning, a 19yearold from Short Hills, N.J., who turned professional two months ago, posted the first upset of the $75,000 Swiss indoor tennis tournament when he ousted Ray Moore, a veteran from South Africa,. 67, 61, 64.

title: Young Tells of Attemtpt to Win Israeli Support for Him
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  Andrew Young said today that the White House had worked with the Israelis on a statement that would have put Israel co record as opposed to his resignation as United States delegate to the United Nations.

title: Yuba and Placer In Dredging Pact
description: MARYSVILLE, Calif., Oct. 18 (AP)  Yuba Goldfields Inc. said yesterday that it had entered into a joint venture agreement with the Placer Service Corporation for the possible resumption of gold dredging on Yuba properties near here.

title: FranchiseRule Stay Is Denied
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP)  Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court today rejected arguments that the Federal Trade Commission's franchising regulation should not apply to the petroleum industry. The rule,issued by the agency last Dec. 20, requires detailed disclosure of the financial risks as well as opportunities that await those who buy local franchise outlets.

title: Role of Radon Gas in Predicting Earthquakes Is Examined
description: Scientists know that larger than normal quantities of radon, a radioactive gas, are released prior to some earthquakes.

title: Show of Force by U.S. Put Off for Television
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 16 (AP) Military officials have delayed a scheduled beach assault at the Navy base at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, in part to provide more light for television crews.

title: Utah's Press Brouhaha on Elections at a StandOff
description: DENVER, Oct. 16  Utah's Great Washington County Press Freedom HooHa has reached a standoff, with the First Amendment, at last check, still unscathed.

title: A Metropolis Rises in the Desert
description: JUBAIL, Saudi Arabia  A passenger's car darts in and out between mammoth trucks carrying materials to build a new civilization  sewer and water pipes big enough to let a manstand in them, small mountains of concrete bags, quarried blocks of stone, mounds of gravel, long gangling bars of steel.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Given some spare time and a partner, a backgammon addict will reach for the board and play around the clock. For those who play backgammon on planes and trains, there is now a sidebyside board that opens out so that players in adjacent seats can click away without having to be opposite each other in confined spaces. The board folds up to become a traveling case. Board, dice and cups are $35 in Saks Fifth Avenue's stationery department.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: SOONER or later it happens to many car owners. And one day it happened to Lillian Feinstein  she locked herself out of her car. So there she was, at the corner of 86th Street and Third Avenue, in the midst of plight, when a man offered his assistance. In fact, he volunteered to go in search of a wire coathanger, a wellknown implement of amelioration in such cases.

title: Scotto's Defense Told to Proceed
description: A judge rejected defense motions yesterday to dismiss all the charges in the trial of Anthony M. Scotto in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: The Region
description: HARTFORD  Connecticut will buy 450 buses and 100 railroad cars over the next five to seven years in a $400 million mass transit program if Congress passes the proposed windfall profits tax on oil companies, Arthur B. ,Powers, the state's Commissioner of Transportation, said yesterday.

title: Citicorp Paper at 14.143%
description: The average rate on Citicorp's 91day commercial paper rose to a record 14.143 percent yesterday in the bank holding company's weekly auction of these shortterm notes. A week ago, therate was 13.944 percent. With $620,7 million of bids submitted for the $150 million issue, Citicorp accepted rates ranging from 13.5 percent to 14.25 percent, including 16.3 percent at the high.

title: TV: RetirementHome Comedy Movie
description: OLD age and retirement homes may seem unlikely subjects for comedy, but television movies will evidently try anything to meet bustling schedule demands. Tonight at 9 o'clock, NBCTV's movie of the week is Better Late Than Never, formerly titled Never too Young, which accounts for the theme song You're Never too Young to Try. The credits don't specify, but the offcamera singer sounds very much like Fred Astaire.

title: NATO's Shortcomings: Old Weapons, New Doubts
description: LONDON  The tanks, the guns, the armored cars, the jeeps are back in their motor pools. In these first cold days, sergeants are shepherding their platoons into the local training areas to correct mistakes made during the big exercises.

title: Appeals Court Opened to Cameras for First Time
description: Yesterday's session of the New York Court of Appeals in Albany was opened still and television photographers for the first time in the court's history. Henry J. Smith, standing at right, attorney, argued case of Westchester Rockland Newspapers v. Leggett before the court. From left were Justices Jacob D. Fuchsberg, Hugh R. Jones, Matthew J. Jasen, Chief Justice Lawrence H. Cooke, Domenick L. Gabrielli, Sol M. Wachtler and Bernard S. Meyer.

title: Impact of WineBarrel Inflation
description: Since 1962 many California wineries have aged their products in French oak to capture some of the same characteristics that the wood imparts to the wines of Burgundy and Bordeaux. But inflation and changing tastes have forced a reassessment.

title: Leading Chinese Dissident Gets 15Year Prison Term
description: PEKING, Oct. 16  The most prominent leader of the small but vocal dissident movement here, Wei Jingsheng, was sentenced to 15 years in jail today after being found guilty of providing military secrets to a foreigner and engaging in counterrevolutionary activities.

title: Candelaria Warms a Household
description: By the sixth inning of last night's World Series game, John Candelaria's mother was a nervous wreck.

title: The Prettiest Baby In All of Boksburg
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 16 Gerrie Coetzee won his first championship at the age of 6 months when he took the blue ribbon as the prettiest baby in Boksburg, the middleclass suburb of Johannesburg where he lives today on a fiveacre plot with his wife, Rina, a spaniel named Wendy and a couple of horses. I wasfat, said the heavyweight champion of South Africa, and his legal adviser, Hal Tucker, proved it by displaymg a newspaper photograph of the contest winner.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Die Teufelskathe, Dvorak; Concerto in A minor No. 6, Vivaldi; Sonatina in A, Torroba; Concerto No. 2, Handel.

title: PAKISTAN PRESIDENT CALLS OFF ELECTIONS
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Oct. 16 (AP)  President Mohammed Zia ulHaq announced today that he had postponed indefinitely next month's elections, banned all political parties and meetings, outlawed strikes, closed some newspapers and magazines and imposed censorship on the rest.

title: News of the Theater `CanCan Riding Wave Of Musical Revivals
description: SOME producers cannot seem to get their hands on musical revivals fast enough. James M. Nederlander, already involved in bringing Peter Pan, West Side Story and Oklahoma! to Broadway this season, is working on a new version of CanCan for next season.

title: Nobel Economics Award Shared By 2 Experts on Poorer Nations
description: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science was awarded jointly yesterday to two economists known for their work on the economic problems of developing nations.berg, a member of the selection commit tee, said: They are both, in the truest sense, wise men  men of vast experience. We have a lot of crazy people in economics, brilliant but crazy. These two are different. They have influenced many others.

title: Hugh Woods, ExPilot, 73, Dies; Shot Down by Japanese in 1938
description: MIAMI, Oct. 16 (UPI)  Hugh L. Woods, a pilot for the old China National Aviation Corporation and the first American pilot shot down by Japanese fighter planes in 1938, died at a Miami hospital Sunday. He was 73 years old.

title: The Nobel Prize Theory: A Correction
description: This chart illustrates the theory about the weak force in subatomic behavior for which the Nobel Prize in physics was awarded Monday. It was known that the collision of a neutrino and a neutron, each with no electrical charge, could produce a negatively charged muon and a positive proton, the result of a charged current flowing through the reaction. In some copies of The Timesyesterday, the neutron was incorrectly identified as a neutrino. To fit the force of electromagnetism, which is one of the basic forces of nature, into the same theoretical framework with the subatomic weak force, Dr. Steven Weinberg and Dr. Abdus Salam proposed a type of collision producing no change in charge, in which a neutral current is the carrier of the weak force.

title: Merrill, E.F. Hutton List Gains
description: Merrill Lynch & Company and the E.F. Hutton Group said yesterday that they had each had increases in revenues and earnings in the third quarter, which ended Sept. 30.

title: 2 Republicans Criticize Connally's Israel Plan
description: Two New York Republican leaders criticized John Connally for proposing that a Palestinian state be created and that Israel return all occupied lands in exchange for ironclad assurances of Israel's security. The critics. Vincent

title: A Social Institution Called Trader Vic's
description: SAN FRANCISCO STARTING with $800 borrowed from his aunt in 1934, Victor Bergeron, otherwise known as Trader Vic, has built an empire of 21 restaurants in five countries and a multimilliondollar food products line in six countries. Mr. Bergeron, a shameless selfpromoter, delights in telling how he once attracted customers by sticking an ice pick into his wooden leg.

title: More Than 400 Hurt in 3Train Crash in Philadelphia>
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16  A chain reaction crash involving three trains on an inbound commuter line this morning injured more than 400 people, at least 25 of them seriously, derailed and buckled five cars, twisted steel rails upside down and closed a rail line to evening homebound traffic.

title: HARDER CUBA STAND BY CARTER REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  The Carter Administration, whose policy toward Cuba was originally based on efforts to normalize relations, has decided on a concerted effort to discourage Cuba's military involvement abroad and to undercut its influence in the third world, officials said today.

title: Sports Today
description: Nets vs. Philadelphia 76ers, at Rutgers Athletic Center, Piscataway, N.J., 8 P.M. (Radio WVNJ, 8 P.M.)

title: The Consequences Of an Open Door
description: IT was a warm June day. The typewriter made sporadic little bursts of sound as I sat working at my desk. Our apartment is in an enclave of narrow brownstones in east midtown New York, with windows facing a communal garden. No one can beadmitted downstairs without being buzzed in, or unless that heavy guard door is inadvertently left open for a moment or two.

title: Merger Activity Up 1% in Quarter
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (AP)  Rising interest rates and the economic downturn have not slowed the pace of mergers and acquisitions in this country, the chairman of a concern specializing in mergers said today.

title: F.B.I. Removes 2 in Theft Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  Two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have been removed from their jobs for allegedly stealing Government and private property, the bureau said tonight.

title: Sindona Enters A Hospital Here With a Wound
description: Michele Sindona, the Italian financier who disappeared two and a half months ago while awaiting trial on fraud charges in connection with the collapse of the Franklin National Bank, was admitted to Doctors Hospital yesterday with a possible bullet wound in the leg, Federal authorities said.

title: Events Today
description: LADYKOUSE BLUES, by Kevin O'Marrison; St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue at Ent 54Th Street, 6.

title: TV: CBS's Concrete Cowboys
description: CONCRETE COWBOYS is the goldarndest, thighslappingest, awfuIlest madefortelevision movie to come down the pike in a coon's age. It will be shown to the unwary from 9 to 11 o'clock tonight on CBS.

title: Judge on Coast Rules I. Q. Test Is No Gauge For Retarded Students
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 Declaring that standardized intelligence tests were not a valid means of determining mental retardation in black schoolchildren, a Federal district judge ruled today that it was unconstitutional to use such tests to place blacks in classes for the mentally retarded.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ARIA AREA Two years ago a small group of young operagoers created an organization called Camerata. The name came from the 18thcentury Florentines who created the musical form that led to opera. The latterday Camerata unit, affiliated withthe New York City Opera Guild, now has a membership of nearly 400 music buffs.

title: Best Buys
description: Food prices declined?? ever so slightly last week, with the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs reporting a 6cent decline in the cost of the 41item market basket. The cost of feeding a family of four in New York City dropped to $88.49 for the week ending Oct. 12, although shoppers paid 8.3 percent more for food than during the same period last year.

title: Howard Simon, 76; Artist Was Teacher At the Barlow School
description: Howard Simon, artistinresidence at the Barlow School in Amenia, N.Y., died Monday at the White Plains Medical Center of the effects of a stroke he suffered in August. He was 76 years old.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE award of this year's Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science to Sir Arthur Lewis of Princeton University and to Theodore W. Schultz of the University of Chicago is a tribute to the efforts of both men to bring humanity to the center of the attention of their fellow economists  and bring the skills of the economist to bear on the problems of poverty that still afflict most of the human race.

title: Joseph Calderon, 69, A Professor of History And Political Science
description: Joseph M. Calderon, professor emeritus of history and political science at Anne Arundel Community College near Baltimore, died last Wednesday after emergency surgery at the Maine Medical Center in Portland, where he had been visiting. He was 69 years old and lived in Baltimore.

title: Arab Businessmen Give $10,000 To Jackson's Rights Organization
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 16  The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson has obtained a $10,000 contribution from an ArabAmerican organization that says it has been trying for 12 years to establish relations with major civil rights groups.

title: High School Dropout Rate at 45%, Macchiarola Reports to City Board
description: Nearly one out or every two Students dropped out of New York City's public high schools over a fouryear period end. ing in 1978, School Chancellor Frank J Macchiarola said yesterday.

title: N.A.S.L. Limits Rosters
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  The North American Soccer League voted today to reduce team rosters and to restrict further the maximum number of nonNorth American citizens allowed on each club and on the field during games.

title: Heavens Gets Tryout
description: TORONTO, Oct. 16 (UPI)  Jerome Heavens, who holds the Notre Dame career rushing record, was signed to a fiveday trial today with the Toronto Argonauts of the Canadian Football League. Heavens was a ninthround college draft pick cut by the Chicago Bears prior to the opening of the National Football League's regular season.

title: Dozens Killed in Western Iran
description: LONDON, Oct. 16 (AP)  Teheran Radio said today that dozens of counterrevolutionaries were killed in a moppingup operation by army special forces in Seylichir in western Iran. In another report, trie radio said 7 persons were killed and about 30 injured in two days of disturbances arising from the grievances of fishermen in the Caspian Sea porf of Bandar Anzali.

title: NATO Leaders Receive Letters From Brezhnev
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 16 (Reuters) NATO leaders are receiving letters from the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, drawing attention to his recent speech announcing the reduction of troops and tanks in East Germany.

title: New York Light Opera To Make Debut Nov. 6
description: The New York Light Opera, a new chamber operetta company that began its first season in August at the 1979 Edinburgh Festival Fringe, will make its New York debut with six performances of Offenbach, Plus . .. at the Network Theater. which is also new. at51st Street and Ninth Avenue. The first performance will be on Nov. 6.

title: The City
description: State Senator Joseph L. Galiber, who visited Japan in August in search of help for the South Bronx, said the Japanese Government had shown interest in building an industrial park there, providning 5,000 to 10,000 new jobs. He said the Japanese had made a formal proposal.

title: Careers
description: THE field of public relations probably encompasses as many diversified skills and personalities as any business could.

title: Dollar Gains
description: A feeling among foreignexchange traders that the latest rise in oil prices by Iran and Libya would hurt other nations more than the United States sent the dollar upward yesterday. Gold prices slumped.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1979

title: Expert Paints a Gloomy Picture of U.S.Soviet Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  The Government's ranking Soviet expert said today in Congressional testimony that the United States and the Soviet Union were at loggerheads on almost every issue except their treaty limiting strategic arms and that these differences are unlikely to be reconciled in the near future.

title: Stocks Sag Further as Rally Fails
description: The stock market posted its seventh consecutive decline yesterday in continued active trading after an early rally attempt evaporated.

title: Escaped Suspect Is Brought Back For Murder Trial
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 16  As Robert R. Reldan was returned here voluntarily today for the last part of his murder trial, the county sheriff disclosed that a second can of Chemical Mace was missing from a locked jailhouse storage cage. The cage contained the Mace the defendant used before he escaped yesterday by leaping from a thirdfloor courthouse window.

title: Estee Lauder's Home Is Invaded by Robbers; Loss Put at $ 1 Million
description: Three armed men, one of them posing as a chauffeur, invaded Estee Lauder's East Side town house last night, tied up Mrs. Lauder and four other persons and then escaped with about $2,000 in cash and jewelry valued at as much as $1 million, the police said.

title: Prices Rise in Austria
description: VIENNA, Oct. 16 (AP)  Austria's consumer price index rose onetenth of 1 percent in September and was up 3.7 percent over the last 12 months, the Central Statistical Office reported today. Home heating fuel rose the most; produce was lower.

title: Baseball Puts ABC In TV Lead
description: Aided by three World Series games televised in prime time, ABCTV won last week's round in the audiencepopularity ratings. But it was not the sort of overwhelming victory that is expected when the leading network carries baseball's final and most important matchup.

title: Notes on People
description: Nearly 15 months after the birth of their daughter, the parents of Louise Brown say they've had it with people referring to her as a test tube baby.

title: Theodore William Schultz
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 16  During the heavy snows of last winter, one of the worst this city has ever seen, an unfailing figure plowing through the drifts on the University of Chicago campus was a tall, slender scholar named TheodoreWilliam Schultz, looking younger than a septuagenarian.

title: Ah, Mr. Kissinger, We Agreed
description: PARIS  Thank you [Henry A. Kissinger] for finally saying out loud what I've been saying in public for years. Until now, whenever we met each other in Brussels or Washington or elsewhere, there were circumstances to explain your silence. In 1973, you were Secretary of State of Richard Nixon, a President so pressed by domestic opposition that he feverishly sought diversion abroad. Thus, you proclaimed 1973 The Year of Europe, a declaration that made no demands on you. After all, Europe and America have been bound to each other so long and in so many common interests and problems that no one can criticize you for thinking about us in your own way. But we were in agreement about the facts, especially about the nuclear protection you extended over Europe (the famous nuclear umbrella, so full of holes) that inyour eyes justified our dependence on your country's good will. Our European partners seemed convinced that they were not simply lining up for a nearlyempty dish. We French were the only ones, under General de Gaulle, to see all the holes in the umbrella.

title: Real Estate
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. IF New Rochelle had had its way five or six years ago, the vacant and blighted land that long ago served as freight yards for the New Haven Railroad might have been developed asmiddleincome apartments. But New York State's middleincome housing production effort was rapidly decelerating at the time. It has yet to recover.

title: RHODESIA REBELS SAY ITEM SNAGGING TALKS CAN BE WORKED OUT
description: LONDON, Oct. 16  The Zimbabwe Rhodesia guerrilla leaders, trying to retain a role for themselves in the peace conference here, today further modified their objections to the constitution that Britain has proposed for the country.

title: Boatique Seeks Trade in Japan
description: TOKYO  It's a giant floating exhibition of American consumer products, labeled Boatique America in fine Madison Avenue style, and it is offering 800,000 items to the Japanese public.

title: Tips; From an Expert; Whipped Cream; Tips From an Expert on Pastry; Egg Whites; Egg Yolks And Eggs in General; On Baking Pans And Their Preparation; Star of Zurich; To Make a Star Pattern; Pt Feuillete (Puff Pastry); Pattern for Star of Zurich Cake
description: BAKING is a highly specialized branch of cookery and seems to require a particular kind of talent. It is rare to find someone who is equally good as cook or baker. This is even true of professionals  chefs and patissiers who are traditional rivals, trading generally goodhumored Jibes, but each secretly believing the other is just a little peculiar.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday incorrectly suggested that Federal transportation officials had approved building a section of Interstate Highway 84 east of Route 52 in Connecticut to Providence, R.I. The approval covered only parts of the highway between Hartford and Route 52.

title: Saint Laurent Styles: A Return to Reality
description: PARIS, Oct. 16  For the first time since the spring fashion shows started here almost a week ago, people were talking about what clothes they would buy for themselves this morning. It was a clearsign that Yves Saint Laurent had scored another triumph.

title: Key Israeli and Egyptian Clash Over Settlements
description: CAIRO, Oct. 16  Israel's Minister of Agriculture, Ariel Sharon, arrived here today for a fourday visit and promptly clashed with his Egyptian counterpart over expansion of Israeli settlements in occupied Arab territory.

title: Chess:; How Do Collaborators Play When Facing Each Other?; Safe vs. Sorry
description: Players who do their opening preparation together often have an agreement to draw their games when they meet in a tournament. This makes sense because each knows all the other's secrets and might well be butting his head against a stone wall.

title: Mayor Voices City's Thanks To Volunteers
description: Twentyfive New Yorkers and organizations, part of a volunteer army of half a million who give their time and effort to help others, were honored by Mayor Koch last night at Gracie Mansion.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: 3 Sentenced in Attack Using Bats Against 6 In Central Park in '78
description: Three young men from the Upper East Side received prison sentences of three to 15 years yesterday for their attack in the Central Park Ramble in July 1978, which left six men seriously injured.

title: Knicks Win
description: After having shown little respect for Wes Unseld, one of the National Basketball Association's most physical centers, last Saturday night, Bill Cartwright showed even less respect last night for Moses Malone, the league's most valuable player last season.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Transition In Rhodesia
description: LONDON  The most powerful man in Zimbabwe Rhodesia arrived here last weekend. He Is not the Prime Minister, Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa, nor the former Prime Minister, Ian D. smith, nor the leaders of the Patriotic Front, Joshua Nkomo and Robert Mugabe. Rather, he is Lieut. Gen. Peter Wald, commander of the Rhodesian defense forces.

title: U.S. Calls Coup Leaders Moderate And New Direction Encouraging
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  The United States gave an unusually friendly reception today to the military coup that overthrew President Carlos Humberto Romero in E1 Salvador, while stoutly denying any American involvement.

title: Corporate Earnings
description: For periods as short (N ) Indcates stock Is listed on the New York Stack Exchange, (A) the Amerkan Exchange and (O) overMecounter.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Oct. 16,1979

title: Livingston to Start for Chiefs
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 16 (AP)Mike Livingston, the veteran who lost his job earlier this year to Steve Fuller, will be the starting quarterback Sunday when the Kansas City Chiefs meet the New York Giants.

title: 79 World Series Not Late Starter
description: For those of the opinion that the World Series begins and ends too late in the fall, a look at the record book might offer some small consolation.

title: A Jail Becomes a Downtown Art Center
description: To say the least, it is not the usual sort of artist's garret. First of all, it is a majestic fourstory example of the Renaissance Italianate style built in 1909. And if that weren't singular enough, until 1975 it was a police station complete with 30 cells

title: Common Questions
description: The following are some of the most commonly asked questions about pastry making and bread baking, with answers from John Clancy.

title: Pay Advisory Committee Set
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) Waiting until the day before his Pay Advisory Committee was to hold its first meeting, President Carter announced today his choice of 17 people to join the chairman, John T. Dunlop, on the panel.

title: First Sizable Shipment Of Food for Cambodia Has Arrived by Barge
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 16 The first substantial food shipment for Cambodia, 1,500 tons, has arrived in the port of Kompong Son, relief officials reported today.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 (AP)  The Shell Oil Company announced today that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Belridge Oil Company for $3.6 billion in what would be the the largest corporate acquisition in history. However, two other oil companies said they might challenge the sale.

title: Britain to Sell More of Its B. P. Stock
description: LONDON, Oct. 16  The Government announced plans today to sell about $600 million worth of stock in the British Petroleum Company to private investors, reducing its stake in the country's biggest industrial enterprise to 46 percent from 51 percent.

title: Books of The Times
description: ATLHOUGH 58 people were murdered in New York in one week a few years ago and 13 in one day, most of us still find it difficult to imagine a murder committed for what might be called purely personal reasons. We tend to assume thatmurders are committed by gangsters, by psychotics and by people in a rage who kill in an unthinking reflexive action.

title: Charity Begins at 600 Feet
description: Looking out at Upper New York Bay yesterday morning, residents of New York City and New Jersey had the usual spectacular view  and more

title: Islanders Beat Flames, 51, for First Victory
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 16  The Islanders started the game tonight with a couple of fights. Then they began to forecheck and take out their men the way they were taught. After that, they started skating and shooting and the puck began to go in the net, as the coach said it would. When the third contest of their National Hockey League season was over, the Islanders had their first victory, an emphatic 51 rout of the Atlanta Flames.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Litton Industries has named Leonard Erb, president of Litton's Ingalls Shipbuilding division, a corporate vice president.

title: The Passing of a Club for the Elite at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN FOR years it was a bastion of privilege, where a man of means could go for a good meal, to shoot some pool or have a quiet drink with a few college buddies. Cyrus Vance drank at its basement bar, as did William and James Buckley, John Lindsay and many other students who passed through Yale before the admission of women and minorities changed the nature of a Yale education.

title: Musicians Agree to Terms With St. Louis Symphony
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 16 (AP)  Striking musicians and the St. Louis Symphony Society reached agreement yesterday on a new threeyear contract, ending a strike that began Sept. 4.

title: HALLECK LEFFERTS
description: Halleck Lefferts, an educator who served as headmaster of the Pomfret (Conn.) School from 1930 to 1942, died yesterday at the Washington Hospital Center in Washington. He was 85 years old.

title: Carey Vows to Veto Quick Fuel Tax Repeal
description: ALBANY, Oct. 16  Saying that I read the signs and I see it coming, Governor Carey warned the State Legislature today that he would veto an attempt to repeal immediately the state sales tax on residential fuel, but he implied he would accept a gradual abolition of the tax.

title: A Family Goldfish Farm's Net Results
description: LILYPONS, MD. Remember the goldfish you bought for a dime at Woolworth's, or won at the country fair by tossing a PingPong ball into its bowl? Did you ever wonder where those fish came from?

title: Pirates Triumph, 40, and Tie Series
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 16 Jim Palmer knew what the Baltimore Orioles would have to do to eliminate the hothitting Pittsburgh Pirates in the sixth game of the World Series tonight. If you put four, five runs on the board, the Orioles starting pitcher had said, you have a chance. If not, you're in trouble.

title: Weaver to Retire After 82 Season
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 16  Earl Weaver, whose Baltimore teams have won four American League pennants during his 11year tenure, said tonight he planned to retire to Florida following the 1982 season.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, October 8, to Sunday, October 14), listed according to their rank In the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: Puerto Rico Offers 9% Bonds
description: Puerto Rico offered taxexempt bonds yielding 9 percent yesterday, the highest rate of return on its securities in almost four years, and investors quickly spoke for the $100 million involved, underwriters reported.

title: New York Labor Aide Joins President's Staff
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  Linda TarrWhelan, an administrator in the New York State Department of Labor, has been named deputy assistant to President Carter.

title: Bridge:
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 16  For a while today, those who are predicting a world championship final between Italy and the United States became less confident when the Australians, struggling in third position. built up a lead against Brazil at the halfway stage in the 13th round at the same time that both their rivals were having trouble. The Italians trailed the Far East team, and the Americans were doing poorly against Central America.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE wine world is buzzing with talk of a Parisian blind tasting that once more has confirmed the ascendancy of California. Under conditions of deep secrecy last summer, some 300 wines from 33 countries were tasted and analyzed by 62 experts in the vast cellars of Nicolas,a French wine company, in Charenton, a Paris suburb. Because I was not present and therefore cannot personally attest to the conditions, I report the results with some trepidation, for havoc will erupt anew in the wine market when it becomes known how well some California wines apparently fared.

title: Week's Figures Meet U.S. Fuel Stockpile Goal
description: By achieving the biggest oneweek jump in inventories so far this year, the oil industry has satisfied the Government's request to stockpile 240 million barrels of heating oil, diesel fuel and other socalled middle distillates two and a half weeks ahead of schedule, according to figures released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: French and Chinese Broaden Ties
description: PARIS, Oct. 17 (Reuters)  France and China signed new economic, cultural and technological cooperation agreements today that may broaden the scope of relations between the two countries up to the year 2000.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: ForemostMcKesson Inc., the West Coast food, drug and liquor company, disclosed yesterday after a phone call from the New York Stock Exchange that it had received a friendly takeover proposal from an investor group offering to purchase the company for $36 share, or $650 million in cash.

title: Man Guilty of Oklahoma Murders; Defendant in Nebraska Acquitted
description: An Alabama drifter was convicted yesterday by an Oklahoma jury of murdering six persons in a steakhouse meat locker, and a jury in Nebraska found another man not guilty by reason of insanity in the slayings of six members of a family.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: ALOT of people still want to be writers. Writing may not have quite the cachet that it had when Dickens, Tolstoy and Victor Hugo were around, but it is still pretty nice to be known everywhere and instantaneously as the famous author.

title: 4 Black Leaders See Danger in Conflict Over P.L.O.
description: Four prominent blacks expressed concern yesterday that the debate among blacks over the Palestine Liberation Organization might seriously damage the black movement.

title: ESSAY Carter, the Innocent
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  I suspected that the reason for the secrecy surrounding the President's personal business affairs in 1976 had to do with the financing of his campaign. The report of Special Counsel Paul Curran has allayed that suspicion.

title: Money
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1979

title: Entertainment Events
description: SNOW WHITE AND THE SEVEN DWARFS, book and lyrics by Joseph Cook, musk by Jay Blackton, with Mary Jo Salerno, Radio City Music Hall, the Avenue of the Americas and West 50th Street, 6:45.

title: John M. P. Thatcher, a Lawyer, 94
description: John M. P. Thatcher, senior partner in the New York law firm of Thatcher, Manderen & Pullman, died Tuesday in Lake Cumberland Hospital, Somerset, Ky. He was 94 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: GERMANS BID DUTCH ACCEPT NATO MISSILE
description: THE HAGUE, Oct. 17 West German officials have told a group of Socialist Party leaders here that if the Netherlands did not agree to the basing of new American intermediaterange missiles on its territory, the Government of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt would be unable to go along with NATO plans to deploy the missiles in West Germany.

title: For the Assistant D.A., It's Nothing Like TV
description: An 8yearold boy, his voice soft but steady, told how he had seen robbers shoot his father to death in front of the family's Brooklyn grocery store.

title: S. J. Perelman, Humorist, Is Dead
description: S. J. Perelman, the humorist and author whose penchant for wordplay, spoofery and zaniness, indulged in essays, books, plays and movies, helped to shape American humor, died yesterday morning in his apartment at the Gramercy Park Hotel. He was 75 years old. Thecause of his death was not disclosed, but friends said he had died of natural causes.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: For the first time since the Federal Reserve Board's new moneytightening program was announced 12 days ago, interest rates in the credit markets reached highenough levels yesterday to spur investors to buy new bond issues.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Players Are Pained By Perkins's Attitude
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 17 Gordon Gravelle left by plane today. Joe Pisarcik is sure to follow. The Giants are on a winning streak, but on Ray Perkins's Giants, winning isn't everything.

title: Art: Portraits By Sargent
description: DETROIT THERE was a period  the Edwardian period  when the American painter John Singer Sargent (18561925) was looked on by people of power and influence as one of the greatest artists of his time.

title: Piano: Miss Yablonskaya
description: Oxana Yablonskaya's third New York recital was given on Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y as the initial event in a series called the New Americans: From Russia With Music, which is presenting relatively recent migr artists from the Soviet Union. The pianist, a 38yearold native of Moscow, came here two years ago and made an impressive debut at that time in Alice Tully Hall.

title: Salvadoran Junta Asks Aid of Moderate Opposition
description: SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 17  El Salvador's military junta invited moderate opposition groups today to participate in a government of transition before free elections are held.

title: Writer of 10 Criticizes Studio's Ads
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 17  Despite the success of 10 at the box office during its first two weeks, the movie's writerproducerdirector, Blake Edwards, is publicly angry at the advertising and marketing campaign chosen by studio executives for his comedy about the midlife crisis of a man searching for the perfect woman  a 10 on a scale of 1 to 10.

title: Adventures in Design Shops Abroad
description: FOR the inquisitive and the acquisitive, shopping on a trip abroad has always been a necessary activity. But while food shops and clothing boutiques, in Paris and London, for example, offer tantalizing buys for the gourmet and the fashion fiend, the traveler interested in home furnishings and design could feel frustrated.

title: Converting Thrifts Studied
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  A report prepared by the General Accounting Office, the investigating arm of Congress, has urged Congress to decide national policy on whether, and under what circumstances, federally chartered savings and loan associations should be permitted to convert from mutual to stock ownership.

title: STEVEN KYLE, 66, DESIGNER, IS DEAD
description: Steven Kyle, a designer of decorative accessories and the husband of Betty Comden, the actress and playwright, died yesterday morning in Mt. Sinai Hospital of acute pancreatitis. He was 66 years old. He had been admitted to the hospital's intensivecare unit two and half weeks ago. Mr. Kyle had recovered completely from a similar attack 11 years ago.

title: 1980 Soccer Bowl Is Set For R.F. Kennedy Stadium
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  Soccer Bowl80, the North American Soccer League's championship game next season, will be played at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium here on Sept. 20.

title: Pirates Earn Prize That Lasts Forever
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 17  The great shootout of the 76th World Series came to an end at 11:30 o'clock tonight when Pat Kelly of the Baltimore Orioles pinch hit a fly ball to Omar Moreno of the Pittsburgh Pirates in center field. On the pitcher's mound, Kent Tekulve turned to watch.

title: Calling a SolarHeated Barn Home
description: THEY are perfectly willing to admit that things were on the chilly side when they first moved in. After all, it was December. Can you imagine  practically the coldest day of the year, said Parry Jones. The house had no time to do its stuff. The house in question is a newly converted 18thcentury barn on a windy Pennsylvania hillside. And the stuff it does is keep 6,000 square feet of living space toasty in winter through solar energy.

title: Mother Teresa of Calcutta Wins Peace Prize
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 17  Mother Teresa of Calcutta, a Roman Catholic nun of Albanian stock who has cared for the poor and sick in India for more than 30 years, was named the winner today of the 1979 Nobel Peace Prize.

title: 9 U.S. Boxers Reach Finals of World Cup
description: Tony Tucker, a lightheavyweight from Grand Rapids, Mich., scored a victory before another sparse crowd at the Felt Forum last night to lead a parade of Americans into the finals of tomorrow night's World Cup boxing tournament.

title: Home Improvement
description: AFTER the two beams are securely bolted in place at the proper height (as explained in last week's column, the beams are the full length, doubled 2by8's that run parallel to the house wall), the exposed end of each 2by8 is trimmed off to an angle of about 30 degrees as shown in the drawing. This helps shed water and thus minimize the likelihood of splitting.

title: Carey Names Ravitch to Head M.T.A.
description: Governor Carey yesterday named Richard Ravitch, a wealthy builder, as chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: GARDENING
description: IF the menu at bird feeders includes sunflower and thistle seed, nutmeats, cereal grains and cracked corn, flocks will come to dine. Nuthatches, chickadees, titmice, finches, whitethroated sparrows and juncos are among the winter resident birds that will appreciate these morsels at feeders, especially if the weather gets rough.

title: Memorial Service for Firemen Killed in the Line of Duty
description: Mayor Koch, placing a wreath at the Firemen's Monument on Riverside Drive yesterday, was joined by, from left: Chief Joseph A. Flynn; Nicholas Mancuso, head of the Uniformed Firefighters Association; Edwin F. Jennings, head of the Uniformed Fire Officers Association; Commissioner Augustus A. Beekman; and Chief of Department Francis Cruthers. The Mayor paid tribute to the three firefighters killed in the line of duty the past year: John T. McKenna, Walter Smith Jr. and Gerard D. Crowley, who died Sunday and will be buried today.

title: ABCTV Head Confident Network Is Ready for 80's
description: ABCTV is entering the 80's with full confidence it can hold its own in the marketplace invaded by new communications technologies because of the network's long experience as provider of entertainment and informational programming, Frederick S. Pierce, president of ABC Television, said yesterday.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: LONDON, Oct. 17  Responding mainly to a change in the way the United States will auction gold, the price of gold dropped $8.25 an ounce in European markets today in moderate but very nervous trading.

title: Debate Again Rages on the Best Way to Package Meat
description: The kind of packaging supermarkets in New York City use for meat, a subject of tumultuous discussion in the city a decade ago, has again grown into a heated dispute between two competing industries, and the issue will be considered today by the City Council Committee on Consumer Affairs.

title: Biggest Bank's Net Rises 11%
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the world's largest banking concern, reported thirdquarter net operating earnings yesterday of $163 million, up 11 percent from $147 million in the comparable period of last year.

title: Brennan Protests Criticism by Press
description: NEWARK, Oct. 17  Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. said today that the nation's press overreacted to some of the Supreme Court's decisions involving First Amendment guarantees of a free press.

title: Padres Face Rent Increase For Use of Office Space
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 17 (AP)  The City of San Diego is raising the San Diego Padres office space rent by 86 percent and says the National League baseball club must agree to the new lease by Monday or face eviction from San Diego Stadium.

title: Food Fair Study Cites Insider Deals
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct 17  A pattern of insider dealings between the former management of financially ailing Food Fair Inc. and companies controlled by relatives of Food Fair executives has been reported in an investigation ordered by the company's creditors.

title: 2 Suspects Arrested in Sicily
description: ROME, Oct. 17  Two more members of a known organized crime family were arrested last night in Palermo, the Sicilian capital, on suspicion of involvement in the disappearance of Michele Sindona.

title: SOLUTION EXPECTED IN RHODESIAN TALKS
description: LONDON, Oct. 17  One of the coleaders of the Patriotic Front said today that a break was imminent in the deadlock that has resulted in the exclusion of the guerrilla alliance from the negotiations here on Zimbabwe Rhodesia for a week.

title: Net Plunges At T.W.A., American
description: Hit by increasing fuel costs and price wars on some key mutes, two major airlines yesterday reported sharply lower thirdquarter earnings.

title: The Noisy Neighbors
description: FOR THE last couple of years I have been living in an almost perfect New York City apartment. The rooms are large, the rent is reasonable, the doormen are courteous and the neighborhood is quiet, convenient and virtually crimefree. My apartment is almost perfect because it has only one small drawback  upstairs neighbors. A neighbor is something that isn't mentioned in the lease but comes with every apartment.

title: Car Renting Agencies Accused by New York Of Deception on Rates
description: All eight nationwide car rental agencies operating in New York City were charged yesterday by the city's Consumer Affairs Department with deceiving the public by giving conflicting rates and misleading information over the telephone.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Judge Rules Carter Cannot Bypass Congress in Ending Taiwan Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  A United States District judge ruled today that President Carter could not end the Mutual Defense Treaty between the United States and Taiwan without the consent of Congress.

title: Reagan Plans New York Announcement of Candidacy
description: Ronald Reagan will announce his candidacy for President on Nov. 13 at a fundraising dinner in New York City, and not in Washington, in an attempt to demonstrate that he has strength in the Northeast. Reagan aides said yesterday.

title: Letters
description: To the editor:

title: Taiwan Denies Accepting Soccer Federation Terms
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 17 (UPI)Taiwanese sports authorities denied today a report that Taiwan had agreed to change its name, national flag and national anthem to retain membership in the International Federation of Football Associations, soccer's worldwide governing body.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Andrew H. Tisch, the 30yearold son of Laurence A. Tisch, chairman of the Loews Corporation, was quietly named president last week of the 105yearold Bulova Watch Company, acquired by Loews last March.

title: Letters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Around the Nation
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 17 (AP)  Bert Lance, former Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and three codefendants were rebuffed yesterday in their bid to have a 33count indictment dismissed. United States Magistrate Allen L. Chancey Jr. said that the indictment on charges of conspiring to violate Federal banking laws had itself provided probable cause for holding the defendants for trial.

title: Asbestos and 11 Chemicals Under New Rules in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Oct. 17  Under pressure from the Federal Government, the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection adopted new air pollution regulations today, including rules designed to cut down pollution from asbestos and 11 toxic chemicals suspected of causine cancer.

title: Carter Selects Bowdler For Latin Affairs Post
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (Reuters) President Carter today nominated William G. Bowdler, the State Department's intelligence chief, as Assistant Secretary of State for InterAmerican Affairs.

title: 1,800 Marines Land at Guantnamo in Show of U.S. Might
description: UNITED STATES NAVAL BASE, Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, Oct. 17  Hampered by a sometimes driving rainstorm, 1,800 marines in battle gear landed at this lonely American outpost on Communist soil this morning.

title: Obituary 8  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Witnesses Attest To Kush CoverUp
description: TEMPE, Ariz., Oct. 17  Five football players and five assistant coaches signed statements yesterday that appear to support the contention that Frank Kush did punch a player during a game last year and that he recently attempted a coverup by asking coaches and players to deny that they knew about the matter.

title: Reldan Is Guilty In 19 75 Slayings Of Two Women
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 17  Robert R. Reldan, a 39yearold house painter with a lengthy criminal record that includes rape and assault, was convicted tonight of strangling two young New Jersey women whom he abducted at random on Bergen County streets four years ago.

title: Horse V.D. Quarantine Is Eased
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI)  The Agriculture Department today lifted a statewide quarantine of thoroughbred breeding horses in Kentucky that was imposed a year and a half ago because some had contagious equine metritis, a venereal disease.

title: The Theater: Ladyhouse Blues, Five Women in a Household
description: THE five women in Ladyhouse Blues who share a household and only a little bit of hope like to sing. They sing without thinking, sing when they are quarreling, sing when they are reading, sing because it's twilight and sing because it's dawn, and they sing right into the rumble and crackle of a thunderstorm.

title: F.B.I. and Police Question Sindona; Closer Watch at Hospital Ordered
description: Federal agents and New York detectives yesterday began questioning Michele Sindona, the Italian financier who had been missing for two and a half months. But they said they could not immediately judge whether he had been kidnapped or had dropped out of sight intentionally to avoid trial on charges of bank fraud.

title: Tremor Shakes Yugoslavia
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 17 (Reuters)  A strong tremor shook the earthquakeprone region of Yugoslavia's south Adriatic coast last night, but no casualties or damage were reported, officials said. The epicenter was placed 20miles southwest of Titograd, capital of Montenegro. On April 15, more than 100 people were killed and 1,000 injured by an earthquake in the region.

title: The City
description: The city received a $4 million Federal grant yesterday to convert two vacant Harlem schools into a multiservice center bringing area employment, health, day care, legal services, mental health, drug prevention and recreation services under one roof.

title: Job Rights Backlog Reduced
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI)  The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has reduced its backlog of cases by more than 41 percent, it was announced yesterday. The reduction amounted to $30 million in settlement and conciliation benefits, the commission chairman, Eleanor Holmes Norton, said.

title: Senate Unit Backs Aid On Heating
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  A program extending tax credits for high home heating costs to families with incomes of up to $22,000 a year was approved today by the Senate Finance Committee.

title: E.E.C. Studies U.S. Exports
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 17 (Reuters)  The European Economic Community Commission said today that it was too early to specify what measures it might take against rising United States exports of petrochemicals and manmade fibers to member nations of the community.

title: Family Finance Liability Insurance For Homeowners
description: BARRY K. was desperate. One Saturday morning, while shopping at his busy neighborhood supermarket, he had careened around the corner of a crowded aisle and hit a toddler with his shopping cart. The little boy's skull was fractured, and now Barry was being sued for $250.000.ers feel morally obligated to pay, even though they are not at fault. This might be the case if your aunt slips and twists her ankle on a loose rug, or your child breaks a vase at a neighbor's house. Typically, protection is low  between $250 and $500  although larger amounts can be purchased.

title: Joseph Stein, ExCommissioner Of Buildings Department, Was 52
description: Joseph Stein, a former Commissioner of the New York City Department of Buildings, died Sunday of a heart attack at Highland Park Hospital in Illinois. He was 52 years old and had lived in Glencoe, Ill., in recent years.

title: ANOTHER DISSIDENT ON TRIAL IN PEKING
description: PEKING, Oct. 17  A dissident, Fu Yuehua, was put on trial today on charges of having disrupted public order and of having falsely accused a Communist Party official of raping her.

title: ABROAD AT HOME Next Move To Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  Some people still seem to think that Senator Edward Kennedy may not, in the end, say yes. They see a chance that he will shy away from what he must now realize will be no free ride but a long, grinding battle.

title: British Ship Is Reported Aground After Collision in the Dardanelles
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 17 (Reuters)A British freighter that collided with Greek ship in the Dardanelles this morning has been run aground near Intepe on the Anatolian coast, the Turkish radio said.

title: Dr. Frank R. Smith, 83, Physician and Teacher
description: Dr. Frank R. Smith, a gynecologist who had been associated with New York and Roosevelt Hospitals, died Monday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

title: Q &
description: Q. The wroughtiron hinges on my kitchen cabinet have been painted over several times, as have the brass plates and handles on my closet doors. What is the best way to remove all of the paint from this hardware? M.M., Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Music: Lieder by Prey
description: GERMANY'S baritone lieder singer seem to come in pairs. Before World War II, the great names were Gerhard Hsch and Heinrich Schlusnus. In recent years, the dominant figures have been Dietrich FischerDieskau and Hermann Prey, who have vied with each other in the best possible ways, to the high profit of song enthusiasts all over the world. It was the turn of Mr. Prey, as a lineal descendant of this baritonal line, to bring his craft and art to us last night at Carnegie Hall.

title: Cabaret: Dorothy Collins
description: SINCE Dorothy Collins made her Broadway debut in Stephen Sondheim's Follies in 1971, her cabaret and concert performances have usually been a mixture of the happygolucky Hit Parade songs that brought her to prominence early In the 1950's and the Sondheim repertory that she has acquired since Follies.

title: U.S. Gives China Public Rebuke Over Dissident Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  The State Department for the first time since the establishment of diplomatic relations rebuked China publicly today in a human rights case. It said the United States was surprised and disappointed by the severity of a prison term given a dissident in Peking yesterday.

title: Chrysler Offers New Aid Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  Late this evening, the Chrysler Corporation submitted a revised financial rescue plan to the Treasury Department that seeks $750 million in Federal loan guarantees. The revised proposal requests assistance within the limits outlined a month ago by G. William Miller, Secretary of the Treasury.

title: About Newark
description: NEWARKThere is a notquitehidden village in Newark, a Portuguese village where the identity crisis does not nibble, at least not yet, at the peoples confidence in what they are.

title: U.S. Trust Net Off 70% for Quarter
description: The United States Trust Company, whose main business has been to manage other people's money, reported a 21 percent drop in thirdquarter operating income yesterday and said net income had dropped 70 percent, primarily as result of losses from its investment activities.

title: Sharon, in Egypt, Visits Desert Reclamation Site
description: INSHASS, Egypt, Oct. 17  Ariel Sharon, the Israeli Minister of Agriculture, put politics aside today and toured one of of Egypt's reclamation areas. He talked of possible agricultural exchange programs.

title: Stubborn Fighter for the Poorest of the Poor
description: Ambulance drivers of Calcutta once risked beatings by angry crowds when occasionally they were caught dumping a dying man or woman back on the streets, instead of confronting the futility of overcrowded hospitals. Intothis desperation and hopelessness came an Albanian nun, Mother Teresa, to found a mission that gave to thousands something their lives couldnever promise before, a dignified place to die.

title: Mrs. Miller Leads Golf
description: NORTHFIELD, N.J., Oct. 17  Mrs. Toby Miller of Ridgewood posted a 41, 3980 today and took an 11stroke lead after the first day of the Grace Dickerson Memorial Trophy twoday golf tournament.

title: Grasso Proposal For Heating Aid Asks 22 Million
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 17  Gov. Ella T. Grasso announced emergency fuel aid proposals today that would include $22 million in aid to the working poor, a doubling of a $3 million program of energy conservation loans to homeowners and the granting of new powers and money for municipalities to prevent housing abandonment because of higher fuel costs this winter.

title: Rival Says Outgoing Premier Mismanaged Turkey
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 17  The big problem in Turkey is management, the conservative opposition leader, Suleyman Demirel, insists, accusing the outgoing Social Democratic Prime Minister, Bulent Ecevit, of having mismanaged the country.

title: Wide Impact Is Seen for Coast Ruling on I.Q. Tests
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17  A group of black psychologists predicted today that a Federal district judge's ruling yesterday prohibiting California officials from using standardized intelligence tests to place black children in classes for the mentally retarded would affect similar use of the tests across the country.

title: Oil Industry Target of Demonstrations
description: Union members, elderly persons and hundreds of other Americans demonstrated against the oil industry yesterday with protests intended to end the rise in energy prices. Many of the crowds were smaller than expected.

title: Stoical Holzman Excited About Cartwright
description: Red Holzman does not bestow praise easily. The Knick coach likes to save communications with his players for the basketball court. Even when the Knicks won their only two National Basketball Association championships, Holzman would spare his words and let the players do the talking.

title: Soldiering On in E1 Salvador
description: The world doesn't normally take much notice when a new military government pops up in El Salvador. Central America's most densely populated country has been under military rule of one kind or another for the past 45 years. Since a peasant uprising in 1932 badly frightened the few families that control much of El Salvador's wealth, repressive force has been the only response to demands for social reform.

title: Coors Learning How to Sell
description: GOLDEN, Colo.  The Adolph Coors brewery, the largest one in the country, looms over this company town like a gray fortress. Huge boxlike buildings, assembled from giant slabs of concrete, run together like a battery of overbuilt bunkers backed against a Rocky Mountains foothill.

title: Paris Audience Is Cool to the New Revealing Fashions
description: PARIS, Oct.17  A funny thing happened at the end of the fashion shows for spring here. Nobody clapped.

title: Burke Team Triumphs
description: LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 17  Mike Burke Sr., the Deal professional, and Susan Stockfisch, women's club champion, combined for a 68, 68136 to capture the New Jersey proladies championship today at the Woodlake Country Club by eight strokes.

title: Every Nickel and Every Peanut
description: Paul Curran, a Republican lawyer of experience and probity, says he has now tracked every nickel and every peanut of Jimmy Carter's business when he was running for President and has found nothing criminal. The special counsel has concluded that the Georgia warehouse enterprise, despite disorganized and irregular loan dealings, was not a source of illegal campaign funding in 1976. This broad judgment, supported by a detailed public report, commands considerable respect, which may increase as political opponents probe it for mistakes.

title: Obituary 7  No Title
description: Deaths

title: RUSTIN DELEGATION CONFERS WITH BEGIN
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 17  Bayard Rustin, the longtime civil rights leader, assured an audience of Israelis today that the vast majority of politically active American blacks were committed to Israel's safe existence, a resolve, he said,that grew out of blackJewish ties extend ing far beyond shared social causes and into the Old Testament traditions of Judaism itself.

title: Bush Brings His Quest For the White House To New York's G.O.P.
description: George Bush brought his campaign for the Republican nomination for President to New York City last night, exemplifying what his local supporters say are the twin elements of his game plan for the city  to attract some money and a lot of attention.

title: Lindsay, a Scotto Witness, Testifies to High Integrity
description: Former Mayor John V. Lindsay testified in a criminal trial yesterday that he regarded Anthony M. Scotto as a man of high integrity who helped New York City.

title: OHIO TOLD TO MEET CLEANAIR DEADLINE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  Officials of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that they would require the state of Ohio to meet a deadline of Friday for complying with federally imposed standards on clean air but, to save jobs, would grant temporary exemptions to some polluting coalburning plants.

title: U.A.W. Offers Package
description: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich., Oct. 17 (AP)  Douglas A. Fraser, president of the United Automobile Workers, today presented Chrysler with a package of possible contract concessions.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: FOR a household with very young children there are many hardware items especially designed to keep children out of harm's way. While none of these products is foolproof, each makes it harder for a child to get into dangerous places or things.

title: New Home Building Increases
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP)  New home construction increased 4.2 percent nationwide in September as the industry continued to show considerably more strength than had been predicted, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Oct. 17, 1979

title: West German Investments
description: BONN, Oct. 17 (AP)  New West German private direct investments abroad rose 23.7 percent in the first half of 1979 while foreign investments in West Germany climbed only 4.6 percent, the Economics Ministry reported today. The ministry said West German investments overseas totaled $1.88 billion at current exchange rates, up from $1.52 billion in the first half of 1978.

title: How To Sell The Gold You've Got
description: WHILE people who are interested in buying gold items are being advised to go ahead before retail prices are pushed up by rising inventory costs, another group is rushing to sell gold  and silver  articles while there is still time to benefit from the current skyhigh market prices.

title: Rattlesnake Stakes
description: One man's meat is another's poison. But we suspect one reason some of the heman power brokers who dine at Dominique D'Ermo's gourmet restaurant in Washington, D.C., like to eat rattlesnakes is that in life the snakes were poisonous. A formerly dangerous creature sauted in wine and safely tucked into the stomach makes them feel stronger and is something to boast about. Cannibals felt the same way about consuming an enemy. So do cowboys after a meal of prairie oysters  bullcalf testicles. Cecil Andrus, who as Secretary of the Interior is in charge of the endangered species program, eats at Dominique's and says he hates rattlesnake. He fired a scientist in his department who wrote the restaurateur to protest the use of an Easterntype rattler, fast dwindling in numbers.

title: Arthur Mendel, Music Professor At Princeton and Expert on Bach
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 16  Arthur Mendel, a professor of music at Princeton University for 21 years and an authority on Bath, died Sunday at the age of 74 in the Beth Israel Medical Center in Newark.

title: Hunter S. Marston, 94, Financier Who Founded Dixie Cup Concern
description: Hunter S. Marston, an investment banker who headed the BancamericaBlair Corporation in New York in the 1930's and later founded a number of concerns, among them the the Dixie Cup Company, died Tuesday at his home in Watch Hill, R.I. He was 94 years old.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: New York Acts to Cut Dropout Rate
description: Serious consideration is being given to a plan to create additional alternative high schools in New York City to cope with the soaring dropout rate, a Board of Education official said yesterday.

title: Strauss Plans New Mideast Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's special Middle East envoy, said today that he planned to fly to London next week for another round of talks with the chief Egyptian and Israeli negotiators. But he added it was doubtful that the target of next May for completing negotiations on Palestinian selfrule could be met.

title: Cycles of History
description: Popular culture in America has become Europeanized to an extent unimaginable 25 years ago. Not many people then drank wine with meals, and no one drank imported water. Soccer was something played in places like Tottenham; there was no way it could fill stadiums in places like Portland, Oregon. It's hard to know which idea would have been more astonishing then  that Americans would pay a premium for German cars, or French jeans.

title: Party Never Starts For the Sad Orioles
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 17  Everyone and everything was in place. The television camera was mounted in the center of the Orioles clubhouse, the champagne was nearby, and the President of the United States was there to offer congratulations.

title: F.B.I. Agent Resigns After Charges Over Money Intended for Informers
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 17 (AP)  An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who had been suspended for allegedly stealing money intended for informers and discussing participation in a theft ring officially resigned today.

title: Israeli Bank TieUp Ends
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 17 (AP)  Bank Leumi, Israel's largest bank, settled labor dispute today that had closed 300 branches for two weeks and disrupted financial transactions throughout the country. Details of the settlement between Bank Leumi and its 9,000 employees were not immediately announced, but bank branches throughout Israel were expected to reopen tomorrow, the bank said.

title: 15 British Consulates to Be Shut In Conservatives Economy Drive
description: LONDON, Oct. 17 (Reuters)  Britain's Foreign Office announced today that it was closing 15 consulates overseas and cutting its diplomatic staff abroad as part of the Conservative Government's economy drive.

title: Insurers Assail F.T.C. Report
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI)  The life insurance industry told Congress today that a Government report criticizing some forms of insurance was a reckless misrepresentation of our business.

title: Stocks Up Slightly in Slower Trading
description: With oil shares leading the way, stock prices registered a token advance yesterday after seven straight declines. But analysts noted that volume remained well below recent levels and interpreted this as a sign of investor caution.

title: OilSupply Forecasts Are Bleak
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  Federal energy officials issued bleak forecasts today for oil supplies and prices. They predicted a probable return of gasoline lines in the early 1980's and a price tag as high as $86 for a barrel of oil 15 years from now.

title: Coast Thrift Unit Lifts Mortgage Fee
description: Gibraltar Savings and Loan Association, a large California thrift institution, announced yesterday that it had increased its prime mortgage rate for home loans under $75,000 to 13 percent from the 12 percent rate it instituted just last week.

title: Home Beat
description: THE fake cake, iced in red, white and blue, was especially American, according to Ingo Maurer, the innovative Munichbased lighting designer. But then the occasion about to be celebrated was indeed American, and Mr. Maurer wanted to be sure it was properly recognized. Thomas Alva Edison's electric light bulb burned successfully for the first time on Oct. 21, 1879, he said. I have been continuously fascinated with the lightbulb, the designer said. Fragile, poetic, symbolic, yet technically developed and strong, is how he described what to some may be just an ordinary object. That explains why Mr. Maurer's latest lamp is a tribute to Edison's achievement. It's a bulb within a bulb, he said of the oversized fixture, which sits atop the candlelighted birthday cake, at left, but could also light a coffee table or sit on the floor. A limited number of the Europeanmade lamps are available at Morsa, 182 Hester Street, for $115 a unit. Mr. Maurer is working on developing an Americanmade version of the lamp. In the meantime, he encourages us to sing Happy Birthday, Light Bulb.

title: House Unit Asks Stepup In Relief to Cambodians
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee voted unanimously today to recommend VS million in additional emergency aid to help Cambodians avoid famine.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: THURSDAY. OCTOBER 18, 1979

title: Times of London Talks Collapse; Closure of Papers Looks Imminent
description: LONDON, Thursday, Oct. 18  Lastditch negotiations to save The Times and Sunday Times of London collapsed this morning, and the management of the two newspapers appeared on the verge of decision to close them.

title: Midwest Business Tends to Back Fed
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 17  Top business executives in the Middle West, in no mood to panic because a worried market has been buffeting some of their stoElcs, generally applaud the Federal Reserve Board's recent moneytightening moves and tend to look beyond what they see as shortterm problems.

title: Notes on People
description: Laurance and David Rockefeller said yesterday that they had put up for sale their 4,085acre estate on St. Croix in the Virgin Islands. The asking price is $10 million.

title: The Region
description: SHOPT HILLS  Thirteen workmen were injured, two seriously, in a construction accident yesterday at the Short Hills Mall on Kennedy Highway and Route 124, according to the Millburn police.

title: Brooklyn Brownstones: Two Tours Scheduled
description: FOR brownstone buffs, two outoftheordinary house tours of Brooklyn brownstone areas are scheduled for this weekend. A house and garden tour of Sunset Park, in southwest Brooklyn between Park Slope and Bay Ridge, will be held Sunday between 1 and 5 P.M.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Hers
description: I WAS one of the people who cried when The Mary Tyler Moore Show went off the air. Mary, Lou, Rhoda and the others were almost real and the stories often hit close to home. During that last episode  as Mary took her final look at the empty newsroom  I relived my own last day as Carl Reiner's secretary. In many ways Carl and I were Lou and Mary. Remember how she'd knock on his door when she had a problem? Well, I had a problem every 10 minutes, only I never bothered to knock. For five years Carl listened to all my stories, not once confusing the boyfriend who'd never leave the right tip with the one who'd never leave his wife.

title: Cheer Marks First Pay Panel Meeting
