description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  President Carter's new Pay Advisory Committee held its first meeting today in an atmosphere of bonhomie, steering well clear of the issues  wages and benefits  that are likely to cause friction between the committee's six business members and Its six labor leaders.

title: Cooper Is Named Head Of Indianapolis Speedway
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 17 (AP)John R. Cooper, the first employee of the United States Auto Club when it was formed in 1955, has been named president and chief executive officer of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

title: Weaver Named Manager of Year
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 17 (AP)Earl Weaver of the Baltimore Orioles has been named The Sporting News's major league manager of the year, the newspaper announced today.

title: Rep. Diggs Is Given Permission To Tour Africa as Appeal Pends
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI)  Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr. was given permission today to take a 20day tour of Africa and Europe while awaiting a ruling on his appeal of a payroll kickback conviction.

title: Russians Buy More Grain
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI)  The Agriculture Department said today that Moscow had bought another 787,000 metric tons of United States grain from private traders. The purchases are part of the record 25 million tons that the United States has offered to sell this year to the Russians, whose grain crop is expected to be down 26 percent from last year.

title: Repeal of a Home Fuel Tax Appears Assured in Albany
description: ALBANY, Oct. 17 After days of political wrangling over how to deal with soaring heating costs, repeal of the state sales tax on residential fuel was virtually assured today but it would not take effect until next fall. Meanwhile, Governor Carey said that he would seek additional relief measures for this winter from the Legislature in a special session.

title: FoodProcessor Asset Sale
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 17 (UPI) StokelyVan Camp Inc., an Indianapolisbased food processor, announced late yesterday an agreement to purchase some assets of Theobald Industries, Kearny, N.J., for $9.5 million. Involved are a vegetable oil refining and processing facility, a detergent manufacturing facility and substantial storage capacity for unrefined imported vegetable oil.

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: Deaths

title: England Wins and Nears Nations Cup Soccer Final
description: LONDON, Oct. 17 (AP)  England defeated Northern Ireland, 51, today in Belfast and moved a step closer to gaining the finals of the European Cup of Nations soccer tournament.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: WILLIAM W. FUCHS

title: Bridge:
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 17  The final of the Bermuda Bowl here tomorrow and Friday will, as most observers had expected, be between the United States and Italy, a rerun of many similar battles in the past. But there was a moment today when this seemed in doubt.

title: Bank Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) indcates stock is listed on the New York Rock Exchange, (Al the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Daniel F. Cohalan, 74, Lawyer in Manhattan
description: Daniel F. Cohalan, a lawyer for many years in Manhattan, died Monday at the New York HospitalMedical Center. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Headline in The Post Quoting an Irish Slur Brings a Halt in Work
description: A headlined remark about the Irish, attributed to Princess Margaret, caused a threehour work stoppage by paper handlers at The New York Post yesterday.

title: Technology
description: ON the site of what used to be the Men's Bar Manhattan's Biltmore Hotel is an unusual kind of store. It sells computers  not those faddish, hobbyoriented home computers, but rather fullblown, professional data processing systems.

title: Clem Dixon Johnston, ExCommercial Chief, And Top U.S. Official
description: ROANOKE, Va., Oct. 17 (AP)  Clem Dixon Johnston, a former president of the Chambers of Commerce of the United States and Virginia, died yesterday at a Roanoke hospital. He was 82 years old.

title: Number of Poor in U.S. Tops Most Populations
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP)  The number of Americans living in poverty exceeds the population of more than half the nations in the world, Patricia Roberts Harris, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today.

title: Louise Kroepfl of Milwaukee, 93
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 17 (UPI)  Louise Kroepfl, who carried her 4yearold daughter to safety in the second to last lifeboat launched from the Titanic 67 years ago, died in her sleep yesterday. She was 93 years old.

title: HOUSE STIFFENS CURB ON CAMPAIGN FUNDS FOR ITS OWN RACES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  The House of Representatives voted today, 217 to 198, to place strict limits on campaign contributions to House races by special interest groups.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Pops Hit One For The Family
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 17  In the sixth inning, Willie Stargell was swinging his big brown bat in the ondeck circle when Bill Robinson bounced a single off Kiko Garcia's glove into left field. Now the leader of the Pittsburgh Pirates, the father of

title: Dominicans Buy Gold Mine
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Oct. 17  The President of the Dominican Republic, Antonio Guzman, announced on television today that the Government of the Dominican Republic had bought Rosario Dominicana, the biggest openpit gold mine in the Western Hemisphere.

title: Keep Spanking Legal, A Regents Panel Votes
description: ALBANY, Oct. 17  A committee of the New York State Board of Regents, which fixes education policy for the state, voted 3 to 2 today to recommend retaining a state law that permits corporal punishment in the public school system.

title: Retired Nurse, 81, Stabbed to Death
description: An 81yearold retired nurse, Faith B. LeLacheur, was found dead of multiple stab wounds yesterday in the bedroom of her apartment at 223 East 61st Street. Pending a report from the City Medical Examiner today, the police would say only that she had possibly been raped.

title: Adopted People Seeking Records Find Many Files Closed
description: At a time when such personal data as credit information and police files are increasingly being made available to Americans, no state allows adopted persons unrestricted access to their records despite a large number of requests from adults seeking to learn their histories.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style page last Friday about a designer showcase known as the Ronald McDonald House erroneously described Janis Herman and Richard Mervis. Mrs. Herman has been a professional designer for 17 years and Mr. Mervis for three years. The showcase, scheduled to close Nov. 4, has been extended to Nov. 17.

title: I.C.C. Drops Transport Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  The Interstate Commerce Commission, as a step to increase competition in the trucking and intercity bus transportation industries, voted today to ease the procedures for new entries to qualify.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WELCOME BACK In a rare club appearance at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street, the 73yearold Edith Wilson is reprising oldtime vaudeville blues and jazz songs. Her accompanist is Little Brother Montgomery, blues composer and one of the last of the turpentine camp pianists. They are performing through Saturday and again next week, resuming on Wednesday.

title: Big Labor It's a Big Myth
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa.  The myth of big labor lives on, even though the average worker, including union members, has made little or no progress in his buying power in recent years and the United States labor movement recently has lost several major political battles. Of course, overstating organized labor's power is convenient for its detractors, who would reduce the legitimate collectivebargaining rights for which unions have fought.

title: Space Shuttle Problems Delay New Jupiter Mission
description: Problems in developing the space shuttle have forced a twoyear postponement of the 1982 Galileo mission to orbit Jupiter and to study its atmosphere, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced yesterday.

title: Irving Bank Corporation
description: The Charter New York Corporation said yesterday its shareholders had approved a change in its name to the Irving Bank Corporation. The Irving Trust Company is its main subsidiary.

title: Comedy for Lunch at American Place
description: THE American Place Theater, which works mostly in live drama, is filling the lunch hour laughably on film these weekdays.

title: Earvin Johnson Injures Knee
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 17 (UPI) Earvin (Magic) Johnson, the Los Angeles Lakers top draft choice, tore a ligament in his right knee going for a rebound against Seattle tonight and was carried from the court.

title: Noble Dancer Breaks Down
description: The racing career of Noble Dancer H, an $8,222 purchase that won nearly a million dollars as a leading grasscourse competitor, has ended because of a leg injury incurred during a workout at Belmont Park. The 7yearold horse ruptured ligaments on Monday, and efforts were under way yesterday to save him for stud service, though the feeling was that he would have to be destroyed.

title: Calendar: Antiques Fair Starts in Morristown, N.J.
description: The 12th annual Morristown Antiques Fair opens today with 100 dealers showing a wide variety of collectibles. The fair continues through Sunday evening.

title: Mandatory Controls Are Next
description: HARTFORD, Conn.  Wage contract bargaining under Federal guidelines, which rapidly emerged as an exercise in futility for employers and labor unions, has become a nightmare for the Administration and will end up with imposition of mandatory controls. Washington has been desperately trying to save its illfated guidelines by cosmetic surgery that has only served to blur even more basic flaws inherent in the program.

title: Plan for a Mayoral Aide Rejected By Puerto Rican Officials in City
description: A majority of New York City's Puerto Rican elected officials yesterda) rejected Mayor Koch's offer to appoint a Hispanic mayoral adviser as an attempt to mollify us.

title: Sound
description: THE recent trend toward smaller stereo components has spawned a new generation of minispeakers, most of them no bigger than a shoebox and some as small as a loaf of bread. These bantams are evidently intended as attractive companions to the other new and notably handsome minicomponents amplifier, tuners, and tape decks discussed in this column on June 21. But the match is often more successful in its visual than in its sonic aspects, giving rise to suspicions that the attempt is to sell style rather than sound. With a few remarkable exceptions listed later  the musical results obtained by these minispeakers are questionable.

title: Kodak's Profits Up 20%
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's largest producer of photographic products, said yesterday that its thirdquarter earnings had risen 20 percent to a record $285.9 million, or $1.78 a share, from $238.1 million, or $1.48 a share, in the comparable period last year. The Rochesterbased company reported that sales in the period rose 14 percent to a record $2 billion from $1.75 billion last year.

title: Dance: Threnody, Redlich's Antiwar Manifesto
description: IN his new dance piece, Threnody, Don Redlich has created a disturbing antiwar manifesto that is also a retelling of Christ's Crucifixion.

title: Tests Link Formaldehyde to Cancer in Animals, U.S. Agency Is Told
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP)  Tests done for an industry group indicate that formaldehyde, which is used in products ranging from houses to toothpaste, has caused cancer in laboratory animals, a Government agency said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Alton Box Board Company, Alton, Ill., has elected Michael W.J. Smurfit president and chief executive.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the name of the commander of the Zimbabwe Rhodesian armed forces was incorrect in Conor Cruise O'Brien';s article on Rhodesia yesterday. It is Lieut. Gen. Peter Walls.

title: Copland to Be Feted On 79th Birthday
description: Aaron Copland will be honored on Nov. 14, his 79th birthday, by the Third Street Music School Settlement, which will present him with its Award for Distinguished Achievement in Music at a luncheon at the Plaza Hotel.

title: Market Place
description: WHILE the United States looks for ways to tax oil company profits, the Canadian Government has worked out an incentive program that no doubt robs the treasury of immediate revenue but makes it likely that almost any prospective exploration there will be actively pursued.

title: Cornfeld to Sue On Liquidation
description: GENEVA, Oct. 17  Two days after his acquittal here of fraud charges, Bernard Cornfeld announced today that he would bring suit in Canada to halt the liquidation of Investors Overseas Services Ltd., the parent company of the multimilliondollar financial complex that he founded.

title: World News Briefs
description: Pakistani Military Regime Rounds Up Opponents

title: Dollar Finishes Mixed
description: The dollar briefly reached a 19month high in Tokyo yesterday but otherwise was mixed in foreign exchange trading at home and abroad. The price of gold fell.

title: 76ers Top Nets by 25 As Erving Sparkles
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Oct. 17 There is nothing else quite so heartwarming as the reaffirmation of talent in a player whose skill has earned him renown for excellence in his chosen occupation.

title: Nuns in South Bronx Shun Fame
description: On a quiet block in the South Bronx, not far from where Pope John Paul II urged the people of the area not to despair, 16 nuns did what they could yesterday to shut themselves off from the world.

title: COMMODITIES
description: A change in the Government's goldsale policy helped deflate gold futures yesterday, while silver turned mixed and copper prices rose after two days of decline.

title: Light Earthquake Hits Los Angeles as Shocks Of First One Continue
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 17 (UPI)  A light earthquake jolted metropolitan Los Angeles today, two days after a bigger tremor that injured more than 60 people in Imperial County, 200 miles away.

title: Advertising
description: SPEAKING about his company's current corporate advertising campaign, Roger B. Smith, executive vice president of the General Motors Corporation, said, What we're saying is that the customer's best friend when it comes to information about our products or our company is not the Government or the consumerists or the environmentalists  it's General Motors.

title: EARNGS
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's largest chemical company, said yesteday that its earnings had climbed 21.2 percent in the third quarter from the level of a year earlier.

title: Carter Signs Measure Creating a Department of Education
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  President Carter today signed legislation creating a new Department of Education at a White House ceremony attended by 200 applauding education officials.

title: Chicago Board Rejects School Desegregation Under U.S. Conditions
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP)  The Chicago school board set the stage for a Federal lawsuit last night when it voted to reject conditions for school desegregation prescribed by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Volcker Asserts U.S. Must Trim Living Standard
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, asserted today that Americans must accept a reduction in their living standards, if inflation is to be reduced.

title: Explosion Is Reported At Offices in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP)  An explosion rocked the Cook County Building in Chicago's Loop just before midnight, the police said. The blast reportedly damaged a bathroom on the fifth floor of the building at 120 North Clark Street. No iniuries were reported.

title: Pirates Capture World Series With 41 Triumph
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 17  Willie Stargell, who is Pops to Pittsburgh's mostfamous family, helped the Pirates win their fifth World Series championship tonieht.

title: Republic National, Bankers Trust Link
description: The Republic New York Corporation said that its Republic National Bank of New York subsidiary had agreed to purchase 12 New York City branch offirs of the Bankers Trust Company.

title: Cleveland Teachers Set to Strike After Rejecting Final Board Offer
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 17 (AP)  Leaders of 5,000 Cleveland teachers rejected wage increase of 6 percent tonight, paving the way for an immediate strike.

title: Pop: Karla Bonoff Sings
description: IN some quarters these days, the mainstream popular music of Southern California isn't considered all that hip. But Karla Bonoff, who was at the Bottom Line Tuesday night, might be either defiant about or oblivious of that fact. From her opening act, Jack Tempchin, through the John David Souther music played during the intermission through her opening trio of songs, recorded either by Linda Ronstadt or Bonnie Raitt, to her own music and band, Miss Bonoff was unabashedly Californian.

title: Troops Guard Pusan After Protest and Riot
description: PUSAN, South Korea, Oct. 18  There were tanks and armored personnel carriers outside the city hall here today, parked in a rainstorm provoked by a typhoon off this southern port city of three million people, the second largest in South Korea.

description: Deaths

title: Pittsburgh Almost Sedate in Its Celebration
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18  Shortly after the Pirates won the World Series last night, police officers in riot gear, reinforced by canine units, moved into Market Square to face more than 3,000 baseball enthusiasts. The box score follows: 120 arrests, 10 dog bites, vandalized street signs, uprooted trees and broken windows.

title: NATO's Deterrent Power Seen at Stake in Missile Debate
description: When Western strategists discuss the deployment of mediumrange nuclear missiles in Europe, they speak of the window, meaning the period of time in which the Soviet Union is likely to enjoy a

title: Peru Termed Ready to Purchase Stockpiled Silver U.S. Might Sell
description: LIMA, Peru, Oct. 18  The president of Peru's central reserve bank said today that the bank stood ready to buy all 15 million ounces of silver that could be released from the United States strategic stockpile under a proposal approved this week by the Senate.

title: The City
description: A Jamaica, Queens, man has been found mentally competent to stand trial on charges of pushing a 17yearold flutist and music student, Renee Katz, in front of an IND subway train last June 7.

title: REBECCA CLARKE
description: Rebecca Clarke, a composer and violist, died Saturday at her home in New York. She was 93 years old.

title: Atlantic City Jobless Rate Is Rising Despite Casinos
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 16  Despite a twoyear construction and casino boom that has provided thousands of jobs, the laborers union hiring hall and unemployment claims office are jammed daily and this city's unemployment rate is back up to about 13 percent.

title: Fed Pushes Bill Rate To 12.02%
description: The Federal Reserve System moved to tighten credit further yesterday, driving the Treasury bill rate to a record 12.02 percent.

title: Patriots and Dolphins In FirstPlace Battle
description: Coming up in pro football is a battle for first place in New England and the appearance of the league champions, the Pittsburgh Steelers, on Monday night against a formidable foe, the Denver Broncos.

title: Art: The Beasts Of Daisy Youngblood
description: PRETTY they aren't, the animal heads that Daisy Youngblood shows at the Willard Gallery, 29 East 72d Street. And they are singularly lacking in the cheerful, anthropomorphic presence that we often associate with animals portrayed in art. The strained, vulnerable. almost mummitied quality of these heads in fired clay suggests nothing so much as the skinned, sacrificial beasts of myth and biblical account.

title: NBC Gives Lester Crystal, ExNews Head, New Post
description: Lester M. Crystal, the recently deposed president of NBC News, has assumed a new post in the organization as senior executive producer of politics and special news programs. In that capacity he will be responsible for all political programming during the 1980 election year and for all specialevents broadcasts.

title: DEATHS
description: BARCLAYWilliam J. On Tuesday Oct 16, 1979. Beloved husband of Madelyn M. Devoted father of Jean Murphy and Robert. Dear grandfather of Ingrid, Paul and Steven Barclay. Reposing at The Gleason Funeral Home 1025 150 St. Whitestone NY. Mass of Christian Burial on Sat Oct 20, St. Luke's RC Church at 9:30 AM. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. Visiting hours 25 and 710 PM.

title: South Africa: Rich Land, Poor People
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 18  The Cherokee Six took off from the Grand Central airfield, which small planes use, and flew northwest over flat farmlands. It is an arid plain with plowed fields stretching away from little patches of green where trees surround the farm buildings. In most of these compounds, a swimming

title: Screen: Al Pacino in '...and Justice for All':Sorts of Breakdowns
description: NORMAN JEWISON'S new comedy about the bitter awakening of an idealistic young Baltimore lawyer, ". . . and Justice for All," pretends to be about the shortcomings in our judicial system, but it's really an extended introduction in how to lose control, have a nervous breakdown, go crazy, commit suicide and perform other antisocial acts.When we first see Arthur Kirkland (Al Pacino), the selfless young lawyer who still believes in the theoretical possibility of justice, he is spending a few hours in the lockup for contempt of court. That afternoon, during a hearing, Arthur had lost his temper and threatened the judge with bodily harm. Clearly Arthur doesn't have a grip on himself. Nor, for that matter, does his friend Judge Rayford (Jack Warden), who is a good jurist but a bad risk. When he's not sitting on the bench, Judge Rayford plays Russian roulette with  among other things  a shotgun because, we are led to believe, a judge's life is such a terrible one. Decisions. Decisions.Then there's Arthur's partner, Jay Porter (Jeffrey Tambor), who, like Arthur, spends his life defending people who are often guilty. Poor Jay once prided himself on winning an acquittal for a man he knew to be guilty of murder. When Jay learns the same man has run right out and disemboweled two small children, he suddenly goes to pieces. First he shaves his head. A few days later, he runs amok in the Criminal Court Building, throwing crockery at the guards, other lawyers, judges, policemen and casual passers-by.With the exception of two old men, one of whom is senile, all of the characters in " . . . and Justice for All" have such low thresholds of emotional distress that I wouldn't trust one of them to see "The Sound of Music" unless accompanied by a parent or adult guardian. They dress sloppily. They talk dirty. Yet they are of an innocence that boggles the mind and sinks the movie.I suspect that Valerie Curtin and Barry Levinson, who wrote the original screenplay, and Mr. Jewison, who directed it, might have conceived " . . . and Justice for All" as what Hollywood rather loosely calls "a black comedy," because it attempts to locate humor in matters that are obviously grotesque. I also imagine there were more than a few references to "Catch-22" and "M*A*S*H" in the course of interminable story conferences. What they've come up with, though, is not a satire, but a demonstration of hysteria that, being hysterical, satirizes nothing, having no direction and no point of view.Everybody in this movie is at his wit's end: Arthur because Judge Fleming (John Forsythe) won't release an innocent prisoner for technical reasons; the innocent prisoner (Thomas Waites) because he has been in prison for almost two years, on a traffic violation, and is getting raped frequently; Judge Fleming because he's psychotyic and has just been charged with the rape of a very young woman; a black transvestite (Robert Christian) because he's being sent to prison for three years on a robbery charge and doesn't want to go, as well as Judge Rayford and Jay Porter for the reasons cited above.Nearly sane are a pretty lawyer (Christine Lahti), though she sleeps with Arthur while sitting on a committee that is investigating Arthur's ethics; Arthur's senile old grandpa (Lee Strasberg), and grandpa's best friend (Sam Levene).The big moral question facing Arthur is whether or not he should defend the rapist-judge. Because the judge has political connections, Arthur is threatened with disbarment if he stands by his principles and refuses. This might be a valid quandary if Arthur weren't such a hyperventillating idiot to start with. In this movie, it's not a moral problem, only one of plot.With the exception of Mr. Strasberg and Mr. Levene, the actors are as hysterical as their material. When the movie opens, Mr. Pacino is behaving as if he were at the end of his rope, which leaves him no place to go except crazy with moral indignation. Miss Lahti is attractive but, along with everyone else, has been directed to play it as if she were in the last act of "Three Men on a Horse."The screenplay has one funny exchange. When Arthur is called before the ethics committee, he asks why they have to use microphones when there are only five people in a small room. "Well," one of the inquisitors says, "this is a hearing."Other than that, the screenplay and the direction are a complete muddle. If you follow what seems to be the film's feeble point to its logical end, it is that our judicial system is rotten not only because of the people who administer it, but also because it provides safeguards for the accused. The next step, one should think, is a nice, predictable law-and-order state.I can't be sure, however. " . . . and Justice for All," which opens today at Loews Tower East and other theaters, is in the throes of a nervous breakdown from beginning to end.

title: Publishing: ExChildren Unite to Aid Libraries
description: ONE evening in the fall of 1977, the members of the Children's Writers and Artist Collaborative, a New Yorkbased group designed for mutual selfhelp, found themselves talking about what was happening to the children's reading rooms in the branches of the moneystarved New York Public Library. They noted that in some branches, hours were being curtailed; others were closing these rooms altogether.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  In a continuing dispute with the United States Postal Service over electronic mail, a Federal Communications Commission bureau has denied the agency permission to beam messages across the Atlantic.

title: By and About Elytis
description: Following is a list of books in English by and about Odysseus Elytis:

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: 40% in Survey Say Inflation Is Major Issue for 1980 Race
description: Kathy Paulo of Fremont, Calif., would like to be able to afford some meat, instead of just more potatoes, in a stew. A widowed Rochester shipping clerk worries that we'll all be living by candlelight because of high electricity rates. Arthur K. Barnum of Lewiston, N.Y., wants a President who does something about inflation, even if he does it wrong.

title: U.S.Pakistan Talks Inconclusive
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  The United States and Pakistan ended two days of intensive highlevel discussions yesterday without resolving serious differences about the Pakistani nuclear program, which, Washington fears, may include the development of nuclear weapons.

title: 3 Downstate Counties Discuss Ways to Seek Lower Electrical Costs
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 18 Representatives of the legislative branches of Westchester, Nassau and Orange Counties met here today to consider forming a bipartisan group to seek lower electricity rates for the populous downstate region.

title: GUERRILLAS ACCEPT RHODESIAN CHARTER PROPOSED BY BRITISH
description: LONDON, Oct. 18  The Patriotic Front accepted Britain's proposals for a new Zimbabwe Rhodesia constitution today, and Britain responded by indicating that the guerrilla alliance could resume its role in the threesided negotiations tomorrow.

title: O'Neill Asks Speed on Fuel Help
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. took issue with the White House today and pleaded for a prompt Congressional appropriation of $1.35 billion to help the poor and elderly pay rapidly rising home heatinn bills.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  The Appellate Division of New Jersey Superior Court yesterday rejected arguments that police officers had blanket immunity from being sued for negligent acts and upheld a $75,000 judgment against two state troopers who refused to assist group of stranded motorists on Interstate 80 in 1974. Two of the group were struck and killed by passing cars.

title: Elytis, Greek Lyric Poet, Is Given The Nobel Award for Literature
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 18  The 1979 Nobel Prize for Literature was awarded here today to Odysseus Elytis, a 68yearold Greek poet noted for lyric and often mythical evocations of his native land.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: A Lyric, Poetic Greek Voice That Has a Special Texture
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 18  Odys- seus Elytis, born in 1911, was the young- est of the group of preWorld War II poets, sometimes called the Generation of the 30's, who established the new voice and new sensibility that still dominate

title: U.S. Starts an Appeal to Overturn Judge's Ruling on the Taiwan Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  The Justice Department began an effort today to overturn a ruling by a United States District judge that President Carter could not end the Mutual Defense Treaty with Taiwan without the consent of Congress.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Kennedy Speeds Campaign Table Fora U.S. Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  Senator Edward M. Kennedy has speeded up the timetable for setting up his national campaign committee, now set to be announced about Oct. 25, partly because of frustration over organizational problems a the Draft Kennedy movement in Florida.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Dividends
description: x  accrox $046 to be paid in January 1980.

title: At Paris Showings, Both Creativity and Confusion
description: PARIS, Oct. 17  This week's showings of readytowear spring and summer fashions left everybody reeling from exhaustion. They also demonstrated certain truths that had nothing to do with the revival of the miniskirt.

title: EARNINGS Goodyear Posts Loss; Goodrich Little Changed
description: Two of the nation's major tire makers issued thirdquarter results yesterday, with one reporting earnings virtually the same as the comparable yearago quarter and the other reporting a loss.

title: BUSINESS  Digest
description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1979

title: Black Capitalism Still on Trial
description: It was the Nixon Administration that decided decade ago to soothe angry blacks in riottorn cities by promoting black capitalism. The idea was to help minorityowned businesses gain a larger share of Government work by awarding some contracts without the normal competitive bidding. It therefore created the Section 8(a) program, setting aside Government contracts for entrepreneurs who are deemed disadvantaged. So much for theory.

title: Boomerang Fling Set for Old Westbury
description: Close to 30 boomerang throwers from the Eastern Seaboard will compete tomorrow at 1 P.M. in Old Westbury, L.I. The contest, which is sponsored by the American Boomerang Association, will feature events in throwing, catching and juggling and attempts will be made to break a world record of 115 yards for a throw. As in Australia, boomerang competition in America stresses accuracy and distance as Well as showmanship.

title: New Junta in El Salvador Says It Will Recognize Cuba
description: SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 18  El Salvador's new armybacked junta made an open bid for popular support today by announcing plans to recognize the Cuban Government and to investigate the whereabouts of more than 400 persons who have disappeared.

title: Women Gather To Hear Nuclear Power Promoted
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  Dr. Estelle Ramey said she didn't have any special case to make for nuclear energy. She didn't care where the energy came from, she said, but she knew that women needed it to continue to be liberated. If that meant nuclear energy, then so be it.

title: Fans Honor Orioles As if They Had Won
description: BALTIMORE, Oct, 18  The sun came up here, as hoped, at 7:19 on the morning after. The victory parade started, as planned, shortly after 11:30. Earl Weaver, the manager of the Baltimore Orioles, reminded everyone that his team had won more games than any other team in baseball this season. And for a little while, thousands of people chose not to remember that the Orioles had lost the last one.

title: Continental Stock Plan
description: The Continental Corporation, an insurance holdingcompany, said yesterday that it planned to purchase up to three million of its common shares over a period of time in the open market and in negotiated transactions.

title: First Boston Net Off 9% for Quarter
description: First Boston Inc., the investmentbanking and brokerage firm, said yesterday that its net earnings for the third quarter were $3.1 million, down 9 percent from $3.4 million earned in the third quarter of 1978, while its revenues for the quarter rose 8 percent to $30.5 million, from $28.3 million in the comparable veriod a year ago.

title: Suit Ends In Favor Of I.B.M.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18 (AP)  A Federal judge ruled today that the International Business Machines Corporation did not violate antitrust laws in the computer equipment field, as had been charged by the Transamerica Computer Corporation in a sixyearold multimilliondollar suit.

title: W. H. Luers Weds Wendy Turnbull
description: William Henry Luers, Ambassador to Venezuela, was married in San Francisco yesterday to Wendy Woods Turnbull, who is with Amnesty International, U.S.A. Judge Robert Drewes of Superior Court performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: Iraq Oil Prices Raised by 10%
description: The latest round of oil price increases by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries continued yesterday as Iraq raised its prices by about 10 percent.

title: Auctions
description: WILL The Icebergs, Frederic Edwin Church's longlost painting, shatter the $980,000 auction record for American painting when it comes up for sale Thursday morning at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street? Sotheby's hopes it will. The glowing study that the 19thcentury landscape artist painted after sketching icebergs off the coasts of Newfoundland and Labrador was first exhibited in New York in April 1861 to wide acclaim. The New York Times described it as the most splendid work of art that has yet been produced in this country.. . thoroughly original in conception and execution... It is an absolutely wonderful picture, a work of genius that illustrates the time and the country producing it.

title: Twins' Koosman Signs for 3 Years
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 18 (AP)  Jerry Koosman, who made his American League debut last season by winning 20 games, signed a threeyear contract with the Minnesota Twins today. The financial terms were not disclosed.

title: On City Island, Development Is a Bride Many Residents Won't Cross
description: For City Islanders, there is a geography of the map and a geography of the mind, and no bridge can ever connect the two.

title: Pope John Paul II: His First Year
description: TUBINGEN, West Germany  Twelve months are a short time. Yet for such an encouragingly energetic and tirelessly active Pope as John Paul II so many speeches, so many trips months are a long time. There is no significant issue on which has not already taken a definite stand. After just one year, the contours of this pontificate stand out in bold and unmistakable relief. The intense activity of the Pope in Rome and, above all, his triumphal trips to Mexico, Poland, Ireland and the United States, have presented him to world public opinion as an impressive champion of peace, of human rights, of social justice, and also of strong church, as a man who knows how to satisfy the desire of the masses for a morally trustworthy leader  a rarity in today's world  in a manner both impressive and highly skillful from the publicrelations standpoint.

title: Federal Agency Approves Grants For City Region
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  The Department of Housing and Urban Development has approved several urban redevelopment grants for the New York metropolitan area that will be announced tomorrow by President Carter on the second anniversary of the program.

title: Backward March in Pakistan
description: All the while protesting his strong commitment democracy, Gen. Mohammed Zia ulHaq is making Pakistan more and more undemocratic. The military president has canceled elections, for the second time since he seized power two years ago. And he has now tightened the grip of martial law in unprecedented ways.

title: Group Makes Bid For MG Operation
description: A consortium led by AstonMartin Lagonda Inc. yesterday made a $64.5 million bid for the MG car operation now owned by financially troubled BL Ltd. AstonMartin is proposing to take over both the company's Abingdon, Oxfordshire, plant and the MG name.

title: Mondale in City for Smith Dinner
description: Vice President Mondale touched base with two major religious groups yesterday in New York City. He gave the major address at the annual Alfred E. Smith memorial dinner, attended mostly by Roman Cgitholics, and he met privately with Jewish leaders from New York and New Jersey.

title: Pierre Bernac, 80, Baritone And Poulenc Partner, Dies
description: Pierre Bernac, a French baritone and teacher of artsong interpretation, died Wednesday in a hospital in VilleneuvelesAvignon, in southern France, following a series of heart attacks over the last several months. He was 80 years old.

title: Bush, in Manhattan, Describes the P.L.O. As Similar to the Klan
description: Comparing the Palestine Liberation Organization to an international Ku Klux Klan, George Bush, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination who visited New York City yesterday, focused on Israel, a potent subject in New York politics and now in the forefront of the Republican campaign.

title: Art: Treasury of Moderns at Janis Gallery
description: YOU don't have to be an old man with a long white beard to remember when some of the best free education in New York City was to be had at the Sidney Janis Gallery, 6 West 57th Street, when Mr. Janis mounted one of his periodical anthologies of major achievement in modern art.

title: Restaurants
description: WE have often been asked by readers if we have ever been tempted to keep a restaurant find to ourselves, preferring to reserve it as a hideaway rather than to go public with our disovery. The answer has always been no, but the biggest temptation to date Hakubai, a quiet, orderly and engaging restaurant the Kitano Hotel on Park Avenue and 38th Street. This hotel caters to Japanese guests, and its small dining rooms, with their beautiful appointments, are geared to the same clientele, offering simple, wellprepared, authentic Japanese fare, gracefully served by waitresses clad in kimono and obi.

title: ITALY'S COMMUNISTS ASK ATOM ARMS TALK
description: ROME, Oct. 18  The Italian Communist Party, issuing a cautiously worded statement today, proposed a conference between NATO and the Warsaw Pact as way to get around an American request for introducing new nuclear missiles into Europe.

title: TV Weekend Marciano's Story Joins Live 'sportsworld Bout
description: APPARENTLY by chance, boxing is being highlighted in both sports and entertainment. Tomorrow afternoon at 4 NBC's Sportsworld is carrying live from Pretoria the scheduled 15round bout between the black American John Tate and the white South African Gerrie Coetzee. The winner will officially succeed Muhammad Ali as heavyweight champion.

title: Art: William Wilkins, Miniaturist of Light
description: THE English painter William Wilkins had his first solo exhibition in New York only two years ago, and he was at once recognized as an artist of a certain distinction  small in scale, perhaps, but exquisite in sensibility. His subjects were then landscapes and figures, which he painted in a highly refined style that owed much to Seurat. To paint in this somewhat modified Pointillist manner represented a considerable challenge, of course, but Mr. Wilkins proved to have the requisite gifts.

title: SOME OPEC NATIONS MAY NEED TO LOWER OUTPUT, CARTER SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  President Carter took a conciliatory stance toward the major oilexporting nations today, saying that he believed their production was at maximum levels and that it was in the national selfinterest of some countries to stop overproduction.

title: Pick Your Own Pumpkin
description: Cold weather is unwelcome by most farmers, but to Deane Lewin, who with his brother Ernest, operates Lewin Farms in Wading River, L. I., the recent drop in temperature only enhanced the beauty of his pumpkin fields. The pumpkins didn't suffer they're so hardshelled, he said. It killed off the green vines and for miles you see only brilliant orange mounds.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Advertising
description: ON a recent trip in the Orient, Miles David picked up 5,000 radios in Hong Kong. Even fox the president of the Radio Advertising Bureau, that seems a bit excessive. But they are very special radios, made as they are of bright red plastic in the form of the word RADIO, with the works and speaker inside the O and an aerial attached to the R.

title: Stage: Reunion, 3 Mamet Plays
description: IN David Mamet's Reunion, a father and a daughter meet after a separation of 20 years. Each has abandoned the other. What now draws them together is loneliness. They have become older, their lives more barren. Finding her marriage unfulfilling, the young woman (Lindsay Crouse) looks back to daughterhood for consolation. This tenderly evocative play, the principal piece in an evening of three Mamet oneact plays that opened last night at the Circle Repertory Company, is a playwright's reflection on the renewal of faith.

title: Economic Scene
description: PESIDENT CARTER has given his support to the moneytightening actions of the Federal Reserve Board with a firm statement: Whatever it takes to control inflation, that's what I will do. And he has followed this with an equally firm

title: Stocks Edge Higher, Led by Oil Issues
description: Stock prices continued to edge higher yesterday, with oil issues were once again the strongest sector of the market.

title: About Real Estate Rental Housing Facing Serious Financial Problems Again
description: Forget all the rhetoric! Here are the brutal facts.

title: Carey Asks Bills To Help Monitor Oil Heat Market
description: Governor Carey called yesterday for closer monitoring of the heating oil market, backed by tighter restrictions against price gouging.

title: Sharon Buys Stock In City Investing
description: The Sharon Steel Corporation said it had increased its holding in the City In. vesting Company to 1.6 million shares, or about 7.1 percent of the common shares outstanding .

title: Car of a Fiat Foreman Set on Fire In 2d Burning Over 61 Dismissals
description: TURIN, Italy, Oct. 18 (Reuters)  A Fiat foreman's car was set on fire outside his home today in what a telephone caller said was part of a campaign against the automobile company's dismissal of 61 workers. The car of another Fiat foreman was set afire yesterday.

title: New Bankruptcy Law: Creditors, Debtors Aided
description: The first complete overhaul of bankruptcy statutes in threequarters of century took effect earlier this month, and although it is too soon to tell precisely what its impact will be, the law appears to help corporate creditors as well as consumer debtors.

title: A Secular Saint
description: How typical of Mother Teresa of Calcutta that she should remark, I am unworthy when told she had just won the Nobel Peace Prize. Her comment was not a casual expression of blushing modesty, only a restatement of her lifelong conviction that helping the helpless  indeed, helping those beyond help  is the simple duty of us all.

title: Leader of a Heroin Ring and Five Found Guilty of Drug Possession
description: Leroy Butler, accused by Federal narcotics agents of having headed a major heroin ring, and five other men were found guilty yesterday of charges that could bring each of them up to 15 years in prison.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: PRACTICE FOR REMOVAL OF NERVE GAS: Technlclans at the Duprey Proving Grounds in Utah handling a dummy nerve gas shell in a practice exercise for removal of hundreds of pounds of deadly chemicals that had been stored there over the years. After 8,980 sheep died in 1968, the Army revealed that chemical and biological warfare testing had been conducted at the proving grounds for years. In 1878, charges were made that wild horses in the area died as a result of leaking chemicals from the facility. A cleanup of dangerous chemicals in now under way.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Telephone and Telegragh Company has elected Howard J. Trienens vice president and general counsel.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, Oct. 18,1979

title: CREDIT MARKETS Prices Slide to WeekAgo Lows
description: Prices in the credit markets yesterday fell to the lows they reached a week ago, and Treasury bill rates topped 12 percent for the first time.

title: 10 Miners Feared Dead in Spain
description: CABOALLES DE ABAJO, Spain, Oct. 18 (Reuters) Four miners died and six were feared dead after an explosion in coal mine in this northwestern Spanish village, police sources said today. Four bodies were recovered after the blast last night. Rescuers who worked through the night said there was little hope of finding the other six alive.

title: Books of The Times
description: HENRY JAMES called her a perfect Voltaire in petticoats. Henry Adams, who seems to have had a lower opinion, nevertheless married her when she was 29 years old, and then didn't bother to mention her at all in his autobiography, The Education of Henry Adams. Perhaps she had em barrassed and confused him by drinking, after 13 years of what appeared to their friends an idyllic marriage, a bottle of potassium cyanide. Perhaps he felt he had already mentioned her too much. Wasn't she Esther in his novel Esther? Couldn't she have been Madeleine Lee in his novel Democracy? Mightn't she even have been Verena in Henry James's The Bostonians? Clover must have...

title: Deaths
description: FRIEDMANLaura, beloved mother of Natalie Auerbach, Dorothy Appleby, Harry, Minnaq Melssner, Charles and Evelyn, adored grandmother of eleven and greatgrandmother of ten. Services Friday 12 noon, Schwartz Brothers, Forest Park Chapels', Queens Blvd. and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Units Set for Massing of Colors
description: Representatives from the armed forces and patriotic organizations from the metropolitan area will join at 2 P.M. on Sunday for the 58th annual parade and massing of the colors, sponsored by the New York chapter of the Military Order of the World Wars.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: George J. Arnold, 53 years old, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation, effective Nov. 1. He will succeed Dennis J. Carney, 58, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Weight Gain in Pregnancy: A More Tolerant Approach
description: In her sixth month of pregnancy, Janine Ricozzi, a 28 yearold Westchester County woman, began to develop swot len ankles, a condition that is very common among pregnant women. Her doctor, who had previously ordered her to re strict her weight gain, gave her further instructions familial to millions of American women: restrict salt intake and talc( a diuretic, a drug that causes the body to excrete fluid.

title: Abraham Bloch, 85, Retired Judge
description: Abraham M. Bloch, the last chief magistrate before a state law in 1962 reorganized the New York City court structure, died Wednesday at his Manhattan home. He was 85 years old.

title: 6 NEW UHF STATIONS IN JERSEY APPROVED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  The Federal Communications Commission sought today to meet New Jersey's demands for more television service by authorizing six new UHF stations to add to the state's existing 10, with possible network affiliation for the new ones.

title: Schumer Says Police Give a Low Priority To Protection of Buses
description: Assaults and robberies on New York City buses have increased sharply this year, especially in outlying residential areas where bands of youths strike at will, because the city police and the transit police have given low priority to bus protection, a Brooklyn Assemblyman charged yesterday.

title: Dance: Ballet Hispanico
description: BALLET Hispdnico of New York is one of the city's most handsome and vibrant small dance companies. Its dances reflect the special mixture of cultures that is the SpanishAmerican's heritage. On Wednesday, however, Ballet Hispanic opened a fourperformance run at the Dance Umbrella festival at Camera Mart /Stage One with dances that gave a somewhat limited view of the company and its aims.

title: Italian Filling Stations Are Shut In a Strike for Increased Profits
description: MILAN, Italy, Oct. 18 (AP)  Gasoline station owners shut down throughout Italy today in a strike for larger profits.

title: Soul: Ashford & Simpson
description: ASHFORD AND SIMPSON seem to have been as pleased with their weeklong run on Broadway last year as their fans were. They are presenting a series of similar shows this week at the City Center55th Street Theater, between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, and with the same opening act, Noel Pointer. But because their shows are primarily reflections of what they've been up to lately rather than recapitulations of their greatest hits, this year's model is different in one significant respect.

title: Brown Pledges U.S. Will Not Force South Korea to Ease Repression
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Oct. 19  Secretary of Defense Harold Brown made clear today that the Carter Administration would not use American security commitments here to force the South Korean Government to ease its nolitical repression.

title: County Embracing Detroit Unable to Meet Payroll
description: DETROIT, Oct. 18  Wayne County, the nation's thirdlargest, after several months of limping along millions of dollars in debt, has run out of cash and will not be able to meet tomorrow's payroll.

title: Notes on People
description: They weren't exactly close to begin with, so there was no great amount of love to be lost in a family tiff between Everett Raymond Kinstler, the artist, and William M. Kunstler, the lawyer.

title: Money
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 18, 1979

title: White House Using Grants To Woo States in Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  After more than two years of reticence, the Carter Administration is boldly working the politics of incumbency this fall by directing Federal aid to its political allies and timing aid announcements for maximum political impact on states involved in the early staves of the 1980 campaign.

title: Rehnquist Denies Stay for Killer
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI)  Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist denied a stay of execution today for a convicted killer, Jesse Bishop, who is scheduled to die in Nevada's gas chamber on Monday.

title: President of Consumers Union Is Retiring After 43 Years
description: Kellogg's Corn Flakes was 7 cents a box and Ivory soap 9 cents a bar in May 1936 when a new magazine headed by a 35yearold economics professor set about methodically testing these and myriad other everyday products for the technical guidance of the country's hardpressed consumers.

title: Black Demonstrators Peacefully Take Over Urban League Office
description: Twenty black demonstrators took over the executive offices of the National Urban League yesterday to protest criticism that the league president, Vernon E. Jordan Jr., had made about American blacks who approached the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: MILTON G. WHITE, 69, PHYSICS PROFESSOR
description: Milton Grandison White, Eugene Higgins Professor of Physics Emeritus at Princeton University, suffered a heart attack Tuesday during a tennis match and was pronounced dead at Princeton Medical Center. He was 69 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Spectator's Guide to Sunday's Marathon, the Biggest of Them All
description: They will arrive by the thousands from 45 states and 40 foreign countries, lured by the prospect of trying to complete 26 miles and 385 yards in the New York City Marathon. Many in the field of 14,000 have run previous marathons, including the fiveborough trek from the VerrazanoNarrows Bridge to the Tavern on the Green in Central Park. But for more than 4,600 runners, including 919 women, Sunday's race will be their first marathon experience and their supreme test.

title: Racial Strife Disrupts Boston High Schools for 3d Day
description: BOSTON, Oct. 18  Protests and scattered fighting between black and white students embroiled several Boston high schools for the third day today as school administrators met with students in a search for a way to end the latest racial tension.

title: An Elytis Sampler
description: The Autopsy

title: C. Richard Soderberg, Turbine Engine Pioneer
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 18 (AP) C. Richard Soderberg, a pioneer developer of the turbine engine, died of cancer yesterday at his home. He was 83 years old.

title: Broadway
description: EDWARD ALBEE'S The Lady From Dubuque will open at the Morosco Theater the week of Jan. 21. Besides Irene Worth, it will have in its cast Swoosie Kurtz, Earle Hyman, Maureen Anderman and David Leary, and will be directed by Alan Schneider. Richard Barr and Lester Osterman will produce. Mr. Albee began thinking about this play at least as early as 1961, when he mentioned it to Mr. Barr and when he was thinking of calling it The Substitute Speaker. It now, he says, a perfectly straightforward play about reality, just as Tiny Alice was a perfectly straightforward play and just as Virginia Woolf was, too. In other words, Mr. Albee would rather not tell you what The Lady From Dubuque is about. is possible he is not exactly sure himself.

title: Deaths
description: CASNERStanley on October 17, 1979. Funeral arrangements private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Stanley Casner Memorial Fund Lukemla Society of America, 215 Lexington Ave, NYC 10016.

title: MISSILE BID TO DUTCH IS DENIED BY BONN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  The West German Government has informed the Carter Administration that the support of the Netherlands for stationing new American mediumrange missiles on Dutch soil is not a prerequisite for a decision by Bonn to allow the rockets on its territory, Government officials said today.

title: 85 'sweatshops Accused by U.S. On Work Rules
description: Eightyfive actions charging sweatshop conditions in garment factories in the Chinatown area of Manhattan have been filed by the United States Labor Department.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 18 (Reuters)  Vietnam accused the United States, Thailand and China today of trying to bolster Cambodian guerrillas under the pretext of sending famine aid.

title: Business and the Law
description: LONDON

title: Screen: 'Head Over Heels,' Drama, Opens:Bachelor in Love
description: "HEAD OVER HEELS," Joan Micklin Silver's screen adaptation of Ann Beattie's novel "Chilly Scenes of Winter," is a tantalizing movie, seeming to be on the verge of some revelation of profound feeling that, at long last, never comes.By the time we reach the end, we realize that everything we were to learn about its characters we knew in the first 20 minutes. After that, they continue to talk a great deal, laugh a lot and change their minds noisily, but they grow dimmer and dimmer until they've all but disappeared, though the actors remain. As George S. Kaufman once said on meeting a friend who was supposed to have left town, "Forgotten but not gone."One possible problem is Mrs. Silver's fidelity to the scope of the novel and even to her dialogue, which might read better than it plays. Such fidelity appears to prevent the movie from developing any style or momentum of its own. There's also something wrong when we're well into a movie before we know where it's taking place. Are those tall buildings in New York? No. There's a lot of snow around, so it might be Minneapolis. No again. We look for landmarks and wonder. There's a reference to someone's working for the state of Utah, but the reference goes by so quickly we think the job could be in a New York public-relations firm. It isn't. The setting really is Salt Lake City, but we've wasted a lot of time that could have been better spent elsewhere.The principal characters are a bachelor named Charles (John Heard), who has a boring job as a "reports analyst" for Utah, and Laura (Mary Beth Hurt), the young woman he falls in love with while she's temporarily separated from her husband.Charles worships Laura. He tells her she's more beautiful than a movie star and a better cook than a professional chef, which makes Laura angry because she feels inadequate. Laura is the sort of woman who is more at ease with a husband who doesn't appreciate her enough than she does with Charles, who appreciates her too much.When Laura returns to her husband and to the stepdaughter she adores, Charles becomes obsessed with getting her back. He begins to behave strangely. He builds a dollhouse replica of her A-frame house and staffs it with little figures representing Laura, her husband and the child. At night he parks outside the A-frame and waits until all the lights go off.For a while it seems as if Charles might be certifiably nuts. After all, his mother (Gloria Grahame) is the sort of neurotic who sits, fully clothed, in a bathtub full of water and threatens to commit suicide. His grandfather did commit suicide. "He went out in the morning for grouse," Charles says laconically. "In the afternoon he went out for himself."Such details  novelistic details  keep us hooked to the film. There must be more to Charles and Laura than the two rather average, slightly mixedup people we see on the screen. The movie goes on, through one mild crisis after another but Charles and Laura become tiresome instead of more interesting. It's not because of the performances. Mr. Heard and Miss Hurt ("Interiors") are two of our best young actors, but the material is either thin and unfocused or rich but beside the point. The most appealing characters in the movie, though seen only briefly, are Charles's mother and the stepfather (Kenneth McMillan) who attempts to protect her unreliable sanity.Mrs. Silver tries to cover a lot of ground by having much of the movie unfold in chronological flashbacks, with Charles talking to us directly, but the past is so much like the present you forget where you are. One begins to dread Charles's confidential asides to the audience, knowing that we are again going back in time when all we want to do is get on with it. Further, there is a recurring gag with a blind news dealer that is progressively oppressive, not because it's in bad taste but because it is what the entire movie eventually becomes  mercilessly arch.Even so, there's not a false performance in the film. Miss Grahame and Mr. McMillan are especially fine, but there are other noteworthy contributions by Peter Riegert, Nora Heflin, Tarah Hunter and Griffin Dunne (one of the film's producers), who's very funny as the sort of fellow who, when asked if he'd like a glass of milk, totes up the amount of calcium he's already consumed that day.The film opens today at the Trans-Lux East."Head Over Heels," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some slightly vulgar dialogue.

title: Three Shows Celebrate Old New York
description: BURIED in the heart of every dedicated New Yorker is a fascination with some aspect or other of city history. Did Lincoln really sleep in that nowdilapidated hotel on Chambers Street? Did Melville gaze out over this same riverscape? Was this the path Lily Bart took up Fifth Avenue on that last, bedraggled trip in Edith Wharton's House of Mirth? Or did Jim Fisk grind out his big cigar at this very corner on Elk Street? The city will be celebrated this weekend with three very different shows that explore old crannies and shed light upon some newer ones.

title: Deaths
description: McTIGUE, Mary BarrettOn October 15, 1979. Wife of the late John B. McTigue. Sister inlaw of Andrew C. and Madeleine McTigue. Funeral Mass Church of St. Thomas More, 65 E. 89 St., Friday 10AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to St. Joachim's Church, Cedarhurst, L.I. NY 11516

title: Market Place
description: TIGHT money and doubts about the determination of the Imperial Group Ltd. to acquire Howard Johnson have contributed to the decline Howard Johnson's shares from the high levels reached after it and Imperial disclosed their merger plans in midSentember.

title: F.C.C. Lifts Rules on Antennas In Bid to Spur Satellite Service
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  The Federal Communications Commission, in a move to encourage expansion of satellite service, voted today to lift its costly and timeconsuming regulatory requirements over antenna dishes for receiving signals.

title: Politics as a Tool in a HealthCare Dispute
description: Having failed thus far to get the Federal Government to save the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn, state officials said yesterday that Governor Carey was determined to have President Carter take the blame if the state's latest proposal to rescue were rejected by Washington and the hospital closed next week.

title: Inquiry Reported Into New Theory On 'son of Sam
description: The Queens District Attorney has reportedly assigned at least two assistants and a number of detectives to look into the possibility that David R. Berkowitz, the socalled Son of Sam murderer, might have had an accomplice when he killed some of his victims.

title: Irish Premier to See Carter
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 18 (Reuters)Prime Minister Jack Lynch of Ireland will make an official visit to the United States Nov. 715 at President Carter's invitation, the White House announced today. The President and the Prime Minister will confer on the eighth.

title: Events and Openings
description: AND JUSTICE FOR ALL..., directed by Norman Jewison; starring Al Padno, at the Laws Tower East, Loews State I I and other theaters.

title: Dr. Henry L. Wen, 62, Manager Of Technology at the Singer Co.
description: Dr. Henry L. Wen, manager of advanced technology for the Singer Company, died Monday at his home in Hackensack, N.J. He was 62 years old.

title: Problem of Campaign Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  Money, has been said, is the mother's milk of politics. Why, then, did the House of Representatives vote yesterday to limit the campaign cash that Congressmen can receive from special interests?

title: Stage: HeighHo, Heigh Ho for Snow White
description: SNOW WHITE and the Seven Dwarfs is a spectacle, and is inspired as much by the circus or maybe the Oberammergau Passion Play as it is by Walt Disney's old celluloid charmer. It is supposed to be family entertainment, and it is, although the youngest members of the family will love it best of all. It opened at Radio City Musical Hall last night.

title: Dr. Joseph Willits, 90; A SocialFiancial Expert
description: Dr. Joseph A. Willits, a former director of the social services division for the Rockefeller Foundation, died Tuesday at his summer home in Jackson, N. H. He was 90 years old and lived in Langford, Pa.

title: Routine Is Happily Shattered
description: ATHENS, Oct. 18  Odysseus Elytis is known both as the sundrinking poet, for writing heavily on themes of sun and light, and as the owl, for working only at night and sleeping during the day.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1979

title: Times of London Given a Reprieve Of 72 Hours After Frantic Sessions
description: LONDON, Oct. 18  A day of frantic negotiations has produced a 72hour reprieve for two of the world's most influential newspapers, The Times of London and The Sunday Times, despite a previous management pledge to close them permanently today.

title: IN THE NATION Hope And Threat In Africa
description: The Government's highest ranking Soviet expert, Marshall D. Shulman, has told a House foreign affairs subcommittee that the most serious potential problem between the United States and the Soviet Union was the possibility of escalating war in Southern Africa.

title: Screen: 'Meteor,' a Disaster Tale, Opens:Menace From the Blue
description: "OUTER space  limitless and timeless  an infinite playground for that occasional blazing visitor, the comet," says a somber narrator at the beginning of "Meteor." This is a fine warm-up to a movie in which the terrible, hurtling menace of the title looks like a big hunk of week-old bread. The earth can be saved only through the diplomatic efforts of Henry Fonda, who plays the President, and Karl Malden, still wearing his "What will you do?" hat. Together, they negotiate with the Russians, who say things like "the Volga is about to overflow its banks, and we are discussing swimming lessons!" They also send over their ace interpreter and trouble-shooter, Natalie Wood.In a heartwarming gesture of cooperation, the Soviet and American Governments agree to reposition the missiles that each nation had previously aimed at the other (theirs is called Peter the Great), and instead blow the meteor to smithereens. The director, Ronald Neame  also responsible for "The Poseidon Adventure"  accompanies each Big Bad Missile shot with theme music that sounds a bit like "She'll Be Comin' Round the Mountain When She Comes." This, plus the fact that the missiles look like undernourished bowling pins, makes them considerably less formidable than they might have been.Mr. Neame's specialty is, of course, the underwater scene, and he doesn't come into his own  in this film that opened today at the Loews Astor Plaza and other theaters  until Manhattan has been squashed and the survivors, huddling in a subway, are bathed in ugly brown-green muck. Before that, he devotes too much attention to lifeless shots of computers and arguments between National Aeronautics and Space Administration officials and military personnel, who bellow at the tops of their lungs. There are also occasional glimpses of monitors saying things like "Time to impact  Days: 2." These signs don't inspire confidence in the scientific talent that has been brought in on the case.The chief American scientist is played by Sean Connery, who, of course, sounds like a Scotsman. And Miss Wood, who is accompanying a Soviet bigwig played by Brian Keith, seems to have resurrected her "West Side Story" Spanish. If only love had a chance to bloom between these two, perhaps the movie would have a bit of momentum. As it is, the suspense is sludgy and the character development nil; even the inadvertent comedy is spotty. The spectacle of Manhattan's demolition is interesting enough, but there's a lot of time-killing before the city actually goes up in flames.Actors in movies like "Meteor," which is standard disaster fare, don't give real performances  they just do time. Miss Wood and Mr. Connery are pleasant but unremarkable, much less riveting than Martin Landau, who seems absolutely unhinged as the general who does all the hollering. Mr. Keith is genial and funny in a role that involves no English dialogue, except for one rude remark about the Dodgers. Mr. Fonda has played the President so often he ought to run."Meteor" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It includes several episodes of violent catastrophe, and one close-up of a corpse that might frighten children.

title: HUA IS IN BRITTANY ON INDUSTRIAL TOUR
description: RENNES, France, Oct. 18  After A warning that we cannot let Vietnam do in Indochina what Cuba did in Africa, Prime Minister Hua Guofeng of China and his suite flew to this Breton center today to inspect the latest French technology in industry and agriculture.

title: U.S. Set to Sue Chicago To Integrate the Schools
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP)  The Government took the first step today toward what could become a long and bitter battle over school busing, serving notice on Chicago that it would sue to force an end to alleged widespread school segregation.

title: Alvin Ailey Gets New Headquarters
description: With the cutting of a long red ribbon yesterday by such citizens of the Great White Way as Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert Organization, Jerome Minskoff, theater owner, and the Broadway stars Ann Reinking and Sandy Duncan, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Center officially opened the doors to its new, theater district headquarters in the Minskoff Building, on Broadway between 49th and 45th Streets.

title: New Face: Tony Beckley
description: I DO tend to get these rather quirky, offbeat people to play, says Tony Beckley. But he doesn't quite know why. I would be surprised if you could see anything psychotic in my behavior, he added.

title: Lakers' Johnson To Miss 10 Days
description: Earvin (Magic) Johnson of the Los Angeles Lakers is expected to be sidelined only 10 days with a knee injury he incurred in Wednesday night's game against the SuperSonics in Seattle. It had been thought that the injury was more serious and that he would be out at least six weeks.

title: Windfall Landfall
description: When it comes to important domestic legislation, Washington has for years had its very own Bermuda Triangle, the Senate Finance Committee. Fleets of bills dealing with welfare, social security and, more recently, energy have gone there only to disappear. In 1977, for instance, the President sent in the crude oil equalization tax, the flagship of his original energy program. All that could be found was an oil slick. This year, Admiral Carter tenaciously sent in a proposed Windfall Profits Tax, on which his 1979 energy program is based. For a while, that vessel, too, seemed to disappear. The Finance Committee had quickly gone to work devising new tax credits that would have given away billions more than the new windfall tax could bring in.

title: Next Pirate Goal Is to Stay on Top
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates, stressing that it was all in the family, have become baseball's new champions, but that does not prove that a team has to pray together to play together.

title: Bridge:
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 18  The United States team led the Italian team in the finals of the world championship at midpoint this evening after losing lead it had established in an astonishinu set of 16 deals in the afternoon.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Oct. 18 (AP) Clarence Tillman, a former basketball star at West Philadelphia High School who withdrew from the University of Kentucky last week, has announced that he will attend Rutgers University.

title: Mattick Named Blue Jays Pilot
description: TORONTO, Oct. 18 (AP)  Instead of looking for a bigname manager, the Toronto Blue Jays have hired a man who has signed and developed several stars in a career as a baseball scout and olaverdevelopment executive.

title: Jury Chosen in VoteBuying Trial
description: LAKE CHARLES, La., Oct. 18 (UPI) A jury of eight men and four women was chosen today in the conspiracy and votebuying trial of Representative Claude (Buddy) Leach, Democrat of Louisiana. Mr. Leach defeated Jimmy Wilson, a Republican, by 266 votes in the November general election, but investigators said they uncovered evidence that more than 900 votes were bought.

title: Loews Shift Hinted on Woolworth
description: The Loews Corporation, which announced last June that it planned to acquire a large stake in the F.W. Woolworth Company, recently disposed of a substantial percentage of its stock in Woolworth, the nation's fifthlargest retailer, reliable financial sources said yesterday.

title: Film: 'Avalanche Express':Snow Job
description: AS junk movie melodramas go, "Avalanche Express" is of a not-quite-all-star tackiness that should make Sir Lew Grade furious with envy. Indeed, though the Abe Polonsky screenplay is based on a novel by Colin Forbes, the story about United States and Soviet agents, set mostly aboard a European train, seems to have been lifted from Sir Lew's "The Cassandra Crossing, but why anyone would want it is difficult to fathom. The movie opens today at the Forum and other theaters.With Lee Marvin, the late Robert Shaw, Maximilian Schell, Mike Connors, Horst Bucholz, Linda Evans and a very sheepish looking Joe Namath, the movie has as many so-called name actors as different locales  Basle, Zurich, Milan, Moscow and the coastal waters off that part of the Netherlands that has mountains."Avalanche Express" hasn't any wit but it has a few laughs, such as the sight of Mr. Namath reacting when one actor delivers some startling information to another actor. Apparently told to do something, Joe looks hurt and surprised, as if no one wanted his autograph.The other actors are also at a loss. My favorite scene, though, is the one in which several Central Intelligence Agency men disguise themselves in voluminous monks' habits so as not to attract attention on a sightseeing tour of La Scala. As Maxwell Smart might exclaim, "The old monks'-habit bit!" Nobody has had the nerve to use the old monks' habit bit since Robin Hood and his merry men employed it to gain entrance to the archery contest at Prince John's castle.The movie was produced and directed by Mark Robson, and was his last work. Mr. Robson, who directed a number of much better things in his day, including "Von Ryan's Express," died June 20, 1978, of a heart attack shortly after finishing the movie."Avalanche Express," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some violent sequences that are never very frightening.

title: Watson Assumes Post As U.S. Envoy in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 18 (UPI)  Thomas J. Watson Jr., former chairman of the board of I.B.M., has taken over as United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, the first noncareer diplomat in the sensitive post since World War II.

title: Affirmed On Mind Of Delp
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct 18  Bud Delp still hasn't given up hope that a match race between Spectacular Bid and Affirmed can be arranged.

title: Japanese Group Tours City to Examine Manufacturing Possibilities
description: A group of 50 Japanese businessmen were taken on a tour of the South Bronx and other New York City areas yesterday, where they were urged to look beyond what was there to what might be.

title: Two Bombs Explode in Chicago, Four in Puerto Rico
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 18  Six of eight bombs planted here and in Puerto Rico, apparently by Puerto Rican nationalists, exploded overnight, but no injuries were reported from the blasts.

title: Authorities Voice Doubts On Sindona Kidnapping
description: After a second round of questioning of Michel Sindona, the Italian financier who had been missing for two and a half months, authorities indicated they remained skeptical yesterday that he had been kidnapped and had not disappeared intentionally to avoid trial on bank fraud charges.

title: Officials Seek to Examine Body in Oswald's Grave
description: DALLAS, Oct. 18 (AP)  Dallas County medical officials said today that they have asked the authorities in neighboring Tarrant County to dig up the body buried in Lee Harvey Oswald's grave to verify its identity.

title: Carter Aides Split on Issue of Arms Sale to Morocco
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  President Carter's chief foreign policy advisers are split over the issue of supplying Morocco with new types of arms for use against guerrillas in Western Sahara, Administration officials said today.

title: ClassAction Lawsuits Planned On Lung Illness in Textile Mills
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 18  The first classaction lawsuits in behalf of workers who contend that they contracted byssinosis, the socalled brown lung disease, while exposed to cotton dust in Southern textile mills will be filed tomorrow in Alabama and next week in South Carolina.

title: Film: 'French Postcards,' Traps-Atlantic Comedy:Greenhorns in France
description: THE best parts of "French Postcards" are those episodes that capitalize on the characters' sweet navet. They're a group of American college students spending a year in France, and the early section of the movie makes the most of their status as greenhorns. There are subtitles that lovingly translate their wretched French ("Yesterday, we suffer the weather wet . . . but today everything is chestnuts"). There is one boy's alarm as his teacher proudly shows him a room she has decorated in a style she calls "Eisenhower-50's," and identifies one coffee table as "early Formica."This teacher, played delectably by Marie-France Pisier, intends to found branches of her institute in every major European city. "Then what will you do?" the boy inquires. "Move to Los Angeles," she says sweetly. At moments like this, the movie hones in on the cultural cross-pollenization that has created such phenomena as Le Blue Jean or the French versions of American rock songs that turn up on the soundtrack. It also makes it eminently clear that the Americans' culture- and experience-mongering ("There are 212 important sights in the Michelin Guide, so I don't have time for self-pity," one girl writes home) constitutes an utterly hopeless undertaking.The gentle, moderate tone of these touches is perhaps too mild to keep the movie going; in any case, it's a tone that the film makers, Gloria Katz and Willard Huyck, aren't content to maintain. Midway through the story, which they wrote (Miss Katz produced the film, and Mr. Huyck directed it), the plot dissolves into a series of wild coincidences. It winds up on the night-before-graduation note of "American Graffiti," which Miss Katz and Mr. Huyck also wrote. But it never develops a comparable poignancy, perhaps because the characters' fates have become so implausible.Miss Pisier's schoolmistress, for example, is a very strange creation indeed.
