The early parts of the film show her to be wonderfully attractive, married to a man (Jean Rochefort) who pays more attention to his mistress, and developing an extracurricular interest in a very handsome, intense student named Alex (David Marshall Grant). Then, perhaps to keep the film from devoting itself to too many dewy romances, her feelings for the boy are made to disappear. Alex, in turn, is sent back-packing through Spain, and when he returns, he becomes conveniently enamored of the screenplay's one leftover young woman. The wheel of fortune does some very loud creaking as it spins.Nevertheless, parts of "French Postcards," which opens today at the Baronet, have considerable charm, even if it is charm with the consistency of bunny-fluff. And the movie introduces some very appealing new players, among them Mr. Grant and Valrie Quennessen, who makes an irresistible French gamine. She is wooed and won by Miles Chapin, who does a funny job with what would have been the Richard Dreyfuss role, before Miss Katz and Mr. Huyck helped make Mr. Dreyfuss famous.Blanche Baker, as the group stick-in-the-mud, is more unyielding than the others, and seems to have less of a flair for comedy than the rest of the cast. But she gets involved in at least one funny episode, as Mandy Patinkin, playing an Iranian travel agent, offers to squire her to a Medieval Culture festival, then kidnaps her in his Cadillac and comes close to killing her with caviar."French Postcards" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It contains brief nudity and several non-explicit sexual interludes.

title: September Savings Outflow Reported
description: Withdrawals exceeded new savings inflows by $800 million at the nation's savings and loan associations during September, according to estimates by the United States League of Savings Associations.

title: French Premier Getting A Checkup at Hospital
description: PARIS, Oct. 18 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Raymond Barre was admitted to a hospital today for a medical examination, but a bulletin said his condition was not serious.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  Relations between the United States and Israel are rather sad these days. There is no new specific or urgent question dividing these old friends, but, maybe more serious, there is a kind of slow and even sullen drift into misunderstanding.

title: U.S. CHECKS RUMORS OF BREZEINEV DEATH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  Rumors of the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, swept through Washington and other Western capitals today, and the Administration was compelled to take extraordinary steps to check them.

title: The Pop Life
description: WHAT we have in music today is a confusing  or stimulating, if you're an optimist  potpourri of musical styles, old and new. Almost any piece composed in a particular style can be popular, at least within its own frame of reference. And almost any piece can be good or bad. In lower Manhattan today, this stylistic miasma is being determinedly

title: 20 Said to Perish in South Africa As a Hailstorm and Floods Strike
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 18 (UPI)  A hailstorm and flash floods have killed at least 20 people in a remote area of northeastern South Africa, reports said today.

title: Music: Mehta and Watts
description: ZUBIN MEHTA conducted the first of his season's concerts last night, taking the New York Philharmonic through the Piano Concerto No. 1 by Brahms, with Andr Watts as soloist, and then the Symphonie fantastique by Berlioz. Mr. Mehta had commitments prior to becoming music director of the Philharmonic. Thaw other conductors had to fill for him in the first few weeks. Future seasons will see Mr. Mehta at the helm for the opening concert.

title: For Children
description: ARISTIDES THEATER DANCE REPERTORY COMPANY, will perform as part of the Albert Einstein Centennial Exhibit, Sunday at 1 and 3 P.M., in the Hall of Science, Flushing MeadowsCorona Park, 111th Street and 48th Avenue, Flushing, Queens. Donation: children and the elderly, 50 cents; adults, $1. Call 6999157.

title: Teachers' Walkout in Cleveland Shuts Most of the School System
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 18 (AP) A walkout by Cleveland teachers virtually shut down classes in Ohio's largest public school system today, and most of the system's 92,000 students were sent home.

title: Dana: Few Rules, Many Sales
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 17  When Rene C. McPherson became president of the Dana Corporation 11 years ago, one of his first acts was to toss out the company's 22-inch-thick book of policies and procedures. He has been writing his own book on management ever since.

title: Ricci And Sabicas, Two Masters Of Strings
description: TODAY's conventional stringed instruments are either bowed or plucked and strummed, and an outstanding virtuoso of each method can be heard in New York's concert halls this weekend. Representing the bowed violin will be Ruggiero Ricci, who will be celebrating to the day the 50th anniversary of his local debut with a recital Carnegie Hall tomorrow night at 8: 30. The plucked and strummed guitar will have its exponent in Sabicas, who is regarded as the most gifted and profound flamenco musician of his time. His appearance will Sunday night at 8 in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Music: Endymion Ensemble
description: A PROGRAM both short and fascinating opened the Endymion Ensemble's fourconcert series in Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night. Its brevity apparently allowed for sufficient rehearsals of some difficult works, which were extremely well played, while it preserved the proportions and relationships of the music.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: For nearly five years, the Jazzmania Society has been attracting fans in its livingroom sort of loft at 23d Street and Madison Avenue. Now it is expanding into the Shandon Tavern below, and will be known, reasonably enough, as Jazzmania Up n Down. Down in the tavern tonight and tomorrow you can hear the Al Cohn Quartet, while up in the Penthouse these days you will find the bop vocalist Joe Carroll with Mike Morgenstern's AllStars. Patrons of either facility can catch the last set on the other floor at halfprice. Friday and Saturday admission is $5. On Sunday, only the Penthouse is open and admission is $2.50. For information: 4773077.

title: Chrysler' s Aid Bid Gains Some Favor at Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  The Chrysler Corporation received its first bit of encouragement today from the Treasury Department, which is evaluating the ailing company's request for Federal loan guarantees.

title: Jewelry Sale Sets Record
description: A world record of $8,616,700 for a jewelry sale was set yesterday at a twoday auction of 449 individual diamonds and precious gems and jewelry held by Sotheby Parke Bernet.

title: Pittsburgh Orderly In Greeting Pirates
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18  Shortly after the Pirates won the World Series last night, police officers in riot gear, reinforced by canine units, moved into Market Square to face more than 3,000 baseball enthusiasts. The box score follows: 120 arrests, 10 dog bites, vandalized street signs, uprooted trees and broken windows.

title: Dow Profits Advance 29.3% in Quarter
description: The Dow Chemical Company, the nation's thirdlargest chemical concern, said yesterday that its thirdquarter earnings rose by 29.3 percent to $198.4 million, or $1.09 a share, from $153.4 million, or 85 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago. Sales rose 46 percent to $2.43 billion from $1.67 billion.

title: Art People
description: IT'S not just anyone who can relinquish two jobs at one fell swoop, but Charles Cowles has managed to bring it off. The 39yearold art collector, a scion of the Cowles publishing family, will soon not only be former curator of modern art at the Seattle Art Museum, but also former publisher of Artforum, the highminded art magazine.

title: COMPANY NEWS Inflated Costs Laid To 4 Oil Companies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP)  The Government charged four major oil companies today with pricing irregularities involving nearly $100 million following the 197374 Arab oil embargo.

title: Times's Computer Ranks Football Top 20
description: Beginning today, The New York Times will publish its own weekly ranking of the top 20 college football teams. Unlike the existing Associated Press and United Press International rankings, The Times's top20 list is not determined by a poll of experts but by an I.B.M. 370 computer.

title: Swing: Connie Haines
description: WHEN Connie Haines was singing Will You Still Be Mine?', Let's Get Away From It All and Oh, Look at Me Now with Tommy Dorsey's orchestra in 1940 and 1941, she had a brighteyed, bubbling vitality that gave a special sparkle to her singing.

title: Green Rehired by Phillies
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 (AP)Dallas Green, who replaced Danny Ozark as manager of the Philadelphia Phillies for the final six weeks of the 1979 season, was rehired today. The 45yearold Green was given a oneyear contract.

title: Study by the Church of England Opposes a Ban on Homosexuals
description: LONDON, Friday, Oct. 18 (AP) After pondering the subject for five years, the Church of England produced report today saying that homosexual relationships can be justified and recommending that homosexuals not be barred from the priesthood. But it rejected the concept of marriage between homosexuals.

title: At the Movies
description: HIS parents could scarcely have imagined what would ensue when they permitted the 5yearold Miles Chapin to appear in a production of A Christmas Carol at the Amateur Comedy Club. The club was. after all. an institution among New York's oldest ??amines. Its headquarters in a carriage house in Sniffen Court, just off Lexington Avenue at 36th Street, was a model of lateVictorian rectitude. Miles's own uncle, John Steinway, of the pianomanufacturing family, was a former president.

title: Deaths
description: ANTOLOTTIVictor. Beloved broth er of John Antolotti and chef of An tolotti's Restaurant, died October 19. Funeral at Monday, 10AM at Holy Family Church, 47th St.

title: U.S. Wins 7 Gold In World Cup Bouts
description: The young American boxers left no doubt that they are ready for next year's Moscow Olympics.

title: A.M.C. Elects Renault Officer
description: SOUTHFIELD, Mich., Oct. 19  The board of directors of the American Motors Company today elected Bernard VernierPalliez, chief executive officer of the Renault automotive con cern in France, as a member of the board in keeping with the terms of A.M.C.'s limited partnership with the French car maker.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Concert Oct. 29 to Aid Indochinese Refugees
description: Asian artists and groups not regularly heard in New York's principal concert halls, including the Chinese Music Ensemble and the United Chinese Chorus of New York, will be among the highlights of a Benefit Concert to Aid Indochinese Refugees on Oct. 29 at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: A Town Marks Its Ties to Edison
description: OGDENSBURG, N.J., Oct. 18  While others celebrate the 100th anniversary of Thomas A. Edison's greatest success  development of the first practical electric light bulb  the 2,700 residents of this onesquaremile community in southeastern Sussex County are commemorating what some think was his only failure.

title: Changing Careers Is Job in Itself
description: As Bob Marshall tells it, one day in 1972 he gathered the gumption to walk into the office of W. Michael Blumenthal, then president of Bendix Inc. and later Secretary of the Treasury, and ask for a Job as assistant to the president.

title: Finance Minister Said to Resign In a Dispute With India's Premier
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 19 (Reuters Finance Minister Hemwati N. Bahuguna resigned today shortly after receiving a letter from Prime Minister Charan Singh, the Press Trust of India reported. The news agency said Mr. Singh was believed to have asked for the resignation.

title: Scotto's Trial Is Delayed Again
description: Anthony M. Scotto's racketeering trial was delayed again yesterday because of a defense lawyer's illness. The trial was adjourned on Thursday after the lawyer, Gustave H. Newman, became ill. It is now scheduled to resume Monday. Mr. Scotto, a leader of the International Longshoremen's Association, has been on trial since Sept. 11 in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: PAUL G. HAMBY
description: Paul G. Hamby, an industrial executive, died Oct. 8 in Misericordia Hospital in the Bronx after a short illness. Mr. Hamby, who lived in North Brunswick, N.J., was 53 years old.

title: Turks Meeting on a New Regime
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct.19  President Fahri Koruturk met tonight with Suleyman Demirel, the conservative opposition leader who is expected to be asked to form a new government because of his Justice Party's victory in Sunday's byelections.

title: Genstar Bids $55 a Share For Flintkote Common
description: Genstar Ltd. of Canada, a diversified industrial company with a 21.5 percent ownership in the Flintkote Company, yesterday gave Flintkote until Wednesday to reply to a $55ashare takeover bid.

title: Brooklyn Man Slain in Holdup
description: A 55yearold Brooklyn man, Peter Monte, was shot and killed at 8:15 P.M. yesterday during an apparent robbery attempt as he parked his car in the garage of his home at 733 East 51st Street in the Flatbush section. His assailant escaped.

title: Saudis Expel Over 88,000 Aliens For Entering the Country Illegally
description: BAHRAIN, Oct. 19 (Reuters)  Saudi Arabia has deported more than 88,000 aliens in the last four months for entering the country illegally, Interior Minister Prince Nayef said in an interview on Saudi television.

title: ECONOMY'S GROWTH SURGES IN QUARTER AT A RATE OF 2.4%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19  In a display of surprising strength, the nation's economy grew at an annual rate of 2.4 percent in the three months that ended Sept. 30, the Government reported today.

title: Auto Workers and Deere Accord Is Now Disputed Over Language
description: Contract talks between the United Automobile Workers and the Deere and Company took a step backward yesterlay and a scheduled ratification vote this weekend on a new threeyear contract was delayed, a union official said.

title: Father Gigante Starts Serving 10Day Contempt Term
description: The Rev. Louis Gigante began a 10day jail sentence yesterday for refusing to answer questions about efforts to ease the rigors of prison for James Napoli, a reputed gangster.

title: Knicks Overcome Turnovers At End and Beat Nets, 111106
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Oct. 19  The New Jersey Nets' volatile coach, Kevin Loughery, was called into the office of the National Basketball Association commissioner last season for contending that there was a conspiracy against him by league officials, who had awarded him the most technical fouls of any coach in the league. He left Larry O'Brien's office chastised by a fine and supposedly chastened by his promise to improve his behavior.

title: Police Recover Weapons After Car Crash
description: Police Officer examining suitcase containing several weapons and hundreds of rounds of ammunition after arresting Kenneth Gaynor, at left. Mr Gaynor, according to police, was apprehended after he ran from his overturned car on the Brooklyn Bridge clutching a rifle and several suitcases.

title: Censured Congressman Calls Off Trip Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UPI)Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr., Democrat of Michigan, who was censured by the House and convicted of Federal crimes, bowed to Congressional pressure yesterday and called off plans to tour Africa and Europe despite winning court permission for the trip.

title: Navy Secretary Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)  Edward Hidalgo, once a campaigner for Richard M. Nixon, was confirmed by the Senate today as Secretary of the Navy. He had been Assistant Secretary since 1977. His nomination was approved on a voice vote, as were the nominations of Robert W. Komer to be Under Secretary of Defense for policy and of Lieut. Gen. Dennis P. McAuliffe, retired, to be administrator of the new Panama Canal Commission.

title: Rio's Residents Are Fast Losing the Battle Against Cars and Smog
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 19  On one side are five million Cariocas, residents of a place so beautiful that, according to a popular saying, if God spent seven days creating the world, He must have devoted two of them to Rio.

title: Administration Presents  Brief on Taiwan Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19  The Carter Administration today warned of possible serious damage to United States relations with China unless a Federal court decision requiring the President to obtain approval of Congress before ending a defense treaty with Taiwan was promptly reversed.

title: MOTIVES IN SLAYING OF A MAYOR SOUGHT
description: PHOENIX, Ill., Oct. 19 (AP)  some people in this poor, bluecollar community say it is almost unthinkable that someone in town could have murdered their mayor. But investigators are looking at recent controversies, including a police strike, for possible motives.

title: Nuclear Plant Unit Shut M a North Carolina Site
description: SOUTHPORT, N.C., Oct. 19 (UPI)  A unit at a North Carolina nuclear power plant was shut down and evacuated as a precautionary measure today because of an increase in radioactivity inside the main steam line

title: COMMODITIES Precious Metals Futures And Grains Advance
description: Grains and precious metals rose yesterday while interest rate futures plunged in chaotic conditions.

title: Ford Rules Out Active Candidacy; Calls on Supporters to Back Others
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19  Former President Gerald R. Ford today rejected appeals that he enter the 1980 Republican Presidential contest and urged his supporters to jump into the fray behind other candidates.

title: Tower Approved for Bonwit Site
description: The City Planning Commission approved a proposal yesterday to replace the abandoned Bonwit Teller building on Fifth Avenue with a $100 million 56story skyscraper containing apartments, offices and space for stores.

title: Affirmed vs. Spectacular Bid: Racing's Battle of the Bankrolls
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 19  A few hours before last night's $361,000 Meadowlands Cup, somebody asked Laz Barrera if he would be willing to run Affirmed in a match race against Spectacular Bid.

title: Letter: On School Bus Contracts
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Orders Silence On the Sindona Case
description: A Federal judge ordered prosecutors and law enforcement agents yesterday not to talk to reporters about the investigation into what happened to the Italian financier Michele Sindona during the 10 weeks he was missing between Aug. 2 and last Tuesday.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, Oct. 19 (AP)  All major Italian airports were closed today when the country's air traffic controllers resigned in a labor dispute. But the controllers returned to work later in the day and air traffic was expected to be back to normal tomorrow.

title: Zenith Chairman Quits; Former Head Is Recalled
description: John J. Nevin resigned yesterday as the chairman and chief executive officer of the Zenith Radio Corporation, the company announced.

title: Bridge: United States Defeats Italy To Take World Team Title
description: RIO DE JANIERO, Oct. 19  Amid wild excitement, the United States defeated Italy to win the world team title here this afternoon in the most remarkable final in the history of the game.

title: Notes on People
description: Celebrating her 12th birthday yesterday, Amy Carter had two birthday parties in the White House theater and, in order to be polite to her guests, she sat through two showings of the same movie.

title: Soviet Reports Major Step Toward a Fusion Plant
description: The Soviet Union has announced major advance toward the construction of a demonstration plant for producing fusion reaction, viewed by many physicists as a promising energy source.

title: A Demand for Firewood Brings Steep Rise in Cost
description: CEDAR GROVE, N.J., Oct. 17 They were quite brazen and open about it all, the wood poachers were. After all they were collecting what is today a commodity both scarce and expensive  firewood  and there was an urgency.

title: Imprisoned Chinese Dissident Leader
description: PEKING, Oct. 19  When Wei Jingsheng was 12 years old, his father began to make him memorize the writings of Mao Zedong. His father had risen from humble surroundings, thanks to the Communist Party, to be- come a deputy director of the State Capital Construction Commission, and he was a staunch believer in Mao's dictums. Mr. Wei had to learn a page a day or he got no dinner

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Architecture: Mies at National Gallery
description: WASHINGTON The reputation of Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, the Germanborn architect who is regarded as the father of the austere modern glass box , has been in some disarray lately.

title: Retarded Boy's Heart Surgery Put to High Court
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP)  California is taking the fate of Phillip Becker, a retarded 13yearold who needs heart surgery, to the United States Supreme Court. The boy's parents have refused to permit the surgery because they fear it will prolong Phillip's life beyond theirs and into what they believe will be a bleak future for him.

title: First Food Stamp Families Remember 1961.
description: BEARTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 19 (AP)Now that their 15 children are grown, Chloe and Alderson Muncy have plenty of time to sit on the porch of their remote mountaintop home and watch the coal trucks roar past. Sometimes, between trucks, they recall their one, brief fling with fame.

title: Theater: Brecht's `Simone Machard at the McCarter
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 19 During his underproductive sixyear residence in the United States (19411947), Bertolt Brecht wrote The Caucasian Chalk Circle, one of the primary plays on which his reputation rests, and, in collaboration with Lion Feuchtwanger, the novelist, The Visions of Simone. Machard. Simone Machard, the story of a Joan of Arc in World War II, was also turned into a novel by Mr. Feuchtwanger; together, they were bought, but not filmed, by Samuel Goldwyn.

title: Hanoi Aide and Thai Leader Meet
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 19  The Vietnamese Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Nguyen Co Thach, arrived here today following a strong Vietnamese denunciation of Thailand's actions in the Cambodian conflict.

title: OpEd Readers Reply To an ExTeacher
description: To the Editor:

title: Roofer Is Guilty In Mass Murders Near Waterbury
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 19  A 29yearold roofer was found guilty today of stabbing and bludgeoning to death young mother, her seven children and visiting child in the largest mass murder in Connecticut history.

title: Money
description: Prime Rate: 14

title: Salvadoran Women Plead For Word on Missing Sons
description: SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 19 Alicia de Zelayandia spoke firmly but tears ran down her face. We don't want to lose hope, she told El Salvador's new armybacked junta today. You have to find out what happened to our sons and you have to punish those responsible. Only justice will make the people believe in you.

title: Korean Students Extend Protests Against Regime
description: PUSAN, South Korea, Oct. 19  Defying martial law, students who oppose the Government of President Park Chung Hee took to the streets here for the fourth successive night, and troops and armor poured into the city center to keep order.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Soweto, Black Area, Is Divided on Fight
description: SOWETO, South Africa, Oct. 19 Nothing is black and white in Soweto.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: 1. I am unworthy, said Mother Teresa of Calcutta, pictured above. To what was the Roman Catholic nun referring?

title: F.B.I. Aide, Dismissed in Inquiry, Found Dead in Apparent Suicide
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)  An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who was dismissed Tuesday for alleged corruption was found dead today at his home in suburban Burke, Va., an apparent suicide, the bureau said.

title: 34 Food Establishments Cited as Code Violators
description: The New York City Health Department has cited 34 food establishments as violators of the Health Code and two as having corrected earlier violations. The businesses were listed as follows:

title: About New York
description: Public School 179 no longer has classes, and the brittle din of childish voices no longer punctuates the enforced silences of compulsory education. It is, however, still a learning center.

title: Jury Is Recalled In Aranow Case Over Irregularity
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., Oct. 19  Members of the jury that convicted a Columbia University medical student of manslaughter in the stabbing of a classmate were brought back to court today for an inquiry into the conduct of some of the jurors during their deliberations

title: Mexico, Unable to Cap Runaway Oil Well, Plans to Use Chemicals for Cleanup
description: Still thwarted in efforts to cap a runaway oil well in the Gulf of Mexico that blew out four and a half months ago, the Mexican state oil monopoly plans to try to treat the gushing oil spill chemically to facilitate collection of the oil, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Mendenhall Braces To Play for Giants
description: Some of his teammates think it looks like a toilet bowl. The tubular piece of white laminated plastic was tried on for size by several players, but it fits only John Mendenhall. And Mendenhall fits into the Giants game plan for the first time in four painful weeks.

title: U.A.W. President Promises Concessions to Chrysler
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19  The president of the United Automobile Workers told a House Banking subcommittee today that his union would make significant concessions to the Chrysler Corporation that defy 42 years of history and tradition, to save jobs.

title: World Gold
description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1979

title: Carter Expects to Recoup in South After Kennedy Successes in North
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19  President Carter told a group of Democratic political insiders yesterday that although he might fare poorly against Senator Edward M. Kennedy in the New England primaries he expected to recoup in the Southern states and believed that the Illinois primary March 18 would be an important barometer for both of them.

title: Presence of U.S.C. Arouses Irish
description: SOUTH BEND Ind., Oct. 19  There will be no gimmicks used to stimulate the enthusiasm of the Notre Dame football team against Southern California tomorrow, according to Dan Devine, head coach of the Irish.

title: Karate Politics in Korea
description: In its dealings with South Korea, the Carter Administration has been solicitous to a fault. Since President Carter's visit to Seoul last July, President Park Chung Hee has driven the entire opposition from the parliament, turned riot police against women demonstrators and used raids and arrests to silence criticism by politicians, trade unionists and priests. The timing of the crackdown conveys open contempt for American opinion. Secretary of Defense Brown reached South Korea just as a major student uprising impelled the Government to impose martial law.

title: Expert Is Sure Body Is Oswald's
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 19  The Lee Harvey Oswald who was buried in Fort Worth is the Lee Harvey Oswald who was in the Marine Corps, according to G. Robert Blakey, former staff director for the House Assassinations Committee.

title: CBS News Names Leiser Head of Political Coverage
description: Ernest Leiser, a longtime television news producer and executive, has been named vice presidentspecial events and political coverage for CBS News.

title: Cambodian Refugees Show No Desire to Return Home
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 19  Whenever refugees pouring out of Cambodia are asked what they want to do next or where they want to go, the most frequent replies are: It is up to the Thais, or It is up to the United Nations or Wherever I am told to go.

title: A Rikers Takeover Is Causing 2d Thoughts
description: Last June the proposed state takeover of New York City's prison complex on Rikers Island looked like an ideal arrangement. For the state it meant a possible end to overcrowded upstate prisons through a 99year lease of Rikers. In exchange the city would gain $200 million from the state to modernize an antiquated, inefficient jail system.

title: 2 Arrested as Hillside Stranglers After a Confession
description: BELLINGHAM, Wash., Oct. 19 (UPI)  Knneth A. Bianchi today pleaded guilty to killing two college coeds here and then admitted five of the 13 hillside strangler murders in Los Angeles. He and his cousin, Angelo Buono Jr., were immediately charged with 10 of the California killings.

title: The Man From Moss Swamp
description: McCLELLANVILLE, S.C.  I live near a neglected river delta that once produced the finest staple crops in the New World. Rice and cotton are gone now  to the Southwest and the West  and many of the people who cultivarea tnem are gone, too. But many have stayed on, and older ones remember when cotton and turpentine were all the go  the only ways to make a living. No one has lived long enough to recall the clearing of the cypress. swamps and the breaking of the land. A cloak of wilderness has grown over the ruins of African and European, handiwork. This history may be approached on foot, or by boat. Meander into the forests and darkwater swamps that hold to the river and you may trip upon a mound of smoothedged bricks, the remains of a colonial outbuilding; or you may wade over sunken file of hewn timbers where mill once stood. Then again, the relics you find may be of more recent vintage  rusted pans and drums from turpentine works and whiskey stills.

title: Big Selloff Sends Dow Down 15.44
description: The stock market sustained a sharp setback yesterday in accelerated trading amid growing investor fears about increases in shortterm interest rates.

title: Entertainment Events
description: LET THERE BE JOY, musical, starring Shimon Dzigan, Ben Bonus and Mina Benn, Norman Thomas Theater, East 33d Street and Park Avenue, 8:30.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, Oct. 19,1979

title: Theater Gala Will Benefit Clinton Housing Unit
description: Spotlight on Clinton  Broadway's Back Yard, a gala to benefit the Clinton Housing Development Company, will present, among others, Celeste Holm, the actress; Sarah Jessica Parker of Annie; Vic Miles, a WCBSTV personality; the Pepsi Bethel Authentic Jazz Dance Theater; Hector Elionzo of Steambath ; Saeko Ichinohe, the dancer, and Jill O'Hara of Promises, Promises. The gala will take place at the Royale Theater, 242 West 45th Street, on Oct. 29.

title: COMPANY NEW
description: TORONTO, Oct. 19  The Dominion Bridge Company, a large Canadian manufacturer of structural steel with interests in engineering and construction, announced today that it planned to make a $200 million cash offer for the Warner & Swasey Company.

title: Recital: Nina Beilina, a Violinist
description: So many migr musicians have arrived in America from the Soviet Union in recent years that the casual concertgoer must be bewildered at this proliferation of talent. It will take years. probably, before even close observers are able to sort out the best from the rest, and before a legitimate hierarchy can be restored. Where, for instance, does Nina Beilina fit into the picture?

title: Dance: Sharon Kinney Turns to Romance in Passages
description: Romance is back. Or so it seemed in the Dance Theater Workshop concert by Sharon Kinney and Dancers on Thursday night at the American Theater Laboratory. 219 West 19th Street.

title: The Region
description: MINEOLA, L.I.,A 28-year-old Wit liston Park man who was apparently upset over a broken engagement and his inability to get a job, shot his mother, his dog and himself to death on Thursday, the police said yesterday.

title: Peking Permits OnceBanned Exhibit of New Art
description: PEKING, Oct. 19  In what appears to be an easing of the restrictions on artistic freedom, Chinese cultural officials have decided to allow an exhibit of modem painting and sculpture by 23 artists that was forbidden by the police.

title: Carter Is Assured of Big Margin; In Florida Democratic Caucuses
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19  With the pro- tracted count of ballots in the Miami area at finally completed, Democratic offi- cials in Florida said tonight that Presi- dent Carter was assured a solid victory over Senator Edward M. Kennedy in the caucus voting that took place last Satur- day.

title: The City
description: A judge refused to bar the press from a pretrial hearing involving Allen Curtis Lewis, who is charged with attempted murder for allegedly pushing Renee Katz, a music student, in front of a subway train last June 7.

title: Tate Weighs a Surprising 240.
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 19  When John Tate keeps his tryst with Gerrie Coetzee in Pretoria tomorrow night, he will be the heaviest man to fight for championship in 37 years.

title: OBSERVER Delayed Replay
description: For ten days grandmother and hunkered down in the parlor watching the flight of the Israelites out of Egypt in miserably cold, rainy weather. Everyone complained about the weather. It is very hard for the Israelites to flee like champions under these intolerable and meteorological conditions, said Howard from his vantage point high in the broadcast booth.

title: White House Shifts View On Tying Oil Aid to Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19  The Carter Administration, in a shift of strategy, today dropped its insistence that $1.2 billion program to help poor people pay heating bills this winter remain contingent upon Congressional approval of the windfall profits tax on oil companies.

title: Wayne County Payroll Is Unmet; Judge Bars Proposal for I.O.U.'s
description: DETROIT, Oct. 19 (AP)  Wayne County was unable to pay its employees today, and a judge rejected a plan to use redeemable i.o.u.'s instead of real money.

title: 2 Coast Phone Companies Bid for Time
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19  The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company and the General Telephone Company of California, faced with the prospect of having to refund nearly $500 million to their customers in California and pay $1.6 billion in back taxes to the Internal Revenue Service, are playing for time.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Gold Strong in Europe; Dollar Finishes Higher
description: Gold staged a strong comeback in Europe yesterday, with reports of heavy buying from the Middle East. At the same time, the dollar chalked up gains in Europe and New York on speculation that the Federal Reserve will raise the discount rate again.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 21.

title: Minority Leaders Petition Board To Pick Black City College Chief
description: A group of black leaders, concerned with what it considers to be a lack of minority group representation at the top levels of the City University of New York, has urged the university's Board of Trustees to appoint a black to the presidency of City College.

title: Execution Delay Denied
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)  The Supreme Court, by a vote of 7 to 1, refused today to postpone the execution of a convicted Nevada murderer, Jesse Bishop, who is scheduled to die in the state's gas chamber Monday. The Court's denial was its second this month in the Bishop case. On Oct. 1, the Justices voted, 7 to 2, to reject arguments aimed at delaying the execution. Mr. Bishop was sentenced to death after he pleaded guilty to the 1977 shooting death of a Baltimore man in a Las Vegas casino robbery.

title: Regents Oppose A Law Allowing Pupil Spankings
description: Confronting an issue that has divided American educators for nearly two centuries, the New York State Board of Regents voted yesterday to seek the repeal of a 19thcentury law authorizing corporal punishment in the state's 700 public school districts outside New York City.

title: OPEC Head Sees No Price Increase
description: TOKYO, Oct. 19 (AP)  The president of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that he expects the price of oil to remain at current levels through the end of 1979 and into next year.

title: Inquiry on Coast Court Is Stalled After Panel Bars Public Hearings
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19  The public investigation of how California Supreme Court justices handled sensitive cases appeared to be dead in the water today after a temporary panel sitting as the high court held that the investigation's public sessions were unconstitutional.

title: Brezhnev Reported III After a Fatiguing Hunt
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 19 (AP)  Leonid I. Brezhnev is ill, Communist sources here said today, and is thought to be overfatigued from a dawn hunt while visiting East Germany.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Deaths
description: KUKLINNorman B. Of Pelham Manor, New York on October 18th, 1979. Husband of Deane, father of Anthony B. and Jeffry P. Brother of Cella Mendelsohn. Also survived by six grandchildren.

title: Police in Boston Will Investigate Racial Violence
description: BOSTON, Oct. 19  Police Commissioner Joseph M. Jordan of Boston today ordered an investigation into a possible conspiracy behind an outbreak of racial violence that entered its fourth day as scattered attacks continued outside the schools.

title: President Salutes Urban Grants As Centerpiece of Cities Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19  President Carter today saluted the second anniversary of a $1 billion urban grant program that he said was the centerpiece of his urban policy, and found himself praised by Henry W. Maier, the longtime Democratic Mayor of Milwaukee, as a man who kept his promises to the cities.

title: Talks on Rhodesia Resume, but a New Snag Develops
description: LONDON, Oct. 19  The peace conference on Zimbabwe Rhodesia resumed today with the participation of the Patriotic Front, but almost immediately ran into difficulties when the guerrilla leaders demanded that Britain present all its ideas on the transition of power.

title: U.S. Resumes Attempt to Deport Head of Croatian Wartime Police
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19  After nearly three decades of fruitless efforts to deport Andrija Artukovic, Minister of Interior and Justice of the Nazi puppet state of Croatia during World War II, the United States Government has again moved to reinstate deportation action.

title: Remembering Kennedy, and Dallas
description: In a sense, the dedication of the Kennedy Presidential Library in Boston today cleaves the population. That is not meant as a comment on the contest between President Carter and Senator Kennedy, no matter how much 1880 politics will reverberate among the echoes. What comes to mind at this more reflective occasion a cleavage of memory.

title: L.I. Pet Shop Burglar Takes Deadly Snakes
description: DEER PARK, L.I., Oct. 19 (AP) The police said here today that they did not know if the thief knew what he was getting into when he broke into a pet shop here last night.

title: Opera: The Marriage of Figaro
description: The New York City Opera's first performance this season of The Marriage of Figaro on Thursday night was thoroughly engaging, without ever having any exalted moments. Nevertheless, the Mozart work showed off the company at its best, because the singers in their youthful teamwork onstage seemed to revel in this enchanting comedy.

title: Four Years After Nursing Home Case, Bergman's Affairs Remain a Tangle of Litigation
description: Four years after Bernard Bergman's indictment for Medicaid fraud, his tangled business affairs are still in the hands of more than two dozen lawyers, numerous Federal and state officials, Federal and state courts here and in New Jersey and Federal Tax Court in Washington.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SALUTE IN STEPS A choreographic tribute to Albert Einstein will take place tomorrow afternoon in conjunction with the celebration of the Einstein centennial and an exhibition at the Hall of Science in Queens. At 1 o'clock and again at 3, the Aristides Theater Dance Company will creatively interpret scientific theories of Einstein, such as the expanding universe, photoelectric effect and relativity. The accompanying music ranges from folk to Classical.

title: Norden Hits Primary Target
description: NORWALK, Conn.  Although it was nearly 6:30 on a recent Friday evening, executives of Norden Systems Inc. were not about to go home as they waited here in the secondfloor offices of the company's factory for a telephone call from Washington.

title: Israeli and a Palestinian Win Awards in Austria
description: VIENNA, Oct. 19 (Reuters)  An Israeli and a Palestinian who say they have been meeting regularly since 1976 were awarded human rights prizes today by Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria.

title: Around the Nation
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19 (UPI)  Four more tremors rattled southern California early today, a few hours before Goy. Edmund G. Brown Jr. asked President Carter for $21 million in Federal assistance to the Imperial Valley, site of the hardest of a series of temblors this week.

title: U.S. Sues Lettuce Grower
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19 (UPI)The Department of Labor has filed a Federal court suit against Sun Harvest Inc., the nation's largest lettuce grower, in which it charges violation of the Farm Labor Registration Act. The suit contends that the company violated the law by engaging farm labor contractors without determining whether they were registered with the labor department.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) over-the-counter.

title: British Retail Prices Rise
description: LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP)  Retail prices in Britain rose 1 percent in September, up from an increase of eighttenths of 1 percent in August, the Department of Trade reported today.

title: Boston Gathering Recalls Era of Camelot
description: BOSTON, Oct. 19Camelot?

title: ARABS VOICING FEAR ABOUT PERSIAN GULF
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 19  Arab countries are voicing increasing fear over security in the Persian Gulf and the Strait of Hormuz, through which more than 60 percent of the nonCommunist world's oil moves.

title: For Working Women, A Clothes Department
description: Take one suit, one blouse, a silk dress, a knitted twopiece dress and tweed or plaid skirt and what do you have? A workable wardrobe for the working woman, as envisioned by Abraham & Straus.

title: Corporation for Public Broadcasting Delays Decision on Campaigns
description: With time running short for planning, the extent to which public television and radio will cover the political scene in the 1980 election year is still up in the air because of major questions of financing.

title: Successors to Chief Chosen at Dutch/Shell
description: LONDON, Oct. 19  Peter B. Baxendell, a 54yearold petroleum engineer, and Dirk deBruyne, a 59yearold economist, have been named to succeed Carmichael Pocock as chief executive of the Royal Dutch/ Shell Group and a subsidiary company. Mr. Pocock died last week.

title: Dayan Asks Wider Role For Holy Site Overseers
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 19 Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan has suggested that Israel offer Christian and Moslem religious overseers more responsiblity at their holy sites in Jerusalem as one means of keeping momentum in the talks with Egypt over Palestinian selfrule in occupied territories.

title: Japanese Car Makers Fear U.S.
description: TOKYO, Oct. 19 (AP)  Despite brisk sales of Japanese cars in the United States, auto makers here fear they cannot compete indefinitely with the billions of dollars that Americans are pouring into new technology.

title: Deaf Students Rehearse With Choreographers For Special Performance
description: Louis Falco watched as a group of students he is coaching for a special dance performance stretched and bent, leaped and ran in an ebullient dance. Throw your arm with such force that your body will naturally follow. Mr. Falco, who has his own dance company, instructed them. Even if your legs can't travel because you don't have room, your torso should. But don't look as though you were directing yourself. That looks too neurotic. Do you know what neurotic means?

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The nation's economy grew at an annual rate of 2.4 percent in the three months ended Sept. 30, according to Government figures. The unexpectedly large increase is likely to bolster the Federal Reserve's argument that credit must be tightened to contain inflation. Apparently conceding that the Fed's tightmoney policy will restrain economic growth, Treasury Secretary Miller said he expected the economy to return to slower, negative growth in the next few quarters. [Page 1.]

title: Afghanistan Said to Subdue Military Uprising but Not Civilian Rebels
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 19  President Hafizu1lah Amin's monthold Government successfully subdued a military uprising in Kabul three days ago but is making no headway in attempts to placate civilian rebels, according to reports reaching here from Afghanistan.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON THE Atlantic Research Corporation, which manufactures rocket motors at Alexandria, Va., plans to test a new solar energy collector that absorbs heat in slowly moving black water. Patent 4,170,984 was granted for the invention this week to Robert S. Scheffee, chief of an energy technology group at the company.

title: Something Cheaper Than Oil
description: The rising price of oil spells misery in one way or another for all New Yorkers  all, that is, except the Republicans in Albany who are making partisan capital of it. They are pressing for an immediate repeal of the state sales tax on heating oil, which would yield little tangible benefit other than forcing a veto from politically embarrassed but fiscally responsible Democratic governor.

title: PANEL WOULD DELAY ANY NEW REACTORS FOR SAFETY CHANGES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19  The President's Commission on the Accident at Three Mile Island has voted to recommend a halt in the construction of new reactors until its recommendations for improving nuclear safety have been adopted, commission officials have disclosed.

title: Judge's Soap Sentence Administered by Police
description: CORTLAND, N.Y., Oct. 19 (UPI) All Thomas South did was cuss at two policemen, but the Police Department here has been getting telephone calls from as far away as California because of his punishment: having his mouth washed out with soap.

title: Frazier Waived
description: The career of Walt Frazier, the former Knick and one of the top guards to play in the National Basketball Association, may be over. The Cleveland Cavaliers placed the 34yearold Frazier on waivers yesterday to make room for Foots Walker, who had been on the injuredreserve list. Teams have until Tuesday to claim Frazier, a 13season veteran, but it is unlikely that he will be picked up.

title: Short Interest on the Big Board Is at Record Level
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 4.4 million shares in the month ended Oct. 15 to a record 54.5 million shares. This surpasses the previous high of 50.4 million shares on Aug. 15. The short interest for the yearearlier level totaled 41.3 million shares.

title: Zatopek Recalls Golden Days of His Career
description: His hands are everywhere, setting scenes as if they were yesterday. His voice is warm and enthusiastic, describing people, places and things with elaborate detail. There is no rhythm to the flow, but then Emil Zatopek was always a man of motion. not form.

title: STOCKS AND BONDS DROP SHARPLY AGAIN
description: A sharp selloff broke out again in the nation's securities markets yesterday, spurred by the latest signs that the Federal Reserve was tightening credit still further and intended to push interest rates still higher.

title: Libyans Awash in Oil Money, Technology and Foreigners
description: TRIPOLI, Libya - The quaint old har- bor of this Mediterranean city has been transformed into a scarred beachhead for a huge Western technological inva- sion.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Your Money
description: WITH shortterm interest rates continuing rise, many savings and loan associations are caught in an earnings squeeze, and one of them, the Astoria Federal Savings and Loan Association. has decided to do something about it.

title: Books of The Times The Cool Sun of Winter
description: Tolstoy was on his deathbed when he said, I don't understand what I'm supposed to do, but many old people feel this way for 20 years before dying. The average man has learned to stay alive until 70 instead of 90, and as Ronald Blythe sees it in The View in Winter, he may also have learned how to be old.

title: Negotiations Resume On Times of London; Deadline Is Tomorrow
description: LONDON, Oct. 19  Negotiations designed to save The Times of London and The Sunday Times resumed today, with new deadline of 4 P.M. Sunday.

title: Hatalsky Leads by Stroke
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Oct. 19 (AP) Morris Hatalsky, a thirdyear pro seeking his first tournament victory, scrambled to a three-under-par 69 today and a oneshot lead at the halfway mark of the $200,000 Pensacola open.

title: VIRGINIA FAIN WILLIAMS
description: Virginia Fain Williams, who was active in civic affairs in New York CIty, died Tuesday of a heart attack at her home in Manhattan. She was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan and Norfolk, Conn.

title: Amoco's 3dQuarter Net Up 49%
description: The thirdquarter profits of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) rose 49 percent compared with the third quarter of 1978, the company said yesterday. It reported net profits of $433.8 million, or $2.97 a share, versus $292 million, or $2 a share, in last year's third quarter.

title: Dollar Off Against Yen
description: The dollar gained in value against most major currencies except the Japanese yen. Largescale intervention by the Bank of Japan and rumors of an impending increase in Japanese discount rates and of a possible increase by some Japanese commercial banks of their own rates buoyed the troubled yen, according to dealers.

title: Miss Hunter Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman Field Hunter of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Stuart Hunter, to George Hotchkiss Wightman, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Wightman of Wayland and Chatham, Mass. A spring wedding is planned.

title: 66 at Chicago Concert Held
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (UPI)  At least 66 persons were arrested last night, mostly on disorderly conduct charges, in the second night of concerts at the Chicago Stadium by the music group Earth, Wind and Fire. The arrests were made when people without tickets to the soldout con cert tried to enter the stadium, the police said. More than a thousand people without tickets to the Thursday night concert were denied admission.

title: U.S. Magistrates Get New Powers to Speed Access to Justice
description: THEY are a rare breed in the Federal court system, usually little noticed but now about to assume added responsibility to help clear dockets.

title: GARDENING
description: VINES are a much overlooked element in the landscape. Trained over an arbor, they will provide cool shade during the summer. On a fence or trellis, they may be used as a screen for privacy or to block out an unpleasant view. Used against a masonry or stone wall, they will soften its starkness and provide a pleasant contrast in texture. Growing on the trunk of a tree, they become nature's equivalent of a ball gown.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, Oct.21

title: U.S.C.'s White Crushes Notre Dame, 4223
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 20  Southern California may not be elected the best team in the land this year because of a tie with Stanford a week ago, but Charles White looked every bit like the best individual in college football today. The 21yearold Trojan running back turned in the finest performance of his career with 261 yards rushing and four touchdowns as Southern California trounced Notre Dame, 4223.

title: Amy Friedlander and Norman Gorin to Be Wed Feb. 2
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Friedlander of Montreal and Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Susan Friedlander, to Norman William Gorin, son of Ruth Nayor Conroy of Boston and Harold Edwin Gorin of Brookline, Mass.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: It appears that the state's Board of Medical Examiners has suspended the license of my family doctor, Grant B. Dellabough of Teaneck.

title: Utility Takeovers: How Others Fare
description: SYRACUSE

title: De Paul Triumphs
description: Rick Cuaycong carried 22 times for 121 yards and scored three touchdowns as undefeated De Paul defeated Kinnelon, 270, at Wayne for its fifth success. Cuaycong scored on runs of 6, 3 and 18 yards as De Paul amassed 352 yards on offense. Kinnelon (14) managed just 44 yards offensively.

title: A Merger of Plastic And Performing Arts
description: CONTROVERSIAL in some cirles because of her feminist message, the sculptor Suzanne Benton has received strong support from churches, generally consiaered to be conservative, or at least cautious. While this seems, on the surface, to be a contradiction, her art deals with symbolism and ritual, modes of communication that the churches understand, value and use.

title: Elizabeth E. Finger To Be Wed Nov. 24
description: Mr. and Mrs. John H. Daniels of Toronto and New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Daniels's daughter, Elizabeth Ellen Finger, to William Russell Finger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Finger of New York and Amagansett, L.I. The couple, who will be married in New York Nov. 24, are not related.

title: Outdoor Programs for the Handicapped
description: Wilderness programming for the physically disabled is a relatively new concept, but one that catching on nationally as word spreads about the benefits to both disabled and ablebodied participants. Below is a listing of programs around the country that offer a range of outdoor experiences

title: LETTERS
description: To The Business Editor: The article China's Jobless Youth: A Mounting Problem (Sept. 29) was interesting and instructive. So sparse has information reaching us been about that vast country during recent years that its modified form of independent endeavor  collectively owned enterprises  may have surprised more than one reader.

title: INVESTING
description: Over the last two weeks, the bond market was thrown for its biggest loss in financial history. Prices of Treasury, corporate and taxexempt bonds sank and interest rates rose to their highest levels on record.

title: Inflation: We're Fighting Yesterday's War
description: The current Carter Administration strategy for defeating inflation is the economic equivalent of trench warfare. As enunciated by Treasury Secretary G. William Miller, the country must undergo 6 to 7 years of austerity while tight monetary and fiscal policies create enough idle capacity to squeeze inflation out of the system.

title: Words and Music Under Stalin
description: DMITRI SHOSTAKOVICH was one of the world's most celebrated composers. As such he was the pride of the Soviet Union, which lavished the pride of the Soviet Union, which lavished all honors on him. He was a man of mystery, with few friends, and he lived almost a reclusive life. But he had strong party connections, knew everybody, even knew where the skeletons were rattling.

title: GARDENING
description: VINES are a much overlooked element in the landscape. Trained over an arbor, they will provide cool shade during the summer. On a fence or trellis, they may be used as a screen for privacy or to block out an unpleasant view. Used against a masonry or stone wall, they will soften its starkness and provide pleasant contrast in texture. Growing on the trunk of a tree, they become nature's equivalent of a ball gown.

title: Selling Healthy Companies
description: Last March, at a time when the SCM Corporation stood at a dismal $18 a share, the stock suddenly sprang to life. Wall Street rumors were that the diversified industrial company was surely a takeover target. It was a target all right, but there was more to the story.

title: The Jersey Devil, Warmed by Nukes, Is Now Benign
description: THE atomic colossus of Oyster Creek dominates the flat landscape of nearby Lacey Township, its generatingplant tower looming like a primeval specter over the scrub pines. By night, its sanguine glow conjures up eerie, atavistic visions of sacrifices to a transplanted Baal.

title: Tales From All Over
description: WORLD TALES is a collection, as much for adults as for children, of 65 folktales from almost every culture. To those who feel that adults should put away childish things, this must seem a contradictory remark. But for someone

title: U.S. Plans More Funds For Dr. King Memorial
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 20 (UPI)  Vice President Mondale says that the Government has approved another $1.5 million for construction of a memorial to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Backroom Reissues Of Rare Recordings
description: While the controversy over pirated or unauthorized recordings of live musical performances and commercial disks continues to be aired in the courts and in the press, a growing number of small recording companies have been quietly engaged in what might be called legal piracy. These Mom and Pop operations are not out to compete with EMI or give RCA an elbow to the ribs. Nor are they in business to cheat recording artists out of their royalties.

title: Ulster Moves to Forgo County's Share of Tax On Owners of Realty
description: KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 18 With elections less than three weeks away, the chairman of the Ulster County Legislature announced today that he and his fellow Democrats had decided to enact oneyear moratorium on the county government's share of Ulster Property taxes.

title: Erica Hutson Bride of Samuel Gillespie 3d
U.S IS SOIINDIN6 OUT MOSCOW ON MISSILES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  The United States has started discussions with Soviet officials on whether a recent offer by the Russians to reduce their mediumrange missiles targeted on Western Europe held out the possibility of genuine negotiations or was merely a device to keep the West at a disadvantage.

title: Safety Board to Study Commuter Airline Accidents
description: The National Transportation Safety Board, alarmed by the rise in commuterairline accidents, announced yesterday that it would hold an unusual hearing before all five board members to explore ways to correct shortcomings in the fastexpanding industry.

title: Engineer Fianc Of Gari B. Locker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Locker of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gari Beth Locker, to Charles Day Palmer 3d, son of Gen. Charles Day Palmer, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Palmer of Washington.

title: A Case for County Offices Move
description: WHY not locate the county offices in Yonkers? To look at that matter in the light of political reality, it is a longshot, but, to look at it in the light of economics. it makes vent good sense.

title: Changing Times in the Fish World
description: WOODBURY

title: $1,000aPlate Dinners for G.O.P. Are Set for Nov. 6 in 5 Key Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP)  The Republican Party will hold five dinners in key cities around the country on Nov. 6 to raise money for elections next year, the party's national committee has reported.

title: Other Ideas & Trends
description: Americans Smoking Less

title: ART
description: HARTFORD

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN plaster becomes loose or crumbly in sections, or when it is so loose that pieces actually fall off (often the case after a bad leak has occurred), patching it properly calls for complete removal of all the loose and defective plaster and building up the surface with new material.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: IT had been snowing all day, a freak snow that fell on leaves just turning gold and orange, but the crowd in the grandstand didn't care. Bundled up in old wool overcoats,cardigans and polyester jackets lined with fake fur, clutching cups of coffee and cheweddown cigars, they stood in the cold night air and shouted encouragement to their favorites.

title: Preserving the Irreplaceable
description: HAMDEN FROM the hilltops of the farm his father founded in 1892, George Hindinger can see downtown New Haven spread out like a road map. uurmg HIS z years there, Mr. Hindinger has witnessed more than just the rise of the skyscrapers at the edge of the Sound; he has watched the city advance up the hill toward him. Now the advance guard, comfortable singlefamily houses on quarteracre plots, has reached his border.

title: Realty News New Office Tower To Rise at 520 Madison
description: Teeco Properties will begin construction soon of a 38story office tower on the west side of Madison Avenue between 53d and 54th Streets.

title: Eye Operation on Suslov Reported to Be a Success
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 20 (AP)  One of the three American eye surgeons who performed an operation on a top Soviet leader said today that it had been a success and would not affect his ability to do his job. He declined to identify the patient beyond saying that he was a member of the ruling Politburo.

title: David M. Campbell, 49, Minister Of First United Methodist Church
description: The Rev. David M. Campbell, pastor of the First United Methodist Church of Mystic, Conn., died Thursday at the Pequot Treatment Center in Groton, Conn. He was 49 years old and a resident of Mystic.

title: How the Programs Work
description: Medicare is Federal healthinsurance coverage that is available to people over 65 on Social Security. It supplements other insurance benefits, such as Blue Cross and Blue Shield, and, as it applies to nursing homes, is restricted to a specified period of days for hospital and hospitalrelated illnesses (such as weakness or debilitation as a result of major surgery). It pays hospital rates for a limited nursinghome stay.

title: Localities Temper
description: NEARLY 75 percent of Westchester's communities have passed legislation banning the use, or even possession, of alcohol in public places.

title: STAMPS
description: The United Nations is concluding its issues for the year on Nov. 9 with a tribute to the International Court of Justice. And this Thursday the United States is issuing its first stamps for use by charitable organizations, rather than the usual embossed stamped envelopes.

title: Study Says Playground Surfaces Are a Factor in Serious Injuries
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP)  Playground surfaces are a major factor in the seriousness of the nearly 100,000 injuries to American children each year that are related to playground equipment, according to a Government report.

title: Jersey Broker Fighting For Lists
description: Wayne Pomanowski says he feels like the loneliest real estate broker in the State of New Jersey. He says his friends and colleagues are reluctant to send him referrals. Salespeople are wary of working for him.

title: Localities Adopting PetCleanup Laws
description: WESTCHESTER municipalities are beginning to follow New York City's example by requiring dog walkers to be responsible for their pets waste habits on public property.

title: 76ers 2dHalf Surge Tops Knicks, 136111
description: The advance scouting reports to all coaches in the Eastern Conference of the National Basketball Association have been the same. They said that the Philadelphia 76ers had put together big, strong, experienced starting five and an almost equally powerful line of substitutes.

title: Countries Turn To U. N. Aides In Tough Cases
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 20  If Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria had followed the book when he feared that Honduras might turn over some Nicaraguan political refugees to Anastasio Somoza Debayle and certain death, he would have called on the Austrian Ambassador to Mexico.

title: F. T.C. Judge Finds Ads Sears Used Were False
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20(AP)  Sears, Roebuck & Company, the world's largest retailer, used false advertising for ,its dishwashers, a Federal administrative law judge ruled this week.

title: Guards Call Indian Point Plants Highly Vulnerable to Terrorists
description: BUCHANAN, N.Y. (AP)  The men who guard the Indian Point nuclear plants warn that it is there for the taking.

title: FreeAgent System Still an N.F.L. Issue
description: John Dutton, a premier defensive end for the Baltimore Colts for five years, officially becomes a Dallas Cowboy tomorrow when he will be added to the club's active roster. Although still rusty, having not played since last December, Dutton may see spot action against the Steelers in Pittsburgh next Sunday.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Little was known about Karol Wojtyla before he formally became Pope John Paul II about a year ago, on Oct. 22, 1978, although the former Polish cardinal is much more familiar to everyone today, of course. Vatican coins and medals also were somewhat obscure, in the numismatic scheme of things, prior to the series of dramatic events that led to the coronation of the Polish Pone. but now they too, enjoy a greater following  thanks, in large measure, to the worldwide appeal of the Pontiff himself.

title: Martha Blomstrom Bride of Hugh Balaam
description: Martha Lee Blomstrom and Hugh Vincent Balsam were married yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church in Mountain View, Calif., by the Rev. Harry Wooding.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: HEN plaster becomes loose or crumbly in sections, or when it is so loose that pieces actually fall off (often the case after a bad leak has occurred), patching it properly calls for complete removal of all the loose and defective plaster and building up the surface with new material.

title: Major News
description: Jimmy Carter, Paul A. Volcker and G. William Miller took to the road last week  the President from the White House to the Middle West, Mr. Volcker from the Federal Reserve and Mr. Miller from the Treasury to Capitol Hill. Their mission was probable  the selling of the Fed's new antiinflation policy to worriers about the recessionary effects of supertight money. The salesmen couldn't have asked for a stronger supporting argument than last week's figures on the gross national product for the third quarter.

title: First Public Trip on Revived Adirondack Train
description: After a lapse of 14 years, the Adirondack Railway is being reactivated between Utica and Lake Placid, N.Y. One of the first trips open to the public on the line is scheduled for Nov. 9 as part of a PreOlympic Tour Weekend offered by the Lake Placid Resort Hotel, formerly the Lake Placid Club.

title: New Link in the Lower 48 Was Approved Last Week
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Alaska pipeline was authorized In 1973 only after intense Congressional debate. By most measures, the pipeline - which began delivering North Slope oil nearly two years ago has turned out to be an immensely valuable addition to the national industrial plant. The 800mile line has delivered 872 million barrels of oil when the United States needed them most.

title: Mailbox: Let Sun Shine for Series
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Challenge Of Comic Dance
description: The scarcity of good comedy in dance probably results from the longheld prejudice that dance must be serious art. It also demonstrates the fact that comedy is devilishly hard to create. Such obstacles might sober the most blithe spirits, but, fortunately. they have had no daunting effect on Bob Bowyer and JoAnn Bruggeman, two young performers specializing exclusively in comic dance. Their company  featuring themselves, Scott Bryant and Marianne Claire  will be appearing this week in the Dance Umbrella series at the new Camera Mart/ Stage One theater on West 54th Street.

title: Must BlackJewish Relations Erode?
description: THE number of articles and letters to the editor regarding the dismissal of Andrew Young as chief United States delegate to the United Nations would undoubtedly fill an auditorium.

title: Big Bay de Noc Scores, at Least
description: Ron Collins scored on a 1yard plunge to end Big Bay de Noc's scoreless streak, but the team from Cooks, Mich., still suffered its 25th consecutive loss, losing to North Dickinson High, 348.

title: Soviet TVBetter Packaging for The Party Line
description: Moscow Dmitry Andreyevich Golovanov, deputy director of the Soviet Union's major television news program, picked up the telephone at his desk and let out a stricken cry: What do you mean there's no live footage? We filmed it. didn't we?

title: THE POISONING OF THE INDIAN WATERS
description: On the outskirts of the modern world in northwestern Quebec, some 500 miles to the north of Montreal, rows of recently constructed prefabricated houses meet at suburban right angles on streets waiting to be paved. These are the houses of the Waswanipi band of Cree, a community of some 1,000 Indians, whose settlement is, for now, the last outpost before the imposing wilderness of James Bay.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: Ticknor & Fields

title: His Orchestra Grows in Brooklyn
description: It was about 10 years ago, Lukas Foss reckons, that his doubts about the continued usefulness of the symphony orchestra reached peak proportions. As one of America's prominent composers, he had seen his music evolve from tonal, neoclassical beginnings to wild avantgardist excursions bearing little discernible relationship to the mainstream symphonic repertory. As conductor of the Buffalo Philharmonic, he had subjected audiences to bristling doses of Luciano Berio, John Cage and Karlheinz Stockhausen  hardcore contemporary programing not everyone appreciated. Meanwhile, the Buffalo orchestra was riddled by spiraling deficits, and so were others elsewhere in the United States. Artistically and financially, the symphony, at least as traditionally constituted, seemed on the brink of bankruptcy to Mr. Foss. And he was not the only American composer who thought so.

title: S.I. Jewelry Store Robbed
description: Burglars took $75,000 in assorted jewelry from a Staten Island store this weekend, the police said yesterday. The police said the Royal Jewelry Store, at 1537 Forest Ave, in the Port Richmond section, was entered through the roof sometime between 9 P.M. Friday, when the shop closed, and 9:30 A.M. yesterday. The theft was discovered by the shop's owner, Henrietta Rosen.

title: ProCastro Cubans in Puerto Rico Are Terrorists Target
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 20 (UPI)  The thousands of Cubans who fled Fidel Castro's revolution 20 years ago to settle in Puerto Rico have compensated for their uprooted lives by tenaciously sticking together.

title: Mr. Fixit of Northern Telecom
description: MONTREAL  The year was 1962 and Robert C. Scrivener, vice president for finance at Bell Canada, the country's largest telephone company, had just been assigned to see if anything could be salvaged from the utility's equipmentmaking subsidiary, the Northern Electric Company.

title: Talmadge's Backers Plan Dinner For Reelection Campaign Effort
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 20 (AP)  Backers of Senator Herman E. Talmadge, the Georgia Democrat whom the Senate last week voted to denounce for alleged financial misconduct, plan a $1,000aplate dinner next month in Washington to raise money for his reelection campaign.

title: Panel May Ask Rollback Of Social Security Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  A federally appointed advisory panel will soon recommend that Congress rescind most or all of the scheduled 1981 increase in the Social Security payroll tax, according to officials familiar with the panel's findings.

title: Chemical Spill Evicts Residents
description: HOLLISTER, Mo., Oct. 20 (AP) Residents near this Ozarks community returned home today after cleanup teams removed a toxic chemical spilled by a truck on busy highway U.S. 65. When the tractortrailer rig overturned last night, the authorities blocked off the highway and asked residents within a twosquaremile area to leave their homes. The truck, loaded with six 6,900pound bins of powdery phosphorous pentasulfide, overturned on a curve. Three of the bins were cracked and some of the chemical was spilled.

title: Kurds Said to Control City in Northwest Iran After Heavy Fighting
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 20 (Reuters) Residents of Mehabad in northwest Iran said Kurdish rebels were in control of most of the city tonight after heavy fighting in which they destroyed Government tanks and captured the radio station.

title: MISSING ARGENTINA
description: A woman in Buenos Aires holds up a photo of a missing relative.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: STATE transportation officials are worried about the weather because repairs have not been completed on thousands of potholes that followed last winter. A repeat of the severe freezethaw cycles that were the rule early this year would ruin more than 500 roadpatching and resurfacing projects completed since last spring, the officials said.

title: Hooked on Hook ern Horns
description: ON'T ask me how, but in four years of living in Austin, Tex., my husband and missed every football game the University of Texas played. Call it character. Call it boredom. Call it blindness.

title: Strange Gets Lead on 62
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Oct. 20 (AP) Curtis Strange shot a 10underpar 62, a course record, and took the lead after three rounds of the $200,000 Pensacola open golf tournament today.

title: Cheatin Or Hurtin
description: OF all the intricate ways Americans manage segregate themselves from one another, segregation by musical taste can be one of the most uncompromising, if least harmful. People who enjoy Bach and Beethoven won't listen to Tony Bennett or Frank Sinatra. People who worship Charlie Parker and Dave Brubeck can't abide the Jefferson Airplane

title: Pamela M. McCain Bride in Missouri
description: Pamela Meade McCain, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Meade M. McCain of Webster Groves, Mo., was married yesterday to Bradford Putnam Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew O. Miller of Key Biscayne, Fla., formerly of Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. Paul Davis performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church in Webster Groves.

title: GARDENING
description: VINES are a much overlooked element in the landscape. Trained over an arbor, they will provide cool shade during the summer. On a fence or trellis, they may be used as a screen for privacy or to block out an unpleasant view. Used against a masonry or stone wall, they will soften its starkness and provide a pleasant contrast in texture. Growing on the trunk of a tree, they become nature's equivalent of a ball gown.

title: State of Press Freedom In Americas Set Back, Yearly Survey Reports
description: TORONTO, Oct. 20 (AP)  Freedom of the press faces a somber situation in the Western Hemisphere and has suffered setbacks even in the United States, the Inter American Press Association said this week.

title: A Pilgrim's Tour Of Old Churches In East Anglia
description: Few American travelers to England  even those who have explored beyond the London-Stratford-CambridgeCanterbury circuit  ever venture into what is one of its loveliest and least spoiled areas, that expanse of farm, marshland and fen known as East Anglia. The ancient kingdom of the East Angles, which today comprises the counties of Suffolk and Norfolk, was the last region of England to be subjugated by the Norman invaders and something of its fierce independence still lingers in country villages and hamlets. They seem virtually to have ignored the industrial revolution of the 18th and 19th centuries.

title: Air of Independence
description: NO matter who is elected Suffolk County Executive in November, he is not going to have a bunch of yes men down the hall at the legislative branch. Suffolk legislators have tasted independence these last few years and they want more.

title: State Commissioner Wins Praise From Both Sides
description: TRENTON  Opposition by environmental and commuter groups helped kill transportation bond issues in New Jersey three times  in 1972, 1974 and 1975. If a new, $475 million issue is passed on Election Day next month, a lot of the Credit may be due Louis J. Gambaccini, the Transportation Commissioner who has been tireless as a spokesman before those same opponents. If he hasn't always won endorsements (and he has in some cases), he has been able to keep the lid on outright opposition.

title: World News Briefs
description: GABORONE, Botswana, Oct. 20 (Reuters)  Botswanans voted today in their third general election since independence from Britain in 1965, and Sir Seretse Khama's Botswana Democratic Party seemed certain to retain its unbroken rule.

title: Inside Lotto Central
description: WHITE PLAINS URING any given week, about 400,000 Lotto tickets are sold in New York. Up until Saturday night, each game filled out on one of the cards has the same chance of winning a prize in the parimutuel numbers game for its hopeful buyer, because the list of six winning numbers has not yet been chosen. And every Friday, every Lotto card, each still worth anywhere from nothing to half a million dollars, is on its way to a single collection point, a squarish, twostory, beigebrick building at 240 Westchester Avenue in White Plains.

title: Donna L. Jarosak Bride Of Lieut. Peter H. Liotta
description: Donna Lee Jarosak, daughter of Mrs. Virginia Jarosak and Stephen Jarosak, both of Brooklyn, was married there yesterday to Lieut. Peter Hearns Liotta, U.S.A.F., son of Col. Robert G. Liotta U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Liotta of Al Khobar, Saudi Arabia, and Lawton, Okla. The ceremony was performed in St. Edmund's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Marcellus Liotta, an uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Jane A. Johnston Is Bride of Clifford Balkam
description: Jane A. Johnston, an assistant professor of nursing at the Catholic University of America in Washington, and Clifford R. Balkam, a staff resources specialist at the American University in Washington, were married yesterday morning in the Gate of Heaven Roman Catholic Chapel in Roscoe, N.Y. The Rev. Alan Mitchell performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Revs. William McPeak and John Baldovin.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: New Approaches to the Heroic
description: WHEN we think of the heroic in art, we usually think of specific works. A monumental goldandivory statue of an Olympian deity by Phidias might spring to mind, or a soaring Gothic cathedral or perhaps Michelangelo's Sistine ceiling. These are ex

title: Mississippian Backs Connally
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP)  Senator Thad Cochran, Republican of Mississippi, today endorsed John B. Connally for the 1980 Republican Presidential nomination.
