He said the former Texas Governor could provide forceful, decisive leadership in the White House. Senator Cochran issued his endorsement at a Connally campaign barbecue and rally in Adrian, Ga.

title: Susan Bitner, M.R. Weaver Are Married
description: Holy Trinity Lutheran Church was the setting here at noon yesterday for the marriage of Susan Franklin Bitner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lynn N. Bitner of Hilton Head Island, S.C., to Michael Ritner Weaver, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Ritner Weaver of Orange, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. A. James Laughlin.

title: Soviet Cuts Arms Aid in Favor of Economic Pledges
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  Sovietbloc military aid commitments to less developed countries dropped sharply last year, while pledges of economic aid soared to unprecedented levels, a tally published this week by the Central Intelligence Agency showed.

title: Cairo Crash Kills About 30
description: CAIRO, Oct. 20 (Reuters)  About 30 people were killed early today and about 25 were injured in the collision of a a passenger train and a bus at a grade crossing here, the police said. Most of the casualties were in the bus.

title: Sweden Considers Letting Children Divorce Parents
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 18  A blueribbon Swedish Government committee on children's rights has recommended that children here be permitted to divorce their parents.

title: Sullivan Helps Yale Rout Columbia, 377
description: Yale's offense came out from the shadow of the nationally ranked Eli defense yesterday and racked up 489 yards in a 377 shellacking of Columbia before a crowd of 7,350 at Baker Field.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: RUNNING DOG, by Don DeLillo. (Vintage, $2.95.) When a seedy, genteel dealer in erotic bric-a-brac, about to sell an extraordinary film about Hitler's last hours, is found murdered in a deserted spot in Manhattan, a frantic scramble of Mafioso, intelligence agents, journalists and other folk on the make is set in motion. Michael Wood, our reviewer, called this a very funny novel, a skillful exhibition of landscapes,

title: INTEGRATION DELAY SEEN IN CHICAGO SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  The Government's decision to sue the city of Chicago to force an end to alleged widespread school segregation may enaole the city to forestall further desegregation at least five more years while it is protected from Federal sanctions under the appeals process.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: Continued from I'uge 54 few days before the military junta officially deposed Isabel Peron, Noni's husband, Adrian Saidon, also 24 years old, was gunned down in the street when he did not obey the command to halt. His body was never recovered.

title: When a Jury of One Makes Selections
description: SOUTHAMPTON WHEN viewing juried exhibitions, the public and rejected artists alike must take into account the fact that the selection process involves a series of compromises between a group of jurors  the more jurors, the greater the number of compromises. This can result in a muddled, unfocused show that does little justice to the artists represented or the institutional sponsor.

title: Birth Notice 1 -- No Title
description: Births

title: Religious Group's Plan for Subsidized Housing Debated in Suffolk
description: ROCKY POINT PLANS of a religious coalition to build at least 200 units of federally subsidized housing or low and moderateincome families on 40 acres of farmland opposite the Joseph A. Edgar Elementary School on Route 25A here are causing some community opposition.

title: IN THE NATION A Substitute Disaster
description: No wonder Secretary of the Treasury G. William Miller has repudiated the view that the current recession already is past its halfway point. If that ever was true, Chairman Paul Volcker and the Federal Reserve Board have made certain that it no longer is.

title: Marriage Announcement 13 -- No Title
description: Engagements

title: U.S. Loses on Bias Suit On Chicago Fire Dept.
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (AP)  The Federal Government has lost a sixyear court battle in which it tried to prove that Chicago's Fire Department had given white firefighters a better chance at promotions than nonwhite firefighters.

title: WASHINGTON Dealing With the Russians
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  When the U.S. Ambassador to the Soviet Union, Malcolm Toon, left his post in Moscow the other day for the last time, he indulged himself in a gesture most retiring ambassadors or journalists in that forbidding capital would understand. On his way out, he slammed the door.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: The alternative space or unstandardized arena is very much with us, all over the world. In London or Paris it is taken for granted that some of the best theater may be going on in n locomotive shed or a skating rink. If we want to see modern dance in

title: Jazz: 2 Big Names Please Princeton
description: PRINCETON

title: Scabies in West Forces Rescue of Wild Sheep
description: SANTA FE, N.M., Oct 20 (AP) Seventy desert bighorn sheep will be evacuated from the San Andres Mountains next month in an effort to save them from a scabies epidemic that has claimed about twothirds of the herd.

title: Gilles's Run Is Decisive
description: Undefeated Ramapo picked up its fourth victory yesterday by defeating Tatman Zee. 157.

title: A Capital Visit From Mr. Schpiedlweiser
description: Multinational corporations have many foreign visitors. The company work for is based in Switzerland, and whenever the biggies from the home country come to visit, this becomes

title: Where New Playwrights Take Center Stage
description: Where have all the new playwrights gone? Certainly not to Broadway where, with the significant exception of The Elephant Man, the theatrical clock has been turned back several decades. No, certainly not to Broadway, where the season's first big success is Sugar Babies, a nostalgic evocation of the hoary charms of burlesque.

title: Kennedy to Tap Key Aides From 3 Presidential Races in 80 Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  Senator Edward M. Kennedy's top Presidential campaign staff will combine key figures from different political generations and traditions. They will include his brotherinlaw, Stephen Smith, from the 1960 race, and Richard G. Stearns and Carl Wagner from the 1968 and 1972 Democratic campaigns.

title: Disabled Blaze New Trails In the Wilds
description: Day One

title: Notes
description: Travelers who find that it is time to renew their passports might consider getting a world passport in addition to a regular United States passport.

title: 3 MILE ISLAND PERIL REPORTED NI1IIIIELD BY AIDES AT REACTOR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  Federal investigators have obtained testimony indicating that some supervisors at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant fully comprehended on the first day of the reactor accident there that the possible consequences were more serious than they were reporting to the Government.

title: Basques, Catalans Will Vote This Week
description: MADRID  In referendums this week, the Basques and their nextdoor neighbors in northern Spain, the Catalans, are expected to approve home rule for their prosperous regions. Both will be breaking with four decades of Francoite centralism, but the similarity stops there.

title: NEW JERSEY ROUSING
description: LTHOUGH the event itself took only 30 minutes and the ending was somewhat anticlimactic, the recent auction of a highly unusual house in this Morris County community showed that there is no dearth of creativity in homeselling techniques these days.

title: Ford Decision Not to Run Relief to Senator Baker
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate Republican leader, said today that he was relieved and delighted by former President Ford's decision not to run for President and that he hoped it would improve his chances of winning the Republican nomination.

title: SEOUL ORDERS ARMY TO MAINTAIN ORDER IN TWO MORE CITIES
description: PUSAN, South Korea, Oct. 20  President Park Chung Hee put his army in charge of the industrial cities of Masan and Changwon today, officially extending military control outside Pusan for the first time since violent student demonstrations started in the region this week.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: ENDS PARIS VISIT: Hua Guofeng, Prime Minister of China, in the French capital yesterday. Today, he leaves France for West Germany, continuing his tour of Europe.

title: Baylor Overwhelms Army, 550
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 20  Baylor erupted for three touchdowns within 2 minutes 18 seconds early in the game and went on to rout Army, 550, at Michie Stadium before 32,591 fans today.

title: Brown Beats Cornell, 287; Defense Excels
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 20 Around the Ivy League, the BrownCornell football game today was regarded as a battle of the behemoths. But Brown turned out to be the only giant.

title: Marlene Pennison Taps Universal Vein
description: Very few choreographers today bother with character studies, but Marlene Pennison proved a master of the form Friday night at her concert in a thirdfloor loft at 117 Hudson Street, between Moore and Franklin Streets.

title: POLITICS
description: SOME politicians chuckled when State Senator Joseph R. Pisani of New Rochelle announced his candidacy for the 1982 Republican gubernatorial nomination about three years ahead of time. The timing made Jimmy Carter, who started running for President in late 1974, look like a late bloomer.

title: Mingus Dynasty Band Keeps Bassist's Sound Alive
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  Charles Mingus fans gathered recently at the Bayou, a club on the Georgetown waterfront, to hear the Mingus Dynasty Band  a sevenman ensemble of the Minguses closest musician friends  play the music of the renowned jazz composer, band leader and virtuoso bassist who died last January at the age of 56.

title: Holmdel Prevails, 1614
description: Mark Buczynski blocked a punt and then tackled the St. John Vianney kicker, Greg Golden, in the end zone for a safety to help Holmdel (401) down previously undefeated St. John, 1614, at Holmdel. The safety gave Holmdel a 97 lead and, moments later, Chris Leila ran s yards for what proved to be the decisive touchdown. Del Johnson ran 8 yards for Holmdel's first score. St. John (91) got its points on Tom Deits's 95yard touchdown pass to Bill Cowley and Don Corrigan's 1yard scoring run.

title: Clark Moves Slowly to Impose His Views on Canada
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 20  They no longer refer to him as Joe Who? but since Charles Joseph Clark became Prime Minister a little over four months ago, he has moved slowly in imposing his views on Canada.

title: Eisenhower Reported To Have Taped Talks In Secret in His Office
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 20 (AP)  For at least five years President Eisenhower secretly recorded conversations in the Oval Office of the White House, including one in which he criticized his Vice President, Richard M. Nixon, The Houston Chronicle reported today.

title: Colorado Sect Ready to Give Up Cars to Keep Faith
description: PUEBLO, Colo., Oct. 20 (UPI) Laycher Gonzales says that, if they must, members of his religious sect will give up their automobiles and return to the horse and buggy rather than have their pictures taken to obtain Colorado driver's licenses.

title: Tenants Are Fighting A Rise in Conversions To Condominium Use
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  A right to rent movement is gaining momentum among urban dwellers around the country as more and more rental housing is converted to occupantowned condominium or cooperative status, bringing profits to financially troubled landlords and grief to displaced renters.

title: Teacher Evaluation, A System in Dispute
description: CONECTICUT'S teacher evaluation law, five years in the development stage, begins functioning in earnest this year  with strong support from education officials but with reservations from some teachers and their unions.

title: A State purvey Finds Physical Education Lagging for Children
description: Four of every five elementary schools in New York State did not meet the statelegislated minimum requirements for physical education activity last year, according to a State Education Department study.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: For weeks, oil buyers have been puzzled: The worldwide shortage of crude oil that sent prices soaring on the international market earlier this year seemed to be over. After all, inventories, have been rebuilding nicely throughout the industrial countries. Yet prices on the open, or spot, market, have not only remained high but have started climbing again.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: WHEN officials of Yale University discovered on Sept. 28 that the gold and silver gilt president's collar was missing from its wooden case in the vault at Woodbridge Hall, there was some speculation that it might be a prank. But no more.

title: Urban Origins
description: FROM the earliest colonial period there were cities in the American wilderness that preceded the agrarian frontier. If they were not truly urban, apart from Boston and other seaboard cities, they were nevertheless compact, vigorous settlements, often walled or protected by a fort, and nearly always laid out on a grid, without much regard for natural terrain or architectural niceties. This pattern continued across the Alleghenies and the Mississippi, and northward from the long chain of Hispanic pueblos, presidios and missions between the Gulf Coast and California. Without such strong points to serve as markets and supply bases, even when military protection was no longer necessary, neither farming nor mining could flourish. The Gold Rush, like the agricultural wealth of the Central Valley, would have been impossible without the instant port metropolis of San Francisco, inland cities such as Sacramento, and the rough, crowded encampments  hardly pastoral  of the Mother Lode.

title: Jane Harrison Wed To Philip Embury
description: Jane Cary Harrison and Philip Aymar Embury, who are horse trainers in Middleburg, Va., were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Millwood, Va. The Rev. E. Guthrie Brown performed the ceremony.

title: Article -- No Title
description: The World Continued

title: A Party for the Pike? Too Little, Too Soon
description: NEW JERSEYANS working in Washington and nostalgic for their home state held a party here last week and, needing theme, decided that the 30th birthday of the New Jersey Turnpike would be just fine.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Commenting on the article of Andree Brooks concerning town and gown relations at Fairfield Beach, Fairfield [Town vs. Gown at Fairfield Beach, Oct. 7], I respond in my capacity as chairman of the Fairfield Zoning Board of Appeals. The article is well written and adequately describes the longtime problems we have on the beach. However, it is not true that the town has not acted almost daily to find solutions.

title: Letters by Eleanor Roosevelt Detail Friendship With Lorena Hickok
description: HYDE PARK, N.Y.  A correspondence consisting of more than 3,000 letters between Eleanor Roosevelt and Lorena Hickok, a reporter and author, provides new insights into the former First Lady's life and reveals the intimate nature of a friendship between the two women that went on for 30 years, until Mrs. Roosevelt's death in 1962.

title: U.S. Collegians Triumph In Cuba Baseball Tourney
description: HAVANA, Oct. 20 (AP)  Behind the onehit pitching of Clemson's Mike Brown, the United States collegiate baseball team defeated Puerto Rico last night, 21, and raised its wonlost record to 31 in Cuba's international tournament.

title: U.S.Canadian Pact on Air Quality Reported Near
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 20  Talks are expected to begin soon between the United States and Canada on an air quality agreement that would ease the damage the two countries are wreaking on each other's lakes, forests and farmlands.

title: Design
description: The site was stunning but seemingly impossible to build on: a patch of land on the ridge of a mountain range south of San Francisco. Ripped by 100mileanhour winds that drive rain up the hillsides with the force of a firehose, the lot is adjacent to a scenic highway, so any plans for prospective structures had to be approved by an architectural review board whose mandate was to keep the view unsullied. Still, for five years the owner, California attorney George Norton, held onto the land and his hopes that one day he'd live up there.

title: How Six Preis On
description: NIVERSITY presses, those staid processors scholarship that boast big theories and drowsy sales, came upon especially bumpy times the early 1970's. Many floundered; some were wiped out. Caught between shrinking income and rising costs, they found it necessary to move into new,areas and change their ways. The Book Review contacted the directors of the university presses of Harvard, Johns Hopkins, Notre Dame, Princeton, Chicago and California to see what they were up to.

title: City Has Plan to Upgrade Section of Williamsburg
description: A broad program of housing rehabilitation and commercial revitalization was proposed last week by the Department of City Planning for one of Brooklyn's historic communities, the Southside section of Williamsburg.

title: THIS WEEK IN SPORTS
description: BASKETBALL

title: AIR PERMIT NEARING
description: After a recess of almost one year, hearings have been scheduled for Oct. 31 on the air pollution permit required by the Westway highway project.

title: A Sweeping Structure Symbolizes Years of Promise
description: BOSTON  The years of John F. Kennedy's Presidency were years of hope, of promise, of an almost unquestioning faith in the ability of technology and human intelligence to assure a noble future. It is an attitude that is far less characteristic of American culture today, yet it seems to have been recaptured, strikingly, in the new John Fitzgerald Kennedy Library here.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Amendment to provide emergency fuel assistance funds to be transferred to the Director of the Community Services Administration, rejected, 47 to 43, Oct. 15.

title: THE CHEEVER CHRONICLE
description: At a dinner party a decade ago, a television executive leaned over to John Cheever to explain why, despite Cheever's reputation in literary circles, he would never be financially successful on the grand scale. The thing is. John, you have no image, the man said, with an urgency which suggested that Cheever might do well to rush out and acquire one. John Cheever was so frequently broke during those years that he often spent Christmas week painting his children's bedrooms in lieu of worldlier gifts, and he thought this was a potentially valuable suggestion. He still does. It was just not a particularly useful suggestion for a writer who, back when he was 12, was given his parents permission to write for a living only after he had promised: 1 have no idea of becoming famous or wealthy.

title: Marriages
description: LOUGHRANSASSON

title: Sydney Maree: Apartheid in Reverse
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 20 Sydney Maree, one of the two or three best mile runners in the world, is a victim of apartheid in reverse. The Villanova junior is a South African, and because the world sports community has ostracized South Africa in hope of persuading the Government to abandon its policy of separate and unequal status for blacks, he is barred from international competition. Maree, who can do a mile in 3:53, may represent his university

title: In Iowa, Central Bids Crank Phones Goodbye
description: DES MOINES, Oct. 20 (AP)  Another slice of Americana is leaving the Middle West: The last crank telephone system has been voted out of Iowa.

title: ANTIQUES
description: What may well go down in history as the age of the American desk begins with rolltops, ends with flat tops, and sandwiched in between are what some people view as the most important designs of all  the handcrafted classics of Gustav Stickley and some of his contemporaries. Just what these are, and the role they played from the turn of the century to World War I, may be seen in a small but choice exhibition, The Arts and Crafts Desk: A Study in Style and Function 19001915. The show opened Wednesday and remains through November at the JordanVolpe Gallery, 457 West Broadway.

title: Sherlock's Devoted Mom
description: This month is the 100th anniversary of the events in The Musgrave Ritual, the Sherlock Holmes story in which Watson complains that Holmes was in his personal habits one of the most untidy men that ever drove a fellow lodger to distraction. Roommates who endure one's peccadilloes are still to be found, but what lodging house would allow such a tenant as Holmes?

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: IF Thomas T. Vaughan, the newly appointed Suffolk County Legislator from Lindenhurst, is defeated in November's election, he will undoubtedly have held the shortest legislative term on record.

title: Carter and Kennedy Share Stage at Library Dedication
description: BOSTON, Oct. 20  President Carter, sharing the stage with Senator Edward M. Kennedy and two generations of the Kennedy family, praised the late John F. Kennedy today as a symbol of human aspirations and poked a little fun at the Presidential aspirations of his younger brother.

title: Six Armed Men Rob Store on 5th Avenue; One Suspect Arrested
description: Six armed men forced their way into the Lane Bryant department store at 465 Fifth Avenue as employees were reporting for work yesterday morning and stole an undetermined amount of money, the police said.

title: ART VIEW
description: The career of Paul Outerbridge (18961959) is one of the most interesting in the entire history of American photography. At once a dandy, a playboy and an esthete, he was also a highly accomplished technician. (In 1940, he published a book about Photographing in Color, based on his own Technicolor experiments.) Many of his best photographs of the 20's  his most creative decade  are pure distillations of the Cubist esthetic, which he applied to photography with a good deal of originality and success. Yet, the purity of form we find in those pictures was, for Outerbridge, only one interest among many. His versatility, amounting at times to a sheer lack of direction, was as remarkable as the talent he sometimes squandered on meretricious goals.

title: The Friendly Stranger
description: IN recent years the United States may have led the world in massmurderers, but it hasn't had a monopoly on them, as Serpentine, Thomas Thompson's account of the career of a Vietnamese-Indian psychopath, makes clear. From 1972 until 1976, when he was arrested, this man, Charles Sobhraj, and various accomplices were almost certainly responsible for 12 killings and perhaps as many as 24. Nearly all of their victims were Western visitors to the Indian subcontinent and Thailand. However, Sobhraj has been convicted of only one murder, in New Delhi, for which he began serving a sevenyear sentence in August 1978.

title: Miss Howard To Wed Dec. 8
description: Alison Barr Howard, an interior designer, and Robert Mark Blumenfeld, an associate of the corporate finance group of Fahnestock & Company, investment brokers, will be married Dec. 8 in St. James Episcopal Church. mrs. llavid Muss of New York and Frank Atherton Howard Jr. of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of M. E. Blumenfeld of Savannah, Ga., and the late Helen Davidson Blumenfeld.

title: Tenants Fight Battle To Save Apartments
description: I KNOW things like this happen in the South Bronx, but I didn't think it could happen in Westchester, Helen Verona said last week as she sat in her condemned, unheated apartment in Mount Vernon.

title: Seeds of South Korean Protest Were Sown by New Prosperity
description: PUSAN, South Korea  Martial law was declared in Pusan last week, after the worst street riots by students in the 18 years since the authoritarian exgeneral, Park Chung Hee, came to power in a coup d'tat.

title: Democrats in Montana Challenge Party's Rules
description: HELENA, Mont., Oct. 20 (AP)  Montana Democrats have asked the State Supreme Court to find that the national party's rules on selection of Presidential convention delegates violate state law and the constitutional rights of voters.

title: DINING OUT
description: HARTFORD ITALIANfood enthusiasts can have a field day in the bakeries and restaurants on Franklin Avenue here. One of the halfdozen or so restaurants on the street is Boccaccio's, a small place that offers good value.

title: Three Big Museums Give Chicago a Cultural Lakefront
description: Sandburg's City of the Big Shoulders? Indeed it is. The nation's transportation hub? Certainly. The Windy City? Without a doubt. But a museum center? Yes. Chicago is that, too. The three principal museums would make the city a rewarding place to visit even if it had no other attractions for tourist and conventioneer.

title: Deng Seeks Return of Taiwan
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 20 (Reuters) China's senior Deputy Prime Minister, Deng Xiaoping, has urged nonCommunist partisans and former Chinese capitalists with contacts on Taiwan to work for Taiwan's return to the country, the New China News Agency reported today.

title: DownestoRielly Passes Lead John Glenn Victory
description: Jerry Downes passed to Jim Rielly for two touchdown in the second half to lead undefeated John Glenn of Huntington (50) to a 192 Suffolk Conference III victory over Harborfields. Downes completed 9 of 21 passes for 135 yards and Rielly made three of the receptions for 70 yards.

title: Whippany Park Wins
description: Four players joined in the scoring as undefeated Whippany Park (50) cruised to a 246 victory over Chatham Township at Chatham. Chatham Township dropped to 131. Eric Graupner ran 22 yards in the first period, and Ken Webb, who later had a 24yard field goal, kicked the placement. John Larkins returned the secondhalf kickoff 90 yards for a touchdown, and Kevin Ellis ran 8 yards in the third period for the other Whippany Park scores. Kevin Eidt ran 1 yard for Chatham Township's touchdown.

title: Ukrainian, Home Again, Tells of Woes in Buffalo
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 16  A Soviet industrial paper has published an article about a Ukrainian family who emigrated to Buffalo, N.Y., only to be driven back to the Soviet Union by what were depicted as low wages, high rents, high medical costs and other woes.

title: CAMERA
description: What can a photographer do when a vacation trip is over and the 35mm slides that come back from the processor include many key shots which are overexposed or tinted with strange hues, or are otherwise distorted in color?

title: New Providence on Top
description: Mike Darling carried 27 times for 77 yards and scored both touchdowns as New Providence beat Caldwell, 136, at New Providence in a battle of undefeated teams. Darling ran 1 yard for a firstperiod score and Jeff Cross kicked the conversion. l:attlwell mane it 76 just before halftime on Tom Bryant's 36yard pass to Glenn Mastey. Darling's 5yard run early in the fourth period gave New Providence its final margin.

title: THE MARKETS
description: The stock market cooled off for most of last week as the selling spree that convulsed Wall Street in the proceeding week evaporated. However, on Friday prices dropped sharply as fears of yet higher interest rates prompted selling pressure.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A photograph of Paul Outerbridge's SelfPortrait in today's Arts and Leisure section should be credited to the Gilman Paper Company collection.

title: BRIDGE
description: Sponsorship of expert teams takes different forms on opposite sides of the Atlantic. In the United States it is common for a wealthy player to hire an expert group who can help him to win a coveted title. In Europe commercial organizations are apparently willing to finance an expert team in a major tournament.

title: Kenya Leader Asks Africans to Overcome Divisions
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 20  President Daniel arap Moi today called on African nations to overcome their ideological differences and work harder for the political and economic unity of the continent.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Strande Alliances
description: When Pope John Paul II and Fidel Castro used their command of the virtually undivided attention of the news media to enter pleas for the world's poor, they agreed at least on the diagnosis of the problem.

title: The Romanticism of the Beatles Lives On
description: Plans for the Beatles to reunite this fall for a benefit performance under the auspices of the United Nations do not seem, so far, to have materialized. Maybe they were nothing more than rumors in the first place. But if such concert was at one point a real possibility and one or more of the Fab Four finally scotched it, here's one guess why: They're afraid of the competition.

title: Arkansas Topples Texas, 1714
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 20 (AP)  Darryl Mason's tumbling touchdown reception and Ish Ordonez's fourthquarter field goal carried unbeaten Arkansas to a 1719 victory over Texas in a Southwest Conference football game today.

title: NBC Is Picketed In Fight Protest
description: Seventy demonstrators picketed NBC headquarters at Rockefeller Plaza yesterday to protest the network's coverage of the World Boxing Association heavyweight title bout between John Tate and Gerd Coetzee in South Africa. Representatives of black South African sport organizations participated in the demonstration.

title: GOVERNOR AND FINK SPLIT ON FUEL PLAN
description: A major rift has developed between Governor Carey and a fellow Democrat, Stanley Fink, the Speaker of the Assembly, over the political maneuvering that forced the Governor to accept a plan to repeal the sales tax on home fuel.

title: Sense and Nonsense Happily Wed
description: EAST FARMINGDALE

title: DINING OUT
description: THE Buffet de la Gare in HastingsonHudson is an ideal example of a restaurant that sets its own modest limits of price and ambition and operates within them with pride and considerable success. Simplicity is the ruling virtue here. The owners have left the two small rooms more or less as they found them. They are as unmistakably turnofthecentury American as the Hudson Line across the street  their walls and ceilings seemingly cut out of great rolls of stamped tin.

title: Auction Season Moves Into High Gear
description: The New York auction season has moved into high gear during the last 10 days with recordbreaking sales of 19thcentury paintings, Latin American art and jewelry.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: FOOTBALL

title: Woodman, Don't Spare That Tree
description: ONE of the biggest ripoffs in Connecticut history occurred with the passage of the Farmlands Preservation Act in 1978. Under this bill, the state buys development rights from farmers to keep their land as a farm or as undeveloped land forever. The result? Taxpayers are being bilked to the tune of $5 million just because a few powerhungry reactionaries have the silly notion that farms enhance the beauty of Connecticut.

title: Gerulaitis and Vilas Reach Indoor Final
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 20 (AP)  Topseeded Vitas Gerulaitis of the United States and Argentina's Guillermo Vilas, seeded No. 2, gained the final of the $175,000 Australian indoor tennis tournament at the Hordern Pavilion today.

title: The Nation
description: The larger lesson from this is that some of the reports of the political demise of the President are very greatly exaggerated, Jody Powell, Mr. Carter's press secretary, declared last week. By reading deep significance into the Florida strawvote (which gave Mr. Carter 508 delegates to a makebelieve convention scheduled for midNovember to Senator Edward M. Kennedy's 291), Mr. Powell appeared to be applying a degree of exaggeration himself. Ninetynine percent of the state's eligible Democrats had ignored the event.

title: Cynthia Phifer, An Architect, To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. John C. Phifer of BelAir, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Joan Phifer, to Benjamin Kracauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kracauer of Montreal. Plans have been made for Jan. 5 wedding at the Phifer home.

title: TelevisionThisWeek
description: Today

title: A Mystery: The Police Chief Case
description: PORT WASHINGTON THE fact that a Port Washington Police District Commissioner, Charles D. Murphy, permitted the district's Chief to remain in his job after he had failed a Civil Service test three times and was declared ineligible for the post is under investigation by the office of the Nassau County District Attorney, Denis E. Dillon.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Thirtyfour events, marking the 34th year of the existence of the United Nations, will have taken place around the state by the end of October, with the central focus at the University of Bridgeport, where Lord Caradon is conducting a residency and receives an honorary degree on United Nations Day this week.

title: Future Events
description: Lure of the East

title: CHESS
description: Resigned sighs, whoops of delight when the opponent misses a winning move, acrimonious selfcriticism, and smug descriptions of powerful positions  these will all be on the sound track of a series of halfhour television programs filmed by the British Broadcasting Corportion from its tournament here.

title: Incumbents Are Strong Favorites in Nassau
description: MINEOLA THE Republicans have the advantage of incumbency, registration, manpower and financial wealth, so they are rated strong favorites in the Nassau County election on Nov. 6. The Democrats, traditionally underfinanced and lacking in patronage workers, and with no gubernatorial or Presidential candidate to arouse their supporters, are hoping to spring upsets by asserting that Nassau bears the heaviest tax burden in the nation.

title: State Audit Criticizes City Hospitals Agency For Poor Bookkeeping
description: The State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, has accused the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation of sloppy recordkeeping that has held down the amount of money it has collected from Federal programs and delayed its bill collecting.

title: Laureine Knight Fiance Of David R. Greenbaum
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murray M. Knight of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laureine Knight, to David Roy Greenbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Greenbaum of Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Neighborhood Characters
description: OF late, whenever one encounters an urbanbased novel, especially one set in Manhattan (or worse yet, in Greenwich Village), it's oddson to be a claustrophobic affair; the activity is usually limited to treks to Bloomingdale's and smart bistros and the inner isometrics of pumping ego. By Vincent Patrick. 280 pp. New York: Seaview Books. S9.95.

title: ataroo
description: Memories. The Times They Are AChangin  were the words with which Bob Dylan won the hearts American youth back in 1963. Now, on the eve of the 1980's, Dylan's declaration seems to be timely once more. The last products of the postwar baby boom, the generation that came of age to the rock n roll Dylan and Elvis Presley, are old enough to be joining the Establishment. Rock may survive in altered forms, but the recent precipitous drop in record album sales and the failure of many concerts to sell out suggest that the end of an era has been reached and the old stars have become proper subjects for nostalgia. These thoughts are prompted by the essays with which Angie Errigo and Steve Leaning have larded The Illustrated History of Rock Album Art (Mayflower, $9.95), one of two handsome Justpublished paperbacks about the world that was rock. Through reproductions of the covers of some 200 albums, beginning with the matter-of-fact mug shots of the in the mid50s through the gimmick-and-joke efforts of Andy Warhol and others in the late 60's to the art-tor-art's sake efforts of the past few years, Miss Errigo and Mr. Leaning document the evolution of the unique form of pop art that pop music inspired. (The quintessential rock album cover reproduced to the right introduced the Beatles to British youth in 1963. The American cover, released the same year, was similar, but it was called Meet the Beatles.)

title: The World
description: China is seeking a new rule of law on the Western model. Last week, Peking got a scary idea of the possibilities inherent in the notion of a government of laws, not men  not even the President of the United States.

title: Bolivian Asks Extension of Term To Deal With Economic Troubles
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 20  Walter Guevara Arze, Bolivia's interim President, said today that his Government could not resolve a serious economic crisis unless Congress extends his term until 1981.

title: Danbury and Greenwich Copy Each Other's Style of Winning
description: Danbury and Greenwich posted comefrombehind victories yesterday to remain tied for the top spot in the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference Western Division.

title: TV VIEW The Rise of MadeforTV Films
description: Long an object of derision, the madeforTV movie finally beginning to get glimmers of appreciation. In early December, the form will be the principal subject of a film discussion in no less an august and tastesetting temple than New York's Museum Modern Art. Devised primarily as a schedulefiller, the form always exhibited promise, which occasionally was fulfilled in a Brian's Song or a Glass House or a The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman. More recently, there was Too Far to Go, based on a number of John Updike stories and featuring outstanding performances by Blythe Danner and Michael Moriarty. The TVmovie has provided a testing ground for new talent, spinning off to the more prestigious and remunerative boxoffice films such actors as John Savage and such directors as Steven Spielberg (Close Encounters of the Third Kind). For at least a decade, it has been a oneway artistic street, with talent getting a showcase on television and then moving on to the Art Film. Things are changing.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: THERE'S no law that says everybody has a right to place in the sun  but a national group of planners has suggested that something be done about that. In fact, there are towns and cities, including some in Westchester, where a place in the sun  for solarenergy equipment  is restricted by zoning laws and building codes, and some people, including public officials, think something ought to be done about that, too.

title: Thinking Big: P. T. Barnum on a Smaller Scale
description: I ALWAYS wanted to own a circus, says William R. Brinley when visitors inquire about his handcrafted miniature circus. As simple as that.

title: A Runner Sees Time Gaining on Him
description: HUNCINGTON WHEN the 10th annual New York City Marathon gets under way this morning, Gary Muhrcke of Huntington, winner of the first such race, back in 1970, may not be running in the best of spirits.

title: Jane Turano Bride Of James J. Lee Jr.
description: Jane Van Norman Turano, daughter of Mrs. Edward L Turano of Cedar Grove, N.J., and the late Mr. Turano, was married yesterday to James Joseph Lee Jr., son of Mr. Lee of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mary Kate Gilmore Lee. The ceremony was performed in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York by Msgr. James G. Wildem.

title: Congress Hasn't the Will To Update Social Policy
description: WASHINGTON  President Carter and, apparently, all members of Congress want to spend billions of dollars in the next several years to help poor people meet the skyrocketing cost of home heating. But legislation to accomplish that end has become so bogged down that little if any money will reach the poor in time for this winter's cold. It is typical of what is happening to social policy initiatives.

title: R. J. Levine Fianc Of Cindy B. Israel
description: Dr. and Mrs. Hyman Israel of West Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cindy Beth Israel, to Ronald Jay Levine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis L. Levine of North Valley Stream, L.I.

title: Miss FitzGerald Traces History of History Texts
description: We study history with the hope Leopold Von Ranke thought it too ambitious  that the past will instruct the present about the future. When we teach history to our children, on the other hand, we are using the past to instruct the future about the present.

title: Youth Stabbed to Death in Brawl
description: PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Oct. 20 (AP)  A cchtinuing rivalry between high school youths along the New YorkPennsylvania border erupted into a street brawl here last night, and a 15yearold Orange County youth was killed. A 16yearold Pike County, Pa., youth was charged today with murder.

title: Squirrel Is Blamed for Rail Fire
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 (AP) fire and explosion that caused an estimated $1 million in damage to an electric substation supplying power to railroad trains and delayed thousands of travelers Thursday was caused by a squirrel, an Amtrak spokesman said. We found the squirrel, Lois Morasco said yesterday. Its hair was totally burned off and there we had it  dead proof. The explosion and fire delayed 20 Amtrak trains and 60 to 70 commuter trains.

title: SPEEDING IS COSTLIER IN CONNECTICUT NOW
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 20  Like the price of everything else, the price of speeding is going up.

title: No One Conducted Stravinsky Like Stravinsky
description: There can be no doubt that Igor Stravinksy's warhorses have been flogged to death by the record companies: There are 31 versions of Le Sacre du Printemps on sale in the United States right now, according to the Schwann Catalogue  counting some multiple versions of the same performance in different packagings.

title: Assembly Races: Lots of Footwork
description: WITH no statewide contests on the ballot this November, New Jersey voters are learning about the various campaigns again from their doorsteps, not their television sets.

title: CRIME
description: In his first novel, THE NOVEMBER MAN (Fawcett. paper, $1.95), Bill Granger. who has been a reporter and was on assignment in Ireland for a while, has drawn upon his own experiences with the Irish problem. But this is far from a story about terrorists or ideals. Mr. Granger has other things in his background, and if the Central Intelligence Agency works the way the author suggests in this book, we had all better start doing something about it.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Stony Brook Taking A Broader Role in the Arts
description: STONY BROOK FORMALLY opening Wednesday with a Gala Week of special events, the new $21 million Fine Arts Center on the campus of the State University of New York here is bidding to move Stony Brook toward new status as a comprehensive university, and also to serve as a cultural center for the thousands of Long Islanders in the university's immediate area.

title: New Look, New Sound
description: THE rousing fanfare  glittering flourishes of brass  took the children by surprise. But then a sea of grins broke out among the 156 young faces gathered around the musicians in the gymnasium of the Alpine elementary school in Bergen County.

title: Wyoming Seminary Takes 28th
description: Doug Murphy took the opening kickoff 66yards for a touchdown and Wyoming Seminary went on to a 2915 victory yesterday over Williamson Trade. The Kingston, Pa., school ran its unbeaten streak to 28 games and is 50 this season; Williamson Trade lost its first game in five starts.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN plaster becomes loose or crumbly in sections, or when it is so loose that pieces actually fall off (often the case after a bad leak has occurred), patching it properly calls for complete removal of all the loose and defective plaster and building up the surface with new material.

title: Music Notes: Help From The Mayor
description: In the daytoday problems of running the city you can lose sight of some important matters, including the fact that New York is the capital of the arts in all its forms.

title: Rock: Roy Loney at Club
description: If you keep playing an unpopular style of popular music long enough, eventually it's likely to become popular again. Roy Loney, who opened a run at Hurrah on Thursday, started singing basic rock n roll with the Flamin Groovies around 1988, Just when that kind of music was going out of favor. He has continued to make music with strong rockabilly and rhythmandblues influences, with the Groovies and more recently with his new band, the Phantom Movers, and suddenly it's beginning to sound contemporary again.

title: Small Motels Are Flourishing Outside Manhattan
description: Driving along Northern Boulevard in Bayside, Queens, it is easy to miss the Anchor Motel, a twostory brick structure. There are no architectural flourishes here; no neon signs beckon. But the Anchor, with its 50 units, eight equipped with small kitchenettes, is usually 100 percent occupied.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: IT was a different kind of summer for me. I, a dyedinthewool New Yorker, did what I said I'd never do: I commuted. But commuting is a generous way of describing my daily travels.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Some writers get through frustrating moments by gnawing on pencils or simply abandoning their typewriters. Jerzy Kosinski copes by clawing at his desk. I go like this, he said, digging his nails into the long, deep gouges he has carved in his desk's surface.

title: No Such Places
description: CITING Nietzsche (only that which has no history can be defined), Frank and Fritzie Manuel begin this spectacular treatise on utopianism by refusing to provide a tidy definition their subject. They prefer to think of it not as a definable idea or cluster of ideas, but as an everchanging, By Frank E. Manuel and Fritzie P. Manuel. Illustrated. 896 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press. $25. ambiguous product of a recurring mental act. Since the Renaissance, many of the most gifted Western intellectuals.  including More, Bruno, Comenius, Bacon, Leibniz, Rousseau, Condorcet, Kant, Comte, Marx  have exhibited a striking utopian propensity, and the Manuels set out to describe and, if possible, explain that curious habit of mind. The result is work of monumental scope, written with authority, wit and unfailing lucidity. Utopian Thought in the Western World challenges received ideas about an entire mode of expression and, by implication, about creativity itself.

title: Hofstra Sends Pace To First Defeat, 217
description: George Muller was a oneman show yesterday afternoon in leading Hofstra University to a 217 victory over previously undefeated but oncetied Pace University.

title: When an Actress Goes It Alone
description: GREAT NECK ASPIRANTS to the theater may still be drawn to the bright lights of Broadway, but, according to Shirley Blanc Romaine, the most eager audiences are waiting in the suburbs.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN plaster becomes loose or crumbly in sections, or when it is so loose that pieces actually fall off (often the case after a bad leak has occurred), patching it properly calls for complete removal of all the loose and defective plaster and building up the surface with new material.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: Dego Goldberg Sygma

title: FollowUp on the News
description: How did the metal get in the mozzarella? That, said Kraft Inc., was what it and the Food and Drug Administration were trying to determine as the company announced last Aug. 27 the recall of 36,492 packets of the cheese. Bits of aluminum had been found in packet in New York State. The recall affected 11 states in the East and Puerto Rico.

title: MISSING OR DEAD IN ARGENTINA
description: Since the military took over the government in 1976, thousands of Argentiniansdesaparecidos have vanished without a trace, caught up in a vast and brutal dragnet against 'subversion.

title: Late TV Listings
description: Noon (Channel 2) Newsmakers Bruce C. Ratner, Commissioner of Consumer Affairs.

title: Natural Universe
description: In this, her fourth book, Jean Valentine often begins her poems with concrete particulars (rendered in clean, stark lines) that she invokes like spells or mantra to enliven her meditations. From these, human correlations are induced

title: Wedding Set By Miss Duffy
description: Christine Duffy and David M. Rogers, cum laude graduates of Harvard University, will be married next August in Millburn, N.J. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John F. Duffy of Linden, N.J. Mr. Rogers is son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan J. Rogers of East Rockaway, L.I.

title: Chinese Moslems on Pilgrimage
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 20 (Reuters)  The first group of Chinese Moslems to make a pilgrimage to Mecca since the Cultural Revolution left Peking for Saudi Arabia yesterday, according to the New China News Agency.

title: How Funk Grew Up
description: To many and perhaps most of its casual fans, funk is simply a heavily rhythmic dance music played mostly by black musicians. Unlike disco, which to a certain extent derives from it, funk doesn't usually have a smooth, pretty surface. Disco creates a sonic wonderland of strings, brass, electronics and voices over a dance groove; in funk, the groove is just about everything. But while such singleminded devotion to bodily movement may not sound like very fertile ground for the development of artistry, funk has become, in the late 1970's, the chosen idiom of some of the most talented and creative contemporary pop musicians. It has also spawned its own orthodoxies and heresies and, along with them, its own set of myths, the most pervasive and interesting of which might be called (with apologies to the title of a current bestselling book) Macho and the Myth of the Black Funkenstein.

title: Executives to Teach Business Ethics
description: MIDDLETOWN FROM the leafy center of Wesleyan University's campus, the problems of operating a Wall Street brokerage or even Hartford insurance company seem remote indeed. While some students have organized in recent years to protest nuclear power and university investments in companies that do business in South Africa, to most undergraduates, business issues are not even of academic interest.

title: GERMANY: Land of Infinite Variety
description: A hundred years ago Mark Twain, that inveterate traveler of another era, called Germany the land of infinite variety. And it still is like that for the same reasons as in Twain's time, along with a range of developments that the American author could hardly have imagined.

title: Graceful Salutes, Skirting Conflict
description: BOSTON, Oct. 20  The setting was dramatic, the ceremony impressive, the audience celebrated, the moment tempting, and the political future as much on everyone's minds as the past.

title: Remaking It
description: NIETZSCHE says that the man of character seems to have the same experience, recurring time and again. Consider, in this light, Norman Podhoretz. At irregular intervals he turns out a piece of writing  his essay My Negro Problem

title: Lynn Fitchet Wed To Mark Filipski
description: Lynn Flint Fitchet, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Duncan Maclellan Fitchet of Hanover, N.H., was married yesterday afternoon to Mark William Filipski, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Michael Filipski of Little Falls, N.Y. The Rev. Park Dickerson performed the ceremony in the Congregational Church of Christ on the Dartmouth College campus. The Rev. Paul L. Gregoire of St. Denis Roman Catholic Church in Hanover assisted.

title: U.S. Family Is Puzzled and Split By Events Surrounding Brother
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 16  Pyotr Kovalik's relatives here say they have received no word from him and his family since they went back to the Ukraine. The only information they have obtained was in letters from other relatives in the Soviet Union saying that Mr. Kovalik had appeared on the radio to denounce his stay in Buffalo and the treatment he had received.

title: Medical Team Flying to Japan To Treat Burned U.S. Marines
description: TOKYO, Oct. 20 (AP)  A team of burn specialists is flying here from an Army hospital in Texas to examine 43 American marines who were burned when a fuel tank toppled and exploded in a typhoon and sent blazing gasoline cascading into their barracks at a training camp near Mount Fuji.

title: POLITICS
description: POLITICS is a rough business. Downfalls are swift and decisive. Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein should know. Defeated in the September primary after heading the county government for the last eight years, he is not even a factor in the current race for County Executive, except as a handy target for the potshots of the candidates trying to succeed him.

title: The Annals of Robbery
description: Ronald Biggs remains cheerful. I have been lucky. Somebody always seems to come by with a 500buck proposition, and it keeps the boat floating, he recently told Warren Hoge, The Times's correspondent in Brazil. Mr. Biggs appears to have little left besides his good cheer.

title: Zoning, to Preserve a Town's Status Quo, Is Losing, Slowly
description: Within a few weeks, tenants will begin moving into 60 garden apartments on a wooded hill overlooking a lake in New Canaan, a town of 20,000 that is Connecticut's wealthiest municipality. The apartments have more than a practical importance, for they are New Canaan's first housing for low and moderateincome people and they represent the town's response to what may be the premier social concern of suburban towns in the tristate region: zoning and the assaults against it as a form of illegal discrimination.

title: 4State Unit Ponders The Delaware's Role
description: MUCH of the drinking water for more than eight million people in four states  New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware  comes from the four billion to five billion gallons that flow to the sea every day along the historic Delaware River.

title: Editors Choice
description: CANNIBALS AND MISSIONARIES,(Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $10.96.) A plane filled with liberals and art collectors, on their way to the Shah's Iran for their particular purposes, U hijacked by terrorists: a novel that assesses the temper of our times.

title: Andrews Run Victor
description: Jerry Andrews of Highland Regional led the regional qualifiers for the first national schoolboy crosscountry meet when he posted the fastest time yesterday in one of the four varsity races at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Yesterday's regional qualifying was held in conjunction with the annual St. John's scholastic crosscountry run.

title: A Storm Over New Uses for Oral School at Mystic
description: MYSTIC Aproposal to use some facilities at the Mystic Oral School to house the mentally retarded has led to an intensely emotional fight over how the deaf should be treated in relation to those with other handicaps.

title: Astronaut Hall of Fame
description: In commemoration of the 10th anniversary of man's landing on the moon, Meteor Crater  a training site for moonwalking astronauts near Flagstaff, Ariz.,has opened the Astronaut Hall of Fame.

title: U.S. Rescues 40 Vietnamese
description: SUBIC BAY, the Philippines, Oct. 20 (Reuters)  A Seventh Fleet frigate picked up 40 Vietnamese refugees today in the South China Sea, a United States Navy spokesman said. A group of 24 were found in a 35foot fishing boat about 250 miles south of Ho Chi Minh City, and several hours later, about 45 miles away, 16 refugees aboard a small riverSUBIC BAY, the Philippines, Oct. 20 (Reuters)  craft were sighted. The spokesmen said the refugees were in good condition.

title: After Pause for Quake, Californians Turn to Big Problems
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20  The earth shook in California this week, and for what seemed like a passing moment, Californians again worried about earthquakes.

title: Nobel Prizes
description: Last Monday, it was announced that, once again, an American  Theodore W. Schultz of the University of Chicago  had won the Nobel Prize in Economics, sharing it with Sir Arthur Lewis, a British citizen who, since 1963, has been a member of the Princeton faculty.

title: $3.80 General Assembly Takes Vosburgh at Big A
description: Put General Assembly into a race where he doesn't have to cope with Spectacular Bid, and the results can be devastating.

title: SHOP TALK
description: LAKE GROVE

title: A Worldly Accent In Shrewsbury
description: OME years ago, Frank Martelli had a businessmanagement consulting business in Switzerland, a business that required him to make trips to just about every corner of the globe.

title: CHILDREN'S BOORS
description: This picture book selection has little in common save that two are wordless and two are about pirates. The simplest book of the lot, Ora Ayal's UGBU (Harper & Row, $6.95), is billed as being for ages 3 to 7, but a 2-year-old could grasp the

title: Dance: David Woodbury
description: Although David Woodberry and Friends were pleasant company Wednesday night at the American Theater Laboratory, they left one vaguely perplexed. Yet they did manage to suggest that Mr. Woodberry enjoys taking choreographic risks  both compositional and physical risks.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: IS it possible to build an energyefficient house and still maintain a competitive price? Two independent builders  one in Tolland and the other in Newtown  say it is not only possible, It is becoming crucial.

title: JUDGE SUGGESTS BAN ON USE OF PESTICIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI)  An Environmental Protection Agency judge today recommended the banning of all products containing the pesticide DBCP, a popular fruit tree spray blamed for sterilizing male workers in California.

title: Beauty
description: A new era in black cosmetics and skin care is here, with an increased awareness of the subtleties and requirements of dark skin and a host of makeup and treatment products to help the fashionable black women look her best.

title: Letters TO THE EDITOR
description: I strongly object to the canonization of unwed teenage mothers ("Children of Desire text by Francis X. Clines, photographs by Mary Ellen Mark, Sept. 30). These girls are neither saints nor heroines, but children. The impor tant highschool years, needed for developing minds and emotions, are lost to these new mothers, leaving them emotionally immature and intel- lectually underdeveloped. What starts as a schoolgirl crush or a curiosity about sex ends in the creation of another human being whose needs are endless.

title: Growing Up Female In a Feminist Family
description: HER greatgrandmother, Elizabeth Cady Stanton, helped found and lead the American suffragist movement. And her grandmother and mother followed in those feminist footsteps  marching, picketing and pouring tea for women's rights.

title: Homosexuals Press for Rights
description: WASHINGTON WHEN Bill Agosto was 18 years old, he told his parents that he was a homosexual. He began seeing a psychiatrist, who prescribed shock treatment, and for the next few years he went through life afraid that his homosexuality would come to the attention of the wrong people and make trouble for him.

title: Billy Zeoli, Michigan Evangelist, Has Dinner With Arafat in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 20  The Rev. Billy Zeoli, a friend of former President Gerald R. Ford, met here today with Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and announced later he was considering making a film about the Palestinian question.

title: Manuel Alum Discovers A Difference in Cultures
description: TOKYO, Oct. 20  The idea was perfect. An American modern dancer, one of the best, and a master of Japanese classical dance on a double bill. This was to be a first such performance here, so far as is known, one evening at Toranomon Hall before an invited audience, with several solos by each dancer and a final duet.

title: Madison Avenue's Rosser Reeves
description: Two and a half years ago, a 66yearold man strode up Madison Avenue and opened an advertising agency. In short order he hired a roster of top talent for sixfigure salaries, won three major accounts and now the young agency boasts $46 million in billings. It was a gilded debut, but surprised few in advertising because the man in charge was Rosser Reeves.

title: In Egypt, the Ghost of the Tax Man Is Suddenly Looking Very Lively
description: CAIRO, Oct. 19 A specter is haunting Cairo, prompting even some respectable citizens to lock their doors and to refuse to answer the bell. The tax man is on the prowl in Egypt's first comprehensive tax survey since before the 1952 revolution.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  Richard III, in an Actor's CafTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through Nov. 10). $3.50$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$4.50; group rates. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: Cuba Set to Free Its BestKnown Political Prisoner
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 20  When last seen by the outside world in December 1959, Huber Matos was 90 years old, had a dark beard and a powerful face, and was sitting erect in his Cuban revolutionary army uniform in a Havana courtroom as his former comrade, Fidel Castro, accused him of treason.

title: Tate Outpoints Coetzee in South Africa for W.B.A. Title
description: TATE DEFEATS COETZEE FOR TITLE: Genie Coetzee, right, missing with a right hand during heavyweight match with John Tate of the United States yesterday in Pretoria, South Africa. Tate, who won the 15round tight by decision, will be recognized as the heavyweight champion by the World Boxing Association. Article, Section 5.

title: Canada to Press a $13.8 Billion Button
description: OTTAWA  When Premier Ren Lvesque pushes a button in a vast underground vault hewn out of rock in Northern Quebec, he will start the first of 16 turbines that will be producing more than 5,000 megawatts of electricity by the end of next year.

title: Oil in Ocean May Be Far Greater Than Estimated
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP)  Government scientists are reconsidering their estimates of how much oil is naturally present in the oceans, after the discovery of a gigantic glob of oilrich water in the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Of Pregnancy and Nutrition
description: GALL Sforza Brewer was a 27yearold college professor of speech and theater when she became pregnant with her first child. I had been through endless years of education, she said, but when it came to having a baby, it was like being in kindergarten.

title: BLACK SUPREMACIST hEADS GUYANA CULT
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana  A 50yearold American who heads a black supremacist group called the House of Israel, has become the most prominent cult leader in a country that abounds in cults.

title: U.S. Magistrates Gain Authority To Process Misdemeanor Cases
description: WASHINGTON  They are a rare breed in the Federal court system, usually little noticed but now about to assume added responsibility to help clear dockets.

title: Publishing Poetry Is an Act of Love
description: TELLA MONDAY, an enthusiastic 30yearold book publisher from Sonoma County, California, via Great Neck  where she was raised and where her parents still reside  is the kind of person who knows how to get what she wants.

title: The Evolution of PopSoul
description: Middleoft aroad music, that unabashedly glamorous gush that dates from the 1940's and includes the recorded work of everyone from Frank Sinatra to Barbra Streisand is increasingly being taken over by gospelinfluenced black performers. And so now it goes by the name of popsoul. If rock and its black counterpart, funk, are committed to an aggressive pop realism, the chief concerns of popsoul artists such as Dionne Warwick, Diana Ross, Ashford and Simpson, Peaches and Herb, Chic, the Commodoges and Michael Jackson are softfocus romance and spiritual affirmation.

title: Today's Havana: Few Reminders Of a Gaudy Past
description: The Cuban Government has decided after all to promote tourism, but it is proceeding cautiously.

title: Unbeaten Ohio State Trounces Wisconsin
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 20 (AP)  Art Schlichter, the Ohio State quarterback, figured in four touchdowns today in leading the undefeated Buckeyes to a 590 romp over Wisconsin, the Badgers worst defeat ever, in a Big Ten Conference game. The worst setbacks previously for Wisconsin were 560 defeats by Ohio State in 1975 and Michigan two years ago.

title: Grand Opera in the Living Room
description: The next best thing to a night at the opera is sitting down with a recording of a favorite work sometimes the musical results can be even more satisfying since record companies can often assemble casts that impresarios only dream about. Then, too, operagoers who attend the Metropolitan this season may well wish to recall the experience via the phonograph, and, luckily, each opera in the current repertory is available on disk, many of them in several versions. Herewith is a survey of recordings of the operas which the Met will produce this season.

title: Turkish Government Falls After Election Loss
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Less than two years after his last unsuccessful attempt to deal with Turkey's longterm economic and political crises, Suleyman Demirel and his Justice Party are getting another chance. Not that the Demirel forces have developed any new miraculous cures for the country's ills, but under its rivals, the social democrats led by Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit, life for the average Turk has grown steadily worse.

title: Shows and Events
description: Today  Antiques show at the Rehabilitation Center for the Handicapped, 260 Tabor Road, Morris Plains. Free admission. Hours: Noon to 5 P.M. Antiques watches will be appraised for $1 donation. For information, call (201) 5395636.

title: Diane E. Wooters Plans Wedding to Peter Thom
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Dukes Wooters Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Elizabeth Wooters, to Peter Thom, son of Lieut. Col. Andrew Thom of the British Army and Mrs. Thom of London.

title: Trash Recycling Plant Is Emitting Foal Odor, L.I. Residents Charge
description: Hempstead's resource recovery plant has begun drawing new complaints from neighbors about foul odors since it reopened this month after a 59day strike and resumed burning the Long Island town's garbage.

title: MUSIC
description: THE upswing of audience interest in chamber music may not be a nationwide phenomenon, but it certainly continues apace here in Westchester, with more and more concerts filling the county schedule. This afternoon at 3, for instance, the Manhattan Woodwind Quintet will provide 18thcentury elegance during the course of its free concert at Philipse Manor Hall in Yonkers. Elegance is no stranger to Philipse Manor, of course. It was one of the great houses of Colonial America, and the scheduled music  by Bach, Scarlatti, Haydn, Mozart and Vivaldi, among others  would undoubtedly have made old Frederick Philipse feel right at home. I remember the young players of the quintet from their performances on WQXR, by the way, and recommend them highly.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: Books about women in their 30's having babies are about as original these days as reports of Hamilton Jordan's indiscretions, only less spicy. However, this account of Phyllis Chesler's pregnancy and childbirth stands out of the crowd because the author is one of the more articulate of the socalled radical feminists in this country. Moreover, in her most famous book, Women and Madness, Miss Chesler herself exhorts women to shake themselves free of the models of mothering and nurturing so long imposed upon them, she believes, by a maledominated society. The irony of her pregnancy, therefore, is not lost

title: Deborah Duncan, James Cottrell Jr. To Marry May 24
description: Mr. and Mrs. David A. Duncan of Dedham, Mass., have announced the engagment of their daughter, Deborah Leigh Duncan, to James Harvey Cottrell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cottrell of Rumson, N.J.

title: The Low Price of Progress in The Audio Field
description: With penny postcards selling for a dime and gooseliver going at $60 a pound in Macy's Cellar (which used to be the basement), it's good to be able to report that stereo stands fairly firm against inflation. The Electronics Industries Association, which keeps tabs on such things, reports that the Consumer Price Index for sound equipment has barely budged in a dozen years. From a base of 100 in 1967 it rose to 102 by June of this year. In the same period, the figure for all items listed in the Consumer Price Index has more than doubled; soaring from 100 to 216.6.

title: STAGE VIEW; Waxing Nostalgic, but Why?; WALTER KERR
description: Everyone's talking about the theater's capitulation to nostalgia these days, and it's true we've had positive riverspill of oldies these past few weeks what with Peter Pan, The Most Happy Fella, Sugar Babies and The 1940's Radio Hour already on tap while the perennial Oklahoma! bides its time in the wings. But no one really seems to know what they're nostalgic about.

title: A Shelter for Youths In Mt. Vernon Faces Cutback in 1980 Budget
description: NOTHING fails like success is the motto Art Buchwald, in a recent article, attributed to government when it comes to lack of financing for proven projects. The trouble is, he commented wryly, you can't get the money when you have a plan that works.

title: Christina L. Madden Is Married
description: In Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Chnstina L. Madden became the bride of Charles Seymour Whitman 3d, son of Civil Court Judge and Mrs. Whitman Jr. of New York and Watch Hill, R.I. The Rev. Edward A. M. Cobden performed the ceremony.

title: Marriage Announcement 14 -- No Title
description: Engagements

title: THE SEARCH FOR A BIONIC HEART
description: Two letters in 1964 had an electrifying effect on Congress and the National Heart Institute in Washington, D.C. Both of them dealt with the development of an artificial heart.

title: Three Poets
description: Robert Hayden's American Journal, his first publication since Angel of Ascent (1975), consists of 13 poems supplemented by two prose interludes: the epistolary psychograph Letter From Phillis Wheatley and the log of an interloper from another planet, nameless and invisible. The heart of the

title: Miss Lachman Has Nuptials
description: Linda Lee Lachman, daughter of Ruth Mabee Lachman of New York and the late Charles R. Lachman, and Ian Keith Tamblyn, son of Leslie Rosevear Tamblyn of Llanfairpwll, Isle of Anglesey, North Wales, and the late Ena Mary Tamblyn, were married yesterday. The Rev. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony in the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: RIVALS IN HIS PARTY CHALLENGING OHIRA
description: TOKYO, Oct. 20  A fierce factional struggle, with Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira's political leadership at stake, has split the governing Liberal Democratic Party in the aftermath of the general elections two weeks ago.

title: ReporterStudent Freed For a Day in Philippines
description: MANILA, Oct. 20 (UPI)  A Philippineborn American reporter freed for 24 hours was back in detention at a suburban military stockade on charges of subversion, the authorities said today.

title: Love of Words: Greeks Uphold Long Tradition
description: ATHENS, Oct. 20  In Greece, poetry, conversation and word play are as much a national pastime as betting on the soccer scores. The President relaxes by writing poetry, the work of Greece's finest poets become best sellers and are set to music by popular composers, often rising to the top of the hit parade.

title: ART
description: LAWRENCE TWP.

title: Nut Trees Yield Double Dividends: Harvest and Shade
description: The autumn harvest is in full swing from fruits to nuts. But some nuts are missing, such native American delicacies as butternuts, hickories and black walnuts. They are getting scarce and hardto find.

title: Teaching Without Schools: Legal, but Problematical
description: FARMINGDALE

title: Injured Schoolboys: Best of Care
description: The 186pound offensive tackle from George Washington High is resting comfortably at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan. So is his family, which will not have to pay a penny for knee operation that would cost the man in the street $7,000, an operation performed by the same surgeon who helped save the life of Hoist the Flag and the knees of Billie Jean King, Larry Csonka and Julius Erving.

title: Fairleigh Soccer Victor
description: TEANECK, N.J., Oct. 20 Fairleigh Dickinson University upset sixthranked St. Louis University, 10, in soccer today. Val Kovalenko, a freshman midfielder from the Bronx, scored his first career goal with 21:39 left in the game. St. Louis is 123 and F.D.U. 5-3-2 this season.

title: Music: National Arts Center Orchestra of Canada
description: The National Arts Center Orchestra of Canada is celebrating its 10th anniversary this season, and as part of the festivities it came to New York and gave a concert in Carnegie Hall on Friday night. The ensemble is not the normalsized symphony. Its basic complement is 45, because it was created for the National Arts Center in Ottawa, which is not a big metropolis. Its medium size has proved to be just right for the immediate community it serves as well as for tours that crisscross Canada.

title: Rebecca Kelly Sets Wedding For December
description: Rebecca Susan Kelly and Craig David Brashear, dancers, will be married on Dec. 15 at the Friends Meeting House at Stuyvesant Square. Their engagement has been announced by Miss Kelly's parents, Helen Hackett Kelly of New York and Giles Merrill Kelly of Washington. Mr. Brashear is a son of Dr. and Mrs. David Brashear of Norristown, Pa.

title: Private Aid Groups Told to Expect Big Cuts in World Relief Programs
description: Private relief organizations distributing United States Governmentdonated food abroad have been warned to expect drastic cuts in their aid programs because of soaring commodity prices and shipping costs.

title: Rosemary Bryce Is Wed To Roger L. Schintzius
description: Rosemary Bryce, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Bryce of Chatham, Mass., formerly of Buffalo, was married there yesterday to Roger Leonard Schintzius of Buffalo. son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Leonard B. Schintzius. Msgr. Paul R. Juenker performed the ceremony in St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church.

title: From a Sculptor, a Line of Brass Clothes
description: What does a designer of women's accessories do when he turns sculptor? If he's Lee Menichetti he raids the family closet.

title: WHAT MAKES ANDY RUN?
description: Since his father helped him buy a seat in the New York State Assembly, Andrew J. Stein has lived most of his professional life among people who detest him. They tell him so, face to face. Mr. Stein, boyishly smiling, ignores the hostility and, moving from investigation to investigation, from headline to headline, persists along the political path that he hopes will make him the first Jewish President of the United States.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Of Special Interest

title: N.Y. Awaits Boom In Quebec Energy
description: It seems too good to be true. New York State, embroiled in controversy about nuclear power plants, emissions from coalfired plants and soaring costs at oilfired plants, needs all the power it can get. And Quebec, which already helps satisfy some of the state's energy needs, is adding enormously to its electricityproducing capacity with the mammoth James Bay power project, which goes into operation next Saturday.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: The first program in a subscription series of four concerts will be given at 8:30 P.M. at Benjamin Franklin Junior High School, Taft Road, Teaneck. The others will be presented in December, February and March.

title: Land Swaps Make a Greenbelt
description: Twenty years ago, Jules Liss bought a 135-by156 foot lot on the Staten Island waterfront because he wanted to build his wife a house with water view.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: The Westchester & Boston was the little railroad that couldn't. Reaching only as far as Port Chester it made its last run from the Bronx in 1937, whereupon the White Plains terminal was demolished to make way for B. Altman & Co. and Alexander's department stores.

title: LSD Use Said to Rise Again in Northern California
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 20  The use of LSD is rising again in northern California, where it first gained notoriety in the 1960's, according to law enforcement officials and public health authorities familiar with the illicit drug culture here.

title: Penn State Passing Sinks Syracuse, 357
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 20  Penn State, for years one of the East's stronger football teams, routed a rebuilding Syracuse squad, 357, today in Giants Stadium before a crowd of 53,789.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Suite in F sharp minor, Pachelbel; Quartet No. 6, Rossini; Sextet in E flat, Pleyel; Blindekuh, Strauss.

title: Dalai Lama, Tour of U.S. at End, Has Mixed Views on Prosperity
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 19At the end of his sevenweek visit to the United States, the Dalai Lama today praised many spiritual and material aspects of this country, but, as a friend, he also raised a few gentle concerns.

title: Coach and Staff Reinstated After Incident With Player
description: TOMS RIVER, N.J., Oct. 20 (AP) The head football coach at Toms River North and two assistants, suspended after the head coach allegedly hit a player on an opposing team, were reinstated yesterday, officials said.

title: On Language Goodbye Girl
description: Appearing on a Houston television show, and fulminating about Leon Jaworski's coverup of Koreagate, I noticed a goodlooking blonde taking still ohotoeraohs on the set.

title: An Atlantic City Gasoline David
description: ATLANTIC CITY ATINY Atlantic City gasoline distributor, a company whose owner describes himself as the president, stockholder and truck driver, is waging a legal battle against the huge Mobil Oil Corporation, one of the world's business giants.

title: Why Don't the Voters Vote?; POLITICS
description: DESPITE new state laws in recent years designed to make it easier to register to vote, the percentage of registered Connecticut residents who do vote has been steadily declining.

title: Giants Big Three Building Optimism
description: THE new era is half a season old today, and whether or not the Giants celebrate with a victory at Kansas City the three main men of the era have done more in half a season than many others have done in 15 years of lousy football. That is how many Giant fans refer to the past era.

title: New Marathon Record Is Voided by Short Course
description: SPLIT, Yugoslavia (UPI)  Michel Kousis's winning time in the marathon at the Mediterranean Games last month will not be recognized because the course was too short, according to the race organizers.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1979

title: Lawyers Debate a Public Tithe
