description: In the past two decades, innovative legislation and court decisions have given new legal rights and remedies to everyone, including poor people. One recent study has found that there are two legal problems per year for every 10 poor people. The number of lawyers now serving the poor  either fulltime or parttime, whether in legal clinics, as courtappointed attorneys or as volunteers  could not possibly supply so many legal necessities.

title: PBS's Connections: The Many Sides of Technology
description: How safe are nuclear reactors? Utterly safe the technologists said, until an explosive hydrogen bubble that no one foresaw formed inside a reactor at Three Mile Island. Chemicals? For decades companies thought it was safe enough to dump their wastes and forget them  until the Love Canal evacuation. And how about computers, supersonic transports or plastics? They all solve problems, to be sure, but they also create problems.

title: When the Snow Falls On Green Tomatoes
description: I was awakened by my teenaged daughter: Snow! Snow! I can't believe it, she was yelling. It was 6:30 A.M., about an hour before my usual waking time, but that word  snow got me out of bed fast. It was Oct. 10, and by 8 A.M. an inch had fallen, with no signs of stopping.

title: A Balancing Act: Education and the Economy
description: WHILE last year's Levittown decision requiring redistribution of state aid to public and elementary education is on appeal, Governor Carey and Chancellor Theodore M. Black of the New York State Board of Regents have establishd the Special Task Force on Equity and Excellence in Public Education. The task force has begun hearings, has issued a preliminary report and will make recommendations to the Governor and the Legislature in 1980.

title: Fight Fans Accept Integrated Seating
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 20 From the $12 seats, the stadium's least expensive, the ring looked like a square blue poker chip in the center of a card table today for the John TateGenie Coetzee heavyweight title bout.

title: Vietnam Says Its Troops Will Not Enter Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Oct. 20 (Reuters)  Secretary of State Nguyen Co Thach of Vietnam said today that Vietnamese troops operating in Cambodia would not enter Thailand in pursuit of guerrillas loyal to the ousted Prime Minister, Pol Pot.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: AVON  Works in fiber, clay and paper by Diane Brawarsky and Mary Barringer through Nov. 3. Farmington Valley Arts Center, Avon Park North. Daily except Mondays 11 to 4, Sundays 1 to 4. Phone 6781863.

title: Immaculate Romps, 556
description: Marcus Hackett returned punts 60 and 67 yards for touchdowns and also caught a 36yard scoring pass from Tim Cummings as undefeated Montclair Immaculate (60) overpowered Paul VI, 556, at Montclair. Mike Ormsby. who gaired 107 yards in nine carries, scored on runs of 1 and 52 yards, while Cummings had a 42yard touchdown run in addition to kicking seven placements. Paul VI fell to 06.

title: The Literary Roots of `Apocalypse Now
description: Toward the end of Francis Coppola's Apocalypse Now, the camera casually, almost randomly, roams across a disheveled hut, passing a small number of scattered books lying in such way as to suggest recent usage. One of these books is Sir James Frazer's The Golden Bough. It is no accident. Indeed, this book holds the key to understanding the conclusion of the film that has baffled  and annoyed most critics and will very likely be unsettling number of moviegoers now that Apocalypse Now is entering general distribution.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: After dabbling in small shows throughout the Island this fall, the antiques and collectibles dealers on the local scene are to gather today at the Nassau Coliseum for what they call an extravaganza. More than 200 exhibitors will display their wares. There will also be an appraisal service (at $1.50 an item) and a dollrepair corner. The show will run from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. at the Coliseum in Uniondale. Admission is $2; children under 12,75 cents.

title: DINING OUT
description: LE CHABLIS is a tiny, charmingly intimate French restaurant in a cottage opposite the Hewlett railroad station. It seems more like a home than a restaurant. Two cozy dining rooms, one with fireplace, are set with pinkclothed tables, an assortment of comfortable chairs and china plates and framed memorabilia on the walls.

title: Suburban Caucus Gets a Nod In Washington
description: WASHINGTON JUST about this time two years ago, Representative John W. Wydler, a conservative Republican from Garden City, found himself in an unusual position: He was sitting on the Democratic side of the House chamber.

title: Eiffel Tower to Get New Manager Because of Renovations Dispute
description: Paris, Oct. 20 (Agence France Presse)  Mayor Jacques Chirac said yesterday that the city would not renew the contract of the company that manages the Eiffel Tower, which refuses to share the financing of muchneeded renovations.

title: U.S. Analysts Say Cuba Is Keeping Forces Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  Government analysts report that, contrary to new denials by Fidel Castro, Cuba continues to maintain large expeditionary forces and groups of army advisers in a number of third world countries.

title: Stricken Chargers Kicker Reported in Fair Condition
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 20 (AP)  The San Diego Charger placekicker, Rolf Benirschke, was in intensive care but in fair condition after emergency surgery yesterday at University Hospital. The 24yearold player had been stricken with a digestive disease.

title: Jazz: Jaki Byard Big Band
description: When the Public Theater's New Jazz concert series presents a big band, it's usually a oneshot affair featuring a collection of celebrated soloists who are used to following their own muses. This is as it should be, for without the Public's program, one would probably never be able to hear what kind of big band music some of New York's more gifted jazz musicians are capable of making. But it was a distinct pleasure on Friday night to hear a big band at the Public that actually sounded like a band.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: CON'T make it sound as if I'm some kind of dogooder trying to save humanity and the law, said Francis A. Auleta, a lawyer in Mamaroneck who is president of Prepaid Legal Services of Westchester County, a nonprofit concern. I hate dogooders. Give me a good honest crook rather than a dogooder.

title: Deadline Is Nearing On Boat Sanitation
description: After nearly 10 years of push and pull among two Federal agencies and the boatmen, the Federal course for marine sanitation devices, also known as heads, appears firm, and the deadline for complying is rapidly approaching.

title: New Puerto Rico Status Favored
description: A decision by a majority of the Puerto Rican people to change their commonweath status, either to become the 51st state in the Union or an independent nation, would have widespread support among all groups of Americans, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Tight Money: Here Goes Housing
description: THE annual convention of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America is usually mixture of business and bonhomie, but last week's meeting in Chicago resembled a wake. Delegates were trying to jump out the windows, but thankfully the windows were sealed, said Thomas Harter, the association's chief economist, in a tone that suggested he was laughing to keep from crying.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR  Landscapes by Robert Maione; 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays; 1 to 6 P.M. Sundays; through Nov. 3; Harbor Gallery, 43 Main St.

title: Jane Lori Mirken Sets July 3 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan B. Mirken of Roslyn, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Lori Mirken, to Avram Charles Greenspan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leon Greenspan of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Formed in 1976 and now in residence at the Vineland (N.J.) Public Library, the Kapelle Woodwind Trio made its New York debut last Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall. The three young members of the group are Virginia Nanzetta, flutist; Benjamin Christy, clarinetist, and Lawrence Stewart, bassoonist.

title: Music: From California By Contemporary Unit
description: The Group for Contemporary Music began its 18th season Monday night with Music From California at the Manhattan School of MusIc's Borden Auditorium.

title: THEATER
description: WE no longer see white actors in blackface playing black roles, and we hope some day that those roles that there are for deaf peopleand there are a reasonable number of themwill be played by deaf people. The speaker was David Hays, athleticlooking man with a mane of white curly hair, the founder and producing director of the National Theater of the Deaf, which is based at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Councilman Barbara Blumberg's recent letter to the editor was simplistic and selfserving.

title: Family Memoir
description: THE third volume of Ved Mehta's familial biography opens irresistibly: In Lahore over a century ago, an accursed couple (10 of their infants have died) seek guidance from a holy woman. She tells them where to find a halfburied statue of the goddess Durga. Worship it for six months, and they will be delivered of a son. That prophesied son  Ved Mehta's maternal grandfather, Babuji  led the family out of squalor and superstition, gained wealth and a title, fathered 15 children and died a centenarian in 1973. Mamaji closes in the year 1938 with the author, only 3 and already blind from the effects of meningitis, being taken by his mother (Babuji's daughter, Mamaji) on furtive missions to seers and healers. Despite being a doctor's wife and a lawyer's daughter, she remained convinced, at least in an active part of her, that blindness was a spell to be lifted by prayer and flagellation. But we are now in the modern world, Daddyji's world of Western medicine. Even though one seer is able to describe the occasion of Ved Mehta's initial infection with eerie precision, her prescribed cure  Durga worship  this time proves ineffective.

title: Ashland Oil's Dry Kentucky Home
description: ASHLAND, Ky.  Ashland Oil Inc., one of the country's largest independent oil companies, took its name from this tiny Appalachian city of 30,000 on the Ohio River and in time the company grew to become the city's biggest employer. With 4.500 workers here and just outside the city, Ashland Oil is now such a part of the local fabric that without it, says community activist Doris C. Leslie, this area would be a dry hole.

title: Sindona Gives Account of 10Week Disappearance
description: The Italian financier Michele Sindona has told agents of the Federaa Bureau of Investigation and police detectives that he has difficulty recalling many details of his 10week disappearance because he was apparently drugged at times by his captors.

title: House Panel Asks Study On New Rail Corridors
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI)  Leaders of the House Commerce Committee have asked for a study of new rail passenger corridors that could lead to frequent highspeed service between major cities in the Middle West, California, Texas and other areas.

title: Manhasset Halts Cold Spring Harbor Streaks,12O
description: The long undefeated streak of Cold Spring Harbor was was stopped yesterday by Manhasset, a 12.0 victor in their Conference IV game. The defending conference champions had won 27 consecutive league games and 21 in a row,including playoffs. The last time the Seahawks lost was in the 1976 playoffs, when they bowed to Floral Park, 2814.

title: The Pirates Provider
description: During the World Series, about the only time that Harding (Pete) Peterson was visible was in Chuck Tanner's office after a game, standing far from where the Pittsburgh Pirates manager was surrounded by newsmen. Pete Peterson is the Pirates executive vice president, the man who assembled the World Series

title: Deaths
description: Abo, Norman

title: Alabama Overcomes Tennessee by 2717
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 20 (UPI)  Major Ogilvie scored two thirdperiod touchdowns today to help topranked Alabama rally from a 170 deficit to a 2717 victory over Tennessee.

title: Capital Report: Faulting NoFault
description: NEW JERSEY'S insurance industry, alarmed over the practical effects of the state's nofault autoinsurance system, is gearing up for a new drive to persuade the Legislature to make some changes.

title: Deaths
description: CROSBYLemuel S., 86, on October 16, 1979. Survived by his wife, Megara; his daughter Magere Finn, his son, Stephens, and six grandchildren. Services will be held In Mohawk, Tennessee. The family suggests that expressions of sympathy be in the form of contributions to the United Methodist Church of Montville, N.J.

title: Loose Laws Make Care of Aged Costly
description: MIDDLESEX Hospital for the Chronically Ill in North Brunswick is county institution for old people who need nursing care. Its staff seems dedicated and hard working, but it is fighting a losing battle.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Our friend Winokur, who is ill at ease in New York, arrived from Iowa for a visit recently and immediately noticed two cucumbers on the sidewalk in front of our house. Apparently he had never seen cucumbers on a sidewalk before.

title: Market for MiddlePriced Coops Softens
description: When Alan Ripp went coop shopping, the first apartment he saw was priced at $40,000 and the monthly maintenance fee was $350. It was a studio near Columbia University, and was far too small and too far north of where he wanted to live.

title: G.A.O. Attacks Bill on U.S. Aid to Nursing Homes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  Congressional auditors have sharply criticized a Senate proposal that would largely eliminate the Federal Government's control over the nearly $8 billion a year it pays to the nation's nursing homes.

title: W. H. Auden at Oxford
description: AUDEN'S beautifully proportioned, oakpanelled rooms [at Oxford) were in the northwest comer of Peckwater Quadrangle (known as Peck), on the third floor. In addition to his sittingroom and bedroom, there was a small cupboardlike space into which a piano had been squeezed and whose walls had been covered by a previous occupant with a startling mural of scarlet and black cubist design, described in due course by Christopher Isherwood as apparently representing a series of railway accidents and copulations between traction engines and pyramids. It was in these rooms that Auden would hold court with the small group of acolytes who began to assemble around him, reading aloud his own poems and those of other poets whose work impressed him. In middle age, Auden tended not so much to converse as to lecture, and even at the age of eighteen his discussions of the poetry of, say, Emily Dickinson or Wilfred Owen were, more often than not, monologues. They were, however, monologues which his listeners found quite fascinating, occasionally as much for the oddly impressive, somewhat portentous manner of his delivery as for his actual words. [John] Betjeman was impressed by Auden's oracular and master and lecturer. He was equally impressed by Auden's refusal to adopt the fashionable undergraduate pose of looking down on one's parents as boring philistines: this young man spoke with af fection and respect of his parents, and of Birmingham and the country around it with interest and, almost, nostalgia. Clearly, he fitted into no Oxford pigeonhole.

title: Magic Stones
description: SCATTERED about the chalk downs in parts of southwest Britain are thousands of sandstone blocks, which lie on the ground like gigantic dead sheep. Indeed, the locals still sometimes refer them as wethers. As we now know, they are the stranded relics of a long geological process that began 40 million years ago. In earlier ages they puzzled and fascinated men. Sir Christopher Wren thought they were cast up by some volcanic explosion; Pepys believed they grew out of the ground, organically. It's not surprising that primitive men felt they had magical potency, for in the dawn mist, or as night falls, they assume strange and terrifying shapes. With enormous labor, using vast gangs of men and primitive sledges, prehistoric societies dragged some these megaliths into rectangular processional avepues, leading to ceremonial circles. Once In place, the massive stones were upended and sunk into shallow pits. They are traditionally called sazzens or sarson stones, from the medieval identification of heathenism with the Saracen opponents of the crusaders.

title: Drugs
description: WEST BERLIN  West Germany has been troubled for some time by the growing use of illicit drugs. But only of late have West Germans come to the painful realization that drug abuse in general, and heroin abuse in particular, are approaching epidemic proportions in this affluent country known for its hardworking people and middleclass values.

title: 5,000 Join Feminist Group's Rally In Times Sq. Against Pornography
description: More than 5,000 feminists, college students and community activists marched through Times Square in a protest against pornography yesterday, parading In the bright Manhattan sunshine past the dimly lighted sex shops, peep shows and pornographic movie houses along 42d Street.

title: About 150 New England Companies Now Use Timber as Fuel
description: Last week bulldozers in Lincoln, Me., broke ground for the first plant in the Northeast to produce fuel pellets from sawdust and wood slabs, making nine such mills nationwide, each churning out 250 tons of pellets daily. About the same time, the Cornell University heating plant received the first load of an order of 10,000 tons of wood chips, and the Wood Energy Institute moved from rural Maine to Washington, D.C., where five staffers are to lobby for wood energyrelated legislation.

title: Brown Observes Japanese Defense Force Exercises
description: Mr. Brown, ending a fourday visit to Korea and Japan, insisted on coming to this northern island of Hokkaido, close to the Soviet Far East, despite a tight schedule. A violent storm yesterday forced Mr. Brown to delay his departure from Korea for half a day.

title: Gelding, 7, Is Winner
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 20  Katie Monahan, who finished as a runnerup  and leading American rider  last spring in the world jumping championships in Europe, rode Silver Exchange to the Open Jumper title tonight at the closing session of the weeklong Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The Lyric Opera of Chicago has an anniversary this season, and the 25th year of its existence was marked by an elaborate gala concert last Sunday afternoon in the Civic Opera House. A good representation of the world's leading singers participated, and also on hand to share in the festivities were famous great ones of the past who had appeared with the Lyric Opera in 1954 and its great seasons after that. Don't think it wasn't a thrill to see the likes of Giuseppe di Stefano, Giulietta Simionato, Nicola RossiLemeni, Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, Bid Sayao, Hans Hotter and Eleanor Steber, among others, walk out on stage and say a few words to the huge audience.

title: Deaths
description: ABONormen. On October 20, 1979. (Past President of Congregation Beth Israel, Hempstead, N.Y.) Beloved husband of Ina. Devoted father of Elyse Zuckerman and Martin Abo. Dear brother of Edward and David. Loving grandfather of Jodi and Amy. Services Monday 12:15 PM at The Colonial Chapels of I.J. Morris, Inc. 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, L.I.

title: Events Today
description: Dance Tribute to Albert Einstein: Celebration of Einstein centennial, including photographs and demonstrations; exhibition open from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.; dance performances at 1 and 3 P.M.; Hall of Science, Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: Researcher Challenges Conclusion That Apes Can Learn Language
description: Thirteen years of research involving gorillas and chimpanzees that were apparently taught human language have been thrown into question by new evidence that, according to a researcher, shows that the apes may be doing nothing more remarkable than a dog does in learning to sit or heel. Investigators are already at loggerheads in what promises to be a major dispute about whether the human capacity for language is unique.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: B.Y.U. Routs Wyoming; Wilson: 4 Scoring Passes
description: LARAMIE, Wyo., Oct. 20 (UPI) Marc Wilson, the nation's leading passer, threw for four of Brigham Young's eight touchdowns today to lead the Cougars to a 5414 rout of Wyoming in Western Athletic Conference game, played in a snowstorm here.

title: Tour Earnings
description: P.G.A. GOLF

title: Ideas &Trends
description: For every atomic particle there exists, in theory, an equal and opposite antiparticle  for the negatively charged electron a positively charged positron, for the much more massive, positively charged proton an equally massive but negatively charged antiproton. Such particles of antimatter have been created and observed in laboratories, but last week scientists published the first report of the detection of antimatter outside the laboratory  streams of antiprotons from outer space, identified by balloonborne equipment.

title: Around the Nation
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 20 (AP)  A tentative agreement on a new contract was reached early today in the monthold strike against Ozark Airlines, officials said.

title: Another Try for Open Justice
description: The Supreme Court's decision to rereview the question of closing courtrooms to public and press was both necessary and welcome. It was necessary because the first review last July, in a case brought by the Gannett newspaper chain, created rampant confusion. It is welcome for the chance it gives the Court to go beyond clarifying that 5to4 decision, to rise above presscourt disputes and to confront afresh the broad implications of closing public institutions.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE  Side by Side, musical. Today 2 P.M., Thursday to Saturday 8 P.M. Through Nov. 4. $5.50 to $7.50. Reservations. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, junction of Rtes. 6 and 118.6281169.

title: Heat Is the Hot Item In Marathon Today
description: Heat, the long distance runner's No. 1 enemy, has emerged as the hot item of conversation for today's 10th New York City Marathon.

title: State's First Professional Black
description: NEW BRUNSWICK

title: THE CASE AGAINST BAILING OUT CHRYSLER
description: You're chairman of the Senate Banking Committee. You're in a position of responsibility and decision in considering any bailout of the floundering Chrysler Corporation that involves credit. The two kinds of bailouts most likely to be used, a loan or a loan guarantee, involve credit. So the ball's in your court. What do you do?

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: As James T. Farrell's biographer, I welcome accurate information about Farrell's life. Alp Fred Kazin's James T. Farrell, 190479 (Sept. 16) raises several questions that illustrate a biographer's problems.

title: 4 Sailors Guilty Over Klan Rally
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., Oct. 20 (AP) The Navy has convicted four sailors of violating its order not to attend an Oct. 5 Ku Klux Klan rally in Virginia Beach. The four enlisted men were convicted at a captain's mast earlier this week of violating the Navy's order placing the rally offlimits. James Maxon, Robert Downey and John Petty, all stationed at the Portsmouth Naval Hospital, were ordered to forfeit;100, the Navy said. It declined to identify the fourth sailor, saying only that he was stationed aboard the U.S.S. Eisenhower.

title: National Unity Is Vital Task For Nigeria's New Regime
description: KANO, Nigeria  While President Shehu Shagari has been struggling to stitch together a national cabinet in Lagos, Muhammed Abubakar Rimi, Governor of Kano, has not only sworn in an administration but has also made moves in just two weeks that have made him a hero in Nigeria's most populous state.

title: Infighting Over Scott
description: WOODBRIDGE JAMES SCOTT, the lightheavyweight boxer who was stripped of his rating by the World Boxing Association on Sept. 28, says he will honor his commitments to fight Jerry Celestine next Saturday and Alvaro (Yaqui) Lopez on Dec. 1.

title: Pope John Paul Meets Kissinger
description: ROME, Oct. 20 (UPI)  Pope John Paul II received former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger at a private audience today. It was their first meeting. Mr. Kissinger, who is touring Europe promoting the first volume of his memoirs, is also scheduled to meet with Prime Minister Francesco Cossiga.

title: In Defense Of TriState
description: AS TAXPAYERS everywhere become increasingly cost-con- scious about government ex- penditures, those who live in New Jersey have every reason to be satisfied with their investment in the TriState Regional Planning Commission.

title: Black English Training Is Begun By Group of Ann Arbor Teachers
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 20 (UPI)A gathering of more than three dozen teachers and school administrators in an elementary school library has inaugurated the first session of socalled black English training.

title: Suburban Caucus A Medley of Voices
description: WASHINGTON FOR years, there has been considerable emphasis here on the need to aid old, blighted urban centers, especially those of the Northeast  the Newarks, the Patersons, the Camdens.

title: Islander Rout Led By Harris
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 20 Most of the attention was on Gordie Howe tonight, but Billy Harris stole the spotlight by scoring three goals and leading the Islanders to a 61 triumph over the Hartford Whalers.

title: Stakes Are High at Arizona State in Coach CoverUp
description: Following three decades of hard work and an expenditure of millions of dollars by the state, the university and private citizens, the Arizona State University athletic program achieved its goal of national recognition a year ago when it was admitted to the Pacific10 Conference. The Sun Devils were finally on an equal basis with the likes of U.C.L.A. and Southern California. Conference. The Sun Devils were finally on an equal basis with the likes of U.C.L.A. and Southern California.

title: East Side Garage Manager Held In Slaying of Manhattan Woman
description: A 38yearold garage manager has been charged with the murder of a Manhattan woman whose body, bearing stab marks beneath the right ear and collar bone, was found Friday morning jammed against a factory fence in Long Island City, Queens.

title: CrotonHarmon Stays Perfect
description: CrotonHarmon won the battle of the unbeatens yesterday. Coach Terry Smith's Tigers beat Pleasantville by 70 in a defensive battle between teams that had each won four straight going into the contest.

title: Florida Gets Grants for Parks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP)  The Interior Department has approved grants totaling almost $10 million tor use by Florida in establishing and expanding state and local parks.

title: Temple Downs Bearcats
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 (AP)  Brian Bloomell threw five touchdown passes to lead Temple to a 3519 victory over Cincinnati today.

title: A Special Man and. His Special Way With His Game
description: IT is interesting to speculate what would have happened if Willie Stargell had played his career in Yankee Stadium. For one thing, he would have at least 800 home runs by now. There is no telling how many balls he could have parked in the rightfield porch at the Stadium.

title: Covington Paces Bayside, 346
description: Jamie Covington had another outstanding game yesterday, rushing for 137 yards on 12 carries and scoring a touchdown as Bayside remained unbeaten by trouncing Adams, 346. Covington has scored 13 touchdowns this season.

title: Miss Hessenbruch And John McKeon To Be Wed May 3
description: Mrs. H. Markle Hessenbruch Jr. of Ridgewood, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Carolyn Hessenbruch, to John B. McKeon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. McKeon of Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Koch Mends. Fences With Puerto Rican Legislators
description: Mayor Koch made an apparently successful attempt to improve his relations with Puerto Rican elected officials yesterday in a twohour breakfast at Gracie Mansion that ended with 10 legislators proclaiming that a new and fruitful dialogue had begun between themselves and the Mayor.

title: The Sources Of Revolt
description: WHILE most of sociology's European forebears, from Herbert Spencer to Max Weber, directed much of their efforts to comparative historical research and to macroscopic investigations, American sociology until recently has largely eschewed such research and has tended to concentrate on ahistorical problems, mainly within the context of American society. This began tc change after World War II, but it is only in the last 10 years or so, partly under the influence of a young generation neoMarxist or Weberian scholars, that comparative historical sociology has begun to make important contributions to American scholarship.

title: Canadiens Edge Rangers, 54
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 20  As Claude Ruel, the Canadiens assistant coach, remembers it, the first three times Montreal played the New York Rangers last season, the Canadiens played very sloppy and gave them all kinds of open plays.

title: Nevada High Court Rejects Appeal For Delay of Execution Tomorrow
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Oct. 20 (AP) The Nevada Supreme Court refused today to block the execution of the convicted killer Jesse Bishop. The American Civil Liberties Union said it would appeal to the United States Supreme Court.

title: Columbia Soccer Victor
description: Steve Charles and Shahin Shayan scored two goals apiece to lead Columbia to a 40 soccer victory over Yale at Baker Field yesterday. It was the Lions sixth straight. Charles has now scored 16 goals and Shayan 14. The Lions wonlost records are 101 over all and 40 in the Ivy League. Yale is 53 and 21.

title: Wisconsin County Tense Over Vietnamese Resettlement Program
description: MANITOWOC, Wis., Oct. 20 (AP) Criticism of a refugee resettlement program, simmering since a dispute last summer over fishing rights in Lake Michigan, has flared anew with a county board rejecting a resolution to end the Droram.

title: Office Condominiums Gaining in Popularity

But all that is behind him now, and Mr. Picaro not only has sold 17 offices in his condominum project  they are all within one complex in East Brunswick  but also has a waiting list for more that are planned.

description: MY friends gave a party for me last week. I was the first of our crowd to make a right turn on red, and it seemed to call for a celebration.

title: Black Disunity Goes Deeper Than the Andy Young Affair
description: Eight weeks ago, after the resignation of Andrew Young as Ambassador to the United Nations, new tension between blacks and Jews was apparent. Many blacks were convinced  and remain so  that Israel and the American Jews were to blame. But then, in a turn of events whose irony was only heightened by Mr. Young's comments last week that Israel and the White House had worked together on a statement that would have put Israel on record as opposing his resignation, black leaders themselves began to fight. Since a euphoric meeting of 200 members

title: Two Are Killed and Eight Injured In a 3Car Crash on Belt Parkway
description: Two men were killed and eight other persons were injured early yesterday when a car crossed into oncoming traffic on the Belt Parkway in Queens, the police reported.

title: Some Trees Are Not Worth the Effort
description: Although fruits and nuts are pleasing rewards from many trees, a few don't deserve landscape space. They are troublemakers and litter the ground with their unwanted fruits, limbs or seed pods. It can truly be said, he who plants one of these on his property, will live to regret it.

title: ART
description: THE British were not pioneers in the medium of the transparent water color, having been preceded by Drer and various Dutch artists of the 17th century. But where the portrayal of landscape was concerned, they made the technique their own. And, if Through English Eyes at the Katonah Gallery is not a comprehensive survey, it gives a good idea of the native accomplishment during the years 1760 to 1860. These 38 drawings and 11 illustrated books come from such institutions as the Rhode Island School of Design's Museum of Art and from the Fogg Art Museum. They were selected by Dr. Isabel Stuebe, guest curator, and by Patricia Sands, exhibition coordinator, and will be on view through Oct. 28.

title: On Spending All Day in Bed. Some People Even Admit to It
description: So it isn't everyone's idea of heaven. Still, for a lot of busy people, it's an awfully nice way to spend the day. Let those who will jog, cycle or roller skate in the park, windowshop the avenue, do the museums, drive to the country. The sybaritic, some say the smart, stay in bed.

title: Poets Explain Themselves
description: THIS anthology brings together essays by 20thcentury poets on their own art: some concern themselves with its deep sources and ultimate justifications; others deal with technique, controversies among schools, the experience behind particular poems. The great Modernists of most countries are represented here  Paul Valry, Federico Garca 29 Masters of 20th Century Poetry on the Origins and Practice of Their Art. Edited by Reginald Gibbons. 305 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. Cloth, $12.50. Paper, 56.50.

title: Jets Rekindle Old Feeling for Raiders
description: And then there was the time Ben Davidson broke Joe Namath's jaw.

title: Girl, 8, Is Veteranin Front of Camera
description: MARA HOBEL was watching television when she decided what she wanted to do the rest of her life. I was sitting on the floor, watching Eight Is Enough,  she recalls, when suddenly I jumped up and said, I can do that. Right then, I knew I was going to be an actress.

title: GARDENING
description: VNES are a much overlooked element in the landscape. Trained over an arbor, they will provide cool shade during the summer. On a fence or trellis, they may be used as a screen for privacy or to block out an unpleasant view. Used against a masonry or stone wall, they will soften its starkness and provide a pleasant contrast in texture. Growing on the trunk of a tree, they become nature's equivalent of a ball gown.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The sum is worse than the parts. That is pretty much how the dance season has been shaping up in October. Now is the time to speak the unspeakable. It a season distinguished by mediocrity. Never before has a supposedly slow dance month been so filled up with overlapping dance series. There is the Dance Umbrella, the Riverside Dance Festival, the Loftdance Festival, the usual Dance Theater Workshop series at the Ameri can Theater Laboratory, the new dance series at the EmanuEl Midtown YMYWHA, plus more loosely coordinated events in other performing spaces.

title: Letters
description: In her article [Transfers Are Often Traumatic for Churches and Synagogues, Sept. 30], Jill Jonnes caught the spirit of what I had to say but apparently I did not make myself clear on one important point.

title: Heatless Dakotans May Live in Public Buildings
description: MITCHELL, S.D., Oct. 20 (AP) Davison County officials have drawn up a plan to turn public buildings into shelters for families who cannot meet the high cost of heating oil this winter. Social workers estimate that at least 500 families may need the shelters.

title: Home Is Where The Loneliness Is
description: IN 1977, the Health, Education and Welfare Secretary, Joseph A. Califano, signed regulations outlawing various forms of discrimination against the country's 35 million handicapped citizens. For decades, he said, handicapped Americans have been an oppressed and, all too often, a hidden minority ... subject to unconscionable discrimination, beset by demoralizing indignities, detoured out of the mainstream of American life, unable to secure their rightful role as full and independent citizens.

title: Shopping Around for a Better Deal on a Rental Car
description: If you are planning to rent a car in the New York area, you should shop around carefully before making a commitment. Because of high overhead, the nationwide rental companies tend to charge more in New York City than in the rest of the country. Their business is so competitive, however, that they sometimes announce promotions to undercut one another. Or they just as suddenly raise rates across the board.

title: Merchants of Myth
description: John Connally and Jesse Jackson, of all people, have now joined their voices to promote a wicked and dangerous diplomatic bargain: trade the West Bank the Jordan for reliable, affordable supplies of Arab oil. The former governor of Texas has made this the main plank of his foreign policy platform as he pursues the Reoublican nomination for President; he says the idea will save Western civilization. Mr. Jackson, a prominent black leader, cites the prospect of such a deal explain his effort to get blacks to embrace the Palestinian cause; he says only that can protect the poor from economic disaster.

title: Couple in 80's Are Starting Anew
description: MAMARONECK PUT your arms around me, too, Kitten, Isaac D. Corkland, 82 years old, said to Martha Munzer, 80, as he embraced her for the photographer and smiled sheepishly.

title: FILM VIEW
description: With the opening this week of The Marriage of Maria Braun, Rainer Werner Fassbinder's epic comedy about the postwar economic miracle called West Germany, there are now two women in competition for the Oscar that, next spring, will be given for the best per- tormance by an actress in a leading role in 1979. Only two? Well, until the arrival of the Fassbinder picture, in which Hanna Schygulla gives a mesmerizingly funny and touching performance as the sort of Mother Courage who wouldn't be caught dead pulling a cart, there was, in my estimation, only one: Sally Field, whose guts, humor and raisedconsciousness illuminated Martin Ritt's Norma Rae, which opened here last March.

title: Last Week's Coup Signalled Mostly a Change for the Military For Now
description: SAN SALVADOR  After ruling the country for the benefit of a tiny minority for the past 47 years, El Salvador's armed forces last week overthrew the conservative regime of Gen. Carlos Humberto Romero and promised sweeping reforms and early free elections. Not surprisingly, few Salvadorans believed them.

title: Laurelle F. Sheedy and Robert T. Mathis Of Blyth Eastman Dillon Have Bridal
description: Laurelle Foote Sheedy and Robert Trimble Mathis, who are with Blyth Eastman Dillon & Company, were married yesterday in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frederick B. Northup. He was assisted by Msgr. Paul John Vianney Walsh of St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church.
