title: Marjorie Hirschland Fiance
description: Jean Macintosh Hirschland of Wilmington, Del., and Herbert E. Hirschland of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Lea Hirschland to Stephen D. M. Robinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Robinson of Barrington, Ill. The future bride, coowner of Bedfellows, a specialty linen retail store in Greenville, Del., and her fianc, a partner in Robinson, McKelvie & Geddes, Wilmington law firm, will be married in January at the Greenhill Presbyterian Church in Wilmington. Mr. Robinson's marriage ended in divorce.

title: The Region
description: N.Y., Connecticut Assemblies to Act On Heating Oil

title: Topics Smoldering Black Rubber Architecture
description: The idea was to light a fire under Atlantic City, not to burn down the Boardwalk. But the casinos have had some curious side effects. Lately, the sun's rays have been bouncing off the golden prisms of Caesar's Boardwalk Regency, causing small fires and smoldering planks. A few warped panels, explains the management, are the culprits; when they're replaced the golden glow will return to normal.

title: Even OneTime ArchEnemy Tito Was Friendly Last Week
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia  The first Albanian students to study in the West in a generation arrived this month in Paris, Vienna, Stockholm and Rome bearing interesting news: Albania is preparing to rejoin the community of nations.

title: Headliners
description: The Harvard Business School is where the elite learn meet before they get jobs ruling the world. But though the institution is widely considered the foremost business school the United States, Harvard president Derek C. Bok last spring announced a reexamination of the school's programs and methods. One of his priorities was the selection of a new dean, and last week the office was awarded to John H. McArthur, already second in command as senior associate dean of the faculty of business administration. The appointment of an insider has been widely regarded as Mr. Bok's vote of confidence the school's ability to repair its own deficiencies.

title: Bank Aide to Wed Mary K. Callaghan
description: Mr. and Mrs. William D. Callaghan Jr. of Belleair, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Kathryn Callaghan, to Paul Lukens Miller Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller of New Vernon, N.J.

title: The Buyers Are Very Fearful
description: LOS ANGELES

title: For Tennis Junkie, a Dog's Life
description: WEST REDDING IF there is such a thing as a third world tennis, Joe Fahey Jr. is part of it. The first world is populated with the John McEnroes, Arthur Ashes, Bjorn Borgs and all those other bigtime pros who cannot lift a racket without making $100,000. Joe Fahey Jr. wouldn't know beans about that stratospheric level of the game.

title: Carol L. Huntington Is a Bride
description: In Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston, yesterday afternoon, Carol Lee Huntington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan Trumbull Huntington of Salem, Mass., became the bride of Duncan Earle Chapman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Earle MacArthur Chapman of Brookline, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas B. Kennedy.

title: What's Doing in the TWIN CITIES
description: TWO CITIES  Minneapolis and St. Paul are called the Twin Cities  but if you arrive by plane at Minnesota's two largest cities, what you see from aloft is a practically unbroken pattern of streets or bright lights stretching for miles on each axis, the very picture of unity. When you are afoot, however, unity may well be the last and least impression as you discover two cities competing on a dozen fronts. And if afloat, arriving or sightseeing by boat, you may be even more puzzled to realize that the Mississippi River is a natural divider between the cities for barely four miles while the rest of the river's curving urban sweep has become a unifying influence.

title: MAURICE C. KIVEL
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Oct. 20 (AP)  Maurice C. Kivel, retired chief assistant city editor of The Daily News of New York, died today at De Poo Memorial Doctor's Hospital. He was 78 years old. Mr. Kivel's wife said he had recently suffered a heart attack.

title: Colgate 17, Princeton 6
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 20 (AP)  John Marco threw two scoring strikes and the Colgate defense shut down Princeton's ground game as the Red Raiders triumphed, 176, today.

title: Novel With Notes
description: L KAUFMAN'S first novel since Up the Down Staircase is a book within a book. Jessica, a divorced writer and a teacher of fiction workshops, is struggling to complete a novel about the painful divorce of a woman named Isabel. The emerging chapters, along with several false starts, are presented verbatim, accompanied by Jessica's notes herself  queries, criticisms, thoughts for future chapters. Interspersed, in the form of diary entries and letters to a friend, is the story of Jessica's current love affair with a mysterious silverhaired stranger.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Scouts. Ever since college sports became a matter of national concern, early in this century, many American institutions of higher learning have regularly turned to friends of the university to help scout promising athletes for their teams. The University of Chicago Press, largest of the university presses, is now using this strategy in performing its mission, the dissemination of scholarship.

title: SWINDLER SETS OFF GRAND JURY INQUIRY
description: TRENTON Oct. 19  Allegations by Barry S. Marlin, a convicted swindler who is trying to talk his way out of Federal prison, have brought about a Federal grand jury investigation of $4 million in loans by a New Jersey teamsters pension fund.

title: ANTIQUES
description: VISITORS to most museum houses spend the greater part of their time examining the furnishings. But at 351 Farmington Avenue it is the architecture itself, the stenciled walls and ceilings, the carved and decorated woodwork that command attention.

title: Target Europe
description: BONN  In German, a carrot-and-stick policy translates out to someone who is manipulating both the whip and a sugar cookie. If Leonid L Brezhnev's important speech on European security in Berlin is seen this way, as a combination of threats and proposals to negotiate, then it is the West Germans. of all the Western allies, who are least willing to challenge the lash and most anxious to bite into the confectionery.

title: Weekly Lotto Numbers Drawn
description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 6, 14, 34, 19, 23 and 20. The supplementary number was 1.

title: Sikkimese Fear Loss of Ethnic Identity as Indians Move In
description: GANGTOK, India, Oct. 17  On one level the recent elections in the lush Himalayan state of Sikkim were like the buoyantly retributive last act of a Rudolf Friml operetta.

title: Sports Briefs
description: ROCKINGHAM, N.C., Oct. 21 (AP)  Richard Petty fought back from being one lap down and avoided a fiery crash to win the American 500 Grand National stockcar race today.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Rangers Beat Penguins, 63
description: The 17,425 fans at Madison Square Garden would not stop cheering for Phil Esposito last night.

title: Koch's Performance Wins Mixed Reviews
description: Nearing the midpoint of his term of office, Mayor Koch  whose style has been to ask repeatedly, How am I doing  is generally praised for confronting explosive issues candidly but is criticized for failing to improve the overall delivery of city services.

title: Mozambique Reports Its Forces Shot Down Rhodesian Helicopter
description: LONDON, Oct. 21 (Reuters)  The Moiambic radio reported today that its forces had shot down a Zimbabwe Rhodesian helicopter and repulsed a series of air and ground attacks over the last three days.

title: Refilling Is Delicate Art for Marathon
description: The runner's cry, part solicitation and part desperation, was even more desperate yesterday because the sun was hot and their bodies had been running for miles and miles. In the New York City Marathon, not unlike life in the rest of New York City. there is lime time for pleases and thank yous. The runners just hold out a hand to grab a paper cup, or maybe two  one for now and one for the road.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Few Expect Relief From Higher Rates
description: No relief from higher interest rates is in sight. That is the conclusion several leading moneymarket economists reached late last week after they surveyed the Federal Reserve's actions, the performance of the economy and the demand for borrowed funds over the next several months.

title: Susan Paladino Wed to Peter Lubin of Columbia Records
description: Susan Elizabeth Paladino, daughter of Diane Degen and James A. Paladino, was married at the St. Moritz Hotel yesterday to Peter Sanford Lubin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard L. Lubin of Woodbridge, Conn. Rabbi Roy A. Ro senberg performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Joel E. Scholefield, a Universalist minister.

title: Schultze and Jackson Differ Over Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (Reuters)  President Carter's chief economic adviser said today that the United States inflation rate this year would be slightly below the present 13 percent level, but a leading Senator disagreed with his forecast.

title: Sky Ride Gondolas Fall at Texas State Fair, Killing 1 and Injuring
description: DALLAS, Oct. 21 (UPI)  A gondola car moving on a cable 80 feet above the packed midway at the Texas State Fair snagged on a tower today and was hit from behind by another gondola. Both cars crashed to the tenttop booths below, killing one person and injuring 16.

title: Play: Letters Home From Sylvia Plath
description: ALL of the surprises in Letters Home are sharp disappointments. The new evening at the American Place is, in essence, a staged reading of excerpts from the 696 letters written to her mother by the talented, deeply troubled poet Sylvia Plath. They begin with Miss Plath's going off to college at the age of 20 and end with mother Aurelia Plath's terse, tightlipped comment on her daughter's suicide at 30. But the letters  at least as excerpted and arranged by Rose Leiman Goldemberg  give us virtually no clues at all to the furies that bedeviled, and finally killed, a remarkable young woman.

title: Events
description: THE WINTER DANCERS, by David Lan, presented by the Phoenix Theater, Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street, 6:15.

title: A Wonder of the Race
description: When Grete Waitz ran the 1978 New York Marathon in 2 hours 32 minutes 30 seconds, a world record for women, she was a stranger to the city. Most of the people who saw No. 1173F pass along the 26mile385yard course wondered, who is that tier name was not listed in the official program as she participated in her first marathon.

title: San Francisco's Mayor in Drive to Keep Job She Got by Appointment
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21  Indications are that Dianne Feinstein, who was twice defeated for Mayor but is now holding that post on an interim basis, could be elected to a full term in municipal elections here Nov. 6.

title: Iran Calls For Parley On Oil Price
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 21 (Reuters)  Iran's Oil Minister said yesterday that his country had called for an emergency meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to review world oil prices.

title: Sports Today
description: Steelers vs. Denver Broncos, at Pittsburgh. (TelevisionChannel 7, 9 P.M. RadioWCBS, 9 P.M.)

title: The Wooing of Labor by the White House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21  The Presidential box at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts is lined with plush, contains a small refrigerator, often stocked with champagne, and  on almost any given night, it seems  is occupied by

title: Gilmore of Bulls Faces Knee Surgery
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP)  Artis Gilmore, who had never missed a game in his college and professional basketball career, will undergo knee surgery Wednesday and will be lost to the club for at least two months.

title: Quickened Search for Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21  Moshe Dayan's resignation as Israel's Foreign Minister seems likely to produce a crisis in Middle East negotiations earlier than most American officials had expected.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: $105,000 Is Paid For a Yearling
description: YONKERS, Oct. 21 (AP)  Dowdstown, a colt consigned by Shamrock Farms of Woodbine, Md., was purchased for $105,000, becoming the most expensive of the 135 yearlings bought at Yonkers Raceway's Aid Glory Sate today. Dowdstown was bought by Allen Wechter of New York, head of a petroleum concern.

title: U.S. Expects Bigger Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21  The Federal deficit in fiscal 1980 (which began Oct. 1) could be as much as $10 billion more than the $29 billion tentatively estimated for fiscal 1979, Administration officials said today. This outlook further dims prospects for President Carter's goal of a balanced budget.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Bolivia Puts Aside Political Troubles for O.A.S. Parley
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 21  Although it appeared to be teetering on the edge of a military coup last week, Bolivia seems to have overcome its chronic political instability long enough to be host to the ninth General Assembly of the Organization of American States opening here tomorrow.

title: School Violence in Boston Reflects A DeepSeated Racial Animosity
description: BOSTON, Oct. 21 His straight blond hair just covering his eyes, the junior at South Boston High School hung his head and searched for a reason why, after five years of courtordered busing, schools such as his remain plagued with racial fear, tension and sometimes violence.

title: Sara Gore Davidson Married To David J. Stone in London
description: Sara Gore Davidson, daughter of Mrs. Alfred Rand of New York and the late Ralph Gore, was married in London yesterday to David John Stone. Rabbi Louis Jacob performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Stone.

title: ABROAD AT HOME Memory And Desire
description: BOSTON, Oct. 21  In the sun outside the Kennedy Library the emotions of history and politics and self all ran together. It was a day, in T.S. Eliot's phrase, that mixed memory and desire.

title: Toby Sue Weintraub Married to Robert Jay Beckenstein
description: Toby Sue Weintraub, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Weintraub of Jericho, L.I., was married yesterday in Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I., to Robert Jay Beckenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Beckenstein of West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony.

title: Brazil's Outcast Shanty Dwellers Offered a Helping Hand at Last
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 21The favelas of Brazil, the pastelcolored jumbles of squatters shacks that crop up near modem apartment towers, on hillsides and along the shorelines of the country's major cities, have long attracted social scientists, painters, musicians, poets and folklorists.

title: Chess:
description: Mikhail Tal, the former world champion, played beautifully to win the Interzonal Tournament in Riga, U.S.S.R., with a powerful 143 score. Playing before his hometown fans, the terrible Tal gave evidence that, after a lapse of 18 years, he wants to get the title back.

title: The Missiles of Europe
description: If you think you understand the basic issues of SALT II, you may be ready for the diplomacy now unfolding over the nuclear balance in Europe. This, too, concerns a SovietAmerican arms race, but it turns on the psyches of the Western allies, all of whom are actors in the drama and the smallest of whom may turn out to be decisive. Unless the United States ratifies SALT II, this European contest can end badly for the West. Beyond that, nothing about the matter is either simple or clear.

title: Africa's Rhinos in Peril Because of Superstitions About Their Horns
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Upon receiving an erroneous report recently that the President of the United States had accepted the horn of a rhinoceros from the President of Zaire, the president of the World Wildlife Fund was horrified. The rhino is in desperate straits and laces imminent extinction, Russell Train told Mr. Carter in a cablegram.

title: 8 Ohio Sheriffs Indicted in Year; Latest Guilty on Felony Charges
description: AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 21  Eight Ohio sheriffs have been indicted in the last year on a wide range of felony charges, the latest being the former sheriff of Mahoning County, who was convicted last week on charges of racketeering, bribery and extortion.

title: Carole Wolf Is the Bride Of John Friedler Upstate
description: The marriage of Carole Wolf, a social worker, to John Friedler, an officer of Techint Inc., an international industrial and engineering concern, took place yesterday in Harrison, N.Y., at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Jack Wolf. Rabbi Lawrence Schwartz performed the ceremony.

title: Decorating a New Chinese Restaurant With the Rich Flavor of Elegance
description: They've already done it in England and in California, and next Friday, when Mr. Chow opens on East 57th Street, Tina and Michael Chow will be introducing to New York their latest glittery, elegant and nonChineselooking Lntnese restaurant. to the oegm ning, we were afraid that it wouldn't look lavish enough, said Mrs. Chow. They needn't have worried.

title: Commodities
description: SILVER, sometimes described as the poorer man's inflation hedge because it is cheaper ounceforounce than gold, appeared last week to be hesitating just below the record price levels it reached recently. And most of the small silver speculators appeared to have fled the market.

title: Conoco Raises Dividend
description: Conoco Inc., formerly the Continental Oil Company, yesterday announced a 5 cent increase in its quarterly dividend to 47.5 cents a share, payable Dec. 14 to shareholders of record Nov. 9.

title: A Woman's Crusade Against OneStep Breast Surgery
description: KENSINGTON, Md.  Rose Kushner's surgeon rattled the bars of her crib in the hospital recovery room. His angry face loomed through her anesthetic fog. I never should have let you get away with it. The biopsy shows cancer, he snapped, and strode away.

title: Murphy Reportedly Subject of 3 Inquiries
description: The Internal Revenue Service has opened inquiries into whether Representative John M. Murphy, the nineterm Democratic Representative from Staten Island and lower Manhattan; reported all of his income for the years 1979 to 1978, according to interviews with Government sources.

title: Richard Friedenthal, an Author And Head of West German P.E.N.
description: KIEL, West Germany, Oct. 21 (AP) Richard Friedenthal, an author and honorary chairman of the West German center of P.E.N., the international writers organization, died Friday after suffering an embolism in his lungs, it was announced today. He was 83 years old.

title: Janet Milstein Cox, an Artist, Is Wed to Peter Frank, Critic
description: Janet Milstein Cox, an artist, and Peter Frank, an art critic and curator, were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Reuven Frank of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi Stephen Pinsky performed the ceremony.

title: Advertising
description: Japanese Agency's U.S. Goal

title: Kennedy Archivists Hope for Wide Appeal
description: BOSTON, Oct. 21  For scholars, the new John F. Kennedy Library here is just a shell.

title: Letter: On the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Banks Profitability Tested
description: The thirdquarter profitability of the nation's largest bank holding companies was not as favorable as the yeartoyear increases in the net operating earnings that most of them reported would indicate, according to some banking analysts.

title: The City
description: The president of Fordham University has pledged a renewed commitment by the university to the revitalization of the South Bronx.

title: SOVIET SUPPRESSING DISSIDENT JOURNAL
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 21  An 18-month-old attempt to create an unofficial fat journal, in the tradition of the bulky journals that operated as an unofficial political and cultural forum under czarist censorship, seems headed for defeat.

title: Wilton Holm, 65, Won 2 Oscars For Developing Movie Lenses
description: ROCK ISLAND, III., Oct. 21 (AP)  Wilton Holm, twice an Academy Award winner for his work in developing motion picture lenses, died Thursday in Lutheran Hospital in Moline. He was 65 years old.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: All of us who have ever played baseball learned early to keep the trademark on the bat facing toward us to avoid breaking the bat. I presume this is still advisable, and yet, watching the World Series on television, it appears as if more bats are being broken these days. Is this true, and if so, why? Also, doesn't a batter get more power by hitting the ball where the grain is strongest?

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON WITH price increases running at doubledigit levels, there is new interest in the price indexes used to express the rate of inflation. In particular, complaints are increasing that the Consumer Price Index  the most popular of the measures  overstates the extent to which prices are really increasing. And analysts say that overstate ment is particularly acute wnen inflation results from peculiar factors, as is now the case.

title: Kim Leslie Stanton Wed To Steven S. Ertrachter
description: Kim Leslie Stanton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Stanton of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Steven Sheldon Ertrachter of Kew Gardens, Queens. He is the son of Mrs. Benjamin J. Miller of Far Rockaway, Queens, and the late Herman Ertrachter. The bridegroom's stepfather, Rabbi Miller, performed the ceremony at Leonard's in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Court Orders CBS to Pay Damages to Chaplin Unit
description: A Federal Court has ordered CBSTV to pay $717,281 to Roy Export Company, a company formed by Charles Chaplin to protect his film holdings, and allied plaintiffs as a result of a suit brought against CBS charging violation of copyright and unfair competition. CBS is filing a motion to dismiss the verdict. If the verdict is upheld, it plans to appeal, a spokesman for the network said.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Western economic aid to Peking is under consideration, diplomatic sources said in Paris, with industrialized nations considering the granting of developing nation status to China. The concept, first raised by Japan, was viewed as a means to speed up massive Chinese orders to industrial nations. [D1.]

title: News Summary
description: Moshe Dayan resigned as Israel's Foreign Minister because of his disagreement with Government policy on the future of the West Bank and Gaza. Mr. Dayan has been urging his Cabinet colleagues to adopt a more moderate position in dealing with the Palestinians demand for selfrule. Mr. Dayan said he had been increasingly estranged from the mainstream of Government policy. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Italian Suspect Said to Have Been In City at Time Sindona Vanished
description: Italian authorities say that a businessman they have arrested in connection with the disappearance of Michele Sindona, the Italian financier, was in New York City on Aug. 2 when Mr. Sindona dropped out of sight.

title: NICHOLAS MARCALUS, PAPER MAKER, DEAD
description: Nicholas Marcalus, the inventor of many machines and methods used in the manufacture of paper products, died Saturday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. Mr. Marcalus, who lived in Wyckoff, N.J., was 86 years old.

title: CARTER CITES VIEWS SNARED BY KENNEDY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP)  President Carter says that he is tighter with the Government's money and stronger on military matters than Senator Edward M. Kennedy, his potential rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination. But otherwise, he says, there is little real incompatibility between us.

title: The Power Gamble in Westchester
description: On their ballots next month, Westchester voters will find Proposition One, authorizing the county to buy out Con Edison's facilities for distributing electricity. Some contend that this referendum merely facilitates further study, but in fact passage would sanction a purchase, by condemnation if necessary. And condemnation  with the courts fixing value  would be necessary, for Con Ed is almost certain not to negotiate sale. Proposition One seems an unwise gamble.

title: Concert: Chamber Music Society
description: THE Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, with two new faces, started its season late yesterday afternoon in Tully Hall, and now New York is running on its full music schedule. The new faces were those of Ani Kavafian and AndrMichel Schub. Miss Kavafian has replaced Jaime Laredo, who left Chamber Music Society after five seasons to pursue his own career. Mr. Schub is the replacement for Charles Goode, the pianist who had been with Chamber Music Society since its beginning 11 years ago. He too has a solo career to advance, but he will not altogether be leaving the group, and is scheduled for several appearances this season.

title: A Sad Finale for Frazier
description: THE did not get the big sendoffs that followed Bill Bradley in his final season with the Knicks. There was none of the excitement generated by the Boston Celtics, the league office or national television when John Havlicek's retirement approached. Walt Frazier's illustrious N.B.A. career probably will end quietly and unceremoniously tomorrow afternoon.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Behind the Jets Five Interceptions
description: ON the films that Walt Michaels studied during the week, the Oakland Raiders were using two tight ends, Dave Casper and Raymond Chester, but the Jets coach had seen that before. More than 20 years ago he was a linebacker for the Cleveland Browns in those memorable games with the New York Giants, who occasionally used two tight ends.

title: Citizens to Review Police Shootings in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 21  The Los Angeles Police Commission last week assumed new authority over the disciplining of officers who may have fired their guns too quickly.

title: Golden Act Triumphs in Canada
description: TORONTO, Oct. 21 (UPI)  Golden Act, ridden by Sandy Hawley, charged out of a tight field to beat Trillion, with Willie Shoemaker up, to win the $200,000 Canadian International Championship.

title: Deborah Lehman Bride of Harry Conover
description: The Georgian Suite was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Deborah Lehman, daughter of Penny Hallock Lehman and Robert H. Lehman, to Harry Conover, son of Candy Jones and the late Harry S. Conover. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Ronald Sobel.

title: OMAN RESIGNS POST AS FOREIGN MINISTER IN DISPUTE ON ARABS
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 21Moshe Dayan resigned as Foreign Minister of Israel today in a fundamental disagreement with the Government over the future of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Pitt and Navy Move to Showdown
description: Pittsburgh and Navy moved toward their showdown game next Saturday as if there was no Penn State to worry about in the race for Eastern major college football supremacy. The Panthers will eventually have to reckon with Penn State, and the Middies will avoid meeting the Nittanv Lions this year.

title: Canadiens Tie Flyers On Houle's Goal
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 (AP) Rejan Houle's goal with 2 minutes 49 seconds left in the third period capped a Montreal comeback that earned the Canadiens a 66 tie with the Philadelphia Flyers in a National Hockey League game tonight.

title: Singer Job Cut In Germany
description: KARLSRUHE, West Germany, Oct. 21 (Reuters)  The Singer Company's German subsidiary, Singer G.m.b.H, may have to dismiss up to 50 percent of the 1,100 workers at its plant here over the next two years as part of continuing consolidation, a company spokesman announced on Friday.

title: Around the Nation
description: ROME, Ga., Oct. 21 (AP)  A Federal jury today found Mike Thevis, a pornographer, guilty on three counts of racketeering and murder conspiracy after long trial on charges that he used murder and arson to try to gain control of America's pornography industry.

title: Flemish Protesters Dispersed
description: 'sGRAVENVOEREN, Belgium, Oct. 21 (Reuters)  The police used tear gas and water hoses today to disperse about 1,000 Flemish demonstrators in the town square of tiny 'sGravenvoeren in eastern Belgium. The demonstration was called to press demands that six villages close to the BelgianDutchGerman border area remain part of Dutchspeaking Limbourg Province.

title: Jets Down Raiders, 28 to 19
description: Suddenly, the Jets are no longer afraid to have their defense on the field.

title: PriceFixing Bill Viewed As a Test for Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, resolving a dilemma that has dogged him for five months, has decided to ask the Senate Majority Leader, Robert C. Byrd, to bring to the floor a controversial antitrust measure known as the Illinois Brick bill, according to Senate sources.

title: Funding Called Key to Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP)  The Federal Trade Commission has urged President Carter to allow the several companies who propose to build a pipeline to move Alaskan oil into the United States to compete for financing before deciding which one would be given permission to carry out the project.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Moments after the Pittsburgh Pirates had defeated the Baltimore Orioles in the seventh game of the World Series last Wednesday night, a group of Oriole fans gathered in front of the Baltimore dugout and chanted: We want Earl. They continued chanting for 15 minutes until Earl S. Weaver, the Oriole manager, appeared, tipped his cap, then returned to the privacy of his office. He sat down and began talking about the Series, the climactic seventh game, and wound up discussing his future in baseball after 12 seasons, one world championship and three American League titles with the Orioles.

title: Market Place
description: RISK arbitragers have reeled in the wake of the higher interest rates that have resulted from the Federal Reserve Board's moves to slow the money supply's growth. But because of the subsequent decline in stock prices, there is an opportunity for rich rewards for some who purchase shares in companies about to be acquired.

title: New York's Ethnic Slays Gather for Festival
description: Wearing the traditional babushka of Eastern Europe, Raisa McLachan enjoyed the performance of a folk dance during the second annual InterSlavic Exhibition held yesterday in Manhattan. The festivities, sponsored by St. Sergius High Scool, the nation's only fullyaccredited RussianEnglish preparatory school, included the music, foods, and arts of all the Slavic cultures.

title: U.S. Gets Soccer Tie
description: VOLENDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 21 (UPI)  Greg Villa scored a goal in the 73d minute today and gained a 11 tie for the touring United States national soccer team against the Volendam club.

title: Rock Concert: The Yachts and Dirty Looks
description: THE most impressive thing about The Yachts late show at the Bottom Line on Saturday night was the opening act. Dirty Looks, a rock trio from Staten Island that was recently signed to a contract by England's Stiff Records, has a really fresh perspective on the latest developments in popular music. The mid60's poprock influence that's so pervasive now is present in the group's music, for despite its lean instrumentation Dirty Looks projects a full sound, with Pat Barnes's guitar taking care of both lead and rhythm duties and all three musicians singing. But there's a lot more here than that.

title: Maxine Diamond Married in Jersey
description: Maxine Diamond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Diamond of Pompton Lakes, N.J., was married there yesterday to Samuel Kosofsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Kosofsky of Maplewood, N.J. Rabbis Bernard Schecter and Haskell Lookstein officiated at Temple Beth Shalom.

title: Strange, With 271, Scores First Victory
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Oct. 21 (AP) Curtis Strange rolled in a sixfoot eagle putt on the 15th hole today and scored his first PGA Tour victory, by one shot in the $200,000 Pensacola open.

title: Reserve Begins Getty Talks
description: DENVER, Oct. 21 (Reuters)  The Reserve Oil and Gas Company said that it had begun negotiations for the possible merger of the company into the Getty Oil Company or one of its subsidiaries. The talks are with the con currence of Denison Mines Ltd., which had been negotiating for the acquisition of Reserve.

title: Rogers Beats 11,532 in Marathon As Grete Waitz Makes Record Run
description: Bill Rodgers and Grete Waltz again gave New Yorkers something to cheer about yesterday with spectacular victories in the 10th New York City Marathon.

title: Police Release a Sketch in Case of Missing Patz Boy
description: The police have released an artist's sketch of a man who, detectives say, may have vital information about Etan Patz, who disappeared while on his way to catch a school bus in SoHo last May.

title: 'sagebrush Rebellion? High Noon? Sez Who?
description: LEWISTON, Idaho  There's a rumor going around that the angry West is in revolt against the Federal Government and that we will all ride out any minute now and take over the national forests. Hardly.

title: Soviet Censors in a Losing Battle To Keep Space City Out of Print
description: Soviet censors seem to be fighting a losing battle to keep the name of a highly secret space city out of public print. For the second time in recent years, it has shown up inadvertently in the controlled Soviet press  in a dispatch about an inoperative hotel elevator.

title: Need for Modernizing Erie Canal Muddies Its Future
description: MAY'S POINT, N.Y.  The skipper and mate, garbed in yellow and red foulweather gear, worked topside in a steady rain to dismantle the pilothouse of the Emita II on the Erie Canal. Pilothouse and pilot stand too high on the deck to clear the 100 spans over the channel between Syracuse and Buffalo.

title: Matos Is Freed in Cuba After 20 Years in Prison
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 21  Huber Matos, perhaps the most prominent political prisoner left in Cuba, was set free at 7 A.M. today in Havana, exactly 20 years after he was arrested on charges of treason for having resigned his military post in protest against growing Communist influence in Cuba.

title: Indians and Demonstrators Rally Over Construction of Tellico Dam
description: VONORE, Tenn., Oct. 21 (UPI) Angry Cherokee Indians joined youthful environmentalists over the weekend for pep rally livened by banjo strumming, bomb threat and verbal attacks on the Tennessee Valley Authority's Tellico Dam.

title: Books of The Times
description: ALICE: THE LIFE AND TIMES OF ALICE ROOSEVELT LONGWORTH. By Howard Teichmann. 286 pages. PrenticeHall. $12.95.

title: Special did Suggested For China
description: PARIS, Oct. 21  Major industrial nations, in an effort to strengthen their commercial and political ties with Peking, are giving cautious consideration to offering China the same aid and trade privileges they give developing countries, according to diplomatic sources here.

title: Chicago Crash Inquiry Delayed
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP)  Investigators say it could be up to six months before a report is issued on the cause of the switching error that resulted in the Oct. 12 Amtrak train crash near here. Two persons were killed and 44 iniured when the Amtrak train crashed headon into a parked Illinois Central Gulf freight in the suburb of Harvey. There was indeed an I.C.G. employee who opened that switch moments before the arrival of the passenger train, said William Pugh of the National Transportation Safety Board. We're trying to find out why.

title: Cairo Aide Says Dayan's Decision Reflects Problem in Palestine Talks
description: CAIRO, Oct. 21  Butros Ghali, the Egyptian Foreign Minister, said today that the resignation of Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan showed that Israel's decision to expand its settlements in the West Bank was a hindrance to the negotiations on Palestinian autonomy.

title: World News Briefs
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 21  Uganda closed its borders with its five neighboring countries today and announced that all the nation's currency would be replaced by next Sunday with new shilling notes that no longer bear the image of the deposed dictator Idi Amin.

title: Laker Offers Plan to Cut Cost of Flights in Europe
description: LONDON, Oct. 22  Sir Freddie Laker, the pricecutting nemesis of the airline establishment, is at it again.

title: Study Predicts Soviet Oil Gap
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union may be forced to buy oil from outside sources to supply East European countries in the mid1980's, according to a Congressional study released today.

title: An Author Ponders Metaphysics of Race
description: PARIS

title: Christa Ludwig Sings Lieder
description: WHO is it that can make people deliriously happy by singing sad songs to them? A great lieder artist, of course. Although there is a modicum of good humor in most Heder programs, the inescapable fact is that the literature is heavily weighted toward pain the Herzen and Schmerzen theme that ruled so much of the 19thcentury esthetic.

title: Dance: Kozlovs With the Maryland Ballet
description: WHAT could only be called a heterogeneous evening at the ballet took place Sasturday night at Brooklyn College's Whitman Hall. A program originally planned as the New York debut of the Maryland Ballet also became, by circumstance, an occasion for Leonid and Valentina Kozlov to dance in New York for the first time since they defected from the Bolshoi Ballet while on tour in Los Angeles last month.

title: Outdoors: Waterfowl Hunting in the Northeast
description: HUNCHED against winddriven snow, sleet or rain waiting for a duck or goose to fly within range of my shotgun, I often attain a kind of euphoria without which my life would be poorer.

title: Opera: A New Jos in Met's  Carmen
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's first Carmen of the season on Saturday night proved to be a performance of solid routine, if scarcely one to set the pulses beating. Not much is left of the original Goeren Gentele/Bodo Igesz conception that focused on the tragedy of Don Jos and made extensive use of the spoken dialogue. Instead, we now have a standard grandopera Carmen with the Guiraud recitatives and the heroine very much back in the limelight.

title: Caboose Mentality
description: BILLINGS, Mont.  For probably the last time, the full length of the westbound North Coast Hiawatha had pulled out of the eastern Montana town of Glendive. A few people quietly watched as the train and an era left their station; most simply could not believe that a Government preaching gas conservation was ending passenger rail service in this land of farflung communities.

title: Lon Susan Goldsholle Is Bride
description: Lori Susan Goldsholle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Goldsholle of Brooklyn, and Dr. Robert Steven Lash, son of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin H. Lash of North Woodmere, L.I. were married yesterday. Rabbi Arnold Marans performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Giants Win on a Fumble
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 21  Less than two minutes remained when The Fumble happened again, but this time the ball bounced the Giants way.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Dieter zur Loye, 51 years old, has been named senior executive vice president and chief operating officer of the American Hoechst Corporation. On Jan. 1 he will move into this No. 2 spot at the United States subsidiary of the world's largest chemical company, Hoechst A.G. of West Germany. He will succeed H. Klaus Hamann, 64, who now holds the titles of vice chairman and senior executive vice president and who will become a senior adviser.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: TV: Pregnancy at Age 46
description: A ND Baby Makes Six, which will be seen from 9 to 11 o'clock tonight on NBC, describes what happens when a 46yearold woman, played by Colleen Dewhurst, with three children, the youngest of whom is 18, learns that she is inadvertently pregnant.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Basketball fans confined to a room, office or the like can still take their shots with Mini Basketball, a set that consists of a 16by24inch wood backboard, a steel hoop seven and a half inches in diameter with net, and a threeandahalfinch rubber basketball. The backboard can be easily hung on a door. Priced at $20, plus postage, it also includes a logo of a National Basketball Association team or most colleges, as requested. The kit may be ordered directly from Durham Wood Products, Post Office Box 1931, Durham, N.C. 27702, (919) 6881356.

title: Study Discloses Banks Practices In Releasing Data on Customers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21  Federal, state and local governmental agencies last year asked the average large bank in the United States for information about the financial activities of 483 of the bank's customers, a survey by University of Illinois researchers has found.

title: TV: A British Salute To U.S. Stage Lyricists
description: ONE of the most attractive things about Song by Song is the snazzy ad that Mobil Oil, the underwriter, is distributing all over town, from Playbill magazine to BusStop Shelters. Curiously, the same ad may turn out to be something of a liability. The image of an elegant 1930's couple dancing across a giant piano keyboard promises the charm and vitality of an old Fred AstaireGinger Rogers movie. This new television project comes closer to a glossy version of Name That Tune.

title: Revue: Bebop Takes Look at Late-40's Jazz
description: NOW that early black musicals have provided a framework for Eubie, Harlem in the 20's and 30's for Ain't Misbehavin  and the Swing Era for The 1940's Radio Hour, the next logical musical progression is to the later 1940's and bebop. Hence the musical revue called Bebop at the Wonderhorse Theater in which the now classic improvisations of Charlie Parker, Dizzy Gillespie, Thelonious Monk, Bud Powell and other boppers are sung, danced and played by a company that includes a quintet of appropriately knowledgeable and skilled musicians along with five singers of varied backgrounds.

title: Jazz: Baikida Carroll Leads Septet Called Ring
description: AIKIDA CARROLL has been one of the more impressive trumpeters in the new jazz for several years now. He boasts a big sound, firm control in all registers and an original conception that updates aspects of several jazz trumpet lineages, including those of both Miles Davis and Fats Navarro. This listener always enjoyed his work as a sideman but never really thought too much about whether he might have something original to say as a composer and group leader  until Saturday night at the Public Theater.

title: Submarine Study of Lake Tahoe Brought to Early End by a Storm
description: TAHOE CITY, Calif., Oct. 21 (UPI)  The first submarine exploration of Lake Tahoe, one of the world's deepest lakes, ended yesterday when storms forced the cancellation of the remaining dives.

title: Connally Argues Realism Is Base Of Mideast Plan
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 21  John B. Connally, the former Texas Governor, strongly defended his peace proposal for the Middle East, which has drawn sharp criticism from some Jewish groups and several of his rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Notes on People
description: The master photographer Henri CartierBressan is coming to New York from his home in Paris for the Nov. 11 opening of a 50year retrospective of his work at the International Center of Photography, but under stiff conditions.

title: Boy's Leukemia Death Is Confirmed in Autopsy
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 21 (AP)  Leukemia caused the death of Chad Green, his doctor confirmed yesterday after conferring with a pathologist who assisted with the boy's autopsy.

title: U.S. Aid for Academic Centers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP)  The Department of Health, Education and Welfare today announced the award of almost $8 million in grants to 108 colleges and universities to assist members of mi nority groups and female swamis uo graduate and professional study. Of the total, $6.77 million will provide funds for 874 fellowships, while $1.11 million will be used for recruiting, counseling, special orientation and student services.

title: Resignation by Dayan Could Lead To Solution of Problem in Cabinet
description: TEL AVIV, Oct 21  Moshe Dayan's resignation today shook a Government whose survival had already been in doubt, but political sources here said that it might also have opened a door to a solution to a broader crisis the Government is facing over the economy.

title: Cambodian Refugees Find Little Aid Along Border
description: BAN KLONG WAH, Thailand, Oct. 20  From the northern end of Cambodia's border with Thailand to its terminal in the Gulf of Siam, a traveler sees hunger, illness and the suffering spirit in all its forms. In four days of journeying alone the heavily forested frontier, there is little evidence of the major international aid effort that that has been the subject of diplomacy and official declarations.

title: OTC Funds List
description: Because of a computer malfunction, the weekly table of supplementary overthecounter listings of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers was unavailable.

title: Winn's Stores Merger
description: Winn's Stores, based in San Antonio, said Friday that it had entered into a definitive merger agreement that provides for its acquisition for $50 million by a United States subsidiary of Heinrich Bauer Verlag, a West German publishing concern. Winn's previously announced that its board had approved the plan.

title: Koch Sets Feb. 23 for the Start Of LongPlanned Trip to China
description: Mayor Koch has set Feb. 23 for the start of his longplanned visit to China, during which he and at least three other city officials will try at their own expense to drum up business and good will for New York City.

title: Venezuela Sets OilPrice Curb
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 21 (UPI)  Venezuela will not push its oil prices above the $23.50abarrel ceiling set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Humberto Caldern, Minister of Energy and Mines, announced.

title: Bridge:
description: There have been exciting finishes to the world championship in the three decades since the Bermuda Bowl contests were begun: St. Vincent, Italy, in 1963, and Bermuda in 1975 are examples that come to mind. But for the viewers watching on VuGraph. nothing has been quite as heartstopping as Friday's finish in Rio de Janeiro.

title: RENEWED SHELLING JARS SOUTH LEBANON
description: BEAUFORT CASTLE, Lebanon, Oct. 21  From the ancient battlements of this Crusader fortress, Palestinian guerrillas can look down across the Litani River to the strip of southern Lebanon controlled by Israelibacked militias that once were part of the Lebanese Army.

title: Dispute at Times of London Ends; Paper Plans to Publish Next Month
description: LONDON, Oct. 21  The labor dispute that has kept The Times and The Sunday Times of London off the streets for almost 11 months was settled today, and the two newspapers plan to resume publication about the middle of next month.

title: 2 Journalists Win Cabot Awards For Their Work on the Americas
description: Juan Zuleta Ferrer, director of El Colombiano, a newspaper in Medellin, Colombia, and Jeremiah O'Leary Jr., diplomatic correspondent for The Washington Star, will receive the 1979 Maria Moors Cabot Prizes tomorrow night for distinguished journalistic contributions to the advancement of interAmerican understanding.

title: Violin: Ricci's Golden Jubilee On the Stage
description: UGGIERO RICCI'S violin recital Saturday night at Carnegie Hall marked a special occasion  the 50th anniversary of his New York debut as an 11yearold prodigy. The concert was also made special by the phenomenal Martha Argerich, who joined Mr. Ricci in sonatas by Franck and Prokofiev (Op. 94a). The pianist, hardly known as a chamber musician, did her first international concert playing on tour with Mr. Ricci as a teenager; when she heard he was celebrating his Golden Jubilee here, she volunteered to be his partner.

title: Economists Criticize Volcker
description: BOSTON, Oct. 21  Wherever Paul A. Volcker was last Friday, his ears must have been burning, for the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and his recent moves to tighten credit came under blistering criticism from some of the nation's most distinguished economists.

title: Effects Are Disputed as Migrants Continue Ohio Tomato Walkout
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 21 (UPI)  Both sides claim success after the second harvest season of a strike by migrant farm labor in the tomato fields of northwest Ohio.

title: Lynn Flaster Married to Kenneth Alvord
description: Lynn Meredith Flaster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Flaster of Floral Park, L.I., and Kenneth Barnham Alvord of Washington, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Donald Alvord of Clearwater, Fla., were married yesterday by Rabbi Eugene Lipsey at the Flaster home.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  Everyone who has helped a President prepare for a meeting with reporters is aware of the phenomenon that can be called the phantom press conference.

title: Susan Klebanoff, a Writer, Is Bride of Peter Fleischman
description: Susan Klebanoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Klebanoff of Verona, N.J., was married last evening to Peter G. Fleischman, son of Mrs. Stephan Fleischman of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the late Mr. Fleischman. Rabbi Herbert Weiner performed the ceremony at the TavernontheGreen.

title: De Gustibus Too Kay, And Other Anecdotes
description: Looking through my files recently, I came across one of my favorite food anecdotes. It is from a book by the late novelist Elliot Paul, who wrote The Last Time I Saw Paris, as well as many mysteries.

title: Letter From Dayan Telling Israeli Leader Reasons for Quitting
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 21 (AP)  Following is an unofficial translation of Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan's letter of Oct. 2 to Prime Minister Menachem Begin explaining the reasons behind his wish to resign. At today's regular Cabinet meeting, Mr. Dayan gave Mr. Begin a brief letter saying he had decided to resign.

title: Pumpkins in Good Supply
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP)  The Department of Agriculture says it is lucky that Halloween comes in October because 80 percent of all fresh pumpkins in the United States are marketed then. Bill Paterson, a marketing expert, says the pumpkin supply should be adequate but prices may be slightly higher than a year ago.

title: Colby Urges the Senate To Approve Arms Pact
description: William E. Colby, former director of Central Intelligence, urged the Senate yesterday to approve the nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: Fairbanks at Colorado: 15 and Building
description: BOULDER, COLO.

title: Heavy Financing Set By U.S. Amid 12% Rates
description: This week, the Treasury will sell twoyear notes that may yield more than 12 percent  the highest rate the department has ever paid, exceeding even rates paid during the turbulent period between Abraham Lincoln's election in 1860 and his inauguration in 1861.

title: Michael Grossinger Weds Sally Trinca
description: The marriage of Sally Trinca to Michael Grossinger took place yesterday at Grossinger's Hotel. Chief Justice Milton Mollen of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: Gerulaitis Is Fined After Beating Vilas
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 21 (AP) Topseeded Vitas Gerulaitis overcame his temper and Guillermo Vilas today, winning the $175,000 Australian indoor .tennis championship. The American, who was fined $250 for making an obscene gesture, earned $34,290 for his 46. 63. 61. 76 triumph in the final.

title: New Yorkers Take Marathon in Stride
description: It was the biggest marathon in history, and it drew a record crowd. And, as it has increasingly each year, yesterday's New York City Marathon turned the five boroughs into a cheering section for what Mayor Koch labels the best happening in the world.

title: Redskin Defense Stops Eagles, 177
description: Two weeks ago, the Washington Redskin defense was in shame following a 2817 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles. They had permitted Wilbert Montgomery to score four touchdowns and to gain 127 yards.

title: Marathons Run At Three Sites
description: New York City was not the only site of a marathon yesterday. While 11,533 racers answered the starting gun here, about 7,500 runners were in the starting field in Chicago for the America's MarathonChicago race, while another group or runners in Virginia staged the second annual Richmond Marathon.

title: Bronx Science, Despite Changes, Still a Top School
description: Even for the Bronx High School of Science, a school that is used to high honors, the news that two of its graduates had become Nobel laureates was a reason for surprise and celebration.

title: Trial by Association
description: Stephen Aiello, the president of the New York City Board of Education, is being considered for appointment as a White House assistant for ethnic affairs. He has strong credentials: intelligence, capacity to work with people, interest and experience in addressing ethnic problems. He has been an able member of the Board of Education since 1971 and the idea of his appointment has won the support of educators and other prominent New Yorkers.

title: To Get Advice
description: The address of Rose Kushner's Breast Cancer Advisory Center is P.O. Box 422, Kensington, Md., 20795.

title: Beverly Solochek Is Married
description: Beverly Solochek, a writer with the ABCTV Good Morning America show, and Joseph P. Fried, a reporter with The New York Times, were married yesterday at the Central Synagogue by Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman. The bride, who will keep her maiden name, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Solochek of Milwaukee, where her father is a partner in the publicrelations concern of Barkin Herman Solochek Paulsen Inc. Mr. Fried is the son of Irving Fried of Brooklyn, a retired truckman, and the late Mrs. Fried.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PRANKS AND CANDOR Two merryeyed satirists, Marjorie Burren and Nelson Avidon, have been drawing praise at various clubs for their comedysketch performance titled Unnatural Acts, reportedly as funny as that title is misleading. When Greenwich Village's Duplex concentrated on humor rather than music last month down at 55 Grove Street, Unnatural Acts turned out to be one of the cabaret's most popular bills.

title: Korean Boat With 23 Is Missing
description: TOKYO, Oct. 21 (AP)  A 91ton South Korean fishing boat with 23 crew members is missing off northern Japan after a typhoon, the Japanese Maritime Safety Agency said today. An agency official said the Ildong No. 15 lost radio contact with another South Korean fishing boat last night after sending a distress call saying fishing nets had caught in its propeller. said the Ildong No. 15 lost radio contact with another South Korean fishing boat last night after sending a distress call saying fishing nets had caught in its propeller.

title: BONN WELCOMES HUA IN LOWKEY FASHION, REFLECTING UNEASE
description: BONN, Oct. 21  Prime Minister Hua Guofeng of China arrived here today on the second stop of his threeweek tour of Western Europe and received a lowkey welcome from West German officials that betrayed some discomfort within the Government of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt about the visit.

title: Sarah Wald Bride Of Steven D. Stark
description: At the Woman's National Democratic Club in Washington at noon yesterday, Sarah Elizabeth Wald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wald of Chevy Chase, Md., became the bride of Steven David Stark, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Stark of Bethesda, Md. Rabbi David Saperstein performed the ceremony.

title: Fashion Revivals: Are the 1980's Really Ready for the 1960's?
description: It has long been a maxim of fashion that, sooner or later, everything comes back into style. It still is, only nowadays things are coming back sooner and sooner.

title: The Region
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  After two years of debate over student living and the future of private eating clubs, Princeton University has decided to establish a system of residential colleges like those at Harvard and Yale and to encourage the clubs to join it.

title: In Soweto They Danced
description: JOHANNESBURG

title: Proposal for U.S. Aid to Expand Key West Hotel Draws Criticism
description: KEY WEST, Fla.  A proposal that would put almost $1 million in Federal urbanassistance money into the expansion of a luxury hotel here has met with criticism by opponents who charge that it could damage rather than improve the living standard of this resort city's lowerincome residents.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Amex Commodities Exchange has elected Elliot J. Smith chairman and J. Gary Windus a vice president.

title: Patriot Rally Beats Dolphins, 2813
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Oct. 21  The standing ovation for the defensive team, a warming moment in the National Football League, took place again and again here today in the second half, as a capacity crowd of 61,096 at Schaefer Stadium saluted the New England Patriots effort against the Miami Dolphins.

title: Government Accounting Experiment
description: Some 3,000 state and local governments are being asked to keep their financial records the way businesses do in an experiment designed by the accountants professional organization, the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants.

title: Letters
description: In supporting Carol Bellamy's highly commendable efforts to improve the fostercare system in New York City (news story Oct. 9), it is vital not to indict foster parents in general for the abuses of a very, very few.

title: Bethpage Wins Polo
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., Oct. 21  Joe Schwartz scored two goals and led the Bethpage polo team to a 42 victory over Huntington today at Bethpage state part. Led Shapiro also had a goal for Bethpage, which enjoyed a onegoal handicap. Chris LeSauvage and Tom Monaco scored for Huntington.

title: Two Groups of Cuban Refugees Rescued From Boats Off Florida
description: MIAMI, Oct. 23 (AP)  Two groups of Cuban refugees, including a 3monthold baby, have been rescued from the seas between Cuba and the Florida Keys, the Coast Guard said today.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Prices of gold, silver and copper futures closed moderately lower yesterday as professional traders continued to extricate themselves from spreads that had backfired in the recent volatile market.

title: U.S. May Sue Over Oil Spill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI)  The Federal Government is expected to sue Sedco Inc., a Texas oildrilling concern, tomorrow for hundreds of millions of dollars in damages as a result of the world's worst oil spill, sources said today. More than 100 million gallons of oil have gushed from the Ixtoc I well in the Gulf of Mexico since the blowout June 3.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization's meeting in December gives the Carter Administration a strong new argument for the ratification of SALT II, which is in doubt in a Senate that still seems to see peripheral problems more clearly than it does the treaty itself.

title: Nadia Boulanger, Teacher of Top Composers, Dies
description: Nadia Boulanger, the French teacher of musical composition whose pupils included Aaron Copland, Virgil Thomson, Roy Harris, Elliott Carter, David Diamond and many other prominent American composers, died yesterday in her apartment in Paris after having been in coma for three weeks. She was 92 years old.

title: OBSERVER
description: Like American beers, Presidential candidates these days are all pretty much the same  heavily watered for blandness, and too much gas. This homogenizing of candidates results because the American Presidential election has turned into an advertising campaign, complete with markettest studies aimed at discovering what buyers will put up with. campaign, complete with markettest studies aimed at discovering what buyers will put up with.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Toll From Korea Rioting Shrouded
description: PUSAN, South Korea, Oct. 22  It was dark in the vestry at the Protestant church. Two South Korean youths leaned forward and craned their heads.

title: Dr. Kanematsu Sugiura, 89, Dies; A Pioneer in Cancer Chemotherapy
description: Dr. Kanematsu Sugiura, a research scientist and pioneer in the development of chemotherapy for treating cancer, died of a stroke Sunday at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. He was 89 years old and lived in Harrison, N.Y.

title: Zapata Plans to Sell Mines in Canada
description: The Zapata Corporation of Houston announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell its Canadian copper mining assets to Noranda Mines Ltd. of Toronto for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Bolivia Opens O.A.S. Assembly With Disputes on Land and Tin
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 22  Bolivia opened the ninth General Assembly of the Organization of American States today, claiming territory for an outlet to the Pacific Ocean and protesting United States plans to sell stockpiled tin.

title: soviet TV: Heroes, Workers and the Party Line
description: CONSIDERING that is was made for Swiss television, the neutral tone of Soviet TV: Heroes, Workers and the Party Line was probably to be expected. Whether this presentation of the world series, which will be seen from 10 to 11 o'clock tonight on WNETTV, had to be quite so dull is another matter.

title: Sun Turbulence Approaches Peak Period
description: Aweather report for the solar system this week might read something like this: Fair, light winds, but gathering storms. The sun, in fact, is relatively quiet these days  insofar as an inferno of thermonuclear reactions can be quiet  but it is entering a period that scientists predict could be one of the most turbulent on record, a time of roiling magnetic forces, twisting and knotting just beneath the surface, with menacing blemishes like storm clouds on the surface, and great explosions that spew hot gases and intense radiations out into interplanetary space.

title: Udall Offers Bill to Limit Powers of Energy Board
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  Representative Morris K. Udall and a bipartisan group of House conservationists moved today to block an energy bill that would permit a new Federal board to override substantive Federal, state and local law.

title: Clint Hodgins, 72, Leading Driver And Owner of Harness Horses
description: LONDON, Ontario, Oct. 22 (AP) Clint Hodgins, a member of harness racing's Hall of Fame, died last night after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

title: The Next Rhodesian Hurdle
description: Through persistence, brinkmanship and legerdemain, British diplomacy has somehow kept the London talks on Zimbabwe Rhodesia alive. The acceptance by all parties of a Britishsponsored constitution is itself an interim triumph. Now the British must pass the test they have set for themselves: to forge a comprehensive agreement that will end a civil war and assure a fair vote for a new government. Such an accord would not only end the drift to racial war in southern Africa; it would write an honorable finale to an imperial history.

title: One of Two Seized as `Hillside Strangler Pleads Guilty and Gets Life
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 22  Kenneth A. Bianchi, who, psychiatrists say, may have been driven to commit murder by the effects of a pathological motherson relationship, today admitted the strangulation murders of five young women and was sentenced to life in orison.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods is shown. (N) indi cates stack is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Bridge:
description: Whenever a match is won by a small margin, the losing players are likely to brood for several days on the decisions they made that could have tipped the scale in their favor if made differently. And if the match is a world team championship, as happened four days ago in Rio de Janeiro, the brooding may continue for years.

title: Kennedy Presses Leadership Issue In Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22  Senator Edward M. Kennedy said tonight that the American people want action, not ex cuses and need the same quality of leadership we have always had that are great moments in the past.

title: Humane Society Hailed at Gala 75th
description: Glamour was the lure for last night's party at the Rainbow Room to celebrate the Humane Society's 75th anniversary. The attractions included entertainment by Bobby Short, a raffle of designer evening fashions and another of such prizes as a Cartier ring and a gourmet cruise on the Avon River in England, and, not least, the Art Deco splendor of the Rainbow Room itself. It was a difficult combination to resist. and very few of those invited did.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Earning more  and reporting less? According to University of Wisconsin economist Edgar Feige, you are not alone. Writing in the November issue of Challenge magazine, he estimates that as much as one dollar of income in four never enters the books.

title: Muriel Ashwell, Helped The Elderly in New York
description: Muriel W. Ashwell, for many years an advocate for New York's elderly, died Saturday at Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx of injuries received in a traffic accident. She was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Method Found To Increase Whooping Crane Population
description: SOMEWHERE between Idaho and New Mexico last week researchers who were anxiously tracking the flight of a southbound whooping crane with a radio transmitter about the size of a lima bean strapped to its leg lost contact with it. But on Wednesday the 5monthold bird's first migratory flight ended successfully when it landed at a crane wintering refuge in southern New Mexico. The researchers breathed a sigh of relief, for the flight of the bird, whose species is threatened with extinction, had been an historic one.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Deaths

title: S. & P. Cuts Rating On Fidelity Bond
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday that it had lowered its rating on mortgagebacked notes of the Fidelity Bond and Mortgage Company to A3 from A1. S. & P. said it downgraded the notes because trading transactions caused sudden and unexpected losses.

title: Gag Order Covers Murder Trial
description: Over the objections of lawyers for the defense, a State Supreme Court justice in the Bronx yesterday barred prosecutors, defense attorneys, witnesses, court personnel and the police from outofcourt discussion of an impending murder trial.

title: ExWife of Washington's Mayor Is Linked to a Fraud of $600,000
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP)  In 1967, President Johnson's War on Poverty helped a pioneering effort called Pride Inc. to provide jobs and selfconfidence to Washington's black teenagers and former convicts.

title: Panel Gets Long View of Fuel Sources
description: SECAUCUS, N.J., Oct. 22  A Federal commission studying the merits of producing alcohol fuel from corn, sugar, wheat, garbage and sewage sludge got a bird'seye view today of two potential sources of the energy alternative and gasoline supplement  the vast garbage dumps of New York City and northern New Jersey.

title: Dr. Robert Krooth, 51, A Specialist in Genetics
description: Dr. Robert Schild Krooth, chairman of the department of human development and genetics at the Columbia University medical school, was found dead in his apartment on Sunday, apparently of selfinflicted gunshot wounds. He was 51 years old and lived at 100 Haven Avenue in Manhattan

title: Sale of Orioles to Williams Approved by Club Owners
description: American League baseball team owners approved unanimously yesterday the sale of the Baltimore Orioles to Edward Bennett Williams, a Washington attorney.

title: Deaths
description: COHANFay L, wife of the late Lee, dear sister of Arm Dryer and Lena Levin. devoted and and greataunt. Services were held October 21 at The Riverside.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: HIKASTA, of course, is our earth, as watched over and trifled with by three separate galactic empires for millions of years of botched evolution. Once upon a time, we were good genetic material.

title: Special Coin Phone Credit Card available for those customers who have certain disabilities
description: On November 1 we are introducing, subject to Public Service Commission approval, a Special Coin Credit Card Service for customers who qualify because of visual or physical dis abilities.

title: MURDERER IN CASINO EXECUTED IN NEVADA
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Oct. 22  Jesse Walter Bishop was put to death in the gas chamber early today for a murder he committed two years ago. It was the first execution in Nevada in 18 years, and only the third in the nation in the last 12.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: Every piece of jewelry has a story to tell.

title: Events Today
description: THE WHOLE SHOOTING MATCH, by Eagle Pennell, at the Public Theater, 125 Lafayette Street.

title: Arms Pact Races the Clock
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  Earlier this month, New York's Daniel Patrick Moynihan told his fellow senators that the constantly increasing inventory of nuclear weapons confronted mankind with

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TONE TEAMS Young Brooks Kerr, the pianist and singer, has drawn praise from John S. Wilson of The New York Times as an engaging and authoritative exponent of Duke Ellington's ballads. As this week's entertainer at the Citicorp Center, Mr. Kerr will be presenting a mixed songbag, blending Ellington songs with those of Harold Arlen, George Gershwin, Irving Berlin and James P. Johnson. Near the keyboard will be Sonny Greer, the famous Ellington drummer, now 83 years old. Mr. Greer was with the Ellington band when he arrived in New York in 1923, and remained with the group for more than 30 years.

title: Hanover Bank to Buy First Penn Finance Units
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to pay $106.5 million to acquire the consumerfinance and mortgageservicing subsidiaries of the First Pennsylvania Corporation.

title: The 60 Trail Blazers Emphasize Defense
description: When the National Basketball Association season began, fans thoughts turned to instant offense  the exciting oneonone play of Lloyd Free, the magical moves of Julius Erving, the 3point play. In Portland, however, the Trail Blazers have been restoring

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Senator Criticizes Moves To Ease U.S. Regulation
description: RESTON, Va., Oct. 22  The chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee bluntly warned Federal regulatory agencies today to be more cautious in their moves to relax their control over industries and wait for clearer directions from Congress.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILINGTODAY

title: Recital: PrizeWinning Baritone
description: JAY WILLOUGHBY, winner of the 1979 Joy in Singing Award Recital, picked up the prize at Alice Tully Hall last Thursday by singing a recital there under Joy in Singing auspices. It was his New York recital debut.

title: WHITNEY STONE, 71, OF ATOMIC INDUSTRY
description: Whitney Stone, chairman of the executive committee of the Stone and Webster Engineering Corporation and a prominent figure in thoroughbred horse racing, breeding and equestrian sports, died Sunday at his farm in Charlottesville, Va., where he bred horses. He made his permanent home in New York City. Mr. Stone was 71 years old.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Thomas A. Vanderslice, executive vice president of the General Electric Company, has been named president and chief operating officer of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, effective Dec. L The post has been vacant since 1976, when Theodore F. Brophy was elected chairman and chief executive officer.

title: U.S. Files Five Suits Charging Sears With Job Bias
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  The Federal Government today filed five suits against Sears, Roebuck & Company, charging the world's largest retailer with discriminating against women, blacks and Hispanic persons.

title: A Test for Democrats Who Seek Javits Seat
description: Potential candidates for the Democratic nomination next year for the United States Senate seat held by Jacob K. Javits will be questioned on economic and physical resource development tonight at the first of three forums sponsored by the Americans for Democratic Action.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION What Can Be Done About Dropouts?
description: A dismal, eloquent, straightforward description of a most serious problem. That was how Ronald Edmonds described last week's disclosure that nearly half of New York City's high school students never make it graduation. Mr. Edmonds is senior assistant to School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola and former acting director of Harvard's Center for Urban Studies.

title: U.S. Policy On Angola
description: LOS ANGELES  Until his death in September, Angola's first President, Agostinho Neto, was described in the news media as a Soviet puppet and a dogmatic Marxist, while United States officials were concerned more with his Cuban guests than his foreign and domestic policies. Since his death. he has been described as moderate ... a strong nationalist ... honest ... committed to nonalignment ... [and an] uncompromising supporter of multiracialism.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Gold
description: Handy & Harman: base price, NY

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Plan Revived for Plant to Make A Synthetic Gas Out of Coal
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, the Government ratesetting body for natural gas, overruled one of its hearing officers today and tentatively cleared the way for the country's first commercial plant that would manufacture synthetic pipeline gas from coal.

title: Atlanta Acts to Fight Crime After Spate of Slayings
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 22  A legal secretary to former Gov. Carl Sanders was shot to death during the lunch hour in the center of downtown last week by a Vietnam veteran who then killed himself, setting off chain reaction of outrage, protests and fear.

title: About New York
description: Standing in line comes with growing up in New York. New Yorkers stand in chic lines to see movies on the East Side, in financial lines to deal with bank tellers, in automotive lines to get driver's licenses, in health lines to get medical care, in gourmet lines to get tables for gracious dining. Lines often become transient communities of their own, people of common interest waiting for common goals.

title: Carter, in Shift, Backs New Arms For Moroccans
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  In a shift in policy, President Carter has decided to seek Congressional approval for the sale of armed reconnaissance planes and helicopter gunships to Morocco for use against guerrillas contesting its control over the Western Sahara.

title: Major Tax Revisions Discussed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  Farreaching changes in the Federal tax system were discussed in Congress today.

title: A New Museum Traces Blacks Role in Fashion
description: The Sunday dress Rosa Parks designed .in 1955 has never been worn. Shortly before the dress was finished, its creator changed history. Mrs. Parks, a black woman, refused to give up her seat .on the bus to a white man. Her subsequent arrest brought about the Montgomery, Ala., bus boycott, and that resulted in the Supreme Court ruling that bus segregation is unconstitutional.

title: The Region
description: CarterArtis Appeal Rejected by Court

title: Forum on BlackJewish Relations Hears Vows for Initiatives on Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  Relations between black and Jewish civil rights organizations bave been seriously set back by the continuing debate on affirmative action policies and over whether Palestinians should have a role in settling the conflict in the Middle East, representatives of two of those organizations said at a public forum here last night.

title: Midland Bank and Heller Terminate Merger Accord u.s. to Settle
description: LONDON, Oct. 22  The proposed $520 million acquisition of the Walter E. Heller International Corporation by Midland Bank Ltd. has fallen through, both companies announced in a onesentence statement tonight.

title: Good Fumble Sends Giant Hopes Soaring
description: A day later, it still seemed unreal, as unreal as the lightning and thunder that shook Kansas City, Mo., after the Giants left Sunday night with an incredible 2117 victory over the Chiefs and their first threegame winning streak since Phil Simms entered high school.

title: News Summary
description: American military aid to Morocco has been approved by President Carter. In a policy shift, he decided to seek Congressional approval of the sale of armed reconnaissance planes and helicopter gunships for use against guerrillas contesting Morocco's control over the Western Sahara. Opposition by key members of Congress is anticipated. [Page A1, Column 5.]

title: Deposed Shah of Iran Reported Ill And Flown to New York for Tests
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI)  Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, the deposed Shah of Iran, in rapidly failing health, was flown to New York today for medical examinations, the State Department said.

title: Study Depicts Mayan Decline
description: N0E of the great mysteries of human history has been the sudden collapse of one of the main centers of Mayan civilization in Central America at a time when it was apparently at a peak of culture, architecture and population around A.D. 800.

title: 6 CZECH DISSIDENTS ON TRIAL IN PRAGUE
description: PRAGUE, Oct. 22 (Reuters)  Six Czechoslovak dissidents went on trial today on subversion charges.

title: Berliner Gets 11Year Term
description: EAST BERLIN, Oct. 22 (AP)  An East German court in Frankfurt on the Oder sentenced Werner Stufe of West Berlin to 11 years imprisonment today for trying to help people escape to the West. He was found guilty of having abused the transit agreement that allows travelers from West Germany to cross East Germany on their way to West Berlin.

title: Stress in the Lives of Women: Seminar Examines Its Causes
description: Stress is not killing women, but it may be killing the unmeasurable parts, particularly their spirit.

title: State Justice Testifies On Scotto Reputation And Calls It Excellent
description: Justice William C. Thompson of the New York State Supreme Court testified yesterday that Anthony M. Scotto of the International Longshoremen's Association was a labor leader with an excellent reputation.

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Indiana Pacers, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:30 P.M. (Television  Manhattan cable, 7:30 P.M. Radio WNEW, 7:25 P.M.)
