title: Church Backs OilCurb Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) Senator Frank Church said today that big oil companies should be forced to put their earnings into finding new energy supplies.

title: Institute Is Championing Poetry's Cause
description: M.L. ROSENTHAL  poet, critic and teacher  looks around and sees a world in which dance audiences are burgeoning, museums are packed and concerts are oversubscribed. But he sees, too, that there seem to be few public poets. Something, he says, has separated the people from their poetry.

title: Street Cleanup Ads Get Free Ride Worth $100,000
description: New York City's volunteer street cleanup campaign, headed by an organization known as I Love a Clean New York Inc., will intensify its efforts to enlist public support with the help of $100,000 worth of donated advertising space in buses, subways and terminals.

title: Around the Nation
description: RENO, Nev., Oct. 22 (AP)  Gov. Robert List ordered the closing today of the state's lowlevel radioactive waste dump  an action that leaves only one such commercial waste site in the country.

title: Howard Johnson Acquisition Gains
description: LONDON, Oct. 22 (Reuters)  Imperial Group Ltd. said today that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Howard Johnson Company for $28 a share, or a total of $630 million.

title: Japan Bank Rate Up
description: TOKYO, Oct. 22 (AP) The average interest rate on business loans at 13 major Japanese commercial banks increased by 0.229 percentage points during September to stand at 6.37 percent a year, the Bank of Japan said today.

title: Beechhurst Residents Oppose Builder's Landfill Plan
description: A developer's request for permission to fill in a small strip of the East River in Beechhurst, Queens, drew accusations yesterday from residents of the area that the developer had already illegally filled in part of the property.

title: Texaco Reports Natural Gas Find Off New Jersey
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 22 (AP) Texaco Inc. struck natural gas about 105 miles off the midAtlantic coast, the third such discovery in a small area of the Baltimore Canyon Trough, the oil company announced today.

title: FarmCity Week Proclaimed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI)  President Carter said today that he had proclaimed Nov. 1622 as National FarmCity Week. The close working relationship between farms and cities, he said, is a crucial interdependence that requires our constant attention.

title: Defensive Shift Keys Jet Success
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 2  Jim Kensil, the New York Jets president, didn't realize it until he returned home last night, but this morning he reminded everyone:

title: LakerI.A.T.A. Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP)  Sir Freddie Laker clashed today before the Civil Aeronautics Board with representatives of the International Air Transport Association, the organization that fixes many such fares. The C.A.B. is proposing to lift the immunity of I.A.T.A. from United States antitrust laws, a move the operator of cheap flights, as it would open all air traffic to and from the United States to free rate competition.

title: Nebraska Governor Says Parents Of Chad Green Can Stay in State
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 22 (UPI)  Gov. Charles Thone today told the parents of Chad Green that they may remain in Nebraska, their home state, without fear of extradition.

title: Letters
description: The Q & A column in your Science Section this morning [Sept. 25] caught my eye with a question  How is plutonium made? The answer stopped me dead in my tracks. Plutonium is made, it tells us, in certain types of nuclear reactors (not the type used for generating energy in the United States.) Your answer is wrong. In these days of worldwide concern about how to deal with the problems introduced by plutonium, we need to do all we can to keep misinformation about it to a minimum.

title: Britain Proposes Governor Rule Rhodesia Until Election Is Held
description: LONDON, Oct. 22  Britain formally proposed today that a British governor be appointed with executive and legislative authority to rule Zimbabwe Rhodesia until elections are held under a new constitution.

title: HOW TO GRADE AN ELEMENTARY SCHOOL
description: SALEM, OregonWhat difference does the elementary school your child attends make?

title: Parisians Attract Their Own Audience At Designers Shoves
description: The best fashion show in Paris last week was the one outside the tents in the Forum des Halles where the spring and summer fashion shows took place. Thousands of spectators lined up early before the shows six or seven times day, startling the natives and the tourists alike with their outlandish garb.

title: Moshe Dayan's Last Battle
description: The resignation of Moshe Dayan is the plainest signal yet that the present Government of Israel will not relinquish real control over the Arab populations of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Prime Minister Begin's Cabinet has been whittling away at the meaning of the autonomy it offered the Palestinians in the Camp David treaties. While bemoaning the absence of any Palestinians at the negotiating table, it has left very little on the table to talk about. So long as the Foreign Minister, Mr. Dayan, and a few other dissenters struggled on inside the Cabinet, there could be hope for a change of direction. That hope has now been destroyed. Still, by further weakening the Begin Government, Mr. Dayan's departure at least brings all of Israel closer to a reexamination of its policies.

title: Eastern Buys 2 Planes
description: MIAMI, Oct. 22 (Reuters)  Eastern Air Lines said yesterday that it had acquired two 250seat A300 airbuses from Airbus Industrie for $60 million. The company said it would use the planes on its air shuttle between New York and Boston.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Talcott Is Selling Factoring Business
description: The Talcott National Corporation yesterday announced plans to sell its factoring business to the British concern Lloyds & Scottish Ltd. for about $118 million.

title: American Brands Surges
description: American Brands Inc., the nation's fourthlargest cigarette producer, reported yesterday that thirdquarter earnings more than doubled to a record $114.5 million, or $4 a share, from $52.9 million, or $1.99 a share, for the comparable three months last year.

title: Hua Takes AntiSoviet Themes To West Germany
description: BONN, Oct. 22  Prime Minister Hua Guofeng of China, making the kind of antiSoviet speech his West German hosts hoped he would forgo, called on peaceloving countries tonight to resist the aggression and expansion of hegemonism.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: Buoyed by tightmoney policies in the United States, the dollar advanced yesterday to trade at its highest level in more than a month against major world currencies. European gold prices edged higher in quiet trading.

title: 25th Reunion for The Car of World Series
description: Now it's as much a part of the World Series as the composite box score. As the Series progresses each year, people ask, Who'll win the car? Willie Stargell won it this year, of course, without argument. On Thursday he will be handed the keys to a new Corvette by Sport magazine at a WaldorfAstoria Hotel luncheon Sports of The Times that also will serve as a silver anniversary reunion for all the Series most valuable players dating back to 1955 when Johnny Podres of the Brooklyn Dodgers was awarded the first car. I'm sitting on top of the world, Johnny Podres said that day, perched on a white Corvette with redleather upholstery and a redleather dashboard. Believe me, that's just how I feel. And that's just about how all the other Series most valuable players have felt in each of the last 25 years. Of the 22 players involved (Reggie Jackson, Sandy Koufax and Bob Gibson each was honored twice), only Roberto Clemente is deceased. His widow, Vera, will attend the luncheon and the dinnerdance that evening. But as of yesterday, three others were doubtful Jackson, Koufax and Pete Rose.

title: 2:27:33  and Waiting
description: There may be more important indices of women's progress in recent years but probably none so dramatic as 2 hours 27 minutes 33 seconds. That was how long it took Grete Waitz, a 26yearold Norwegian teacher, to run the New York Marathon in Sunday's heat. It is no act of disrespect toward Bill Rodgers, the men's winner again, in 2:11:42, to dwell on Mrs. Waitz's time. Not only did it make her the first woman to finish. Not only did it break her own world's record for the 26mile, 385yard distance. It meant that in just 15 years, the women's record has improved by one hour.

title: Deposit Outflow Is Near Record
description: Depositors, lured in part by rising interest rates elsewhere, withdrew a nearrecord amount from savings banks last month, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday.

title: No People
description: Better late than never. The 101-yearold Yale Daily News, one of the oldest college daily newspapers in the country, got its first female editor in chief yesterday. Anne Gardner Perkins, 20, a junior from Baltimore, took over a chair that had been occupied by some distinguished predecessors, including Associate Justice Potter Stewart of the Supreme Court, the author and editor William F. Buckley Jr. and Kingman Brewster Jr., who later became president of Yale and is now Ambassador to Britain.

title: The City
description: A 20-year-old Queens youth hanged himself last night in his single cell at the Rikers Island Adolescent Reception and Detention Center where he had been held two weeks in lieu of $750 bail on a charge of breaking and entering.

title: Article 8 -- No Title
description: UPENDED TACKLER: Steve Foley of Broncos wound up in an awkward position as he tackled John Stallworth of Steelers after Stallworth had caught pass for 3yard gain in first period.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday. Oct. 22, 1979

title: Market Place
description: IS it possible that the postbankruptcy Penn Central Corporation is a better investment now than it has been since the heyday of the nation's railroads? That is one Wall Street view, anyway.

title: Status of Licenses for New Reactors
Pop: Elton John Is Back
description: ELTON JOHN, whose melodic softrock hits sold in the millions and were perhaps the most characteristic pop sound of the early and middle 1970's, gave his first of eight performances at the Palladium last Thursday night. Although he has kept a low profile for the last few years, releasing relatively few records compared to his prolific output between 1971 and 1975 and making no live appearances, he still has legions of fans. His playing small and mediumsize halls with what's mostly a oneman show seems to be an attempt to reduce the dimensions of his celebrity.

title: Enforcer Unit Loses Support in S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  In its efforts to reduce regulation and make it easier to raise capital in public markets, the Securities and Exchange Commission has been increasingly disregarding the warnings of its enforcement division that investor safeguards may be eroded.

title: 3 Senators Visit the Thai Border For Report to Carter on Refugees
description: KHLONG KHAI THUEN, Thailand, Oct. 22  Three American Senators preparing a report for President Carter made a visit here today to this border region, which is providing bleak sanctuary for up to 200,000 refugees fleeing the war and famine in Cambodia.

title: Kreisler: Too Much Too Soon
description: By all accounts, the Kreisler Group was a victim of success. Kreisler, the manufacturer of the noted Ralph Lauren line of women's clothes, grew too fast, turned to outside capital to finance its galloping expansion and then was caught and crushed by an unexpected business reversal. The company, as a result, filed for protection last month under Chapter XI.

title: New El Salvador Regime Appoints 12 to Cabinet
description: SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 22 (Reuters) El Salvador's civilianmilitary junta named a 12member Cabinet tonight that represented all moderate opposition to the ousted Government of President Carlos Humberto Romero.

title: BUSINESS
description: Exxon reported that its thirdquarter profits rose by 119 percent to a record $1.15 billion. The jump in earnings for the world's biggest oil company seemed certain to touch off renewed protests from critics who maintain that the oil industry has profited unduly from the recent shortages of petroleum products. The White House immediately indicated that it would try to get a stiffer windfall profits tax than the one proposed by the Senate Finance Committee. [Page A1.]

title: Smokers Death Rates Double At Any Age, Insurer Reports
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22A new mortality study of life insurance customersthe first of its kindconfirmed today that the death rate of cigarette smokers is significantly higher than that of nonsmokers.

title: Strains of Bitterness Underlie Koch's Broad Popularity
description: Since taking office almost two years ago, Mayor Koch has achieved what politicians agree is an astounding popularity. They say that polls they have seen show that twothirds of the voters give him a favorable performance rating and that not since Fiorello H. La Guardia has a Mayor struck such a responsive chord.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: Has a high toe box, rubber sole and Unlined butterysoft leathers. In Black, Navy, Belge, Ten, Rust, White ?? Burgundy fine Calfskin, Black, Brown, Navy, Beige, Taupe or Gust Suede, Black, Brown Bone, Navy or White Patent Leather Mall orders, add $2.00 plus applicable NY sales tax, Inctuc  2nd color choice and send to TreeMark, 27 West 35th St., Y.C. 10001

title: Author Decries Casting Of Miss Redgrave by CBS
description: Making a special trip to this country, Fania Fenelon, a French survivor of the German concentration camps, met yesterday with officials of CBSTV to protest the casting of Vanessa Redgrave in the dramatization of her book, Playing for Time, an account of her Auschwitz experiences. Miss Redgrave, a supporter of the Palestine Liberation Organization, will portray the aethor, who survived the camp by playing in an allwoman's orchestra.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: FUEL COSTS PUT STEERS BACK ON THE TRAIL: herd of 4,500 cattle being driven recently to the stockyards at St. Onge, S.D. The cattle, which are usually trucked, were herded the 75 miles from the range to save on the cost of diesel fuel. Seventy cowboys took part in the weeklong drive. Wayne Beeler, owner of the cattle, estimated that he had saved about $10,000 of the $15,000 that would have cost him to transport the herd by truck.

title: EXXON PROFIT JUMPS BY 119% IN QUARTER; HIGHER TAX IS URGED
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, reported yesterday that its thirdquarter profits rose by 119 percent to a record $1.15 billion, the first billiondollar quarter in the company's history.

title: Judge Asks Officials, One by One, if They Have Talked on Sindona Case
description: A Federal judge called into court yesterday Federal and city law enforcement officials who have been questioning the Italian financier Michele Sindona about his 10week disappearance and asked them to stand up individually and say whether they had violated the order he issued last Friday prohibiting them from talkIna to reporters.

title: Affirmed Is Retired As Trainer Decides Against Grass Race
description: Affirmed, thoroughbred racing's biggest moneyearner and last year's Triple Crown winner, was unexpectedly retired from competition yesterday.

title: Mrs. Waitz Cites Unknown Help
description: Before running five or six easy miles yesterday to help ease the pain in the legs that carried her to a world record performance in Sunday's New York City Marathon, Grete Waitz of Norway gave thanks to a man, I don't know his name or number, who gave me help during the last seven miles of the race. don't know his name or number, who gave me help during the last seven miles of the race.

title: 8 Kids Having a Crack At the American Dream
description: AT 2:41 one recent afternoon, Alan Parker, whose last film was the hugely successful Midnight Express, returned from lunch to a high school on the West Side. The British director was on his way to finish a scene of Fame, which follows an octet of students through their four years at New York's wellknown High School of Performing Arts.

title: Appellate Judges Set Restrictions On Strip Searches in High Schools
description: The right of public school teachers and administrators to conduct strip searches of high school students has been severely curtailed by a Federal appeals court.

title: Steelers Rout Broncos, 427; Bradshaw Star
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 22 (AP) Coach Chuck Noll liked what he saw as his backtothebasics Pittsburgh Steelers trounced the Denver Broncos by 427 tonight.

title: Dent, White to Be Free Agents
description: Bucky Dent and Roy White could still wind up in the Yankee lineup next season, but for now they plan to have their names in the freeagent lineup for the Nov. 2 draft.

title: Matos, Freed by Cuba, Says Case Was Not Unique
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 22  It was past 2 A.M. today, and one of the passengers on the Cubans airliner had been awaited for 20 years. As the plane's propellers stopped, the crowd hushed. Only the squeaks of the ramp could be heard as it was rolled into place.

title: 3 MILE ISLAND PANEL CRITICAL OF UTILITY AND U.S. REGULATORS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  The President's Commission on the Accident at Three Mile Island has concluded in its final draft report that the utility that operated the reactor did not have sufficient knowledge, expertise and personnel to operate the plant or maintain it adequately.

title: Marboro Is Sold to Barnes & Noble
description: Marboro Book Stores, the country's largest retailer of remainder books  former bestsellers and other publishers overstock retailed at a fraction of their list prices  has sold its assets to Barnes & Noble and has ceased operations after 30 years.

title: J. Odeon Christian, ExHead of Athletics At U. of Connecticut
description: WILLIMANTIC, Conn., Oct. 22 (UPI)  J. Orlean Christian, former coach and athletic director at the University of Connecticut and commissioner of the Yankee Conference, died yesterday in a convalescent home after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: New Spending Might Lower Bond Ratings, State Learns
description: One of the nation's top investment services has warned New York State that its rating of state bonds may be downgraded if the financial decay of the state's housing projects persists and it continues to take on major new spending obligations.

title: Theater: All 5 Yeats Cuchulain Plays
description: IN his search for heroism and also in his attempt to understand himself in relation to others, particularly the women in his life, William Butler Yeats repeatedly returned to the legend of Cuchulain. Over a period of 40 years he wrote five short plays about this Irish warrior, composing the final play, The Death of Cuchulain, on his own deathbed. period of 40 years he wrote five short plays about this Irish warrior, composing the final play, The Death of Cuchulain, on his own deathbed.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 22 (Reuters) Kurdish forces holding most of the city of Mehabad have been ordered by their political leaders not to begin any fresh offensives against Government positions until the outcome of peace negotiations is known, sources close to the rebels said today.

title: EARNING
description: Amax Inc., one of the world's largest producer of molybdenum, an element used in making steel, reported yesterday that its thirdquarter profits advanced 113.8 percent on a 61 percent rise in sales.

title: Major Contenders for Suffolk Executive Disagree on Cuts in Welfare
description: SELDEN, L.I., Oct. 22  The Republican and Democratic candidates for Suffolk County Executive diverged from traditional party positions yesterday as they disagreed on the feasibility of cuts in welfare costs, which account for nearly 40 percent of the county budget.

title: Most Boston Schools Are Quiet After a Week of Racial Incidents
description: BOSTON, Oct. 22  Boston's public schools reopened in relative calm today after the worst week of racial unrest here since the first years of courtordered desegregation in 1974 and 1975.

title: Israeli High Court Orders Removal Of Disputed West Bank Settlement
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 22  Israel's highest court struck at part of the Israeli Government's settlement policy today by ordering the dismantling of a disputed outpost in the occupied West Bank set up on land seized from Arab owners.

title: Advertising
description: Usefulness Of Research Questioned

title: 3 Men Escape From Jail in Goshen
description: Three inmates of the Orange County Jail in Goshen, N.Y., including one man who had escaped last July, cut their way out of a recreation area at about 7:30 P.M. yesterday and were still at large early this morning, according to officials at the jail. Since June there have been nine escapes from the onestory cinderblock building in the center of town.

title: Marketing Kissinger's Book Is a Fine Orchestration
description: Several days ago, former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger stood up before nearly 900 European journalists in Frankfurt and said, Ich spreche keine sprache ohne akzent.

title: Norfolk &
description: The Norfolk & Western Railway Company yesterday reported that its thirdquarter profits tripled and revenues more than doubled the results of the comparable period last year. The railroad also projected record profits for 1979.

title: Topps &Trowsers In Bankruptcy Court
description: SAN FRANCISCO. Oct. 22 (AP) Topps & Trowsers, a San Franciscobased young men's clothing chain, filed a reorganization petition in Federal bankruptcy court here today.

title: Autumn Breaks Stride for a Day of Sun
description: For New Yorkers, it was a sunny and agreeable interlude. After the snow flurries of two weeks ago, temperatures began to rise over the weekend and climbed precipitously yesterday to 88 degrees, breaking the previous high for Oct. 22 of 83 degrees, set in 1920.

title: Taxes
description: IT now appears not only that a Congressional pro- posal to liberalize depreciation will be far more expensive than originally advertised but also that its effects will vary widely from industry to industry. The utility and communications sectors would be big gainers, while automobile manufacturers would initially suffer a negative tax impact, according to new figures from the Treasury Department.

title: Accounting Body Issues Loan Rule
description: Businesses will be required to specify the cost of borrowed money used in buying certain assets under a rule change issued yesterday by an accounting ru!emaking body, the Financial Accounting Standards Board.

title: Robert Benjamin, 70, Executive Of Film Company and a Lawyer
description: Robert S. Benjamin, cochairman of Orion Pictures and a former cochairman of the United Artists Corporation, died yesterday at the North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, L.I., after a brief illness. He was 70 years old and lived in Kings Point, L.I.

title: Senatorin Jersey Is Indicted On $360,000 Bride Charge
description: TRENTON, Oct. 22  A State Senator and his father were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of extorting $360,000 in bribes in return for arranging $4 million in loans from a teamsters union pension fund.

title: Israel Bars Rabin From Relating 48 Eviction of Arabs
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 22  A censorship board composed of five Cabinet members prohibited former Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin from including in his memoirs a firstperson account of the expulsion of 50,000 Palestinian civilians from their homes near Tel Aviv during the 1948 ArabIsraeli war.

title: Science Watch
description: Insects on the wing have long been a bane to meteorologists trying to detect weather patterns by radar. The insects, which reflect the microwave radiation of radar, can distort or obscure weather features.

title: Bond Rates Top Record Levels
description: Interest rates rocketed upward again yesterday, sending the rate on overnight loans between banks as high as 18 percent and lifting a whole basketful of other key rates  from Treasury bills to Bell System bonds  to record levels.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Helms and 2 Successors in Clash On Publishing of C.I.A. Reports
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  The question of whether the Central Intelligence Agency should enter the marketplace of information pitted Richard M. Helms, a former Director of the agency, against two of his successors today.

title: Q&A
description: Q Why does hair grow at different rates on different parts of the body?

title: Stage: Winter Dancers, A Tale of Indian Anguish
description: AS one of the last surviving American Indians on Vancouver Island, off the coast of British Columbia, Jacqueline Brookes spends her onstage evening in a rocking chair, gently keeping time to remembered tribal songs with a restless toe, steadily smoking the pipe that is her one last comfort. My people used to give, give, give, she declares with sudden heat as she continues to narrate the Phoenix Theater's production of David Lan's The Winter Dancers, spitting out her thorough distaste for the new white ethic of take, take, take.

title: CarringtonGuides Rhodesia Talks With Lordly Aplomb
description: LONDON, Oct. 22  At the Lancaster House negotiations on Zimbabwe Rhodesia Friday, Lord Carrington, the British Foreign Secretary, wearily yielded to the demand of the Patriotic Front guerrillas that he commit to paper his proposals for outtimt into effect a new constitutinn

title: Deaths
description: STIMSONAmelia Eadie. In Sait bury, Connecticut on October 22, 1979. Mother of Rev. Frederick B. Stlm son, Jr. of Sharon. Connecticut. Also survived by 4 grandchildren. Services Thursday, October 25Ih Christ Episcopal Church, Sharon. Connecticut 11AM. Interment 2PM Flushing Cemetery, Flushing, N.Y. Memorial contributions Sharon Hospital or Noble Horizons. Salisbury, Connecticut.

title: Feminists Turn to Economic Issues for '80
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  The feminist movement, preparing for the 1980 Presidential election, has quietly shifted its focus from traditional women's issues to the nation's economic problems  the impact of inflation, unemployment and recession upon women.

title: Arab Reaction Is Mixed On Mayans Resignation
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 22 (AP)  A Palestine Liberation Organization spokesman said today that the resignation of Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel shows the Camp David accords have reached a dead end.

title: A German Concern Is Seeking Pertec
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 22 (AP)  The chairman of the Pertec Computer Corporation said today that the company had entered a definitive agreement to be acquired by a West German computer concern for $120 million.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Amoco Chemicals Corporation, Chicago, the chemicals manufacturing and marketing subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), has named George A. Nersesian vice president of international business ventures.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CORVALLIS, Ore., Oct. 22 (AP) Oregon State University dismissed Craig Fertig as football coach today, effective at the end of the season. The team has not won in seven games.

title: A Yele Star Dreams of N.F.L.
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 22Mike Sullivan, who scored two of Yale's five touchdowns in a 377 victory over Columbia on Saturday, is counting the games now. There are only four remaining, and then the love affair with football probably will be over for the senior fullback from Orange,. Conn.

title: Los Angeles Busing Trial Opens
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 22 (UPI) Dozens of witnesses and thousands of documents were lined up as a trial began in Superior Court today to determine if a current busing plan was integrating Los Angeles city schools or if another plan was needed. The Board of Education and an antibusing group called Bustop contend that mandatory busing is ineffective in the city and should be replaced by an allvoluntary method.

title: Late Rally Blunts Stock Drop, But Interest Worries Persist
description: A late rally halted the stock market's downward plunge yesterday, but prices still recorded widespread losses amid intense investor nervousness over skyrocketing interest rates.

title: Cy Slapnicka, Big League Hurler, Also General Manager and Scout
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Oct. 22 (AP) Cyril (Cy) Slapnicka, who spent half century in professional baseball as pitcher, general manager and scout, died Saturday night. He was 93 years old.

title: Saudis Deny Split Over Oil
description: The Saudi Arabian Government denied yesterday that its oil minister had indicated that a major split over oil prices and production levels had developed among the kingdom's leaders.

title: Two Seek Kirkland's Post in A.F.L.C.I.O.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  With Lane Kirkland running unopposed so far to succeed George Meany as president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., attention within the labor movement is focusing on the contest for the position Mr. Kirkland will be vacating  secretarytreasury of the federation.

title: Forensic Science Expands Its Role
description: THE intersection of science and criminal justice, which has produced the crossbred disciplines of the forensic sciences, is accounting for more and more criminal convictions in this country. Forensic scientists, who are still sometimes referred to by the police as the lab

title: Life in Uganda Is Still in Chaos Half Year Later
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct. 20  Asked whether it is worse living in Kampala today than it was under Idi Amin, who was overthrown by Tanzanian forces on April 11, a foreigner who lives here picked up a pen and started figuring.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an error in transmission, a dispatch in Business Day last Wednesday incorrectly named the company that designed a water and power plant for the new metropolis of Jubail, Saudi Arabia. The company is Sanderson & Porter Inc. of New York.

title: The Brigade's My Fault
description: As I have learned more about the Soviet brigade in Cuba and heard alarm expressed over some unprecedented and novel violation of the Monroe Doctrine, it has slowly come home to me that this whole noncrisis is my fault.

title: BeefPrice Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP)  The Government announced today a proposed settlement of a civil suit against 14 beefpacking companies accused of fixing prices in the Los Angeles area.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Concerto for Violin and Orchestra, Bonporti; Concerto in E flat for Horns and Strings, Forster; Wedding Cake (Op. 76), Saint Saens; Le Ballet Interrompu, Campra; Concerto in C Minor for Strings and Harpsichord; Vivaldi.

title: A Wide Receiver Signed by Giants; Gravelle to Rams
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 23  The Giants today signed Gene Washington, a 5foot9inch, 169pound wide receiver who has never played a regularseason game in the National Football League.

title: Kitchen Equipment A Variety of Steamers
description: ICAN think of any number of good reasons to cook food in a steamer, but perhaps the most compelling is something called pommes vapeur, steamed small potatoes. These potatoes, as you'll observe it you make them, are not like anything else of their genre. They are drier, less soggy and more flavorful than their closest relative, boiled potatoes. And they are a magnificent acompaniment to many dishes prepared in butter. Sauteed fish is a frequent beneficiary.

title: Letters
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: JOHN DREBINGER, 88, REPORTER FOR TIMES
description: John Drebinger, who was dean of the nation's baseball writers when he retired in 1964 after 40 years with The New York Times, died on Monday at a nursing home in Greensboro, N.C. He was 88 years old.

title: Deaths
description: BENJAMINRobert 5. Funeral services private. Memorial services Sunday, October 28, 1PM, Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th Street and Park Avenue, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Brandeis University for the Robert and Jean Benlamin Fellowships In International Affairs.

title: Bulls Halt Net Rally, Win by 5
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 23  Frankly, the Chicago Bulls had been worried. News last Saturday that their dominating center, Ards Gilmore, a key scorer and rebounder for the team, would need surgery on his right knee had put a crimp in their plans for the season.

title: Foie Gras
description: Larousse Gastronomique, the authoritative dictionary of gastronomy, quotes C. Gerard, the author of L'Ancienne Alsace  table, as follows: The goose is nothing, but man has made of it an instrument for the output a marvelous product, a kind of living hothouse in which grows the supreme fruit of gastronomy. That fruit, the product of forcefed geese, is, course, foie gras.

title: Best Buys
description: THOSE who enjoy oldfashioned, truly American grapes  such as the tiny reddish pink Delawares and the giant, dark purple Concords  may want to make a trip to Earth's Harvest Trading Company this week to share in the shop's fall harvest of organically grown produce. For the next few weeks the health food store, at 700 Columbus Avenue at 95th Street, will be offering a quartet of fragrant and luscious grapes grown in New York State, including the Delawares and Concords, along with tart green Niagaras and large, purplishred Catawbas, all priced at 89 cents a pound.

title: Radio
description: 7Noon, WNYCFM. Concerto No. 5, Marcello; Sonata in G, Scarlatti; Symphony No. 101, Haydn; Sonata in D, Albinoni; Serenade in G for Flute and Guitar, Carulli; Rinaldo Overture, Handel.

title: McGuire Denies Report That He Will Be Dismissed
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 23 (AP) Frank McGuire, the University of South Carolina basketball coach for the last 15 years, denied today a broadcast report that he would be leaving the job by Friday.

title: Flaming Crepe Bums 3 Actors at End of Play
description: Three actors were slightly burned last night when a flaming crepe suzette flared up and splattered them with droplets of burning liquid just before the final curtain of a performance of The Art of Dining being staged by the New York Shakespeare Festival at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: Choosing the Right Glasses
description: Special glasses are traditionally used for Sauternes and other sweet wines, and even if they don't affect the taste of the wine, they do provide a visual accent for the dining table and offer an efficient way to avoid pouring wine into the wrong glass.

title: TV: A Series of Stories By John Cheever Begins
description: HREE Cheever Stories begins tonight at 9 o'clock on WNETTV with The Sorrows of Gin. Coming up on the next two Wednesdays are 0 Youth and Beauty and The Five FortyEight.

title: Braths
description: LEVINSON  Jennie. Congregation Sons of Israel, Wcodmere, records with sorrow the Passing O. Its member. beloved wife of Harry N., devoted mother of Its member, Mrs. Steven Mazur, and extends Its ccndolences.

title: Theater: Sorrows of Stephen, Romantic Comedy
description: WHEN a drama is heavy with portent, and the evening seems like a marathon  the end is 26 miles away  sometimes we wish that we were at the movies, watching a light, frothy entertainment. Peter Parnell's Sorrows of Stephen, which opened last night at the Public Theater's Other Stage, is, refreshingly, the stage equivalent of a good movie comedy.

title: The Region
description: GOSHEN, N.Y. (AP) A 21yearold Town of Newburgh man was convicted of two counts of firstdegree manslaughter yesterday after an Orange County Court jury rejected charges of seconddegree murder in the shooting deaths of his parents. During the threeweek trial, the defense charged that Glenn Lord had been sexually abused by his mother, Jeannette Lord, and that he was driven into temporary insanity by her acts.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: IN all my years as a professional chef, I have never met a colleague who was weaned on what is called haute or classic cuisine. Most chefs, including myself, were born in modest circumstances in which eating was a major diversion. The food in my own home was definitely cuisine bourgeoise or familystyle cooking, and as such was marked by a simplicity both in ingredients and cooking techniques. It was also marked by economy.

title: Eurofood: Britons Win Some, Lose Some
description: LONDON IT seems that the British will be allowed, after all, to keep the frozen pig fat in their ice cream, the moistened cereal rusk in their sausages and the brown FK dye in their kippers. That's the good news. The bad news is that they won't have any Johnnie Walker Red Label with which to wash down these culinary specialties.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: As the trend toward higher interest rates continued to build yesterday, the Treasury sold twoyear notes at a record 12 percent, a startling 2 percentage points higher than the rate set only three weeks ago.

title: Deaths
description: BRAZINSKYRebecca. Beloved wife of Israel, devoted mother Irving and Herbert, loving grandmother of Howard, Michael, Greg and Stephanie, devoted motherinlaw of Rosalie and Carole.

title: Notes on People
description: For an Affair With the Wife of a Friend: $80,000 Eyebrows were raised when a jury in Warwick, R.I., ordered a man to pay $80,000 in damages to his former friend because he'd had an affair with the friend's wife. At issue was a concept rooted in common law  but not recognized in more than a dozen states known as criminal conversation, which despite the name is the civil equivalent of adultery.

title: C.C.N.Y. Opening PerformingArts Complex Today
description: CTY COLLEGE has a new performingarts complex  the first in its 132year history and will open it today with appropriate fanfare: a concert that will include the dancers Mikhail Baryshnikov and Patricia McBride, Peter Martins and Suzanne Farrell; the singer Ella Fitzgerald, the New York Choral Society and the American Symphony. Attendance is by invitation only.

title: Brooklyn Jewish Hospital Wins ShortTerm Rescue at Deadline
description: State and Federal health officials reached agreement last night on a shortterm financial rescue plan to prevent the closing of the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn.

title: New Oil, New Safety, New Risk
description: Some 20 billion barrels of oil, enough to provide a fifth of America's needs for 15 years, will probably be found off the coast of Alaska. But under current Federal leasing schedules, very little of that oil will be available before 1995.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Official Calls Scotto a Reputable Leader
description: Lane Kirkland, secretary treasurer of the A.F.L.C.I.O., testified in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday that Anthony M. Scotto's honesty and integrity were above reproach.

title: Careers
description: FOR many young college and businessschool graduates entering the job market and for middlelevel managers fntstrated by blocked career paths, an overseas assignment, or even a career overseas, might sound ideal. But among those who have been excited by mouthwatering helpwanted ads, a majority have found the actual opportunities not nearly as numerous or as exciting.

title: Japan's Car Output Up
description: TOKYO, Oct. 23 (AP)  Japan's motor vehicle production in September totaled 811,052 units, up 17.7 percent from August and up 4 percent from the yearearlier month, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association announced today.

title: C.W. Smith, Professor at Bucknell
description: Dr. C. Willard Smith, professor emeritus of English at Bucknell Unversity in Lewisburg, Pa., died Monday at Evangelical Community Hospital in Lewisburg at the age of 80. He lived in Lewisburg.

title: House Democrats Seek a Return to Strong Leadership
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  The once reformminded Democrats of the House of Representatives have asked their leaders to end five years of increasing autonomy that sometimes bordered on anarchy. They have requested stronger leadership, greater discipline and a return to some of the more efficient but less egalitarian methods that were once used to run the chamber.

title: Benefit Evening Salutes Dior's Marc Bohan
description: MARC BOHAN says he was bowled over. Although the French designer is a regular visitor to New York and has shown his Christian Dior collection in stores here before, he admits he was dumbfounded when he saw a retrospective of his clothes in Altman's windows and aisles.

title: Many Republicans Are Fearful of Kennedy Candidacy
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23  Running against Senator Edward M. Kennedy is a prospect that frightens many Republicans, chiefly because of his expected strength in the Northeast but also because no Republican is close to him in national polls.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Peter J. Carney, president of Chas. E. Quincey & Company, a Government securities firm owned by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., has been named the New York financial representative of the Farm Credit Bank System. He will supervise billions of dollars of public securities sales for the system, which consists of 37 Governmentsponsored banks that make loans to farmers, ranchers and commercial fishermen under the supervision of the Department of Agriculture.

title: Carey, on L.I., Seeks Support for Bonds
description: Governor Carey stumped on Long Island yesterday for the state's proposed $500 million transportation bond issue, while aides and advisers struggled to find money to promote the issue among an apparently lethargic electorate.

title: A Perfect Partner: Sauternes
description: ONE of the most astonishing experiences for the neophyte in the world of wine is that first taste of Sauternes, perhaps the richest, most luscious potion known to man. It is a golden wine of intense natural sweetness balanced with fruit that fills the mouth, creating a taste sensation that clings to the memory. No serious oenophile will ever forget his first encounter with this extraordinary product of the grape.

title: Freed Cuban Tells of Time Spent In a Concrete Box Underground
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 23  Outside, afternoon rain was falling on the orchids and the rose garden, but the man who once spent a year underground in a concrete closet did not pause to remark on them. Huber Matos. nerhans the bestknown of Cuba's political prisoners, felt the need first to speak of the world he knew for 20 years, a world of isolation, punishment, and endurance.

title: House Energy Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP)  Here is how representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut voted today on a measure passed by the House that gave President Carter standby authority to impose gasoline rationing. An xxx indicates a member who did not vote.

title: REXFORD W. McCURDY
description: Rexford W. McCurdy, a former vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died yesterday of a heart attack in Thomas Hospital, Fairhope, Ala. He was 60 years old and lived in Daphne, Ala.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  This city these days somehow seems happier in sort of a goofy way than it has in a long time. After the perplexities of trying to govern the country and pacify the world, which are an endless nuisance, it has finally come back to its main love  the simpler illusions and brutalities of Presidential politics.

title: Venezuela Says U.S. Overreacted on Soviet Troops
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 23  Venezuela told the Organization of American States here today that the United States had overreacted to the presence of Soviet troops in Cuba with an excessive demonstration of force in the Caribbean.

title: Czechoslovakia Convicts 6 Dissidents of Subversion
description: PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 23 Six humanrights activists, among them Vaclav Havel, the playwright, were convicted tonight of subversion of the republic and sentenced to prison terms ranging up to five years.

title: U.S. Sues Oil Driller for $6 Million in Mexico Gulf Spill
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 23 (UPI)  The Department of Justice, seeking $6 million for cleanup expenses and an unspecified amount for other substantial damages, today filed claims against a Texas oildrilling company as a result of the June 3 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: 6 Prague Dissidents Given Jail Terms Up to 5 Years
description: jected a request for release of the defendants pending a hearing on the appeals. All had denied the charges against them.

title: Recipes Using Pt
description: 2 cups finely chopped shallots

title: Private Lives
description: IT is safer to stay hidden behind the typewriter. Inside, they can't see your act. Outside, in public, it is cold. My experience of the legitimate theater is minimal. (The illegitimate theater is another matter; I get that at home.) Usually, I visit plays, under protest, just when they are about to close, long after the critics have gone elsewhere to put out some other fire. Once, I went to a Broadway opening. Everybody in the audience looked either like an owl or a flamingo. The reviews the following morning were incomprehensible to me. Where had I been the previous night? In Miami or on Mars?

title: State Workers Strike Shuts Docks in Hawaii And Disrupts Shipping
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 23 (UPI)  A statewide strike by bluecollar government workers today shut down docks in Honolulu and Hilo, paralyzing cargo movement to Hawaii's outer islands and threatening to disrupt the sugar industry.

title: Associated Press
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, Oct. 23 A major war crimes trial, probably one of the last of its kind, began in tumult here today, with screams in the courtroom and fighting between demonstrators and policemen. Then, in contrast, came the reacting out in monotone of the lists of trains and human cargoes that represented the role of the defendants in the Nazi slaughter of Europe's Jews.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LIVES An art display entitled Holocaust opens to the public today at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. Eighty paintings and drawings by Anna Walinska project the horror of Nazi oppression ana tne agony or its victims. The art works are in color and black and white and range from the abstract to the figurative. The prizewinning artist has dedicated the exhibition to the millions who were persecuted and destroyed.

title: Eratim
description: SCHEUERS.H. The Brandeis University community mourns the death of a long time supporter of our institution whose devotion to Brandeis is reflected In the Simon and Helen Scheuer Scholarship Fund. We extend our heartfelt rendolences to his wife, Helen, his cNIdren and his grand children.

title: Issue and Debate Missiles for Europe Now, or Talks With Moscow First?
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  The question whether a new generation of American nuclear missiles should be spread across Western Europe has emerged as the hottest issue confronting the governments of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Serving Foie Gras
description: A word or two about serving foie gras, fresh or tinned:

title: Around the Nation
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 23 (UPI)  President Eisenhower's personal secretary has confirmed a Rice University historian's report that General Eisenhower installed a White House taperecording system, but she disputed an assertion that the system was used extensively.

title: Steel Output Climbs 1.7%
description: Steel production rose to 2.454 million tons in the week ended Oct. 20, an increase of 1.7 percent from the preceding week's 2.912 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reoorted yesterday.

title: Begin's Cabinet Wins 5 NoConfidence Tests
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 23 (UPI) Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Government defeated five noconfidence challenges in Parliament today.

title: S.E.C. to Repeal Accounting Rule
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, as expected, said yesterday that it would repeal its rule requiring replacementcost accounting by larger companies.

title: Priest Asking to Disconnect Comatose Colleapie's Respirator
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 23A Marianist priest, the president of a local Roman Catholic high school, has filed papers in State Supreme Court here seeking permission to disconnect a brother in the school's Marianist community from the respirator doctors say has been keeping him alive since Oct. 2.

title: Opera: Malfitano Manon
description: MANON has been one of the gems in the City Opera repertory for a decade, and its charms were as fresh and winning as ever on Sunday night during the opera's first performance this season. The cast was largely a familiar one, headed by Catherine Malfitano in the title role.

title: Two Pioneering Black Scholars, DuBois and Bond, Are Honored
description: AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 22  The memories of W.E.B. DuBois and Horace Mann Bond, two major black scholars who challenged the prevailing social attitudes of their time by professing the beauty and dignity of black people, were celebrated in events over the weekend in New England.

title: Canada to Push Pipeline Talks
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 23  The Canadian Government assured the House of Commons today that it would make clear to President Carter during his visit here next month Canada's opposition to any Alaska oil pipeline route that called for an increase in tanker traffic along the West Coast.

title: COMRIODMES
description: Prices of precious metals futures continued to slide yesterday in the absence of fresh buying and further strength in the dollar. Brokers again noted that gold and silver spreaders who had sold dollars short and bought metals were still unwinding these losing vositions.

title: Mortgage Bond Bill Is Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP)  A bill to restrict the use of taxexempt bonds for singlefamily home mortgages was returned to the House Ways and Means Committee today, creating a new delay for the controversial legislation.

title: SENATE PANEL, BY 87, DEFEATS AMENDMENT PERILING ARMS PACT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee narrowly defeated today a socalled killer amendment to the strategic arms limitation treaty that would have asserted a legal right by the United State to match the Soviet deployment of heavy missiles.

title: Boston Policemen Tell of Seeing Same Adults at Student Protests
description: BOSTON, Oct. 23 (AP)  The police say they have spotted the same adults at student protests in various parts of the city, lending credence to allegations that the demonstrations are orchestrated by adults rather than spontaneous student acts.

title: A Gusher Near City Hall
description: A TORRENT soaked Broadway traffic crossing Chambers Street after a Consolidated Edison crew opened a hydrant yesterday. Its valve broke. No one could turn it off.

title: Boeing Sells Jets
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 23 (AP) TransAmerica Airlines of Oakland, Calif., has ordered three Boeing 747 jumbo jets at a cost of about $200 million, the Boeing Company said today. The airline, formerly known as Trans International Airlines, said that it has three more 797's on option.

title: Three Members Named To Pulitzer Prize Board
description: Two specialists in urban affairs and university president have been added to the Pulitzer Prize board, it was announced yesterday by Dr. William J. McGill, president of Columbia University.

title: Ballet: Tudor's Cereus
description: ANEW  or at least unfamiliar  ballet by Antony Tudor is always cause for special interest. On Sunday at the Theater of the Riverside Church, the Bernhard Ballet of Connecticut provided a surprising look at the master choreogra pher with a revival of his Cereus.

title: Mayor of Detroit Warns on Chrysler
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  The mayor of Detroit warned a House Banking subcommittee today that the failure of the Chrysler Corporation would be devastating not just for Detroit but for many cities throughout the country.

title: Arlen Sells Its Interest In Tower
description: The Arlen Realty and Development Corporation, the financially troubled real estate developer that built the Olympic Tower in 1974, has sold its 50 percent interest in the Fifth Avenue building to a subsidiary of the Onassis interests.

title: Doctor Would Let Sindona Testify
description: The psychiatrist who has been treating the Italian financier Michele Sindona said yesterday that he had no objection to his patient's appearing in court today for a hearing.

title: Cheap and Profitable Horror Films Are Multiplying
description: LOS ANGELES ASTAIR creaks; a shutter bangs; the hauntedhouse movie is back and thriving. Halloween has already grossed $50 million, and its homicidal maniac with his butcher knife is returning to theaters everywhere on Friday. Despite unanimously unfavorable reviews, The Amityville Horror and its malevolent house dominated the box offices last August. And now, When a Stranger Calls  with its homicidal maniac telephoning a terrified babysitter from an upstairs extension  has earned nearly $12.5 million in its first 24 days.

title: Fire in Canadian Capital
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 23 (UPI) A huge fire spread from Canada's most famous private club to the offices of Prime Minister Joe Clark today, forcing the evacuation of Government offices and the American Embassy next door. The fire completely destroyed the 114yearold Rideau Club, which is located on the same block as the Canadian Parliament building.

title: Israel Finds 2 Guerrillas Guilty of Murder in Raid
description: LOD, Israel, Oct. 23 (AP)  An Israeli military court today convicted two Palestinians of murder in a raid on March 11, 1978. that took the lives of 34 Israelis.

title: U.S. Agent Arrested in Sex Case
description: A Federal agent was arrested yesterday and charged with sexually abusing two 14yearold Queens girls at knife point in separate incidents more than year apart.

title: Dubai Revises Conoco Accord
description: Conoco Inc. yesterday announced that new agreements on the sale of crude oil and offshore exploration had been reached between the Government of Dubai and the Dubai Petroleum Company, a Conoco subsidiary that has a 30 percent interest in Dubai's oil production.

title: Only 7,911 at Garden Watch Knicks Rout Pacers by 136112
description: Before an announced crowd of 7,911, the smallest for professional basketball in the 111/2 years of the present Madison Square Garden, the young Knicks made their finest offensive showing of the season last night.

title: About Real Estate Kennedy Airport Spurs Growth of Freight Warehouses
description: Such is the expansion of the airfreight forwarding business in the vicinity of Kennedy International Airport that a builder who was putting up houses there 20 years ago is now demolishing them to build warehousing. That fellow was a holdout, said the builder, Jacob A. Green, as he drove past a modest house of 1920's vintage on 182d Street near 147th Avenue. It was a house someone else had built, but Mr. Green developed the two warehouses squeezing each side of the narrow plot. Now he can't sell the house to anyone, he said.

title: Sports Today
description: A.A.U. intercity championships, at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 8 P.M.

title: Islanders And Oilers In 33 Tie
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 23  Ask any Islander, and he'll tell you the New Yorkers were lucky tonight to tie the Edmonton Oilers, 33. Ask Billy Smith, the goalie, and he'll say he thought the expansion club looked more like the Montreal Canadiens. But don't ask the coach. Al Arbour was too upset to comment.

title: Business Records
description: ELLIOT LAVIGNE, 17 E. 67th St., N.Y. Liabilities, 525,505; assets, 5901.

title: Pan Am's Net Plunges By 40% in Third Quarter
description: Pan American World Airways, suffering from higher fuel prices and enjoying an extraordinary gain on the sale of aircraft equipment, yesterday reported a 40 percent profit decline as revenues climbed 10.5 percent.

title: Advertising
description: VICEROY RICH LIGHTS, the lowtar line extension of the nation's oldest filtertip cigarette, is getting its first national promotion and it is a first for the cigarette industry  a game promotion featuring one of those scratchoff cards once so popular at gas stations and supermarkets.

title: A Tiny Food Shop With Big Ideas
description: IT started small. Very small. The pocketsized shop measures only 11 by 16 feet, and when the Silver Palate opened at 274 Columbus Avenue at 72d Street just two years ago, the offerings were traditional and modest. A selection of tiny sausages, French cheeses, an elegant, takeout entree of the day. The young entrepreneurs, Sheila Lukins, a onetime graphic artist, and Julee Rosso, formerly in advertising, wanted a simple, Upper West Side shop, where the food was fresh, the atmosphere homey, the quality exceptional.

title: A British TV Network Resumes Today as Pay Dispute Is Settled
description: LONDON, Oct. 23  The Independent Television Network, which has been blacked out for almost 11 weeks by a dispute with the Association of Cinematograph, Television and Allied Technicians, announced today that it would resume operations tomorrow after achievement of a twoyearwage accord.

title: Jerome Davis, Educator, 87, Dies; Active in World Peace Movement
description: Dr. Jerome Davis, an educator, author and world traveler who spent much of his life and work espousing world peace, died last Friday at a nursing home in Olney, Md. He was 87 years old and had previously lived in West Haven, Conn.

title: Subway Crime at High Since Start of Patrols
description: For the first time last week, subway crime rose above the level for the week before intensive patrols wet6 begun in March, according to transit police figures.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) indi cotes stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: News of the Theater
description: pLAYS often take unpredictable routes to Broadway. In the case of Strider, which is making its way to the Helen Hayes Theater, the trip began in Leningrad, with a stop on Manhattan's West Side.

title: Soul: Peaches and Herb
description: OMANTIC duos have long been a popular subgenre of rhythm n blues, from Gene and Eunice in the 1950's to Peaches and Herb in the late 60's. Usually such pairings celebrate puppy love more than the real thing and don't outlast the dimples on the cheeks of the principals, who tend to start young and retire early. But Peaches and Herb, who were the sweethearts of soul during the 60's, have bounced back in recent years, albeit with a different Peaches. They've become bestselling disco artists with broad crossover appeal and, on Monday night, they headlined at Carnegie Hall.

title: 2 Lance Codefendants Object to a Trial Ruling
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 23 (AP)  Attorneys for two of Bert Lance's codefendants say a Federal magistrate miscounted under the Speedy Trial Act when he refused to dismiss bank fraud charges against them.

title: Aid for Young Audiences
description: Young Audiences, the national nonprofit organization that sponsors performances and educational programs in public schools by musicians, dancers and actors, will present Murray Perahia in a benefit piano recital in St. Peter's Church at Citicorp Center on Nov. 26.

title: Life of Brian Stirs Carolina Controversy
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 23  Monty Python's Life of Brian has been filled with upheaval here and, through the intervention of Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, the satirical movie is looking for a foster home.

title: U.S. Riders Triumph at Landover
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 23  The United States Equestrian Team, with Peter Leone in the lineup for the first time, won the Prix des Nations class at the Washington International horse show tonight.

title: Dr. B. J. Sanger, 88
description: Dr. Bertram J. Sanger, former associate clinical professor of medicine at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 years old and specialized in diseases associated with metabolism.

title: San Francisco Teachers End Walkout in 7th Week
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23  A teachers strike that began last month as schools were about to open ended today when members of Local 61 of the American Federation of Teachers voted overwhelming to return to classes.

title: Carter Reaffirms Support for Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  President Carter today reaffirmed his strong support of the equal rights amendment, terming it one of the most serious needs of our country.

title: Medical Tests in Manhattan
description: Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, the deposed ihah of Iran, who was flown secretly into Jew York from Mexico late Monday light aboard a chartered jet, was under leavy guard by his private security force at a Manhattan hospital yesterday as he Inderwent medical tests.

title: Bill Wheeler Captures $87,625 Jersey Futurity
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 23  Overcoming the No. 15 post position, Bright View Farm's Bill Wheeler scored a 1 1/4length victory tonight in the $87,625 New Jersey Futurity at the Meadowlands.

title: 40 Years After Start of War, Poles Memories Still Vivid
description: WARSAW, Oct. 23  Warsaw's golden autumn is over. There is a bite to the wind that sweeps across the Vistula, the leaves have been on the ground for weeks now and the sky is an unending gray.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The losstroubled Kaiser Steel Corporation, in the first move of its kind by a major American steelmaker, announced yesterday that it had begun discussions for the possible sale of a substantial part of its assets to Nippon Kokan K.K., Japan's secondlargest steel company.

title: English World Cup Hopes Rise For '82 After a Favorable Draw
description: With a little more luck, England will make it to the World Cup soccer tournament's final stage in 1982 for the first time in 12 years.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THERE he was  a goodlooking, whitehaired, welldressed man, standing on a Park Avenue corner one day, talking to a friend and waiting for the light to change. As E.M. Russell tuned in, the whitehaired gentleman could be heard talking prouctiy about his nrst grams son  his first, apparently, after a succession granddaughters.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Can youtell me what the term  grilled bone means?

title: Economic Scene
description: REPORTS of soaring oilcompany profits in the third quarter have set off the predictable political explosion. But virtually no politician or Government official has proposed any action capable of reaching the real root of the problem of escalating oil prices: the use of monopoly power by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to restrict supply.

title: Air Force May Reassess Design of F15 Engines
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP)  Air Force experts are considering whether to tune down the F15 fighter plane's highperformance engines to prevent widespread breakdowns.

title: WRITERS SAY SOVIET YIELDS IN A DISPUTE
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23  In a compromise that would have been unthinkable in Stalin's day, or even a decade ago, the Soviet authorities have said that they will reinstate two young writers expelled last winter from the official Writers Union for taking part in a protest against censorship, according to writers involved in the affair.

title: The Servant Problem Or, His Master's Voice
description: It is impossible to go anywhere in the country these days without listening to complaints about the servants.

title: Higher Supports For Sugar Prices Barred by House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  A consumerminded House of Representatives dealt the sugar producers lobby a defeat today by refusing to raise sugarprice supports.

title: Curing the Biases of Childhood
description: MADISON, WISC. GREENEYED Katie has bright red hair and lots of freckles. When children see her, they laugh. Why are you laughing? Katie asks. You have silly freckles and silly hair, like a carrot top, the children titter. I know why you're really laughing, Katie says, undaunted. You don't understand hair and skin differences. Would you like to know more about them?

title: World News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 23 (UPI) South Korean authorities shortened curfew hours today to try to bring life back to normal in two southern port cities where thousands of troops have been maintaining order after four days of antiGovernment riots last week.

title: Bridge:
description: Preemptive opening bids are a twoedged sword. They can, and often do, make life so difficult for the opponents that they cannot locate their best contract, are shut out of the bidding when they could make a game or a slam, or enter the auction and run into trouble. Conversely, the preemptive action can often make it difficult for the preempting side to locate a good slam.

title: Judge to Hear Motion of Misconduct in Jacobson Case
description: A State Supreme Court justice agreed yesterday to hear a defense motion alleging that the Bronx District Attorney's office had engaged in prosecutorial misconduct while pursuing the murder indictment of a 49yearold race horse trainer and real estate investor.

title: Stocks Retreat on Reduced Volume
description: Takeover situations moved back into prominence on Wall Street yesterday as the stock market posted a modest decline on reduced trading volume.

title: Deaths
description: ABELSPeggy. Beloved wife of the late Nell. Devoted mother of Robert and the late Jack and the late Geald. Adored grandmother. Services at BoulevardPark West, 115 West 79 Street, Wednesday 11:00 A.M.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Congress approved legislation giving President Carter authority to draw up a standby gasoline rationing plan for the nation and put it into effect if a shortage occurs. The House passed the bill by onesided 301tol12 vote and sent it to the White House, where the President's signature is assured. [Page A1.]

title: Michigan Chemical Suits Settled
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (UPI)  The Velsicol Chemical Company said today that it had reached a multimilliondollar outofcourt settlement involving 70 property suits filed by farm families affected by Michigan's PBB catastrophe.

title: One Goshen Jail Escapee Gives Up
description: GOSHEN, N.Y., Oct. 23  One of the three inmates who escaped from the Orange County Jail here last night surrendered to authorities in his hometown of Newburgh late today, the sheriff's office reported.

title: Harvest in the Park for Preschool Planters
description: Youngsters scrutinized a seed that did not sprout as they returned yesterday to harvest the peanut crop they had planted in Central Park's North Meadow last spring. The children, who were taking part in the Parks Department's preschool education program, picked the peanut crop and, with a little help, made fresh peanut butter.

title: News Summary
description: The arms treaty narrowly survived a socalled killer amendment that would have asserted the United States right to match Soviet deployment of large intercontinental missiles. The proposal was defeated by 8 to 7 in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. But the close vote and support for the amendment by three moderate Democrats were worrisome for proponents of the pact. [Page A1, Column 1.]

title: U.S. Judge's Office Broken Into
description: The chambers of a judge were broken into Monday night at the Federal Court House in Brooklyn, but nothing of value was believed to have been taken. The chambers, a threeroom suite, were those of Eugene H. Nickerson, a District Court judge. The courthouse is at 225 Cadman Plaza East.

title: Brooklyn's Cathedral Undergoing a Revival
description: It is a lovely cathedral, situated at the edge of bustling Brooklyn Heights, graceful combination of neoGeorgian and neoPalladian architecture. But so many Roman Catholics have left the downtown neighborhood that the Cathedral of St. James draws only 200 people at its major mass every Sunday when it can accommodate up to 900.

title: Dionne Scores 4 Goals As Kings Beat Rockies
description: DENVER, Oct. 23 (AP)  Marcel Dionne, the National Hockey League's leading scorer, unloaded four goals on the Colorado Rockies tonight and led the Los Angeles Kings to a 74 triumph.

title: SCM Factions Vie for Votes of Holders
description: Emily Drake, a retired secretary, confided the other day that she was uncertain about how to vote the 200 SCM shares she owns. By yesterday, she had made un her mind.

title: Consumers Show Confidence Surge
description: Consumers confidence in the economic outlook improved markedly last month, according to a survey made by the Conference Board. The results were released yesterday.

title: Gems of W.B.L. Get Rights To Deal With Ann Meyers
description: The New Jersey Gems of the Women's Basketball League said yesterday that they had acquired the negotiating rights to Ann Meyers.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Committee  9:45 A.M. Political and Security Committee 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Theater: One Mo Time
description: ONE Mo Time is really two zws, ana although much of the music that goes with this is fun, the spoken words are not. Sometimes, in fact, they are embarrassing. One Mo Time opened Monday night at the Village Gate Downstairs.

title: Meadowlands to Conduct Two Daylight Programs
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 23  Meadowlands Race Track received permission today from the New Jersey Racing Commission to compete with Aqueduct in New York on two daylight dates, Thanksgiving Day, starting at 11 o'clock, and Dec. 29, beginning at P.M.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AMERICAN ARCHER (U.S. Lines),I Rotterdam Nov. 7, Bremerhaven 9 and Le Havre 11; sails from Howland Hook, Staten Island.

title: Koch Concedes Big Difficulties: Police, Sanitation and Hospitals
description: When he ran for Mayor, Edward I. Koch said he would try to put more police officers on the street, improve the city's sanitation services and scale down the municipal hospital system, which he termed an unmitigated disaster.

title: Spurs Down Celtics; Gervin, Kenon Star
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 23 (AP) George Gervin and Larry Kenon each scored 28 points and led a fourthquarter drive as the San Antonio Spurs defeated Boston, 129120, tonight.

title: Chrysler Workers Seek Representation on Board
description: In its negotiations with the Chrysler Corporation for a new labor contract, the United Automobile Workers union has asked that workers be represented on the company's board of directors.

title: Creation of Inquiry Board Asked In Strike on Bus Line in Queens
description: The chairman of the State Mediation Board requested yesterday that a board of inquiry be set up to try to resolve the Green Bus Lines strike,. which has crippled bus service in Queens for nearly four months.

title: British Abolish Controls On Foreign Currency
description: LONDON, Oct. 23  For the first time in 90 years, Britons will be free beginning tomorrow to buy and use foreign currency without any restriction, it was announced today in the House of Commons:

title: ABC Earnings Up 25.6% in Quarter
description: The American Broadcasting Companies, which is seeking to expand its interest in the publishing field through the acquisition of Macmillan Inc., yesterday reported a thirdquarter earnines rise of 25.6 percent to a record $31.9 million, or $1.14 a share, from $25.4 million, or 91 cents a share, in the yearearlier period.

title: CHINESE TRADE PACT IS SENT TO CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  After months of delay, President Carter today formally sent to Congress the agreement signed last July granting trade preferences to China. If Congress approves the accord, China would receive mostfavorednation status.

title: The City
description: A state audit reported that the City University of New York overstated its fall 1978 enrollment for three of its community colleges, and the university faces reductions of at least $1.5 million in state aid unless it supports its enrollment claims.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: This is the time of year when wild game reappears in the kitchens of those who hunt, and how it is handled before it arrives there is allimportant.

title: Warner &
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 23 (AP)  A $200 million attempt for a takeover of the Warner & Swasey Company, makers of industrial machinery, by a United States subsidiary of the Dominion Bridge Company of Montreal was set back today when a Federal judge here refused to consider the suitor company's challenge to Ohio's tenderoffer legislation. The subsidiary, the AMCA International Corporation, said that it would go ahead with the offer.

title: Nevada Governor Denies Radioactive Dump Pleas
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Oct. 23 (AP) Gov. Robert S. List turned aside pleas from around the nation today, saying he was sticking with his decision to close a radioactive waste dump  a move leaving only one such dump operating in the nation.

title: Israeli Debate: Way to Peace
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 23  Moshe Dayan's resignation as Foreign Minister has highlighted the uncertainty that Israel is facing as the country moves ahead, tentatively, into the unknown territory of peace. Many feel themselves and their Government inflicted by an absence of vision, an inability to form a clear picture of how IsraeliPalestinian relations would look after a permanent and stable Middle East solution.

title: Congress Gets Sexual Harassment Appeal
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP)  A former Justice Department employee who says she was dismissed for protesting the advances of her boss appealed to Congress today to protect Federal workers victimized by sexual harassment.

title: First John Hour on WNYC Names Clients of Prostitutes
description: The names of nine men convicted of patronizing prostitutes were broadcast yesterday over New York City's municipal radio and television stations.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: WASHINGTON  The talent of the stupid right for scoring a goal for the other team has nowhere been more vividly or enthusiastically deployed than during the ZimbabweRhodesia negotiations over the last year.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: MARGOLIN 275 Madison Ave agency 6793930

title: Oil Profits Surprise Analysts
description: Only a handful of oil companies have released their thirdquarter earnings thus far, but it is already clear that the current round of oil profits will surpass the startling increases that riled the public earlier this year.

title: Quarterly Earnings Soar At Gulf Oil and Conoco
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday that its thirdquarter earnings had almost doubled, and Conoco Inc. said its profits were more than twice the level of the yearearlier quarter.

title: G.O.P. Official Disputes Connally Mideast Stand
description: Washington, Oct. 23  Bill Brock, the Republican national chairman, has expressed sharp differences with John B. Connally, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination who has called for a new approach in United States policy in the Middle East.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Mozart's Die Entfuh. rung aus dem Serail, 8.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Lakers Johnson Returns Friday
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 (AP)  Earvin (Magic) Johnson, the Los Angeles rookie guard who has been sidelined with sprained right knee, will return to action Friday night when the Lakers face Kansas City, the National Basketball Association team has announced.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: C.D. Bard Inc., Murray Hill, N.J., manufacturer of medical and surgical products, has named Jack Olshansky president of its Inspiron Division.

title: Prime Rate Is Raised to Record 15%
description: Most of the nation's major banks increased their prime lending rates yesterday by half a percentage point to record 15 percent. Bankers said the move was in reaction to chaotic market conditions in which their own costs of funds had been rising sharply.

title: 2 Britons Freed in Afghanistan
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23 (Reuters)  Two British journalists who were detained in Afghanistan Sunday were released today and will fly to New Delhi tomorrow, a British Embassy official in Kabul said tonight.

title: Jorgensen Is Returning to Mets
description: Just as he was preparing to cut firewood outside his home in Arlington, Tex., yesterday morning, Mike Jorgensen learned what he had suspected for two months: He was returning to the Mets as the second of two players to be named later in the deal that made Willie Montanez a Texas Ranger last Aueust.

title: Misstatement by Senior Official Sends Ripples Across the World
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  The Senior State Department Official, who speaks with the same voice as Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, misspoke about some Soviet contacts the other day and the repercussions were almost immediate. Hie white House was irritated, Western allies were troubled, the Soviet Ambassador was baffled and the embarrassed State Department had to rush to correct the error.

title: Deaths
description: SCHEUERS.H. The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith mourns the death of an eminent leader and friend. Those who are in the forefront of the continuing struggle on behalf of human rights and In opposition to bigotry and iniustice have lost a dedicated adherent. His was life devoted to the community and Public service and his deep sensitivity to the needs of others will be truly missed. We offer our profound sympathy to his beloved wife, Helen, his daughter. Amy S. Cohen and his sons, Richard J.,James H., Walter and Steven H. Scheyer.

title: Of Muscadines and Other Sippin Wines
description: ATLANTA IT began with the armfolded solemnity usually accorded events with sixword titles, but by the time it was over the contestants were passing around and extolling such entries as a darn fine sippin wine made from elderberries and discussing the best places around to eat catfish and barbecue.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in Business Day yesterday on the thirdquarter earnings of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation incorrectly quoted Theodore F. Brophy, the company's chairman. He actually said the earnings showed a gain from the level of a year earlier if the distortion caused by accounting rules was excluded.

title: Wayne County, Mich., Lays Off Its 4,800 Employees in Budget Crisis
description: DETROIT, Oct. 23  Wayne County, the country's third largest, laid off all of its 4,800 employees today because it has run out of money and cannot pay them.

title: N.F.L. Records
description: BALTIMORE

title: Solomons Area Struck by Quake; No Report of Damage or Injuries
