description: GOLDEN, Colo., Oct. 23 (Reuters)  A major earthquake shook an area of the Solomon Islands today, the United States Geological Survey reported.

title: The Peaceful Life Eludes Nigeria's Former Ruler
description: ABEOKUTA, Nigeria  After handing over control of the Government to the elected civilian administration of President Shehu Shagari, Lieut. Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo has come home to live, as he puts it, peacefully and quietly. But so far at least, peace and auiet have eluded him.

title: Chess:
description: In the Interzonal tournaments to determine the semifinalists for the world championship, the International Chess Federation stipulates that when there are several entrants from one country, they must be paired against each other in the early rounds. The idea is to prevent the throwing of games in the late rounds, when it would be clear which player would benefit most from this kind of cheating.

title: Market Place
description: FOR a time, investors were willing to buy Kaiser Steel on the theory that the company's new facilities would enable Kaiser to make money. But even if that did not work out, the company's assets were valued far above the market and, if trouble ensued, the assets could be sold, the theory went.

title: For a Delightfully Horrifying Halloween
description: Some trace its beginnings to worship of Baal, the Phoenician fertility god. Others say it started with the druids. Whatever its origins, Halloween  with its tales of hobgoblins, witches, ghosts and devils, with its mischievous games and impish extortions still thrives in the affections of children, whose year is a bridge built of holidays and birthdays.

title: Park Ryan to Close
description: Park Ryan Inc., a small bond firm established in September 1953 that specialized in New York State taxexempt authority bonds, has decided to go out of business, Leonard J. Collins, president, said yesterday. The bond market's steep decline this month in the wake of the Federal Reserve's new credittightening move was one reason, he said.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: DRIVER THROWN CLEAR IN CRASH: Dean Chenoweth, who was piloting the hydroplane Miss Budweiser, being thrown clear of the ship yesterday as it was about to crash. The craft had been trying to break a world speed record. Chenoweth suffered six broken ribs in the crash.

title: At Least 30 Feared Dead in Chile As Village Is Buried by Mudflow
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 23 (AP)  A mudflow buried a village near Puerto Montt, 600 miles south of Santiago, today, probably kilning at least 30 persons, radio reports said.

title: Comex Planning Branch on Coast
description: New York's Commodity Exchange, the world's leading metals futures market, plans to open a West Coast branch in Los Angeles next year, Lowell Mintz, Comex chairman, said yesterday. It would be the first time that any exchange, commodities or securities, established an offshoot anywhere, he said.

title: Brown, in Harvard Talk, Steps Up Attack on Carter
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 23  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, cam paigning in Massachusetts and New Hampshire, charged today that President Carter's economic policies had turned the Democrats into the party of inflation, expensive home mortgages, costly nuclear power, scarce gasoline and budget deficits.

title: Drive to Sign Up Voters Is Begun In High Schools
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP)  Civic groups and educators, alarmed at the precipitous drop in the number of young Americans who register to vote, are mounting a drive to sign up this year's high school senior class at school.

title: CARTER EMPOWERED TO ESTABLISH PLAN FOR GAS RATIONING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  Congress voted final approval today of legislation giving President Carter authority to draw up a standby gasoline rationing plan for the nation and to put it into effect if a shortage should occur.

title: Fastnet Cost: $752,500
description: LONDON, Oct. 23 (AP)  The 605mile Fastnet yacht race, in which 15 yachtsmen died and dozens had to be rescued from the sea last August, cost the British Government $752,500, the Trade Department reported today.

title: Letters
description: The Chrysler Corporation has recently been in the news with its request for financial assistance from the Federal Government. Such a request raises an array of issues, one of which we would like to address.

title: Music: Eliot Fisk's Guitar
description: ANDRES SEGOVIA devoted a good portion of his career to trying to bring the guitar into the orchestral picture as a solo instrument, encouraging composers to write concertos and other ambitious works. Some years ago, he gave up the struggle, having decided that too few conductors and orchestral musicians had any sympathy for the guitar and most made little attempt to adjust their ears to its delicate sonorities. Other guitarists, however, have continued to work for solutions to these sticky problems, sometimes with splendid results.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: Books of TheTimes
description: GRANTED: One of Norman Podhoretz's chief strengths as an editor, writer, and social critic has always been his ability to make connections. Lionel Trilling might almost as well have said of him wnat ne saia of ElllOt wno was Podhoretz's predecessor as editor of Commentary magazine as well as one of his early intellectual heroes namely, that he has a sense of the subtle interrelations that exist between the seemingly disparate parts of a culture, and between the common places of daily life and the most highly developed works of the human mind.

title: El Salvador Junta Names Cabinet
description: SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 23 (AP)  El Salvador's new junta of three civilians and two officers has named a Cabinet. Among those appointed by the junta were Ruben Zamora as Minister of the Presidency, Hector Darra Hirezi as Foreign Minister and Col. Jos Guillermo Garcia as Defense Minister. Colonel Garcia was the only army officer named to the new Cabinet.

title: For the Champion, an Easy Gallop
description: A car slowed to a nearstop outside Barn 47, and the driver rolled his window down and called out to Laz Barrera.

title: Careless of the Mentally Ill
description: The only beneficiary of the state's effort to send mental patients back to their local communities has been the New York State treasury. That is the grim conclusion of an audit of the program just released by New York City Comptroller Harrison Goldin. Indeed, it is hard not to notice the mentally ill as they wander the streets of New York. Some act strangely, embarrassingly; some are pitiful. A few look dangerous, though in fact they are not; the dangerously ill are still kept in hospitals. Why not all?

title: 2 With Eyes on Javits Don't See Each Other
description: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 23 Two Democrats who might run in 1980 for the seat held by Senator Jacob K. Javits missed each other tonight at what was to have been a debate.

title: Personal Health
description: AWESTCHESTER mother was no less horrified to find that lice had infested the hair of her two schoolage daughters. She reported it to the small parochial school they attended and the school nurse then examined the heads of all the other stuRobert Burns was aghast at seeing a louse on a Lady's Bonnet at Church':

title: Moscow Gets First Snow of Fall
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23 (UPI)  After an unusually mild early autumn, Moscow received its first heavy snowfall today. The storm began shortly after noon, sending madcleaning crews into the streets. Last winter was Moscow's coldest in a century.

title: Uniroyal Agrees to Pay $5 Million To Settle 7  Year Sex Bias Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  Uniroyal Inc., recently barred from doing business with the Federal Government, agreed today to pay $5.2 million plus pension benefits to hundreds of past and present female employees who had charged the international rubber and plastics maker with sex discrimination.

title: Datsun Cites Peak In Exports to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) record 520,000 Datsun cars and trucks were sold in the United States in the 12 months that ended in September, Takashi Ishihara, president of the Nissan Motor Company, announced today.

title: Nunn Warns Against Tying Arms Pact to Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, said today that attempts by the Carter Administration and leaders of allied governments to link Senate approval of the strategic arms treaty with a decision to deploy mediumrange missiles in Western Europe could shake the very foundations of the alliance.

title: Silverman Explains NBCTV's Surge
description: Coming off a bleak spring and a barren summer, NBCTV has made an astonishing comeback in the audiencepopularity ratings this season without benefit of a single new smash hit. Five weeks worth of Nielsen audience data nave persuaded most experts that the network's recovery from a threeyear downslide is not a momentary one and that NBC is back firmly in the primetime ratings competition.

title: Election Unit Challenges DraftKennedy Groups
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  The Federal Election Commission has notified draftKennedy groups across the country that it has reason to believe that they may have violated Federal election laws, according to several officials associated with the groups seeking to draft Senator Edward M. Kennedy for the Presidency.

title: Vengeance Without Mercy
description: Two decades in prison can only cut the heart from a lifetime. Rarely has this surgery been inflicted more pitilessly than in the case of Huber Matos, who arrived this week in Costa Rica after 20 years in Cuban jails, forced to serve out an unyielding sentence to the last minute.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: One way to beat the price of fashion fads is to keep an eye on the ethnic clothes coming to us from the East. Quilted jackets from India and China, for instance, were great bargains last summer and have been copied in expensive designer lines. Now that lacy or embroidered blouses with designer labels and threefigure price tags are the rage, it's worth hunting up the ethnic shops for lessexpensive embroidered shirts made in the Far East. Among the best we've seen are the silk shirts from China, beautifully embellished with cutout embroidery at the front and on the cuffs of long sleeves. The China Emporium, at 154 West 57th Street, has them for $80. Pierre Saffir, at 805 Lexington Avenue (62d Street), has less expensive versions from Thailand. They are not silk, but polyester georgette or rayon satin, in pastels and deep colors, lavishly embroidered. These are $45.

title: Mrs. Grasso May Head 1980 Credentials Panel
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 23  Gov. Ella T. Grasso has been chosen by Democratic Party officials to serve as chairman of the Credentials Committee at the 1980 Democratic National Convention, her spokesman said yesterday. The decision would have to be approved next August by the full convention for her to become permanent chairman.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The United States new tightmoney policies, and the prospect of still higher United States interest rates, firmed the dollar further and depressed the price of gold on world markets for a second straight day yesterday.

title: Dr. Philip M. Johnson, Nuclear Medicine Chief
description: Dr. Philip Martyn Johnson, director of nuclear medicine at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Ridgewood, N.J. The 54yearold physician was also professor of radiology at the hospital.

title: TV: The Baffling Magic Of David Copperfield
description: MAGICIANS have always had a difficult time making their illusions seem convincing on television. One can intellectually accept the statement that no camera tricks are involved and yet remain emotionally unconvinced. Perhaps it is the remoteness in time and space of taped television displays of sleightofhand that tends to reduce their effectiveness.

title: Orders for Durables Up by 5.9%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI)New orders for durable goods rose 5.9 percent in September for the largest gain in a year, reflecting the.economy's unexpected strength during the third quarter, the Government said today.

title: Walt Frazier a Free Agent
description: Walt Frazier, released by the Cleveland Cavaliers last Friday, cleared waivers yesterday and became a free agent.

title: CENTER PARTIES GAIN IN DANISH ELECTION
description: COPENHAGEN, Wednesday, Oct. 24 Danes voted yesterday for the fourth time in less than six years in hopes of electing a Government that could deal forcefully with the country's rapidly mounting economic problems.

title: Rural Hospital Gains In Quest for Survival
description: STAR LAKE, N.Y.  Peter Holden became administrator of the CliftonFine Area Hospital in December 1977. At the time, the hospital was in the same shape as the battered compact car that had carried Mr. Holden north from Washington's Georgetown University to his new job in the Adirondack Mountains. Both were small, and both seemed ready to die.

title: EARNINGS
description: Citing strong demand and higher metals prices worldwide, Asarco Inc., the largest custom smelter of nonferrous metals, yesterday reported sharp increase in thirdquarter profits to $70.4 million, or $2.32 a share, from $9.7 million, or 34 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: For Physicians, Music Is the Healing Art
description: If the concertmaster came in half an hour late for rehearsal with most orchestras, the very least that might happen would be a scowl from the conductor. But Dr. Pauline Hecht got a grateful smile from the conductor of the Doctors Orchestra because, as a higniy trained violinist, she was vital to the amateur group's nexttolast rehearsal for tomorrow night's concert at Stuyvesant High School.

title: Marshall Warns of Adverse Impact From Policy of High Interest Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall, expressing reservations about Federal Reserve Board policies, said today that mterest rates are a very inefficient way to deal with inflation. It was the first such reservation raised publicly by a member of the Carter Administration.

title: Lack of Funds May Block Presidential TV Debates
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  The League of Women Voters said today that the confused state of the Government's attempt to regulate televised political debates may very well make it impossible for the league to stage next year's Presidential television debates.

title: Dr. King's Family Seeking Damages
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP)  Coretta Scott King, the widow of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., disclosed today that the family of the slain civil rights leader was seeking reparations from the Government for attempts by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to discredit him.

title: Advertising
description: AT first blush, it is hard to believe that Seventeen magazine could fashion an advertising sales pitch out of the workingmother explosion, but it has.

title: Business Records
description: JEANINE BARONE, 532 W. 111th St., N.Y. Liabilities, $23,200; assets, none.

title: Koch Now Backs Hospital Funds
description: Despite his insistence last week that the Board of Education and the Health and Hospitals Corporation would have to eat their projected budget deficits this year, Mayor Koch has apparently moderated his view toward the hospital agency and has proposed that the city use $25 million as a reserve for it.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Baldwin & Lyons Inc., Indianapolisbased insurance agency and broker, has elected Fred C. Peoples, president, to the additional post of chairman, succeeding Merritt W. Smith, who is resigning.

title: Westar Satellite Accord Advanced
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 24  Fairchild Industries and Continental Telephone said today they would acquire a share in Western Union's Westar and advanced Wester satellite systems, subject tc the agreement of the respective boards of directors.

title: Supply of Distillates Off
description: For the first time in several months, supplies of distillates fell slightly last week, according to the weekly statistical report released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: CARTER NAMES PANEL TO STUDY 80'S GOALS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  President Carter today created the Commission for a National Agenda for the 80's to examine inflation, energy, demographic shifts and other domestic issues and make broad recommendations to deal with them some time after the Presidential election next year.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LOST WORLD Many American tourists on the highrise, scimitarshaped Aegean island of Santorini, or Thera, which some scholars believe to be the fabled Atlantis, have watched the diligent excavations led by Christos Doumas, who is also overseeing construction of a new island museum. The distinguished Greek archeologist is in New York City to set up a special exhibition on Greek Art of the Aegean Islands next month at the Metropolitan Museum.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Meat futures prices plunged yesterday, while gold and silver futures rose despite a major new dollardefense step by the Government.

title: Vienna State Opera Making US. Debut
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  Eight years of dreaming and planning will come to fruition this weekend when the Vienna State Opera makes its United States debut at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts with performance of Beethoven's Fidelio on Saturday. Leonard Bernstein will conduct.

title: Sound
description: IMAGINE buying a car piecemeal: the engine from one place, the wheels from somewhere else, then matching up a suitable transmission and topping it all off with a nice, comfortable body.

title: Cross Burned on Staten Island
description: A cross five feet high was burned on the football field at New Dorp High School, at Lindbergh Avenue and Clawson Street, Staten Island, the police reported. They said witnesses saw several white youths ignite the cross about 8:10 P.M. Tuesday after pouring gasoline on it.

title: Panel of Inquiry Seeks New Curbs On Atom Plants
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  The President's Commission on the Accident at Three Mile Island is to recommend to President Carter next week that the Government not permit construction or operation of new reactors until state and local emergency plans have been approved.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The pattern at the Securities Industry Association, the major trade group of Wall Street, has been to elect an unpaid chairman to a oneyear term every three years from a socalled regional firm based outside New York City. Yesterday, that tradition was kept intact when the association announced that Benjamin F. Edwards 3d, president and chief executive officer of A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. of St. Louis, had been nominated as chairman for the forthcoming year. The action is tantamount to election next month in the closely structured brokerage and investment banking business.

title: Triumphant Notes For a Neighborhood
description: ONE Saturday, the neighborhood went to a wedding. It had been a long time since anybody in the block had got married. In fact, over the past several years, the block in Washington had been nit by a distressingly high number of separations and divorces. These, plus the deaths of Bertha and Bernie Topkiss, the resident grandparents on the street, who died within six months of each other, had made holes in the neighborhood, and the Topkiss's middleaged, unwell daughter Connie, who lives alone in the house, cries often. She is afraid of being alone.

title: Oslo Exchange Expanded
description: OSLO, Oct. 24 (AP)  Foreigners can now invest in Norwegian shares and bonds for up to one million kroner, or $200,000, the Bank of Norway announced today. The former maximum was $10,000. The reform, which takes effect immediately, is aimed at stimulating the domestic stock exchange market, the Bank of Norway said.

title: News Summary
description: Food for Cambodians was pledged by President Carter, who announced that Washington would provide up to $70 million as part of an international aid program. Earlier, Senator Edward M. Kennedy assailed the Administration for what he charged was a lack of concern as disease and famine spread in Cambodia. The Senator called for the United States to begin an immediate airlift of food and medicine to Cambodia. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Study Finds Use of Laughing Gas May Be Hazard to Dental Workers
description: Dental workers exposed to anesthetic gas have significantly more kidney disease, liver disease, spontaneous miscarriages and other serious health problems than those who are not exposed, according to the results of a nationwide, federally financed study.

title: A Female Cadet Takes Command
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 24 (AP) A 21yearold senior at the United States Coast Guard Academy here has become the first woman to command an entire cadet corps at any of the nation's four service academies. The senior, Cadet First Class Linda Johansen of North Dartmouth, Mass., has been named regimental commander of the 817 Coast Guard Academy cadets. There are 83 women among the Academy's total student body of 817.

title: Tate Itching to Even Score With Stevenson
description: Unmarked by Gerrie Coetzee but nearly knocked out by jet lag, John Tate struggled to his feet yesterday in time for a night on the town. The itinerary included dinner in the Rainbow Room and a visit to the Studio 54 discotheque.

title: CARTER PLEDGES AID OF UP TO $70 MILLION TO FEED CAMBODIANS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  President Carter pledged today that the United States would provide up to $70 million as the American share of an international food and relief program for Cambodia to avert what he called a tragedy of genocidal proportions.

title: U.S. Navy Ship Rescues 46 Vietnamese Refugees
description: SUBIC BAY, Philippines, Oct. 24 (UPI)  A United States Navy supply ship rescued 46 ailing Vietnamese refugees off Singapore, but eight of their companions had already died at sea, the Navy said today.

title: No One Dying, Cambodian Says
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 24  Pen Sovan, Defense Minister of the Sovietsupported Cambodian Government in Phnom Penh, said in an interview published in the Communist Party paper Pravda today that no one is dying of hunger in our country.

title: 2Party Fight Shapes Up in Assembly on Fuel Relief
description: ALBANY, Oct. 24  Complaining that Democratic plans to offset a possible shortage of heating fuel this winter offered the public too little too late, Assembly Republicans were polishing politically attractive amendments today to make the program more generous sooner.

title: 2 New Contemporary Art Museums Are Being Planned for Los Angeles
description: EVER since the nearby Pasadena Museum of Modern Art went belly up six years ago, Los Angeles has been starved for a contemporaryart facility. Now there is a possibility that it may get not one, but two.

title: Beacon Hill Gets a Condominium Garage
description: FOR $8,500 you can buy a nice car, but that amount  plus $66 monthly maintenance charge  is what people are spending for a single parking space in condominium for cars on Beacon Hill.

title: United Press International
description: HAWKS TOP CAVALIERS, 128118: Dan Roundfield Hawks, left, moving past Mike Mitchell of Cleveland Cavaliers in first period last night in Atlanta. Roundfield scored.

title: Rock: Miss Chapman
description: MARSHALL CHAPMAN started as a singersongwriter with a strong strain of country in her music, but she has been gravitating more and more toward hard, basic rockandroll. Judging from her show at the Bottom Line on Tuesday night, the transition is just about complete. She was rocking, with backing from a loud threepiece band, and while the idiom she has chosen doesn't allow for many of the vocal subleties that made her earlier work affecting, at the show this listener saw she more than made up for that lack with spirit and raw power.

title: Notes on People
description: There was an interesting matchup in Bonn yesterday: Prime Minister Hua Guideng of China versus Red Rudi the old nickname for Rudi Dutschke, West Germany's radical student leader of a decade ago. The advantage was all Mr. Hua's.

title: Algeria Lifts Crude Price
description: ALGIERS, Algeria (AP)  Algeria announced an increase of $2.77 per barrel of crude oil today, making it the sixth member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise prices reecently The official Algerian news agency said the price would go from the OPEC ceiling of $23.50 a barrel to $28.27, effective immediately, bringing Algerian crude oil into line with increases announced by other Mediterranean exporters.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I used duct tape to apply plastic to the outside of my windows, but the plastic tore so I had to remove it all. There is still a sticky residue from the tape on the white aluminum frames of my windows. I have tried alcohol, paint thinner and nail polish remover, but it doesn't seem to come off. What do you suggest for getting this sticky stuff off? - Mrs. E. D., Philadelphia.

title: High Point Market: Furniture Makers Scale Down
description: HIGH POINT, N.C. DESPITE such distractions as balmy weather, mimes, entertainers and cocktail parties, the buyers who flocked to the fall Southern Furniture Market here last week never succeeded putting the state of the economy far from their minds. In every crowded showroom, it was the inescapable tonic.

title: 2 MORE AMENDMENTS OF ARMS PACT LOSE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today rejected two amendments to the strategic arms limitation treaty that would have required the Soviet Union to dismantle its most powerful missiles.

title: Mobil Net Up 130.6% In Period
description: The Mobil Corporation, the nation's secondlargest oil company and a partner in the consortium of American companies that produces most of solidi Arabia's oil, yesterday reported a 130.6 percent increase in thirdquarter profits, compared with the corresponding period in 1978.

title: HOUSE, IN REVERSAL, CONTINUES CONTROLS ON GASOLINE PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  Reversing a 12dayold decision, the House voted today to continue price controls on gasoline. The 225toI89 vote, after routine debate, reflected strong White House opposition to the immediate abolition of controls.

title: Australian Costs Up
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 24 (AP)  Australia's consumer price index rose 2.3 percent in the third quarter and was up 9.2 percent over the last year, the statistics bureau reported today.

title: Salvador Leftists Hold Two Ministers Hostage
description: SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 25 (AP)  Leftists, many armed with guns and machetes, seized the buildings of the Labor and Economy Ministries today, taking two Cabinet ministers and about 130 other people hostage, witnesses and policemen said.

title: Market Place
description: SOME market analysts believe that margin calls, already in evidence at major brokerage firms, will continue to keep the stock market offbalance in the weeks ahead as it becomes more and more costly for small investors to finance securities purchased on credit.

title: B.P. Forms Gas Unit
description: LONDON, Oct. 24 (Reuters)  The British Petroleum Company announced today that it had formed a new subsidiary, B.P. Gas Ltd.. to develop its gas activities outside North America. It said the new company will take over the functions of B. P's existing gas department.

title: ABROAD AT HOME The Energy Disaster: I
description: Just six years ago, in the wake of the Yom Kippur War, Arab oil producers cut production and put an embargo on oil for the United States and some other Western countries. The result here was gas lines  and panic. Americans suddenly realized how vulnerable they were. The United States, once an exporter, was now heavily dependent on others for its energy supply. President Nixon proclaimed Project Independence, to make America once again selfreliant in energy.

title: B.F. Herberick, Retired From Conference Board
description: Bernard F. Herberick, former executive director of operations and services of the Conference Board, a nonprofit business and economic research organization in New York, died Monday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: Argentine Overcomes Opposition and Wins New Term at O.A.S.
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct.24  The Organization of American States today reelected Alejandro Orfila, the candidate of Argentina's military regime, as Secretary General for a fiveyear term.

title: Theater: joy Opens Yiddish Season
description: AJOKE, a song, a dance, and the Yiddish'Theater's season is off to a start on a cheerful, even refreshing note.

title: Protesters Shout Death to Shah Outside Hospital
description: As Mohammed Riza Pahlevi lay recovering from surgery yesterday, some 200 shouting antiShah demonstrators outside protested his presence in the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center.

title: Campbell Resigns As Columbia Coach
description: Frustrated by his team's failure to win consistently over the last five and half seasons, Bill Campbell resigned yesterday as head football coach at Co. lumbia University, effective at the end of this season. The surprise action went against the wishes of his employers, who expressed a desire that Campbell remain as coach at his alma mater.

title: Eleanor R. Belmont Dies at 100; Leader in Charities and the Arts
description: Eleanor Robson Belmont, a legendary figure in the world of society and the arts, died last night in her sleep at her home at Fifth Avenue and 93d Street. She was 100 years old.

title: Topics Old Treasure, Manors Reborn
description: Saudi Arabia, as part of a billiondollar archeological program, plans field work that it hopes will uncover, among other things, the site of biblical Ophir. That was the place to which Solomon dispatched his ships from Eziongeber on the shore of the Red Sea. And they came to Ophir, and fetched from thence gold, four hundred and twenty talents, and brought it to King Solomon. And the navy  brought in from Ophir great plenty of sandalwood and precious stones.

title: Inforex Files Chapter 11 Petition
description: Inforex Inc. of Burlington, Mass., a maker of minicomputer systems, said that it had filed for court protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act while it seeks a merger partner and agreements with creditors. The company's European subsidiaries are not included in the filing.

title: Deaths
description: LEVINSONJennie. October 22, 1979. Beloved wife of Harry, dear mother of Irene Mazur, Bobby and Larry. Loving grandmother of Joyce, Beverly, Laurie, Gary, Karen, Paul, 5 greatgrandchildren. Loving sister of Esther Wigler and Jack Spielhoiz. Shiva at family residence in Hewlett.

title: Bank of China Expands
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 24 (Reuters) With the growth of overseas financial activities, the Bank of China is preparing to open branches in New York and Tokyo and a representative office in Paris, the managing director of the Bank of China said today in a lecture on China's banking business.

title: Events Today
description: ALL THE WA,Y HOME, written by Tad Mosel, at the Equity Library Theater, West 103d Street and Riverside Drive, 8, through Nov. 11.

title: U.S. Sets $6.75 Billion Bond Sale
description: The Treasury, at the end of the bond market's biggest daily price gyrations ever, announced plans yesterday to sell $6.75 billion of new notes and bonds next week to refinance securities maturing in midNovember and to raise $1.36 billion of additional cash to help finance the Federal budget deficit.

title: Seven Governors Vow To Promote Coal Use In Appalachian States
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 24  The Governors of seven Appalachian states pledged today to work together to promote the use of coal, the region's most abundant energy source, for both power and economic development.

title: Hifi Stereo TV Coming in 2 to 4 Years
description: The television set in the last 30 years has gone from black and white to color, from bulky to portable, from tabletop size to wall size. Virtually all the engineering and manufacturing changes so far have involved the television picture.

title: VOLCKER CAUTIONS BANKERS ON CREDIT
description: Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, in an apparent attempt to avert a credit shortage and a steep recession as a result of the board's restrictive monetary policy, has asked the nation's banks to ration credit evenly across the full spectrum of the economy in a letter sent to Federal Reserve member banks on Tuesday and released yesterday, Mr. Volcker warned the banks against siphoning funds away from one sector, such as homebuying, in favor of more lucrative areas, such as loans to large corporations. Unlike corporate loans, home mortgages are often subject to state interest rate ceilings.

title: Lockheed's Profit Slid 96.1% in Quarter
description: BURBANK, Calif., Oct. 24 (AP) The Lockheed Corporation, citing substantial writeoffs on its L1011 TriStar aircraft, reported today that its thirdquarter net earnings plunged 96.1 percent to $1.1 million from $27.9 million recorded in last year's third quarter.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: FLEXIBLE track, which is made to be used in boats and vans and can be bent by hand, provides a way to hang curtains in places where it might be difficult to put up standard curtain rods. It is useful in corners or oddly shaped windows and for such decorating jobs as putting curtain around a bathtub, hanging bed curtains or dividing a room with curtains.

title: Gigante to Be Released From Jail 3 Days Early
description: The Rev. Louis R. Gigante, who was given a 10day jail sentence for refusing to answer questions about his efforts to make prison life easier for a reputed gangster, will be released today  three days early  for good behavior, the Correction Department said yesterday.

title: The City
description: Charitable groups, which collect $4 billion a year in New York State, should be subject to more stringent reporting rules, witnesses at a hearing at the World Trade Center said yesterday. The hearing was conducted by Attorney General Robert Abrams.

title: Design Notebook
description: IT is hard to say exactly what creates the ambiance of a hotel. The overall architecture is surely part of it; and so is the clientele. But we tend to be more aware or little details in a hotel than in another sort of public place. The placement of a piece of furniture, the colors of a carpet, the size of a room, the flowers on the table  all affect our feelings more markedly in hotels than they are likely to do in such places as office buildings, schools or shopping centers.

title: Gerson Reichman, 71; Was Board Chairman Of Lamport Company
description: Gerson Reichman, former president and chairman of the board of the Lamport Company, textile distributors, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Purchase, N.Y. He was 71 years old.

title: Boeing Unit Sells 5 Chinook Helicopters
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 (AP)  A subsidiary of the Boeing Company has sold five commercial Chinook helicopters for $55 million to a British company that operates the world's largest fleet of commercial helicopters.

title: Queen Elizabeth Visits France
description: TOURS, France, Oct. 24 (UPI) Queen Elizabeth II of Britain arrived today for a private twoday visit to France that will include a dinner given by President Valery Giscard d'Estaing. The visit includes sightseeing at the chateaus along the Loire River southwest of Fans and a visit tomorrow to Beaune in the heart of the Burgundy wine country. It is the Queen's first visit to France in five years.

title: Power Failure in London Darkens Palace and Parliament Buildings
description: LONDON, Oct. 24 (AP)  Buckingham Palace and Parliament were among the buildings in central London blacked out by an hourlong power failure today during a heavy downpour.

title: F.U. RULES OUT BAN ON ADS BY DOCTORS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  The Federal Trade Commission ruled today that the American Medical Association could not prohibit medical doctors from advertising their fees and services.

title: Deaths
description: SCHEUERS.H. On October 22, 1979 Devoted husband of Helen. Father of Richard, James, Walter, Steven and Amy Cohen. Grandfather of twentytwo and recent greatgrandfather. Services Thursday, 10:30 at Temple Emanuel, 65th Street and 5th Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions to JASA or U.J.A.Federation would be appreciated.

title: Annual Decorating Exhibition
description: Decoration and Design Show, Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 66th Street.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The House voted to continue price controls on gasoline. The 225to189 vote, reversing a 10dayold decision, reflected strong White House opposition to the immediate abolition of controls. Congressional leaders also cited high oilcompany profits and predictions of gasoline shortages next year. [Page Al.]

title: New Car Sales Off 6.6% From MidOctober in 78
description: DETROIT, Oct. 24 (UPI)  New car sales by United States auto makers in midOctober fell 6.6 percent below the level of a year earlier, indicating a slow start for the auto industry's 1980 models.

title: Sun Alliance Buys 9% of Chubb Stock
description: The Chubb Corporation, a large insurance holding compary, reported that Sun Alliance End London Insurance Ltd., a large British insurance company, had acquired in the open market about 9 percent of Chubb's outstanding common shares.

title: Algeria Seeks Loan
description: LONDON, Oct. 24 (Reuters)  The Algerian state oil and gas company, Sonatrach, signed an agreement with a consortium of international banks to raise a 1500 million dollar loan. a spokesman for Citicorp, the agent bank, said today. The 10year loan, which carries interest of 1 percent above London interbank rates and has a fiveyear grace period, is expected to complete Sonatrach's project financing for this year, the spokesman said.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: I was agreeably surprised by your Oct. 13 editorial on the U.S. attitude toward Cuba. In it, as well as in Craig R. Whitney's Oct. 12 article on Moscow's uncertainty about U.S. foreign policy, you have made the highly commendable effort to look at a dispute from the opponent's point of view. Certainly it is fruitful to do so merely for strategic reasons.

title: Jumper Returns To Win
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 24  Tuscaloosa, one of the leading mounts of the United States Equestrian Team for the last five years, sustained a leg injury four months ago and no one was sure lust when he would get back in shape.

title: House Gasoline Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP)  Here is how representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut voted today on a measure by which the House reversed itself and refused to lift price controls on gasoline.

title: Deaths
description: MILLERCharles, of New Hope, Pa. He was a famous musical arranger. Died Sunday, October 20, 1979 at the age of 96 years. Mr. Miller was born in Amsterdam, Holland and he came to the United States with his Parents in 1888 and they settled in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. In 1906 he married the former Adella Metzl who died in 1965. The had one son Everett who died in 1951. Mr. Miller started a long and illustrious musical career. In 1910 when he wrote the popular song Let Me Call You Sweetheart, he was mainly known however as one of the foremost arrangers of his time. He was head arranger for the Harms Inc. He made musical arrangements, scores for victor Herbert, Sigmund Romberg and Rudolph Friml, Irving Berlin, George Gershwin, Jerome Kern, Richard Rogers and many others.

title: Bomb in Tel Aviv Bus Terminal
description: TELAVIV, Oct. 24 (UPI) A bomb set off by a wrist watch exploded at the central bus terminal today, shattering windows and sending a woman into shock. The police said that they believed the twopound bomb was planted yesterday by members of a local Arab guerrilla group. They rounded up dozens of suspects from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip for questioning.

title: Archeologists Hard at Work At Site of the First City Hall
description: Archeologists digging into more than three centuries of New York City's history on the site of the first City Hall say they expect to find new data on how the early Dutch settlers lived at the southern tip of Manhattan Island.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Times Tuesday misstated Mauritania's actions in giving up its part of Western Sahara. In August, Mauritania, in an agreement with the Polisario guerrillas, gave up its rights to a part of Western Sahara. Morocco then seized the area and annexed it.

title: A Theater for Bettors Opens in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 24  The nation's first gambling theater, a significant new attraction in the relentless pitch for the gamblers dollar, opened here today with live television coverage of horse racing from New York.

title: A $14 Million Health Care Project To Aid 2 Poor Sections of Brooklyn
description: A $14 million pilot project to provide health care for the poor of the BedfordStuyvesant and Crown Heights sections of Brooklyn was announced yesterday by Federal and New York State health officials.

title: Alleged Plot on Coast Led to Tight Security For Princess Margaret
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24  Police officials here said today that they had imposed extraordinary security procedures in a visit late last week of Princess Margaret of Britain because of reports that there might be an attempt to assassinate her.

title: Carter '76 Fund Raiser To Join Kennedy Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  Morris S. Dees Jr., the Alabama civil rights lawyer who raised campaign money for President Carter in the 1976 election, will work for Senator Edward M. Kennedy in the 1980 campaign.

title: Seeking a Full Season, Beaumont Theater Postpones Reopening
description: Instead of reopening this winter, as originally announced, Lincoln Center's Vivian Beaumont Theater will reopen next fall. The reasons for the delay have to do with artistic planning and economic necessities.

title: Jazz: Lewis and Machine
description: IF George Lewis doesn't watch out, his AIM 65 microcomputer is going to acquire enough of a following to leave his band and start a group of its own. There'll have to be new category so that listeners and critics can vote for it in the annual jazz polls, something like machines deserving wider recognition.

title: Technology
description: INDUSTRIAL robots, some of them equipped with cameralike eyes, are marching out of the foundaries and paint shops and into the cleaner environs of light industry.

title: Music: Bostonians Open Season at Carnegie Hall
description: SEIJI OZAWA keeps his New York audience guessing, you must admit. Last season the Boston Symphony's music director brought us one of the orchestral repertory's most grandiose works,Schoenberg's Gurrelieder, memorable contribution, though no doubt a painfully expensive item to take on tour. This season's opening program, which Mr. Ozawa conducted at Carnegie Hall last night, was considerably less ambitious. In fact, it hardly distorts the facts to call it a Boston Pops concert sans Arthur Fiedler.

title: Blazers Top Nuggets for 8th in Row
description: DENVER, Oct. 24 (AP)  Kermit Washington sank two foul shots with 17 seconds to play tonight and then insured Portland's eighth straight victory by blocking David Thomoson'sshot to give the Trail Blazers an 8887 National Basketball Association triumph over the Denver Nuggets.

title: Trifecta Returns $20,573
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 24  Cast A Pattern, a $19.60 winner, topped a $20,573 trifecta payoff in the Special to The New York Times race tonight at the Meadowlands. The large return was the second iighest payoff in Meadowlands thorughbred history. A 1161 shot, Away Regret, finished second and paid $98.40 to place and $28.60 to show. Queen Flush, a 61 shot, finished third.

title: Casinos Ordered To Let Counters Play Blackjack
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 29  The Casino Control Commission ordered Atlantic City's two casinos today to permit card counters to play blackjack beginning Dec. 1, but modified the rules for an indefinite trial period to make it harder for them to beat the odds.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Charity Is Big Business, So Let's Regulate It
description: Americans, who are unequalled in their generosity, give to charity at the rate of $100 million a day, or a total of approximately $40 billion a year. If we add the estimated $60 billion a year that the nation's 800,000 nonprofit agencies and institutions, large and small, receive in Government grants and service fees, their total annual income comes to at least $100 billion.

title: Uganda, Pearl of Africa, Battling Legacy of Amin
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct. 18  Uganda, said Winston Churchill, is the pearl of Africa.

title: AGENCY TRANSFERS LINKED TO POLITICS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP)  The Small Business Administration is transferring 25 percent of its district directors in what many of those affected say is an attempt to replace Republicans with Democrats.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Ballade et Polonaise, Vieuxtemps; Sonata for Two Flutes in C minor, Chedeville; Sonata for Recorder and Continuo, Loeillet; Concerto No. 1 in B flat, Handel.

title: 8,000 Haitians Need Political Asylum Now
description: The issue of granting political asylum to Haitian refugees must cross the threshold of the White House and move directly into the Oval Office for immediate action by the President.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Extensive cloudiness extends from New England through the lake region and the Ohio Valley. Rainshower clouds are visible in the Northern Plains States and layered rain and snow are apparent over the Pacific Northwest. Clear skies cover the rest of the country.

title: RICHARD HOOD
description: Richard Hood, who built and operated the Top Notch Lodge in Stowe, Vt., and was one of the resort area's top tennis and golf players, died Oct. 9 in Long Beach, Calif. where he had resided the last few years. He was 55 years old.

title: Propane Blast Kills 2 and Hurts 7 Just After Closing of Kansas Cafe
description: LATHAM, Kan., Oct. 24 (UPI)  Two employees of a cafe were killed and several others injured tonight in a propane explosion that leveled the cafe only minutes after it closed for the night.

title: Ottawa Moves to Relax Its Official Secret Rules
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 24  The Canadian Government introduced in Parliament today the first freedom of information bill in the country's history after long years of criticism of official secrecy.

title: The Dance: 2 Premieres Are Offered
description: E BB was the exception. Choreographed by Kazuko Hirabayashi to a song by Kurt Weill, Ebb was new solo for Marla Bingham during which Miss Bingham tried to defy adversity with big, bold gestures and then crumpled beneath the blows of fate. Ebb was brief and pungent. But Ebb was the exception.

title: U.S. Harshly Rebukes Prague for Dissident Sentences
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  The United States denounced Czechoslovakia today for its conviction of six humanrights activists on charges of subversion and what the United States called the unreasonably harsh sentences.

title: About Washingtonville
description: WASHINGTONVILLE, N.Y.  As a beneficent sun beamed down outside, the Rev. Lee H. Poole, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in this tiny Orange County village, sat down to lunch and said grace.

title: Home Beat
description: EDWARD ACEVEDO needed to do something with his hands when he was trying stop smoking. He didn't stop smoking, but got involved in making miniatures, mostly 18thcentury ones. In January 1978, he approached Gene Moore, then at Tiffany's, with the idea of doing miniature rooms by contemporary designers. Last fall's rooms were such a success the store decided to do a new series. This year's rooms were handled like regular interior design jobs, Mr. Acevedo said. The designers gave him detailed floor plans and fabric samples. Jack Soskin & Associates did the scaleddown needlepointed versions of the carpets. Lisa Paull, Valerie Nykula and Pat Tornborg painted fabrics and made accessories. Dennis Homlitas helped with the construction.

title: Operating Net Off For Texas Airline
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 24 (AP) Texas International Airlines today reported thirdquarter earninns of 521.9 million. or 53.10 a share. This included $19.3 million from the sale of 790,700 shares of National Airlines stock to Pan American World Airways.

title: With Lloyd in 34 Defense, Giants Are 30
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 24 - His name is not Phil Simms, but the Giants have been undefeated since he, too, became a starter three games ago.

title: Beaths
description: ARTHUREffie Thixton. Wife of the late Wilbur L. Arthur, N.Y. advertising representative of the Chicago Daily News. On October 24 at her home in Wilton, Connecticut. She is survived by her nice, Mary Ellen Bacon of Flagler Beach, Florida. Interment private at Louisville, Kentucky.

title: Hers
description: FOR a year I had a glamour job. I was movie star's secretary. You've seen his 8by10 glossy, with slick hair and iridescent tuxedo, hanging in the windows of delicatessens and of shirtmakers to the stars. If the oicture is more than 10 years old, there's a chance I signed it. One of my first assignments was learning to duplicate his signature.

title: The Least Favorable Trade Ploy
description: After repeated vows that he would treat them alike, President Carter now proposes to exempt China, but not yet the Soviet Union, from discriminatory trade tariffs. This tilt toward Peking is explained as merely a matter of convenience. But it depreciates the President's word and leaves the United States in the odd position of making large judgments for trivial reasons. That is not the way to play the bigpower game.

title: Brown Bid Hits New Hampshire Obstacles
description: ROCHESTER, N.H., Oct. 24  This campaign is going to be much more slogging through the rain than the blitzkrieg effect we had in 1976, said Michael J. Gage, a California Assemblyman and principal campaign operative for the Presidential effort of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. It's more formidable going up against an incumbent President in your own party and a popular Senator than a wide open field.

title: A Thoroughly Politicized Czech Playwright
description: Vaclav Havel, the dissident Czechoslovak playwright, recalled with relish an incident last year at his country place 80 miles northeast of Prague. He was under house arrest there, way out in the woods, and the police had a terrible time watching me, he said. To keep track of my conversations, they strung a long wire through the woods into the house. One night. Pavel Landovsky, the actor, discovered the wire. We ran through the woods, rolling it up as we went. The next morning he went down to town and sold it.

title: ESSAY The Road To Morocco
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  When President Carter changed his mind and decided to sell offensive arms to conservative King Hassan of Morocco, it marked the end of the Andrew Young era of United States diplomacy. At a White House newly wakened to political reality, the third world no longer rules the roost.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: U.S. Said to Ease Ban on Export of Atom Materials
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  A report prepared for the White House's National Security Council says that the Carter Administration has softened its opposition to the export of sensitive technology and materials that could be used to fashion nuclear weapons. State Department officials strongly dispute the finding.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For per 1003 as snown.(N) Ind cafes stock is listed on the New Yort Stock Exchange, (A) the America, Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: County Refuses to Pay Overtime For Protecting Kennedy on Visii
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Oct. 24 (AP) The commissioners of Kanawha County today refused to authorize $1,636 in overtime pay for sheriff's deputies to protect Senator Edward M. Kennedy during an appearance here.

title: U.S. Said to Abandon Ceiling on Chrysler Aid
description: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich., Thursday, Oct. 25  The Carter Administration, pondering strategies for helping the troubled Chrysler Corporation, has apparently decided to back loanguarantee legislation in Congress on the company's behalf but leave to the lawmakers the decision of how much money should be involved.

title: Home Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH most of the emphasis on fuel conservation for the home has been placed on the need for adding insulation, experts in this field have become increasingly aware of the fact that cold air infiltration is often responsible for just as much heat loss as inadequate insulation.

title: Michigan May Provide Some Relief for Wayne County
description: DETROIT, Oct. 29  Wayne County officials, faced with an empty bank account, began the paperwork for laying off the county's 9,800 employees today while holding out hope that at least temporary relief in the fiscal crisis might come from Lansing, the state capital.

title: U.S. Looking Into Disappearance of Korean ExIntelligence Director
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  The Justice Department has begun looking into the disappearance of the former director of the South Korean Central Intelligence Agency, Kim Hyung Wook, who was a key witness in Congressional and Justice Department investigations of the Korean scandal two years ago.

title: Billy Taylor and Friends To Play Jazz on Radio
description: To help generate more jazz on radio, WNYGFM will cosponsor a twohour broadcast on the Public Radio Network next Monday of Billy Taylor and His Friends. The group includes Dexter Gordon, saxophonist, and Johnny Hartman, baritone balladeer.

title: Kaiser Expects Rise In 80 Capital Outlay
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 24 (Reuters)  The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation expects capital spending in 1980 to rise 15 to 20 percent above 1979's estimated $185 million to $190 million, William Hobbs, treasurer, told securities analysts today.

title: Walton To Miss 3 Weeks
description: Bill Walton, the San Diego Clippers center who still has not played a National Basketball Association game this season, will be sidelined for about another three weeks according to Dr. Ernie Vandeweghe, his friend and adviser. Walton has a sixyear contract at a reported $1 million a year.

title: 10/ 24/ 29: The Day Market Started To Slide
description: Thursday, Oct. 24, 1929. President Hoover, Henry Ford, Will Rogers and Thomas Edison had just finished merrily toasting the 50th anniversary of the light bulb in Detroit. In a stormy marital dispute in London, charges of unfounded extravagance were leveled in court against Lady Heath for spending $45 for a typewriter. Someone tried to shoot the heir to the Italian throne.

title: OKC Postpones Liquidation Vote
description: The OKC Corporation, of Dallas, which has been negotiating to sell its cement and refinery operations, postponed a special stockholders meetine scheduled for this fall to vote on liquidating the company. Instead, shareholders will vote on the plan at the annual meeting in January or at a special meeting later next year. As previously announced, the company recently sold operating assets of its dredging company subsidiary.

title: Rural County Split on Saving Tiny Schools
description: KINGWOOD, W.Va., Oct. 29  Ten years ago this coal mining and farming county on the rolling western slope of the Alleghenies  in gentler terrain than much of West Virginia, but sharing the state's stubborn affection for rural remoteness  discovered it still had several ancient schools with outdoor privies.

title: Three Mile Island Crew Fixes Clean.Up Machine
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., Oct. 24 (UPI)Technicians have overcome a snag in efforts to decontaminate radioactive water at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant, according to officials of the Metropolitan Edison Company, which operates the plant.

title: Power Test Expands
description: The Power Test Corporation told the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that it had purchased 42,500 shares of Alpha Portland Industries on Oct. 9, increasing its ownership to 31.9 percent from 29.4 percent. Leo Liebowitz, president of Power Test, said the purchases did not represent a specific plan by Power Test to increase its Alpha Portland holdings significantly.

title: Bridge:
description: For the last 22 years, the world team championship has usually boiled down to a battle between the Americans and the Italians. Until 1975, there was standard scenario: a close battle with Italy prevailing on the last day. Occasionally it was less exciting: the Italians went ahead at the start and won in a landslide.

title: John Ballard, Former President Of Bulova Watch, Is Dead at 86
description: John H. Ballard, a watch industry leader who in 1941, as president of the Bulova Watch Company, commissioned the first authorized spot commercial in television history, died yesterday at the DeWitt Nursing Home in Manhattan. Mr. Ballard, who later became chairman of Gruen Industries, was 86 years old.

title: Hongisto Gets New Job As Special Carey Aide
description: Richard D. Hongisto, who resigned last summer as head of the New York State prison system in the face of Republican legislative opposition, was given a new, $45,000ayear state job yesterday.

title: Big Things Expected Of Oilers Gretzky, 18
description: The teenager who wears the blue and orange No. 99 jersey skates with his hands grasping his stick and his stick resting across his knees. His lees move gracefully, whisking him across the ice toward the faceoff circle in Nassau Coliseum. His upper body is tense, almost quivering, as if it is all he can do to hold back the energy inside him. Once in the faceoff circle, that potential energy becomes almost an unstoppable flow of motion. The stick slaps like claw on the ice as he digs the puck free, snaps it to a teammate and rushes down ice at the head of a pack of skaters.

title: Most Airlines Prospering Under Deregulation Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  The era of airline deregulation, one year old today, has drawn mixed reviews from the industry and passengers, but many fares are lower, traffic has been up hugely, and some record profits have been made.

title: U.S. to Sell More Bonds In Germany
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  The Treasury Department, pressing advantages won for the dollar by the Federal Reserve's austerity policies, announced plans today to sell up to $2.25 billion of securities in West Germany. The securities will be denominated in marks.

title: China to Learn Accounting, U.S. Style
description: China, which washed its hands of standard accounting practices 30 years ago when the Communists took over the country, has signed an agreement with Coopers & Lybrand, one of America's Big Eight accounting firms, to train 50 Chinese Government bookkeepers in the computerbased accounting techniques of the West.

title: Intruders at St. Patrick's Smash Part of a StainedGlass Window
description: Intruders broke into St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday by smashing through a small section of a stainedglass window, but they were apparently frightened away by a nieht watchman It was the first breakin that anyone could remember at the 100yearold cathedral. The damage was described as minor, nothing was reported missing and a cathedral official said, We're not making an issue of it.

title: U.S. Gypsum Sets Inward Goal
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 29  At a point when companies that live off housing and construction might be casting about for ways to diversify, the head of the United States Gypsum Company says he is looking inward.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Petrie Stores Corporation yesterday took its biggest step to increase its holdings in Toys R Us, the nation's largest toysupermarket chain.

title: Japan Society to Open Film Center Nov.
description: The Japan Society, in a move to formalize its presentations of Japanese films, is establishing a film center that will show on a regular, yearround basis classic masterworks, new films and theatrical, animated and experimental films The Japan Film Center will begin with The Demon Pond (Yashagaike), a Gothic fantasy contrasting the world of men to the supernatural. The year's most highly publicized film in Japan, The Demon Pond was directed by Masahiro Shinoda and stars Tamasaburo Bando in two leading female roles. The two men will be present at the premiere screening on Nov. 6 at Japan House, 333 East 47th Street, between First and Second Avenues.

title: Carter Pokes Fun at Kennedy at a Dinner
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  President Carter poked fun at Senator Edward M. Kennedy tonight, mimicking the Massachusetts Democrat's earlier hints that he would seek the Presidency, and making clear in the process that the campaign between them has begun.

title: 4 Seized in Raid Accused of Sales Of Car Licenses
description: Four persons were arrested yesterday and charged with running a criminal operation that, according to the police, sold virtually everything from new identities, complete with false birth certificates, Social Security cards and drivers licenses, to stolen airline tickets and cigarettes.

title: U.S. Upheld on Cotton Dust Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  The Occupational Safety and Health Administration won a major victory today when the United States Court of Appeals here upheld the agency's standards requiring industry to spend hundreds of millions of dollars to protect workers from cotton dust disease.

title: The Region
description: The board of trustees of the State University of New York yesterday approved a proposed $936.7 million operating budget for the university's stateoperated campuses in 198081, an 11.5 increase over the current fiscal year.

title: Catholic Interracial Group To Honor Helen Hayes
description: Helen Hayes will receive the 1979 Hoey Award, presented by the Catholic Interracial Council of New York to a distinguished Catholic who has worked to combat racial and religious bigotry and discrimination in our society.

title: Board Delays Hearing On Presley's Physician
description: NASHVILLE, Oct. 24 (AP)  A hearing on revoking the license of Elvis Presley's physician, Dr. George Nichopoulos, has been postponed indefinitely to allow attorneys more time to prepare their cases.

title: Danish Premier Begins Talks on New Cabinet After Election Victory
description: COPENHAGEN, Oct. 24  Prime Minister Anker Jorgensen began consultations today toward forming a new Government as a result of the victory his Social Democratic Party scored in Denmark's elections yesterday.

title: Largest Soviet Group on a U.S. Tour
description: The sleek blue and white ocean liner that docked at 53d Street and 12th Avenue this week possessed all the familiar amenities of a cruise ship: five classes of cabins, four bars, a sauna, lots of slot machines and even a gift shop displaying sable coats. In the captain's cabin, though, there was an added touch: a framed picture of Lenin.

title: SENATORS PRESS AID ON WARY CAMBODIA
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 24  Three United States Senators visited Phnom Penh today and asked the Vietnamesesupported Government to allow trucks from Thailand to deliver large quantities of international food relief to its starving population. They reported on their return here tonight that the regime had agreed only to consider the unconditional offer.

title: Sports Today
description: Oakland Raiders vs. San Diego Chargers, at OaklandAlameda County Coliseum, Calif. (Television  Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio  WCBS, 9 P.M.)

title: Man Holds Off Police With a Gun For 12 Hours at His Queens Home
description: A disabled construction worker drove his wife and children out of their apartment in Hollis, Queens, and held off the police with a shotgun for 12 hours until he surrendered a few minutes before 1 A.M. today.

title: Kinney and Carson Plan a Casino Deal
description: The National Kinney Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement with Johnny Carson, the entertainer, and a former gambling executive to develop casino businesses in Las Vegas and elsewhere.

title: Polaroid Reports Loss Of 23.1 Million in Period
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24 (AP)  An attempt by the Polaroid Corporation to cut losses on its Polavision instant movie system has helped to put the photography giant $23.1 million into the red in the third quarter, company officials announced today.

title: Deaths
description: SCHEUERS.H. The officers, directors, and employees of Adams & Co Real Estate Inc. mourn the loss of our clear friend and extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Samuel Field Chairman of the Board

title: Alleged Bourse Fraud Studied
description: PARIS, Oct. 24 (AP)  French police are investigating an alleged fraud estimated at nearly $6 million at the Paris Stock Exchange. known as the Bourse.

title: Television
description: 5:00 (E)News

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: ETZKOWITZBenjamin. West Side Institutional Synagogue records with sorrow the passing of its tree surer and Men's Club Financial Se cretary.

title: More Saudi Oil Reportedly Due
description: LONDON, Oct. 24 (AP)  Saudi Arabia is considering stepping up oil production by a million barrels a day, to 10.5 million, in a bid to stabilize prices, according to the latest edition of The Economist, the London financial weekly.

title: Soviet Atomic Test Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (Reuters) Seismic signals indicating a Soviet underground nuclear test north of the Caspian Sea were recorded at 2 A.M. this morning by the Atomic Energy Detection System. An Energy Department spokesman, making the announcement, said it was the 12th Soviet test this year.

title: U.S. Studies Landing Of a 747 Low on Fuel In Newark Emergency
description: Federal officials are investigating an incident at Newark International Airport Saturday in which a Pan American World Airways jumbo jet ran so low on fuel that the pilot had to declare an emergency and two of the four engines failed just after completion of the landing roll.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The price of gold rebounded by $10 an ounce or more on major bullion markets yesterday, more than making up its losses in the previous session. However, the dollar showed only mild reaction to the Treasury's latest effort to By The Associated Press support tne currency on imernationat markets.

title: Shah's Surgeons Unblock Bile Duct And Also Remove His Gallbladder
description: Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, the deposed Shah of Iran, underwent a twoandahalfhour operation yesterday to remove several small gallstones that had blocked a bile duct and caused him to turn yellow from jaundice. Surgeons at the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center also removed his gallbladder because it contained several additional gallstones.

title: Egypt, Israel and the Palestirdans: Impasse on Autonomy
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 24  With virtually no progress in the fivemonthold talks on Palestinian autonomy, Egypt has been casting about for other ways of getting Israel to concede a broader measure of home rule to the Arab inhabitants or tne occupied west Bank of the Jordan and Gaza.

title: Deutsche Babcock Adds Ford, Bacon
description: OBERHAUSEN, West Germany, Oct. 24 (Reuters)  Deutsche Babcock A.G. said today that it had acquired the United States engineering concern Ford, Bacon & Davis Inc. for an undisThe purchase is being carried out through Deutsche Babcock's United States subsidiary, Deutsche Babcock Technologies Inc., and will be financed from the parent company's reserves, a spokesman said.

title: The Boruses: Stylish but Select
description: THEIR names are almost unknown. Like their clients, they shun publicity. But Ronald and Victoria Borus are responsible for some of the most exquisitely elegant, beautiful and talkedabout rooms in the city.

title: Money
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1979

title: Shamrock in Offer To San Juan Racing
description: The Shamrock Broadcasting Company, privately owned by the Roy E. Disney family of California, has made an offer to acquire a radio station and some other communications assets of the San Juan Racing Association, according to Hyman N. Glickstein, chairman of San Juan. Mr. Glickstein said that he and other major stockholders have reacted favorably to tie offer of about $62 million plus assumption of about $5 million bank debt.

title: Chile Recognizes Salvadorans
description: SANTIAGO, Oct. 24 (Reuters)  Chile has recognized the Government of the junta that overthrew President Carlos Humberto Romero in E1 Salvador, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Money Funds Gain As Others Decline
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) Money market funds grew by $1.7 billion in September to a record $34.2 billion, but other mutual funds experienced a decline last month of $204.3 million, the Investment Company Institute reported today.

title: 4th WalltoWall Series Turns to Brahms Nov. 24
description: Symphony Space's fourth walltowall music program will be presented Nov. 24 with 12 hours of chamber music in a free Brahms concert. Previous events have presented Bach  twice and Schubert.

title: Disks: Dallapiccola Piano
description: THE last halfcentury has perhaps not been abundantly rich in firstrate music for solo piano. But it hasn't been as abundantly poor as a glance at local pianorecital programs might suggest. Thougn Luigi Dallapiccola (190475) is remembered more as a composer for the voice than the keyboard, his two solo piano compositions, Quaderno musicale di Annalibera and Sonatina canonica on Paganini Caprices, are both stimulating contributions to the literature.

title: A Day With Mother Teresa: Kindness Is Her Key Theme
description: CALCUTTA, India, Oct. 22  Five days after she was named the winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, Mother Teresa began her labors, as she always does, with devotions. With her sisters, barefoot, she knelt on a stone floor, holding the Gospel and the alarm clock that roused her an hour earlier, at 4:30.

title: Suggs Eager for Shot at Stopping Campbell
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct 24  Be cause he gained only 4 yards before leaving last Sunday's game with an injury, Earl Campbell has a mere 230yard lead over the American Football Conference's nextleading fusner. He has 11 touchdowns in his 757 yards gained and no other player has scored as many as 10.

title: Federal Water, Finding Its Level
description: National water policy has become more confused than effective, even in the old game of pouring Federal money into Western and Southern states. Low rainfall in the West and siltladen rivers in the South once justified unequal distribution. But now, many other states need help for which they cannot qualify under the old rules. A bill introduced by Senators Domenici and Moynihan offers a wiser approach.

title: General Foods Net Surged in Quarter
description: The General Foods Corporation, citing gains in its grocery and coffee business, reported yesterday that earnings in its second fiscal quarter surged 51.3 percent on a sales gain of only 7.2 percent.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: MAYERLING  the hunting lodge in the Vienna Woods, the suicide pact, the distraught ravens and the howling dogs  seems by now to belong more to Hollywood than to history.

title: 10 to 20 Years for Store Robber
description: A heroin addict who was suspected of robbing 255 women's shops in Manhattan was sentenced yesterday to 10 to 20 years in prison. Justice Burton B. Roberts said in State Supreme Court in Manhattan that the defendant, Larry Wallace, 32 years old, of 817 East 134th Street, the Bronx, had been identified by 176 shopowners and saleswomen, but was being sentenced only for the four robberies to which he pleaded guilty.

title: Film: 2 Clowns Spark Whole Shootin Match
description: LLOYD (Lou Perry), who looks like a younger Slim Pickens, and Frank (Sonny Davis), whose hair is receding with increasing speed as he approaches his mid30's. are not losers in any tragic sense. They simply dream beyond their means. Though they live in rural Texas, they (like the rest of us) are subjected to constant barrage of hype designed to make them dissatisfied with their lives. By the time that Eagle Pennell's The Whole Shootin Match opens, they've already failed as farmers of frogs, of chinchillas and of flying squirrels, and they're ready to chance their fortunes once again, this time in the polyurethane business. As Lloyd points out, There's money to be made from rich hippies who like to spread (polyurethane) all over their houses.

title: Wider U.S. Bank Role in Canada Seen
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 24  Longdelayed revisions of the Bank Act allowing foreignowned banks to operate more freely in Canada are expected to be approved by Parliament in the next few months and to go into effect next year.

title: Rangers Rout Oilers With 6 in First, 102
description: Glen Sather was shellshocked. In the wake of the New York Rangers 102 rout of the Oilers last night at Madison Square Garden, the Edmonton coach stood outside his team's dressing room and tried to come up with an explanation.

title: GARDENING New Pots Indicate When To Water
description: PLANTS can't talk. But when growing in the new types of selfwatering plastic pots, plants can indicate when they need another drink. The pots are fitted with water gauges, either clear plastic windows in deep drain saucers, or hollow plastic tubes fitted with floats. quick glance tells when the water level is low and the plants are in need. Watering chores are cut down to once every week to 10 days or so, depending on the plant and light exposure.

title: Wagner Testifies Scotto Is Honest And His Friend
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner characterized Anthony M. Scotto yesterday as a man of integrity and ability  and a darned good labor leader.

title: Raymond A. McConnell Jr., Editor And 49 Winner of Pulitzer Prize
description: PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 24 (AP) Raymond A. McConnell Jr., executive editor of The Pasadena StarNews and winner of a Pulitzer Prize, died Monday while hospitalized for treatment of vascular problems. He was 63 years old.

title: Chrysler Bankers Silent On Loan Guarantee Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  While an unusual coalition of corporate executives, labor leaders, car dealers and state and local government officialsmillion to Chrysler Financial, declined to comment at all.

title: Carter Is Said to Select Judge for No. 2 Justice Post
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  President Carter has approved the selection of Federal District Judge Charles B. Renfrew as Deputy Attorney General, ending long, problemplagued search for someone to fill the No. 2 job in the Justice Department, according to White House officials.

title: Stocks Advance Slightly As Volume Retreats
description: The stock market made a slim recovery yesterday after finishing Tuesday at its lowest level of this year. However, following the lead of wide fluctuations in the interestsensitive bond market, equities gave up their best gains late in the session.

title: Around the Nation
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 24 (UPI)  A Federal district judge today sentenced Dr. Murdock Head, the director of a taxexempt foundation, to three years in jail for conspiring to bribe two Congressmen. But the judge indicated that he might reduce the punishment to community service.

title: AUSTIN H. M'CORMICK, AIDE TO LA GUARDIA
description: Austin H. MacCormick, who as Correction Commissioner under Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia uncovered scandals and brutal conditions in the prison system on Welfare Island, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 86 years old.

title: World News Briefs
description: BONN, Oct. 24 (Reuters)  China and West Germany today signed two major agreements to increase their economic and cultural cooperation.

title: Toia Leaving City Post To Be Chase Executive
description: Philip L. Toia, Deputy Mayor for Finance, announced yesterday that he would leave the Koch administration on Oct. 31 to become a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: Transit Police Chief Revises Night Patrols to Fight Crime
description: In a move designed to give his commanders greater flexibility in responding to shifting patterns of subway crime, James B. Meehan, the chief of the transit police, has ordered major immediate modifications in the highly publicized nighttime patrols that were instituted under direct orders from Mayor Koch last March.

title: Sindona, in U.S. Court, Recounts Abduction Ordeal
description: Speaking in halting English, at times inaudibly, the Italian financier Michele Sindona presented a dramatic account in court yesterday of how he had been kidnapped in midManhattan and held prisoner for 10 weeks.

title: At Your Service: Repairing Lacquer
description: IN this age of high gloss, high tech, high taxes and highways, lacquer appears to reflect the times. But lacquer has similarly reflected other times, including 11thcentury China and 18thcentury Europe, and has been equally prized.

title: About the AllBlack Knicks
description: To anyone aware of the racial mix of the National Basketball Association in recent years, it was inevitable that the Knicks would be an allblack team sooner or later. Now that it's happened, some white basketball aficionados in New York appear surprised or offended, or both. That's only natural. Race, like sex and religion, inspires an awareness in virtually everybody whenever there is change. For the Knicks to comprise all black players indeed is change. Not a drastic change, however. During recent seasons the Knicks white players were benchwarmers. Even so, some white Knick followers suddenly are annoyed, some black Knick loyalists suddenly are proud. But those are strictly shortterm reactions. For the long term, the game is bigger than the genes. Pro basketball at Madison Square Garden will depend on the success of the Knicks as a team, not on the racial makeup of the roster.

title: The New York Tifnes/ Lou Mumm
description: WHAT'S Halloween without pumpkins? Since early Roman times the pumpkin has been a symbol of a successful harvest season, and in the Northeast the October pumpkin crop is one of the last to be gathered in.

title: Pollock Acquisition Set
description: Four former senior executives of Merrill Lynch Government Securities have completed negotiations to acquire Wm. E. Pollock & Company, a smaller Government securities firm, William E. Pollock, the 81yearold chairman and founder, announced yesterday. Terms were not disclosed. When the acquisition is completed Wednesday, Robert H. Meyerhoff, will become president and David A.
