Quigley, George H. Grimm and Morton Swinsky will become executive vice presidents. Austin C. Dowling, Pollock's president, plans to remain with the firm.

title: Letters
description: To THE HOME SECTION: William R. Dunnett's article [The Noisy Neighbors, Oct. 18] offered unnecessarily bleak alternatives for the tenant who is plagued by noisy neighbors: retaliate with louder noise or break the lease and move out.

title: Allon Denies 48 Ouster of Arabs
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 24  Yigal Allon, the former Foreign Minister who commanded Israel's elite Palmach forces during the 1948 war of independence, denied today that Arab civilians were expelled by Jewish troops from two towns near Tel Aviv in that war.

title: Text of Volcker Letter to Banks
description: Following is the text of a letter sent Tuesday by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, to the chief executive officer of all member banks of the Federal Reserve system:

title: Campaigning for College President
description: The City University's Board of Trustees has flunked the job of appointing new presidents to City and Hunter Colleges. A new board, albeit with some holdovers, will take its place at the end of the year. The lameduck board should therefore be persuaded to give up the task.

title: S. H. Scheuer, Legislator's Father
description: S. H. Scheuer, a New York investor and philanthropist and the father of Representative James H. Scheuer, Democrat of Brooklyn and Queens, died of a heart attack Monday at Doctor's Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Who Church Was
description: Frederic Edwin Church, one of the foremost 19thcentury American landscape painters, was born in Hartford in 1826. When he was 16 years old, he was accepted by Thomas Cole, then recognized as the foremost American landscapist, as his first and only pupil. It was while he worked with Cole in Cole's studio at Catskill, N.Y., that Church developed his love of nature and the art of interpreting it. In his earliest work, he concentrated on Catskill scenes.

title: Children's Folk Art at Heckscher Museum
description: About 55 examples of folk art created by children from the 1800's and early 1900's will be on display through Nov. 25 at the Heckscher Museum, Prime Avenue and Route 25A in Huntington, L.I. The items include toys, paintings, drawings, stitchery and penmanship exercises, once known as frakturs. In addition, there are two mourning pictures, pieces of art work to memorialize a death; one of the mourning pictures is a landscape,, d the other is a sampler.

title: Notes on People
description: Janet Auchincloss, with her daughter Jacqueline Onassis serving as her witness, married Bingham Morris, a retired investment banker, in a ceremony yesterday in the living room of her home in Newport, R.I.

title: New Uses For Paper Unfold On 54th St.
description: THOUGH the use of paper in art goes back a considerable distance, in recent years this versatile medium has been loved more and more for itself alone, rather than simply as a surface on which to make marks. For the last decade or so, artists have been exploring the textural possibilities of paper, its sculptural potential and the wonderful transmutations that can result from mucking about with the pulpy mash that paper begins as.

title: Irving Petlin, Storyteller
description: ONCE upon a time, pictures told stories. Babies were born, and a great future was predicted for them. Kings pardoned their enemies. Girls wept over their lost virtue. Drunken fathers brought ruin to their families. Heroes returned hcme when they were not expected. Christians hid from heathens. There was always something going on.

title: CHRYSLER PAY PACT TO SAVE $203 MILLION
description: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich., Oct. 25The United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation reached tentative agreement today on a new threeyear contract that would save the ailing auto maker approximately $203 million in the next two years compared with provisions of other contracts in the industry.

title: Radio
description: 7 A.M.Noon, WNYC. Sonatas, Scarlatti; Sinfcnia to Cantata BWV 35, Bach; Chansonetta Tedesca, Anon; Sonatas, Scarlatti; Sinfonia in E, Roman.

title: U.S. MONITORS SIGNS OF ATOM EXPLOSION NEAR SOUTH AFRICA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  The United States said today that it had detected signs that a lowyield nuclear explosion may have occurred last month in a region around South Africa.

title: IN THE NATION Paying for Politics
description: Months before the arrival of the 1980 campaign year, the nation had its first controversy under the Byzantine provisions of the Federal Election Campaign Act. Carter supporters charged mat Dratt Kennedy committees were cooperating across state lines and pursuing a common strategy  and therefore should be limited to accepting $1,000 per individual donor, rather than the $5,000 a truly independent, unauthorized draft committee could accept.

title: Pope, in Paper on Synod, Guides Church Teaching
description: ROME, Oct. 25 Pope John Paul II appealed to civil authorities everywhere today to show greater respect for human rights and religious freedom, especially religious teaching in schools. warning mat the church is living through an important but hazardous time of theological research, he urged priests to eschew outlandish theories, useless questions and unproductive discussions and to give young Roman Catholics the simple but solid certainties that will help them to seek to know the Lord more and better.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Loses Ground; Gold Down by $3 to $392
description: The dollar retreated yesterday against most currencies in lackluster foreignexchange trading, but firmed against the British pound and Swiss franc in New York. Meanwhile, gold prices fell.

title: Restaurants
description: IN the 14 or so years that have passed since Maxwell's Plum opened on the corner of First Avenue and 64th Street, that monument to turnofthecentury Art Nouveau kitsch has inspired countless imitators across the country, all pallid shadows of the exuberant original. Warner LeRoy, founder of Maxwell's Plum and son of the film producer Mervin LeRoy, is every inch a child of Hollywood who understands the true nature of the extravaganza and ascribes to the esthetic precept that more is more. For this caferestaurant, swingingsingles bar, he amassed kaleidescopic swirls of antique and reproduction stained glass, blazes of brass, forests of carved wood and waterfalls of crystal, combining them into the city's most fabulously festive interior. The concept of good taste has about as much validity at Maxwell's Plum as it does at a threering circus; in both instances, it seems very much beside the point. Those who seek peace, quiet and restrained elegance had best look elsewhere, but if razzledazzle suits your mood, there is no better place in which to encounter it.

title: Super Bowl Foes Battle on Sunday
description: The Dallas Cowboys and Pittsburgh Steelers, Super Bowl opponents last January, meet Sunday in the National Football League's feature game. The contest from Pittsburgh will be televised in the New York City area by Channel 2 starting at 1 P.M., in conflict with the JetsOilers game (1 P.M., Channel 4), at Houston. Channel 2 will follow the match at Pittsburgh with the Giants game against the Rams in Los Angeles at 4 P.M.

title: Around the Nation
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 25 (AP) A Federal judge said today that he would place Alabama's mental health system under the control of a courtappointed receiver.

title: BEaths
description: SOROCKAAorris, Dr. Practicing dental surgeon for flypast 55 years, Passed away on Thursday, October 25. Devoted husband of Christine and the late Lillian. Dear father of Edward James, and Phyllis Kanter. Loving grandfather of Peter, Gary, Steven and Andy. Services Friday, October 26, 12:45 PM The Riverside 76th St & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Black Leaders Assert Some Jews Are Pressuring Them on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  The top echelon of American black leaders, meeting here as a group for the first time since the resignation of Andrew Young as chief United States delegate to the United Nations, said last night that its members had been subjected to pressure and intimidation from some American Jews.

title: 79 Deficit, $27 Billion, Is Lowest in Five Years
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  The Government finished the 1979 budget year on Sept. 30 with a deficit of $27.7 billion, the lowest such figure in five years and less than half the $60.6 billion originally alarmed by President Carter.

title: Finances on Endangered Species Are Backed for 3 Years by House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI)  The House yesterday extended financing for the Endangered Species Act for three years but gave the Interior Department power over an independent agency that helps determine which species should be traded internationally.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Enlistments Off, Military Will Ask Increase in Pay
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  The Department of Defense will ask for an increase in military pay and benefits next year to help overcome this year's drop in enlistments in all of the armed forces, a senior official said today.

title: Nuclear Efforts Disavowed
description: JOHANNESBURG, Friday, Oct. 26The South African Government, although long suspected of conducting nuclear weapons research, has consistently denied that any efforts to gain a nuclear capability were being pursued.

title: Auctions
description: PHOTOGRAPHY sales are among the most controversial and provocative in the auction world these days. That's because the field is relatively new for collectors, and until now has been dominated by dealers. Next week, when all three of New York's Britishbased houses will be gaveling away to disperse everything from daguerreotypes to silver prints, New Yorkers will have their first opportunity to bid on what is described by Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, as the most important photography auction ever held in New York.

title: Israel's Negotiator at London Talks Hints of Initiative to the Palestinians
description: LONDON, Oct. 25  Israel's Interior Minister, Yosef Burg, who arrived here this afternoon to take part in talks with Egypt and the United States on Palestinian autonomy, said Israel might offer an initiative aimed at ending the Palestinians boycott of the selfrule talks.

title: Singer Has Loss Of $125.4 Million
description: The Singer Company, faced with heavy losses in its Singer Sewing Machine division, reported yesterday it had lost $125.4 million in the third quarter this year, compared with a profit of $6.4 million, or 30 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. Sales for the quarter were $626 million, up 5.8 percent from $591.9 million from 1978.

title: Drama: Beckett Novel Adapted
description: SAMUEL BECKETT'S novel Mercier and Camier, written in 1946 but not published until 1970, is in many respects a fictional godfather to Waiting for Godot. Two cronies  the tall, bonethin Mercier and little, fat Carrier cousins to Didi and Gogo in Godot embark on an aimless journey toward some unquestioned goal. The novel is a labyrinth, filled with vaudeville comedy. These are two tramps in mudtime who manage to survive in what the author regards as a world of hospitable chaos.

title: Business and the Law
description: COMMODITIES fever has spread far beyond the silver ring of the Comex and the soybean pits of the Chicago Board of Trade. It has hit the legal profession as well. Spurred by the creation of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission in 1975 and the surge in commodities trading in the past decade into a 81trillionplus market, the demand for experienced commodities lawyers in private firms and as inhouse counsel to the 11 exchanges, brokerage houses, banks and commercial users of the markets has spiraled.

title: Margaret McLaren, Nurse, Dead; Hospital Named for Her in Flint
description: FLINT, Mich., Oct. 25 (AP)  Margaret E. McLaren, a nurse and hospital administrator whose fundraising efforts helped create the medical facility that bears her name, died Tuesday. She was 90 years old.

title: Van Cortlandt Gains Footing
description: The crosscountry course at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx has undergone major renovations in an attempt to restore the site as a challenging showcase for the snort.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Broken to overcast clouds cover New England and the lake region. Heavy clouds are over the Northern Plains States and from the Pacific Northwest through the Central Pacific States to the Southern Pacific States.

title: Brewers Warned by U.S. On Agent Tied to Cancer
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP)  The Food and Drug Administration said today that it would take regulatory action against any domestic beer made after Jan. 1, 1980, that contained more than 5 parts per billion of cancercausing nitrosamine substances.

title: Beaths
description: CARTERBetty Frances (Nye) of Rye, New York on October 25, 1979. Beloved wife of Charles Henry Carter. Sister of Margaret VonderAhe of Greenbrae, California. Memorial service will be held at Christ Church In Rye Saturday, November 3rd at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Rye Free Reading Room would be appreciated.

title: The New York Times College Football Rankings
description: Top 20 teams derived from computer ratings based on games through Oct. 20.

title: Cape Frets as Oil Lease Auction Nears
description: CHATHAM, Mass.  Other summer resorts are described as desolate after the flood of tourists are gone, but here on Cape Cod these last few days of fall are too beautiful for that and so the Cape can only be said to be wrapped in Special to The New York Times The Talk of Chatham stillness.

title: EARNINGS Tenneco Up 28.2%; Schlumberger Gains
description: Tenneco Inc., paced by its energy operations, yesterday reported a 28.2 percent profit increase for the third quarter on sharply hither revenues.

title: British Plan Conference on Reinstating Limited SelfRule for Ulster
description: LONDON, Oct. 25  The British Government announced tonight that it planned to call together all of Northern Ireland's political parties to explore the possibility of transferring some administrative powers back to local government in Ulster.

title: Lotte Lenya Recalls Weill's StreetScene
description: Shortly after Kurt Weill came to this country in 1935 he attended a dress rehearsal of Porgy and Bess,  Weill's widow, the legendary Lotte Lenya, reminisced the other day. He listened very closely and he said, You know, it's possible to write an opera for Broadway. After that, whatever he wrote, a Broadway opera was his eventual aim. In Lady in the Dark, for instance, there were musical sequences which were really miniature operas. In One Touch of Venus he included a big bacchanal. He was always working consciously towards an opera.

title: Art Gallery Season Is in Full Swing
description: THIS is the time of year when the art galleries of Manhattan fairly teem with exhibitions of every sort, and New York easily earns its reputation as the art capital of the Western world. To see everything there is to see in the galleries just now  uptown, downtown and all around the town  would probably require as much physical stamina as running in the New York Marathon, and it would be a lot more taxing on the mind. But to see everything is not the point, of course. The galleries happily offer a variety of artistic expression wide enough to please the most diverse and specialized interests and tastes.

title: 2 in Israel Get Life Terms
description: TELAVIV, Oct. 25  Two guerrillas were sentenced to life imprisonment today for a series of shootings on Israel's coastal highway last year when 34 persons were killed and 72 injured. A military court in Lod said the crimes merited the death penalty but it could not be imposed because one of the prisoners, Khaled Hussein, had been a minor at the time and it was not certain that the other, Hussein Fiad, had been over 18 years old.

title: The City
description: Part of the 2,900member Transit Authority police force will go on a new subway patrol schedule tomorrow in a move to check subway crime by freeing more policemen for quick assignment by transit district commanders.

title: Votes by the Basques and Catalans Seem to Favor HomeRule Statutes
description: MADRID, Oct. 2  The Basque region and Catalonia appeared tonight to have heavily approved statutes that will restore home rule institutions extinguished four decades ago by the triumph of Francisco Franco's armies in the Spanish Civil War.

title: COMPANY NEWS   U.S. Cites Arco and Texaco
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP)  Texaco Inc. and the Atlantic Richfield Company overcharged customers by almost $200 million after the Arab oil boycott of 197374 sent fuel prices soaring, the Government said today.

title: Ballet Theater Lockout
description: American Ballet Theater has informed its personnel that, effective next Monday, the company is canceling all work scheduled to be performed by members of the American Guild of Musical Artists, the union that represents Ballet Theater's 82 dancers, until a new contract has been negotiated.

title: 10 Arrows Games on TV
description: The New York Arrows, defending champions of the Major Indoor Soccer League, announced yesterday they would have 10 games televised live this season by WPIX (Channel 11) on consecutive Friday nights Jan. 4March 7.

title: Poverty Board Election Is Scheduled for Dec. 4
description: The election of representatives to poverty boards in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens will be held Dec. 4, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: U.S. Painting Sold for Record $2.5 Million
description: Icebergs, the longlost masterpiece by Frederic Edwin Church, the American 19thcentury landscape painter, was sold yesterday morning for $2.5 million, the highest price ever paid at public sale for an American painting.

title: Japan's ColorTV Exports
description: TOKYO, Oct. 25 (AP)  Japan's color television exports in September rose 9 percent from August to 374,000 units, but were 17.7 percent below the level of a year earlier, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: Soviet Reporter Defects And Asks U.S. Asylum
description: TOKYO, Oct. 25 (AP)  A 38yearold Soviet journalist, the fourth Russian to defect in Japan this year, left his wife and child here and departed for the United States to seek political asylum, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Turkish Court Dooms 4 Palestine Guerrillas In Attack on Embassy
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 25  A military court condemned tour Palestinian guerrillas to death here today for a raid on the Egyptian Embassy in July in which two Turkish guards were killed.

title: U.S. Nine Routed by Japan And Drops to Third Place
description: HAVANA, Oct. 25 (AP)  The United States team at the Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament will have to settle for no better than a tie for secondplace after suffering a 124 drubbing by Japan last night.

title: UAL, Citing Airline Costs, Records $15.9 Million Loss in Quarter
description: UAL Inc., the parent company of United Airlines, Western International Hotels and GAB Business Services, reported yesterday a $15.9 million loss, or 54 cents a share, for the third quarter.

title: For Children
description: HEAD OVER HEELS, an original children's show, about carousels, fun houses and other amusement Park wonders, Saturday and Sunday at 2 P.M., at the Richard Morse Mime Theater, 224 Waverly Place (near Seventh Avenue and 11th Street). Admission: 52.50. Call 2420530.

title: Events and Openings
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Meverbeer's Le Prophete, 8.

title: Plea Slated On Nuclear Dumping
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP)  With two of the country's three lowlevel nuclear waste dumps closed, the Government is planning to ask governors to provide temporary storage sites for radioactive waste produced in their own states, officials said today.

title: FM's Success Is Loud and Clear
description: When Metromedia arranged to buy KLAC, an AM radio station in Los Angeles, it also got KMET, the jointly owned FM outlet, as a sort of bonus. This was 1965, and KMET was not much of a bonus. It merely broadcast the same shows as its big AM counterDart. And it was losing money.

title: Panel Checking Olympics Licensees for Crime Ties
description: The New York State Senate Crime Committee has begun an investigation into possible organized crime connections in companies having business dealings with the 1980 Olympic Winter Games in Lake Placid, it was disclosed last night.

title: David Kennedy Out of Hospital
description: BOSTON, Oct. 25 (AP)  David Kennedy, 24yearold son of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, was discharged today from Massachusetts General Hospital, where he had been treated for an infection of the heart lining.

title: Nuns Feel No Pressure to Alter Ways
description: American nuns have felt no pressure to change their way of living since Pope John Paul II made his call for tradition on his visit to the United States.

title: The Polities of Tax Repeal
description: ALBANY, Oct. 25  The Assembly's repeal of the sales tax on residential energy today was rooted not in legislators fears that New York residents would be left out in the cold this winter, but in their fears that some legislators might be left out in the cold next fall.

title: FezlerZiegler, 11 Under, Lead in $250,000 BestBall
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA. FLA., Oct. 25 (AP)  Forrest Fezler fired six birdies and his partner, Larry Ziegler, added five, combining for an 11underpar 61 and the firstround lead of the $250,000 National Team Golf Classic at Disney World today.

title: Times Company Reports Record 3Month Results
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that its earnings in this year's third quarter rose to a record of $7.7 million, or 65 cents a share.

title: Breaths
description: ALTMANEthel. Beloved mother and grandmother, son Leonard Altman and daughter Rita Weinisch. Grandchildren, Philip, Michael, Randy, Stewart and Gary.Funeral, Friday, October 26 at Parkside Me mortal Chapel, 1345 Jerome Avenue, Bronx 1PM.

title: F.A.A. Grounds Prinair, Largest Commuter Line
description: The Federal Aviation Administration issued an emergency order yesterday grounding Puerto Rico International Airlines (Prinair), the world's largest commuter carrier, pending its compliance with the agency's safety regulations.

title: Brown Accuses Carter of Failure on Nuclear Waste
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who is trying to make nuclear power and the energy shortage major issues in the Democratic Presidential campaign, charged yesterday that President Carter had failed to put into force a program on disposing of nuclear wastes and that this lapse borders on reckless inchilerence to the health and safety of Americans.

title: Albany Assembly Votes to End Sales Tax on Fuel Next October
description: ALBANY, Oct. 25  In a fractious session on rising fuel costs, the Assembly voted today to abolish the state sales tax on home heating fuel nearly a year from now and approved other legislation designed to provide relief this winter.

title: Pan Am Sets Flight Cutbacks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  Pan American World Airways will drop all of its charter flights and some scheduled flights, including some between New York to London, in an effort to cut fuel costs and reduce expenses, the company's president said today.

title: Mobilizing Congress and Energy
description: The Senate has already passed a bill giving the President what he needs to cut red tape on critical energy projects: an Energy Mobilization Board with the power to force decisions at each level of government. Now it is up to the House, where opinion has been sharply divided over what sort of board  if anyshould be created. Happily, prospects are good for a compromise along the lines of the Senate's bill.

title: Marathon of Dance Comes to the Beacon
description: If Ballet at the Beacon has a pleasantly alliterative ring, the program to be seen this weekend at the Beacon Theater on Broadway and 74th Street could also be described as a balletic bouillabaisse, a mixture of new and old faces and snippets of dance.

title: Soviet and South Yemen Sign 20- Year Friendship Pact
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 25  Southern Yemen bound itself to the Soviet Union today in 20year treaty of friendship that consolidates Moscow's economic and military influence in the southwest corner of the Arabian Peninsula.

title: Balbuco Faultless In Victory
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 25  Balbuco, a graybeard in the equestrian world, and Tuscaloosa, a mount recently recovered from a leg injury, won the two openinternational jumper classes today at the Washington International Horse Show.

title: ArchitectTurnedFarmer Says Nigerian Agriculture Is Neglected
description: RIDO JUNCTION, Nigeria  Everyone talks about Nigeria's socalled green revolution,  Yusuf Mohammed was saying here the other day. Well, I decided that I would not just talk but do something about it. So I'm a farmer now.

title: The John Minute
description: This week's premiere of Mayor Koch's John Hour, which broadcast the names of nine convicted customers of prostitutes, was a shabby show, in no way redeemed by its brevity. It took only about a minute for cityemployed announcers to read the names over cityowned radio and television stations. But it was a mighty misuse of government power.

title: Vague U.S. Statement Casts Doubt on Ability to Monitor Nuclear Blasts
description: The ambiguous language used by the United States Government last night in its statement that South Africa might have set off an atomic bomb raised some disquieting questions about the reliability of America's monitoring systems.

title: 26 Food Establishments Named Health Violators
description: The New York City Department of Health yesterday released the names of 26 food establishments that it said had violated the health code.

title: At the Movies
description: THE Marriage of Maria Braun is the 13th of Rainer Werner Fassbinder's films since 1969 in which Hanna Schygulla has appeared. An association of this duration and intensity, which is infrequent in the film world today, can be a source of problems as well as satisfactions, Miss Schygulla was saying over lunch the other day.

title: CARTER SEEKING RISE IN MILITARY OUTLAY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  The Carter Administration, attempting to offset Senate pressure for increased military spending, is in the last stages of preparing a budget request that would call for rise of about $20 billion for the Defense Department in the next fiscal year, Government officials said today.

title: Dance: Senta Driver, A Wit in Brooklyn
description: THE pitterpatter of notsotiny feet resounded through the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Lepercq Space on Wednesday night as four dancers in Senta Driver's company created their own rhythms and accompaniment in Primer one of two premieres on an offbeat program that runs through Sunday afternoon.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Heeeeere's Johnny. Johnny Carson, the National Broadcasting Company's $3 millionayear entertainer and host of The Tonight Show, showed again this week that he was still interested in different business investments and not resting on his salary alone.

title: N.F.L. Leaders; AMERICAN CONFERENCE RUSHING; PASSING (Based on a minimum of 96 attempts ); RECEIVING; TOUCHDOWNS; KICKING; NATIONAL CONFERENCE RUSHING; PASSING (Based on a minimum of 96 attempts); RECEIVING; TOUCHDOWNS; KICKING
description: Standing based on percentage of completions, percentage of touchdowns, percentage of interceptions and average gain per attempt.

title: Associated Press
description: In Bilbao, Spain, a woman walks past posters in Basque asking for amnesty for 11 women who are facing trial for abortion. The prosecution is demanding prison terms ranging from 5 to 60 years.

title: Books: Lionel Trilling Encores
description: ONE tends to think of the late Lionel Trilling as a master of large views, a man who looked out upon literary and moral landscapes, a formulator of inspired generalizations. His view of things strikes us as aerial, spacious, cartography of culture.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: IT seems a long time ago  can be 10 years?  that I first heard about a publisher's scheme to give Jack Richardson a stake to gamble with and send him off to the casinos of the world, in exchange for his writing a book about his experience.

title: Still Winter in Prague
description: The Prague trials are an effrontery, even by the socialist standards that the Czech Government purports to uphold. The conviction of six human rights defenders on charges of subversion further stains an already inglorious reputation.

title: Beaths
description: HARDI NGCharles B. Age 80. On Oc tuber 25, 1979, of 157 Ridge Rd. Rumson, N.J. Father of Joan H King and Robert S. 0. Brother a Catharine Harding Taller and Lau ra Harding. Grandfather of seven Funeral services on Monday, Octo bar 29, at 3 p.m. at St. George's bh the River, Rumson, N.J. In lieu flowers, contributions may be sent to a state chapter of the Arthritis Foundation, The New York Botanical Garden, or the Frick Collection. Memorial services will be held in New York City at a date and place to be announced.

title: Raiders Win
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 25 (UPI)Booker Russell gained only three yards rushing on three carries tonight but scored three touchdowns in the process, and Ira Matthews ran a kickoff back 104 yards for another score. leading the Oakland Raiders to a 4522 National Football League victory over San Diego despite a record passing performance by the Charger quarterback, Dan Fouts.

title: Wadkins Leads by Shot
description: CHIBA, Japan, Oct. 25 (AP) Lanny Wadkins, winner of this year's Los Angeles open, fired a sixunderpar 66 for a onestroke firstround lead in the $130,000 Bridgestone golf tournament today.

title: Documents Made Public in Case Of Infiltration by Scientologists
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP)  Documents made public today say that the Church of Scientology planted spies at the Justice Department and the Internal Revenue Service and bugged an I.R.S. meeting at which the church's tax exemption was under discussion.

title: 6 Nations Are Known To Have Made ATests
description: Since the United States first exploded an atomic bomb during World War II, five other nations are known to have detonated nuclear devices  the Soviet Union, Britain, France, China and India. Two other countries, Israel and Pakistan, are believed to possess nuclearweapons capability, and many other nations are said to be on the threshhold of acquiring atomic weapons.

title: Emigr Violinist at Carnegie Hall
description: Early in the afternoon a couple of days ago, the violinist Albert Markov was a few minutes late for an interview across the street from Carnegie Hall, where posters were up announcing his Sunday night recital. He arrived full of apologies delivered fluently in lightly accented English. How had the Ukrainianborn Soviet migr gained a command of the language so swiftly? Well, he said, I taught at Marines College for three years, and I had good English lessons working with the students.

title: COMMODITIES Gold and Silver Down; Corn Futures Off Sharply
description: Gold and silver futures fell in quiet trading yesterday while corn futures dropped sharply under the weight of record harvest.

title: World News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 25 (AP)The police turned back 500 students demonstrating for democracy today as they tried to march out of the Kyemyung University campus in the city of Taegu.

title: The Pop Life
description: RICK JAMES says he did his first two albums, Come Get It and Bustin Out of L Seven, as experiments, trying out a lot of different things because I had finally managed to get through the door. As experiments. they were pretty successful  the first album was certified platinum, the second double platinum, making Mr. James one of the strongest sellers in black popular music.

title: Ozark to Resume Flights Soon
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 25 (UPI)  Ozark Air Lines, shut down for six weeks by a flight attendants strike that ended this week, says that it will probably resume operations in November. No exact determination on a startup aate has been made at this time, Don Morrison, an Ozark spokesman, said yesterday. It is expected that air service will resume sometime after Nov. 1.

title: U.S. MAY WITHDRAW 1,000 NATO WEAPONS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  The Carter Administration is seeking approval from Western allies for a proposal to withdraw up to 1,000 oldgeneration nuclear weapons now deployed in Western Europe, officials here said tonight.

title: Connally Speech on Israel: A Move for the Limelight
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  There is an old story about a mule trainer who, in explaining his art, said that the first thing to do was to hit the mule across the head with a 2bv4 to get his attention.

title: Strike Set at Air France
description: PARIS, Oct. 25 (UPI)  Union officials said today that Air France ground and flying personnel will stage a 29hour strike Nov. 8 to back demands for higher wages.

title: Concert: New Work By Earlikim
description: IT was a somewhat unusual program that Zubin Mehta put together for his New York Philharmonic concert last night. He conducted a Haydn symphony. Then Itzhak Perlman played a violin concerto. Mr. Mehta conducted another Haydn symphony. Then Mr. Perlman played another violin concerto.

title: Fights and Looting RoCk Salvador
description: SAN SALVADOR, Friday, Oct. 26 (AP)  Mobs looted several department stores today after a day of rockthrowing and fist fights between opponents and supporters of the new Government.

title: 300 Filipino Reds Reported Held
description: MANILA, Oct. 25 (Reuters)  Military authorities today announced the surrender of 300 Communist guerrillas and sympathizers on the central island of Samar and said troops killed two Communists in a clash on Panay Island.

title: SCM President Indicates Victory in Proxy Battle
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 25  The president of the SCM Corporation, a company fighting for its life against a dissident group that seeks to sell off its nearly $1 billion in assets, asserted here today that management had proxies representing a majority of shareholder votes. He thus indicated that it had won its battle.

title: In Saudi Arabth, Stability- Rests on Loyalty to Saud Family
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  A few months ago, when the United States Central Intelligence Agency leaked reports about split in the royal family of Saudi Arabia, one Western diplomat here raised the issue.with a member of the royal family. He received a very curt, and very pointed, answer.

title: Save More, Spend Less
description: Americans now save a smaller portion of their income than at any time since the outbreak of the Korean War. According to estimates of the gross national product for the third quarter, that portion is now a mere 4.1 percent.

title: Dip Forecast for Building Value
description: The value of construction contracts in 1980 will decline by 8 percent from this year although dollar volume will be up by 2 percent because of inflation, George A. Christie, chief economist of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company, told the annual Building Products Executives Conference in Washington yesterday McGrawBill's F.W. Dodge division forecast that construction contracts in 1980 will amount to $169.5 billion compared with this year's anticipated total of $185.5 billion.

title: Chinese Court Dooms Manager In $380,000 Embezzlement Case
description: PEKING, Oct. 25 (UPI)  The manager of a coal distributing station in north China has been sentenced to death for embezzling the equivalent of $380,513, the Communist Party newspaper People's Daily said today. It said she had embezzled the money over a sevenyear period.

title: Thrift Units Pursue Eurodollars
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25  The nation's thrift institutions, inspired by savings and loans associations in California, are looking eagerly to the Eurodollar market as a new source of badly needed funds.

title: Friendship Binds Todd, Robinson
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.1., Oct. 25  Richard Todd and Matt Robinson knew that their friendship would be tested this season, when one of them would emerge as the Jets regular quarterback. And Todd disclosed today that the pair had made a pact that they never would lose sight of the fact they were friends.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Braths

title: Private Natural Gas Wells Yield Saving to Western New Yorkers
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 25 With its annual heating bill for natural gas now at $10,000, Mother of Divine Grace Roman Catholic Church in suburban Cheektowaga recently decided to dig for its own supply, joining a growing number of institutions and small businesses in western New York seeking to cut fuel costs.

title: A Top South African Aide Denies Knowledge of Nuclear Explosion
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Friday, Oct. 26 (Reuters)  Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha, in response to a State Department announcement in Washington, today denied all knowledge of South Africa's having conducted any nuclear test.

title: Sindona Returns To Hotel Rooms After Being Held
description: Michele Sindona, the Italian financier, was permitted to return to his apartment in the Pierre Hotel yesterday after his bail had been temporarily revoked and he had been incarcerated for four hours by a Federal judge.

title: TV Weekend The Making of a Dance
description: THE AVIARY is a dance created by Alwin Nikolais during a fiveweek residency of the choreographer and his company at the University of Wisconsin. It is also the title of a film that can be seen at 11 tonight on Channel 13.

title: Phillips, Getty Nets Up
description: As sharply higher earning reports continued to be released by major oil companies, the Phillips Petroleum Company said yesterday that it had 62.5 percent aftertax profit increase in the third quarter, partly a result of higher oil prices. Getty Oil reported an 81.2 percent Jump in profits for the third period.

title: Law and Order at Issue on S.I.
description: Four years ago, the Conservative Party on Staten Island gave its nomination to Thomas R. Sullivan, the Demoicratic candidate for District Attorney. He !won easily.
