title: President of Arizona State Launches Football Inquiry
description: TEMPE, Ariz., Oct. 25 (UPI)  Arizona State University's president, Dr. John Schwada, acting in the wake of the dismissal of Coach Frank Kush, today asked the National Collegiate Athletic Association to investigate the school's football program in an attempt to bring to light all potential violations

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Federal Reserve said it had made a $3.7 billion error in calculating the basic money supply for the first two weeks of October. The mistake resulted from a reporting mistake by a money center bank, a spokesman for the New York Fed said, but he declined to identify the bank. Money market dealers were skeptical of the explanation, and bankers were angry. The Fed also announced that the M1 had dropped $700 million in the week ended Oct. 17. [Page A1.]

title: About Real Estate
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 25  The old Carroll castle on a hill in Tarrytown is visible for miles in all directions, arousing the curiosity of outlanders speeding along the New York Thruway and neighboring highways. As the locals Know, casue was ouutoy Howard Carroll, the son of a Civil War general, between 1900 and 1910. It was used as a school in the 1930's, and it was bought in 1941 by Mr. and Mrs. Emerson W. Axe as their home and place of business.

title: Sports Today
description: Nets vs. Atlanta Hawks, at Rutgers Athletic Center, Piscataway, N.J., 8 P.M. (Radio  WVNJ, 8 P.M.)

title: Times's Computer Ranks Arkansas 9th
description: Arkansas's 1719 victory over previously unbeaten Texas moved the Razorbacks into the top 10, but still left them ranked three places behind Texas, which fell from second to sixth, in this week's New York Times computer ranking of the top college football teams. Other major findings showed that North Carolina continued its strong showing, while unbeaten Houston climbed from 18th to 14th place.

title: Fiji Helps U.N. But U.N. Fails To Reciprocate
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25 What with depressed prices for coconut oil and sugar, Ram Sir Kamisese Mara, Prime Minister of Fiji, had reason for concern. His statesmanlike solution, he thought, would demon strate the will of the South Pacific island chain to be a good global citizen and would also ease the economy's strains.

title: Foreigners Add U.S. Ventures
description: Foreign companies reported 108 new manufacturing investments in the United States during this year's third quarter, according to a survey by the Conference Board. More than half of them represented the acquisition of American companies, the business research group said. This was in contrast to the first half of 1979, when most new foreign investments in this country involved construction of new facilities.

title: Villeneuve, Rohrl Victors
description: MONZA, Italy, Oct. 25 (UPI) Gilles Villeneuve, a French Canadian Formula One star, and Walter Rohrl won the seventh Tour of Italy automobile rally today driving a turbocharged Lancia Beta Monte Carlo.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Express Company has appointed Robert E. O'Connell vice presidentcorporate personnel, Europe, Middle East and Africa.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. tarn. 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES 1914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 669.1800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Randall Gould, a China Editor, 81; Ran a Paper in Shanghai Till 1949
description: MILL VALLEY, Calif., Oct. 25 (AP) Randall Gould, former publisher of The Shanghai Evening Post and Mercury and a newspaperman for 45 years, apparently killed his ailing wife in bed and then fatally shot himself, the police said.

title: United Press Interns tional
description: RED WINGS SHUT OUT SABRES: Jim Rutherford, Red Wing goalie, bracing himself to block shot by Danny Gare of Buffalo in first period last night at Detroit. Red Wings won, 40.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: ART (GR 37014)

title: Penn Central's Net Income Down
description: The Penn Central Corporation said its third quarter aftertax profits slipped 16 percent despite a 53 percent jump in revenues. The cornpany noted that profits from its three continuing operations  energy, recreation and real estate  actually exceeded the yearago totals. However, last year's total included a $5.6 million aftertax profit from the sale of a crude trunk line.

title: Flyers Set Back Rangers With 3 In 3d Period, 52
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25  The Rangers could have drafted Brian Propp. New York, choosing just ahead of Philadelphia in this year's National Hockey League draft, picked Doug Sulliman, after which the Flyers chose the 20yearold left wing. The rap on Propp was that he could not skate.

title: U.S. CENTRAL BANK ADMITS HUGE ERROR IN MONETARY FIGURE
description: The Federal Reserve Board acknowledged yesterday that it had made a huge error in calculating the basic measure of the money supply for the first two weeks of October. The mistake created additional turmoil in unsettled money markets and, according to dealers, caused large losses during the past week for some financial institutions.

title: Israeli Gasoline Price Up
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 25 (Reuters) Israel has raised the domestic price of gasoline by an average 25 percent, the second increase In the last three months, the Government said today. The price of the popular 94octane gasoline is now $3.10 a gallon, up from $2.51.

title: ANDERSON STRESSES AN ISSUES CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  In what amounted to a plea for national attention, Representative John B. Anderson, a Republican Presidential candidate, said today that the public was tired of unfulfilled promises and was looking for serious assessments of the problems facing America.

title: Landlady Asks City in Vain For Help in Buying Boilers
description: If the 70 tenants in the three apartment buildings that Grace Yee owns in Chinatown do not have heat this winter, Miss Yee said yesterday, it will be the fault of the city officials who have taken nearly a year to respond to her request for a loan to replace the building's boilers.

title: Martin Denies That He Hit Man in Hotel
description: Billy Martin, the fiery Yankee manager who went hunting for pheasant in South Dakota earlier this week, denied yesterday that he went looking for trouble in a Minnesota hotel bar the other night. However, Martin might have encountered enough trouble to make him the Yankees exmanager a second time.

title: Automation Fails, Delaying New York Mail
description: The delivery of several million pieces of mail in the New York metropolitan area has been delayed for at least two days by the breakdown of a conveyor belt at the newly renovated Morgan Station in midtown Manhattan. Outgoing mail has not been affected.

title: Scotto's Lawyers Call Pier Officials to Stand to Rebut Extortion Charges
description: Defense lawyers presented officials of three waterfront companies yesterday to testify that Anthony M. Scotto and other representatives of the International Longshoremen's Association had tried to resolve industry problems without asking for payoffs.

title: New Face: Crissy Wilzak 40's Radio Hour Thrush
description: SHE is on every moment of the two hours and 49 minutes of The 1940's Radio Hour shimmying and shaking and bouncing a leg; straightening her stocking seams; chewing and popping her gum and her big green eyes; putting on her lipstick, thick and perfect; dancing by herself in a corner or winking and twinkling at a member of the audience.

title: Publishing: Mumford Puts Mumford in Perspective
description: LEWIS MUMFORD, who celebrated his 84th birthday Oct. 19, and whose writings on architecture, literature and urban culture are read all over the world, has signed with Harper & Row for an autobiography, to be published in the fall of 1981.

title: Huey Long's Still Alive
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  This city, the state capital, is given to deliberate recall of the past. The city's leading daily, The Morning Advocate, sells posters of the extra edition published when Senator Huey Long was assassinated in the Capitol building on Sept. 8, 1935. The bullet holes in the wall, from the volley of fire returned upon Long's assassin by his bodyguards, still remain as a disturbing memory of Long's assassination, of the populist legacy thus ended, and of the populist legacy thus begun.

title: George Gould Berry, 76; A World War II General
description: Brig. General George Gould Berry, former chief of staff of the New York National Guard, died Sunday at his home in Manhasset, L.I. He was 76 years old.

title: Is New Mailer Book Fiction, in Fact?
description: Fiction or nonfiction?

title: Hasidic Rabbi Shot Dead On Crown Heights Street
description: A 68yearold Hasidic rabbi on his way to a synagogue was shot to death yesterday morning in the racially troubled. Crown Heights section of Brooklyn. Hours later, more than a thousand. Hasidic Jews marched through the area in a funeral procession. Witnesses said the rabbi had been killed by a black man The police said the rabbi, David Okunov, who recently emigrated from the Soviet Union, was shot once in the head at about 7 A.M. in front of 808 Montgomery Street. The rabbi, who lived at 656 Crown Street, was on his way to services at the Congregation Anash Synagogue, 770 Montgomery Street.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports; HOPIN FOOD STORES (O); INTERLAKE (N); INTERPUBLIC GRP OF COS (N); JOHNSON & JOHNSON (N); KENNECOTT COPPER (N); KEYSTONE CONSOL. INDUS. (N); KNUDSEN (O); KYSOR INDUSTRIAL (N); LIBERTY CORP. (N); LIGGETT & PLATT (N); LINDAL CEDAR HOMES (O); LOUISIANA LAND OFFSHRE (O); MANHATTAN LIFE (N); MAPCO (N); MARK CONTROLS (N); MCDONALD'S (N); PENN CENTRAL (N); PHILLIPS PETROLEUM (N); PRESTON TRUCKING (O); PRIME MOTOR INNS (A); PUREX INDUS (N); QUAKER STATE OIL(N); RAPIDATA (O); RAMADA INNS (N); READING & BATES (N); RELIANCE GROUP (N); REVLON (N); RLC (N); ROCKOWER BROS. (N); ROCOR INTL (A); RUSSELL STOVER CANDIES (O); SCHLUMBERGER (N); SHELL OIL(N); SIGNODE (N); SINGER (N); SPECTOR INDUS (A); SQUIBB (N); Profits Scoreboard
description: For periods as shawn.( N) indi cafes stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Of Dollars And Rubles
description: MEDFORD, Mass.  Central Intelligence Agency documents of the last eight years indicate that the Soviet Union has been outspending America on defense annually. If the C.I.A.'s data are accurate, they would constitute important evidence for the debates over SALT II and the American defense budget. But I think that they are not.

title: Party Afloat Has a Toy Boat Theme
description: This is obviously not going to be your usual rawvegetablesanddomesticwinepublication party, a longgowned woman said to her escort Wednesday evening as they boarded The Highlander, a 116footlong ship docked in the 79th Street boat basin.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. on elections to fill vacancies in principal U.N. bodies Political and Security Committee10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Home Mortgages Proposed With Rate Adjustment Every Five Years
description: The New York State Banking Department has proposed a revision in its regulations that would permit both savings banks and savings and loan institutions to offer a new type of home mortgage whose interest rates could be reviewed and adjusted to prevailing market levels every five years.

title: Rosalynn Carter's Jet Grounded After It Is Broken Into in Boston
description: PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 25 (UPI) small jet airplane that was to carry Rosalynn Carter on a campaign swing of New Hampshire today was broken into last night at Logan International Airport in Boston, Mrs. Carter's press secretary disclosed.

title: Broadway
description: F RANKENSTEIN is to open at the Palace Theater on March 13. This is the play that was done in St. Louis last spring, bought by Joseph Kipness immediately after that and then assiduously disassociated from the notion that it was camp, comedy or a pale imitation of the Boris Karloff movie. The play by Victor Gialanella Frankenstein to play the Palace. will star Keith Jochim, who played the monster (herein called the Creature) in St. Louis, and will be directed by Torn Moore. Mr. Moore is now directing The Little Foxes for the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco, while on Broadway in seasons past he has done Grease, Over Here and Once in a Lifetime. He has range.

title: The New York Times /Teresa Zabala
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 25 President Carter told hundreds of applauding Democrats tonight that you are my partners and called on New Jersey residents to vote for a Democratic State Assembly on Election Day next month.

title: Students in Carter's Home County Continue Boycott of Public Schools
description: AMERICUS, Ga., Oct. 25  Parents of public school students in President Carter's home county kept their children at home today for the 12th consecutive school day in protest of what they say is the school board's continued inaction on demands for highquality facilities and curriculums.

title: Police Say Hypnosis Test Prompted School Melee
description: MIAMI, Oct. 25 (AP)  Students and teachers at a military school here went berserk today after a hypnosis demonstration in a science class, the police said.

title: Morton E. Yohalem, 75, a Lawyer And ExAide at 2 U.S. Agencies
description: Morton E. Yohalem, a New York lawyer who held several Government positions, died Wednesday at the George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 75 years old.

title: Market Place
description: WHILE the Flintkote Company has approved a merger bid from the LouisianaPacific Corporation, it is still negotiating, however reluctantly, with Genstar Ltd., the Canadian company that bought 21.5 percent of Flintkote's shares in the summer of 1978 and got management thinking about a takeover in the first place.

title: Schultze Gloomy on Inflation Outlook
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 Charles L. Schultze, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said today that the underlying rate of inflation in this country had risen to 8 or 9 percent a year and that it was unlikely to be slowed soon to 6 or 7 percent.

title: Three New Boutiques Offering Classic, Affordable Clothes
description: Anyone who shops the boutique circuit knows that every time you turn your back, another one springs up somewhere. If you're a true aficionado, you'll poke your head into every new one you come across. If it passes muster  that is, pleases both your tasnion image and your pocketbook  you'll add it to your shopping list.

title: U.S. Sale of Gold Set for Thursday
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP)The United States will sell on Thursday 1.25 million ounces of gold, more than it has at any auction since April, the Treasury Department said today.

title: WASHINGTON Leaders And Followers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  The popular complaint in the United States these days seems to be that we have no outstanding leaders, but a more serious problem may be that we have more leaders than followers.

title: Braths
description: MOSKOWITZArthur. It is with profound sorrow that we note the passing of Arthur Moskowitz, a devoted supporter and long time friend of North Shore University Hospital.

title: Soviet Arms Pact Gets the Support Of Senator Byrd
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  The Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, endorsed the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union today and said he had obtained a written reassurance from President Carter that the United States would proceed with the MX mobile intercontinental missile.

title: McCartney Squelches Rumors of a Beatles Reunion
description: For those who've been following the speculation about the Beatles coming together for a benefit concert on behalf of Indochinese refugees, Paul McCartney's advice is to forget it.

title: Musical Instruments as Crafts
description: Twangs, moans,.bellows and bongs are among the sounds emanating from A Celebration of Musical Instruments and Their Makers at the American Craft Museum, 44 West 53d Street, through Dec. 30. The unconventionally orchestrated event combines a twopart exhibition  spontaneous demonstrations of how some of the instruments are played and performances by some of the makers.

title: The Region
description: FORT LEE, N.J.  A tanker truck hauling 4,000 gallons of toxic, flammable chemicals became uncoupled and skidded for about 150 feet on an approach to the George Washington Bridge before dawn yesterday.

title: News Summary
description: Signs of a lowyield nuclear blast that may have occurred last month in a region around South Africa have been de. tected, the United States said. Administration officials said that efforts were being pressed to determine if South Africa had secretly joined the countries that have detonated atomic devices. A South African Cabinet minister denied any knowledge of such an explosion. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Advertising
description: IF a magazine publisher is to be successful, he or she must be able to gauge the public's desires accurately.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Money Supply's Dip Lifts Bonds
description: Bond prices rallied late yesterday in response to the Federal Reserve Board announcement that the nation's basic money supply fell by $700 million during the latest reporting week. The fixedincome market also benefited from a revision in recent money supply figures.

title: Guatemala Kidnappers Given Ad
description: An advertisement appearing on pages A14 and A15 of today's editions of The New York Times that extols leftwing rebellions in Asia, Africa and Latin America was placed in accordance with demands by kidnappers holding the 27yearold son of a wealthy cotton grower in Guatemala who is a distant relative of the President, Gen. Romeo Lucas Garcia.

title: Austin Igleheart Dies
description: Austin S. Igleheart, director emeritus and retired chairman of the board of General Foods Corporation, died Wednesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn., after a long illness. He would have been 90 years old yesterday.

title: Senate Finance Unit Backs Oil Tax Far Below Level of House Version
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 25  The Senate Finance Committee completed action today on its version of President Carter's plan to tax windfall oil company profits. But the legislation provides less than half the amount that would be raised by House bill passed last summer, and the President promptly urged stronger action.

title: Shah's Cancer Is Diagnosed And Cure Potential Exists
description: Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, the deposed Shah of Iran, has advanced lymph node cancer of a different and more aggressive type than the one for which he was first treated six years ago, his doctors said at a news conference at New York HospitalCornell Medical Center here yesterday.

title: Stocks Move Down In Slower Trading
description: The stock market finished moderately lower yesterday in slower trading, with some of the special situation and oil issues posting the biggest price moves.

title: JOHN J. COX
description: John J. Cox, controller for J. Walter Thompson Company, the advertising agency, died yesterday of a heart attack in Chicago while on a business trip. Mr. Cox, who lived in Ardsley, N.Y., was 46 years old.

title: Giant Drill Distracted By a Visitor
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 25  Billy Taylor ran a sideline pattern, and continued right on running until he reached the gate of the Giants practice field today. He was looking not for a pass, but for the President of the United States.

title: The Equal Pay Issue: Focusing on Comparable Worth
description: It has been more than 15 years since Congress declared it illegal to discriminate against women by paying them lower wages than men because of their gender.

title: Dance Notebook What Can a Designer Do With a Balanchine?
description: WHEN the New York City Ballet visited London last month, British critics chided it for its settings and costumes. They had a mint. Although the company is choreographically and musically brilliant, it can be scenically undistinguished. Yet it is hard to suggest just how this state of affairs might be remedied because the company presents designers with extraordinary problems.

title: Soviet Warns West Europeans Not to Deploy U.S. Nuclear Missiles
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 25  The Soviet Union warned West European countries today that it would take appropriate measures in response to any decision by the Atlantic alliance to deploy new mediumrange American nuclear missiles. The United States wants its allies to take this decision by December.

title: Nursing Home Case
description: Solomon Heisler, an operator of three nursing homes on Staten Island, was indicted by a Richmond County grand jury on charges of stealing $35,000 in state Medicaid funds.

title: U.S. Moves to Ease Squeeze On Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP)  In an effort to ease a nationwide shortage of mortgage loan money, the Carter Administration moved today to make millions of dollars available to savings and loan associations for home loans.

title: Habib's U.S. Peace Visit Leaves Lebanese Skeptical
description: BEIRUT, Oct. 25  Philip C. Habib, Washington's special envoy for the conflict in southern Lebanon, concluded factfinding visit here today amid an atmosphere of skepticism toward peacemaking efforts.

title: City Opera: Mozart's La Clemenza di Tito
description: IT does seem odd, considering that its composer was Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, that La Clemenza di Tito should have had to wait 188 years for a major production in Manhattan. However, thanks to the New York City Opera and the persistence of its former general director, Julius Rudel, that particular gap in the repertory is now closed. Tito, a notoriously problematical work but one crammed with splendid music, appeared last night in a production that accepted the work on its own historical terms. Honor to all involved for that.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Al earmines is at it again. The irrepressible composer and minister at Judson Memorial Church has set Gertrude Stein's Dr. Faustus Lights the Lights to music, thus turning it into an opera, which openS tonight at 8 at the church, 55 Washington Square South.

title: Racing at Ascot South
description: Twenty maiden fillies lined up for the first race, a dash of 1,200 meters (about six furlongs) down a green straightaway from a chute up beyond the clubhouse turn. That is, it would be the clubhouse turn in America, but this was the Vaal Racing Club in the Orange Free State of South Africa, where the horses run clockwise.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE problem of restraining the power of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries urgently demands a solution. Instead of growing feeble with time and breaking down, as some treemarket economists had predicted, the oil cartel appears to have learned how to exploit its monopolyexporting position for all it is worth. Instead of waiting for accidents, such as the ArabIsraeli war the Iranian Revolution, to disrupt supply and put intense pressure on the price of oil, nation after nation in OPEC has learned to be careful to restrain supply to keep prices and earnings rising.

title: Profits Fall 95% at G.M., 65% at Ford
description: DETROIT, Oct. 25  The General Motors Corporation, suffering from declining sales and production, reported yesterday that its net income plunged 95.9 percent in this year's third quarter. Earnings of the world's biggest auto maker wereat their lowest level since a gasoline shortage first disrupted the car industry in 1974. G.M.'s sales in the latest quarter slipped 2 percent.

title: Chevron Cutting Gas Prices 3
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25  The Standard Oil Company of California said today that it was reducing the wholesale price of gasoline from 70 cents to 67 cents a gallon, effective immediately.

title: Dr. Martha Southard Carpenter, Radiology Professor, Dies at 57
description: Dr. Martha Ellen Southard Carpenter, professor of radiology at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia, died Sunday. She was 57 years old and resident of Cherry Hill, N.J.

title: A Guitar Quartet From Buffalo
description: Guitar quartets are as scarce as lefthanded violinists, and so it is news that one has come in from Buffalo to give a concert in Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night at 8:30.

title: Bridge:
description: New York has a distinguished collection of veteran players who have virtually or completely retired from active tournament play but make appearances on social occasions when the strain is at a minimum and the pleasure is at a maximum.

title: L.I. Congressman Persuades State To Add Two New Commuter Trains
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  A Long Island Congressman won agreement today from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to add two commuter trains, using his power as a key figure in New York City's request to divert money intended for highway repair and apply it to mass transit.

title: 13 Years Later, Battery Park City's an Empty Dream
description: With Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller at the head, a troop of state officials 13 years ago proudly unveiled one of their most ambitious redevelopment projects yet a futuristic new town of office towers, shops and apartment buildings to be built along the Hudson River in lower Manhattan. They named it Battery Park City. and they said it would fuel a downtowit economic boom.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: DORIC (Home). Left Bermuda Oct. 25; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: 7 WOMEN ATHLETES BANNED FOR DRUGS
description: Seven East European women track and field athletes, including the year's three fastest 1,500meter runners, have been banned from international competition until further notice for failing drug tests during meets last summer, the International Amateur Athletic Federation announced in London yesterday.

title: Cambodia Aid: Is Carter Late?; Officials Say He Waited For Assurances by U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  Although President Carter has now pledged up to $70 million to feed starving Cambodians, debate continues on why he did not act earlier. Also debated is why his original News Analysis commitment, announced last week, was only $7 million to help cope with a problem that he described yesterday as a tragedy of genocidal nmnortions.

title: Woman Killed in Hallway Dispute
description: A 40yearold woman was shot and killed after an argument in the hallway of her apartment building on the Upper East Side Wednesday night, the police reported. The woman, identified as Martha Rivera, was arguing with someone in the hallway, according to neighbors, who called the police after hearing gunfire.

title: Carter and 3 Senators Ask Cambodia to Admit Aid Trucks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  President Carter joined three Senators just back from Cambodia today in appealing to the Vietnamesesupported Government there to permit a land bridge of trucks, operated by international relief agencies, to carry food from Thailand to millions of starving Cambodians.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday. Oct. 26,1979

title: Carter Gives Byrd Vow on MX and Cruise Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  In promising to proceed with the MX missile and with cruise missiles suitable for use in Europe, President Carter has made clear to Senator Robert C. Byrd that he means I fullscale deolovment of the weanons.

title: Indiana Standard Stock
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (Reuters)  The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) today said it would buy up to 5.1 million of its shares from time to time on the open market. It added that the shares would be bought over the next 12 to 18 months and would be held as treasury stock.

title: The New York Times/JIm Cummins
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Oct. 26  Rich Kelley, the New Jersey Nets' 7foot center, should have been hitting his head on the rafters with joy. Instead, he sat dejectedly in front of his locker, because despite his efforts the Nets had lost, 9490, to the Atlanta Hawks tonight.

title: Carey, on Stand, Says That Scotto Is Trustworthy Tells How the Defendant Helped His Campaign
description: Governor Carey brought the testimony of prominent character witnesses to a climax yesterday by praising Anthony M. Scotto as a labor leader who acted on his conscience for what is right and not what is popular.

title: West Side Success Story of a Restaurant and a Neighborhood
description: To the surprise of bankers and the relief of its backers, West Side Storey is a West Side success story. Since its doors opened on Labor Day weekend, the restaurant-bakery-delicatessen at 95th Street and Columbus Avenue has been a neighborhood hit.

title: Bride:
description: Themes in Deals Are Rare, And Accidental Ones Rarer

title: Slayer Surrenders to Police
description: A 53-year-old Harlem man stabbed his former girlfriend to death with a kitchen knife late Thursday and then surrendered, according to the police. The woman, identified as Eva Scott, 34 years

title: Dow Up Moderately In Light Turnover
description: The stock market registered only a modest gain yesterday in light trading despite some encouraging news about the nation's money supply figures.

title: Today's Football at a Glance
description: Comment

title: A Family With Its Own Kind of Price Index
description: BAYVILLE, L.I. Oct. 26  Doreen and Frederick Stallone measure inflation by listing what they and their two young children now do without, and they note that some former necessities, such as life insurance, have become questionable luxuries.

title: About New York
description: A Chat With a Cigar Encyclopedist

title: Harry Sinclair Drago, 91, Writer
description: Harry Sinclair Drago, a writer of westerns as well as a historian of the Old West, died in White Plains Thursday night. He was 91 years old.

title: New York: Capistrano Of the Provinces
description: I have a theory that moving to New York City from the hinterlands has something to do with a genetic imperative. Certain individuals born in small towns all across the country lead apparently ordinary lives until a latent urge clicks on like a growth hormone released by the pituitary. They get restless and ambitious, and nothing will suffice except to pack up and head . for the Big Time. These gypsies de- scend on New York like salmon horn- ing upstream, like swallows arriving at Capistrano.

title: William Schwartz Weds Miss Straus
description: Melinda Straus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Hollister Straus of New York, was married yesterday to William Frederick Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. William Schwartz of Ocala, Fla. Canon William J. Chase, Episcopal chaplain at Roosevelt Hospital. performed the ceremony in New

title: BASQUE RULE GAINS IN SPANISH ELECTION
description: MADRID, Oct. 26  Advocates of a. limited autonomy statute for the violenceridden Basque region appear to have won a fairly significant victory by getting 60 percent of an electorate of 1.5 million to turn out in rainy weather yesterday. The respectable turnout was seen as a reverse for separatist supporters of the terrorist organization E.T.A., which had urged abstention.

title: San Salvador Leftists Who Are Holding 300 Are Firm in Demands
description: SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 26 (AP)  Leftists holding 300 hostages in two Government buildings remained steadfast today in their demands during negotiations with the country's new civilianmilitary iunta.

title: Rules Proposed On Daisy Chains
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) The Energy Department's Economic Regulartory Administration proposed today to change its rules in order to prevent daisy chains of oil sales, in order to make it more difficult to hide overcharges through transactions designed primarily to increase the price of the crude oil. The proposal faces long administrative procedure.

title: Associated Press
description: CINCINNATI SCHOOLS CLOSE AS TEACHERS DEMONSTRATE: Teachers marched through downtown Cincinnati yesterday to protest against low wages and a plan to close the schools for three weeks in November because of a $7.7 million budget deficit. Teachers,at the University of Cincinnati struck the school for the second day In their demand for higher wages.

title: Sketch of Park's Suspected Assailant in Seoul
description: Reported to have shot President Park Chung Hee to death yesterday.  Appointed head of South Korean Central Intelligence Agency in 1976 atter top K.C.I.A. officer in Washington defected during investigation of Korean Influence scandal. ... Was longtime confidant and friend of President Park, who was in his class at Korean Military Academy ... Rose to rank of lieutenant general. ... Onetime commander of army security, highly sensitive position. ... Served previously as deputy director of the K.C.I.A. ... Believed to have served in Korean Embassy in Washington. ... Said to be gentle in dealing with people ... Brought back to K.C.I.A. after disclosures of Seoul's effort to influence American Congress had apparently compromised former director.

title: Hull Will Rejoin Winnipe
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Oct. 26 (UPI)  Bobby Hull, the only player besides Gordie Howe to score more than 1,000 goals in his pro career, has ended his retirement and will rejoin Winnipeg as an active player next week. John Ferguson. the Jets ueneral manauer said today.

title: Mayor's Arts Awards To Be Presented Nov. 5
description: The actor James Earl Jones, the dancer Suzanne Farrell, the singer Mabel Mercer, the actordirector John Houseman, the caricaturist Al Hirschfeld and the late humorist S.J. Perelman are among recipients of the Mayor's Awards of Honor for Arts and

title: Louisiana Voting Today in a Costly Race for Governor
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 26  Louisiana voters will go to the polls tomorrow in the first stage of what may be the most expensive nonPresidential election in American history, a $20 million extravaganza that is keeping advertisements for car dealers and deodorants off the television stations.

title: Opera: City Company Presents Mozart's Tito
description: It does seem odd, considering that its composer was Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, that La Clemenza di Tito should have had to wait 188 years for a major production in Manhattan. However, thanks to the New York City Opera and the persistence of its former general director, Julius Rudel, that particular gap in the repertory is now closed. Tito, a notoriously problematical work but one crammed with splendid music, appeared Thursday night in a production that accepted the work on its own historical terms. Honor to all involved for that.

title: Letters
description: Letter: On Coop City's Finances The Hard Search for a Total Solution

title: Philadelphia Exchange
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28  The Philadelphia Stock Exchange announced today that it would move its trading floors and offices to a new $35 million complex here to be completed in March 1 1. The building, to be built at 19th and Market Streets, will carry the name of The Exchange and will house the trading floors of the exchange below ground level and will have viewing area in the lobby.

title: Meany Says Carter Will Address Labor Federation Parley May 15
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  President Carter will address the opening session of the biennial convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations on May 15, George Meany, the federation's president, announced today.

title: U.S. to Seek a Reversal In Nixon Tapping Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI)  The Justice Department will ask the Supreme Court to overturn a lower court's ruling that could force former President Richard M. Nixon to pay damages for approving illegal wiretapping of Americans, Ken Geller, a deputy solicitor general, said today.

title: Black Named to Head Office for Civil Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP)  Roma Stewart, a lawyer, has been chosen to head the Office for Civil Rights in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, Patricia Roberts Harris, Secretary of the deparment, announced today. She will be the first black permanent director of the office.

title: Sir Gerald Templer Is Dead at 81; Repressed Red Rebels in Malaya
description: LONDON, Oct. 26  Field Marshal Sir Gerald Templer, who directed the suppression of a Communist insurgency in Malaya, died at his home here yesterday after a short illness. He was 81 years old.

title: South African Calls Report of Nuclear Test Nonsense
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 26 The official directly responsible for South Africa's nuclear development program said today that it was complete nonsense to suggest that the nuclear explosion detected by the United States off southern Africa last month was the result of an atomic bomb test by South Africa.

title: Parisian Buys Bokassa's Homes, Offers Resale Proceeds to U.N.
description: In a daring financial and philanthropic act, a French businessman has per suaded JeanBedel Bokassa, the deposed Emperor of the Central African Repub. lic, to sell him his vast properties is France and is now offering the proceeds from their resale, estimated at $10 million to $12 million, to the United Nations Children's Fund.

title: OBSERVER The Bopco Bopper
description: The Chairman of the Big Oil Petro. leum Company, better known to an embittered humanity as Bopco, was lying on his desk weeping when I arrived for the interview.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 26 (Reuters) Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators turned out today in a show of support for Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini after increasingly pessimistic speeches by the Iranian leader on the course of his Islamic revolution.

title: PRESIDENT PARK IS SLAIN IN KOREA BY INTELLIGENCE CHIEF, SEOUL SAYS; PREMIER TAKES OVER, G.I.'S ALERTED
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Oct. 27  President Park Chung Hee, South Korea's ruler for more than 18 years, was fatally shot last night by the chief of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency at a restaurant near the presidential resi- dence, the Government announced early today. It said the death of the President was the result of an accidental argument between the agency chief and the Mr. Park's chief bodyguard.

title: Prices Up 1.1%, Spurred by Fuel And Food Costs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 With a push from a new upsurge in food prices, increased energy and housing costs drove consumer prices up by 1.1 percent in September, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said today. Over the last three months, prices have been rising at an annual rate of 13.2 percent.

title: Agency to Store Neclear Waste
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Oct. 26 (AP) The Federal Department of Energy plans to start shipping its lowlevel radioactive waste into its Nevada Test Site and other department facilities because ac cess to commercial dumps has been re stricted, officials said today.

title: The City
description: Koch Threatens Sanitation ShakeUp

title: Benefit Sale Gets Glamour Second Hand
description: If you're impressed by celebrities, you might be interested in Frank Sinatra's Britishmade suit for $100 or Liza Minnelli's sequined jacket for $50. If you care more about designer names, you might look at the threepiece challis outfit by Yves Saint Laurent for $110 or the yellow Ultrasuede jacket by Ralston for $45.

title: Spanish Court Suspends Abortion Trial in Bilbao
description: BILBAO, Spain, Oct. 26 (AP)  A threejudge court today suspended indefinitely the abortion trial of 11 women after protests by feminists across the country.

title: Citibank's Prime at 151/4% Peak
description: Citibank, the nation's second largest bank, today raised its prime lending rate to a record 151/4 percent.

title: Top Narcotics Dealer in Harlem Faces a Life Term on Guilty Plea
description: Robert Stepeney of Teaneck, N.J., considered the successor to Leroy Barnes as the top narcotics dealer in Harlem, pleaded guilty yesterday to a charge that could out him in orison for life.

title: Shah Needs to Stay in U.S. Up to a Year, Doctor Says
description: Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, the deposed Shah of Iran, who has advanced cancer of the lymph nodes, should stay in the United States for as long as a year for treatment, the chief physician at the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center said yesterday.

title: Charles B. Harding Is Dead at 80; Retired Partner in Smith Barney
description: Charles Barney Harding, former chair man of the New York Stock Exchange and a retired senior partner in the investment concern of Smith Barney, Hard: Upham & Company, died Thursday at hi: home in Rumson, N.J. He was 80 year

title: Paris Air Traffic Is Slowed
description: PARIS, Oct. 26 (UPI)) Aircontrol tower operators in the Paris area decided today to suspend takeoffs between 9 and 11 A.M. until Monday to press their demands for higher wages and better working conditions. The partial strike is delaying only departures. Landings are taking place normally, officials said.

title: Ray P. Dinsmore, 86; Pioneer of Synthetics For Use in Auto Tires
description: Ray P. Dinsmore, a former vice president and director of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, died yesterday at a nursing home in Akron, Ohio, after a long illness. He was 86 years old and lived in Akron.

title: Wrong Number Wins Tumoer Title
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 26  Wrong Number, ridden by Michele Vaillancourt of the Canadian Equestrian Team, soared over a 7-foot-3-inch fence tonight to win the puissance class, high jumping, in the internationalopen jumper division at the Washington In- terrintinnnl tinrca Chow The event, at the Capital Centre here, will end Sunday night, when the international champion is crowned. The United States Equestrian Team is leading for the title, with 33 points, followed by Canada with 31, Switzerland with 30 and Britain with 23.

title: Bomb Threat Delays Metroliner
description: MILFORD, Conn., Oct. 26 (AP) About 400 passengers aboard an Amtrak 1Vietroliner train bound for Boston were evacuated for 45 minutes here this afternoon while authorities searched for a bomb, the Milford police said. A spokes- man for Amtrak in Washington said it received an anonymous phone warning in New York that a bomb had been planted aboard the Metroliner by a Puerto Rican radical nationalist group known as the F,A.L.N. No bomb was found.

title: Education Chief Validates Controversial Nursing Test
description: ALBANY, Oct. 26  The State Education Commissioner today reversed himself and said there was no evidence that cheating had occurred in New York State on a national nursing examination given last summer. Acting only hours after a judge ordered him to do so, Com- MI.S.510ner Gordon M. Ambach said the state would move quickly to distribute the results of the test and grant licenses to those who passed it.

title: Billy, 'spindle
description: GREAT NECK, N.Y.  The day Joe Reilly died, on my mother's favorite soap opera, the Pope was in New York. So I didn't drive in to tell her that my brother had cancer.

title: Youth Rescued From Bridge
description: A 16-year-old Staten Island youth who was threatening to jump off the Brooklyn Bridge was rescued from atop the cables on the Manhattan side of the span by police from the emergency services division at about 11:15 P.M. yesterday. Officers talked to the youth for about 25 minutes before being able to grab him. He said that he had a fight with his girlfriend and that nobody loved him, said Detective Eugene Flood. The youth was taken to Bellevue Hosnital for observation.

title: Oil, Africa's Weapon
description: WASHINGTON  Almost threequarters of the light oil that the United States imports for gasoline  nearly 40 percent of our total oil imports come from Nigeria, Algeria and Libya., This African oil, known as

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: 'sULLIVANEleanor C. Beloved wife of Thanes G. O'Sullivan, mother of Marcia McOmagh and Douglas Boyd. Also survived by sister Olga C. Fennell and one brother Jules Fessel, and nine grandchildren. Catholic services held October 24. In Los Angeles at Gates, Kingsley, Gates, Price, Daniels Motivery.

title: GUERRILLAS CRITICIZE PLANS FOR RHODESIA
description: LONDON, Oct. 26  The Rhodesian guerrillas today denounced as disastrous a plan that Britain advanced earlier this week for the transition to a new, independent government in Zimbabwe Rhodesia.

title: House Votes Auriculture Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP)  The House today approved $16.7 billion for operation of the Agriculture Department in the fiscal year 1980, which began Oct. 1. The money, about $1.6 billion less than President Carter had requested, was $2.7 billion less than the appropriation last year. The House vote, 304 to 25, sent the bill to the Senate, where final action was expected next week.

title: Spirited Dean of Washington's Art Dealers
description: WASHINGTON  It was an unlikely transplant, the grafting of a refugee art lover from Vienna onto the bare branch of this city's prewar culture, but it took root. Today, the Washington art scene is flourishing, and the refugee, Franz Bader, who founded the city's first private art gallery, Franz Bader Inc., and who encouraged countless local artists with a first sale or show, is unflagging at 76.

title: Undefeated Navy Is Underdog Against Pitt
description: Navy's eightgame winning streak is the longest for the Middies since the 1959 and 60 seasons, when Joe Bellino, the little halfback who won the Heisman Trophy, led the Naval Academy to 10 straight triumphs over two seasons.

title: Memorial to Elizabeth Bishop
description: There will be a memorial tribute on Nov. 19 at the 92d Street Y to Elizabeth Bishop, the poet, who died on Oct. 6 at the age of 68. It is sponsored by the Poetry Center of the Y.

title: Patents
description: Stacy V. Jones

title: Maree Leads Villanova To CrossCountry Title
description: KINGS PARK, L.I., Oct. 26  The course was different, and the field was smaller, but Sydney Maree still won a second consecutive IC4A crosscountry title today, even after stopping for a shoe that sunned off early in the race.

title: Nuclear Aircraft Carrier Is Approved by Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP)  A $2.1 billion nuclearpowered aircraft carrier, which President Carter once described as a waste of money, won final Congressional approval today.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Modern Museum's Anniversary
description: Fifty years ago, on Nov. 8, 1929, the Museum of Modem Art opened its first exhibition, and it will observe this anniversary by displaying its permanent collection and other current exhibitions on Nov. 8. On that day the public will be admitted to the museum free.

title: New England Plant Turns Trash to Energy
description: HAMPTON, N.H., Oct. 26  You see that rise of land over there? the guide shouts, turning around in the cockpit of the sleek Italian helicopter and pointing to a rise in the terrain. It's a landfill in Amesbury. They dump garbage there, and the people are angry because, they say, the fill is contaminating the ground water supplies and making a mess out of the Merrimack River.

title: Village Skirmishes With West Point Over Retail Shops
description: HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 26 The main street of this peaceful little village stretches right to the imposing main gate of the United States Military Academy at West Point. Beyond the gate and inside the Academy grounds the village disappears from view. But in the center of the village, West Point is never out of sight or mind.

title: A
description: A 60-foot-long, 40ton subway car from New York City's famed A line to Harlem, arriving at the state museum in Albany. Car will be part of the Urban Systems exhibition in the New York Metropolitan Hall, which is to open in 1980.

title: He Ran South Korea, Down to Last Detail
description: TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 27  His enemies called him a corrupt and ruthless dictator who stifled dissent, eliminated opponents and created a police state nurtured in fear and repression. His loyalists called him a tough, pragmatic patriot who preserved his nation from Communism and wrought a national economic miracle with his iron will.

title: Prinair Asking Emergency Relief From Grounding
description: Puerto Rico International Airlines yesterday filed an emergency appeal with the Federal Government against the order grounding the airline, the world's largest commuter carrier, until it complied with a variety of safety measures.

title: 12 IRT Subway Stops Get Landmark Status
description: Twelve stations in the original IRT subway system, which is celebrating its 75th anniversary today, were designated as landmarks yesterday.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Gold Prices Off Sharply As Dollar Shows Gains
description: The price of gold ended the week yesterday with a sharp drop of $18 an ounce in London, $16.50 in Zurich and $14.50 in New York as the dollar gained in foreign and domestic currency markets.

title: Coup Brought Park Chunfi Hee to Power in 1961
description: The coup that eventually brought Park Chung Hee to power 18 years ago was carried out swiftly in the early morning hours of May 16, 1961.

title: Westchester Authorities Seek Clues in Killing of
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 26  The police in the town of Greenburgh continued their investigation of the shooting deaths of two men in their home late Wednesday night.

title: Bid to Curb Speculation Lowers Precious Metals
description: Attempts by the Government and two futures exchanges to curb speculation pushed gold and silver futures sharply lower yesterdy, while grains and livestock prices tumbled as well

title: Accountants Back Oil Company Data
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) An accounting firm told the Energy Department today that it had found no evidence that oil companies it checked were giving the Government incorrect information about petroleum supplies.

title: Notes on People
description: A G.O.P. Critic of the President Gets a Bit Carried Away

description: JAMES MITCHELL VICKERY

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1979

title: Prices Went Up 1.2% In the New York Area Last Month, U.S. Says
description: Consumer prices in the New York area soared in September to their sharpest monthly increase in five years, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. The sharp rise was prodded by steep increases in heating fuel and other housing costs.

title: Harvard Opens $250 Million Drive To Spur Undergraduate Education
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 26  Harvard University today announced a $250 million fundraising drive largely intended to finance the university's renewed emphasis on undergraduate education.

title: 8 in Scientology Church Guilty in Data Theft Plot
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP)  Federal District Judge Charles R. Richey today convicted eight members of the Church of Scientology, including the wife of the founder, of taking part in a conspiracy to steal Government documents concerning the church. A ninth defendant was convicted of misdemeanor theft As the defendants and their lawyers clustered in front of him, Judge Richey said that the evidence establishes each and every element of the crimes that resulted in the convictions. He set no date for sentencing.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: 76ers Overcome Knicks, 127116
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26  Steve Mix and Henry Bibby are survivors. Before each National Basketball Association season, it seems the two are involved either in trade talk by the Philadelphia 76ers or in moves that might indicate less playing time. But Mix and Bibby, still talking about their unhappiness, always are ready to play key roles.

title: Family Cosigns $3 Million Bond In Sindona Case
description: Michele Sindona, his wife, one of his sons, his daughter and her husband went to the Federal court building in lower Manhattan yesterday and signed a $3 million bail bond that permits the Italian financier limited freedom while awaiting trial on bank fraud charges.

title: Islanders Beat Whalers. 2 to 1
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 26  In need of a lift before tonight's game against the Hartford Whalers, the New York Islanders got together and talked about what they had not been doing. When they got on the ice at the Springfield Civic Center, all that talk amounted to nothing when they fell behind in the first period.

title: Black and Hasidic Coalition Planning a War on Crime
description: In the wake of the murder of a rabbi In the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn on Thursday, a coalition of black and Hasidic Jewish leaders of the neighborhood announced plans yesterday for a citywide war on crime. They also said they would call for a mass rally at City Hall unless Mayor Koch were more responsive to their community.

title: 2 Tito
description: There are two recordings of La Clemenza di Tito available, both featuring fine casts and both led by conductors universally admired for their interpretations of Mozart. A choice be- tween two such estimable performances is difficult, but there are some differences in approach that may tilt the balance, depending on where the listeners priorities lie.

title: Publicly Traded Funds
description: Friday, Oct. 26,1919

title: Joseph Romanello Is Dead at 51; Worked 31 Years for The Times
description: Joseph Romanello, who had been a secretary in the office of Turner Catledge when Mr. Catledge was managing editor of The New York Times, died Thursday at the Hempstead (LI.) General Hospital. Mr. Romanello, who lived in Levittown. L I.. was 51 years old.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: SHAPING UP The public is invited today to hear an address by the sculptor Isamu Noguchi. The occasion is the second meeting of the International Brancusi Society, at 1 P.M. in the faculty lounge of Fordham University at Lincoln Center, 113 West 60th Street. The guest artist will discuss his work and that of Constantin Brancusi, with whom he worked in Paris. The event is sponsored by the Rumanian Library of the Rumanian Embassy, Fordham University and the philosophy students at Scarsdale (N.Y.) High School.

title: Stage: 'smart Aleck,
description: Alexander Woollcott left nothing much behind him except a reputation. He was famous mostly for being famous, and his deepest involvement was with himself. This makes him an unlikely subject for a onecharacter play, especially one that wants CO De a comedy, and it also makes Smart Aleck a surprise. In Howard Teichmann's onecharacter play, Mr. Woollcott is not only winning, he is funny as well. Smart Aleck opened in the Basement Space of the American Place Theater Thursday night.

title: Colorful Furs of Fendi: Not for the Fainthearted
description: Even competitive furriers agree that the Italian house of Fendi is the most innovative in the world. It dyes pelts in outlandish colors, knits them, pieces them in extraordinary patterns, makes the insides of coats as interesting as the outsides. Generally it treats furs with an insouciant irreverence that scares the wits out of those who think a fur coat is an investment and should be classic and subdued.

title: PBS Is Preparing Satirical Series
description: Public television is attempting its own version of NBCTV's Saturday Night Live with a proposed series of college humor and topical satire, Goodgrief America. The pilot program is to be rand hefnre a student audience at Yale University on Nov. 13 and is expected to be aired on the Public Broadcasting Service later next month.

title: Manufacturers Hanover Concedes It Erred on Money Supply Figures
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company admitted yesterday that it had mistakenly supplied the Federal Reserve Bank of New York with erroneous data that led to major distortions in reports of the nation's money supply earlier this month.

title: Texas Coal Plan: Up in Smoke?
description: SAN ANTONIO  Two years ago, when San Antonio began switching from natural gas to coal for generating most of its electricity, the city was widely praised for helping the country decrease its dependence on oil and gas and increase its reliance on domestic coal.

title: Breath of Energy for Bronx
description: There was a pioneer spirit in the Bronx yesterday as community leaders dedicated New York City's first big windmill in more than two centuries.

title: BIG NAMES OFFERING EARLY CAMPAIGN AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP)  Cecil D. Andrus, Secretary of the Interior, has already contributed to the 1980 Jimmy Carter campaign though Mr. Carter has not formally said he will run.

title: 20th CenturyFox Up 7.1% in Quarter
description: The Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation yesterday reported that thirdquarter net income had risen 7.1 percent to $19.7 million, or $2.39 a share, from $18.4 million, or $2.26 a share, for the three months last year. Revenues, meanwhile, rose 17.8 percent to $189.6 million from $161 million.

title: Drive Is Begun To Fight Fraud In Food Stamps
description: The Commissioner of New York City's Human Resources Administration announced yesterday the creation of a Fraud Control Unit and other measures designed to curtail reportedly widespread theft and fraud in the food stamp program.

title: Equal Coaching For Equal Pay; Steve Cady
description: To tell you the truth, the unemployed coach was saying, I'd rather be called Miss Quinn than Ms. Quinn. I don't appreciate Ms. It's . . . I don't know ... it's iust not me.

title: Windfall of $2.9 Million Enables Wayne County to Pay Off 3,000
description: DETROIT, Oct. 26 (UPI)  A $2.9 million windfall today enabled Wayne County to pay 3,000 workers who got no paychecks last week, but 2,600 other county employees, including sheriff's deouties. were not naid.

title: C.A.B. to Permit Rise in Air Fares
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  The Civil Aeronautics Board, responding to the continued rise in aviation fuel costs, today authorized the domestic airlines to increase their fares up to 3.7 percent, effective Nov. 1. It is the fourth increase this year.

title: Schools Closed and Tourists Suffer In Hawaii's Public Workers
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 26  Hawaii's beauty was marred this week because nearly 8,000 bluecollar workers walked off their jobs in defiance of a court order, leaving garbage piled high at airports and in residential areas and forcing 228 public schools to close.

title: The New York Times/ Larry C. Morris
description: GOMEZ WINS SUPERBANTAMWEIGHT TITLE: As Arthur Mercante signaled end of the bout, Wilfredo Gomez headed toward corner after knocking down Nicky Perez for the third time in the fifth round of title fight. Page 14.

description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, Oct. 26 (AP)  Volkswagen said today that it was interested in acquiring the Argentinian unit of the Chrysler Corporation, the troubled United States auto makPr

title: Fire Forces 50 Students to Flee At Fairleigh Dickinson Dormitory
description: TEANECK, N.J., Oct. 26 (UPI)  A dormitory fire at the campus of Fairleigh Dickinson University here forced the evacuation of about 50 students this afternoon. it university sookesman said one studen. Vglc treated for smoke inhalation.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: 1. The woman above inspired George Bernard Shaw to write not only love letters but also a play. What was the name of this grand dame of society and the arts, and which Shaw play was it?

title: Carter Seeks E.E.C. Fiber Calm
description: BRUSSELS  To head off a potentially serious trade dispute with Western Europe, the Carter Administration is striving to prove that it is not unfairly subsidizing the United States synthetic fiber and petrochemical Industry by allowing it to buy domestic crude oil at prices below the world level, according to officlala hem

title: Johnson Returns, His Magic Intact
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 (AP)  Earvin (Magic) Johnson, returning to the Lakers after missing three games with a sprained right knee, scored 26 points tonight to lead Los Angeles to a 116104 victory over the Kansas City Kings.

title: Park's Faithful Successor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  Choi Kyu Hah, the Prime Minister of South Korea, who has taken over as President, has been known as a staunch supporter of President Park Cluing Hee since General Park took power in a military coup in 1961.

title: Lemuel S. Crosby, 86, Coauthor Of Phone Company Training Text
description: Lemuel Stephens Crosby, a former executive of American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died Tuesday at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Springs, Md. He was 86 years old.

title: Burst of Light Led to Speculation South Africa Exploded ABomb
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  On Sept. 22, an American intelligence satellite, passing over a remote expanse of ocean bounded by South Africa to the north and Antarctica to the south, detected an intense burst of light lasting less than a second. In hours. intelligence aides told President Carter that there was evidence to believe South Africa or some other power had conducted a secret test of a nuclear weapon.

title: Reggae: Bob Marley and Wailers Warm to Task
description: The theme of Bob Marley's four-evening stint (Thursday through tomorrow) at Harlem's newly reopened Apollo Theater is black survival, and Mr. Marley's own survival has been a subject of concern lately. Although he seems to have recovered fully from a shooting incident a couple of years ago in politically turbulent Ja- maica, his reggae nas sounnea ratner pallid on recent albums and his openingnight performance on Thursday was his first New York City appearance in nearly a year and a half.

title: MAXIMUM FINE ASKED IN NUCLEAR ACCIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission charged today that there were serious weaknesses in the management and technical ability of the operator of the Three Mile Island reactor and proposed fining the utility $155,000, the maximum permitted by law.

title: Superior Oil Tender
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 28 (Reuters)  The Superior Oil Company said today that it had acquired more than 90 percent of Canadian Superior Oil Ltd. and extended its tender offer to Nov. 30.

title: Ohio Bell Plans Offering
description: The Ohio Bell Telephone Company announced plans yesterday to sell up to $175 million of debt securities around Feb. 5, 1980. Proceeds from the sale will be applied toward repayment of in-

title: Hua, Warmly Greeted in Bavaria, Bids Europe Arm Against Russians
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Oct. 26 Prime Minister Hua Guofeng of China, receiving an enthusiastic welcome in conservative Bavaria, called on Western Europe today to bolster its military strength against what he suggested was Soviet expansionism.

title: Carey Joins Griffin for an Anniversary
description: Who would have dreamed that there would have come a time when ap- plause signs would blink from the stage of the Vivian Beaumont Theater, Lincoln Center's Temple of Thespis? Or that Governor Carey would thank the man who made such use of state property that would otherwise be dark?

title: Carter Panel Contends Kennedy Is Already Candidate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  The CarterMondale Presidential Committee charged today that Senator Edward M. Kennedy has been a legal candidate, for fundraising purposes, since late August, and that money contributed so far to the various draftKennedy groups should count against the Federal spending limits on a Presidential campaign.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: GROGANEugene L., Sr. On October 26, 1979. Beloved husband of Margaret (nee Hagan). Dear fattier of Mary Ellen and the late Eugene Emmett. Loving grandfather of Max Antoine. Funeral Monday, gam from the McLaughlin and Sons Colonial Home, Third Avenue at 97 Street, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:30am St. Anselm's

title: Around the Nation
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 26 (UPI) The Tennessee Valley Authority, taken to court for at least the 10th time over the Tellico Dam project, denied today that the project would violate religious rights of Cherokee Indians by flooding their sacred burial grounds.

title: EARNINGS
description: Despite the problems the McDonnell Douglas Corporation has been having with its DC10's and DC9's aircraft, the company reported a 15 percent increase in thirdquarter profits and a 31 percent rise in sales.

title: Money Market Funds
description: Funds with assets of 5300 million or more that are available to individual investors. For period ended Oct. 24,1979.

title: Yankee Job Shakier for Martin
description: Billy Martin, who stood perched on the brink of dismissal about half a dozen times before he tearfully terminated his first tenure as manager with the Yankees in 1978, teetered there again yesterday as his boss, George Steinbrenner, pondered the manager's future.

title: Thais Hear Shooting in Cambodia
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 26 (Reuters)  Heavy fighting was reported today 15 miles inside Cambodia, and Thailands Prime Minister, Gen. Kriangsak Chamanand, called on the United Nations to send an inspection team to the frontier.

title: Campbell Likesjersey, Not Its Tomato
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 24  Two giant Campbell Soup cans, water towers painted to resemble the company's red and white label, have been a landmark for decades in this workingclass city on the banks of the Delaware. Although the water towers will remain a doml- Want mature or the downtown Campbell will no longer use New Jersey tomatoes, an ingredient in Campbell products since the 19th century.

title: Delta's Net Drops 61% In Quarter
description: Delta Air Lines, based in Atlanta, said its net in the first fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30 fell 61 percent to $12.6 million, or 63 cents a share, from $32.7 million, or $1.65 a share, in the corresponding period a year ago.

title: Texaco Net Soars 211%; Hess Gains
description: Texaco Inc. reported a 211 percent increase in thirdquarter profits yesterday compared with the yearearlier level. It was the biggest percentage increase announced by any of the major integrated oil companies in their current round of profit reports.

title: Indian Leader Loses a Tribal Post
description: ROSEBUD, S.D., Oct. 26 (AP)  In an election enlivened with free buffalo meat and freeflowing wine, a national Indian leader was unseated on his own reservation today by tribal voters angered by charges of fraud and mismanagement.

title: Tomato Plea Renewed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  In an action that could lead to much higher food prices this winter, Florida tomato growers have quietly refiled an antidumping petition to restrict imports of romnprino nrntiure from Mpxicn

title: Three No. l's on the Ballot
description: Pity on New York voters who will be required on Nov. 6 to vote on two, even three items labeled Number One. There will be an Amendment One and a Proposition One throughout the state, and in Westchester County, there will also be a County Proposition One. We recommend Yes votes for the state issues and a No vote on the county proposition in Westchester.

title: School Gets Harp, but Many Strings Needed Pulling
description: The lilt of harp music is being heard at the High School of Music and Art for the first time in years because of the persistent efforts of a parent who arranged to obtain a rented instrument to replace 43-year-old harp that the school could not afford to repair.

title: Kuhn Tells Mays to Choose Casino Company or Mets
description: Willie Mays, who was inducted into the Hall of Fame three months ago, has been told by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn that he will have to disassociate himself from baseball if he goes to work for a company that owns an Atlantic City hotel gambling casino.

title: Abortive Harlem Raid Investigated By State Anticorruption Prosecutor
description: A police raid on a suspected Harlem weapons and narcotics dealer that led to a dispute between the police and the Bronx District Attorney is being investigated by New York State.

title: U.S., Israel and Egypt Agree on Palestinian Vote Role
description: LONDON, Oct. 26  Egypt, Israel and the United States agreed today that Palestinians in the West Bank and the Gaza strip could participate in the pin cess of organizing, conducting and super. visit* elections for a selfgoverning au thority in the Israelioccupied territories.

title: South Korea AT A GLANCE
description: Korea emerged as a unified kingdom in 668, but China, claiming a vague sovereignty, did not recognize its independence until late in the 19th century. Following the RussianJapanese war of 19041905, the country became a Japanese protectorate. It was formally annexed by Japan in 1910. After World War II, Soviet and American troops entered Korea, meeting roughly at the 38th parallel, to supervise the Japanese surrender. Efforts to set up a Korean government failed, and the country's division into South and North Korea ensued, with Dr. Syngman Rhee becoming the first President of the newly created Republic of Korea in 1948 when the American military Government ended.

title: The Region; Con Ed Contributior Put at $1.2 Million
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I. Oct 26  A neatly dressed gunman, posing as a customer, and two accomplices robbed a Garden City jewelry store of $250,000 worth of gems in a holdup Thursday night, the police said. The authorities said the jewelry robbery was among the biggest ever on Long Island.

title: John K. Jessup, 72, Chief Editorial Writer for Life
description: John Knox Jessup, chief editorial writer for Life magazine from 1951 until his retirement in 1969, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Wilton,

title: Bonds Stage Big Price Rally
description: The bond market staged a rousing rally yesterday to highlight a recovery in fixedincome securities after wild gyrations earlier this week produced the market's loftiest yields ever.

title: Fiorello's Gracie Mansion
description: In 1941, Fiorello H. La Guardia turned Gracie Mansion into a residence for the Mayor of New York City. His idea was to save money for the taxpayers. Now, another budget-conscious Mayor lives at the mansion, parttime. On weekends, Mayor Koch continues to live in his small bachelor apartment in Greenwich Village. Considering the fact that the Landmarks Preservation Commission is preparing a history of the mansion, under a grant administered by the New York State Division of Historic Preservation, to plan a restoration program, it is worth recalling La Guardia's style and why he made Gracie Mansion into the Mayor's house.

title: Reports Say Mets May Soon Be Sold
description: New reports circulated yesterday that the sale of the New York Mets baseball franchise was imminent. Lorinda de Roulet, chairman of the board of the Mets, when asked last night about the report, replied: I can't comment on that. Too much is being written. and it's too complicated.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1979

title: McGuire of South Carolina Will Retire After Season
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 26 (AP) The University of South Carolina trustees formally agreed to end Frank McGuire's 15year tenure as the school's head basketball coach today by paying him $400,000 and allowing him to coach a final season.

title: Kennedy, After Northeast Tour, Vows Increased Campaign Pace
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 26  Senator Edward M. Kennedy swung through the Northeast today in his unofficial bid for the Presidency and afterward said he intended to step up the pace of his campaign and would announce a decision on a 1980 race before Thanksgiving.

title: Washington Warns North Koreans It Will React Strongly
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  The United States ordered its armed forces in South Korea to a higher state of alert today and warned that it would react strongly to any external attempt to exploit the uncertain situation in the wake of the slaying of President Park Chung Hee.

title: Books of The Times Whose Dead Won?
description: Les Enfants Terribles by Jean Cocteau is a little desert of subtle suffering dotted with stiff events and cactuslike descriptions. Mae West, the American actress, has elicited praise from Paris that would give her a liberal education if she traced it all down. Atter she died, Sarah Bernhardt's peculiarly bleating voice was heard again when Marshal Petain came into power. The resemblance was remarkable.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 28,1979

title: N.&W. and Southern End Rail Merger Talks
description: The Norfolk & Western Railway Company and the Southern Railway Company said yesterday that they had broken off merger talks after nearly six months of discussions. The two carriers added that no further discussions were planned.

title: REPORT OF ABLAST OFF AFRICA IS CALLED INCONCLUSIVE BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the evidence of a nuclear explosion in the southern hemisphere was so inconclusive that it was impossible to state categorically that South Africa or any other country had actually detonated an atomic device.

title: Seoul Events May Reshape U.S. Military Stance in Asia
description: The United States Army and Air Force units in South Korea, the only American outpost on the East Asian mainland, have a military and political significance far greater than their size indicates.

title: Dance: Asians Fuse Two Styles
description: The Asian New Dance Coalition was formed a year ago with the aim, in part, of experimenting in the fusion of modern and traditional dance styles.

title: Pine Needle Praises
description: Many gardeners think that pine needles are a nuisance. I once agreed, when I lived on the Connecticut coast and mulched with seaweed. Since moving to New Hampshire, where my property is blanketed with the white pines golden residue, I've been forced to think otherwise. Now I put the needles to good use.

title: Cultivating the Printed Garden
description: IT'S full gallop time again. On my street, even the trees seem stripped for business, rattling their barebone branches in the accelerated wind. The Muzak in restaurants and elevators seems strident, perceptibly louder. The sneakered feet of summer nave been replacea in our house by a roar of Army boots and clanking galoshes. At the office, the dusty rubber plants appear to gyrate, responding, no doubt, to their keepers distress. Our staff's early autumn anticipation of new beginnings and of new projects has given way to the less exhilarating aspect of Getting Things Done.

description: ON the night of April 10, 1979, John Ziegler, president of the National Hockey League, informed me that his high command was preparing a white paper on the subject of violence on ice, and that he would inform me of its contents sometime before the summer.

description: St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in Montgomery, Ala., was the setting yesterday morning for the marriage of Daphne Wilson Dwyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Dwyer of Mont- gomery, to Thomas FitzGerald O'Brien, son of Dr. and Mrs. James A. O'Brien of Dubuque, Iowa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Laboon.

description: Dondi Chambliss returned a punt 67 yards for a firstquarter touchdown as Westfield, unbeaten in six games, defeated Nutley by 216 in Nutley.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: IN 1898, when, as any schoolboy can tell you, we fought the SpanishAmerican War, a number of other events of lasting fascination occurred. Emile Zola forced a new trial for Captain Dreyfus; the Curies isolated radium; the Bayer Co. introduced an opiate cough medicine called heroin; the first corn flakes turned rancid on grocers shelves ; Chekhov had a great success with The Seagull at the Moscow Art Theatre; and this newspaper tripled its circulation by cutting its price from three cents to one. I can go on like this indefinitely now that I possess James Trager's mammoth new historical encyclopedia.

title: U.S. College Stars Lose To Cuba in Baseball Finale
description: MIAMI, Oct. 27 (AP)  The United States college allstars returned from Havana today with a 64 wonlost record in an international baseball tournament.

title: CITY FISCAL FUTURE PROMPTS PESSIMISM
description: HARRIMAN, N.Y., Oct. 27  Nearly 100 former and current New York City, state and Federal officials and educators expressed deep pessimism today on New York City's chances of avoiding another fiscal crisis  possibly as early as 1982 without broad changes in city policy and the political will to make them work.

title: THE $200 MILLION CAR
description: When John Z. DeLorean startled Detroit by quitting his $650,000-a-year executive position at General Motors, it was with the idea of starting his own car company. This was not thought of as the wisest of decisions. No one in his right mind started his own car company anymore. Remember the KaiserFrazer? The Tucker Torpedo? The Bricklin? But now, six years later, DeLorean's fantasy has_materialized in the form of a twoseat sports car temporarily named the DMC12. By the beginning of next year, the DMC12 is scheduled to roll off a Northern Ireland assembly line straight into the hot exhaust fumes of automotiveindustry competition.

title: A Career as Old as the Country
description: SOLDIERDIPLOMATS are hardly unique; nor is their inclination to set the record straight. But Yitzhak Rabin, former Israeli chief of staff, Ambassador to Washington and Prime Minister, was privy to a fascinating and rather contemporary record, and that helps set this account apart.

title: Landmarks in Marketing: Beer in Green Bottles
description: Ask a beer drinker why he drinks imported beer, and he'll probably wax eloquent on the hops or the head or the virtues of centuries of brewing experience. Ask a market researcher and he's just as likely to say it's the color of the bottle.

description: The city's major commercial real estate brokers and builders are bracing for a downturn  but not a crash in commercial space development following the Federal Reserve Board's moves to tighten credit.

title: Music Notes: With An American Accent
description: The American Composers Orchestra is worth keeping tabs on, because there is nothing quite like it here. It is larger (it has about 60 players) than other ensembles that devote themselves to American works, and its repertory is decidedly eclectic. It does not serve one historical era, and in stressing the works of contemporary composers it does not cater to any particular school.

title: Lausanne Bandits Get $1 Million
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Oct. 27 (UPI)  Four masked men held up guards carrying more than $1 million into the main branch of the Union Bank of Switzerland and escaped in an automobile with Paris license plates, the police here reported. The French border is 30 minutes away. One shot was fired at a guard but missed, passing through his trouser leg.

description: Reservation problems led the list of airline consumer complaints made from January through July this year, according to a survey released this month by the Civil Aeronautics Board.
