description: The upswing of audience interest in chamber music may or may not be a nationwide phenomenon, but it certainly is continuing apace in Connecticut, as more and more concerts dot the state schedule. This afternoon, for instance, major chambermusic series are being started in Salisbury and Westport, and at least two more will get under way during the next two weeks in Bridgeport and Wilton.

title: Associated Press
description: JUDGES MEET IN LOS ANGELES: Chief Justice Rose Bird of the California Supreme Court, center, during a break at a gathering of the National Organization of Women Judges. Addressing 100 jurists from 30 states, she spoke of the special talents of women on the bench and the need for more of them. She received a standing ovation.

title: GARDENING
description: THE story of the gypsy moth is a typical tale of man's good intentions gone astray. In an attempt to create a hearty strain of silkworm capable of survival in New England, a scientist imported the gypsy moth from Europe in 1869. His intention was to hybridize it with the less hearty silkworm, the basis of the silk industry. When a severe windstorm blew open the door of their cage, in Medford, Mass., the gypsy moths escaped. Within 10 years they were defoliating nearby woodlands, and after 20 years, they had spread throughout eastern Massachusetts.

title: Princeton Field Goal Defeats Harvard, 97
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 27 (UPI)  Lou Vaccarello kicked a 40yard field goal at 5:06 of the final period today and lifted Princeton to a 97 Ivy League triumph over Harvard.

title: Ronson Corp.'s Flickering Flame
description: A generation ago, before the first urgent warnings of the hazards of smoking, people would walk a mile for a Camel and light it with a Ronson. Once the warnings came. the Ronson Corporation sensed that the heyday of the cigarette was passing and, like the tobacco industry, set out to develop new businesses in less troublesome markets. But for the proud old maker of the Cadillac of cigarette lighters, the effort has proven painfully unrewarding.

title: On Language
description: When words die, they deserve a decent burial, or at least a respectful obituary. One noun and one adjective bit the dust recently, at least in government usage, and they are herein bid adieu.

title: PRETORIA SUGGESTS CAUSE OF EXPLOSION
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 27 South Africa's navy chief suggested today that an accident aboard a Soviet nuclear submarine could have been the cause of a possible nuclear explosion detected near southern Africa last month by an American reconnaissance satellite.

description: The party is a couple of nights away. This time, you swear, you won't be caught rushing out to the liquor store at the last minute to get the wine. So, with plenty of time, you head off to your local purveyor to make a careful, unhurried choice.

title: Cambodia, Barring Aid, Calls It an Imperialist Trick
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 27  The proVietnamese Government in Phnom Penh today publicly spelled out the reasons for its rejection of a proposal by three United States Senators to open land supply routes from Thailand to bring food to starving Cambodians.

title: Ancient Calendar In Chaco Canyon
description: Archeoastronomy  the study of the astronomical knowledge of ancient peoples from their cultural remains has shown in recent years that many preliterate societies had detailed and sophisticated knowledge of the celestial cycles. Three researchers from Washington have now discovered a remarkable, and apparently unique, solar observatory thought to date from about A.D. 1000.

title: LANE KIRKLAND: NEW STYLE
description: In May of last year, the high command of organized labor was winding up a long and acrimonious White House meeting with President Carter and his principal economic advisers. The President had irked the union chiefs at the outset by lecturing them on the urgency of curbing wages to check inflation, then by getting up to leave before George Meany could respond. Rising through union bureaucracy, rather than from the picket lines, George Meany's successor as head of the A.F.L.C.I.O. hrinps to his iob a mix of scholarly mind and executive skills.

title: A Teamster Aide Sets Terms on Negotiations For New York Unions
description: New York City municipal labor unions will refuse to tie contract provisions for higher wages to increases in worker productivity when new agreements are negotiated next spring for more than 200,000 city employees, Barry Feinstein, a leader of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said yesterday.

title: A Musical Fusion Of East and West
description: The first Indian musicians to have a decisive impact in the West played indigenous Indian instruments  Ravi Shankar and his sitar, Ali Mbar Khan and his sarod. But two of the most impressive Indian musicians who have launched international careers during the past decade, L. Shankar and L. Subramaniam, play the European violin. They also happen to be brothers.

title: Aged Mare Captures Jump Title
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 27  Fair Warning, last year's national highpoint titleholder, won the final class and coasted to the amateurowner jumper championship tonight at the Washington International Horse Show.

description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Oct. 27 (AP) The Cleveland Cavaliers traded Bingo Smith to the San Diego Clippers today in exchange for a thirdround draft choice in 1980 and a future consideration. Smith was the last of the original Cavaliers. He was acquired by Cleveland in the 1970 expansion draft.

title: Official Laxity Threatens Crime Fund in Tennessee
description: NASHVILLE, Oct. 27 (AP)  Tennessee's crime victim compensation fund, the only one in the nation that is collected from felons, is almost empty.

title: Bomb in Car Near Beirut Leftist Office Kills at Least 6
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 27  A large bomb concealed in an automobile near the headquarters of an armed Lebanese leftist faction exploded today and killed at least six persons.

title: Carmichael on Brink Of Tying Pass Mark
description: Harold Carmichael, the wide receiver for the Philadelphia Eagles who is 6 feet 8 inches tall, can tie a significant record today when his team plays the Bengals in Cincinnati. Carmichael, 30 years old and in his ninth season with the Eagles, has caught one or more passes in 104 consecutive games, and the National Football League record is 105, set by Dan Abramowicz of the New Orleans Saints and San Francisco 49ers between 1967 and 1974.

title: A School for Drivers Provides Head Start

title: The Perils Of logammuting
description: TODAY'S joggers all seem dressed to the nines. Some only to the fours or fives, of course. But however well (or ill) clad and shod, they all look like joggers. And this, I suggest, reduces their potential for social contact with the rest of the world.

title: A Complete Guide to House Swapping
description: FRANCIS and Judy Furton took a trip around the world last year and yet they were never far from home. Comfortable beds and prepared meals were waiting for them in Detroit, Spain, Indonesia, Australia, New Zealand and Redondo Beach, Calif. Perfect strangers wined and dined us and took us on tours. said Mr. Furton. who is 73 years old.

title: Liquor Taxes Raised in Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 26 (Reuters) The Swedish Parliament voted today to increase taxes on cigarettes and alcoholic drinks by 10 to 18 percent. The move will raise the cost of a bottle of Scotch whisky to the equivalent of $29.50.

title: Western Tales
description: THE Great American Novel probably would have to be a Western: the Old West has provided us with our national mythology. But one doubts that the Great American Western will ever be written. The natural expressiveness of the region's scenery and history tends to overwhelm the artist: How can any painter capture the Grand Canyon, or novelist create as wonderful a tragic hero as Custer?

It's getting to be a giant enterprise  it expects to reach a halfbillion dollars in sales this year  yet most American consumers have never shopped in its stores.

title: Bus Plunge in India Kills 12

title: Barre Leaves Hospital in Paris
description: PARIS, Oct. 27 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Raymond Barre left a Paris hospital today after nine days of treatment for high blood pressure. A hospital statement said the 55-year-old Prime Minister would be able to resume his activities next week.

title: Sudden Death
description: Soon after he seized power from Syngman Rhee in 1961, President Park Chung Hee of South Korea sent a coconspirator to Langley, Va., to learn how to create a Central Intelligence Agency of his own. Last week, according to the official account in Seoul, the head of that body. Kim Jae Kvu. acci- dentally killed Mr. Park after an argument broke out between Mr. Kim and the President's chief bodyguard during a dinner party.

title: Headliners; Ace in the Hole
description: Winnergate, they call it in South Dakota. Last weekend, reporters for The Associated Press and a Sioux Falls television station were hanging around the backroom of a bar in Winner, S.D., !checking reports of unlawful games of chance. Assembled around the tables of the unlawful games they perceived Mark Melerbertry, who is the attorney general of South Dakota. How paradoxical, the reporters thought, and last week, when they had finished reporting, Mr. Meierhenry had signed a complaint against himself, pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor, and paid his fine  as had David Volk, observed in the same back room. Mr. Volk is South Dakota's treasurer.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy

The Teamsters diverse activities, their power plays and their dirty deals are observed through the lives of nine representative members, ranging from president Frank Fitzsimmons to the rank-and-file. For good measure, there's some informed speculation about the disappearance and death of James R. Hoffa.

title: Once Again, Turbulent Korea Sends Echoes Through Asia

Last week, violence again shook the peninsula, known in ancient times as the Land of the Morning Calm, a name belied by its history.

title: Eclectic Elegance
description: Astickler for detail who leaves little to chance, John Loring, the vice president of design at Tiffany & Company, not only does all his own cooking, but he insists on doing all the marketing and even carries the food home himself. When I'm having guests and I'm responsible for their evening, I don't want to take a chance on even a delivery boy spoiling something, he says. But I do have help for lastminute details in the kitchen and for serving, tending bar and cleaning up. That way I can be dressed up and enjoy my guests and entertain myself as well.

title: Viola da Gamba Program

And difficult is what it was Tuesday night, when Shigenori Sennari played a viola da gamba program at Carnegie Recital Hall. Accompanied on the harpsichord by Rhona Freeman, Mr. Sennari offered Bach's Sonata No. 1 in G, Forqueray's Suite No. 3 in D and two works by Marin Marais  a set of variations on La Folia and Tombeau Pour Monsieur de Sainte Colombe.

title: The Heart of Great Events
description: IHAD just received this book when there they were again, in flickering black and white, on the latenight television screen: Winston Churchill and his sturdily beautiful Clemmie surrounded by cheering crowds in London's bombwracked East End. The memories came flooding back of the time when the only source of hope in a darkening Western world came from the brave, rallying words of Churchill. Norway. Denmark. Belgium. The Netherlands. And France. They had all fallen to Hitler's might. Only England stood.

title: GARDENING Controlling the Gypsy Moth Population
description: THE story of the gypsy moth is typical tale of man's good intentions gone astray. In an attempt to create hearty strain of silkworm capable of survival in New England, a scientist imported the gypsy moth from Europe in 1869. His intention was to hybridize it with the less hearty silkworm, the basis of the silk industry. When a severe windstorm blew open the door of their cage, in Medford, Mass., the gypsy moths escaped. Within 10 years they were defoliating nearby woodlands, and after 20 years, they had spread throughout eastern Massachusetts.

title: Versions Of Singer
description: WHAT is Isaac Bashevis Singer? Paul Kresh asks toward the end of his biography of the Yiddish writer, the first in any language. His own answer is a long lyric catalogue piquant contradictions: ascetic sensualist, innocent sophisticate, friendly loner, boyish old man, and much more of the same. Mr. Kresh concludes his list with grand flourish: He is a man of many paradoxes and contradictions, yet withal a man, like Whitman's poetical self, large enough to contain multitudes, reconciled to the war of forces within himself and somehow at ease with himself. This is the closest the

title: WASHINGTON Hearing It From Henry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  Henry Kissinger has written a fourpound book (1,521 pages) at a little over $5 a pound, which is in keeping with the inflationary trend of these days, but the view here is that it is the most remarkable insider's political memoir of our time.

title: Pop: The Rhythm Kings
description: The Manhattan Rhythm Kings, a natty trio of singing musicians who dress in snapbrim hats, pleated pants and twotone shoes, manage to evoke the goodtime music of the 20's and 30's without exaggerating it or, aside from their costumes, without a semblance of camp. They respect and enjoy the songs that they sing  Get Out and Get Under the Moon, We Just Couldn't Say Goodbye, Shuffle Off to Buffalo, Change Partners  and they let the innate qualities of the songs carry them without intrusive decorative comments.

At his local'PX, the Four Seasons restaurant, the maitre d came up and whispered a Hungarian hello, which Korda said also could mean goodbye. He was placed in a catbird banquette against a wall with clear sightlines, the better to see and be seen in the aviator goggles he al- ways wears. (And why not? He put in time in the Royal Air Force before going on to Oxford.)

description: Suffern, undefeated and unscored upon, rolled over Tappan Zee by 210. Kevin Short scored two touchdowns, the first a 10yard run and the second a 7yard run. Tony DeFrancesco and Keeas Healy connected on a 6yard pass for the final score.

title: Big Arts Plan at SUNY
description: ONE year ago, the doors opened to the four theaters that make up the Center for the Arts at the State University College of New York at Purchase. One year from now, plans call for developments that would make the arts center major force in the region's performingarts scene.

title: Amtrak Adds New Trains Today
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UPI)  Amtrak, after months of budget problems and train cutbacks, has something to celebrate over the next few days: Introduction of a new train to Las Vegas, inauguration of the first new longdistance passenger cars to be built in the United States in more than 20 years, and the takeover of two commuter trains.

title: Woman Named Army's Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP)  Sara Elisabeth Lister yesterday became the Army's general counsel. She is the second woman to serve as the Army's top civilian lawyer. She succeeds Jill Wine Voliner, a forter Watergate prosecutor who recently resigned. Mrs. Lister has held series of legal and administrative jobs in the Navy and Defense Departmeft.

title: Loosening the Energy Noose
description: It was an amazing week for the 1979 Carter energy program. One worthwhile bill after another moved ahead in a wave of progress that, in 1977, would have made the rookie Administration salivate. The Senate Finance Committee approved a windfall profits tax . .. the House finally adopted standby rationing for gasoline emergencies . .. the House approved emergency fuel assistance for the poor ... a proposal for one new agency, to develop alternative energy sources, is on its way to the Senate floor .. . another one, to cut red tape, is moving toward enactment in the House.

title: THEATER Eccentricities
description: THE Eccentricities of a Nightingdale, which opens the fifth season at the Westchester Regional Theater, is not a new Tennessee Williams play, but a new version of one of his plays. The original was Summer and Smoke, which had its greatest success Off Broadway in 1952 in a performance that made a star of the thenunknown Geraldine Page and established its director. Jose Quintero.

title: New Policy May Reduce Maine Spraying Project
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Oct. 27 (AP)  A new policy aimed at protecting residential areas from spruce budworm spraying may substantially reduce the scope of the 1980 aerial spraying project, Maine officials say.

title: INVESTING Tax Shelters in Original Art
description: It's hardly a secret anymore that collecting art can be an effective, if sometimes risky, way to keep ahead of inflation. There's another way of dealing in the art market, however, that can be doubly rewarding: It's the limited partnership in producing original art, and it can offer protection from the tax man as well as from inflation.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Muzorewa Accepts Basis of British Plan for Rhodesia
description: LONDON, Oct. 27  Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa today conditionally accepted Britain's proposals for the transition to new elections in Zimbabwe Rhodesia, including appointment of a British governor to run the country until independence.

title: An Unusual Political; Team in Long Beach
description: LONG BEACH

title: Backgammon:
description: Newcomer to Tournaments Proves Her Mettle and Luck

title: Women Painters and Germaine Greer
description: ASTRIKING testimonial to the effectiveness of the women's movement is provided by the enormous expansion of interest in the history of women artists in recent years. In 1970, when this reviewer embarked on an investigation of women's situation in art history in an article entitled Why have there been no great women artists? there existed not a single recent reliable general study to

title: LETTERS
description: Radioactive

title: The Dance: Pas de Deux In Ballet at the Beacon
description: If you didn't get to the various international dance festivals held in recent years in Chicago or Havana, and if you haven't made it to international ballet competitions lately in Jackson, Miss., or Lausanne, Switzerland, the program entitled Ballet at the Beacon this afternoon at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Street, is one way to catch up.

title: FUND CUTS STALLED IN SPECIAL INTERESTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27  Representative Ray Roberts is a conservative by any definition, and bows to no one in opposing big spenders and supporting a balanced budget. But Mr. Roberts is also chairman of the House Veterans Affairs Committee, and, when it comes to the interests of former soldiers, Mr. Roberts fights for every dollar he can get.

title: Recital: William Grubb
description: Three seasons ago, William Grubb gave a debut recital as the result of winning the Concert Artists Guild Auditions. The American cellist made a return appearance Friday night in Carnegie Recital Hall, presenting an interesting program. This included five Pieces en Concert, arranged for cello and piano from the chambermusic suites of Couperin, Mozart's Divertimento in Eflat for String Trio (K. 563) and the Rachmaninoff Sonata in G minor. The cellist's collaborators were David Oei, pianist; Laurie Carney, violinist, and Daniel Avshalomov, violist.

title: Soviet Parliament Sets Session For Nov. 28 on Economic Plans
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 27 (Reuters)  The Supreme Soviet, or Parliament, will begin its next session here Nov. 28, it was announced today.

title: Teacher Income: The Bottom Line
description: Teacher Income: The Bottom Line

title: In Hartford the Heat Is On; The Heat Is On As Assembly Meets
description: HARTFORD

title: Albuquerque: Frontier of New Turbulence
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 27 With its sprawling subdivisions, clean new public buildings and aspens and adobes that sparkle in the autumn sun, Albuquerque is not a city where one would expect to find a high incidence of crime.

title: Life Among the Tailgaters at the Yale Bowl
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Turner Sets a New Cup Course
description: NEWPORT, R.I.  Ted Turner pulled the engineer's cap off the head of Marty O'Meara, the operations manager for the Courageous syndicate. Only one of us around here can wear a railroad cap, said Turner, flashing his dimpledchin grin at the cluster of photographers on Bannister's Wharf. And that's me.

title: San Francisco's Night Life Is Smart, Funky and Fun
description: Since Gold Rush days, San Francisco has been developing a lusty, bawdy night life of its own in its storied redbrocaded saloons. Good music, good booze and a bit more than a soupcon of naughtiness are its characteristics, and they add up to something quite different from the jaded sophistication of nighttime New York and the glitz of afterdark Los Angeles.

title: ANTIQUES
description: CANTON

title: New Nation Is Born in Caribbean
description: KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, Oct. 27 (AP)  The world's newest nation, a cluster of islands with only 150 square miles of land and 100,000 residents, was born today with fireworks and pageantry as Britain left its last outpost in the Windward Islands of the Caribbean.

title: The Big Battle of Bloomington, Minn.
description: Red Smith

title: Jennifer E. Johnston Becomes Bride of Alan Osofsky
description: Jennifer E. Johnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Johnston, was married yesterday to Alan Osofsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Osofsky of Brooklyn. The ceremony was Der- formed in the Manhattan home of the bride's parents by the Rev. Gary B. Brown of the Scarsdale (N.Y.) Congregational Church and Rabbi David Greenberg of the Scarsdale Synagogue.

title: THIS WEEK IN SPORTS
description: BASKETBALL

title: A Who's Who of Seoul's Multinationals
description: SEOUL, South Korea  In preKorean War days, Chung Ju Yung was an automobile mechanic with only a few won to his name. Today, at 64 years old, he is the controlling stockholder of the Hyundai Group that had sales of $3.7 billion and profits of $329 million last year.

title: Lisa Ferwerda Fiance of G. S. Johnston 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Timothy OsborneHill of Paris have announced the engagement of MrsOsborneHill's daughter, Lisa Ferwerda, to George Sim Johnston 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnston Jr. of New York. A wedding is planned in Rome on Dec. 8.

title: CAPITAL REPORT
description: Martin Waldron

title: Penn Bows by 246 To Undefeated Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 27  Dennis Dunn, the quarterback, and Tim Turnpane, the linebacker, were the most prominent players in the Yale Bowl today as unbeaten Yale defeated Pennsylvania, 246, before a crowd of 19,562 on a cool, clear afternoon.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times on Oct. 21 inaccurately portrayed the views of labor representatives on the Social Security Advisory Council. The labor representatives opposed a majority recommendation for funding the Medicare part of Social Security with income taxes, proposing instead that general tax revenues be used to fund all aspects of the Social Security program.

title: SOME FAMOUS ALSORANS
description: Designed by a salesman, Preston Tucker, the car lured 54,000 people to invest $40 mil lion in 1946. But problems quickly torpedoed the venture.

title: Fordham Team Leading In A.A.U. Water Polo
description: The Amateur Athletic Union's indoor national water polo championship began at Fordham University's Lombardi Center pool Friday, and after three rounds the host college's team was in the running for the title in the doubleelimination event.

title: Letters TO THE EDITOR
description: So much of Karl Rahner's thought (Quiet Mover of the Catholic Church by Eugene Kennedy, Sept. 23) gives reason for rejoicing that it must seem graceless to find points on which to quibble. Yet two statements by the great theologian must be protested, for they perpetuate one of the great wrongs of Roman Catholic, if not all Christian, thought.

title: Mrs. O'Rourke
description: Sheila M. Nolan, daughter of Mr. and .Mrs. Frank W. Nolan Jr. of Essex Fells, N.J., and Bernard C. O'Rourke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton O'Rourke of Inniskeen. Dundalk. Ireland. were married yesterday in the Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Roseland, N.J. The bridegroom's uncle, the Rev. Kevin Lyon of County Wicklow, Ireland, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Msgr. Edward J. Fleming, pastor of Blessed Sacrament Church, and the Rev. Paul Nolan, the bride's uncle.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE salvaged remains of the trunk of a historic white oak accidentally cut down in Stony Brook will be returned soon to the grassy island in the middle of Lubber Street, where the mighty sentinel stood for almost 900 years.

title: Columbia's Losing Tradition Beats Coach
description: Perhaps the easiest time for anyone coaching football at Columbia was between 1870 and 1898  when there was no regular coach. But since the old days, even men like Lou Little, who is enshrined in the Football Hall of Fame and who coached the Lions for 26 years, have had a tough time winning.

title: Loren Sinclair Archibald Fianc
description: Mr. and Mrs. William R. Connor of Essex Fells, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sally Jean Connor, to Loren Sinclair Archibald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert V. Archibald of North Caldwell, N.J.

title: Businessmen and Buttonholes
description: Twenty years ago, a businessman was called welldressed if he had a closetful of sedate dark suits, a stack of white shirts and a row of deeptoned ties. He might have had one or two lightcolored suits for summer as well, but that was as far as he ventured into the thenuncharted world of men's fashion.

title: Federal Effort to Battle Drug Traffic Is Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP)  The Federal battle against illegal drug trafficking has been hampered by a lack of cooperation among government agencies and uneven efforts to jail drug dealers, according to a top Congressional investigator.

title: Jefferson, Cannibals and Others
description: IT would be hard to find a more legitimate subject for a historical novel than Sally Hemings, the slave who was reputed in song and story to have been the mistress of her owner, Thomas Jefferson. The songs, including some doggerel written by John Quincy Adams and Thomas Moore, take an uncharitable view of Jefferson. The history itself is thin; what

title: Father and Son In Lagos Called Rising Dynasty
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  They are so similar in build and feature and manner that people sometimes mistake them for brothers, even though one is a good 20 years older than the other. But Joseph and Simeon Tarka are father and son, and these days they are more than just that. The Tarkas are establishing what some are calling modern Nigeria's first politi- cal dynasty.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: November will be Oz month at Del Rey Books. The paperback house is reissuing the first seven books in the Oz series by L. Frank Baum. There was only one way to do this: It had to be big, says Del Rey's editor in chief, JudyLynn del Rey, who has ordered a first printing of a million copies. The Wizard of Oz is the bestknown title in the series, but The Land of Oz, Ozma of Oz, Dorothy and the Wizard in Oz, The Road to Oz, The Emerald City of Oz and The Patchwork Girl of Oz are also on their way to the stores.

title: Connecticut /This Week; ART
description: BRIDGEPORT- Works by Arthur d'Arazien, industrial photographer, through Nov. 11, Museum of Art, Science and Industry, 4450 Park Ave. $1, students, children and the elderly 50 cents. Closed Mondays. 3723521.

title: How to Cook The Ideal Meal
description: AS so many homes and apartments have become more compact within the past decade or two, the American public has made an esthetic virtue of what is often economic necessity by discovering that copper pots and stainless steel whisks, maple chopping blocks and a sturdy professional range can be just as appealing as a welldesigned sofa or chair to the eye of the beholder. As a result, the

title: The American Dream:
description: EVERY fall, I teach a college course called The American Dream. It's normally a popular course, judging from the enrollment. However, this year, the college, in an effort to conserve energy, rearranged schedules.

title: CALENDARS
description: Dog Shows

title: Hydroelectric Station Begins Power Delivery From Canadian North
description: JAMES BAY, Quebec, Oct. 27  The first power from what will be North America's biggest hydroelectric complex surged through 650 miles of high tension wire from this northern wilderness today.

title: Premier's New Ideas Surprise South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 26  After a year as South Africa's eighth Prime Minister, Pieter Willem Botha has enraged some citizens and delighted others. But he has surprised just about everyone.

title: Keeping Discipline in the Schools Is the No. 1 Education Headache
description: Lack of discipline was the toprated problem among those mentioned by parents, teachers, legislators and others involved in public education in this year's annual Gallup Poll on public attitudes toward education. Twentyfour percent of the national sample of 1,514 adults said it was the most serious worry. Use of drugs, generally considered part of the discipline problem, was mentioned second most often, by 13 percent.

title: North Stars
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 27 Sometimes the Minnesota shots came in rapidfire bursts, and sometimes they came far apart. Usually they came from tough angles, from in close, or behind screens. And 39 times the puck came at Wayne Thomas, the Ranger goalie, and seven times it went behind him.

title: Annette Bricker Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Juli Bricker of Easton, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Annette Bricker, to Richard Alan Sobel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Sobel of East Meadow, L.I. A December wedding is planned.

title: The Wife of A Widower
description: ANYBODY who knows anything about Henry Adams knows that on December 6, 1885 he found his 42-year-old wife lying dead on the rug before her bedroom fire. She reeked of potassium cyanide, the chemical she used in her hobby of photography and which, for mysterious reasons, she had just suicidally swallowed.

title: Editors
description: CANNIBALS AND MISSIONARIES, by Mary McCarthy. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $10.95.) A plane filled with liberals and art collectors, on their way to the Shah's Iran for their particular purposes, is hijacked by terrorists: a novel that assesses the temper of our times.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:30 A.M. (Channel 4) Newscenter Forum: Julio Antonia Martinez, director of the New York State Division of Substance Abuse Services.

title: Students Sought as Census Takers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP)  The Census Bureau is looking for students to work part time counting residents of the United States and Puerto Rico for college credit plus S4 an hour.

title: Athens Calls Time on AllNight Revels
description: In the Symposium, Plato describes how Socrates, Aristophanes, Alcibiades and other prominent Athenians drank, joked and talked of love until the crowing of cocks finally persuaded them it was time to go home.

title: Seton Hall's Streak, Merklinger Stopped
description: John Merklinger never sleeps well the night before the game. He is restless, his mind preoccupied. He lies in bed visualizing how he will run each play. Up early in the morning, he immediately turns on his tape player and listens to the soundtrack from the movie Rocky.

title: A Burst of Aid for Cambodia
description: Many Cambodians have starved todeath3while the United States and the rest of the world worried about which government rightfully represents them. Now, at last, President Carter has shown a practical desire to help with a pledge of about $70 million for aid.

title: Deer Multiply, And So Do Problems
description: FROM her kitchen window one recent rainy Saturday, Penny McCormick, wife of the First Selectman of. Weston; glimpsed a delicate whitetailed deer browsing not 60 feet fromherhouse

title: Grand Central Shops: Customers on the Run
description: At one time the train traveler waiting in Grand Central Terminal could watch a newsreel, get a barbershop shave, have a suit pressed or a button sewn on. But railroad service in the terminal has changed from longdistance travel to commuter use and the merchant community has adjusted to the customer on the run.

title: American Official Praises Marcos For Refugee Center in Philippines
description: MANILA, Oct. 27 (Reuters)  Richard Holbrooke, United States Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, praised President Ferdinand E. Marcos today for his decision to set up processing center in the Philippines for some 50,000 Indochinese refugees.

title: Siamese Twins to Undergo Tests On Feasibility of Being Separated
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 27 (AP)  Twodayold Siamese twin boys who doctors say are acting like very normal babies will undergo tests next week that may determine whether they can undergo surgery to separate them.

title: Cornell Ends Dartmouth Mastery, 21 to 10
description: HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 27  For 11 straight years, Dartmouth's football team had dominated Cornell, winning each time.

title: CHESS
description: ROBERT BYRNE

title: Peking Hears Rumors That Price Of Some Foods May Be Increased
description: PEKING, Oct. 27 (UPI)  Rumors that the Government will impose price increases of up to 30 percent for perishable foods effective Nov. 1 swept through Peking today, but there was no official confirmation If the reports prove true, China could be facing the first round of inflation since the 1949 Communist revolution.

title: Czechs Set The Limits Of Dissent Very Narrow
description: Six Protestors Last Week Were Sentenced in Prague

title: Tibet Struggles for Higher Living Standard
description: LHASA, Tibet  Twenty years after taking full control of Tibet, the Peking Government is still struggling with mixed results to raise the living standards of the Tibetans to the frugal level at which most Chinese live.

title: Eskimos Contest Sale of Alaska Oil and Gas Leases
description: ANCHORAGE, Oct. 27 (AP)  For centuries the Inupiat Eskimos have pulled whales, seals and fish out of the sea, birds from the sky and caribou off the land, subsisting in a fragile environment while developing a distinctive culture.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THIS is the time of year when the season for using snow throwers is practically upon us, while the season for using power mowers is just about over for homeowners in the area.

title: Scott Outpoints Celestine in Fight at Prison
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Oct. 27 James Scott, whose shaved head and fierce scowl might well terrify most of his rivals even before they stepped into the ring, scored an effortless 10round decision over Jerry Celestine today in Rahway State Prison.

title: Concert: An Appetizer Of Music From Vienna
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  The visit of the Vienna State Opera to John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, which will open tomorrow night with Leonard Bernstein conducting Beethoven's Fidelio, was prefaced by a concert given by the Vienna Philharmonic in the Concert Hall tonight.

title: West Essex Falls, 147
description: Morris Knolls scored late in the fourth quarter to gain a 147 decision over West Essex in Rockaway Township. The triumph improved the Morris Knolls record to 60.

title: Young and Old
description: SIMON SHEA, a retired professor of English at a small Minnesota college, has begun to forget things and has negligently set fire to his kitchen. Fearing the onset of decrepitude, he voluntarily commits himself to terminal residence at a private rest home.

title: The Gordie Howe Saga, Cont.
description: Scriptwriter: Have I got a plot for you! The hero's a hockey player. Greatest star the game has known. Broken all the scoring records, won the Stanley Cup four times, made the allstar team every year, married the beautiful girl. Even comes back from a brain operation, which nearly kills him. But now, after 25 years,

title: A Bonus for a Marriage
description: SHE'S old now. She waddles when she walks on swollen legs that hide her ankles and form straight line to her shoes. And it's an effort to get up off the sofa, and more of an effort to make the trip to the store.

title: Illinois Man Sentenced to Death In Highway Shootout Fatal to 5
description: KANKAKEE, Ill., Oct. 27 (AP)  Monroe Lampkin has been sentenced to death for killing three persons in an Interstate 57 shootout.

title: Vernon Jordan Urges Reforms
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 27 (UPI)  Vernon E. Jordan Jr., president of the National Urban League, said today that the income gap between whites and blacks was growing and that the civil rights reforms of the 1960's had not gone far enough. Mr. Jordan, keynote speaker at the second Internatonal Labor-Management Prayer Breakfast, said the changes started in the previous decade must be expanded upon today.

title: 350 Filipinos in Guam Deported
description: MANILA, Oct. 27 (Reuters)  About 350 Filipinos working in the United States Pacific territory of Guam have been deported to the Philippines for overstaying their permits, the Overseas Employment Development board said today. More than 3,000 Filipinos are believed to be staying beyond the expiration of their work permits. Guam has 30,000 legal Filipino residents.

title: Thai open door to refugees is of the revolving kind. page 2
description: BANGKOK, Thailand  For reasons both strategic and political, Thailand is now practicing an opendoor policy toward refugees from famine, diseaseand warravaged Cambodia.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Yes, indeed, wake up, Jeremiah, or, in the words of the old song, rise up so early in the morn. To what purpose? Why, to see Sol rise. In some 19 mostly short exclamatory sentences young Jeremiah is exhorted to get out of bed, dress, hotfoot it

title: James Millner, Lawyer, Fianc of Susan Meyer
description: Dr. and Mrs. Donald C. Meyer of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Linda Meyer, to James Warren Millner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley C. Millner of Trenton.

title: Averell Harriman Fisk Weds Miss van Voorhees
description: Averell Harriman Fisk, grandson of W. Averell Harriman, the elder statesman and former Governor of New York, married Victoria van Voorhees at tile Municipal Building Oct. 10. The private family ceremony was perforkhed by Deputy Clerk Herbert F. Ryan.

title: Tapes Provide Rare Glimpse of UnionCrime Dealings
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27  Friends of Francis J. Sheeran, president of Local 326 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in Wilmington, Del., paid $100 apiece to attend his 59th birthday party at a motel restaurant Thursday night. The aonations were intended to help offset the cost of prime steaks, a Las Vegas band and Mr. Sheeran's defense on charges of murder, attempted murder, arson and embezzlement.

description: WASHINGTON

title: Yukon Takes Step Toward Province Status
description: TORONTO, Oct. 27  At the prodding of Canada's new Conservative Government, the fabled Yukon Territory took another step this week toward becoming the country's newest province.

title: 10 Years After Heyday, Weather Underground Fades to a Footnote
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP)  Richard M. Nixon was the new President and war was raging in Southeast Asia. A tightly knit group that came to be known as Weather Underground viewed itself as the vanguard of a coming revolution. The Federal Bureau of Investigation saw it as a band of terrorists responsible for inciting riots and planting bombs.

title: Civil Rights Lawyer From Phoenix Killed by Holdup Men in Riverdale
description: A prominent civil rights lawyer and civic leader from Phoenix was shot and killed early yesterday morning by holdup men as he, his wife and two sisters-in-law waited in a car outside an apartment building in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

description: This Week:

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: They lost to Cuba, 74, in the last game of the roundrobin, sixteam tournament Friday night. Fidel Castro, Cuba's president, visited the United States dugout during the game, shook hands and signed autographs for the players.

title: Irish Showing Mixed Feelings On Pope's Visit
description: DROGHEDA, Ireland  In a peaceful green meadow here late in September, Pope John Paul II made an urgent and moving appeal for an end to Ireland's siege of sectarian violence.

title: Future Events; Of Celebrities and Causes
description: Tickets to the following may be ob- tained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.

title: Midwest Quake Fault Is Called Most Threatening
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 20 (AP)  The name of the San Andreas Fault raises images of cracked earth and trembling skyscrapers. The name of the New Madrid Fault is likely to ra iCP only Pvphrnwc

title: It's Honey Craven's Show Time
description: Honey Craven remembers the day he first joined the National Horse Show staff as if it were yesterday. It was 53 years ago, and now at the age of 75 he still has an excellent memory.

title: POLITICS Officials and Strikes: a Delicate Balance
description: WHEN a public official intervenes in an industrial labor dispute, perhaps the essential thing is a sense of timing  knowing when the major issues have been resolved.

title: Bowl Game Captures Turf Classic by Neck
description: The $250,000 Turf Classic had a distinct French accent at Aqueduct yesterday but a distinctly American finish. Bowl Game came barreling through the stretch for a neck victory over Trillion and a $7.60 payoff to his $2 backers.

title: In the Land of Opportunity
description: TWO bright reporters have come up with a new method for the habitual effort to describe the way we live now. Instead of traveling the length and breadth of the land to beat the bushes with their notebooks and tape recorders in hand, Robert Kaiser of The Washington Post and Jon Lowell of Newsweek simply rented an apartment in Las Vegas fora summer and interviewed the incoming tourists, a neverending supply of raw material with an estimated turnover of 80,000 every few days.

title: A Question Facing Gymnasts: For Whom to Compete?
description: Although Erin Callan placed second in one division of New York State's gymnastics competition last year, she knew that she would not be on her school team in this, her freshman year.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: HOME CLINIC Between Mower and Thrower
description: THIS is the time of year when the season for using snow throwers is practically upon us, while the season for using power mowers is just about over for homeowners in the area.

title: Unique Chic
description: By day, Mary McFadden's home is her showroom, and in it she frequently entertains guests for lunch. If we are only one or two, says the wellknown fashion designer, I think it is interesting to go to a restaurant. But when it's four or more, its special here. Everyone seems to find this atmosphere amusing.

title: Military Retirees on Pensions Go To Another State for Jobless Pay
description: GOODLAND, Kan., Oct. 27 (UPI) Bill Orr, out of the Army less than a week, drove 300 miles from his Colorado retirement home to the unemployment office in this rural Kansas town.

title: Typewriter Wars and the Revival of Remington Rand
description: The International Business Machines Corporation doesn't only dominate the computer business; it has a lock on electric typewriters, too, with 80 per cent of the market. Nearly two wan ago, the giant Exxon Corporation determined that there was room at the least for another, and it burst into the market with a machine that competes with the best from I.B.M. Now one of the oldest names in typewriters, Remington Rand, has come back from the dead with another challenger.

title: Israeli Natives Fear Extortion In Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 27  In the wake of two brutal murders, this city is wondering about the existence of an Israeli Mafia.

title: SUE BOSNIAK
description: Sue Bosniak, the wife of the late Jacob Bosniak, rabbi emeritus of the Ocean Parkway Jewish Center in Brooklyn, died yesterday at her home in Brooklyn after brief illness. She was 91 years old. Mrs. Bosniak was active in community affairs associated with the synagogue and with Hadassah. Her husband died in 1963.

title: U.S. Study Sees Savings On Recycling of Metals
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UPI)  Product recycling could save 30 percent or more of the copper, aluminum, iron and steel now lost in the production, use and disposal of these materials, according to a Congressional study.

title: U.S. Apple Growers Hiring Jamaicans Over Americans, Suit Alleges
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y.  Arguing that the arrival of 5,000 apple harvesters from Jamaica has denied that number of jobs to American residents, 50 black and Hispanic migrant farm workers filed suit last week in Federal District Court in New York City against Federal and state agencies, the applegrowing industry and the Jamaican Government.

title: STAMPS
description: Cowboy Humorist

title: Celebrating the 30's, When Nearly Everyone Went to the Movies
description: The year was 1930 and in an outrageous film called Madam Satan, an early but already vintage effort by Cecil B. DeMille, a lot of wellheeled people were holding a masked ball  in a dirigible moored over New York. Just Imagine, another film released that year, was boldly anticipating what life would be like in 1980. For one thing, people weren't going to have names any more, and playing one of those numbered souls was a very green young actress named Maureen O'Sullivan. By 1934 Miss O' Sullivan was a seasoned Hollywood hand and had become famous as Johnny Weismuller's jungle partner; that year they were in Tarzan and His Mate. A high point of 1939, for some filmgoers, was being able to watch Gracie Allen bumble her way through a supremely looney suspense story called The Gracie Allen Murder Case.

title: The Liberated Cook
description: I had a lovely day. I spent the day, my husband's birthday, cooking his favorite things. I did nothing else all day. It was warm and sunny, and in the morning I got into my car and drifted from market to market to find the sweet butter I wanted, the choicest cut of pork, the roundest raspberries. In the afternoon, after eating a taco at a drivein. I settled into my kitchen, alone, wonderfully alone, with a glass of wine, country music on the stereo, and the smell of pork stewing in vinegar and hot peppers to make barbecue, a dish from my husband's childhood in North Carolina. I put on my jogging shorts. I al- ways wear my jogging shorts when I cook. I made a pastry shell and put a layer of ca- ramelized sugar on the bot- tom. I washed the raspberries. I made creme fraiche and tole slaw, and batter for corn muf- fins. In the late afternoon, be- fore assembling the tart, I switched from white wine to champagne, from Loretta Lynn to Bach, and put on a long dress. In such a way I passed the heart of a rare late summer day. At the end of such days, I feel a uselessness strangely akin to peace.

Though perhaps he's full of ideas for his next book, he is likely to waffle a bit before beginning again until he feels his strength come back, so he won't make a botch of the first draft and vitiate some precious part of his enthusiasm in a false start. Instead, he busies himself with halfspeed research of a kind, does book reviews or what are called pieces for magazines, travels, drinks, looks out for love affairs, or whatever.

title: CLARIFICATION
description: Regrettably, Ree Morton was discussed in a review (Oct. 7) of work at the Neuberger Museum by artists from Artists Space without mention of her death in 1977. Also, despite emphasis in a catalogue essay by Irving Sandler on giving artists major decisionmaking powers, the director of Artists Space, Helene Winer, wishes it to be known that Artists Space is, in fact, run by professionals, not artists. Nor is the exhibition, which closes Nov. 11, in any way related, as implied, to the publicity engendered by Artists Space's spring show called The Nigger Drawings. Moreover, the reviewer erred in describing the foilcovered rats in Thomas LaniganSchmidt's composition as guinea pigs. Finally, in the process of transcription, the plaster in Barbara Schwartz's sculpture out plastic.

title: THE SHASAN ARAS ARTIST
description: He has one of the great European faces. Implausibly thin and impossibly tall, hollow cheek and hollow of eye, he was endowed by nature with a huge arching forehead, a look lasting wonderment and a quite exceptional does he open his mouth than we know him as a man of sense and a man of scruple, and we can imagine him in a wide range of creditable historical roles. He could have been a Crusader, but a Crusader who dropped out on the march and took no part in the killing. He could have built the great Gothic cathedrals, sat up all night with Paracelsus the alchemist, or ridden part of the way with Parsifal when Parsifal was searching for the Holy Grail. He could have been an itinerant healer at the time of the Black Death, and he could have climbed in the Peruvian Andes with the famous German explorer Alexander von Humboldt.

title: Piano: Lotto Offers Ravel And Chopin

description: Gertrude Stein gave legendary parties because she was a wit, Alice B. Toklas was a cook, and the guests were celebrities. The rest of us may not be so fortunate. We may need a little more artifice and dazzle to make our parties memorable, if not historic. Luckily, there are people who will rent you almost anything you could conceivably want, from basics such as china and chairs to frills such as a hotdog stand, neon sculpture, dance floors, gold lame tablecloths and twoton Buddhas.

title: Huntington Beaten, 136
description: Centereach handed Huntington its first loss of the season, yesterday in a Conference II game. The Blue Devils had won five straight.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE; MUSICAL FAIRY TALES
description: Paul Sills's Story Theater comes to Theater A of the State University's Performing Arts Center today at 1 P.M. with Once Upon a Time, a musical concoction based on the tales of the brothers Grimm and the fables of Aesop.

title: Asians Hail Park for Stable Rule
description: TOKYO, Oct. 27  Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira of Japan, a country with deep economic and security interests in South Korea, and other Asian leaders today expressed concern for stability on the peninsula following the killing last night of President Park Chung Hee.

description: ALBERTSON  Chinese brushwork by Irving M. Affias; 1 to 5 P.M. today; 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. tomorrow, Tuesday; Shelter Rock Library, 165 Searingtown Rd.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 27  A struggle between East and West for a vacant seat on the Security Council ended in a temporary deadlock yesterday.

title: Deaths
description: SELTZERDebbiSisterhood of Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Debbi Seltzer,sister of our dedicated Treasurer and Board of Trustee member,Mrs Leah Lehfang. Our heartfelt sympathy to entire family.

title: Maine Islanders Flee Rising Costs
description: MATINICUS ISLAND, Me., Oct. 27 (AP)  Residents say that soaring fuel prices, uncertainty over food supplies and the cost of trips to the mainland are driving people from this serene little is- land

title: Danbury, Darien Victors
description: Danbury and Darien took strides toward securing berths in the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference playoffs, while Greenwich lost its top spot in the western division after being upset by Westhill yesterday.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Seaward Bolivia
description: LIMA, Peru  As Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance was contemplating his departure the other day from La Paz's 11,909 feet above sea level, cutting short his attendance at this year's Assembly of the Organization of American States, he must have felt, in his head and stomach, a certain hankering for the sea.

title: Carey Budget Is Sandbagged By the Soaring Cost of Fuel
description: ALBANY  It will not show up on any financial statements, but the state treasury will be making major contributions to the reelection campaigns of several legislators next fall. The donations are in the form of the repeal of a politically charged sales tax on the energy that New Yorkers use in their homes, approved in a sometimes bitter session of the State Assembly last week.

title: Columbia Loses to Colgate
description: The New York Times/ Edward Hausner

title: Burns Pair Gets Golf Lead
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, FLA., Oct. 27 (AP)  Ben Crenshaw and George Burns carded a 10-under-par 62 over Disney World's Magnolia course today and took a fourstroke lead in the $250,000 National Team golf tournament.

title: Figure in the Distance Is Unmistakable, but Why Is She Here?
description: THE figure was unmistakable in spite of the distance and the early morning haze that rose from the marshlands. What I had at first taken as swamp grass bending in the breeze was indeed someone running along the causeway, far off still, but running. Anger flashed tnrougn me so strong I felt its flush on my face. I had come to know this early morning time and place as my own for running. I had appropriated it and learned about it, cherishing it as a private treasure, which made me now doubly resent the intruder.

title: 4 Counties Unite for Federal Aid
description: CAPE MAY

title: Keith Pattiz Fianc Of Jill C. Scheuer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney I. Scheuer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill Cathy Scheuer, to Keith M. Pattiz, son of Mrs. Milton Wernick and Howard S. Pattiz of St. Louis.

title: Wisconsin Nature Reserve Begun in 30's Still Thriving
description: BARABOO, Wis., Oct. 27 (AP)  The pioneer wagon track is blacktopped now, but in the early light the shack looks as it did 30 years ago when Aldo Leopold, sitting on the oak bench beside the door with a notebook and coffee, wrote the Journals that became the bible of the ecological movement.

title: Conrail Will Cut Down On Trains for Smokers
description: Beginning tomorrow, the number of smoking cars on Conrail's New Haven, Hudson and Harlem Divisions will be reduced and the number of nosmoking cars increased.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: ADA LOUISE HUXTABLE

title: IN THE NATION The Necessary Bus
description: LIMA, Ohio, Oct. 27  This Ohio industrial city is like a lot of other hustling American communities  it's easy to go somewhere else by car (Interstate 75 passes through, going north and south) but not so easy to get anywhere by public transportation.

title: HOME CLINIC Between Mower and Thrower
description: THIS is the time of year when the season for using snow throwers is practically upon us, while the season for using power mowers is just about over for homeowners in the area.

title: Quakes Felt Indicate a Volcano In Hawaii Is Likely to Erupt Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP)  The United States Geological Survey says the likelihood of Kilauea volcano in Hawaii erupting seems to.be increasing.

title: 200 Foes in the Street And a Fan in the Sky Mark Shah's Presence
description: A light plane towing a banner reading Long Live the Shah made passes up and down the East River near New York HospitalCornell Medical Center, where Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, the deposed Shah of Iran, is recuperating from scrgery.pn the ground, nearly 200 shivering antiShah pickets marched in a noisy but orderly line along York Avenue between 69th and 70th Streets.

title: Testing the Tourist Bureaus
description: The reply was from Cheick Ba of the Permanent Mission of Mali to the United Nations. He is the official representative in New York of his West African country's ministry of tourism.

title: Miss Remmel Becomes Bride Of a Banker
description: At Christ Church United Methodist yesterday, Alexandra Cary Remmel, daughter of Harmon Liveright Remmel of New York and Southampton, L.I., and the late Jacquelin Towson Remmel, was married to Charles Carter Swoope Jr., son of Mrs. Swoope of Newton, Miss., and the late Mr. Swoope of Memphis. The Rev. David Randolph performed the ceremony.

title: Rams and Haden Hurt Too Much to Laugh
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 27  Beneath the portrait of the late Carroll Rosenbloom on the cover of the Los Angeles Rams 1979 media guide is a quote from one of his favorite poems, Ella Wheeler Wilcox's Solitude:

title: John Staelin Weds Elizabeth Locke
description: Elizabeth Louise French Locke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. Locke of Harrisonburg, Va., was married yesterday to John Robert Staelin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Staelin of Riverside, Conn. The Episcopal ceremony was performed in the Old Chapel in Boyce, Va., by the Rev. Walter D. Clark Jr., brother-in-law of the bride.

title: Bernard Donovan, ExNew York Schools Superintendent, Dies at 68
description: Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, the Superintendent of New York City's vast public school system from 1965 to 1969 in a tumultous era of teachers strikes and struggles over decentralization and community control of schools, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. He was 68 years old.

title: Striving for 100%, 100% of the Time
description: FOR all the talk about giving 110 percent of effort, the mathematical, biological, psychological fact is that an athlete does not have more than 100 percent to give, even under ideal conditions. When the conditions are less than ideal  when there are four games in four cities in five nights after overnight flights, rushed meals at odd hours, little time for preparation, and nagging injuries  it is unreasonable to expect maximum effort from every player in every game. And when financially secure athletes play for nearly six months just for a playoff spot, it might be foolish to expect it.

title: Chess:
description: Of the qualifiers for next year's world championship Candidates Matches from the Riga Interzonal Tournament, only Lev Polugaevsky, the Russian Grandmaster, had made it into the previous cycle. There, he defeated Enrique Mecking of Brazil in their quarterfinal match, but was poleaxed by Viktor Korchnoi, 84, in the semifinal.

title: Libyan Government Plans to Build 23Story Tower on East 48th Street
description: The Libyan Government, prospering from soaring oil prices, plans to construct a 23story headquarters in midManhattan to provide offices and residences for its United Nations delegation and consulate staff.

title: Deatha
description: ASCHERDavid. Beloved husband of Mary. Devoted brother of Helene Richmond, Sidney and Ell Ascher. Services Monday October 29 at 12:15 PM at The Riverside, 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave.

description: Music

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Lease Sale Set Off Alaska
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Oct. 28 (AP) Gov. Jay Hammond and Interior Secretary Cecil D. Andrus announced that they had reached agreement to allow a Federalstate offshore oillease sale for tracts in the Beaufort Sea

title: Inquiry in Texas Finds Employers Cheating Aliens
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 28  In several weeks of investigation, a Department of Labor team has found that 40 of 63 local employers it checked were shortchanging alien workers by paying them less than the Federal minimum wage, by not paying for overtime or by not compensating them fully for all hours worked.

title: Poll on Primary Finds Kennedy and Reagan Lead New Hampshire
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts leads President Carter by a 3to1 margin among potential New Hampshire Democratic primary voters, and Ronald Reagan remains the heavy favorite among the state's Republicans, according to the University of New Hampshire's latest statewide Poll.

title: United Press International
description: DEATH TOLL RISES TO 30 IN KOREAN MINE FIRE: Korean coal miner being helped by comrades yesterday after his rescue from a mine in Munkyong, South Korea, 80 miles south of Seoul. An underground fire trapped 128 workers in the mine on Saturday and rescue efforts were hampered until the blaze could be brought under control and the shaft cleared of smoke and gas. Thirty miners were killed in the accident and 11 are still missing.

title: 8 Men Hold Up Players At Brooklyn Card Party
description: Eight to 10 men armed with machine guns, shotguns and pistols invaded a card party at the Brighton Beach Jewish Center in Brooklyn early yesterday morning and left an hour later with three garbage cans containing more than $100,000 in cash and Jewelry, the nolice said.

title: Rangers, in Slump, Tied by Whalers, 22
description: In the dressing room, after a disappointing 22 tie with the Hartford Whalers last night, the New York Rangers were analyzing themselves. The facts at hand were that the team, noted for its offense, had scored only six goals in its last three games. The Rangers lost two of those games, tied one and looked like something other than the Stanley Cup finalists they were only five months before.

title: New Yankee Pilot Is Awed by the Job
description: Dick Howser met with George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, last August to arrange game next spring against Howser's Florida State University team. Howser admitted last night, after Steinbrenner had named him manager of the team, that he was awed by the fact that he would be managing the Yankees, not coaching Florida State, in that game.

title: Police Officer and Friend Stabbed at Park in Bronx
description: An offduty police officer and a friend were dragged from their car and stabbed repeatedly by five men in the Throgs Neck section of the Bronx late Saturday night, the police said, and five men were arrested early yesterday morning.

title: Miss Goolagong Routs Miss Wade
description: OLDSMAR, Fla., Oct. 28 (AP) Thirdseeded Evonne Goolagong needed only a bit more than an hour to score a 60, 63 victory over Virginia Wade today and win a $100,000 women's tennis tournament.

title: Deaths
description: EVN INOscar. Well beloved husband, father, grandfather. May he sleep In peace. Services Monday 2:15 PM at The Riverside Chapel, 76th St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: It Takes Character to Be a Character Actor
description: ON the fourth floor of a building near Times Square, there is a studio used by Broadway casting directors for auditions and interviews. It is a drab place: the plastic on the chairs is peeling, the Formica tables have been burned by cigarettes, and the fluorescent lights burn with a kind of bleak intensity. Broadway Dave, an inveterate collector of autographs who frequents the neighborhood, wanders in and asks several of the waiting actors if they are anybody important, and if so, could he please have their signatures. Receiving no response, he shrugs and leaves in search of more promising prospects.

title: HALLOWEEN FESTIVAL: Yesterday's ghoulish weather could not restrain the enthusiasm of these youngsters as they watched tricks and received treats during a Halloween party sponsored by a New York publisher inside the Citicorp Center on Lexington Avenue.
Sporting Gear
description: Safe Fishing Gaffs

title: Nets Defeat Rockets, End 6Game Streak
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Oct. 28  It was the first time since the Nets seasonopening victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers that the New Jersey coach, Kevin Loughery, had worn anything other then a sullen expression following a same.

title: Advertising
description: Thompson Stressing Growth

title: Saints Defense Halts Redskins, 141 0
description: A week ago, the Washington Redskins used a rugged defensive effort to down the Philadelphia Eagles and move into contention in the National Football Conference's Eastern Division. Yesterday, the Redskins got strong dose of defensive medicine from the New Orleans Saints, who won, 1410 in Washineton

title: Lisa Tarnapol Rides Rumours to Victory
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 28  Lisa Tarnapol rode Rumours, a mount who has won steadily on the Eastern circuit all season, to the small workinghunter championship today at the Washington International horse show.

title: Hussein Calling on Arabs to Offer Their Own Framework for Peace
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 28  Saying that the EgyptianIsraeli negotiations on Palestinian autonomy are foundering, King Hussein of Jordan says he is trying to get the other Arab nations to seize the initiative and come up with their own framework for a comprehensive peace settlement in the Middle East

title: Ghana Aims to Revive Cocoa
description: ACCRA, Ghana  Faced with a sharp decline in its vital cocoa production and vigorous competition from its neighbor, the Ivory Coast, and from Brazil, Ghana is making a belated but spirited attempt to overhaul its cocoa industry and regain its position as the world's No. 1 exporter of cocoa.

title: De Gustibus A Touch of Americana In Strange Food Names
description: Although many Americans tend to view the names of certain British foods with wry amusement, this nation has its own share of odd appellations in the kitchen. Consider, if you will, things like Hoppin John, blueberry grunt and apple pandowdy. The Indians gave us succotash and the South contributed corn dodgers, corn pone and hush puppies. New England provided us with that oddment among breads called anadama, so named because the husband of a lazy wife named Anna created a bread in anger and desperation, all the time muttering Anna, damn er.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Verdi's Aida, 8. BENEFIT CONCERT FOR REFUGEES IN INDOCHINA, Avery Fisher Hall, 8.

title: North Calls Park Death A Sign of Social Chaos
description: TOKYO, Oct. 28 (Reuters)  North Korea said today that the killing of President Park Chung Hee reflected growing political crisis and social chaos in South Korea.

title: Inmate, Held 42 Years, Scorns His Pardon
description: SOMERS, Conn.  After 42 years in prison, bitterly struggling for vindication and freedom, the prospect of imminent release leaves John A. Palm unmoved.

title: ESSAY Prelude To The Bridge
description: WASHINGTON The date was March 26, 1958. Deputy Sheriff T. M. Whitten of Albemarle County, Va., was in his police cruiser that evening at the intersection of U.S. 29 and the U.S. 250 bypass when he spotted a car speeding.

title: Notes on People
description: Amital Etxonl, the sociologist, is leaving Columbia University after 22 years and taking his services to George Washington University. There, starting next July, he will hold the title of university professor, which means he may teach courses beyond a single discipline.

title: Carol Singer, Candidate For a Ph.D, Is Married
description: Carol M. Singer and Daniel Bricklin were married yesterday in Temple Beth El in Sudbury, Mass., by Rabbi Lawrence Kushner.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Israeli Cabinet Agrees to Move Site Of Outpost Called Illegal by Court
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 28 The Israeli Cabinet decided today that a settlement that the Supreme Court has ruled was illegal would be moved to a new site on the occupier! West Bank.

title: In Hands of Stone Carvers, Eskimo Tradition Clings to Life
description: FROBISHER BAY, Northwest Territories  Tagoonarak is uncertain how old he is, where he was born or how his name is spelled in English. But he is sure of one thing: He loves to carve.

title: AT HOME ABROAD The Energy Disaster: II
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 28 The next OPEC meeting is scheduled to be held in Caracas starting Dec. 17. Will there be another oil price increase? Venezuela's Minister of Energy and Mines, Humberto Calderon Berti, shook his head.

title: TV: On a Deadly Drug
description: ANGEL DEATH, an effective examination of the perils of phencyclidine hydrochloride, better known as PCP or angel dust, narrated by Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward, will be shown from 8 to 9 o'clock tonight on WNEWTV.

title: Stage: Emigrs, Drama Of Exiles, at Brooklyn
description: IT is a classic theatrical coupling. One man is tall, highstrung and intellectual. The other is short, easygoing and downtoearth  a hard worker as contrasted to his indolent roommate. In common, they are exiles from the same unnamed country, characters in Slawomir Mrozek's Emigres, which opened last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, as a production of the Dodger Theater.

title: Volcker Takes Issue With Schultze On Inflation and Talks of Fed's Error
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28  Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, took issue today with the suggestion by a leading Administration economist that the nation might have to endure an inflation rate of 8 to 9 percent over a Iong period of time.

title: Outdoors: DoItYourself Firewood
description: JOGGING and hiking are excellent conditioners of body and spirit, but cutting and splitting your own firewood does the same and offers an additional reward.

title: Cost of Bridge Across L.I. Sound Could Run as High as $1.4 Billion
description: To construct a bridge across Long Island Sound linking Long Island with the New England mainland could cost as much as $1.4 billion and provide employment for 18,000 people, according to study released by the New York State Department of Transportation.

title: Networks Gird for 'sweep Ratings
description: Television will look different next month, so different that it will be as though the sixweekold fall season had never begun. Eight of the new weekly series introduced in September, having failed to make their mark in the popularity ratings, are being temporarily retired. A ninth, Working Stiffs, has been officially canceled by CBS.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partlal list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Salute to Fighter
description: Tony Galento Jr. affixing sign yesterday renaming Lackawanna Plaza in Orange, N.J., in memory of his father, Tony (Two Ton) Galento, the heavyweight boxer.

title: TENANTS ARE SOUGHT;FOR BIG RENT REFUND
description: TenantS of 4,800 federally financed housing projects in every state and in Puerto Rico are being sought to share up to $130 million in rent refunds under a settlement that is one of the largest ever reached in a consumer action against the Government.

title: Bond Trade Adapting to A New Era
description: The credit market, reacting to what some saw as its most important challenge in almost 30 years, has begun to adapt to newly volatile conditions. But market experts are also voicing some feeling of no confidence in the antiinflation program that brought the new era into being and are wondering whether it will last.

title: Alice Whittesley Wed to Frederic Krieger
description: Alice Tappen Whittelsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Whittelsey Jr. of Merion, Pa., and Frederic Michael Krieger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Krieger of Wilmington, Del., were married yesterday in Merion. The ceremony was performed at the Merion Tribute House by Rabbis Richard F. Steinbrink and Wayne Franklin.

title: U.S. BUDGET DEFICIT OF $10 BILLION SEEN AS POSSIBLE FOR 81
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28  President Carter's budget planners calculate that the budget now being drafted for the fiscal year 1981 could show a deficit of $10 billion to $15 billion without any tax cut, officials reported over the weekend.

title: Ohira and Challengers in Party Are Locked in Political Impasse
description: TOKYO, Oct. 28 With the opening of the newly elected House of Representatives only two days away, Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira and his rivals within the governing Liberal Democratic Party remain locked in a political impasse over challenges to Mr. Ohira's leadershin

title: Opera: Viennese Sing Tidelioin Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Oct.28 The Vienna State Opera had its gala opening last night at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts with a performance of Beethoven's FideIto conducted by Leonard Bernstein. Friday evening had seen a SchuDert concert with the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Karl Bohm, but that was in the nature of an appetizer.

title: John A. Stephens, Top Negotiator For U.S. Steel With Labor, at 84
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28 John A. Stephens, former chief labor negotiator for the United States Steel Corporation, died Friday in his home in suburban Sewickley. He was 84 years old.

title: Soprano: Magda Olivero
description: THE indomitable and apparently indestructible Magda Olivero returned to New York for a recital in Carnegie Hall Saturday night. Her career is now in its 47th year, and the facts say that she will be 70 next March. If time has not exactly stood still for her, it has nonetheless moved slowly. She has made few concessions to age, tackling arduous roles and their high C's with power, brilliance and dramatic ferocity.

title: The Junk Crisis in Nuclear Medicine
description: The governors of three states have created a crisis for hospitals and research laboratories by refusing store any more nuclear junk. Threefifths of the junk, officially called lowlevel radioactive waste, comes from the nuclear power industry, chiefly in the form contaminated clothing, equipment, filters and sludge. But most of the rest comes from biomedical institutions that use radioactive materials to diagnose and treat disease and perform experiments. The governors are reacting to a genuine problem of inept handling and poor planning. But the total ban on further shipments to Washington and Nevada and severe restrictions in South Carolina threaten to disrupt some of the nation's most valuable biomedical programs.

title: The Legacy Of Black Sox
description: BOWIE KUHN owes his job to crooked gamblers. The baseball establishment was terrified when it was discovered that surething bettors had bribed key players on the Chicago White Sox to lose the 1919 World Series to the Cincinnati Reds. Fearful lest the revelations of dishonesty destroy public faith in the game and sweep away their investment, the owners hired Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis off the Federal bench to replace the threeman National Commission then administering their business.

title: Arnold Soboloff, 48, Actor in Peter Pan, Is Stricken Backstage
description: Arnold Soboloff, a Broadway, movie and television actor, suffered a coronary attack minutes after exiting the stage during last night's performance of Peter Pan, the Broadway musical, and was pronounced dead at St. Clare's Hospital at 9:10 p.m. He was 48 years old.

title: Parachutist From Balloon Falls
description: STATESVILLE, N.C., Oct. 28 (AP) Two parachutists collided in the air today, sending one of them plummeting to his death, the authorities said.

title: Deaths
description: KUKLINDeane. Of Pelham Manor, N.Y., on Oct. 27, 1979, loving mother of Anthony and Jeffrey, sister of Sidney Cable, also survived by six grandchildren. Services private.

title: Walcoal Bids for Olga
description: The Walcoal Corporation of Japan said yesterday that it had made an offer to acquire the outstanding shares of the Olga Corporation, a maker of woman's undergarments based in Van Nuys, Calif. Walcoal owns about 30 percent of Olga's outstanding stock, reportedly numbering a million shares, and is offering to pay $16.75 in cash for each of the remaining shares.

title: Staubach Tingling All Over in Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH

title: Neighbors Angry After Explosion At Cuban Office
description: Residents of an East Side block where bomb exploded outside the Cuban Mission to the United Nations on Saturday night spent yesterday cleaning glass from their apartments and sidewalks and voicing anger over the presence of the mission.

title: JOHN PALFREY DIES; EXCOLUMBIA DEAN
description: Jonn Gorham Palfrey, a professor of law at Columbia University since 1956 and a member of the Atomic Energy Commission from 1962 to 1966, died of cancer yesterday in Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 60 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Sharon. Conn.

title: Firemen Deliver Baby In a Brooklyn Grocery
description: A baby boy came into the world feet first on the floor of a Brooklyn grocery  thanks to two firefighters from Ladder Comnanv 108.

title: FRED P. MURPHY, 90, EXCHIEF OF GROLIER
description: Fred P. Murphy, the honorary chairman of Grolier Inc., who led his company into business enterprises beyond the reference book field, died Saturday at his home in Stamford, N.Y. He was 90 years old.

title: Kuwait Wants Arab Conference To Discuss More Than Lebanon
description: KUWAIT, Oct. 28 (Reuters)  Kuwait's Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, Sheik Sabah alAhmed alSabah, said today that his country would prefer that an Arab summit conference discuss the entire Middle East situation as well as the situation in Lebanon.

title: Georgia Closing In on Bowl
description: Sugar Bowl officials are not very happy about Georgia's four straight Southeastern Conference victories following the Bulldogs three seasonopening losses in nonconference games. As each week goes by, it appears more likely that Georgia will be the host team in the Sugar Bowl instead of Alabama, a team expected to continue to an undefeated regular season.

title: $6.75 Billion US. Offering Due
description: The Treasury is scheduled to sell $6.75 billion of notes and bonds this week, and nobody has a clear idea of what the securities are going to yield.

title: Plane Carryirng a Family Hits House, Killing Girl
description: CONCORD, Mass., Oct. 28 (AP) singleengine plane carrying a family of four crashed into an unoccupied house near the center of Concord late today, killing the pilot's 12yearold daughter. The pilot, his wife and another daughter were seriously injured.

title: Patricia Kallman Bride of Robert V. Gaulin
description: Patricia Beth Kallman and Robert V. Gaulin, New York lawyers, were married yesterday at the Westchester Country Club In Rye, N.Y. Associate Judge Jacob D. Fuchsberg of the State Court of Appeals performed the ceremony. The bride is with the law firm of Robson & Toboroff and her husband is with Friend, Perles, Dorfman & Kleefeld.

title: Piano: Zenaida Manfugas
description: ZENAIDA MANFUGAS put together a grueling program of Spanish piano music Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall. She began with Scarlattilike sonatas by Mateo Albeniz and Joaquin Rodrigo, and a sonatina by Xavier Montsalvatge. Then came Book II of Albniz's Iberia, and the hourlong Goyescas of Granados.

title: Last of Vienna's Great Carriage Makers
description: VIENNA  It might be this year's perfect Christmas gift for the horsefancier who loves snow and has just about everything. Josef Klicmann, the last of Vienna's great carriagemakers, says he is prepared to make a sleigh lust like the Empress Maria Theresa's in the 18th century for anyone prepared to pay the $30,000 or so he estimates it might cost.

title: Around the Nation
