description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 23 (AP)  A Mexican Government airplane flying American prisoners to a border exchange struck a telephone pole in dense fog and burst into flames early today, killing all 10 persons aboard, including four Americans, officials said.

title: Decline in Productivity in US. Spurs Intense Debate and Study
description: Because of inflation, the decline of the dollar and concern that a malaise has come to grip America, a recent abrupt decline in productivity is being given extensive scrutiny.

title: The City
description: An advisory committee to the Metropolitan Transportation Association recommended yesterday that minor subway offenses, such as spitting and writing graffiti, be processed before citizens panel rather than in the city's crowded criminal courts.

title: John McLellan, an N.H.L. Coach
description: John McLellan, the assistant general manager of the Toronto Maple Leafs and the winner of the National Hockey League coach of the year award in 197071, died Saturday of an apparent heart attack after raking leaves in the front lawn of his home in Agincourt, Ontario, a suburb of Toronto. He was 51 years old.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Justice Dept. Won't Use Tax Funds To Continue the Work of Dr. King
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)  The Carter Administration has shelved a request that the Government atone for harassment by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. by using public funds to carry on the work of the slain civil rizhts leader.

title: Pitt's Marino Questions N.C.A.A. Rule on Professionals
description: PITTSBURGH

title: Giants Down Rams, 2044; 4th in Row
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28  Not since Charlie Conerly was the Giants quarterback had the Giants beaten the Los Angeles Rams. Not since Dwight D. Eisenhower was President had they beaten the Rams out here.

title: Aspin Disputes Young Account
description: Mr. Young's resignation as chief American delegate to the United Nations in August.

title: 2 Held, but Boston Art Isn't Found
description: BOSTON, Oct. 28  None of the 50 or more golden coins, pieces of jewelry and decorative objects stolen from the Museum of Fine Art's Asiatic Wing here have yet been recovered, despite the arrest of a security guard last week.

title: City Had 86% of Arrests Under New Juvenile Act
description: New York City accounted for 86 percent of all youngsters arrested in the state for certain violent crimes during the first year of a stricter juvenile justice law.

title: Mrs. Thatcher, Greeting Hua, Stresses China Ties
description: LONIDON, Oct. 28  Prime Minister Hua Guofeng of China was given an enthusiastic welcome today when he arrived in Britain on the third leg of his West European tour.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1979

title: Associated Press
description: WINS IN LOUISIANA: David C. Treen, the only Republican can& date in a nonpartisan gubernatorial primary, after victory. Page A16.

title: Chairman Hua in the West: PraOmatic, Flexible, Curious
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Oct. 28 Twothirds of the way through the first trip ever made to the West by a Chinese Prime Minister and Party Chairman, Hua Guofeng has shown himself to be pragmatic, flexible when possible, and determined to reinforce China's opening to the world of capitalism.

title: Books of The Times
description: T HERE is more pleasure to be found in this elegant little book than in most of the heavybreathing tomes that have, in recent years, oppressed a reviewer's brow and numbed his feet. The apocalyptic is not P.B. Medawar's mode. The

title: The Region
description: LONG BEACH, L.I. (UPI)  An automobile was stolen from a diner here early yesterday as a 5yearold boy slept in the back seat.

title: Park's Bodyguard Was Hated by Korean Officials
description: SEOUL, Oct. 28  Cha Chi Chol, 45 years old, was the first man that Kim Jae Kyu, the director of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency, shot with his Smith & Wesson revolver Friday before turning the gun on President Park Chung Hee.

title: Bridge:
description: To pick up the hand of a lifetime and wind up with a minus score is a deflating experience for anyone, but the ignominy increases substantially if partner is able to point out that a slightly more thoughtful approach to the problem would have left the partnership better off to the extent of about 2,700 points.

title: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900: WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.
Burns, Crenshaw Take Team Golf
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, FLA., Oct. 28 (AP)  George Burns and Ben Crenshaw combined for a finalround 65 and a fourround total of 255 that broke par by 33 strokes and won the National Team golf championship today.

title: AS CONSUMERS SAVE WATER, RATES GO UP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 In communities scattered all across the country, spurred on by utilities, conservationminded citizens are saving water and their good deed is rewarded with higher rates and higher water bills.

title: JapanChina Trade Up
description: TOKYO, Oct 27 (Reuters)  Trade between Japan and China in 1979 will probably rise to a record of between $7 billion and $7.2 billion, compared with $5.08 billion last year, the Japan External Trade Organization said. The semiofficial tradepromotion agency said that for the first nine months of 1979, twoway trade rose by 44.6 percent to $4.92 billion from the corresponding period of 1978 and that Japan's trade surplus with China was up to $701 million from $591 million a year earlier.

title: Ballet Theater's Offer Rejected, Lockout Is On
description: Dancers of the American Ballet Theater have voted unanimously to reject the company's latest offer of a 22 percent package increase over three years. With no negotiating sessions scheduled and a lockout announced by management to start today, the dancers  members of the American Guild of Musical Artists  gathered over the weekend to plan picketing, to start at noon at the Ballet Theater offices on Seventh Avenue.

title: Tool Orders Climb 64%
description: New orders for machine tools in September rose 69 percent from the yearearlier level. Factors in the strong rise Included a surge of orders from overseas and strong domestic demand from such sources as the automobile and aerospace industries.

title: Jets Beaten In Overtime
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 28 A becalmed sea of blue Oiler pompons erupted like a tidal wave at the Astrodome today suddendeath overtime, and that meant that the Jets had lost.

title: Still Befogged
description: There is, of course, an eerie sense of dj vu as the nation commemorates the 50th anniversary of the stockmarket crash. History celebrates the Crisis of 29 with the Crisis of 79.

title: Washington Watch
description: Clashing on Aid To World Bank

title: Issue and Debate Westchester Considers Con Ed Takeover
description: Proposition No. 1, as it will appear atop Westchester County ballots on Nov. 6, is a local issue. But television spots calling on voters to reject it have been seen throughout the New York metropolitan area in recent weeks, and that is appropriate, because the consequences of passage or rejection go well beyond county lines.

title: The President's Test Is Vegetables
description: Some Smaller but still important tests lurk in the trade area. Consumers finally won one when the House beat back efforts to raise sugar price supports. Now President Carter can rebuff the special interests that want to tax Americans at the checkout counter. His issue is the price of winter vegetables  tomatoes, peppers, eggplants, squash, cucumbers  from Mexico.

title: Reader's Digest Articles To Appear in Book Form
description: The Reader's Digest has made an agreement with Berkley Publishing Corporation, the paperback publisher, to bring the contents of the Reader's Digest to a massmarket audience in book form. It is the first time the material has been made available to a massmarket publisher.

title: Letters
description: Albany's Burden in New York's Hospital Troubles

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Alexander & Baldwin Inc., Honolulubased company involved in in ocean transportation, sugar production and property development and management, has elected Gilbert E. Cox chairman and chief executive officer and Robert J. Pheiffer president and chief operating officer.

title: Commodities
description: Squeezing The Market In Silver

title: Mays to Reveal Decision Today
description: Willie Mays, who was told by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn that he would have to disassociate himself from the New York Mets if he went to work for a hotelgambling casino owned by Bally Manufacturing Company, is to announce today whether he will sign a 10year, $1 million contract with the hotel.

title: Dance: Second Ballet at the Beacon
description: THE second Ballet at the Beacon program Saturday afternoon at the Beacon Theater offered some interesting novelties. The good turnout suggested again that a mixed program of excerpts with foreign and American dancers appeals strongly to the ballet public.

title: House G.O.P. Freshmen Are Speaking Up on Party Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 There was time when freshmen Congressmen, like obedient children, were seen but never heard on Capitol Hill. However, the current class of Republican newcomers to the House of Representatives is making lot of noise and attracting a lot of attention.

title: New York Stock Exchange Faces Challenge
description: The New York Stock Exchange, which survived the devastating crash of 1929, the subsequent formation of the Securities and Exchange Commission and cycle after cycle of good markets and bad markets, is now facing its toughest challenge: whether it will modernize fast enough to forestall being replaced, and by a computer system not of its own design.

title: Iran Threat on Oil
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 28 (Reuters)  Employees of Iran's oil industry threatened today to cut crudeoil exports to the United States unless Washington agreed to extradite the Shah. The Shah is in a New York hospital. Doctors removed his gall biadder on Wednesday and said he had a 5050 chance of surviving cancer of the lymph glands.

title: 2 Hasidic Sects Clash In Brooklyn Synagogue
description: Approximately 100 members of two Hasidic sects clashed last night in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, synagogue in a dispute apparently growing out of fight between two of their members in Israel.

title: 29 and 79
description: ROME  Black Tuesday, which signaled the plunge of the entire world economy into crisis, happened in the United States, the very country that had seemed immune to economic crises and had taken the leadership of world capitalism  not in the European countries, though they too had known inflation and depression in the 1920's. The fact that the crisis started at the summit of the capitalist system made it tangibly clear that it was sick structure unable to recover by itself. This led to a growing awareness of the need for socialism. The ensuing debate on what a socialist system and society should be like was not always positive because it led to a tendency to see an allout contradiction between a market economy and a planned economy.

title: SOMALIA STRUGGLING WITH REFUGEE FLOW
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Oct. 22 fourday celebration of the 10th anniversary of the Government of Mohammed Siad Barre ended quietly here today, and the Government returned to the problems it faces from a continuing guerrilla war with Ethiopia, including a staggering daily flow of refugees.

title: Women at Yale: Looking Back at a Decade of Change
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct 28 Women at Yale College. Thtmderation and will wonders never cease? That's the way it was a decade ago, when undergraduate women for the first time entered a supremely male bastion.

title: Kennedy Allies Reunited By Prospect of 1980 Race
description: Senator Edward M. Kermedy's budding Presidential candidacy is returning to the political scene some New York politicians who have moved out of the limelight since the heyday of the Kennedys, between 1960 and 1968.

title: Nuclear Foes Rally in a Prelude to Wall Street Protest
description: About 2,000 antinuclear demonstrators gathered in the rain yesterday in front of the World Trade Center to hear speakers decry corporate investment in nuclear power.

title: Quebec Power Project
description: JAMES BAY, Quebec, Oct. 28  A modest 333 megawatts of electric power, enough, officials say, to operate 220,000 toasters simultaneously and continuously, are now coursing through 650 miles of new transmission lines from this bleak northern wilderness along La Grande river to the south.

title: Chief of Public Employees Union Gains Backing in New York State
description: Jerry Wurf, who is seeking reelection as the president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, received an endorsement during the weekend from the head of a 220,000member union of New York State employees.

title: Ellen R. Winer Married To Steven Louis Galetta
description: Ellen Ruth Winer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Winer of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Steven Louis Galetta, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Galetta of Brooklyn. Justice of the Peace Wesley Rouse performed the ceremony at the Harrison Inn in Southbury. Conn.

title: Market Place
description: Home Swapper Saves Money

title: Lisette Simon Bride of Paul Jacobs, Lawyer
description: Lisette Simon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Simon of New York and Paris, was married yesterday to Paul Jacobs, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Jacobs of Jamesburg, N.J., and Sarasota, Fla. The ceremony was performed at the Simons Manhattan apartment by Rabbi Richard S. Chapin of Temple EmanuEl.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Stockholders of the Walco National Corporation have voted a yearly pension of $100,000 for 10 years to Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn, who retired as chairman at the end of 1978. The vote was taken during their annual meeting in New York.

title: Yanks Oust Martin as Manager And Revlace Him With Howser
description: Billy Martin, a tempestuous figure in his 11 years as a major league baseball player and 10 as a manager, was replaced by Dick Howser last night as the Yankee manager. It was the second time in 15 months that Martin had lost the job.

title: Steelers Rattle Cowboys
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28  It was to be a reprise, an encore, of the last Super Bowl game, but as the Dallas coach, Tom Landry, said, Rematches are never as good as the originals.

title: Bill to Phase Out Regulation Q in Peril
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28  Legislation that would phase out interest rate ceilings on all consumer deposits has become imperiled in the Senate by the lastminute opposition of some thrift institutions and smaller commercial hanks.

title: Californians Favor Propositions to Halt Busing and Limit Spending
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 Two proposed state constitutional amendments one that would limit school busing for racial balance and one that would impose ceiling on spending by state and local governments  appear to have overwhelming support among voterc

title: U.S. Deploys Carrier and Planes To Deter Action by North Korea
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 Secretary of Defense Harold Brown announced today that an American aircraft carrier and radar warning planes were being sent to South Korea to deter North Korea from taking military advantage of the political confusion following the killing of President Park Chung Hee,

title: Ada Miller Bride Of Dr. Richard Ress
description: Ada Diane Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie P. Miller of Rye Town, N.Y., and Dr. Richard R. Ress, son of Shirley Roset Ress of Teaneck, N.J., and Warren L. Ress of Hackensack, N.J., were married yesterday. Rabbi Joseph Speiser performed the ceremony at Kneses Tifereth Israel in Rye Town.

title: Trans World Girds Against Bid
description: Every few years, it seems, Trans World Airlines gets into a lifeordeath struggle. That legacy apparently has been passed on to its holding company, the Trans World Corporation, which is planning a spirited defense against a new takeover threat.

title: Clyde
description: Walt Frazier, the former New York Knick guard, has cleared waivers in the National Basketball Association. Unless some team signs him  unlikely, given the fact that he is now 34 the career of one of basketball's premier performers has come to a close. Walt Frazier was more than just a fine player. He represented the Knicks glory days: he was Clyde.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Tea With a Living Buddha
description: LHASA, Tibet  Living Buddhas were once ensconced in mystic splendor in the temples of Tibet, enthroned and worshiped at a distance. Nowadays it is easy to have a cup of tea or a chat with scme of those who stayed behind when the Dalai Lama fled.

title: Seoul Debating Whether to Shift Succession Rules
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Monday, Oct. 29  Behind the scenes of official mourning, an urgent debate has begun here on how, and with whom, to fill the gap left by the death of President Park Chung Hee, the tough and autocratic man who came to power following a coup in 1961 and in recent years ruled this nation of 39 million people almost singlehandedly.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Off the Beaten Track

title: YVONNE GREGORY
description: Yvonne Gregory, a writer and poet whose work appeared in national black publications in the 1940's and 1950's, died of cancer Friday in Bellevue Hospital. Miss Gregory, who for many years made her home in Manhattan, was 60 years old.

title: Dance: Annabelle Gamson Presents 3 New Works
description: ISADORA DUNCAN'S ghost haunted the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday night. The program  the second of the concerts arranged by Annabelle Gamson under the title From Isadora to Pilolxilus  featured solos to Russian music and there were three new works. Yet the most impressive offering was Miss Gamson's interpretation of the monumental solo that Miss Duncan created in 1916 to portions of Tchaikovsky's Sixth Symphony (the Path tique).

title: TV: Ali in Fast's Freedom Road
description: A GLARING distinction of Freedom Road is that it takes Muhammad Ali, certainly one of the more vibrant personalities of this century, and makes him dull. Years in the making costing more than $7 million, the fourhour adaptation of Howard Fast's novel can be seen on NBCTV tonight and tomorrow at 9o'clock.

title: Senate Is Promised Arms Preview
description: WASHiNGTON, Oct. 28  The Carter Administration has promised to furnish preview of its military spending plans to the Senate within two weeks, according to Senator Robert C. Byrd, the majority leader. Some key senators have said they could not vote on the nuclear arms treaty without that information.

title: Carolyn S. Klaiman, Lawyer, Is Wed to Warren K. Racusin
description: Carolyn Sue Klaiman, a lawyer with the Criminal Defense Division of the Legal Aid Society in Brooklyn, and Warren Kent Racusin, an associate with the New York law firm of Schulte & McGoldrick, were married at noon yesterday in the Chanticler in Millburn, N.J. Rabbi Reuben Levine performed the ceremony.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Shower and thundershower clouds appear to blanket New England, the lake region, the Tennessee and Missouri Valleys and parts of the Pacific Northwest. Skies are clear elsewhere, except for thin clouds over the Intermountain Region.

title: Let's See Who Cares About Inflation
description: The Test for Congress Is Hospitals

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: World News Briefs
description: U.S. Official Calls Soviet Responsible for Hanoi Acts

title: Council Seeks Oil Profit Data
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)  Suspicious of the oil industry's soaring thirdquarter profits, the Council on Wage and Price Stability has asked for data on prices and profits from 20 of the largest refiners by Nov. 5, instead of waiting for the normal deadline at the end of November.

title: Thomas Byrnes Jr., Maeve M. Murtagh Wed in Bronxville
description: In St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville, N.Y., yesterday, Maeve Michele Murtagh, daughter of Mrs. John M. Murtagh of Bronxville and the late State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh, became the bride of Thomas Joseph Byrnes Jr. of Langhorne, Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. Byrnes of Crestwood. N.Y. The Rev. Eugene J. O'Brien performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. Christopher H. Daly.

title: Supplementary OvertheCounter Listings
description: Week Ended Oct. 26, 1979

title: Recital: Menzer, Pianist
description: EDWARD MENZER gave a proficient, wellschooled and frequently rewarding recital in Alice Tully Hall Saturday afternoon. As he demonstrated at his New York debut two years ago, the pianist possesses a surefingered technique that allows him to cultivate a warmly musical tone and handle a variety of styles with a sympathetic response to their expressive content.

title: County Executive's Race Spices Election in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 26  The temperature sign on the West New york Savings Bank Building on Main Stret blinked 38, and heavy, snow clouds hung over Lake Erie.

title: U.S. Experts Say Afghanistan's Civil War Has Reached Stalemate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28  The civil war in Afghanistan has reached a stalemate, United States Government analysts say, in which the army of President Hafizullah Amin controls Kabul and a handful of other cities, while insurgent forces operate with impunity in about half the country.

title: Rally Staged for Missing G.I.'s
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)  About 500 people gathered in front of the White House today to call attention to the nearly 2,500 Americans still listed as missing in Vietnam, according to the United States De At Pnlice. The demonstration was sponsored by the National League of Families of American Prisoners and missing in Southeast Asia. The rally began with a march from the Justice Department to Lafayette Park, across Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House.

title: U.S. Jewish Leader Walks Out During Talks With Snanish Aide
description: Theodore R. Mann, the head of a major American Jewish organization, abruptly walked out of a private meeting with the Spanish Foreign Minister last month when he was told that Spain would recognize Israel but it could take four years.

title: Sidney W. Davidson, Expert in Probate Law Managed Trust Funds
description: Sidney W. Davidson, a lawyer who specialized in trusts and estates and who was a longtime administrator of educational, philanthropic and medical institutions, died Saturday at his home in Brooklyn Heights. He was 85 years old.

title: City's Schools Seek to Attract Middle Class
description: Spurred by Mayor Koch's concern over the stability of New York City's middle class, School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola is seeking ways to make public education more attractive to middleclass families.

title: Text of Report on Park's Murder
description: An investigation nas revealed that the origin of the historic tragedy that occurred on the evening of Oct. 26, 1979 lies in an intentional plot hatched and executed by Kim Jae Kyu.

title: SEOUL LEADERS SAY K.C.I.A. CHIEF KILLED PARK IN POLICY RIFT
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Monday, Oct. 29  President Park Chung Hee was killed Friday in a premeditated plot led by the director of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency rather than shot accidentally as was first announced, the martial law command said yesterday.

title: Question Box
description: S. Lee Kanner

title: Going out Guide
description: MUSIC AND HEART Cabaret and recording artists are performing tonight in Greenwich Village to aid a young mother recently disabled by an accident. The public is also invited to share a concert tonight at Lincoln Center in memory of a slain student.

title: Weekly Lotto Numbers Drawn
description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 27, 38, 8, 24, 37 and 19. The supplementary number was 40.

title: A Benefit for Indochinese Is Effort to Find a Way
description: It brings me to tears that they're not letting the food into Cambodia with all that starvation, said Kazuko Hillyer, one of the producers of a benefit concert last night in Avery Fisher Hall. The benefit was for Indochinese refugees, and Mrs. Hillyer was talking about one of the unexpected frustrations of the task.

title: Profiting By Prison
description: Everyone agrees that victims should be compensated for their losses from crime, but there is public concern that this would increase taxes. The fact is we can both eat our cake and have it too, and here's how.

title: French Bow To British In Wine Test
description: PARIS, Oct. 29  Staggering from the effects of last month's wine olympiad run by the wine and food magazine The Nouveau Guide GaultMillau, in which American wines virtually wiped out their French competition, the French wine industry suffered another, if somewhat milder, blow over the weekend. In a lessthanserious wine competition sponsored by London's Evening Standard and Le Figaro here, the Englishmen swept the field.

title: State Museum Preserving City's History
description: ALBANY

title: European Officials High Life
description: BRUSSELS  Official Europe has discovered the threemartini lunch.

title: Secret Service Protection for 5 Candidates to Begin. Jan. 11.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 Under guidelines made public today by a Congressional advisory committee, Secret Service protection will begin Jan. 11 for certain declared Presidential candidates, They are those who have raised at least $1 million in compliance with Federal election laws or have received at least 10 percent of the total votes cast in two consecutive primaries.

title: The City
description: The New York City Police Department is planning to appoint 411 new officers on Nov. 7. They would be the vanguard of 1,100 scheduled to be added to the force by June 30 and would be the first new officers to be hired, since the city's fiscal problems forced layoffs of municipal employees in 1974.

title: Chicago SchoolBias Suit Is Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP)  The Government today gave up its effort to achieve a negotiated settlement with the Chicago school board and formally recommended that a desegregation suit be filed.

title: The Gambling Seahawks Defeat Falcons by 3128
description: Zorn, who scored one touchdown on 34yard run on fourth down and set up another with a 20yard pass to the Seattle placekicker, Efren Herrera, on fake field goal, added: Unusual maybe. You don't see it every day. But it's a blast. It's fun.

title: Music: Brooklyn Philharmonia
description: LUKAS FOSS and the Brooklyn Philharmonia began their 197980 season over the weekend with a joyous program of Mozart and Verdi at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Opera House. Mr. Foss, who does things differently, began with not one dizzy Mozart overture, but two 1 the Overture in the Italian Style (K. 318, better known as the onemovement Symphony No. 32) and the overture to The Marriage of Figaro. Portions of Figaro, Don Giovanni and Idomeneo followed. The Verdi excerpts were from La Traviata, Otello and Aida.

title: Output Rate Gains a Bit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP)  The productivity of American business and workers rose at an annual rate of onetenth of 1 percent in the third quarter after two consecutive quarters of sharp declines, the Labor Department reported today.

title: OBSERVER
description: Heating conservation tips:

title: Dome Reports Oil In Beaufort Sea
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Oct. 29 Dome Petroleum Ltd. announced today that it had encountered highly significant shows of crude oil in a second well in the Beaufort Sea about 300 miles eastnortheast of Prudhoe Bay. The company said. however, that further testing of its Nerlerk well would have to wait until next summer, when navigation will again be possible in the icy offshore area.

title: Congo Children Reportedly Sent Forcibly to Cuba
description: PARIS, Oct. 29  More than 1,000 young Congolese, 600 of them between the ages of 10 and 15, have reportedly been sent to Cuba for training that will last up to 15 years.

title: Metalworkers Strike in Brazil
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Oct. 29 (Reuters)  Thousands of metalworkers went on strike here today for higher pay, labor sources said. Union representatives said 170,000 metalworkers heeded a strike call made last night. But the regional labor office said only 30,000 failed to turn up for the morning shift.

title: Opera: Carter Attends 'salome
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 With President Carter in attendance last night, the Vienna State Opera gave the second of its series at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. The work was Salome by Richara Strauss. It was cluly noted by many in the audience that the President, a Baptist, was on hand to observe the operatic decapitation of the very first Baptist.

title: EDUCATION
description: WASHINGTON WORKING from cluttered quarters in a redbrick building near the White House, a team of management planners is giving final form to the new Department of Education, an agency that will begin life early next year with serious limitations on its mission.

title: Carey Offers Winter Heating Program With Aid for Poor and Oil Price Watch
description: ALBANY, Oct. 29  Governor Carey presented his proposals today for dealing with this winter's expected hOme heating problems, stressing Federal aid for the poor, energy conservation and state monitoring of oil prices and price gouging.

title: Bridge:
description: For some of the competitors, the 1979 Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship, seemed to take a long, long time. It was completed in exactly a year, just in time for the start of the 1980 event.

title: Conrail Plans To Cut Rates
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct.29 (AP) The Consolidated Rail Corporation has announced that it plans to reduce rates by about 5 percent for more than threefourths of its piggyback freight traffic, subject to Interstate Commerce Commission approval.

title: Northrop Sues to Keep Plane Work
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29  The Northrop Corporation has asked a Federal judge here to prevent the McDonnell Douglas Corporation from unilaterally offering to foreign companies contracts to manufacture certain parts of the F/ A18A Hornet fighter plane that Northrop had agreed to provide. At stake is Northrop's share of a possible Canadian contract valued at $3 million.

title: Cambodian Woman Flees to Thailand a 2d Time
description: BAN KAENG, Thailand, Oct. 28 For the second time, a brighteyed 18yearold Cambodian woman has escaped from Cambodia to a refugee camp in Thailand, and once again her brother has rushed here from Paris in the hope of being allowed to take her home with him.

title: Hospital Issues Appeal For White Blood Cells
description: Officials at the Brookdale Hospital Medical Center, 1275 Linden Boulevard and Rockaway Parkway in Brooklyn, issued a plea yesterday that persons with Bpositive blood volunteer to aid a 16yearold Queens youth with leukemia.

title: New Ecuador Regime Crippled by Feud Between Leaders
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Oct. 29  Personal antagonism between the President of Ecuador and his former mentor, the head of Congress, has paralyzed the new Government that musingly returned this country to democracy two months ago after nine years of dictatorship.

title: Restaurant Death Spot Under New Ownership
description: The Brooklyn restaurant where Carmine Galante was shot to death last July 12 while having lunch was closed soon after. Also slain in the shooting were the owner, who was a cousin of Mr. Galante's, and another man. The owner's son, John Turano Jr., also was shot, but he recovered.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: 3 Korean Generals Assume Major Roles
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Oct. 30About 2 A.M. Saturday, an American officer put through a phone call to the United States Ambassador to South Korea, William H. Gleysteen Jr., to tell him that President Park Chung Hee had been killed.

title: Locked Out Ballet Dancers Picket
description: Dancers of the American Ballet Theater took to the streets yesterday in tutus and velvet doublets to protest a lockout by Ballet Theater. The company declared the lockout yesterday following six months of negotiations with its dancers, members of the American Guild of Musical Artists on the ground that, without a contract, it had no guarantee the dancers would fulfill an engagement scheduled for the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington in early December.

title: The New York Times/ Vic DeLucia
description: Hugh Mutch leading Sandor over a hurdle during przialce yesterday in Central Park

title: Keystone Foods Credit
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 29 (Reuters)  The Keystone Foods Corporation said its Cattle Development Corporation subsidiary had entered into a twoyear $85 million credit agreement to finance its cattle management proEram. The bank erouo consists of the First Pennsylvania Bank, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, the Chemical Bank, Citibank and the First National Bank of Boston.

title: TV: Nova Takes a Look At Drugs in Athletics
description: RACE FOR GOLD, a docu; mentary on public televi; sion's Nova series, on WNETTV at 9 o'clock to; night, manages to be more disturbing than its producers intended. The subject is Me Milling of athletes, with the ultimate goal being a gold medal in the Olympic Games. The legitimate ques; tion: What price success?

title: A Day in the Political Life of Turkey: Shootings and Reprisals by Left and Right
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 28  It was typical day in Turkey.

title: Crash Could Not Happen Again, Heller, Galbraith and Greenspan Tell Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29  Today, on the 50th anniversary of the stock market crash, the Joint Economic Committee of Congress asked some allstars of the economics profession whether the events that ushered in the Great Depression could happen again. Their response: No, but watch some new curve balls, such as oilprice increases and oilrelated balanceofpayments deficits.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in Business Day last Thursday incorrectly stated the size of an acquisition offer by the Shamrock Broadcasting Company. Shamrock has offered to buy all nine radio stations of the San Juan Racing Association, according to Hyman N. Glickstein, chairman of San Juan.

title: Japan Volcano Shows Activity
description: TOKYO, Oct. 29 (UPI)  Billows of smoke and jets of steam spilled from Mount Ontake, a 10,100foot peak situated 120 miles west of Tokyo, yesterday morning. No reports of casualties or damage were received, the police said. It was the first recorded eruption from Ontake, one of the 66 active volcanoes scattered throughout the Japanese archipelago, officials said.

title: Backers of Amendment to Aid State Job Unit Are Uncertain It Will Pass
description: While there is virtually no organized opposition to a state constitutional amendment doubling the bonding limits of the New York State Job Development Authority, its supporters are concerned that the measure will be defeated by voters who react negatively to dollar signs on the ballot.

title: Senators List Concerns on Chrysler
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29  The chairman and ranking Republican member of the Senate Banking Committee have expressed concerns about virtually every aspect of the ailing Chrysler Corporation's rehabilitation plan and its bid for $750 million in loan guarantees.

title: Carter Urges Northeast Leaders To Back Oil Windfall Tax Plan
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 29  President Carter, stepping up his campaign for a tax on oil industry windfall profits, appealed today to a gathering of Northeastern governors and energy officials to help prevent what he said could become a trilliondollar giveaway to the oil companies.

title: Satellite to Map Earth's Magnetism
description: OF all the earth's ups and downs, the mountains and ocean trenches, the bulging equator and flattened poles, few are so subtle or more difficult to measure and map than the irregularities in the magnetic field of the earth's surface. The average strength of this crustal magnetism is about 50,000 gammas, roughly equivalent to that of a toy horseshoe magnet, and the variations from place to place are no more than 10 to 12 gammas.

title: MENDOR T. BRUNETTI,
description: Prof. Mendor T. Brunetti, a teacher of Romance languages at New York University for 54 years before his retirement in 1978, died Saturday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 85 years old.

title: Antinuclear Rally on Wall Street Brings 1,045 Arrests
description: The police arrested 1,045 antinuclear protesters yesterday after they attempted unsuccessfully to shut down the New York Stock Exchange by linking arms and blocking entrances to the exchange building on the 50th anniversary of the historic stock market crash of 1929.

title: Creative Chief Leaves Benton.
description: Alvin Hampel, the worldwide creative chief of Benton & Bowles, has decided at age 52 and after 10 years with the same company that he wants to do something else. After his resignation was an nounced yesterday, he said, There are several options, some in advertising, some not.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: $57 Million Sought for Facilities For MX Missile System on Coast
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP)  The Air Force asked Congress today for $57 million to build roads and facilities for the first test firing of the MX mobile missile scheduled for early 1983.

title: Service for Soboloff Today
description: A funeral service for Arnold Soboloff, the actor who died Sunday night during the second act of Peter Pan, in which he was appearing, will be held at 2 P.M. today at the Riverside, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street.

title: The Editorial Notebook; What Missile Gap?; Soviet Uncertainty; About U.S. Response Is Deterrent Enough
description: Much of the Senate debate over defense, set off by the SALT treaty, turns on dubious propositions about the Soviet Union's nuclear superiority in the future and America's in the past. Just how dubious can be seen in a recent speech by McGeorge Bundy that should get more attention in Washington and Western Europe.

title: U.S. Agency to Temporarily Ban Most Uses of the Pesticide DBCP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI)  The Environmental Protection Agency today announced a temporary ban on most uses of the pesticide DBCP.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Treasury bill rates in the Government's weekly auction declined yesterday for the first time since the Federal Reserve moved to tighten credit early this month.

title: DCL Sets Meeting On Liquidation
description: DCL Inc., a computer leasing company, said that its board had set Jan. 15 as the date for a special meeting of shareholders to consider the proposed complete liquidation of DCL.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Supreme Court to Rule On Patenting Life Forms
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29  The Supreme Court agreed today to resolve a question of increasing commercial importance in an era when new life forms can be readily created in the laboratory: whether the patent laws allow patents for living organisms.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Rooms Afire, 2 on Coast Leap to Death
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 (AP)  A man and a woman, trapped by flames on an 11thfloor ledge of their luxury apartment building, screamed for help and then leaped to their deaths with their dog, the authorities said today. A third resident died of smoke inhalation.

title: I'm the Same Billy Martin  Sadly
description: Dave Anderson

title: $800 Million Error Cited By Fed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29  The Federal Reserve Board disclosed today that an $800 million error had been discovered in the nation's money supply figures in addition to the $3.7 billion mistake reported last week.

title: Hasidim Differ About the Fight In Williamsburg
description: On the streets of the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, they are indistinguishable. The Satmar Hasidim and the Betz Hasidim dress in similar black gabardine coats and felt hats. They shun the modern world and immerse themselves in the practice of Jewish law and custom.

title: A Fair Test for Truth in Testing
description: The New York Legislature enacted a truth in testing law last June and we applauded the idea. Even then, however, it was clear that the testing industry could not meet the law's demands by Jan. 1, when it is scheduled to take effect. And now there is such panic and confusion over the law among testing companies, state officials and students that unless its effective date is delayed, it will do more harm than good.

title: Mortgage Rates Climb
description: Interest rates on residential mortgages continued to climb, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation reported yesterday as it announced the results of its weekly purchase of loans from savings and loan associations and other housing lenders. The average yield on the $24.3 million of mortgages it bought increased to a record 13.363 percent from 12.836 percent last week.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Cyanamid Company,  Wayne, N.J., a diversified chemical company, has elected George A. Midwood treasurer.

title: Money
description: Prime 1515

title: For Firemen, A Busy Hour
description: They fought a fire, caught a mugger and gave first aid to an epileptic, but the men of Engine Company 41 in the South Bronx said it was all in an hour's work.

title: Birmingham Runoff Today Is Focus of Racial Tensions
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 29  The mayoral runoff election tomorrow between a black City Councilman and white lawyer accused of waving the bloody shirt of racism has split this city's electorate along racial lines and, in the view of one political pollster, brought racial animosities here to their highest pitch since the civil rights demonstrations of 1963.

title: Kennedy Authorizes a Campaign Panel and Plans Declaration for Nov.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 Senator Edward M. Kennedy authorized the formation today of a Kennedy for President committee and announced that he would officially declare his candidacy on Nov. 7.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Scotto Denies Getting Payoffs on Waterfront In Testimony at Trial
description: Anthony M. Scotto began testifying in his own defense yesterday and asserted that he had never taken a cent for himself from any waterfront businessmen.

title: Rev. Walter Reilly, Former Head Of St. Ignatius Loyola School, 75
description: The Rev. Walter A. Reilly, former headmaster of the St. Ignatius Loyola School at 50 East 84th Street, died Sunday at a nursing home in White Plains after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: Some Showcases Settle With Equity
description: After delaying the start of their seasons for two months, following a dispute with Actors Equity over new work codes for showcase productions, most Off Off Broadway theaters have decided to proceed with their fall productions. The result is increased theatrical activity in the nonprofit arena, but with the future of Off Off Broadway itself still in question.

title: About New York
description: If folklore develops out of the way people live, it is noteworthy that parking in New York has apparently not yet produced great stories of our region. It is one of the challenges of urban life that has closely touched the people, a challenge that pits man as an individual against an impenetrable iron curtain that keeps him from space at the curb.

title: Stefan CongratButler, a Linguist
description: Stefan CongratButler, a lexicographer and the compiler of a pioneer directory, Translation and Translators, died of leukemia Saturday in his home in Manhattan. He was in his mid60's.

title: Senate Votes Bill to Aid Placement
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29  The Senate today passed by voice vote a bill that would encourage families to adopt hardtoplace children now trapped in the limbo of foster care  those who are handicapped, nonwhite or beyond babyhood.

title: Gustave W. Iser, 83; Architect Was Noted For Housing Projects
description: Gustave W. Iser, an architect who practiced in New York for many years designing apartment projects and religious and institutional buildings, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Hollywood, Fla. He was 83 years old.

title: Pay Panel's Debate on Guideline Is Inconclusive
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 After several hours of spirited, inconclusive debate, President Carter's Pay Advisory Committee today quietly buried the White House's hope that it would make recommendations by the end of the month for a revision of the voluntary standard for nay restraint.

title: EARNINGS
description: NL Industries yesterday reported a 38.3 percent rise in profits for the third quarter, and Ray C. Adam, chairman, said all operating groups had contributed to the record performance.

title: About Education
description: EVERY recent opinion poll about public education has cited discipline as the most serious problem and violence as a constant threat to teacher and student safety. A new study of the issue calls these fears exaggerated, and the disciplinary steps taken to combat school crime often ineffective and irrational.

title: The Doctor's World
description: HENRY, a healthy 55syearold businessman, was puzzled over losing 20 pounds without dieting during recent months and concerned when he ran a fever up to 101 degrees for two weeks. His doctor diagnosed a viral infection and prescribed aspirin, antibioncs and rest. But the weight loss and fever persisted despite a week's course of treatment. Henry entered a community hospital in Missouri for tests.

title: STATE DEPT. WOOING HISPANICAMERICANS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29  About 200 HispanicAmerican political, business and other leaders met at the State Department today for a daylong conference on foreign policy with an emphasis on interAmerican affairs.

title: Steel Output Slips
description: Steel production amounted to 2.406 million tons in the week ended Oct. 27, a decrease of 2 percent from the preceding week's 2.454 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry's production used 83.2 percent of capacity during the week, down from 84.8 percent the week before. Estimated figures for the year to date showed output at 114.102 million net tons, an increase of 2.6 percent from last year.

title: Appeal by Miss Fonda And Hayden for Data On Selves Is Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI)  Jane Fonda, the actress, and her husband, Tom Hayden, lost a court appeal today on a Freedom of Information Act request that the Government release intelligence reports about their activities.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Chicago Bank Signs China Pact
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 29 2014 The First National Bank of Chicago signed an agreement with China today that makes the bank a matchmaker for foreign companies seeking investment opportunities in China.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Hasbro Industries, a Pawtucket, R.I.based maker of toys and school supplies, announced yesterday that its board had authorized certain steps to be taken that could lead to the possible division of the company into two separate public corporations.

title: M.A.C. Sets 8% Rate In $90 Million Bond Sale
description: Longterm bonds of the Municipal Assistance Corporation of New York State were priced yesterday to yield 8 percent. This was well above the 7 percent set in a M.A.C. bond sale in August and the highest rate of return on these taxexempt bonds in three and a half years.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Were there ever spontaneous eruptions of natural gas or oil?

title: Corporate Reports
description: For periods as shown.(N ) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Prinair Commuter Flights Return
description: Puerto Rico International Airlines resumed service yesterday after being grounded by the Government for three days because of deficiencies uncovered in inspections of its operations ordered after a fatal crash in St. Croix, V.I., last July.

title: Milwaukee Rail Aid Plan Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP)  A plan to keep freight trains running for seven more weeks on the western lines of the financially troubled Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad was approved by a Senate committee today.

title: GOING OUT Gulde
description: COME ON ALONG It's time to get ready for the sixth Greenwich Village Halloween Parade, as a walker or watcher. The annual procession of costumed vampires, goblins, ghouls, witches, animals and bizarre creatures won an Obie Ward for artistic achievement  Ralph Lee directs the event and everybody from diaperwearers to the disco set is invited to join in. Assembly time tomorrow is 5:30 P.M. at the Westbeth Courtyard, 155 Bank Street.

title: Rep. Roberts Won't Run in 80
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI)  Representative Ray Roberts, Democrat of Texas, who is serving his 10th term in Congress, announced today that he would not seek reelection next year. Mr. Roberts, 66 years old, began public service in 1935 as director of the National Youth Administration under Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: TV: The Baby Makers
description: CBS REPORTS marks its 20th anniversary tonight with The Baby Makers, a study of artificial mamma; lian reproduction. The program, which will be seen from 8 to 9 o'clock, main; tains the high standards of this admira; ble series. It is a readily comprehensible, fairminded, resolutely unsensa; tional overview of a complex and trou; bling subject.

title: Glamorous Bryn Mawr: $8 Million for Unglamorous Work
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 29 Students ignore it and educators would rather not talk about it. But on many college campuses, building maintenance is declining even faster than student enrollment.

title: Kuhn Is Continuing Martin Case Inquiry; Dent, Spencer Sign
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's investigation into the latest Billy Martin episode is continuing and could be concluded in the next day or two, a spokesman for Kuhn said yesterday. However, the commissioner's findings will come too late to save Martin's job as manager of the Yankees, as Martin's lawyer had hoped.

title: COMMODES
description: Traders in silver futures continued to liquidate their positions yesterday in fesponse to restrictions imposed by the major metals exchanges in New York and Chicago last week.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Heavy clouds cover much of the Northeast and large parts of the Tennessee and Mississippi Valley. Thunderclouds and snowstonns blanket large portions of the Plains States, the Plateau Region, the Rockies and the Pacific Northwest.

title: TOP SEOUL GENERALS SEARCH FOR ACCORD ON A NEV PRESIDENT
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Oct. 30  Leaders of South Korea's armed forces met here last night after curfew began at 10 o'clock to work toward agreement on new leader to replace President Park Chung Hee.

title: 2 More Banks Raise Prime
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (Reuters)  The First National Bank of Chicago and the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago raised their prime rate today to 15 percent from 15 percent. The move was initiated by Citibank on Friday and was followed by the First Pennsylvania Bank and the Manufacturers National Bank of Detroit.

title: Galante Mob Said to Have A New Boss, Now in Prison
description: Philip Rastelli, now in Federal prison in Lewisburg, Pa., has emerged as the new leader of the crime organization that was headed by the late Carmine Galante, police intelligence officials say.

title: Ohira Party Deadlocked as Vote on Premier Nears
description: TOKYO, Oct. 29  A continuing deadlock in the governing Liberal Democratic Party over demands for the resignation of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira raised a possibility tonight that Parliament might have to postpone the election of a head of government, normally procedural formality, when the new House of Representatives convenes tomorrow.

title: P.B.A. Charges Sex Bias by Police In Promotion of Women Over Men
description: A sex discrimination suit charging that the New York City Police Department promotes female officers to the rank of detective ahead of male officers regardless of merit was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

title: Garbage Piles Up as Negotiators Resume Talks in Hawaiian Strike
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 29 (UPI)  Garbage piled up and schools remained shut down throughout Hawaii today as negotiators resumed contract talks to end a weeklong strike by some state workers.

title: Persistent Illegal Chinese Influx Alarming Officials in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 29 (Reuters)  Illegal immigration into Hong Kong from China has reached its highest level since May, with more than 9,500 arrested this month, the police said today.

title: Sluggish Stocks Show Token Gains
description: On the 50th anniversary of Black Tuesday, the darkest day of the 1929 market crash, stock prices dawdled along a narrow path yesterday to finish with token gains.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Carter to Name Judge to Direct Education Dept.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29  President Carter plans to announce tomorrow the nomination of Shirley Mount Hufstedler, a Federal judge in California, as Secretary of the newly created Department of Education, Administration officials said today.

title: Advertising
description: Promoting Flights To China

title: Business Groups Plead for Westway
description: Representatives of New York City business and financial interests appealed yesterday for the construction of the Westway, contending that the proposed sunken artery between the Battery and 42d Street would generate employment, produce revenue and improve the quality of life.

title: 200th Slaying of Year in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 29 (UPI) The police said that a man shot at his home Friday night died today, and that the slaying was the 200th of the year in Atlanta. The victim was identified as Alex Flemister, 56 years old. The police said that Atlanta counted 143 homicides last year.

title: Jets Get Bad News: Walker Out 4 Games
description: Wesley Walker, the most significant player on the Jets, averaging almost 25 yards a catch, will miss at least four games with a sprained right knee.

title: NewLook Sweaters: Where to Find Yarn
description: If you'd love to own one of those Perry Ellis rainbowhued cardigans or a Joan Vass angora pullover but can't see spending close to $200 for one, knit it yourself. That's what hundreds of fashionconscious women are starting to do.

title: Phyllis George: Half of a Glamorous Campaign
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  It's been called the kissing campaign, and it's easy to see why. John Y. Brown Jr., Kentucky's Democratic candidate for Governor, and his wife of seven months, Phyllis George, constantly hug and kiss like newlyweds on the campaign trail. And everybody in Kentucky, it seems, wants to kiss the former Miss America turned television personality.

title: THE CRASH IN RETROSPECT
description: Stock prices virtually collapsed yesterday, swept downward with gigantic losses in the most disastrous trading day in the stock market's history. Billions of dollars in open market values were wiped out as prices crumbled under the pressure of liquidation of securities which had to be sold at any price.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOSTON, Oct. 29 (AP)  Clergymen, public officials and a professional football team announced plans today to try to calm the explosive racial climate that resulted in a Boston blackout of a primetime network television program scheduled for tonight and tomorrow.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29  The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a state can favor widows over widowers in awarding death benefits under state workers compensation laws.

title: Study Finds Stereotyping in TV Casts
description: Men are greatly overrepresented in television's dramatic programs in relation to the actual national population, and women, minorities, juveniles and the elderly are underrepresented, according to a study of network programming conducted for the Screen Actors Guild. A report on the study, based on the monitoring of 1,365 primetime and Saturdaymorning programs from 1968 through last year, was released yesterday.

title: Negotiators Try to Break Zimbabwe Rhodesia Impasse
description: LONDON, Oct. 29  Commonwealth leaders have begun an informal but intensive diplomatic effort in hopes of finding some way to break the logjam in the Lancaster House negotiations on Zimbabwe Rhodesia, which entered their eighth week today.

title: Connecticut Protest
description: GROTON, Conn., Oct. 29 (AP) Eighteen antiTrident protesters, including a Roman Catholic priest, were arrested today outside the General Dynamics Corporation's Electric Boat division shipyard where Trident nuclear submarines are built. No injuries were reported.

title: British Caledonian To Buy Airbuses
description: LONDON, Oct. 29 (AP)  British Caledonian Airways, Britain's largest independent airline, said today that it had decided to buy the Europeanbuilt Airbus to extend its fleet in the mid1980s.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Economy

title: 4 Physicists Challenge Report of Soviet Atom Accident
description: FOUR physicists, including the former director of the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, where the first atomic bomb was developed, have questioned reports that a nuclear accident occurred near the southern Ural Mountains of the Soviet Union in late 1957 or early 1958.

title: Notes on People
description: Jacobo Timerman, the exiled Argentine publisher, was supposed to have held a news conference in New York yesterday, but it was called off  a case of a nonevent being at least as interesting as what had been scheduled. He was worried, Mr. Timerman explained in absentia, that what he had to say might endanger associates in Argentina.

title: Books of The Times
description: MY dear Mr. Storrs mimics Michael Storrs to his wife, Tracy, when she suggests he consider seeking psychiatric help to unravel his problems  you hated your mother, you felt rejected by your father because he died when you were a child, you are subconsciously equating your wife with your mother, your success as a student raised expectations of success in later life that are not satisfied in the job you hold, your jumping out of airplanes etcetera is an unconscious attempt, a symbolic attempt at escape from restrictions and resentments that are rooted deep in your childhood. A textbook case. You must understand these things and, understanding them, adapt yourself to them. Fifty dollars, please?

title: Winds Interrupt Power In Southern California
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 (AP) Winds gusting up to 60 miles per hour interrupted power to more than 300,000 southern Californians, capsized boats, toppled trees and fanned a 300acre fire in the Los Padres National Forest, the authorities said today.

title: School for Deaf Reopens, but Teachers Remain Unhappy
description: The Lexington School for the Deaf, closed for four weeks by a faculty strike, reopened yesterday, but many of the teachers who ratified an agreement late Sunday night were still unhappy.

title: Hartz Mountain Pays Record in Back Wages For Workers in Jersey
description: The regional office of the National Labor Relations Board in Newark said yesterday that it was distributing a record $640,000 in back pay to 46 Hartz Mountain Corporation employees in Jersey City who were dismissed in a 1974 union organizing dispute.

title: 51 Casualties in Crash in India
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 29 (Reuters) Twelve people died and 39 were injured today when their truck crashed into the closed gate of a railroad crossing near Ahmadabad in western India, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: In Afghanistan, 2 Soviet Trends Now Emerging
description: Two trends are now discernible in the Soviet Union's efforts to use Afghanistan as the primary base for Soviet military and political operations in Southwest Asia. One is the establishment of army and air bases near the Iranian frontier.

title: Folkloric History Of a Modern Drug
description: Aspirin's activity is based on chemicals called salicylates, derived from the willow and other plants used as medications since antiquity. More than 2,000 years ago, Hippocrates, the father of Greek medicine, recommended chewing willow bark to counter the pain of childbirth and postpartum fever. In Rome, Pliny the Elder used poplar bark, another salicylate source, for sciatic pain.

title: On the Floor, a Calm Anniversary
description: Despite the attempted disruption by pickets outside protesting nuclear power, the New York Stock Exchange marked Black Tuesday yesterday  the 50th anniversary of the great Wall Street crash of 1929  as just another day.

title: High Court Upholds Injury Suit in N.F.L.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29  The Supreme Court decided today that Charles (Boobie) Clark, a former running back for the Cincinnati Bengals, would have to defend himself against a $500,000 lawsuit brought by a former Denver Bronco player whose neck he allegedly fractured in an endzone incident on Sept. 18, 1973.

title: Johannes Schiefer, 83; Painter and L.I. Curator
description: Johannes Schiefer, painter of landscapes and portraits and former curator of the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, L.I., died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: Kennedy Timetable: Carter's Drive Resulted in a Speedup
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 For the last eight weeks, President Carter has mounted a vigorous political offensive to undercut the rationale for Senator Edward M. Kennedy's entering the 1980 Presidential race.

title: Government Regulation: A Maze Of Scientific Research and Politics
description: WASHINGTON S0 many decisions come into play, it's like a mosaic, Heinz J. Eiermann was saying the other day in his cubicle of an office in a drab Federal building near the Capitol. One must be very careful not to get the public involved before it is necessary. We cannot cry wolf too often. We proceed with proper deliberation. We always must differentiate between a claim and a fact.

title: World News Briefs
description: MADRID, Oct. 29 (AP)  More than 250,000 workers staged a 24hour general strike today to protest the slaying of nonBasque metal worker by Basque separatists.

title: Court Rules on Merrill Lynch
description: If Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith wishes to settle a classaction suit brought by New York customers involving the firm's former practice of writing checks on accounts in California banks, it must pay them damages, a state court judge ruled last week.

title: Westport Youth Held After 8 Get III at Party Involving Angel Dust
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 29  An 18yearold former high school student was arrested here today following a party Friday night at the home of his parents in which eight students became violently ill when they inhaled phencyclidine hydrochloride, a drug known as angel dust, which they apparently believed was cocaine.

title: Wyandanch Teachers Strike Enters 7th Week in Standoff
description: WYANDANCH, L.I., Oct. 29  As the teachers strike here entered its seventh week today, the only point of agreement for the two sides seemed to be that no settlement was in sight.

title: Robber Kills Man in Restaurant
description: Tai Lee Wing, 28 years old, was fatally shot Sunday evening by one of two holdup men who entered the China King Restaurant, 1965 University Avenue in the Bronx, the police said. They said the robbers had fled the restaurant, in the Morris Heights section, without taking any money.

title: Taxes
description: MOST people don't think about setting up a fund for their children's college education until it is too late. The time to start putting away money is when the youngsters enter kindergarten, not when they approach high school graduation.

title: U.N. Leader Intervenes in Case Of Employee Missing in Poland.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29  In a rare display of concern about an individual, the President of the General Assembly today asked Poland's representative to the United Nations to discuss the case of a missing employee, Alicja Wesolowska.

title: 43 Are Arrested in Israel in Sale Of Stolen Guns to Arab Villagers
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 29 (AP)  The Israeli police have arrested 43 suspects, 13 of them soldiers, as members of a ring accused of supplying stolen army weapons and ammunition to Arab villages in Israel.

title: Deaths
description: BASSETTIrene, M. on October 29, 1979. Beloved wife of Thomas A., devoted mother of Julie, Christie and Suzanne, beloved daughter of Rostta Noyes and the late John McCallum. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 MadisonAvenue at 81 Street on Wednesday and Thursday from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 P.M. Funeral mass Church of Saint Thomas More 65 East 89 Street, Friday November 2 at 10 A.M. Interment Saint Joseph Cemetery, Millbrook, N.Y. A memorial mass in Millbrook, N.Y. will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers a contribution to The New York Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Bizet's Carmen, 8.

title: P.L.O. GAINS GROUND IN WESTERN EUROPE
description: PARIS, Oct. 29  The Palestine Liberation Organization has made important diplomatic gains in Western Europe in the last few weeks, including an announcement today of political recognition by the Government of Italy.

title: Keeping the Amex in New York City
description: It would be regrettable for the Board of Estimate, following the example of yesterday's nuclear protesters, to obstruct the continuing work of Wall Street by lying down on the job. The job in question is approving the proposed deal that will keep the American Stock Exchange in New York City. The board has had ample opportunity to study the proposal, a decision on which it has postponed until tomorrow. The case for approval is clear; further delay would be dangerous.

title: House Votes Park Acquisitions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP)  The House passed legislation today that would designate 1,400 acres in seven areas for inclusion in the Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore. The bill, passed by voice vote, also would authorize an additional $39.5 million for land acquisition for the park, which is situated on the southernmost tip of Lake Michigan.

title: Horse Show to Open At the Garden Today
description: For almost two decades, Terry Rudd had been watching the United States Equestrian Team compete in horse shows and wondering if she ever would be chosen for the sauad.

title: Yadin Turns Down Dayan's Post
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 29  Prime Minister Menachem Begin sought unsuccessfully today to offer the post of Foreign Minister to a fellow Cabinet member and said later that for the time being he would keep the portfolio himself.

title: Japan Exports Of TV's Down
description: TOKYO, Oct. 29 (AP)  Japan's exports of color television sets in September totaled 374,347 units, down 17.8 percent from September 1978, but up 9.1 percent from August 1979, the Electronics Industries Association said today.

title: Science Watch
description: Photosynthesis, the biological process by which green plants store the energy of the sun in the form of complex chemicals, is the ultimate basis of all life, including most of the energy sources on which man depends. But photosynthesis is so inefficient that even sugar cane, one of the most efficient plants known, wastes more than 99 percent of the sunlight falling on it over a year's time.

title: As New Uses Arise, Aspirin Remains a Wonder Drug
description: ASPIRIN,hailed as a wonder drug when it was first introduced 80 years ago, is today a drug of everexpanding uses. By turning its main drawback  the ability to cause bleeding  to medical advantage, new research has revealed that aspirin has potential lifesaving effects for persons in danger of heart attacks, strokes and other disorders caused by blood clots.

title: Six Northeast Governors Hold Energy Summit Talks
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 29  The governors of six Northeastern states met here today with more than 250 labor and business leaders in an attempt to recruit their help in combating the region's energy problems.

title: Female Judges Push For More Women On the Federal Bench
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 Only 28 of the nation's 605 Federal judges are women even though more than 45,000 women are now practicing law in the United States, a conference of female judges was told here over the weekend.

title: Carter Group Complains On TV Time for Speech
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP)  President Carter's campaign committee today filed a complaint with the Federal Communications Commission charging the three major television networks with wrongfully refusing to sell him air time for a political speech.

title: Hebrew Union College Opens a New Center
description: With an official welcome from New York University to academic partnership, the Hebrew Union CollegeJewish Institute of Religion dedicated its $7.5 million New York school yesterday. The fivestory Brookdale Center, a blockfront on West Fourth Street from Broadway to Mercer Street, adjoins the university's campus east of Washington Square.

title: Opera: Brent Ellis in Met Debut
description: BRENT ELLIS is no stranger to New York audiences, but it wasn't until Thursday night that he made his debut with the Metropolitan Opera. The 33yearold baritone, a native of Kansas City, Mo., appeared as Silvio in Leoncavallo's Pagliacci.

title: Meeting Planned in Sinai Today
description: CAIRO, Oct. 29 (UPI)  The Defense Ministers of Egypt and Israel, Gen. Kamal Hassan Ali and Ezer Weizman, will meet tomorrow at the United Statesmanned electronic monitoring station in Sinai, the Middle East News Agency said today. The agency did not explain the purpose of the meeting but it was believed to be related to arrangements for Israel's withdrawal from Sinai.

title: Stamford Job Disparities Outlast Gains by Women
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 29The proportion of women holding jobs in this Fairfield County city has increased sharply in the past five years, but women, blacks and Hispanic persons still lag far behind white men at the upper rungs of the job ladder, according to an employment survey made public today by the Stamford Commission on Human Rights.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Exxon to Acquire Balance of Reliance
description: The Exxon Corporation announced that it had reached a definitive agreement to acquire the balance of the Reliance Electric Company's stock that it had not already acquired under a $1.2 billion tender offer announced last September.

title: On CriminalCode Reform
description: BOSTON  The proposed recodification of the Federal Criminal Code sponsored by Senator Edward M. Kennedy and Representative Robert F. Drinan is being rushed to passage without public scrutiny. Although the effort is wellintended, a stepbackward may be taking place. Because of Mr. Kennedy's Presidential aspirations and Mr. Drinan's liberal credentials, opponents of the bill, treating as a political hot potato, remain lowkey in their views. However, the bill is too important to be allowed to slide through without national debate.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Carl D. Glickman is a selfmade multimillionaire who lost his first million some 20 years ago. Today, the 53yearold Cleveland investor and real estate entrepreneur has holdings in hospitals, apartment and office buildings, real estate and banks around the country and manages the affairs of a leading rock band.

title: C.A.B. BACKS OFFER BY PAN AM TO BUY NATIONAL AIRLINES
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board announced yesterday that it had approved and sent to the White House a bid by Pan American World Airways to take over National Airlines, apparently clearing the way for Pan Am to become the nation's thirdlargest airline.

title: N.Y.R.A.
description: LIGHTENED LOAD: Teasdale, whose rider, JeanLuc Samyn, was thrown at start, stayed in running during first race at Aqueduct yesterday. Biz Beth, right, with Jose Amy up, won.

title: Mays Leaving Baseball
description: An upset and unhappy Willie Mays had a lastminute talk with Commissioner Bowie Kuhn yesterday and then affirmed his decision to work for a casino hotel, though it meant severing his ties with the New York Mets.

title: IN THE NATION Up & Down in N.H.
description: The latest poll of New Hampshire's muchsurveyed voters discloses the expected  that Edward M. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan are almost prohibitive favorites in the Democratic and Republican primaries. But close study of the fine print suggests much more.

title: Theater: Robert Wilson's Edison Staged in Paris
description: PARIS

title: Meyers and Bridgeman Keys to Bucks Fast Start
description: Last September, Ann Meyers was the family member in the national basketball spotlight. Now, however, it belongs to her brother, Dave, for his role in the turnabout of the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: Hambletonian Agreement Set
description: Officials of the Meadowlands Race Track reached an agreement on a threeyear contract with the Hambletonian Society yesterday to stage the Hambletonian Trot, harness racing's most prestigious event, at the East Rutherford, N.J., racing complex beginning in 1981. The agreement was reached at Harrisburg, Pa., the site of an annual standardbred horse sale. The contract will be drafted by Ernest B. Morris, the counsel of the society. It will be executed by Max Hempt, the president of the society, and Robert Quigley, the general manager of racing operations at the Meadowlands.

title: Pepperdine Wins Final
description: Terry Schroeder scored six goals to lead Pepperdine to a 126 victory over Bucknell in the title contest of the national Amateur Athletic Union water polo championships at Fordham University Sunday.

title: Market Place
description: ON Monday, March 12, 1929, 38yearold Mike Meehan, a onceimpoverished Irish American who had left grammar school to clerk in a cigar store and who later sprang to Wall Street eminence on sheer talent, stepped to Post 12 on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Canada Abandons Plan to Move Its Israel Embassy to Jerusalem
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 29  The Canadian Government abandoned its plan today to move its embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem after receiving a report from a special Ambassador to the Middle East saying the step could have an adverse effect on the peace process in the region.

title: Giscard a Diplomat in West Berlin
description: WEST BERLIN, Oct. 29  President Valry Giscard d'Estaing, the first French head of state to visit Berlin since Napoleon, affirmed France's security guarantees for the city today as well as determination to strive actively for continuation of dtente in Europe.

title: Bank Board Sees Mortgage Changes
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP)  The conventional longterm, fixedinterest mortgage could fall victim to inflation and volatile interest rates, Jay Janis, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said today.

title: A.T.&T. Suit Ends After 19 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29  A private antitrust suit ended today, 19 years after it was filed and three years after a Federal district judge dismissed it for failure to prosecute. The Supreme Court refused the original plaintiff's request to overturn the dismissal and allow the case to oroceed to trial

title: Union Head Is Firm on Kennedy
description: MARION, III., Oct. 29 The president of the United Mine Workers of America, Arnold Miller, today reiterated his support for Senator Edward M. Kennedy for President and his criticism of President Carter for allegedly failing to promote the use of coal.

title: Giants Now Have Hope Of Playoffs
description: AST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 29  Ray Perkins sheepishly returned the orange rabbit's foot to his pocket. He did not want to talk about goodluck charms today any more than he wanted to talk about the chances of the Giants making the National Football League playoffs. Coaches are not supposed to be silly.

title: Memorial for Norman Lewis
description: A memorial service for Norman Lewis, an abstractionist painter and teacher at the Art Students League, will be held at 2:30 P.M. on Thursday in St. Peter's Church, at East 54th Street and Lexington Avenue. Mr. Lewis died in New York on Aug. 27 at the age of 70.

title: ARAB GROUPS IN U.S. SEEK TO WOO BLACKS
description: Arab groups in the United States have started a new campaign to forge a broad political alliance with blacks, from the community level to major civil rights organizations and politicians, as part of an effort to change American policy on the Middle East.

title: The Region
description: ALBANY (AP)  New York's ban on the use of the pesticide Endrin was upheld yesterday by Robert F. Flacke, the state's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation.

title: Undoing a Tantrum on Foreign Aid
description: Congress has it in its power, perhaps today, to decide whether America will, in a kind of tantrum, turn its back on the world's poor countries. The issue is United States support for the World Bank and other international lending agencies that it helped create. An emotional House would cripple their aid. Only cooler Senate heads can thwart such recklessness.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: O NE of the greatest advances in this nation's taste during the past decade has been the adoption of European or Europeanstyle mustards. There is, of course, nothing wrong with the standard American version, the socalled ball Dark mustard. It is excellent on hot dogs and cold meat sandwiches, but it doesn't work as well when it is used in the preparation of sauces. The reason, I suspect, is the predominant flavor of turmeric, which gives the mustard its rich yellow hue.

title: TWA Discount Bid
description: CHICAGO (UPI)  Trans World Airlines said today that it planned to file a request with the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to offer a greater discount on super coach fares on certain flights between Chicago and Los Angeles. The airline said that it would seek a oneway fare of $119. The airline's current regular coach fare is $229 and the super coach fare is $182.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Treasury's new 3year notes, the first sale of the Government's threepart $6.75 billion financing this week, were auctioned yesterday at an average yield of 11.64 percent.

title: Corporate Sales and Earnings Reports
