description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: TV: Cheever's 0 Youth and Beauty! on WNET
description: AFTER a wobbly start last week, the WNET, Channel 13, series Three Cheever Stories recovers quite impressively tonight at 9 on Channel 13. The John Cheever story in this instance is 0 Youth and Beauty! The sensitive adaptation was written by A. R. Gurney Jr.

title: Market Place
description: THE management of Campbell Chibougamau Mines faces a stiff challenge at the annual meeting in Quebec City today from two former directors who profess to be dissatisfied with the company's diversification program.

title: The Region
description: LOWER ALLOWAYS CREEK, N.J. (AP)  The Salem One nuclear plant received authorization from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to resume generating power. The plant has been shut down since April for refueling and repairs, said Karl Abraham of the N. R.C. WASHINGTON (AP)  The New York State Thruway Authority is blocking a plan to obtain immediate Federal aid for the highway and eventually eliminate tolls, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan charged. Toll roads are not normally eligible for Federal highway aid, but Senator Moynihan, Democrat of New York, sponsored a measure, signed into law a year ago, that would allow such roads to begin receiving Federal assistance immediately if officials agreed to lift the tolls when bonds or construction costs were paid off. BEVERLEY HILLS, Calif.  Governor Carey went to Hollywood to entice

title: CORRECTION
description: Science Times yesterday, a hydrogen atom and an oxygen atom were dropped from a diagram depicting the structure of aspirin, for which the correct formula is CH2COOC4H4COOH.

title: Belle's Gold Triumphs
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 30  A closing rush on the outside by John R. Murrell's heavily favored Belle's Gold enabled the 3yearold son of Key to The Mint to win the first division of the $42,825 Palisades at the Meadowlands tonight before a crowd of 14.352.

title: Women Ask Law on Harassment
description: Repeated instances of sexual harassment of women in their jobs were, cited yesterday to buttress demands for state legislation that would grant unemployment insurance to anyone forced out of work because of improper conduct by a superior, coworker or client of the employer.

title: Prime at 15% At More Banks
description: Several more banks raised their prime lending rates to 15 percent yesterday, but most major ones held back on matching the increase initiated last Friday by Citibank, which is second in size behind the Bank of America.

title: Connally Is First to Air a 1980 Campaign Commercial
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  John B. Connally has bought the earliest Presidential campaign commercial ever, for broadcast tonight, using television to steal a march on his competitors and try to set himself up as the Republican Party's only realistic alternative to Ronald Reagan.

title: New French Vintage Lifts Hope on Prices
description: IT is customary at this time of year to make pronouncements about the new vintage in France, and reports are already circulating that superb wines will be forthcoming from the French vineyards in huge quantities. The custom of making early assessments is pervasive, even though it is far too early to judge the young wines that will result from the grape juice that is now undergoing fermentation in big tanks all across the country. The juice is not yet wine, so any evaluations of quality at this point are premature.

title: S.E.C.: Watchdog 1929 Lacked
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  As protection against financial illusion or insanity, John Kenneth Galbraith observed in The Great Crash, memory is far better than law.

title: Dow Up 15
description: The Dow Jones industrial average climbbd 15.19 points yesterday as the stock market produced its first genuine rally since the Federal Reserve Board abruptly tightened credit policy on Oct. 6.

title: Chess:
description: The playing out of apparently drawn endgames, or endings in which one side has only a minuscule advantage, insufficient to force a victory in itself, has been gaining momentum in recent years. Part of the reason was Bobby Fischer's voracious appetite for winning, which led him to run every game into the ground before acquiescing to split point.

title: Leading Indicators Post
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP)  A Government index designed to forecast economic trends showed surprising strength in September, rising by the largest amount since April 1978, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: SherwinWilliams Stock
description: The SherwinWilliams company announced yesterday that it had purchased for $20.9 million the 730,000 shares of its common stock that were owned by Gulf and Western Industries.

title: The Essential Martini
description: There was once a man who contended thatan atomizer was essential for making martinis. He used it to spray vermouth over the gin: one spritz of vermouth to seven ounces of gin was his preference.

title: Music: Bernstein Leads Viennese in Beethoven 9th
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 The Vienna State Opera temporarily suspended operations last night at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. Instead, Leonard Bernstein conducted the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra in Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. The Vienna State Opera is visiting the United States for the first time, and naturally it brought its own orchestra along. The orchestra, a cooperative, and selfgoverning group, both the orchestra of the opera company and the Vienna Philharmonic. Under any name, it is one of the great ensembles of the world. Mr. Bernstein's performance of the Beethoven Ninth had all his expected

title: BUSINESS
description: WEDNESDAY. OCTOBER 31. 1979

title: 2 Major Stores Join Same Center
description: For the first time, two major department stores, Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus, will be tenants of the same shopping center, Federated Department Stores Inc., parent company of both retailers, announced yesterday.

title: Whooooo Whooooo
description: ROANOKE, Va.  The kitchen hung like a golden globe on that raw day in late October. I was six years old, and had been given a new box of Crayolas, a package of construction paper and a waspwaisted bottle of glue.

title: Pomegranates: Rich In History and Taste
description: THE pomegranate, one of the world's most ancient fruits, has had a long and fascinating history. Although it probably originated in Persia, cultivation spread quickly throughout the Mediterranean and extended to Arabia, Afghanistan, India and China, where it was called the Chinese apple, the alternate appellation.

title: ATOMIC PANEL FINDS NO SURE WAY TO BAR REACTOR ACCIDENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  The President's Commission on the Accident at Thiee Mile Island said today that fundamental changes must occur in the way nuclear reactors are constructed, operated and regulated if the risks of nuclear power are to be kept within tolerable limits.

title: Stage: Pat Carroll as Gertrude Stein
description: ICOME late to Pat Carroll's solo impersonation of Gertrude Stein, but I come to praise her. Her evening  call it no saints in two acts  eluded me while it was shuttling about in repertory at Sheridan Square, but opportunity beckoned the minute it shifted over for a nice, uninterrupted run at the Provincetown Playhouse, 133 Macdougal Street. Off to the Provincetown I went, and I went expecting a great deal. I got more than I bargained for.

title: Economic Scene
description: Leonard Silk

title: Yale Going for 700th Victory
description: The school with the most victories in college football will be shooting for No. 700 Saturday. It is not Notre Dame, Michigan, Texas or Southern California. It is not even Penn, Harvard or Princeton.

title: Independent Recruiters Cash In As Colleges See Enrollment Fall
description: BOGOTA, N.J.  What the man in the pinstriped suit with the rock music slide show and abundance of flattery had come to tell seniors at Bogota High School the other day was this: If you like yourself, you'll choose a college no one else has ever heard of.

title: Kitchen Equipment Why Dark Baking Pans?
description: IFIND myself, every now and then, carrying on about what surely must seem to be a trivial issue: the color of baking pans.Of course I concede that there are many other factors in baking that are more important than the question of whether a pan is light or dark.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: As I infer him from his books, V. S. Pritchett must be one of the most pleasant men in the world. The photograph on the dust wrapper of On the Edge of the Cliff shows a face with more humanity in it than a dozen thick novels. Why, he is even wearing a solendid tie.

title: U.S. Urges Orderly Transition by Korean Military
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  The Carter Administration has instructed the American Ambassador in South Korea to encourage the South Korean army to continue the constitutional posture it has taken since the death of President Park Chtmg Hee last Friday.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: M.A.C. Bond Yield Lifted to 9%
description: The yield on the Municipal Assistance Corporation's $90 million of longterm bonds scheduled for sale tomorrow was increased yesterday to 9 percent from the 87/8 percent rate set tentatively on Monday. At 9 percent, the taxexempt bonds attracted investors quickly, and the issue was reported to be all spoken for.

title: Bridge:
description: For the second time in three years, cheating scandal has resulted in a law suit in which the American Contract Bridge League is the defendant. The first was brought in 1977 by Dr. Richard Katz and Larry Cohen of Los Angeles, whose action is likely to reach the courts in 1981.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Oct. 30  Dome Petroleum Ltd. said today that it had identified two and possibly three potentially commercial deposits of crude oil in Canada's Beaufort Sea. MIAMI, Oct. 30 (AP)  Britain's RollsRoyce Ltd. said today that it would open a plant to manufacture major components for the company's largest jet engines at the Miami International Airport. HOUSTON, Oct. 30  Tenneco Inc. said today that production of natural gas had started from two platforms in the Gulf of Mexico operated by its oil exploration and production unit.

title: Angolan Envoy Reports South African Invasion
description: BRUSSELS, Wednesday, Oct. 31 (UPI)  Angola's Ambassador to Belgium said today that airborne South African troops had invaded Angola, striking near a major Cuban air base on the country's west coast.

title: Hospital Food That Patients Like
description: OIL CITY, Pa., Oct. 29 (AP)  June Bucholz went to Oil City Hospital for surgery. She left with an appetite for the food, which indicates that hospital meals need not taste like medicine.

title: Marijuana Growing Becomes Big Business on Coast
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 29  Commercial cultivation of marijuana has become a booming underground branch of agriculture in California and, according to investigators, is generating many millions of dollars yearly in illicit profits for a newoversion of the oldfashioned mountain moonshiner.

title: A Frenchman Who Reprints Rare Cookbooks for Modern Chefs
description: LUZARCHES. FRANCE

title: 3 Copiers Introduced By Xerox
description: The Xerox Corporation yesterday introduced three medium and highvolume copying and duplicating machines that computer industry analysts say fill a clear performance gap in Xerox's Product line.

title: Tesoro Expansion
description: SAN ANTONIO, Oct. 30 (Reuters) The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation today said that it planned to spend $45 million to expand its Kenai, Alaska, refinery. The company said that the expansion would enable it to raise production of unleaded gasoline by 5,000 barrels a day and that of commercial jet fuel by 4,000 barrels a day.

title: Calvados: The Spirit Of Apples
description: CALVADOS is the most extraordinary product of the apple, ne of the noble brandies of France, a distilled spirit of intense flavor traditionally taken after a repast as a digestif. For no obvious reason it is not nearly as well known as the two dominant grape brandies, Cognac and Armagnac.

title: Cuba and Colombia Battle It Out For Seat on U.N. Security Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 30 The diplomats here are usually punctilious about the rules of etiquette. But today a few took off the gloves and scrapped with the political equivalent of bare knuckles as Cuba once again fell short in a bid for a seat on the Security Council.

title: It Was Not a Night Meant For Staying Home by the Fire
description: Anyone who got all dressed up and had no place to go Monday night, well, pity the poor soul. The town was jumping.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 &M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900: WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 94300; NASSAU CO. (515) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO, (515) 66915001 CONNECTICUT (203) 3484757.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: Glenn Collins

title: Youth Acquitted as Insane In L.I. Abortion Clinic Fire
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 30 Peter I. Burkin was found not guilty of attempted murder and arson with intent to kill in the burning of a Bill Baird abortion clinic in Hempstead. L.L. last Feb. 15.

title: New York State Aide, A Hispanic, Is Chosen For U.S. Housing Post
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  Victor Marrero, the New York State Housing Commissioner, has been selected as the new Under Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Congressional and White House officials said today.

title: Apple Juices: Popular, But Are They Real?
description: APPLE juice is one of the nation's favorite beverages. After orange juice, it is the second most popular fruit drink and is widely regarded as healthful, fresh, pure and unadulterated. But is it?

title: 300 Raid U.S. Embassy in Salvador but Are Repulsed1
description: SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 30 (AP) About 300 leftists attacked the United States Embassy today, firing guns and shouting that they were going to take over the compound, American authorities reported.

title: French Labor Minister Kills Himself After Scandal
description: PARIS, Oct. 30  Robert Boulin, 59yearold Minister of Labor, was found dead in the Rambouillet forest early today, a suicide apparently because of despair over published charges implicating him in a realestate scandal.

title: The Day the Subway Didn't Get Through
description: FOR the subway system, this has been a year of more than passing interest. Scandal over R46 cars; concern over crime; a new map; and a major birthday  the 75th  to celebrate. Those who ride the subway tend to take it for granted, muttering in weary tones about delays, crowding, broken doors and graffiti. Thus it always was, their tone implies; thus it will always be. It's ugly and noisy and gobbles up tokens, but it gets you where you're going. You climb on, bury your head in the newspaper or let the swaying train rock you to sleep. Never fear; you'll get there.

title: Polish Church Making Gains, but Problems Remain
description: WARSAW, Oct. 30  Basking in the worldwide attention showered on its famous native son, Pope John Paul II, the Roman Catholic Church in Poland is flourishing as never before.

title: Notes on People
description: Finding Califano a Job

title: Cities ServiceTunisia Pact
description: TULSA, Okla., Oct. 30 (Reuters) The Cities Service Company said today that it had signed a contract with Tunisia for oil exploration on a 180,877acre tract off Kerkennah Island, Tunisia, in the Gulf of Gabes. It said the initial contract provided for a geophysical survey and the drilling of one test well.

title: Mexican Oil Output at Peak
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 30 (UPI) Mexico's oil production has reached a record 1.7 million barrels a day, the Government oil monopoly Petroleos Mexicanos announced yesterday.

title: Gerald Cook, 63, Editor on Staff Of Hospital Union's Publication
description: Gerald Cook, assistant editor of the publication of the Hospital Workers Union, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 63 years old.

title: Play: All the Way Home
description: TAD MOSEL'S All the Way Home appeared in 1960, won the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1961 and, except for an Off Off Broadway revival a few seasons ago, has not been seen here since. It is stuffed and even surfeited with life, sentiment and juices, and it overflows with good roles. It is a lovely choice for the Equity Library Theater, and E.L.T. is giving it a lovely production.

title: Getting a Hotel Room in China: You're Nothing Without a Unit
description: PEKING

title: Britain Curbs Oil Output
description: LONDON, Oct. 29 (AP)  Shell U.K. Ltd. and the Esso Petroleum Company have been ordered by the British Government to cut oil production in a large field in the North Sea by about 46 percent to reduce flaring off, or burning, of natural gas.

title: Club Owner Is Criticized By Martin
description: Billy Martin spoke out yesterday for the first time since he was dismissed as Yankee manager and was particularly critical of his former boss, George Steinbrenner.

title: Opera Stars Pay Tributes to Mrs. Belmont
description: Past and present operatic luminaries and the family and friends of Eleanor Robson Belmont attended a memorial service yesterday for the woman credited with creating much of the support that has enabled the Metropolitan Opera Company to endure.

title: Iran Spot Oil Sells at $45.30
description: Iran, Oct. 30 (UPI)  Iran sold crude oil at $45.30 a barrel on the spot market two days ago, breaking a record set a few days earlier, the commercial newspaper Bourse said today.

title: Careers
description: THE number of family farms in the United States may be declining, but interest in agriculture as a career is not. From 1970 to 1978, for instance, the number of undergraduates majoring in agriculture at Pennsylvania State University nearly tripled to 3,762.

title: German Breech Chosen by Army
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP)  The Army chose a West Germandesigned breech today for a 120millimeter gun to be mounted in the new XM1 tank. After a review of American and German designs, the Army said, the German breech was found to compare favorably with the prototype of an American breech designed by Benet Laboratory at the Watervliet Arsenal in New York State.

title: Film: Consequence
description: THE first and best part of The Consequence is a tender courtship episode, delicately rendered. Martin, a quiet, sadeyed man of perhaps 30 years old, is imprisoned for having had sex with a 15yearold boy, and while incarcerated he finds Thomas, the son of one of the prison officials. Thomas (Ernst Hannawald) has the cheekbones of a female fashion model and the innocent beauty of an angel. And, more to the point, Thomas has a crush on Martin (Jurgen Proctmow) from the moment they meet.

title: A House That Isn't There
description: A group in Phoenix is fighting for Frank Lloyd Wright and against a new highway. But this is a preservation battle with a twist. The house being battled over, a fine example of Wrights prairie style and built in 1939, is no longer there.

title: U.S.E.T. Leads at Garden
description: The National Horse Show, which started in the cobblestone and gaslight era, got under way yesterday at Madison Square Garden, and the United States Equestrian Team promptly took a commanding lead.

title: Selling The Idea Of Exotic Edibles
description: LOS ANGELES

title: CARTER LOSES CLARK TO KENNEDY'S CAMP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  In a move that drew a muted rebuke from President Carter, former Senator Dick Clark of Iowa announced today that he was resigning as the Administration's Coordinator for Refugee Affairs to join Senator Edward M. Kennedy's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Excerpts From Presidential Panels Report on the Three Mile Nuclear Accident
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  Following are excerpts from the Overview section of the Report of the President's Commission on the Accident at Three Mile Island that was presented to President Carter today:

title: Flanagan Is Winner Of Cy Young Award
description: Baseball opened its season of honors yesterday when Mike Flanagan of the Baltimore Orioles won the Cy Young Award as the outstanding pitcher in the American Leamie.

title: 'snow Aims to Grip Broadway
description: IN the fall of 1973, a television writer named Abe Polsky and his wife, Merrily, were spending a week at Donner Lake in northern California's Sierra Nevada. Chill winds moaned in the tall trees. In a few weeks the dark waters of the lake would be crusted with ice. At night, when the mercury plummeted, Mr. Polsky and his wife huddled gratefully by the fire in the lodge; it was natural for their thoughts to turn to the Donner Party that perished there in the winter of 184647.

title: Corpulent Canines: Victims of Affection
description: The fat dog is no joke. Obesity, veterinarians say, is a major canine health problem. By one estimate, 28 percent of the domestic dog population a decade ago was overweight. More recently it has been estimated that 30 to 60 percent of all pet dogs are markedly obese, with the health of 20 percent of those in imminent danger. The main reason is mismanagement by human beings.

title: Birmingham, Once a Citadel of Segregation, Elects Its First Black Mayor
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 30  Councilman Richard Arrington was elected today as this city's first black Mayor, according to unofficial returns in a runoff election marked by a sharp racial division.

title: Panel on 3 Mile Island Accident
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI)  Following are the members of the President's Commission on the Accident at Three Mile Island:

title: Associated Press
description: CRADLING HER DEAD CHILD, a Cambodian mother waited outside hospital at refugee camp near Sa Kaeo, Thailand. There is nothing we can do, said Red Cross worker, to stop more than a dozen people each day from dying.

title: POPE'S RIGHTS PLEA SHAKES ARGENTINES
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 30 On instructions from Argentina's military rulers, newspapers here omitted all mention last week of charges of human rights violations leveled against Argentine authorities in a report by the InterAmerican Human Rights Commission.

title: New Yorkers,etc.
description: THERE'S someone somewhere who has never felt like a fool, been embarrassed, wished the floor would open up, or wanted to give him/ herself a good swift kick. That same someone would have explained the theory of relativity to Einstein.

title: Tax Unit Puts Off Decision on Funds
description: The New York State Department of Taxation and Finance yesterday postponed making a decision on whether to consider income from certain money market funds that specialize in Treasury obligations as taxexempt.

title: The Nuclear Indictment
description: The Three Mile Island Commission raises disturbing questions about the safety of nuclear power that it does not fully answer. The commission's report indicts Federal regulators and parts of the nuclear industry for a complacency about safety that allowed this accident to occur. But its recommendations, as the commission itself acknowledges, may not suffice to assure nuclear safety.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Royal Fireworks Music, Handel; Nocturne No. 1, Chopin; Symphony in A, Maldere; Symphony in Two Russian Themes, Glinka.

title: EARNINGS
description: The WarnerLambert Company reported yesterday that thirdquarter profits had plunged 92.3 percent to $4.7 million, or 6 cents a share, largely because of a $36 million reserve to phase out a plant.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Ireland After The Pope
description: ARDMORE, Ireland  Ireland, particularly Roman Catholic Ireland, is busy saving itself by mental exertion from being politically kidnapped, pigeonholed and put on exhibition as the docile good boy at the world's social party  the example to all turbulent advocates of change that the old ways are best.

title: Unyielding Left Keeps Salvador in Turmoil
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 30  The latest wave of political violence to convulse El Salvador appears to reflect a decision by extreme leftist groups to undermine the authority of the country's new Government before it can gain popular support.

title: Nurse Recruiting Widens
description: Hospitals in various American communities are of fering bounties ranging from $100 to $1,000 for regis tered nurses, according to the American Nurses Association.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: UP THE LADDER When the Raphael Trio gave its first New York recital in 1975 at Carnegie Recital Hall under the aegis of the Concert Artists Guild, a reviewer for The New York Times called the event a most auspicious debut and the playing eager, fervent and deeply committed. The three young people  Susan Salm, cellist; Charles Castleman, violinist, and Daniel Epstein, pianist  drew more praise the following season at the Chamber Music Festival in Stockbridge, Mass. They have also performed at the 92d Street Y, the Phillips Collection in Washington and the GardMuseum in Boston.

title: Benny Goodman, Author, Swings for His New Book
description: BENNY GOODMAN was swinging again last night at a private party at the Rainbow Grill with a tight, rhythmically supple quartet and several special guests, including Helen Ward, his original hand vocalist. While the musiclans played  and Mr. Goodman at the age of 70 is still as fluent and formidable a clarinetist as ever  slides depicting his career were projected behind them. The slides were blowups from a new picture book, Benny: King of Swing, published last week by William Morrow.

title: 10 Encore Awards Given
description: The Arts and Business Council gave its annual Encore Awards to five corporations and five arts organizations yesterday for their outstanding service to the city through the arts.

title: Personal Health
description: BUFFERIN, the ads claim, acts twice as fast as aspirin without upsetting your stomach. Anacin is said to have more of the pain reliever doctors recommend most. AlkaSeltzer is supposed to help you overcome both the stomach upset and headache precipitated by stress, fatigue or overindulgence. And we've been told that only Excedrin, the extrastrength pain reliever, can conquer an Excedrin headache, whatever that may be.

title: U.S. Steel Profit Off
description: The United States Steel Corporation yesterday reported a thirdquarter profit drop of 8.4 percent from the results for the comparable 1978 period.

title: Sir Barnes Wallis, British Inventor Of Dambuster Bombs, Is Dead
description: LONDON, Oct. 30 (Reuters)  Sir Barnes Wallis, the ingenious designer of airships and jet planes who also invented the World War II dambuster bouncing bombs, died in the hospital today at the age of 92.

title: Dealers Ask Fed To Explain Errors
description: The Public Securities Association, a trade association including many bond dealers, called yesterday for a detailed explanation of the reasons behind the errors in recent money supply figures. The request was made in a letter to Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: WASHINGTON Listen To Our Neighbors
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 30  The new Prime Minister of Canada is Joe Clark of High River, Alberta  a place about the size of Plains, Ga.  and he will be meeting here in the next few days with President Carter.

title: 3 FORMER OFFICERS SENTENCED IN TEXAS
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 30  Federal District Judge Ross N. Sterling, acting under orders from a Federal appeals court to impose prison terms on three former Houston police officers he had sentenced to probation for their roles in the death of a young MexicanAmerican man, today handed the three what amounted to an extra day in orison.

title: Kissinger Revised His Book More Than He Reported
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has said in recent interviews that he added at most a paragraph and one or two footnotes to his account, just published, of United States military action in Cambodia in 196970 to respond to accusations by a British journalist earlier this year.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSONBenlamln. The New Times York Tim records with deep sorrow the passing of Benjamin Abramson associated with The Times from 1950 until retiring in 1974.

title: The Judges Who Made the Selection
description: Thirteen apple juice products, after being analyzed scientifically, were given to a fivemember panel for a blind tasting.

title: The New Secretary of Education
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30  If the nomination of Judge Shirley Mount Hufstedler as Secretary of Education came as a surprise to educators and political observers in California, it was only because they had grown so accustomed to hearing her name mentioned instead as a candidate for the United States Supreme Court.

title: Brazilian Deficit Widens
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 30 (Reuters)  The Brazilian trade deficit widened to $1.59 billion in the first nine months of this year from $678 million in the comparable period last year, the Finance Ministry said today. The value of exports in the first nine months was $10.98 billion, up from $9.11 billion in the comparable period last year, while imports amounted to $12.57 billion, against $9.79 billion in the yearago period, it said.

title: World Gold
description: TUESDAY, OCTOOLD 30, 1978

title: $75,000 Cash Was Given to Help Carey and Cuomo, Scotto Testifies
description: Anthony M. Scotto testified yesterday that he had received $75,000 in cash contributions from two waterfront businessmen and that he had given the money to the political campaigns of Governor Carey and Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: CBSTV Leads Ratings For First Time in Season
description: After a sluggish start this season, CBSTV rallied to lead the audiencepopularity ratings last week with large tallies for its regular Friday and Sunday night series.

title: Ken Norton Says Thank You to Press
description: Ken Norton was in New York yesterday on an extraordinary mission. The main purpose of his visit, he told a dozen or so sportswriters at lunch in Gallagher's, was to thank individual members of the press who, he felt, had treated him fairly in their coverage of his fights when he was winning and losing a version of the heavyweight championship of the world.

title: The Hope of, and for, Welfare Reform
description: This time last year, prospects for reforming the nation's cumbersome welfare programs looked bleak. Congress had summarily rejected the Carter Administration's original reform plan as too ambitious and expensive. But the legislators failed to come up with a practical alternative before rushing home to campaign. Now, however, there's new hope.

title: Promotions at H.C.A.
description: The Hospital Corporation of America, a fastgrowing enterprise in an increasingly complicated field, has established a new level of executive authority and promoted of nine of its top executives. Donald C. MacNaughton, chairman and chief executive officer, said that the positions were both a reflection of our rapid growth and an indication of our continued expansion plans for the future.

title: Surgeons and a Resolute Woman Honored
description: The microsurgery team and ambulance corpsmen who saved a police officer's severed leg and a Bronx woman who apprehended a confidence man were among those honored yesterday by the Police Department for public service.

title: Cider
description: Richard Timperio

title: News Media Defended in Inquiry On Reports of Three Mile Island
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  The President's Commission on the Accident at Three Mile Island has found that, despite prevailing confusion and contradictory statements from sources supplying information, the news media generally attempted to give a balanced presentation of the accident at the nuclear power facility last March.

title: OPEC Denies Meeting Report
description: VIENNA, Oct. 30 (UPI)  The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries does not plan an extraordinary session to discuss oil prices before its regular meeting next month, an OPEC official said today.

title: Money
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1979

title: New Quota On Chinese Apparel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  The Carter Administration announced today that it was imposing a quota on additional categories of Chinese textile and apparel products sold in this country as part of efforts to win Congressional approval of the China trade agreement that was sent to Capitol Hill last week.

title: N.F.L. Is Specializing to Nth Degree
description: In pro football these days the teams seldom field the same 11 players on two consecutive plays. The comings and goings from the sidelines to the offensive or defensive huddles signal the age of specialization, which has never has been more prevalent in the National Football League.

title: For Many, Political Cash Just Isn't Worth It Anymore
description: Cash contributions to politicians hard to control and hard to trace  were supposed to become a thing of the past when New York State changed its election law in mid1974.

title: The City
description: Neckchain Thefts On Rise in Subway

title: Letters
description: The Problems of Brie

title: Connecticut Republican Legislators Offer Supplemental Energy Plan
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 30  Republicans in the State Senate introduced a supplemental energy package today that would hidude a $300 property tax deferral for homeowners to use for winterizing their houses, state tax exemptions for all alternative energy systems and an increase in the lowinterest winterization loan program to $15 million. .1

title: Children's TV Is Short
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  The staff of the Federal Communications Commission reported today that television broadcasters had fallen short of commission goals for children's programming, but the commissioners hesitated to order the industry to increase the programs immediately. Instead, the commission plans to issue sometime in the next two months a variety of new proposed rules, including the most farreaching programming requirements yet contemplated for television.

title: Advertising
description: ON the 23d floor of 777 Third Ave. nue, the decor is green and white. Green plants and white castiron furniture and latticework abound. It is fitting that the offices of Advertising to Women look like this because it is truly a garden of dreams. Advertising created here is sensual and all of the people in it are beauties.

title: Con Ed Plan Will Help Elderly With Heat Bills
description: The Consolidated Edison Company announced a new program yesterday to help an estimated 300,000 elderly customers and those living on a fixed income to pay their gas and electricity bills this winter. unner me new neatingcost program known as Concern, the utility will offer a new 12month budget plan, credit procedures will be modified and the ;10 energy audit fee will be waived.

title: TV Political Season Under Way With Increased Confusion Likely
description: John B. Connally's paid telecast last night marked the opening of the political timebuying season, one that already promises to raise more than the usual amount of confusion and controversy because it has begun so early.

title: Prices Vary Widely For Shoe Repairs
description: Thirteen shoerepair shops gave estimates ranging from $7 to $30 recently for fixing the same pair of dilapidated leather shoes.

title: Halloween Spirit And Ritual Nigh
description: It was unusually busy at the Universal Costume Company. At 7 last night, the Broadway shop was filled with advertising executives and theatrical agents who had stopped on their way home to pick up a few necessities: gorilla hands and feet, bunny cuffs, plastic fangs and a clown nose or two. One man emerged from a dressing room wearing a silver shark suit, eximined his drooping dorsal fin and said with a sigh: I guess I'll have to go with the Conehead getup.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Low clouds cover much of New England and the middle Mississippi Valley. Mldlevel clouds are visible over the southern Appalaclans, while a large area of multilayered clouds associated with a cold front extends across the central portions of the country.

title: Chief Executive Named at Parade
description: Carlo Vittorini, former president of Harlequin Magazines and of Charter Publishing, has been named president and chief executive officer of Parade, the Sunday newspaper supplement, replacing Thomas H. Ferguson, who becomes president of The Washington Post newspaper on Dec. 1.

title: Mr. Carter, Lobbying Is Not A Dirty Word
description: WASHINGTON  The Carter Administration, attempting to make lobbying a dirty word, defines special interest as any viewpoint that does not totally agree with the White House. It paints a picture of goodversusevil whenever anybody questions a Presidential proposal for a new program.

title: Murder Inquiry Widened in Seoul; Park Aide and Many Others Held
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Oct. 31 South Korean military investigators disclosed yesterday that they had widened their investigation into the assassination of President Park Chung Hee by formally detaining Kim Kye Won, chief of the presidential staff, and a large number of other suspects.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have, on my pantry shelf, a Damson s plum jelly that says half stoned. know it sounds like a joke, but can you tell me what that means?

title: State Aid for New Amex Building Criticized at Legislative Hearing
description: The financial arrangments committing New York State to pay most of the cost of the proposed American Stock Exchange building while Amex would pay only a low subsdidized rent was criticized yesterday at a legislative hearing. The criticism came as soaring costs of building and financing continued to raise the projected cost of the project.

title: Salesman Says Martin Hit Him
description: Joseph Cooper, the salesman at the center of Billy Martin's dismissal, said yesterday that the former New York Yankee manager had threatened him and then had hit him with a sucker punch.

title: William Hoge, U.S. General, at 85
description: Gen. William M. Hoge, who built the 1,500mile Alaska Highway in 1942, commanded the combat unit that captured the Remagen bridge over the Rhine River in 1945 and later served as commander of all United States Army troops in postwar Europe, died yesterday at Munson Army Hospital at Fort Leavenworth, Kan. He was 85 years old.

title: L.S.U. Refuses To Move Kickoff
description: Paul Dietzel, the athletic director of Louisiana State University, said yesterday that he had refused to switch the scheduled kickoff of the Tigers home game against Alabama, preventing ABC from showing it on national television Nov. 10.

title: 79 Paintings by Still to Go On View at Met on Nov. 17
description: An exhibition of paintings by the leading abstract expressionist Clyfford Still will be shown at the Metropolitan Museum of Art from Nov. 17 through Feb. 3,1980.

title: Sentencing Set In Cenco Case
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP)  Sentencing has been scheduled for Dec. 21 for three former officials of a medical care company who were found guilty yesterday in a $25 million phonyprofits case.

title: Wife of Three Weeks Sees Pharmacist Slain in Queens
description: New York City detectives hunted yesterday for a man who fatally shot a Pakastaniborn druggist during an apparent robbery attempt just after he and his wife of three weeks had driven up to their home in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Canada Raising U.S. Oil Price
description: OTTAWA (AP)  The price of heavy crude oil exported by Canada to the United States will rise 7.1 percent to about $25.40 a barrel on Nov. 1, the Canadian Government said today.

title: Vote on Premier Delayed in Japan
description: TOKYO, Oct. 30 Japan's new Parliament, hobbled by a power struggle in the governing Liberal Democratic Party, elected a speaker and deputy speaker of the House of Representatives today but adjourned the opening session until tomorrow without receiving a nomination for prime minister from the Liberal Democrats.

title: CHRYSLER REPORTS 460 MILLION DEFICIT, SETTING U.S. RECORD
description: DETROIT, Oct. 30 The Chrysler Corporation today reported a loss of $460.6 million for the third quarter, the largest quarterly loss from continuing operations ever incurred in the history of American enterprise. The results increased to $721.5 million the amount of money the troubled No. 3 car maker has lost in the first nine months of this year.

title: Letters
description: Fish Must Prevail Over Oil on the Georges Bank

title: From Out West Comes the Real Chili Taste
description: There are a good many flavors in this country through which the public is casually misled.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: The New York Times/Robert Levin

title: Senate Approves Giving Congress OilImport Role
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  The Senate moved today to give Congress a measure of control over Presidential authority to limit imports of foreign oil and impose fees on such imports. The vote was 70 to 23.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Ashland Stock Purchase
description: ASHLAND, Ky. Oct. 30 (Reuters) Ashland Oil Inc. said today that it had completed a program of purchasing six million shares of its common stock that it started last March. Ashland said it had purchased and retired more than 15 million shares of common stock since Oct. 1, 1978. On Sept. 30, 1979, actual shares outstanding were 30.4 million.

title: State's Court Chief Plans to Switch Judges And Cut Time Off to Reduce Civil Backlog
description: A plan to reduce the huge backlog of civil cases in New York City and other large cities in the state will be announced today by the state's Chief Judge.

title: Not the Most Sylvan Setting, but It's Where They're Biting
description: His only concern being his choice of bait, his only anxiety, the anticipation of a strike, a fisherman cast his line into the East River off Roosevelt Island yesterday angling for speckled trout on their annual winter migration to warmer waters. New York Hospital's Cornell Medical Center is in the background.

title: Music: Muti Steps Into New Territory
description: IT was hard not to think of Riccardo Muti's program with the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night as something of a calling card. This was the orchestra's first New York concert this season, which is Mr. Muti's last as principal guest conductor. Next season, he will succeed Eugene Ormandy as music director, a post Mr. Ormandy has held for 44 years. Mr. Ormandy is known for his conservative programming. Last night, Mr. Muti offered three pieces not heard before at these concerts.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Angela Taylor

title: News Summary
description: International

title: City Stores
description: The financially troubled City Stores Company said yesterday that its president and chief executive, Morris Goldstein, would resign next Jan. 31, the end of the fiscal year.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, Oct. 30  Prime Minister Hua Guofeng of China delivered a strong attack on the Soviet Union today and hailed Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher for recognizing what he said was the threat that Moscow posed to world peace.

title: Chrysler U.K. Has SixMonth Loss
description: LONDON, Oct. 30 (AP)  Chrysler U.K., the Frenchowned car maker, reported today that it lost $36.6 million in the first half of this year.

title: About Real Estate Jersey City Waterfront Park Designed as Magnet Project
description: Waterfront redevelopment is one of the most effective revitalization tools for city planners because of its removal of blight and its reintroduction of natural resources to a manmade environment.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Major silver futures exchanges yesterday slashed the margin requirements they had imposed last week to prevent a possible cornering of the silver market. The record margins have virtually hobbled trading in silver futures on New York's Commodity Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL MEETS WITH MOROCCAN KING
description: RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 30  After meeting with King Hassan II, Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher declared today that the Moroccan monarch and the United States had a large measure of agreement on the need to develop a peaceful solution to the problems of the Western Sahara.

title: The Five Best Ciders, as Selected by the Tasters Panel
description: From a sampling of 32 fresh apple ciders purchased from supermarkets, greenmarkets and roadside stands in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania, the taste panel selected these five as outstanding. The cider producers are listed according to the number of votes received in the final , testing. The last three received an equal number of votes, and are listed alphabetically.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Letter: On U.S. Aid to Turkey
description: Subsidizing the Occupation of Cyprus

title: School Officials Tell Koch Of a Plan to Cover Deficit
description: Top education officials were summoned to City Hall yesterday by Mayor Koch, who heard them outline a plan for tentative cutbacks to cover an unexpected $45 million budget deficit.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The debate in the Congress over the strategic arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union may be having repercussions for the corporate world. Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the retired Chief of Naval Operations, has resigned as president and chief executive officer of American Medical Buildings Inc., to take, in his words, a more active Dart in the debate on the treaty.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Oct. 30, 1979

title: Issue and Debate
description: The Carey administration carefully fashioned a $500 million transportation bond proposal early this year with something for virtually everybody money for mass transit, railroad and highway improvements in upstate. downstate, suburban and city areas. State officials believed it was a measure that could win wide support from local leaders and, ultimately, from the voters.

title: Shoe Prices Off and Running
description: THAT'S a good investment, sir, a clerk at Eggers & Silk on Fulton Street told Kenneth G. DeWitt, a Wall Street securities manager, as he fitted a pair of deep burgundy Church's Chepstow wingtips on Mr. DeWitt's feet the other day.

title: Congress Votes Milwaukee Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP)  Both the Senate and the House of Representative today approved a freeze on plans to shut down the western lines of the financially ailing Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad.

title: Opera: Met 's First Ada of Season
description: AMEDIOCRE Ada, which is what the Metropolitan Opera provided on Monday night in the season's first performance of Verdi's tale of life and death on the Nile, can add up to a long, long siege.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Continental Group, a diversified company, has named Kenneth L. Lay president of its Continental Resources Company, succeeding Selby W. Sullivan, who has been named executive vice president and chief financial and administrative officer for the Continental Group. Also announced was the appointment of James F. Betts as president and chief executive officer of Continental Financial Services, succeeding Warren M. Pace, who is retiring.

title: Nuclear Industry Problems Foretold Mishap, Panel Says
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  The Kemeny Commission concluded today that because of deficiencies in the design of nuclear power equipment, inadequate training of operators and confusing procedures, an accident like Three Mile Island was eventually inevitable, if not in Pennsylvania then elsewhere in the country.

title: Fairchild Industries Continuing Quest
description: GERMANTOWN, Md.  With one of its big aircraft programs coming to an end and no new major military orders on the horizon, Fairchild Industries, a profitable military contractor, is under growing pressure to diversify.

title: News of the Theater
description: TWO new oneact plays by Sam Shepard, Savage Love and Tongues, are in rehearsal at the Public Theater and will start performances on Tuesday in the Other Stage. Joseph Chaikin, best known as the director of the Open Theater, will head the cast, which includes two musicians performing compositions by the playwright himself.

title: Recipes With the Powder
description: Sopapaillas

title: Senate Panel's Alaskan Lands Bill Opens Range for Oil Companies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  A bill that would lock up 95 million acres of Alaskan lands in national parks and forests and in wilderness areas but would allow petroleum prospecting in the caribou calving areas of the Arctic Wildlife Range was reported out today by the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee.

title: Trade Gap at $2.8 Billion,
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP)  The biggest monthly bill for oil imports that the United States has ever had contributed to a $2.83 billion deficit In the nation's trade accounts last month, the largest deficit in eight months, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Tornado Kills Two in Oklahoma
description: ARDMORE, Okla., Oct. 30 (AP)  A tornado struck the rural community of NewportWoodford in southern Oklahoma this morning, killing two persons and injuring three others. A halfdozen homes were reported damaged in the area, seven miles northwest of Ardmore.

title: 2 Held as Sellers of Bogus Laetrile
description: LINDEN, N.J., Oct. 30  Two Long Island men have been charged here with attempting to sell nearly two million fake laetrile tablets to a legal distributor of the controversial drug, Union County authorities said today.

title: Knicks Defeated, 121112, Despite Cartwright Effort
description: DENVER, Oct. 30 (AP)  Centers Dan Issel of Denver and Bill Cartwright of New York connected with their seasonhighs of 32 points tonight, but Issel got more support from his teammates as the Nuggets scored their second straight National Basketball Association victory by defeating the Knicks, 121112.

title: Private Lives
description: ACCORDING to the noblest minds of the age, all of whom seem to have gone through therapy, we are not supposed to keep score. Keeping score is a form of hostility. There is something analretentive about it. It is especially dangerous in a marriage, which should be a dialectic instead of a bill of lading.

title: East Timor Getting Urgent Aid to Combat Famine
description: DILI, Indonesia, Oct. 30 (Reuters)  A vast emergency operation to feed many thousands of people is under way in Loro Sae, the former Portuguese colony of East Timor.

title: Conrail Reports Loss of $40 Million
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation, the Governmentsponsored freight railroad created from bankrupt Eastern carriers, reported yesterday a loss of $40 million in the third quarter, $8.5 million less than the loss recorded in last year's third auarter.

title: Today's Program
description: MORNING EVENTS  9:30  Open Green Conformation Hunter, 10:15  Conformation Hunter, 10:4551,500 Working Hunter Stake. The

title: Arguments Set for Today on Lease Of Offshore Site for Energy Sources
description: BOSTON, Oct. 30  Arguments are to begin here tomorrow in Federal District Court on a lawsuit to stop again the sale of oil and gas exploration leases on the fertile Georges Bank fishing grounds off Cape Cod. The sale is currently scheduled for next Tuesday.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Fish Getting Smart, Anglers Are Advised
description: What a fish hits savagely today he may ignore tomorrow, a trait that delights lure designers.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Mayor Byrne, Endorsing Kennedy, Favors a Slate Committed to Him
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 30  Mayor Jane M. Byrne made her promised formal endorsement today of Senator Edward M. Kennedy for the 1980 Democratic Presidential nomination, then sweetened the prize by saying that she felt the formidable Cook County machine should slate its proposed delegates to the party's national convention next year in his name.

title: Rachele Guidi Mussolini, Widow Of Italian Dictator, Is Dead at 89
description: Rachele Guidi Mussolini, the widow of Benito Mussolini, died yesterday at her home near Forli, Italy, where she had run a small restauranthotel for the last 15 years. She was 89 years old, having outlived Italy's Fascist dictator by a third of a century.

title: Best Buys
description: THE cost of feeding a family of four In New York City fell last week to the lowest level in nearly six months, the city's Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday.

title: PHILADELPHIA POLICE UPHELD ON U.S. SUIT
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30  A Federal district judge today dismissed the major portion of a Federal lawsuit charging Mayor Frank L. Rizzo and other city officials with condoning systematic and criminal violence by the Philadelphia Police Department.

title: U.S. BACKS IMPORTS OF MEXICO PRODUCE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  In a ruling with significance for overall relations between the United States and Mexico, as well as for food prices this winter, the Treasury decided today that Mexico was not selling tomatoes and other produce in this country at unfairly low prices.
